academia.stackexchange.com_1	<question QuestionId="What kind of Visa is required to work in Academia in Japan" Title="What kind of Visa is required to work in Academia in Japan" Views="144" Tags="hiring,visa,japan" " AnswerId="TOwe6i65TvtbRw7gsSljcw==" Author="5" Date="2012-02-14T20:23:40.127" Score="12" Text="&lt;p&gt;As from title. What kind of visa class do I have to apply for, in order to work as an academic in Japan ? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What kind of Visa is required to work in Academia in Japan" AnswerId="TOwe6i65TvtbRw7gsSljcw==" Author="320" Date="2012-03-02T11:11:22.063" Text="Generally the institution who hires you will prepare the required documents and process the application. If you come to Japan to hunt a job then you must apply for a temporary (tourist) visa that only allows you to stay in 90 days. But you might be waived for a tourist visa as you are a citizen who does not need a visa to enter Japan./>

<answer QuestionId="What kind of Visa is required to work in Academia in Japan" AnswerId="mlRhkQJqBdcW/VxTGVy0dw==" Author="user107" Date="2012-02-16T20:10:34.163" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mofa.go.jp/j_info/visit/visa/process/long.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;This&lt;/a&gt; might help or &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mofa.go.jp/j_info/visit/visa/long/visa1.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;this.&lt;/a&gt; Here is the crux of the information:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The period of stay is quoted as 3 years/1 year with the following documents needed:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;Passport&#xA;One visa application form (nationals of Russia or NIS countries need to submit two visa application forms)&#xA;One photograph (nationals of Russia or NIS countries need to submit two photographs)&#xA;Certificate of Eligibility (Note) - the original and one copy&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This visa applied for &lt;strong&gt;Long-term stay&lt;/strong&gt; for the following occupations:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Working visa: professor, artist, religious activities, journalist, investor/business manager, legal/accounting services, medical services, researcher, instructor, engineer, specialist in humanities/International Services&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The algorithm for obtaining the visa is given on &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mofa.go.jp/j_info/visit/visa/process/long.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;the first link I added&lt;/a&gt;.&#xA;&lt;img src=&quot;http://i.stack.imgur.com/31niR.gif&quot; alt=&quot;Algorithm&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10001	<question QuestionId="How can I ensure that my software is correctly cited" Title="How can I ensure that my software is correctly cited" Views="234" Tags="publishing,copyright" " AnswerId="KOw5pDwXoslo1gfLdI4GCw==" Author="7096" Date="2013-05-15T14:55:34.047" Score="12" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have the following situation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have published a paper and in order to get and analyse the results for my research I created some software. I want to make my software open-source, so that anyone can do research with it and change/improve it for their purposes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But I would like people to cite my paper if they are going to publish anything using my software. So if someone is just using it for fun, I do not care, but if someone modified it and used his modified version to collect/analyse the results, which he publishes in any paper, I want him to cite the paper I have wrote.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is there an appropriate software license or other means for this purpose?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How can I ensure that my software is correctly cited" AnswerId="KOw5pDwXoslo1gfLdI4GCw==" Author="7096" Date="2013-05-16T10:23:02.023" Text="thanks for ideas for editing. And also feel free to edit my question in any way you want./>
<comment QuestionId="How can I ensure that my software is correctly cited" AnswerId="KOw5pDwXoslo1gfLdI4GCw==" Author="7096" Date="2013-05-16T13:54:04.380" Text="In my opinion that there is nothing wrong with this. If you do not want to cite the paper, feel free to write your own software to do everything. That is the same way with any software. If you do not want to comply with agreement, do not use it/>
<comment QuestionId="How can I ensure that my software is correctly cited" AnswerId="KOw5pDwXoslo1gfLdI4GCw==" Author="958" Date="2013-05-16T13:37:49.897" Text="is it ethical to add clauses to a license (which is a commercial contract) such as &quot;if you do X, then you must cite me?&quot; I can see the motivation of the author, but this can go downhill very fast./>

<answer QuestionId="How can I ensure that my software is correctly cited" AnswerId="ch38CDZaLgqghPCBYkudzA==" Author="643" Date="2013-05-16T11:05:54.530" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;You cannot guarantee that people will cite the paper. All you can do is make it easier for them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A rather obvious idea: why not write on the software's web page something like&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;If you use or adapt this software in your research could you please cite it as follows: &lt;strong&gt;[details of citation, such as bibtex]&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Include this message also in the README file, the user manual and so forth.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How can I ensure that my software is correctly cited" AnswerId="qVGVK9znd1k7bPMLlk30kg==" Author="96" Date="2013-05-15T15:28:07.020" Score="12" Text="&lt;p&gt;You could try adapting one of the existing open source licences, with help from your university's Legal IP team.  &lt;strong&gt;But&lt;/strong&gt; a software licence is the wrong tool for the job.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One way to do it, is to write a &lt;strong&gt;methodology&lt;/strong&gt; paper. That's the paper that then gets cited by anyone using your code, or an adapted version of your code, to produce material for subsequent papers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As the paper you published was just about the results you got from the software, I've got some bad news and some good news for you.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The bad news is that you've got to write another paper.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The good news is that this new paper will use work that you've already done. It will be a methodology paper where you describe the software in detail, providing the source as supplementary information. And that's what will get cited, by those who use your software.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can also include something such as a bibtex file in with the distribution of your software, to make citation easier: &lt;strong&gt;the more you can do to reduce hurdles to citation, the more chance you've got of getting those citations&lt;/strong&gt;. Once you've got the above paper written, the bibtex file should describe that paper. And before then, you can do &lt;a href=&quot;http://cran.r-project.org/doc/FAQ/R-FAQ.html#Citing-R&quot;&gt;what the R-project does&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;To cite R in publications, use&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt; @Manual{,&#xA;   title        = {R: A Language and Environment for Statistical&#xA;                   Computing},&#xA;   author       = {{R Core Team}},&#xA;   organization = {R Foundation for Statistical Computing},&#xA;   address      = {Vienna, Austria},&#xA;   year         = 2013,&#xA;   url          = {http://www.R-project.org}&#xA; }&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Citation strings (or BibTeX entries) for R and R packages can also be obtained by citation(). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How can I ensure that my software is correctly cited" AnswerId="qVGVK9znd1k7bPMLlk30kg==" Author="7134" Date="2013-05-23T14:27:53.337" Text="Then your scenario is a perfect candidate for the second paper EnergyNumbers recommends./>
<comment QuestionId="How can I ensure that my software is correctly cited" AnswerId="qVGVK9znd1k7bPMLlk30kg==" Author="7096" Date="2013-05-15T19:36:41.240" Text="Thanks for explaining. In the paper I am not speaking about the software in details. I am stating the results that I got and mentioning briefly the software./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10003	<question QuestionId="Is it a bad idea to send an article under review as a writing sample (faculty job application)" Title="Is it a bad idea to send an article under review as a writing sample (faculty job application)" Views="569" Tags="application" " AnswerId="zNY28IeauhJTDspGLdiV7A==" Author="386" Date="2013-05-15T16:14:03.547" Score="10" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have a manuscript that is under review in a major journal which is a main result out of a few recent years of my research. When applying for faculty positions, I would like to send the draft as a part of my writing sample. But since the material is not yet published, I am not sure if it is a good idea.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What are the foreseeable disadvantages of sending an article in review to the faculty search committee?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My area is neuroscience / biomedical engineering. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10003" Date="2013-05-15T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10003" Date="2013-05-23T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10003" Date="2013-05-15T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Is it a bad idea to send an article under review as a writing sample (faculty job application)" AnswerId="FWK6sLvHJvpjzJKHy6qYAw==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-15T16:25:21.417" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;First, From a legal point of view I do not think you will have any problems sending out a pre-review version of your manuscript since your have the intellectual rights to your own work. Usually most publishers' copyrights start when they have processed the material in some way but even then, if you are not using the material for any commercial purpose or for being reproduced publically, I cannot see any problem. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Then, I cannot really see any problems sending a pre-reveiw manuscript to a search committee unless it is of poor quality. Sending your work allows people to see what you are doing and a manuscript (in very good shape) will allow people to see your latest work in detail. Naturally a manuscript will not carry as much merit as a published paper since it has not been through peer review. But, if it is interesting, well written and in impeccable order you will be showing your skills in some way. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So it could provide a slight positive in a search situation if good but be very negative if bad and your judgement is what will be at stake.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10004" Date="2013-05-15T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Is it a bad idea to send an article under review as a writing sample (faculty job application)" AnswerId="Rl3asQpQHsdQs2MMZo2jlw==" Author="1010" Date="2013-05-23T21:27:34.547" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;To add to the existing answers, I'd note that in some fields, the review process can be very long.  If you stick only to papers that have been published, you'll be giving the committee a picture of your research that may be years out of date.  Committees will understand this; sometimes they &lt;em&gt;explicitly&lt;/em&gt; ask for preprints.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you're confident in the quality of the article, and have a reasonable expectation of eventually getting it published, send it along.  Conversely, if you don't feel the article represents your best work, don't send it, even if it has been published already!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10196" Date="2013-05-23T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10196" Date="2013-05-24T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Is it a bad idea to send an article under review as a writing sample (faculty job application)" AnswerId="yeqerBDokWwkUdKJvGKMeQ==" Author="1429" Date="2013-05-15T17:34:10.530" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Although your question is specifically for faculty job applications, I would like to generalize and add to Peter's answer. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For doctoral program admissions, I often sent out an article under review whenever asked for a writing sample. Not all programs ask for this ; for some its optional and for some its not but I sent them anyway. Usually, when I was interviewed for the position after having made it through some of the initial cut-offs, my writing sample was alluded to and often, questions were centered around it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Therefore, I would like to say that sending it in anyway will not detract from your application but might even add to it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10006" Date="2013-05-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10006" Date="2013-05-15T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10008	<question QuestionId="How complete are academic databases" Title="How complete are academic databases" Views="210" Tags="journals,bibliometrics,data,repository" " AnswerId="FakDqv+aCldyx0ibr340YQ==" Author="7099" Date="2013-05-15T20:23:23.533" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;Right now I'm using Web of Knowledge, ScienceDirect, etc. to find papers to read and get some metadata. My university has a subscription, so this is nice. As far as I know these databases simply have a selection of journals, download all of the articles from those journals, and display them for me, updating every time the journal publishes. My question is: what percentage of journals are actually represented here? Some people say there are between 10,000,000 and 100,000,000 published academic documents in the sciences. Web of Science has about 50,000,000, and it's not clear how many ScienceDirect has.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A good comparison would be: if you take everything that Elsevier, Wiley, Springer, and Nature have, combined, and subtract everything that Web of Knowledge has, how many things are left?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another way to phrase it: Of the major publishers (like the ones I listed above), how many are represented in these databases?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How complete are academic databases" AnswerId="FakDqv+aCldyx0ibr340YQ==" Author="532" Date="2013-12-02T06:29:51.600" Text="google seems a good database. if the first page does not satisfy you then google scholar is better/>

I would say that they are quite complete in general. It is well known that Bradford's Law and Lotka's Law applies quite cleanly for most of these academic databases. Could you rephrase your question perhaps?/>

<answer QuestionId="How complete are academic databases" AnswerId="o5AcWL+yenZ3bZ8wqpEIKQ==" Author="8067" Date="2013-12-02T09:58:11.853" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Previous research has shown strong evidence that there is a &lt;strong&gt;language bias&lt;/strong&gt; in academic databases in the social sciences and humanities[1]. However, evidence for the sciences is mixed: Some cannot find an US bias using the Science Citation Index (SCI)[2], others actually identify also a strong language bias in the SCI[3].  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Furthermore, you have to consider differences in &lt;strong&gt;publication cultures&lt;/strong&gt; between disciplines: The humanities and social sciences still approve &lt;em&gt;monographs&lt;/em&gt; and &lt;em&gt;edited books&lt;/em&gt; as publications which are seldom listed in theses databases.[4]&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;sub&gt; &lt;strong&gt;References:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&#xA;[1] Bookstein, A./Yitzhaki,  M. (1999): Own-language preference: A new measure of “relative language self-citation”, in: Scientometrics, 46 (2), 337-348.&lt;br&gt;&#xA;Hicks, D. (1999): The difficulty of achieving full coverage of international social science literature and the bibliometric consequences, in: Scientometrics (1999), 44 (2), 193-215.&lt;br&gt;&#xA;Hicks, D./Wang, J. (2011): Coverage and overlap of the new social sciences and humanities journal lists, in: Journal of the American Society for Information Science and Technology, 62 (2), 284–294&lt;br&gt;&#xA;Yitzhaki,  M. (1998): The ‘language preference’ in sociology: Measures of ‘language self-citation’, ‘relative own-language preference indicator’, and ‘mutual use of languages’, in: Scientometrics, 41 (1-2), 243-254.&lt;br&gt;&#xA;[2] Van Leeuwen, T. N. et al. (2001): Language biases in the coverage of the Science Citation Index and its consequencesfor international comparisons of national research performance, in: Scientometrics, 51 (1), 335-346.&lt;br&gt;&#xA;[3] Luwel, M. (1999): Is the science citation index US-biased? in: Scientometrics, 46 (3), 549-562.&lt;br&gt;&#xA;King, D. A. (2004): The scientific impact of nations, in: Nature, 430, 311-316.&lt;br&gt;&#xA;[4] Nederhof, A. J. (2006): Bibliometric monitoring of research performance in the Social Sciences and the Humanities: A Review, in: Scientometrics, 66 (1), 81-100.&lt;br&gt;&#xA; &lt;/sub&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="14477" Date="2013-12-23T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="14477" Date="2013-12-02T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="How complete are academic databases" AnswerId="baN72tQ3BcodCVdbXg9rew==" Author="929" Date="2013-05-17T13:38:57.370" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;Not very. For example, Elsevier is a large publisher, but only still publishes a fraction of the total number of journals and articles in the world. By my count, they publish at least &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.elsevier.com/journals/title/a&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;2,797&lt;/a&gt; journals. They also market &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.elsevier.com/electronic-products/scopus&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Scopus&lt;/a&gt; as&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;the world's largest abstract and citation database of peer-reviewed&#xA;  literature and quality web sources&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;By my count again, and you may need a subscription to access this information, there are &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=BrowseListURL&amp;amp;_type=title&amp;amp;_title=A&amp;amp;md5=fcab2d7552e90ca57f4fa29a391c7e48&amp;amp;applyBrowseFilters=Apply&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;3230&lt;/a&gt; journals indexed by Scopus. So unless Elsevier publishes 87% of all the journals in the world, Scopus is missing some. In fact we know they are since &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nlm.nih.gov/bsd/num_titles.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Pubmed&lt;/a&gt; indexes 5,064 journals.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That said, most &quot;reputable&quot; publishers spend the money and/or produce quality products that they get included in the major indices.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10038" Date="2013-05-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10038" Date="2013-12-02T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How complete are academic databases" AnswerId="Gs9t2rXLs0TcpY8jVgQrjw==" Author="5962" Date="2013-05-17T17:17:50.673" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;The precise extent of scholarly publishing is unknown, difficult to estimate, and the subject of some debate. That said, there is lots of evidence that &lt;a href=&quot;http://wokinfo.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Web of Knowledge&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sciencedirect.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;ScienceDirect&lt;/a&gt; are likely only the tip of the iceberg.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That is sort of the takeaway from an article I found in from &lt;a href=&quot;http://lj.libraryjournal.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Library Journal&lt;/a&gt; on &lt;a href=&quot;http://lj.libraryjournal.com/2004/02/technology/online-databases-online-scholarly-journals-how-many/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Online Databases-Online Scholarly Journals: How Many?&lt;/a&gt; (Google WebCache because the LJ copy seems gone) by Carol Tenopir and published in February 2004.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Apparently, one of the best sources online is &lt;a href=&quot;https://ulrichsweb.serialssolutions.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Ulrichsweb&lt;/a&gt; which is a serials tracking website that is part of &lt;a href=&quot;http://proquest.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;ProQuest&lt;/a&gt;. I just did a search for &quot;Academic / Scholarly&quot; and &quot;Journal&quot; and came up with more than 107,000 different results.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How complete are academic databases" AnswerId="QTuw4RDZpU/gjSjt4P/dCA==" Author="8343" Date="2013-12-02T06:13:45.160" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;An answer for you depends on &lt;em&gt;your&lt;/em&gt; purposes and standards.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you're hoping to rule out the possibility that any published prior art is relevant to a patent claim, no database will be anywhere near the degree of completeness that you would prefer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the other hand, every database is complete for some purpose. For example, my understanding is that Web of Knowledge has at least a mere mention (a journal title, volume number, and page number) for every item that has been cited in the core literature since the end of the nineteenth century.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That presumes a definition of core literature that is decided by Thomson Reuters editors in the form of the product's &quot;master journal list&quot; on the basis of Bradford's law. Those seeking an introduction to Bradford's law could start with Sturgeon's law, which apologized for the low quality of much science fiction by observing that &quot;90% of everything is crap.&quot; Bradford's law is the more specific, better studied converse in regard to scientific journals, that if we can examine a small but highly valuable fraction of them all, then for many purposes we can ignore the rest.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="14476" Date="2013-12-24T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>

It appears to be most strong within &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/7980/why-do-many-recent-open-access-mega-journals-only-cover-biological-sciences&quot;&gt;biological sciences, though that may be more of a side-effect of their style of publishing&lt;/a&gt;. An interesting &lt;a href=&quot;http://legacy.earlham.edu/~peters/fos/timeline.htm&quot;&gt;&quot;timeline of open access&quot;&lt;/a&gt; unfortunately stops at 2008. Obviously the graphic, while interesting, is a single data point.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What is the evidence regarding the effect of going open-access and a journal's impact factor? I am especially interested in utilizing resources that have undergone some kind of peer review and scrutiny.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10010	<question QuestionId="What computations of the Lotka function exist for publications in humanities meta-disciplines" Title="What computations of the Lotka function exist for publications in humanities meta-disciplines" Views="82" Tags="bibliometrics" " AnswerId="tCPjb+qUaHCyliVPdb1GYg==" Author="4429" Date="2013-05-15T23:21:16.713" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;Given Lotka's law's general applicability to publishing rates and bibliometrics; what computations of the Lotka function exist for the meta-disciplines in the humanities?  (Philosophy, History, Literary Criticism by language, Film criticism, Anthropology, History and Philosophy of Science / Science and Technology Studies)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I wish to test cultural assumptions (&quot;work culture&quot;) about publication rates of sole authored papers against Lotka values to check managerial assumptions, and my own assumptions, about productivity levels and &quot;workload&quot;.  Yet I have no adequate grounding to find computed Lotka functions for discipline.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10010" Date="2013-06-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10010" Date="2014-04-12T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="What computations of the Lotka function exist for publications in humanities meta-disciplines" AnswerId="GRVh56dtIkPnqEhuk5YPrA==" Author="1429" Date="2013-05-16T00:00:49.260" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;There have been a few papers published in this space by bibliometricians/scientometricians already. Having said this, why would you need pre-configured values of lotka's law for certain sub-disciplines in the humanities? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would collect data (perhaps using Web of Science/Google Scholar/Wiley/Elsevier etc.) ; then do empirical testing with the generalized Lotka's law on particular sub-disciplines and then control against your cultural assumptions and other variables. This is because every discipline changes over time and a paper published on this in the 1970's may yield different results now with the same methodology. Most of my references cited below point this (or some variation of this) out as limitations of temporally specific computations of these laws.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Having said this, there are a few papers which might help you in this task if you haven't found them already:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/asi.4630240607/abstract&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;This&lt;/a&gt; paper specifically looks at generalizing Lotka's Law in the humanities and formulates the same queries that I laid out earlier about it being spatio-temporal specific.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/asi.4630370105/abstract&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;This&lt;/a&gt; paper is the Pao's modification to Lotka's law for humanities and has some empirical evaluations from certain humanities literature. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0306457386900762&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;This&lt;/a&gt; paper is an empirical modification of Pao's variation (see above) to Lotka's Law in certain humanities disciplines.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/asi.4630280115/abstract&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;This&lt;/a&gt; is an editorial response to Lotka's law applicability in the humanities.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.175.4378&amp;amp;rep=rep1&amp;amp;type=pdf&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;This&lt;/a&gt; is a general paper which looks at quantifying author productivity and impact specifically in the humanities. It is a very good read for approaches.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In other words, do some up-to-date empirical evaluation and then perhaps, run your study. The first could actually make for a fine empirical paper by itself in the scientometrics world. Pre-configured function values are like using empirical regression estimates ; they are fine and &lt;em&gt;specific&lt;/em&gt; to &lt;em&gt;that&lt;/em&gt; study but may not be generalizable across all studies.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10012" Date="2013-05-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10012" Date="2013-05-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10012" Date="2013-05-16T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>

academia.stackexchange.com_10013	<question QuestionId="What if I can make a profit for an assignmentproject I did similar to &quotGoogle&quot" Title="What if I can make a profit for an assignmentproject I did similar to &quotGoogle&quot" Views="141" Tags="university,research-undergraduate" " AnswerId="m7xua1Hq8/FctJ63Wod66Q==" Author="7100" Date="2013-05-16T04:31:01.880" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;This is kind of like the google story. We are currently doing an project individually. The idea I came up with can be used as a website that can make profit. My question is, let's say I was able to make money with the code I am writing, since this is a university project that I will submit for marks, do they own a piece of that profit. I know that the Google guys had to pay about $300 million to Standford but it seemed to me like the &quot;patent issue&quot;. And they dropped out so I really can't say much about their case. The facebook story is different.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So am I obligated to share the profit with the university or does this differ from institution to institution? After all, even if they take my code, since I wrote it, I can rewrite it with ease.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Edit:&lt;/strong&gt; It's kind of like inventing something that can be sold or used as a service. Does the institution own a piece of it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="What if I can make a profit for an assignmentproject I did similar to &quotGoogle&quot" AnswerId="IoWxnt6odjiBs9LpbHqo3g==" Author="166" Date="2013-05-16T06:49:33.060" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;This cannot be answered in general.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It depends on the contract you have with the institution and the applicable law in your jurisdiction. It may depend on how you were funded as well.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I know of examples from both extremes: your university owns 100% and your university owns nothing, as well as everything in between. Some intermediate setting is probably more common, but, as I said, it depends.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10014	<question QuestionId="Academic Genealogy" Title="Academic Genealogy" Views="528" Tags="publications" " AnswerId="Cm04xok4RUPOVZ7Dv0f8xQ==" Author="546" Date="2013-05-16T05:02:29.247" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.genealogy.ams.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Mathematics Genealogy project&lt;/a&gt; has existed for many years. It currently  has 170,235 records as of 15 May, 2013. I understand there are many computer scientists in that database since computer science is generally considered a branch of mathematics.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have found several other similar efforts. For example, the &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academic_genealogy_of_theoretical_physicists&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Academic genealogy of theoretical physicists&lt;/a&gt; Wiki page consists of about 100 theoretical physicists. I cannot find Physics Genealogy project in general. A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.scs.illinois.edu/~mainzv/Web_Genealogy/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Chemical Genealogy Database&lt;/a&gt; does not appear to have built a very large database.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My questions are:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Are there genealogy project for other disciplines?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Is there a general academic genealogy project somewhere? If yes, where? If not, are there efforts to construct it?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Academic Genealogy" AnswerId="Cm04xok4RUPOVZ7Dv0f8xQ==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-16T05:21:09.587" Text="So you want to find the 'parent' which would tie together all of the other genealogy projects?/>

It touches many disciplines related to math in contemporary academia and, as you go back in time, includes a wide portion of academic work. 1000 years ago my academic ancestors were a bunch of bishops. The difference between mathematics, philosophy, and theology was not always very clear or very large./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10018	<question QuestionId="Master Thesis - use of cover illustration" Title="Master Thesis - use of cover illustration" Views="267" Tags="masters,thesis" " AnswerId="j/HsBvkP5j3CKXe78zCn0g==" Author="6332" Date="2013-05-16T11:14:46.897" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'm currently writing my master thesis and would like an opinion on whether or not to use a cover illustration on the thesis.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I've noticed many students around me do not take the time to make the cover page attractive (e.g. a simple title is all). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What is the &quot;standard&quot; convention regarding the cover page of a master thesis?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note that I have no restrictions from my university.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10018" Date="2013-05-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10018" Date="2013-05-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10018" Date="2013-05-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10018" Date="2013-05-23T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Master Thesis - use of cover illustration" AnswerId="VyQxy1ble8iK5cZIiGeK/Q==" Author="6936" Date="2013-05-17T10:57:01.303" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'd like to provide a counter to the &quot;content is what matters&quot; advice. Of course the content is what it's all about, but I think that a great many people in academia underestimate the importance of presentation. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Look at the way people decide whether or not to read a paper. They look at the title. If that suggests that it's interesting to them, they read the abstract. If that's interesting enough they read the introduction and maybe the conclusion, and so on. That means that of the 4000 or so words in the paper, the five that make up the title are the most important. You're fully justified in spending as much time on the title as on 1000 words of the description of your method. The presentation of your paper is not just gloss, it determines the size of your audience. If your presentation is bad, your results have to be really exceptional to find even a small readership.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This translates directly to your Master's thesis. A nice cover shows that you care. What's more, the largest group of people that will come into contact with it, will only pick it up, look at it and put it back down again, without even really reading the title. Your cover illustration is the only opportunity you have of communicating with them and enticing them to read the title properly. From that, the summary, and from that the first paragraph of your introduction and so on.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Don't mistake presentation for gloss. Academia is all about communication, and communication is worrying about the details.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Master Thesis - use of cover illustration" AnswerId="VyQxy1ble8iK5cZIiGeK/Q==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-18T11:20:25.707" Text="I agree that it is important to care about your products but I doubt many of us pick out a thesis because it looks nice. In many cases they are not publically available and if they are you most likely search for key words on the internet to find it. Thus, I think the cover is for the bookshelf and to have something to be proud of yourself and to show family and friends. If a thesis is publsihed commercially as a book things look different of course./>
<comment QuestionId="Master Thesis - use of cover illustration" AnswerId="VyQxy1ble8iK5cZIiGeK/Q==" Author="6936" Date="2013-05-18T21:16:46.073" Text="That's true, if it's found on the internet, the title is what matters most for pulling people in, and the cover is less important. Unless of course, someone is reading your thesis to get an idea of your potential (say if you're applying for a PhD position). Then a cover can help a little to show commitment./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10035" Date="2013-07-08T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10035" Date="2013-05-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10035" Date="2013-08-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10035" Date="2013-05-23T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Master Thesis - use of cover illustration" AnswerId="T/7EfWYgH2GDBqOqtE3UJA==" Author="4461" Date="2013-05-16T11:28:28.470" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;It's your thesis, and if your committee approves it with beautiful cover art, then you're all set.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For professional theses, the standard is a plain cover with pertinent details about the thesis.  Departments or universities generally have a template document or provide specific guidance, but if that isn't true for your school, then I wouldn't worry about it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Bottom line: I would discuss it with your advisor, and other committee members.  If you want it to be a surprise to them (not advisable), then by all means give it a shot.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Master Thesis - use of cover illustration" AnswerId="T/7EfWYgH2GDBqOqtE3UJA==" Author="6332" Date="2013-05-16T15:03:50.490" Text="Yeah, there are no real rules but seeing what @aeismail pointed out I don't think I'm going to bother putting in the effort./>

<answer QuestionId="Master Thesis - use of cover illustration" AnswerId="vcQTaeKlo9TS4hel4iwQxQ==" Author="5962" Date="2013-05-17T17:37:25.367" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;For many students, there are strict guidelines that describe how a thesis can be formatted. If you're not restricted by guidelines, and if you have the time and inclination to have your thesis be a beautiful object, there's no reason not to.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Although the content matters much more than any amount of fancy layout, great presentation can make a difference. As in food, the first bite is always with the eye.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10043" Date="2013-05-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10043" Date="2013-05-23T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Master Thesis - use of cover illustration" AnswerId="M70fQC6gmM1k3S3VwaUAqg==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-16T14:08:49.900" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;The primary reason for not having a &quot;pretty cover&quot; is simple: practicality.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Keep in mind that many schools will have &quot;official&quot; copies of the thesis bound; for archival purposes, and to keep production costs down, the covers don't typically have illustrations, but are usually monochromatic standard bindings. The cover art would therefore not be obvious to anybody looking at the thesis—and the low traffic for theses means it's usually not worth the effort to produce it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, as Chris points out, if your school &lt;em&gt;doesn't&lt;/em&gt; have a policy, you can do what you'd like. On the other hand, I'd focus on the quality of the material presented in the thesis before worrying about the cover art!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Master Thesis - use of cover illustration" AnswerId="M70fQC6gmM1k3S3VwaUAqg==" Author="6332" Date="2013-05-16T15:02:55.923" Text="Obviously the content comes first :-) This is more something I would do after the content is completed, however, you point out some compelling reasons not to bother!/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10021	<question QuestionId="Is it legal to run interviews for an academic job when the post has already being assigned" Title="Is it legal to run interviews for an academic job when the post has already being assigned" Views="270" Tags="job,interview,best-practice" " AnswerId="Fxmimi24eeUvORgfZx21wQ==" Author="1520" Date="2013-05-16T14:38:10.680" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;The normal UK process to hire new academic staff would be:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;A call is placed on job adverts, websites, specialised magazines&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The curricula and forms from prospective candidates are collected&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;A filter is applied and a short-list produced&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;5-7 candidates sit in a workbench for an interview&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;the job is assigned to the most apt candidate&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I happen to know of a case where the position is already assigned, but the job avert has been published, so it should be open to all. So steps 2), 3) and 4) are just a waste of paperwork.&#xA;Is this legal?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is it legal to run interviews for an academic job when the post has already being assigned" AnswerId="Fxmimi24eeUvORgfZx21wQ==" Author="1520" Date="2013-05-16T17:30:05.603" Text="the job specification, type and spectrum of requested skills are pointing towards *one SPECIFIC* person, who will be appointed. Friendships and past comraderie also play a part./>
<comment QuestionId="Is it legal to run interviews for an academic job when the post has already being assigned" AnswerId="Fxmimi24eeUvORgfZx21wQ==" Author="5962" Date="2013-05-17T17:26:14.567" Text="This is by no means just a UK thing. Similar processes exist in the US and, I suspect, in *many* other places./>
<comment QuestionId="Is it legal to run interviews for an academic job when the post has already being assigned" AnswerId="Fxmimi24eeUvORgfZx21wQ==" Author="5962" Date="2013-05-18T21:25:03.773" Text="I was suggesting that the process/routine/legal requirements you describe are common in the US. Of course, the practice of ignoring it probably is common as well. That said, I think @Silvado answered this well. The difference between legal and illegal proving people's intent. That's going to be extremely difficult always and frequently impossible./>
<comment QuestionId="Is it legal to run interviews for an academic job when the post has already being assigned" AnswerId="Fxmimi24eeUvORgfZx21wQ==" Author="4511" Date="2013-05-17T10:22:14.827" Text="A better question would be &quot;how do people (public and other job-seekers) can find out whether the employer has not assigned already the position to some specific person before job announcement?&quot; Are there any clues?/>

Seems pretty uncommon for them to interview many people if they already have a top choice and the ad's gone out though./>

<comment QuestionId="Is it legal to run interviews for an academic job when the post has already being assigned" AnswerId="Fxmimi24eeUvORgfZx21wQ==" Author="612" Date="2013-05-16T15:41:33.083" Text="How conclusively do you mean &quot;already assigned&quot;?  There could be a big difference between several cases: an intent to hire a specific person no matter how the applications/interviews go, an intent to hire someone with a willingness to hire someone else instead if a better candidate appears, an offer already made to a candidate with interviews to select a backup in case the offer is turned down, an offer already made and accepted with a possibility of a second offer for an extraordinary candidate, or an offer already made and accepted with no possibility of further offers./>

<answer QuestionId="Is it legal to run interviews for an academic job when the post has already being assigned" AnswerId="5KTy8CUEuw9v+3EzB3wy7g==" Author="3890" Date="2013-05-17T10:26:45.830" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;In many cases, academic institutions will be &lt;strong&gt;legally obliged&lt;/strong&gt; to fill positions according to the procedure you described. This usually requires publishing a call for applications in a suitable medium, and putting together a short list of selected candidates based on qualification for the position and fit to the announcement.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now there may be the &quot;problem&quot; that the person or group that will select the candidate already has a specific candidate in mind and want to &quot;assign&quot; the position to that candidate. However, simply hiring that candidate without going through the formal process would in fact be illegal. So the typical workaround in this case is to make the announcement so specific that the desired candidate will be the best qualified person for the position. It may be ethically questionable, but I fear &lt;strong&gt;it is totally legal&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Still, even for other candidates, this approach seems to be better than allowing the institution to just fill the position without the formal process. Especially if there is a committee deciding on the short list, this may even be different from the group that made up the announcement, and there may be people pushing for candidates they deem more qualified than the originally desired candidate. Chances for other candidates will clearly be rather low, but still higher than zero as in the case without announcement.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As to the question whether it is possible to find out about such a situation in advance, I fear it is not that easy. It works best when one has good contacts to people in the committee, and can ask informally about the situation. Otherwise, a reasonable approach would be to phone a contact given in the announcement and discuss details of the position. In many cases, one should be able to figure out whether the other person is open to applications or not.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is it legal to run interviews for an academic job when the post has already being assigned" AnswerId="5KTy8CUEuw9v+3EzB3wy7g==" Author="1520" Date="2013-05-17T13:54:39.487" Text="@FedericoPoloni: that's a good hint, and it what started the question altogether./>
<comment QuestionId="Is it legal to run interviews for an academic job when the post has already being assigned" AnswerId="5KTy8CUEuw9v+3EzB3wy7g==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-17T15:14:16.927" Text="I have seen a few cases where a _very specific_ position was announced with a _very specific_ candidate in mind, but after the legally mandated search process, someone else got the offer./>
<comment QuestionId="Is it legal to run interviews for an academic job when the post has already being assigned" AnswerId="5KTy8CUEuw9v+3EzB3wy7g==" Author="958" Date="2013-05-17T11:03:26.360" Text="Another clue is an overly specific description of the position and the required research area./>
<comment QuestionId="Is it legal to run interviews for an academic job when the post has already being assigned" AnswerId="5KTy8CUEuw9v+3EzB3wy7g==" Author="6787" Date="2013-05-18T01:06:29.200" Text="In the private sector/industry this is so common that a regular piece of job hunting advice is &quot;if it is published in the paper or on a big job site, the job is already filled.&quot; I once even had a recruiter outright tell me I was only called in because the company required at least X amount of interviews (least pleasant interview ever). However, as @JeffE noted, I've also personally observed a few cases of an *heir apparent* passed over in favor of an outside candidate. Its an unpleasant, though not uncommon, reality of the workplace./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10023	<question QuestionId="How to tackle the bibliographic work as an entering PhD student" Title="How to tackle the bibliographic work as an entering PhD student" Views="225" Tags="phd,bibliography,methodology" " AnswerId="svpPceDXu1NZ1EzadWI0Tw==" Author="7108" Date="2013-05-16T18:18:37.343" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'll be starting my PhD in the next fall. I already looked over the internet for advice for a beginner, even read two books on the subjects. Still, there is one point I haven't seen discussed as I wanted, it's the time and the way the student should be investing in catching up on his field and his specific topic, I'm speaking about the bibliographic part. For sure a student needs a lot of (continuous) input, but at the end he'll be solely judged on his output. From my previous research project, I'm not really confident in my way of balancing between going through articles/textbook material and trying to solve my own problematics. To be honest, it sometimes feels like a sneaky way of procrastinating: I'd tell myself that I'm still not ready to tackle my problem and that I need to make a little &quot;detour&quot; by existing works; and when it's done I don't feel more at ease to answer my questions. Or is it a normal aspect of research?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In my specific case, I'll be working on a quite new subject (string theory) when I only had advanced lecture of quantum field theory and general relativity; so I'm thinking about going through the canonical textbook on the subject during the summer, do most of the exercises and derivations in there (which already represents hundreds of hours invested), maybe revising some mathematical tools I need to be really familiar with. Once I'll have a general idea of the topic I'll jump to the main articles in relation to my thesis. I also know that I will be using numerical tools (Monte Carlo methods) and will need to get conformable with that. So far I only have a superficial knowledge and use of the tool.&#xA;Does it seem like a good use of my time? I already know that time and willpower are limited resources in grad school and I really don't want my desire to do well to burn me out from the beginning.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10023" Date="2013-05-23T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10023" Date="2013-05-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10023" Date="2013-05-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10023" Date="2013-05-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10023" Date="2013-05-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10023" Date="2013-05-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10023" Date="2013-09-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10023" Date="2013-05-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10023" Date="2013-05-17T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How to tackle the bibliographic work as an entering PhD student" AnswerId="jbVctB7a6yoH1D6tlqVE2g==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-16T20:14:12.813" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;That you are thinking about these matters is a very good start. You need to remember that exactly what you need to know and to read up on will only be known in a genral sense. your PhD project theme will provide this general direction. What details you need to pick up in terms of numerical methods etc. will to a lrger extent develop as your research develops. So you do not need to worry about what you could possibly have use for. You probably know key areas relavant to the topic.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, you need to lay a broad foundation and read up on the topic and supporting areas (fields). If there are key methods or equivalent you can start looking at that as well. However,I ould expect your advisor will also provide guidance in setting up direction through course work and suggesting reading. I would personally not expect a student to have a complete background by the time he or she starts. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, as I state earlier, that you are thinking about this is very good but you should not worry too much because you will not know the details until you have the PhD project clearly defined and started woring with your future advisor. So any knowledge you can gain will be a bonus but you are not expected to finish your PhD until you have completed your PhD studies.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10025" Date="2013-05-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10025" Date="2013-05-17T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How to tackle the bibliographic work as an entering PhD student" AnswerId="SeGQJteyi661byIIt096Ig==" Author="346" Date="2013-05-16T22:06:11.320" Score="7" Text="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;To be honest, it sometimes feels like a sneaky way of procrastinating:&#xA;  I'd tell myself that I'm still not ready to tackle my problem and that&#xA;  I need to make a little &quot;detour&quot; by existing works; and when it's done&#xA;  I don't feel more at ease to answer my questions. Or is it a normal&#xA;  aspect of research?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is probably the most common way that new grad students attempt (consciously or otherwise) to avoid doing research :)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You have to remember that prior knowledge is an ocean you're swimming in, not a cup that you have to finish drinking. There's literally no way to &quot;read all the prior literature&quot;: there's always something more. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;General reading is perfectly fine, but when you have a problem to work on, it's best to break down bibliographic research into:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;what does prior work say about your problem and what's the key open question (and this is something your advisor can help you with)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Once you start thinking about a specific problem and are trying to apply some specific tools, is there material to help you understand those tools better ? &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;When you're writing up, what &lt;strong&gt;related&lt;/strong&gt; (not &lt;strong&gt;prior&lt;/strong&gt;) work should you be aware of ? &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;At each stage, read only as much as you absolutely need to, in order to avoid going down rabbit holes. And remember, as a new Ph.D student, it's not a terrible thing if you reinvent something that someone discovered before, and only learn of this after the fact. You just don't that happening at your dissertation defense :)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to tackle the bibliographic work as an entering PhD student" AnswerId="SeGQJteyi661byIIt096Ig==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-17T01:01:11.223" Text="..but _do_ go down rabbit holes _occassionally_.  Some of them have tasty carrots at the bottom!  Not too often, though./>
<comment QuestionId="How to tackle the bibliographic work as an entering PhD student" AnswerId="SeGQJteyi661byIIt096Ig==" Author="7134" Date="2013-05-23T14:16:56.637" Text="I agree with JeffE. I chased a rabbit down its hole all summer last year, only to end up proving to myself why Physical Chemists use the standard water molecule for hydration shell calculations as opposed to Hydroxide or Hydronium or something more exotic. If nothing else, I now know I don't have to waste precious computer time duplicating my experiments with those variations on water./>

<answer QuestionId="E-books and e-publishing" AnswerId="jbWryPhkAEHmKGTJn9t9WA==" Author="4461" Date="2013-05-17T08:18:32.583" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;The good news is that once you've got a text in one eBook format, it is relatively painless to publish it in additional formats (PDF being the notable exception, though it is generally easy to get a document into PDF format--you can do a decent job with a converter such as Calibre--see below--but translating the format properly is sometimes tricky).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;At the very least, you should publish in PDF format.  While not a particularly good format for reading on portable devices, it is a universal format that &lt;em&gt;can&lt;/em&gt; be read on any any modern eReader, and, of course, on a PC screen.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would also suggest formatting the book in the open &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EPUB&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;EPUB&lt;/a&gt; format, and in a Kindle format (either &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kindle_Format_8#File_formats&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;.MOBI, AZW, or .KF8&lt;/a&gt;).  I would then link to all of the formats on your web page, possibly with instructions on how to get the volume onto a particular device.  You could also consider &lt;a href=&quot;https://kdp.amazon.com/self-publishing/signin/187-5862717-6823129&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;self-publishing the volume to the Kindle store&lt;/a&gt;, but bear in mind that there may be restrictions, and I believe you will be forced to charge for the volume.  The iTunes Store is another possibility, but comes with its own restrictions and formatting / conversion guidelines.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You should definiltely download the fine E-Book manager, &lt;a href=&quot;http://calibre-ebook.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Calibre&lt;/a&gt;, which can convert between formats and is free.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In the end, there isn't one true standard for eBook formats yet, but it is not difficult having a few different formats on your web page.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="E-books and e-publishing" AnswerId="jbWryPhkAEHmKGTJn9t9WA==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-17T13:04:08.707" Text="Calibre is great (but not perfect) for converting between ebook formats./>

<answer QuestionId="E-books and e-publishing" AnswerId="LCyNckHR3dRdDxxcTBvGKA==" Author="7198" Date="2013-05-23T05:06:17.903" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would suggest using iBook Author (free).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Drawbacks&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The drawback is that e-books created with this software are only&#xA;viewable as PDF or on an iPad.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;As someone who has used InDesign for&#xA;page layout projects, I find the layout capabilities are limited.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;As @Chris Gregg points out, this application is only available for &lt;strong&gt;Mac running Lion&lt;/strong&gt; or higher.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Advantage&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The advantage is that this format allows teachers to add chapter/unit review quizzes, embedding of 3D objects, image galleries,presentations, &amp;amp; even html.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Feel free to contact me if you need more information about this.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_1004	<question QuestionId="Can a researcher get his full salary from a European Project" Title="Can a researcher get his full salary from a European Project" Views="299" Tags="salary" " AnswerId="p1ur9x002QfB4dwn2fA2XA==" Author="102" Date="2012-04-04T07:39:31.643" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would be interested in creating with some colleagues a &lt;a href=&quot;http://cordis.europa.eu/fp7/ict/fet-open/ye_en.html&quot;&gt;FET Young Explorers&lt;/a&gt; project, in which I would be Work Package leader. &#xA;I've been involved in several european projects, but always as a postdoc recruited by a PI (or WP leader), and I don't have a permanent position yet. So basically, the idea of applying to this project would be to get my full salary paid by the EU project, but I don't know if it's possible. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Indeed, in the FAQ, they say that the applicants need to have a position somewhere. I don't think getting a position would be a problem, but only if I come with my own salary. The question in this case is whether the hosting institution still needs to pay some part of my salary? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;EDIT: A precision on the question. From the &lt;a href=&quot;ftp://ftp.cordis.europa.eu/pub/fp7/docs/calls/cooperation/ict/c-gfastrep-201103_en.pdf&quot;&gt;Guide for Applicants&lt;/a&gt;, Section A3/Budget, p. 47, the part about the requested European Commission contribution:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The requested EC contribution shall be determined by applying the upper funding limits indicated below, per activity and per participant to the costs accepted by the Commission, or to the flat rates or lump sums.&#xA;  Maximum reimbursement rates of eligible costs&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;ul&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;Research and technological development = 50% or 75%*&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;Demonstration activities = 50%&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;Other activities (including management) = 100%&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;(*) For participants that are non profit public bodies, secondary and higher education establishments, research organisations and SMEs.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, if the salary of a researcher is included in the Research and Technological development, then does that mean that it's possible to only ask for 75% of it to the EC? (assuming the researcher is employed by a university). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

Those rules are always confusing. We certainly pay for researchers on EU projects, but I don't fully know what goes on under the hood./>

<answer QuestionId="Can a researcher get his full salary from a European Project" AnswerId="nW/6IF6PTL5HOcIhNW3A8w==" Author="53" Date="2012-04-04T07:50:42.180" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I think this is a function of the EU country in question, and perhaps even the specific institution that you want to work for. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have a particular institution in mind, then you should contact them directly to ask about the specific procedures that apply there. Otherwise, you should take a look at the national-level funding agency or agencies that provide the funding that is comparable to the EU-level program. For instance, in Germany, that would mean looking at what the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.dfg.de&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;DFG&lt;/a&gt; permits as part of their internal practices. [In Germany, this usually shouldn't be a problem, but it might in other countries, depending on their appointment procedures.]&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But I think the other thing is that most likely a &lt;em&gt;temporary worker&lt;/em&gt; can get a full-time salary from an EU-level grant, but a &lt;em&gt;permanent&lt;/em&gt; employee cannot.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Can a researcher get his full salary from a European Project" AnswerId="nW/6IF6PTL5HOcIhNW3A8w==" Author="102" Date="2012-04-04T08:46:44.993" Text="Thanks for your answer, I also think that it only applies to temporary worker (which would be my case). I just edited my question to emphasise more on the exact problem I'm facing, and it doesn't seem to depend on the country or the hosting institution. I'm still quite a newbie in EU project, so I'm having a hard time deciphering the vocabulary :)/>

<answer QuestionId="Can a researcher get his full salary from a European Project" AnswerId="eh2LV/QCeawfPkY3+g1tMQ==" Author="102" Date="2012-05-25T08:31:43.370" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;So, after quite some time spent on reading the paperwork and talking with helpful staff, I finally understood how this system works. There are different amounts involved: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;S&lt;/strong&gt;: the salary of the researcher, corresponding to the gross amount, i.e. before tax. For instance, 50.000 euros per year. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;r&lt;/strong&gt;: the overhead asked by the host institution, which basically corresponds to the indirect costs of hosting the researcher (renting the office, paying the admin staff, etc). This is an agreement between the host institution and the european commission, usually calculated as a percentage of the salary. For instance, where I'm working now, it's 67%. In some places, it can go up to 100%. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;T&lt;/strong&gt;: the travel and equipments expenses. It basically depends on the expected number of conferences to attend per year, the meetings organised for the project, etc. For instance, based on 4 conferences per year, 2500 euros per conference, that makes 10.000 euros. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;C = S + rS + T&lt;/strong&gt;: the total cost of the researcher per year. For instance, that would be 50000 + 33500 + 10000 = 93500. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Req = 0.75 * C&lt;/strong&gt;: is the requested amount to the commission (assuming the host institution belongs to: profit public bodies, secondary and higher education establishments, research organisations and SMEs, 0.5 otherwise). So, for the example, we would request 70.125 euros per year. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note that the request amount is 10.000 euros above the gross salary of the researcher (deducting the travel costs). In other words, one could consider that the 25% the host institution has to pay are indirectly paid by giving an office and proving staff support (who, in general, would be paid anyway, EU project or not), and therefore it does not necessarily mean that the researcher has to find another funding source for the missing 25%. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Can a researcher get his full salary from a European Project" AnswerId="eh2LV/QCeawfPkY3+g1tMQ==" Author="102" Date="2012-05-25T09:05:28.727" Text="Disclaimer: I won't pretend this method works for any project/situation, but that seems the case at least for FET-Open projects. I know it's different for Marie Curie Actions, which work more as a grant than a salary, and for which the salary is fixed by the commission./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1692" Date="2012-05-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1692" Date="2012-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1692" Date="2012-05-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1692" Date="2012-06-13T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1692" Date="2012-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10040	<question QuestionId="How common are monitors (class leaders)" Title="How common are monitors (class leaders)" Views="181" Tags="teaching,group-dynamics,asia" " AnswerId="32csdMCR8xEXFGbDkdubbQ==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-17T14:03:52.437" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have found that in Asian universities, there is a concept I am unfamiliar with: The monitor. The monitor here is not someone who monitors but rather one student, usually elected by the other students, to speak for the group and to perform administrative tasks. This is a position of leadership and signifies that this student is special (and might get preferential treatment from the teacher).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;From my other university teaching experience (outside of Asia), I have never seen this. I'm wondering, is this common across Asia to have these 'monitors?' Is it common in other (non-Asian) parts of the world?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Does anyone have any insights on things to be concerned with (for someone new to the idea of monitors)?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note: It seems the monitor position starts in the earliest years (pre-K) and are not just at the university level but they also go up all the way to graduate-level classes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How common are monitors (class leaders)" AnswerId="32csdMCR8xEXFGbDkdubbQ==" Author="5944" Date="2013-05-17T15:20:36.920" Text="In Canada and in the United States, you often have the concept of a &quot;Student body&quot; or a &quot;student representative council&quot; of sorts. However, they are known to a small number of students and are often not considered that important by most of the student body. In some departments, you have representatives as well; they are usually students who attend faculty meetings and ensure student interests are represented. It's rare however that the representative actually speaks for the group in class though./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10040" Date="2013-05-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10040" Date="2013-05-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10040" Date="2013-05-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10040" Date="2013-05-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10040" Date="2013-05-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10040" Date="2013-05-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10040" Date="2013-05-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10040" Date="2013-05-17T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How common are monitors (class leaders)" AnswerId="LREIX+uyftYHGj0r46C92w==" Author="546" Date="2013-05-18T05:03:05.220" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I can provide details in Taiwan. I know the situations in many other countries in Asia are similar. Hopefully users from Asia on this board can confirm this.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In Taiwan, the role is called class leader in elementary school, middle school and high school. They are usually assigned by the teachers of the classes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In college, it is called the class representative. The representatives are elected by the students. The length of the term usually is a year.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Upon entering college, students already select their major. The university groups all the students having the same major into one or more classes depending on the number of students (the standard class size is 50). &lt;strong&gt;They take all the required courses together if possible.&lt;/strong&gt; The students in the same class know each other very well. The class is like a big family. Naturally, you have a representative who speaks for the class and handles all the administrative matters. You also have a deputy representative in case the rep is not available. There are other students responsible for other duties such as purchase, sports, etc.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The rep gets elected usually because he/she is popular in the class or a good student. I would not say he gets preferential treatment from the professor/department because he is the rep. Sometimes it is the opposite. I once declined a rep nomination because I wanted to concentrate on my study.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, being a rep can be advantageous. You learn how to be a leader. You learn how to communicate with other people who are sometimes superior, such as the professor, department chair or even the dean. Leadership is not something you can learn it all from the books. You have to do it. Two of the four reps in my college class are very successful in their late career.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It would be much easier for the professor to talk to the class rep when he wants the whole class to do some unusual assignments. Once you can convince the rep it's the right thing to do, the rep would then pass the message to the whole class. You are more likely to get the cooperation from the students. I would not recommend you to use him very often, though. He represents the class, not you. He would lose the trust from his classmates when he becomes your pet student. In general, &lt;strong&gt;the class representative concept is more like the department chair of a university department&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Hope this helps. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10044" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10044" Date="2013-06-24T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10044" Date="2013-05-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10044" Date="2013-05-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10044" Date="2013-05-19T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10045	<question QuestionId="How to decide whether a statement requires citing a reliable source" Title="How to decide whether a statement requires citing a reliable source" Views="268" Tags="citations" " AnswerId="hXi+4EWYfFtLloM+0OZmwg==" Author="6333" Date="2013-05-18T06:23:20.620" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;When writing a paper, I usually face the problem of deciding whether a sentence is cite-able or not. Let's say I am writing about optimization of an algorithm. And I used Java to implement it. So, in the introduction, I would say something like &quot;Java is a class based object oriented language...&quot;  This information is available in many java books and online tutorials. Does the ubiquity of the sentence make it un-citeable? Or do I cite that fact. I have read many prominent papers that simply use that sentence without quoting a source. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Or do we only cite numerical facts that go like &quot;Java is x times slower/faster than c++&quot;. I once read an article that says &quot;when writing a paper, you should cite every sentence that you happen to read some where.&quot; But this is unrealistic; and we might have almost as many citations as the number of sentences in the paper. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is there any rule that dictates on what is quotable or not?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to decide whether a statement requires citing a reliable source" AnswerId="hXi+4EWYfFtLloM+0OZmwg==" Author="6333" Date="2013-05-18T15:19:10.657" Text="Thanks @Fuhrmanator, I have changed it/>
<comment QuestionId="How to decide whether a statement requires citing a reliable source" AnswerId="hXi+4EWYfFtLloM+0OZmwg==" Author="3859" Date="2013-05-18T14:59:16.280" Text="I suggest you change the question to say, &quot;How to decide whether a statement requires citing a reliable source.&quot;/>
<comment QuestionId="How to decide whether a statement requires citing a reliable source" AnswerId="hXi+4EWYfFtLloM+0OZmwg==" Author="3859" Date="2013-05-18T15:05:11.050" Text="It ultimately depends on the community you are submitting to, but Wikipedia has a rule that says &quot;cite if &gt;50% likely to be challenged&quot; http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:LIKELY which could serve as a heuristic for you. It's unlikely your first example would be challenged whereas the second one would be highly likely in my opinion./>

<answer QuestionId="How to decide whether a statement requires citing a reliable source" AnswerId="PGukwiQevI3HgG8MJpd9WA==" Author="1318" Date="2013-05-18T08:47:16.107" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;It depends of the audience at which is aimed the article.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In theory, in a scientific document you must explicitly list the basis for all your assumptions, and defend them. If the correctness of the thesis described in your article depends on fact $A$, then you either prove $A$ or give a reference to someone who proved $A$. In practice scientific reports skip some references assumed to be common (e.g. definition and properties of the logarithm): it used to be important to save printing space (not so true now with electronic proceedings), it stays important to keep the article uncluttered. Given the reasons for skipping some references, there cannot be any absolute rule about which ones to skip: the decision depends of the audience you are aiming at, and in particular of your evaluation of the knowledge in common between you and them: put references when they are necessary &lt;em&gt;to your audience&lt;/em&gt; (and do not clutter your article when they are not).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For instance, your sentence about Java being class-based would be unwelcome (in addition of unnecessary) in an article aimed at researchers in computer science, because this fact is supposed to be well known (and agreed upon). But it might be welcome in an article aimed at students (in computer science or not), or researchers in other fields than computer science (e.g. biologists). On the other hand, the fact that Java is slower than C++ might evolve in time (e.g. java compilers getting better), or be argued against (different type of applications):  you should always give a reference for this kind of statement if you did not argue or prove it yourself.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Hope it helps!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to decide whether a statement requires citing a reliable source" AnswerId="PGukwiQevI3HgG8MJpd9WA==" Author="6333" Date="2013-05-18T10:53:09.140" Text="+1 for explaining the &quot;audience&quot; thing. That might explain the inconsistencies I see in well written famous papers. I have seen the same fact cited in some of the papers, presented without citation in the others./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10047" Date="2013-05-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10047" Date="2013-05-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10047" Date="2013-05-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10047" Date="2013-05-18T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How to decide whether a statement requires citing a reliable source" AnswerId="Kl0YA1LDEFkMkwplzr9uKg==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-18T12:08:59.343" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;These are not rules but the way I think about it:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;if the information is basic introductory text book material, you may not need to cite it.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If the information can be found in advanced text books (not intro-level), cite a book that you are familiar with and that supports that statement.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If the informaiton is only found in research papers obviously those are what you reference.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If yu are uncertain, you simply quote a higher level: uncertain if it goes into (1.) then do (2.) etc. It is worse to miss referencing than providing a citation/reference &quot;too much&quot;. In the worst case someone might suggest removing the refence/citation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to decide whether a statement requires citing a reliable source" AnswerId="Kl0YA1LDEFkMkwplzr9uKg==" Author="3859" Date="2013-05-18T15:07:26.230" Text="+1 for better to be safe than sorry/>

<answer QuestionId="How to decide whether a statement requires citing a reliable source" AnswerId="V4JtcdkoZRV+Mrw+SJrNQQ==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-18T06:51:27.357" Score="12" Text="&lt;p&gt;Yes, there are rules on what requires citation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Generally, publicly-known information (widely known, common knowledge, etc.) does not need to be cited. Your sentence about Java being class-based would fall under this category.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Information which is based on someone else's work (analysis, research, pictures, etc.), whether quoted or paraphrased, should always be cited. Your sentence about Java being x time slower/faster than C++ would fall under this category.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you are unsure, cite it to be safe.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to decide whether a statement requires citing a reliable source" AnswerId="V4JtcdkoZRV+Mrw+SJrNQQ==" Author="3859" Date="2013-05-18T15:01:03.660" Text="Wikipedia has specific rules about what is &quot;likely to be challenged&quot; which could be an interesting heuristic to keep in mind: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:LIKELY/>
<comment QuestionId="How to decide whether a statement requires citing a reliable source" AnswerId="V4JtcdkoZRV+Mrw+SJrNQQ==" Author="12587" Date="2014-03-14T21:09:14.217" Text="Also you have to consider how important is the truth of that statement for your results. &quot;C++ is a high level language&quot; may be challenged (depends if you compare it to Assembly or Python), but doesn't affect the results of your computation./>
<comment QuestionId="How to decide whether a statement requires citing a reliable source" AnswerId="V4JtcdkoZRV+Mrw+SJrNQQ==" Author="6333" Date="2013-05-18T07:27:55.703" Text="Thanks @earthling/>

I am 26 and will be 27 soon.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am wondering if I should go back and finish my M.S. in CS, or if rejoining the workforce/starting a career at 28 (when I finish) is going to be looked down upon by employers who could hire someone younger with a B.S.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thanks&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">
