<answer QuestionId="Should I finish the MS CS at this age" AnswerId="rgxrFBQam1atQ8f99rrRiA==" Author="6690" Date="2013-05-19T16:30:50.823" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;My experience is in line with earthlings and since you can't change the past and in my experience you will find many people that are younger but also quite a few that are older in many master programmes. So I think you should pursue that M.S. degree if thats what you really want to do.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Keep in mind:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If you join the workforce now and some years later decide to go back to make your M.S., this will probably become even harder.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;It helps your resume if you can show up with some work experience or extracurricular &lt;strong&gt;activities&lt;/strong&gt;. Maybe you can even find an industry project for your master thesis and/or make 1-2 internships during holidays?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;It would also help if you could focus on a topic that is interesting for you and also possibly relevant for your future career, such as some new internet/web technology (semantic web/web3.0 stuff for example).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Should I finish the MS CS at this age" AnswerId="Q7sxgbNb8ulDExvYzH/FLA==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-18T11:42:23.077" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;In my experience, companies do like to hire young just because they are cheap...this is especially true in CS. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, I think getting your MS is a great idea. The choice you should be looking at is not who is better, you in 2 years when you are 28-29 or someone else with a lower education who is 21-22. You are not 22 so that is simply not an option for you. Getting the MS will compensate in industry for your age but it's not about age. It's about how cheap you'll work and how much you know. Knowing more always helps.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You might have to start cheap (something older people often don't want to do) but if you are willing to sacrifice there is no reason you cannot succeed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Good luck!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10049	<question QuestionId="Should an Editor in Chief publish in their own journal" Title="Should an Editor in Chief publish in their own journal" Views="691" Tags="journals,ethics,editors" " AnswerId="FlqIfUjsKSUSZai1StEKWw==" Author="2827" Date="2013-05-18T10:06:05.727" Score="26" Text="&lt;p&gt;An Editor in Chief of a journal ought to be proud of their journal and consider it a good place to publish their own work, so not publishing in the journal that they edit suggests a lack of confidence in the journal.  On the other hand, is publishing regularly in your own journal ethical?  Can we reasonably expect the editor in chief's papers to be handled with the same rigour as for anybody ese?  Wouldn't there be implicit pressure on the action editor to accept a paper that might be rejected had it come from an external author?  It seems to me that it would be better to be seen to be fair by publishing elsewhere (or al least only publishing occasionally in ones own journal), but I was wondering what the balance of opinion was on this.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Should an Editor in Chief publish in their own journal" AnswerId="FlqIfUjsKSUSZai1StEKWw==" Author="1010" Date="2013-05-18T13:35:43.197" Text="Why the votes to close?  This sounds like a perfectly good question to me./>

<answer QuestionId="Should an Editor in Chief publish in their own journal" AnswerId="pWQYSmjA4LSPoWrnup/OkA==" Author="118" Date="2013-05-20T01:48:24.353" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'm going to chime in with a slightly dissenting answer - I think it's perfectly acceptable for an EiC to publish in their own journal, given some caveats.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think they should be very careful in doing so, and the journal should have a mechanism for handling their submissions that doesn't involve their input in any way - one of the other answers mentions a panel of reviewers to evaluate whether or not the paper gets over the &quot;editorial interest&quot; hurdle, or possibly purely anonymous review. The reasons I think that being the EiC alone is not cause to not submit to your own journals are as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;Publish elsewhere&quot; doesn't necessarily work - first, you've cut the number of journals by one, and for some specialty fields, that's a rather big deal. Additionally, the EiC of a journal is likely working in a field that is particular suited to that journal - &quot;publish elsewhere&quot; forces scholarship into potentially awkward fitting publications for the sake of avoiding the appearance of impropriety. I'd much rather any such risk be addressed head on.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;What about collaborators? For fields where papers often have one or two authors, perhaps this is more clear, but my field routinely has papers with a great many more authors than that. Is any study that recruits one of the finest minds in their field (presumably) then inevitably doomed not to be able to publish in the journal that might fit their work best? What about their graduate students?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Many journals are society journals - you are effectively denying a scholarly society the easiest access to the work of one of their most prominent members (again, presumably). Yes, it could get published elsewhere. But there's no promise I &lt;em&gt;read&lt;/em&gt; elsewhere.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In essence, drawing a hard line and saying &quot;No&quot; is counterproductive - I'd rather have a journal come out with a clear and open policy that says &quot;This is how we handle submissions from our editors&quot; - all of them, than to issue blanket bans.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Should an Editor in Chief publish in their own journal" AnswerId="pWQYSmjA4LSPoWrnup/OkA==" Author="2827" Date="2013-05-20T17:44:36.900" Text="I would have thought that if someone is sufficiently eminent to be an EiC their work ought to be of sufficient quality not to have to resubmit a paper to a different journal more than once!  While luck is an element, to a large extent the author makes their own luck in writing the paper so that it is difficult for the reviewer not to appreciate it.  For fields with &quot;quality breakpoints&quot;, it seems to me if you can't convince the reviewers of two top quality journals, the paper probably belongs in the next rank down./>
<comment QuestionId="Should an Editor in Chief publish in their own journal" AnswerId="pWQYSmjA4LSPoWrnup/OkA==" Author="118" Date="2013-05-20T16:58:53.980" Text="@DikranMarsupial It's not even relatively obscure fields that have a small number of journals. There are, for example, three major &quot;methods-heavy&quot; journals in Epidemiology. Eliminating one is a 33% reduction in the available places you can submit. Even good papers may get rejected from one for one reason or another and find themselves up against the wall. This is also true for fields with clear &quot;quality breakpoints&quot; between journals./>
<comment QuestionId="Should an Editor in Chief publish in their own journal" AnswerId="pWQYSmjA4LSPoWrnup/OkA==" Author="2827" Date="2013-05-20T10:44:42.473" Text="+1 for your helpful answer.  Yes, in relatively obscure fields, there may not be a realistic option to publish elsewhere, but it seems to me that isn't such a health state of affairs either, as it is largely the competition for reputation that is the driver for quality in journals.  I don't think I am in favour of a blanket ban, but currently I still think it is a practice best avoided where possible./>
<comment QuestionId="Should an Editor in Chief publish in their own journal" AnswerId="pWQYSmjA4LSPoWrnup/OkA==" Author="7075" Date="2013-05-20T05:27:43.980" Text="*What about their graduate students?* -- I directly heard from the EiC of a very prestigious specialized math journal that he forbids his graduate students to submit to his journal. I know many of his former students, and indeed they didn't publish their papers there. I don't know how common this practice is in other subfields of mathematics or in non-math fields though./>
<comment QuestionId="Should an Editor in Chief publish in their own journal" AnswerId="pWQYSmjA4LSPoWrnup/OkA==" Author="118" Date="2013-05-20T17:55:30.390" Text="@DikranMarsupial And what if it's their grad student? See the first comment to my answer. And my actual thought for the quality breakpoint example was a field where there is a very clear 1st, 2nd, 3rd type of ranking, instead of ranking categories. Basically, I think a blanket ban is more trouble than it's worth./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10075" Date="2014-03-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10075" Date="2013-10-08T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10075" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10075" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Should an Editor in Chief publish in their own journal" AnswerId="iMjB5a33ZnefCk0pZTWebQ==" Author="64" Date="2013-05-20T11:04:59.673" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;According to page 5 of &lt;a href=&quot;http://publicationethics.org/files/short%20guide%20to%20ethical%20editing%20for%20new%20editors.pdf&quot;&gt;A Short Guide to Ethical Editing by New Editors&lt;/a&gt; by the Committee on Publication Ethics,&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;h2&gt;Can editors publish in their own journal?&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Editors should not be denied the ability to publish in their own journal, but they must not exploit their position. The journal must have a procedure for handling submissions from the editor or members of the editorial board that ensures that peer review is handled independently of the author/editor. This process should be detailed once the paper is published (see: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.wame.org/wame-listserve-discussions/should-editors-publish-in-their-own-journal&quot;&gt;http://www.wame.org/wame-listserve-discussions/should-editors-publish-in-their-own-journal&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That said, in my experience, people tend to look down on editors who publish in their own journals.  The implication is that they published their papers in their journals because other journals wouldn't publish them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10092" Date="2013-10-08T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10092" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10092" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10092" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10092" Date="2013-05-22T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Should an Editor in Chief publish in their own journal" AnswerId="3QZe2iWAtmMnDMskM2l78A==" Author="612" Date="2013-05-18T15:21:09.583" Score="16" Text="&lt;p&gt;There have been only a few times in my career when I've run across an EIC who regularly published in his/her own journal, and in each case it looked like something was seriously wrong.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As a first constraint, it's absolutely unethical for editors to play any role whatsoever in evaluating their own papers.  I.e., they should not suggest referees, solicit or have access to referee reports, participate in the decision making, or even discuss the decision with other editors.  Furthermore, this lack of involvement should be made clear to the referees when the reports are solicited and to the public (for example, by including a paragraph in the journal's web site about how editorial submissions are handled).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Ideally, there should be strong safeguards.  For example, one journal I'm associated with takes the following approach.  If the editor in chief submits a paper, the journal's sponsoring organization appoints a few associate editors to evaluate the submission anonymously and make individual decisions.  If any one of them recommends rejection, then the paper is rejected and the rest of the editorial board never finds out who rejected it.  This avoids the danger of feeling pressure from the EIC, but it leaves open the possibility of favoritism or bias, perhaps even subconsciously.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Because it's difficult to avoid bias and impossible to avoid the appearance of bias, editors should rarely submit papers to their own journals, and EICs almost never.  Aside from special cases such as issues in honor of someone, the only time I think it really looks good for an EIC to submit a paper is if the paper is amazing, far above the usual level of the journal, and it's clear that the EIC is trying to raise the journal's profile by sending a paper there that could easily have been published somewhere more prestigious.  This is risky: it can come across as condescending or self-aggrandizing, it looks strange if done more than very rarely, and others may disagree on how amazing the paper is.  However, if the paper is indeed great then it at least avoids controversy over whether acceptance was appropriate.  The really dangerous scenario is borderline-appropriate papers, where reasonable people could disagree about acceptance and it's natural to wonder whether favoritism might have tipped the balance.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Should an Editor in Chief publish in their own journal" AnswerId="3QZe2iWAtmMnDMskM2l78A==" Author="2827" Date="2013-05-18T15:43:05.227" Text="Thanks for the thoughtful answer, the last paragraph raises another issue, which is what would happen if the paper were flawed?  Could a comment paper be rejected without it reflecting badly on the journal, even if the comment itself were questionable?/>

<answer QuestionId="Should an Editor in Chief publish in their own journal" AnswerId="5QzmO8nWK1PTJBZhSHPd5w==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-18T10:36:48.910" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;There are of course no laws against it but as Editor-in-Chief (EiC) myself I would never do (or at least think twice about doing) it, particularly not as first author. My reasoning behind this is that it could reflect badly on both me but particularly the journal and send signals that all is not necessarily well. I have to point out that in my case we are two and we have an agreement that we do not touch manuscripts from our own spheres of influence (basically departments). Nevertheless, what actually happens within a journal and how people perceive it are two different things and it is my opinion that as EiC one must safeguard the journals reputation as objective. So if the community expresses some form of trust in the editor to publishing in their own journal this could be perfectly fine. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So when an EiC publishes in &quot;their&quot; journal it is not wrong but potentially &quot;dangerous&quot; and can be perceived as poor judgement. They would jeoparize the journals reputation. So even if thetre is no legal problems there are ethical problems. I doubt anyone would have second thoughts aboutth equalit of a journal if the editor does not publish there, after all if the editor has a solid reputation, associating with a bad journal would jeopardize that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Can I see any exceptions? Well, co-authorship may be less serious but in the end even that should be avoided. I also think that if an editor publishess a single paper in a thematic issue of the journal (where someone else has suggested a theme) and this is the only paper by that editor in the journal for years, I would not thik much about it. Obviously frequency of publications is also a factor.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, in conclusion, I consider it unwise under most circumstances.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Should an Editor in Chief publish in their own journal" AnswerId="5QzmO8nWK1PTJBZhSHPd5w==" Author="2827" Date="2013-05-18T10:42:35.967" Text="+1, that is pretty much my intuition.  Even if one was confident of the fairness of the action editors it seems to be putting undue pressure on them, when the question could be easily avoided by publishing elsewhere./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10055	<question QuestionId="Rejecting more papers than accepting" Title="Rejecting more papers than accepting" Views="1207" Tags="peer-review" " AnswerId="aOSdIMHnzixAaeA0NxJ6RA==" Author="4472" Date="2013-05-18T16:35:45.150" Score="26" Text="&lt;p&gt;I made a little statistics about my review decisions. I found out that I reject way more papers than I accept. I honestly try to accept the reviewed papers, I read them carefully and my review are always long. But most papers I review are low quality (in my opinion). Some colleagues told me that I should be more gentle in my review, as this will affect my profile somehow (negatively of course). Is that true ? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also: should I adapt the toughness of my review to the quality of the journal/conference I am reviewing for? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Rejecting more papers than accepting" AnswerId="RrImT1O6FxwoeqEiOPp5rQ==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-18T16:50:02.947" Score="18" Text="&lt;p&gt;It is of course impossible to say if you are overly critical. But, some statistics might help. With prestigious journals the rejection rate might be 90% (very high in any case). I am Editor in Chief of a smaller journal and we have a steady 50% rejection rate. The extremely high rejection rates in some journals come from limited space, in my case we simply impose strict guidelines and the rejections come from reviewers assigned by associate editors. So the rate in our case is fairly certainly upheld by what the community sees as acceptable or not.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So if you end up finding you reject large numbers (at least around 50%) I would not say that it is out of the ordinary. I do not of course know what typical rejection rates are in the journals for which you do reviews, so the number may of course vary.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So getting to the question of how this affects you. I very much doubt that you get a negative effect by being a fair reviewer. If you do many reviewes over time and you are not considered fair, I am sure you would notice the numbers of appointments dropping. If you get re-invited by the same journals/editors, I think they appreciate your work and I would take that as a sign that you do fine.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Should you try to adapt to the journal? In general, no. You should apply your knowledge and understanding to provide a critical review of the submitted work. An editor should take your comments along with comments from one or more additional reviewers and provide a recommendation to the authors. You are not solely responsible in this process! If the journal is such that it publishes material with which you are familiar but where its audience is in a  different field, you may consider handling the paper differently, but obviously not ignoring errors and misconceptions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Rejecting more papers than accepting" AnswerId="uAPoubdOySXiTQkdSEM8VQ==" Author="980" Date="2013-05-19T16:38:12.243" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;In addition to points made in other answers, and strengthening Dave Clarke's first sentence: not only the best, but even &quot;medium-good&quot; journals receive far more &lt;em&gt;good&lt;/em&gt; submissions than they could possibly publish ... at least within the traditional &quot;page limit&quot; constraints, and possibly within some tacit constraint about appearing sufficiently selective. (That is, even if all the papers were quite good, a journal that publishes 10,000 pages a year will be suspect...)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thus, the job of &quot;editor&quot; tends to degenerate into trying to find reasons to reject.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There simply are not enough &quot;prestigious&quot; journals to publish all the (good!) work done by all the good young people... who now can typeset things much faster and get them submitted. (In contrast, pre-TeX, pre-internet, getting something sufficiently presentable to send to a journal was much more of a hassle... Also, the number of researchers has grown much faster than the number of good journals, at least in my field, mathematics.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Returning to the literal question: as others have said, indeed, try to be constructive and helpful, rather than merely a gatekeeper. At the same time, you cannot count on corrective feedback from editors if you are &quot;too harsh&quot;, because they may not realize this, and in fact have incentive not to worry about that exigency, because you are making their job easier.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, one should note that in recent times many respectable journals explicitly declare to referees that they, the referees, are &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; responsible for &lt;em&gt;correctness&lt;/em&gt; of an article. It is supposedly the author's responsibility. This is obviously strange, but can be understood when we realize that the gatekeeper function of journals, editors, and referees is at least as important as the scientific function... as disillusioning as that might be. But it does explain situations that are otherwise baffling and counter-intuitive.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10071" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10071" Date="2014-04-12T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10071" Date="2013-08-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10071" Date="2014-04-11T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Rejecting more papers than accepting" AnswerId="3IZLJzVUgyrCDHj6zTDLIA==" Author="946" Date="2013-05-19T12:20:45.473" Score="14" Text="&lt;p&gt;An important thing to be aware of, is that (as far as I can judge) editors tend not to send papers on which they have a bad first impression to experienced people. It follows that junior researchers tend to receive a relatively large proportion of demands to review papers that are below average. That might explain your feeling.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Rejecting more papers than accepting" AnswerId="mlXSJxQwiaOJIVT4EiKwVw==" Author="643" Date="2013-05-18T16:49:07.443" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;Many more papers are submitted than accepted at top venues/journals, so statistically speaking, you should reject more than you accept.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Harsh reviews are ultimately good for science, so long as they filter the crap and help improve papers with potential but are not there yet. If your review is able to help the PC/editors decide whether or not to accept the paper and help the authors improve their paper, then you are doing your job correctly. If you are harsh but unhelpful, then you need to change your approach.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think your reviews can change a bit depending on the venue. If you are reviewing for a workshop, your goal would be to help choose papers that are likely to generate interesting discussion. This is especially the case if there is no associated official publication. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Rejecting more papers than accepting" AnswerId="mlXSJxQwiaOJIVT4EiKwVw==" Author="938" Date="2014-04-12T22:31:25.137" Text="&quot;Many more papers are submitted than accepted at top venues/journals, so statistically speaking, you should reject more than you accept.&quot;  Yes, but at many journals editors have the discretion to reject papers without refereeing them.  So your statistical conclusion does not necessarily follow./>

<answer QuestionId="Rejecting more papers than accepting" AnswerId="eFTvck454Ij2XysKartGrg==" Author="2827" Date="2013-05-18T16:59:36.383" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;Some journals allow you to see the reviews provided by the other reviewers of the paper, which is often a good way of monitoring your own performance as a reviewer.  If you are harsh to an unreasonable degree, I suspect that editors will stop sending you papers to review, so if they are still sending them, that is an indication of sorts that there is not a fundamental problem.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As long as you are happy that you are applying a standard that you feel is reasonable, I'd stick with it.  You probably review too few papers to know whether you are being unduly harsh or that you have just been sent a series of bad papers by random chance.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When I get a rejection, I am generally fine provided that the reviewer does a good job of explaining what they (incorrectly ;o) feel the problem is and what needs to be done to the paper for them to be happy with it, in sufficient detail for me to be able to do so if it is actually possible.  The problem I have with negative reviews is when they make vague criticisms that can't be addressed as there is not enough information to actually act on, or where reviewers raise additional issues on the second review to reject your paper that could have been raised on the first review.  So if your reviews are detailed and constructive, they are probably good reviews.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;At the end of the day, it is ultimately in the author's best interests not to publish poor work, and if it can be usefully improved, then the reviewer is doing them a favour in not accepting it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10058" Date="2013-05-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10058" Date="2013-08-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10058" Date="2013-05-19T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>

academia.stackexchange.com_10059	<question QuestionId="Mentor trying to be first author" Title="Mentor trying to be first author" Views="1037" Tags="publishing,graduate-admissions,ethics,authorship" " AnswerId="n1HCP02GVIL2ygOdLynGdw==" Author="773" Date="2013-05-18T17:00:40.240" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;I was on an internship with professor A at University B in China. We were working on a computer science project. During the internship I implemented professor A's idea and got some results. Three weeks ago I finished a paper draft and left University B for a new internship. Me and professor A were planning to submit the paper draft to a conference (deadline: May 20). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Until yesterday (May 17), the order of authors was: me, professor A, other students &amp;amp; collaborators in the lab... And professor A had no objection with that. However, last night I received an email from him. He said he wants to be the first author... His reason was for intellectual properties and patent issues. My understanding is that because I was merely an intern at University B, if the first author was me, it would cause IP troubles for him?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;I feel deceived. But, should I feel like this?&lt;/strong&gt; I was counting on a first-author paper because I'm planning to apply for a PhD program in the US. One paper may not mean a lot to someone who's published a lot. But for someone who hasn't published yet, it means something.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Looking on the Internet, I found something that might explain professor A's motivations: &#xA;In China specifically, corresponding authors are often underappreciated by universities and research institues. This might be the case for University B. Given professor A is relatively young, he may want first authorship for promotion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Summary of my questions:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Should I go discuss with professor A and try to persuade him to let me be the first author?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If I want to apply for a PhD program in the US, would being the first author be more helpful or being the second author is as well helpful?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Edit:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;My affiliation for the paper has always been University B. I didn't mention my current university or internship in any sense.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;I emailed back to professor A yesterday, saying I think I should be the first author, because I did most of the work; because the idea was originated from him he should be the corresponding author. He replied this morning, saying he agree with what I said. He explained that because I was doing an internship in his lab and not a student of University B, putting me as the first author could cause IP and patent troubles for University B... So this problem is fixed now.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Mentor trying to be first author" AnswerId="n1HCP02GVIL2ygOdLynGdw==" Author="929" Date="2013-05-20T08:22:09.703" Text="This is why you should always talk about author order before starting to write the paper (ideally before doing the research)./>
<comment QuestionId="Mentor trying to be first author" AnswerId="n1HCP02GVIL2ygOdLynGdw==" Author="929" Date="2013-08-28T14:09:43.773" Text="@perfectionm1ng that is a great new question. Ask it and I will try and come up with an answer./>

How should we address this before writing and meanwhile be nice?/>
<comment QuestionId="Mentor trying to be first author" AnswerId="n1HCP02GVIL2ygOdLynGdw==" Author="2744" Date="2013-07-26T12:06:53.947" Text="Surely any IP issues can be solved by making a separate declaration, if necessary?/>
<comment QuestionId="Mentor trying to be first author" AnswerId="n1HCP02GVIL2ygOdLynGdw==" Author="49" Date="2013-08-28T18:23:54.567" Text="@DanielE.Shub Before doing research? Sometimes it later turns out that one's contribution was great (or non-existing)./>

<answer QuestionId="Mentor trying to be first author" AnswerId="CiUIEWkUgLpdevXcdlPdjw==" Author="546" Date="2013-05-19T14:05:54.867" Score="5" Text="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Should I go discuss with professor A and try to persuade him to let me be the first author?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think so. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;At least you would like him to explain to you why he changed his mind. He had no objection with you being the first author in the first place. Then he sent you e-mail saying he wants to be the first author a few days before the submission deadline. There must be some important reason for that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The intellectual properties and patent issues make some sense to me since you are no longer with University B. They might cause some trouble for Prof. A.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am not convinced the corresponding authorship in your case makes a difference. First authorship does matter in China if you are also a professor at the same level, say both of you are assistant professors. He could be looked down because you made more contribution than he did. But, you are an intern. He can explain to others that you did all these under his supervision. I think he would actually earn extra credits by helping interns/students to publish papers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have the same suspicion as aeismall does. Your active affiliation may be an issue for Prof. A. Which institute will you represent when the paper is presented at the conference? Who will present the paper? I think these questions are his concerns.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Edit&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;After talking to some researchers knowledgeable about the corresponding authorship in China, I learned more about the issue. Some authors don't want to be the corresponding author because they are busy with other research interests. Some are just shy away because English writing is hard for them. Some are interested in the role because they would be more widely known in his area. In most cases, the first author or the one who makes the most contribution to the paper is the corresponding author. So far, no one is able to explain to me why corresponding authors are underappreciated. It seems to have little to do with your issue.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;End of edit&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Mentor trying to be first author" AnswerId="CiUIEWkUgLpdevXcdlPdjw==" Author="546" Date="2013-05-20T06:59:15.097" Text="@CherryQu I updated my answer about the corresponding author issue./>

<answer QuestionId="Mentor trying to be first author" AnswerId="GL1LT7NILeADdhZ24sxJ+w==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-18T19:33:18.050" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;I don't really understand what the motivation here for the professor is. Since you did all of the work for this paper at University B, you should &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; list your new affiliation (whether it's an internship or another school) as an &quot;active&quot; affiliation for this paper. It &lt;em&gt;can&lt;/em&gt; be listed as a &quot;current address,&quot; but not as an active address for this paper. In that way, the professor still gets credit for your work, with your affiliation showing as being part of his group. (I suspect that the professor's concern is that, if you are at another institution and list &lt;em&gt;that&lt;/em&gt; as your address, he won't get credit for his work.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another issue is that if you are not going to present the paper at the conference, he may have felt it was in his interests to list himself as a first author. How appropriate this is I have to leave to the CS community to judge. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In general, however, the first author &lt;em&gt;should&lt;/em&gt; be the person who has made the largest contributions to both the research and the writing of the paper. Deviations from this need to have a very good foundation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Mentor trying to be first author" AnswerId="GL1LT7NILeADdhZ24sxJ+w==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-18T21:43:05.733" Text="@FaheemMitha: That was a slight misreading on my part. But the main point still stands: the new address shouldn't appear in the list of affiliations./>
<comment QuestionId="Mentor trying to be first author" AnswerId="GL1LT7NILeADdhZ24sxJ+w==" Author="285" Date="2013-05-18T20:41:39.830" Text="I saw no mention of University A./>

<answer QuestionId="Mentor trying to be first author" AnswerId="Ajo//4Rlpqb55tozYYV/EA==" Author="285" Date="2013-05-18T17:43:14.133" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;It is possible the professor is trying to take advantage of you, but it would help to clarify things if you would expand on your answer to include the following.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is implied that the paper is based on Professor A's idea. What this a full-blown idea, or just the kernel of something. Or, putting it differently, did he just point you in the general direction of something, or was this a relatively finished idea that just needed to be worked out in detail? Was this an idea you expanded on, or significantly improved? Did he provide significant intellectual input while the project was ongoing, or did he leave you to your own devices?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, you talked about implementation. Does this mean code, or something else? Did Professor A participate in the implementation in any way? If not, did he look at the implementation?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What about the paper itself? Did he participate in a substantial way in the writing of it?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If the answer is that you did most or all of the work, and did much of the working out of the idea, then it sounds like you should be first author. If he contributed substantially, it is less clear.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, the paradigm in general is that the junior person gets the first authorship, because they need it for career reasons. Most people are willing to abide by this. I know someone whose PhD adviser put himself as first author on his (the students) papers, and the person in question regrets it now. If you go along with this, you may also regret it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you don't work for this person, the question is whether you have to do what he says for some reason. If you are hoping for a good reference, a first authorship on a paper might be worth more than a reference. Does he have any other hold on you? Do you need his further input on the project, or are you hoping to publish further papers with him? Also (perhaps not very important but serves to indicate tone) was the email polite or not? Personally, I think a conversation would have been more appropriate than an email in the circumstances.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For the record, I find the argument about intellectual properties and patent issues less than compelling, but it would also help if you could say more about how these things work in your university.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10061" Date="2013-05-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10061" Date="2013-05-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10061" Date="2013-05-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10061" Date="2013-05-24T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Mentor trying to be first author" AnswerId="Gc5CLAVQIqmcIeh84oZFBQ==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-18T17:13:50.207" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;My answer to whether you should feel deceived is yes and no. Strictly speaking, if you have an agreement, it should stand. That is the easy part of the answer. Then comes different traditions and personalities, which makes the territory almost impossible to negotiate. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You could simply send a reply stating you disagree with the reordering. The point of having intellectual property involved is certainly true and merits co-authorship. The problem is of course the weight between your work and the original idea. If you have worked on this on your own without any help or assistance, first authorship seems clear. If you have had help through discussions etc. through the process it becomes less clear.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In the end the matter will be up to you, if you think you will gain much from taking the fight. You can ask to add something in the acknowledgement to make clear who contributed what. Another possibility, if the paper is mostly about your work, is to add yourself as corresponding author (which can be different from first).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_1006	<question QuestionId="How should students approach quals" Title="How should students approach quals" Views="573" Tags="graduate-school,phd" " AnswerId="Vey+HxJCR7G6YIqpUitioA==" Author="user107" Date="2012-04-04T16:42:31.700" Score="13" Text="&lt;p&gt;Most universities (at least in North America) have the concept of &quot;Qualification Exams&quot; taken one year after the student joins the graduate course. These usually encompass all that was done in the first year and as undergraduate and might also test some other (research abilities) of the student by asking him to present papers (s)he found interesting.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some universities treat this as a formality and everyone who attempts usually gets through while some universities take quals very seriously and won't allow the student to continue if he fails the quals (maybe, they will allow for 2nd attempt). These universities might subscribe reading lists consisting of textbooks and papers which comprises of &quot;must-have&quot; knowledge of the field. The latter might constitute as a difficult phase for students who find themselves ill prepared in a certain portion of the exam. (For instance, a pure math undergrad moving to a PhD in Fluid Mechanics and asked to attempt an exam on Fluid Machines)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Assuming STEM graduate course in a university which takes quals seriously (with a structure of written test &gt;   oral exam &gt; interview/research proposal presentation), &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;How should a student approach these exams?&lt;/strong&gt;&#xA;Specifically,&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;How is it any different from the undergraduate exams that students give? &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Do you really &quot;prepare&quot; for these exams or should you bank on the courses you have taken and the homework you solved to get you through?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Repeatedly, I have been told by students (across departments and across institutes) that the faculty is only interested in the oral section of quals as a sanity check and to see whether you have the urge for learning something new; is this universally true? &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How should students approach quals" AnswerId="Vey+HxJCR7G6YIqpUitioA==" Author="65" Date="2012-04-04T19:11:15.977" Text="In my experience, these exams are considerably less common in computer science.  Neither my MS department (UC Irvine), my PhD department (Berkeley), nor the department I work for now (Illinois) have them at all.  (On the other hand, at Illinois we have a non-trivial exam in the second year, called &quot;the qual&quot;, limited to the student's broad research area.)/>

<answer QuestionId="How should students approach quals" AnswerId="G4zFOz0cK3Sizji7bytMdA==" Author="53" Date="2012-04-04T22:48:24.367" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;Qualifying exams are &lt;em&gt;never&lt;/em&gt; to be taken lightly. Even when they prove to be a surreal experience, they need to be given the attention appropriate to their seriousness. These are exams that you typically only have one or at most two chances to pass. As a result, you want to get through them on the first try, so that you don't have to worry about them again. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;How hard you have to work does depend a lot on the structure of the exam, and based on your previous preparation. If there are a lot of subjects to be tested with which you are not familiar, you may have to work harder than if you're getting A's in all of the classes that will be tested on the exam. (Even then, you'll still want to work through some practice problems to get a feel for the kinds of questions that are asked.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As the original questioner mentions, in many cases the oral exam can be a &quot;sanity check&quot;—in more ways than one. If the decision has been largely made on the basis of the previous coursework and written quals, then the oral exam can act either to confirm the decisions of the panel, or as an effective psychological exam. One of my panels turned things into what amounted to a carnival side-show, with everybody acting completely out of character, and in a manner I found entirely unbefitting an oral qualifying exam. However, it made sense to see if there was any way to make me &quot;snap&quot; and lose my cool. (I was too busy trying to figure out why everybody was acting so oddly to really snap.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1008" Date="2012-04-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1008" Date="2013-03-26T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1008" Date="2012-04-05T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1008" Date="2012-05-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1008" Date="2012-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1008" Date="2012-04-23T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1008" Date="2012-04-05T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How should students approach quals" AnswerId="5cBiHegXt39sNpLhp6Dxug==" Author="21" Date="2012-04-04T17:52:05.873" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;At my university (in the US), the quals are a big deal -- both written and oral. The written quals are the tough ones because the oral quals, here, deal only with your research and as you should be reasonably well read in the literature in your field of research, no one really fails the orals.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The written quals need substantial preparation. For my quals (Fluids/Thermodyanics/Heat transfer) back in 2008, I had to work and study hard for about 10-12 hours a day for 3 months straight. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There were several students who didn't make it through the first attempt and had to go through it all over again the next year. Some (miniscule number) didn't make it the second time around and were discharged with a master's degree.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So to answer your question:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;It is very university and area of specialization, the difficulty level and importance given to written qualifiers.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;To be safe, study up hard like you never have before.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;You may have other responsibilities like grants, classes to teach, assignments to do and research but you just have to balance all these.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Good luck! It is just a matter of hard work, thats all!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;-Will be getting my PhD in mechanical engineering at the end of Fall 2012.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10062	<question QuestionId="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" Title="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" Views="3817" Tags="publishing,authorship" " AnswerId="575tE+blVwFHeXDKRxMIDA==" Author="958" Date="2013-05-18T17:50:17.937" Score="17" Text="&lt;p&gt;After reading the question &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/10059/mentor-trying-to-be-first-author&quot;&gt;Mentor trying to be first author?&lt;/a&gt;, I got the impression that (at least in the writers' field) the &quot;corresponding author&quot; flag could carry an implied meaning, such as &quot;did more work than the other authors&quot;, or &quot;is a more senior author&quot;. Is it the case?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am in mathematics, a field where we typically sort the authors alphabetically, and I've never given any importance to that role (apart from &quot;this author is willing to answer a couple of extra e-mails, if needed&quot;).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" AnswerId="575tE+blVwFHeXDKRxMIDA==" Author="285" Date="2013-05-18T17:53:52.933" Text="Good question. I've wondered about that too. I once has a co-author on a project, who happened to be the PI for the contract that paid for people to work on that project, but had done zero work on the project himself. He was suspiciously eager to be corresponding author. Afterwards, I wondered what he knew that I didn't./>
<comment QuestionId="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" AnswerId="575tE+blVwFHeXDKRxMIDA==" Author="648" Date="2014-04-22T08:04:56.293" Text="I though that corresponding author is simply the one, takes care of submitting the article and communicating with the editor./>
<comment QuestionId="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" AnswerId="575tE+blVwFHeXDKRxMIDA==" Author="236" Date="2013-05-19T23:12:53.990" Text="This seems very much field-dependent./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10062" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10062" Date="2013-05-19T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" AnswerId="Sk6yz3UGdMNVeMH4F1WOJw==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-20T11:34:54.173" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;In my field of Physics, there seems to be no implied meaning - the 3 papers that I have got published recently, I have been the first and corresponding author, primarily due to, as Jukka and Peter have mentioned, to doing most of the legwork and having the responsibility for the research.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, it can be seen as a logisitcs thing, where the corresponding author is the port-of-call during the proofing/editing stages by the journal.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10094" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10094" Date="2014-05-01T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" AnswerId="v1SqoPOvtC8rM7KqkuFYRA==" Author="351" Date="2013-05-19T11:20:10.580" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;In theoretical computer science, &quot;corresponding author&quot; does not carry any implied meaning related to who is the primary contributor.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The coauthors are listed in alphabetical order. The corresponding author might be, for example, the coauthor who took care of the interaction with the publisher, or a coauthor with a fairly permanent mailing address.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In pre-prints, conference abstracts, etc. we do not usually mention any corresponding author. This is just a piece of information that is required by journal publishers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is no prestige related to it. Certainly you will not list this kind of information in your CV.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" AnswerId="v1SqoPOvtC8rM7KqkuFYRA==" Author="980" Date="2013-05-19T22:01:12.150" Text="Similarly, no prestige in mathematics, of which I'm aware. If anything, perhaps the opposite, since the &quot;corresponding author&quot; is the one who has to deal with... correspondence./>

<answer QuestionId="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" AnswerId="YKCJB9rbk4QAtsVvfih7yQ==" Author="62" Date="2014-04-22T07:55:52.320" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;The corresponding author is the author designated to be the first point of contact by readers of the paper. In theory, authors could use any rule they like to decide which author is the corresponding author. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, in my experience, the corresponding author is often the author who has made the largest contribution or an author who has made one of the larger contributions to the paper. The corresponding author is also often chosen as someone who is likely to have a stable contact address and is likely to remain in academia for some time to come. In that case, supervisors are sometimes corresponding authors rather than students (even where the student has done most of the work). A similar pattern can hold in the case of industry collaborations where the academic may be the corresponding author.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Importantly, in most models of ethical publishing, all authors are meant to take responsibility for the claims in the published work.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" AnswerId="NnYDAzEDsBqFgeOZbSYkQw==" Author="5962" Date="2013-05-18T21:49:25.407" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;Corresponding authorship is often used to signal the person who is the primary contributor to the work. I've seen this in fields like economics where there is a relatively strong norm of listing authors alphabetically. In these cases, the primary contributor is signaled with the &lt;em&gt;corresponding author&lt;/em&gt; designation. I've seen people go so far as to list corresponding authorship on their CVs when they list their papers although I think this is far from the norm.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In fields where authorship is not simply alphabetic, I've seen the &lt;em&gt;corresponding author&lt;/em&gt; designation used to flag the second author as a major contributor because, even in cases of so called &quot;dual-first authorship,&quot; &lt;em&gt;somebody's&lt;/em&gt; name has to come first.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In lots of other fields, it caries little signal value and really is just used to mark the person who is in the best position to answer questions about the work. Of course, the person marked as best able to answer question will, mostly likely, be someone who was involved in a wide variety of the research reported in the paper.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" AnswerId="NnYDAzEDsBqFgeOZbSYkQw==" Author="5962" Date="2013-05-20T14:53:35.183" Text="@FaheemMitha: It will signal &quot;primary author&quot; when the order is alphabetical. But if the order is not alphabetical (or not in a field where that is normal), it will not trump first authorship that came from explicit ordering./>
<comment QuestionId="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" AnswerId="NnYDAzEDsBqFgeOZbSYkQw==" Author="285" Date="2013-05-19T07:56:16.083" Text="Can corresponding authorship be used to override the &quot;first author is primary author&quot; presumption that seems to be common in some (e.g. biomedical) fields?/>
<comment QuestionId="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" AnswerId="NnYDAzEDsBqFgeOZbSYkQw==" Author="118" Date="2013-05-20T00:58:39.307" Text="@FaheemMitha Not in my experience, no. It's generally just &quot;A senior person&quot; and often just &quot;Someone with a stable email address&quot;. I've never seen anyone assert that it &quot;trumps&quot; the position of the first author./>
<comment QuestionId="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" AnswerId="NnYDAzEDsBqFgeOZbSYkQw==" Author="285" Date="2013-05-20T09:39:17.243" Text="@EpiGrad: Thanks for the feedback./>

<answer QuestionId="Does &quotcorresponding author&quot carry an implied meaning" AnswerId="GogeeLhfDUw9EZ2XLnFuUA==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-18T18:15:09.060" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am sure it can be used for many meanings. I will provide the ones with which I am familiar:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;First, corresponding author means it is the person to contact if you have questions about the research. The reasons for this is what varies.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The first author(s) are not employed at a universiy or are students&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The first author has done much of the leg work but someone else (a senior scientist has provided the original idea, funding aetc.)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Some is specifically responsible for a project in which the work for the publication has been made. There may be legal requirements that a specific person should handl correspondence, for example in a company&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;In some fields the most important author is not first, in which case the flag can be used.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Sometimes you will see first authors stating they are corresponding author. This is mostly implied by default in fields where the first authorship means also doing most of the intellectual work.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am sure there are additional examples which hopefuly are added by additional posts.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10076	<question QuestionId="How to talk to a project advisor as an undergrad" Title="How to talk to a project advisor as an undergrad" Views="123" Tags="etiquette,research-undergraduate,personal-advice" " AnswerId="bwhfoSx3ylGttp9X7UXzRA==" Author="6071" Date="2013-05-20T02:47:55.493" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'm an undergraduate working on a small project with an esteemed scientist, whom I met through a connection. I'm communicating via email due to distance. The problem is that I'm having a lot of troubles with this project, and the last time I asked him a question he just told me to re-read the information he sent me.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I want to tell him that &lt;em&gt;it doesn't make sense&lt;/em&gt; (I think he made an error), but to do so without appearing arrogant or ignorant. He's intimidating and it always seems like he's two seconds away from declaring me incompetent. Yet, I am very interested in his field and this project could yield a publication.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't know what to do; should I just keep asking questions (if so, how do I word them in a way that shows that I'm not just being lazy), or find a way to drop the project? I don't want to close doors on future collaborations when I'm more knowledgeable.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thank you.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10076" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10076" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10076" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10076" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10076" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10076" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How to talk to a project advisor as an undergrad" AnswerId="F6D3lAE1qqHCByGTO4qIiw==" Author="6820" Date="2013-05-20T03:44:25.573" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;If you think your advisor made an error, then I would suggest you figure out how to &lt;em&gt;prove&lt;/em&gt; he made an error. This is the first step to showing someone they've made an error without being ignorant or arrogant (the rest follows from general customs about politeness, but you absolutely must do this first bit. He supposes, presumably in good faith, that he proved something to you; the &quot;burden of proof&quot; that he's wrong now lies in your hands). Besides, this is a good exercise. Lots of things don't seem like they make sense until you yourself figure out how to make them make sense to you. This can be a lot of work. This act of &quot;hacking&quot; someone else's grand idea until it makes sense to me is how I spend most of my time. Thankfully this often leads to totally new ideas and directions that the first guy didn't see (or thought too trivial or obviously wrong to mention, yes that happens too...)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The problem is that, in very many fields, undergraduates &lt;em&gt;are&lt;/em&gt; actually extremely frustrating to work with. They don't yet speak the language, or have the baseline knowledge that all of your colleagues share. But nonetheless, this person is not the ideal advisor if he lacks the patience to put up with a lot of questions -- this is &lt;em&gt;absolutely&lt;/em&gt; normal behavior for an undergraduate advisee, totally to be expected and many advisors find the interactions quite rewarding!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the other hand though, you have some hard questions to ask yourself. Basically, you say that you want to ask questions without sounding lazy, but you must be honest with yourself about whether or not you are in fact asking lazy questions. The research process (again, at least in fields I'm familiar with) is most emphatically &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; &quot;do exactly what some famous guy told you to do.&quot; It generally involves painfully slogging through material that &lt;em&gt;no one&lt;/em&gt; really understands and proving everything you think you know to yourself repeatedly, and then to others, and then occasionally having it pointed out that you made a really silly assumption, or that some obscure paper already solved everything you had set out for. Again, the point is to create new knowledge, and so you have to know your tools inside and out. In fact, if your advisor is explaining &lt;em&gt;anything at all&lt;/em&gt; clearly and to your satisfaction, what he is explaining is, by definition, old knowledge.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to talk to a project advisor as an undergrad" AnswerId="F6D3lAE1qqHCByGTO4qIiw==" Author="6071" Date="2013-05-21T19:18:27.480" Text="Thank you for the detailed answer./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10078" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10078" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10078" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10078" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10078" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10078" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How to talk to a project advisor as an undergrad" AnswerId="Q79wExPnv2oo/9cz8GSjvw==" Author="546" Date="2013-05-20T03:37:34.360" Score="3" Text="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;I want to tell him that it doesn't make sense (I think he made an error), &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would suggest you to write an e-mail to him to explain the error you found.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Do re-read the information he sent you earlier before you write the e-mail. Verify the error is indeed an error. Then write the e-mail in concise manner. Explain the error in details, step by step. Don't just say there is an error. Use evidence, theory to support your claim.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Of course, etiquette is important. However, this has nothing to do with arrogance or ignorance. It has everything to do with finding the truth. Every scientist I have met would like to know any error found before the research project is finished, the earlier the better.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10077" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10077" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10077" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10079	<question QuestionId="How does your area of research affect your chances of getting job in academia" Title="How does your area of research affect your chances of getting job in academia" Views="226" Tags="research,career" " AnswerId="lr4pNBnMTOHdnl4zeYNsnQ==" Author="86" Date="2013-05-20T03:53:55.417" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;I've heard that the trendiness of your area of work is one of the important factor that has am impact your chances of getting job in academia. How far is this true?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, how do I decide what areas are trendy and what areas are not in the field I'm interested that is mathematics?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How does your area of research affect your chances of getting job in academia" AnswerId="lr4pNBnMTOHdnl4zeYNsnQ==" Author="929" Date="2013-05-20T08:19:07.300" Text="One problem with being trendy is that what is trendy now is not the same thing as what will be trendy in the future. At the start of your PhD you might be 10+ years away from &quot;getting a job&quot;/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10079" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="How does your area of research affect your chances of getting job in academia" AnswerId="3RL53ntGSGnrAxUSQjcWMw==" Author="7075" Date="2013-05-20T10:16:10.280" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Regarding the third point of Anonymous's suggestion, here's an article &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ams.org/notices/201011/rtx101101421p.pdf&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Topical Bias in Generalist Mathematics Journals&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/a&gt; by Joseph F. Grcar in the december 2010 issue of the Notices of the American Mathematical Society.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In many branches of mathematics, the so-called &quot;generalist&quot; journals are perceived more prestigious and publish many of the best results. Typically they claim that they publish papers of the highest quality in all branches of mathematics. However, they don't necessarily accept papers from each field equally likely. In fact, as the linked article's figures clearly suggest, there are clear biases for/against certain branches if you count the papers of a certain topic published in generalist journals and compare the number with the total number of papers of the same kind.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Since good generalist journals are among the most prestigious publication venues in many branches of mathematics, by looking at statistics like this, you may be able to detect prejudices about branches among mathematicians, which is mentioned in the linked article. So, if your definition of &quot;trendy&quot; is highly correlated with this type of prejudice (which I think it is because, all else being equal, the number of publications in prestigious journals in your CV increases your chance of getting a job in academia), it can be a fairly reliable measure of trendiness.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The Annals of Mathematics Anonymous mentioned is definitely among the very top generalist journals. So checking the latest issues may tell you something about what's hot in mathematics now.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The big caveat, however, is that it only publishes 50 or so articles in each year. So, if you only look up in recent issues, your statistics can't be extremely reliable. Using a record of several years defies the purpose of knowing what's trendy right now, so you're in a bit of a conundrum. Making things more complicated, each generalist journal has their own bias as well; different journals tend to publish papers of different topics more frequently.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, it might be better to take samples from multiple generalist journals which are considered among the top journals by many. Those journals typically publish an extremely small number of papers though. For example, the Journal of the American Mathematical Society published only 32 papers in 2011 (and 35 in 2010) according to ISI Web of Knowledge. Some prestigious generalist journals publish even fewer papers. (I'm not going to talk about which journals you should use for this purpose because it's inevitably controversial and subjective.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In any case, if you want to check what kind of topic is discussed in a given journal, you can do that quite easily by &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ams.org/mathscinet/index.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;MathSciNet&lt;/a&gt;. The American Mathematical Society classified branches of mathematics and gave a code number to each branch. And they've been keeping track of publications in mathematics. Just search for the MSC code of your field with a specific journal in MathSciNet and see how many hits it returns. This way, you can see how trendy your field is as well as which prestigious generalist journal likes your kind of mathematics more.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This method doesn't always work equally well though, e.g., if you're interested in applied mathematics or mathematical sides of computer science, what the Annals of Mathematics loves nowadays may not be the most reliable measure that reflects what's trendy right now. Another example is when your field became fashionable relatively recently so there isn't a good catch-all MSC code yet. For instance, arithmetic combinatorics has seen a miraculous revival in recent years in mathematics. Ann. of Math. and other prestigious journals are publishing papers in this field, but there isn't a good MSC code to capture this.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10090" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How does your area of research affect your chances of getting job in academia" AnswerId="+zrMB3F5gFf0QcAxEL1iiQ==" Author="6110" Date="2013-05-20T06:51:37.033" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would recommend that you work in an area of mathematics where big theorems are currently being proven. That usually means that lots of moderate theorems are also being proven.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some ways to see what these areas are:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Go to national conferences; for example attend the (US) Joint Math Meetings and go to the hour-long invited talks.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Go to your department colloquium every week, if you have one.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Browse through the tables of contents for recent issues of the &lt;em&gt;Annals of Mathematics&lt;/em&gt;, and see what areas are getting lots of papers published. (This is a sign not only that these areas are &quot;trendy&quot;, but also that they're seeing significant ongoing progress.)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Look at colloquium schedules for top-10 institutions, and/or institutions similar to where you hope to get hired. See what kinds of topics the speakers are lecturing about, i.e., what kinds of topics the professors there want to learn about.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Browse the Math Jobs Wiki, click through to the web pages of successful job candidates, and skim their papers.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;(The most important) If you are in grad school, and have not yet chosen an advisor, find out whose students have gotten jobs similar to what you hope to get, and/or are doing interesting work now.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How does your area of research affect your chances of getting job in academia" AnswerId="+zrMB3F5gFf0QcAxEL1iiQ==" Author="86" Date="2013-05-20T06:56:24.007" Text="Thanks for the reply! I interested in Algebraic Number theory ,arithmetic geometry and things related to that. Will you consider it trendy?/>
<comment QuestionId="How does your area of research affect your chances of getting job in academia" AnswerId="+zrMB3F5gFf0QcAxEL1iiQ==" Author="6110" Date="2013-05-20T10:06:01.737" Text="Yes, very much so./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10085" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How does your area of research affect your chances of getting job in academia" AnswerId="pMZ18xTzhWtSgU6dKMz4Qg==" Author="346" Date="2013-05-20T04:58:12.693" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Trendiness can be factor, but a much more important factor is what needs the hiring department has. If they're chock full of topologists, it doesn't matter how &quot;trendy&quot; your work in topology is: there's a good chance they might be looking to expand in other areas. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;OTOH, if they're looking in your area, then being at the cutting edge can't hurt. The danger of course is timing: trends rise and fall quickly, and what might be trendy right now might not be so in a year or two (maybe in mathematics, trends move more slowly). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So I'd argue that trendiness, while one potential factor, is not a universal key factor at all. Every department has their own needs. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As regards your second question, usual measures of &quot;trendiness&quot; include the relative frequency of publication in that subarea. In CS, it's relatively easy to determine this via conference acceptances, but in math I'm not sure how you'd go about measuring this frequency. It also helps to attend big meetings and listen to where the buzz is. An advisor can also be helpful in this regard (especially if they're pre-tenure and need to keep track of trends themselves :))&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How does your area of research affect your chances of getting job in academia" AnswerId="pMZ18xTzhWtSgU6dKMz4Qg==" Author="3" Date="2013-05-20T13:13:13.683" Text="To piggy back a bit off of this, if you actually follow job listings that might be a good way to identify trendy fields, at least in terms of areas of expertise depts. want to hire! Also I would note there are some schools in the social sciences that specialize in particular areas, and so even if they are chock full of people in that area already they are frequently open to more (tends to be good schools, but not the top schools in my field, so their &quot;hook&quot; is some specific area of expertise)./>

Also, MANY programs automatically ignore the first 1-2 years of grades and just want to know about your last 2 years./>

<answer QuestionId="Is is possible to study mathematics PHD with another bachelor degree like Business Aministration" AnswerId="sS8pzdJD1xecck4vr4Gzxg==" Author="6787" Date="2013-05-20T16:00:03.483" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;The short answer is: &quot;yes, but it won't automatically be easy&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;First, every department of every school in every major has a set of preferences - things they like to see in an applicant. This list includes GPA, GRE, sometimes subject-specific GRE, specific coursework, specific reference letters, and the rarely-ever-listed undergraduate research/term papers that lots of people here give great advice about but that I didn't previously know was a 'thing'.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Looking over the admittance pages of prospective programs can give you an idea of this at times. In your case, I looked at a few schools math departments I'm familiar with, and using this one as an example because its not terribly atypical (but you should research your own preferred institutions): &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.math.wisc.edu/graduate/applying&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;University of Wisconsin Mathematics&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;1) A GPA of at least 3.0 overall and substantially higher in mathematics courses.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;2) 18 or more credits of mathematics beyond calculus. The 18 credits should include at least one semester of both rigorous analysis&#xA;  (sometimes called advanced calculus) and abstract algebra, and&#xA;  preferably two semesters. Advanced undergraduate courses in other&#xA;  topics further strengthen your application.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;6) A “Supplemental Application Form” is required after submitting your&#xA;  online Graduate School application. It is important that you include&#xA;  all advanced mathematics courses you have completed, are currently&#xA;  enrolled in, or intend to take...&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;7) Three letters that address the question of mathematical promise.&#xA;  These letters should be from mathematics faculty, or other faculty&#xA;  familiar with the demands of graduate work in mathematics...&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now keep in mind that any published outlines are a &quot;wishlist&quot;, and they don't automatically toss anyone. But every area you don't fit requires explanation or some other counter-balancing factor. Some programs give a list of x requirements, then say they'll waive 1-2 of them without further explanation needed, etc.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you are missing all of these, then you need to look at a different program, but you might find no program that's a fit. If this happens, that doesn't mean you can't do something, just that you might have to go about it sideways or backtrack a bit.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you are missing just a few things, like a course or two, some programs have probation where they'll tentatively admit you on the demand you complete X courses on your first semester and get at least Y GPA, etc. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Alternatively, you might need to make arrangements to take advanced math courses at an undergrad/graduate level. It's harder to get financial aid for this sort of thing (you can't qualify for a Pell grant anymore, etc), but you can still get loans or pay for it outright. If you need this route, you need to talk personally with professors in advance to discuss what your goals are and make any possible arrangement to do extra work, write an academic research paper, etc. You need to find people you can have enough contact with to be willing to go to bat for you in writing strong reference letters if you don't already have math professors who are familiar with your past work. Join math clubs, go to math study labs, volunteer, whatever you can manage.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Before you go running off and doing any of this, however, you should make contact with math faculty at your present school and/or at a target school, and get an opportunity to talk with them about what you want to do and get their advice. Sometimes just showing &quot;mathematical promise&quot; can get a magic wand waived over your application, which maybe you already have - but only someone familiar with what you've done can tell you that. If you have a piece of mathematical &quot;best work&quot; from your most advanced class, bring it with you to such a meeting.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Once you've gotten a few honest appraisals of where you stand, be kind to yourself in looking for programs that will fit YOU, not some imaginary ideal program for someone else.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Finally, one last piece of advice. Keep your mind open to hybrid possibilities. There are whole fields of study you might really like that you aren't aware of, including applied mathematics study offered by business schools, economic fields that emphasize mathematical theory and/or application, etc.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Sometimes we have to try to mold ourselves to fit an existing mold a little better, but sometimes its trying to fit a square peg into a round hole. Talk to people and investigate the possibilities, get a clearer understanding of your relative shape, and seek out openings with geometry congruent to yours. Good luck in your journey!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10101" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10101" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>

In my first year of studies, I didn't do really well on my exams and therefore my results were not good, with a GPA at around 2. I didn't really put time into it, but when I started learning advanced probability, I found that I am interested in it and want to study more and am even thinking of doing research. Also I think I have found my way to study math as I didn't quite do before. In that semester, I got 2 A+. In my school, I heard that people who apply for a master's degree normally have a first-class honors degree. <answer QuestionId="Is there other way to get into more advanced study of math with a low GPA" AnswerId="hv2rhl/tVqXULK7Ybpi9DQ==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-20T15:34:37.230" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;Admissions committees (at least in the US) are generally forgiving of low grades in your first year, especially if you (and your recommendation letters) tell a compelling story about hitting your groove/finding your passion for the material in your second year.  Keep your grades up, &lt;strong&gt;get some undergraduate research experience&lt;/strong&gt;, and you'll be fine.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Resources for English speaking students with poor command of grammar and writing style" AnswerId="PmFCXlHjayff7H+QBAEfAg==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-20T10:17:53.867" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I know that this can be the source of great frustration for teachers, especially when they do not teach writing. However, writing is one of those things, like other communication skills, that I think we all need to teach (at least a little bit) if for no other reason that our students will fail if they cannot compose a well-reasoned essay, even if they understand the material from our subject quite well.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are plenty of universities which provide very good source material for this. &lt;a href=&quot;http://writingcenter.unc.edu/faculty-resources/tips-on-teaching-writing/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Here is one from the US&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.phrasebank.manchester.ac.uk/index.htm&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Here is one from the UK&lt;/a&gt;. I have used materials from both (and many others) but I do not find that I can simply point the students to these sites and expect everything to work out.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As educators, sometimes we need to teach things which are more fundamental in nature. Unless your school has a 'writing center' so you can direct students there for help (my school does not). I find I need to spend 1-2 hours per semester to cover core writing issues.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">
