academia.stackexchange.com_10088	<question QuestionId="How often do techniquesmethods that are considered old or obsolete become relevant again" Title="How often do techniquesmethods that are considered old or obsolete become relevant again" Views="163" Tags="research,methodology" " AnswerId="Vy7LFJt7ZRjtqfHQCn1ovg==" Author="5674" Date="2013-05-20T09:34:32.010" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;In many, if not most, disciplines methods age, get old and eventually become more or less obsolete, in the sense that some other method perhaps using a different technology becomes common-practice for a particular type of experimentation. One such example could be Edman sequencing, which used to be &lt;em&gt;the&lt;/em&gt; method for sequencing peptides, but is pretty much outdated nowadays, not because it does not work, but because it's costly in time and labor.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In my experience, these old/obsolete techniques are taught both at Masters and PhD level, primarily to give a deep understanding of the field, albeit being more theory than practice. &lt;em&gt;Are there any other benefits in learning/studying older methods, rather than only studying the state-of-the-art?&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I was wondering how often, if at all, such old methodologies come back (perhaps following a breakthrough in overcoming some original limitation) and regain popularity. &lt;em&gt;Are there known examples?&lt;/em&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As a follow-up; is such change in methodologies a phenomenon observed in experimental research, or are there equivalent scenarios in theoretical research as well? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

I guess the point is that you will never know in general what may be truly obsolete./>
<comment QuestionId="How often do techniquesmethods that are considered old or obsolete become relevant again" AnswerId="Vy7LFJt7ZRjtqfHQCn1ovg==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-20T14:30:19.160" Text="In regards to _a breakthrough in overcoming some original limitation_ I suspect there are some old manual methodologies which would have been replaced by a faster manual methodology which could now be useful again with advances in technology (for example, computers). Therefore, I think learning the _old stuff_ can be important; if not now, it might become important later./>

<answer QuestionId="How often do techniquesmethods that are considered old or obsolete become relevant again" AnswerId="xFjG+jcNbvpWbSy6JT6buQ==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-21T20:03:14.457" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;There are some important examples of techniques and problems being &quot;revived&quot; after having lain dormant for many years. For instance, in my own field, one of the cornerstones of computer modeling was originally derived in the 1920's, and then basically remained undeveloped until the 1970's, when it was brought back in fashion. (It has since been replaced by faster methods, but it is still regarded as the &quot;touchstone&quot; for high-accuracy calculations.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Similarly, entire fields of research may have been developed before the applications caught up with them. Again, bringing up an example from my own field of research, the class of materials known as &lt;em&gt;ionic liquids&lt;/em&gt; was known as far back as the early 1900's, but again were forgotten until the 1990's (or so) when they were &quot;rediscovered&quot; because they were nonvolatile materials and could be used as replacement solvents in the chemical industry. (It also offered the ability to do &quot;combinatorial chemistry,&quot; which was also coming into fashion.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;THe point of these examples is that sometimes theoretical and even experimental techniques may be developed in one era, but the ability to exploit the technology to its fullest extent has not yet been attained. Keeping awareness of such methods thus can have some use. Whether it should be taught to every student of a field is a different issue. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10148" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10148" Date="2013-06-05T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10089	<question QuestionId="Getting in between another teacher and his student" Title="Getting in between another teacher and his student" Views="616" Tags="teaching,workplace" " AnswerId="gBoPE/CXRtpqtsQzrVpayw==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-20T10:07:46.733" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;One subject I teach is also taught by another teacher at my university. Usually we do not both teach this subject during the same semester but sometimes we do. Students do not get to choose their teacher, the are assigned into one class or the other.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This has introduced a strange dynamic in that some of the other teacher's students have come to me asking for information about the subject, since they know I also teach it. So far, I've been quite hesitant to answer any such questions because I am worried about getting in between the other teacher and his students. I can imagine that I might have an answer that is different than the other teacher (perhaps my answer is wrong, perhaps my answer is right, and perhaps both of us are right but we have different ways of looking at a problem). The issue is compounded by the fact that I am from the West but the other teacher is Asian so there are cultural issues at play here (and I'm in Asia so it's not my culture).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I imagine this would be less of an issue in subjects like math where there is a specific formula but in management subjects the perspective of the teacher can change things significantly, especially if one teacher might be less strong in the subject than the other.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, what should a teacher in this situation do? Refer the student to their teacher? If they feel they cannot get an acceptable answer then refer them to a search engine? Should I jump in if they feel they are lost and their teacher is not helping them understand (this seems like it could cause serious problems, even if handled well)?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Getting in between another teacher and his student" AnswerId="gBoPE/CXRtpqtsQzrVpayw==" Author="5674" Date="2013-05-20T10:55:53.027" Text="I do not teach so I am not coming from a personal experience, but have you tried to express your confusion or hesitation to your colleague/fellow teacher over a cup of coffee or in a similar (read: casual) atmosphere? He/she might have some insight as to how to handle that situation, besides then you'd have you'd be out in the open with it./>
<comment QuestionId="Getting in between another teacher and his student" AnswerId="gBoPE/CXRtpqtsQzrVpayw==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-21T08:48:41.423" Text="@scaaahu Yes, we both teach in English./>

<answer QuestionId="Getting in between another teacher and his student" AnswerId="2ogQfyWdodihiqsCRjZOmw==" Author="3859" Date="2013-05-20T13:54:49.093" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;[Edit]&lt;/strong&gt; I'm assuming the questions asked are not ones where there is a consensus about the answers. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here's the advice I give to students who come to me from the another instructors of the courses I also teach (sometimes the other instructors are teaching assistants): The person grading your exams is the other instructor, therefore it's in your best interest to get the answers from the other instructor. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The answer sounds perhaps like we're brushing off the student, but if we contradict the other instructor, it won't help the student. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Put yourself in the shoes of the other instructor. What if a student answered an exam question according to advice from the other instructor, but out of context, or according to another perspective. How would you grade it if you disagreed with the answer or point of view?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I teach software analysis and design at an undergrad level. Some students rarely come to class and answer questions based on analysis or design methods they used before. Some get upset when I qualify all questions &quot;according to the process learned in class&quot; because they can't write any old answer from their past experience. One instructor's style or method could be different (not necessarily wrong). But much of the evaluation in a course is based on what the student learned in that course.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Getting in between another teacher and his student" AnswerId="2ogQfyWdodihiqsCRjZOmw==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-20T15:25:24.830" Text="Maybe this is a cultural difference, but _even if_ the grading criteria are subjective, I don't see any harm in telling students &quot;Here is _my_ perspective, but be warned that your instructor's may be different.&quot;/>
<comment QuestionId="Getting in between another teacher and his student" AnswerId="2ogQfyWdodihiqsCRjZOmw==" Author="3859" Date="2013-05-20T15:21:57.923" Text="@JeffE If it were a question about the complexity of a sorting algorithm, I'd answer. If it's a question about how to find domain objects from requirements (use cases), that's not so black and white. There is no consensus on what is the best way. I see this as the same problem in Management style discussed by the OP./>
<comment QuestionId="Getting in between another teacher and his student" AnswerId="2ogQfyWdodihiqsCRjZOmw==" Author="3859" Date="2013-05-20T15:40:14.593" Text="@JeffE Not a bad way to qualify an answer. However, I have had a few students who will invest huge energy to exploit contradictions between instructors for full &quot;drama&quot; potential, with complaints to department chairs, etc. I have seen it happen with colleagues, and had it happen to me early on when TAs or lab instructors are in contradiction. The students aren't always motivated in seeking the truth, but rather seeking maximum points./>
<comment QuestionId="Getting in between another teacher and his student" AnswerId="2ogQfyWdodihiqsCRjZOmw==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-20T15:44:43.237" Text="That's why you need the warning (and a supportive department chair)./>
<comment QuestionId="Getting in between another teacher and his student" AnswerId="2ogQfyWdodihiqsCRjZOmw==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-20T15:17:56.820" Text="This attitude seems very strange to me.  I agree with the reminder that the other instructor's judgment is the one that counts, but that doesn't justify not answering the student's questions.  Hearing multiple perspectives on the same  material is a _good_ thing for the students.  _What if a student answered an exam question... according to another perspective?_  If their answer is correct? **Extra credit!!**/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10097" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Getting in between another teacher and his student" AnswerId="5hv05ZcQx526OJxdeEjP1g==" Author="4461" Date="2013-05-20T11:33:19.543" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;My first question is, why are you (the faculty) both teaching the same class at the same university without talking to each other?  I can understand the cultural differences, but this is even more of a reason to talk to your colleague about the class!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would suggest (as posdef does in his comment) to talk to the other instructor about the class, offer to have him sit in on your class, and ask about collaboration.  You could also ask to sit in on his class if you'd like, but you need to be careful to phrase your request so it is clear that you're there to gain insight into his class and not to provide criticism.  I can't tell from your comment, &quot;...if one teacher might be less strong in the subject than the other&quot; if you believe he is the weak one or if you are, but regardless, you can both learn from each other.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Finally, it is in the best interest of both classes of students that you collaborate with the other instructor -- if both courses are listed as the same in the course catalog, the students should be able to expect that the class will cover roughly the same material.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Getting in between another teacher and his student" AnswerId="FP9Xp/RvhdaRD5K36jJIiA==" Author="546" Date="2013-05-22T04:37:12.840" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;You mentioned you’re from the West teaching in Asia. The school invited you from the West to teach while they already have instructors who can teach the same subject. I would think they all want to learn from you. Here, &lt;em&gt;they&lt;/em&gt; are not only the students but also the faculty.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As posdef suggested in his comment, I would talk to the other instructor in some kind of informal meetings if I were you. You can talk to him about the class, the students and the department. You two are teaching the same course. There must be a lot of things you can share. In particular, you can ask him exactly this question and see what kind of solutions he would recommend. I think he would have a more insightful answer than most users on this site because he is in the same environment as you are.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Whether or not the other instructor is willing to talk to you is another issue. From what I know, most Asians are nice to the guests. If you are  there for a tenure track position, he might see you as a competition. Then I think you should handle this matter in a formal manner. If you are not there on a permanent basis, I think informal meetings would be enough.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The most important thing is, what is the best interests for the students? Many Asian students believe there is always only one standard correct answer for every question. We know this is not always the case. Even for math related subjects, you can have multiple approaches to solve a problem. I suspect the students from the other class came to you to confirm the answer given by their instructor is the standard one. If that’s the case, you and the other instructor need to coordinate. Both need to explain to the students that there may not be only one standard answer per every question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If the students came to you because they doubt their instructor or they don't get acceptable answers, you need to handle this with care. Respecting the teachers is an integral part of Asian culture. However, the best interests for the students is even more important. Talking to the other instructor in person is the first step to resolve this issue. You two together need to figure out how to tell the students the correct answers. Again, learning together is everybody’s goal.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10151" Date="2013-05-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10151" Date="2013-05-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10151" Date="2013-05-22T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_1009	<question QuestionId="Can American students do research in Europe with only a bachelors degree" Title="Can American students do research in Europe with only a bachelors degree" Views="289" Tags="research,hiring,international" " AnswerId="BHB2nJNzaR6Km1rtJFGULQ==" Author="53" Date="2012-04-04T23:04:30.803" Score="10" Text="&lt;p&gt;It's not clear to me, looking over all the various regulations and requirements, how (or even &lt;em&gt;if&lt;/em&gt;) it is possible for students holding a four-year or five-year bachelor's degree from the US can work at a university as a part-time or full-time researcher. Is this possible? If so, are there specific programs to help set this up? Does it matter which EU country the institution is located? Is there a specific type of visa involved?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(Effectively, I guess this question could be boiled down to: what is the equivalent EU mechanism for a &lt;a href=&quot;http://j1visa.state.gov/&quot;&gt;J-1 visa&lt;/a&gt;, when the student will be engaged in research rather than coursework?)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Can American students do research in Europe with only a bachelors degree" AnswerId="kTHvhEYVrnz9oReIEJfadw==" Author="102" Date="2012-04-05T09:09:24.803" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I think there are two parts in your question: can someone with a Bachelor from the US get a job from a university or research lab, and what kind of visa such a person would need. For the first question, it's really depending on the university. As for the visa, it depends if it would be for a PhD student, or for a &quot;regular&quot; researcher (i.e. not a student). However, in both cases, the visa application depends on the country, as far as I know, there is no Schengen Research Visa. For instance, for France, there are two types of Visa the person could apply to (&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.consulfrance-washington.org/spip.php?rubrique98&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Visa section of the french consulate in Washington&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.consulfrance-washington.org/spip.php?article519&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;The “Skills and Talent” Card visa (Carte Compétences &amp;amp; Talents)&lt;/a&gt;. However, for this one, they say: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;University graduates should be PhD. Lower graduates will be required to add proof of profesionnal experience in the same field for a minimum of 1 to 3 years (the lower the degree, the longer profesionnal experience expected) &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.consulfrance-washington.org/spip.php?article398&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Visas for professors and researchers holders of a &quot;convention d’accueil&quot;&lt;/a&gt;. According to this &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.fnak.fr/dn_Formalites/ES_criteres_eligibilite.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;site&lt;/a&gt; (in French, I couldn't find an English version), a &quot;convention d'accueil&quot; would basically be the work contract with the university/lab, and the eligibility requirement seems to be a Master degree or equivalent (but it could be the case that a 5-years US Bachelor degree counts as an equivalent to a 5-year French Master degree). As far as I understand, that would be the best option for someone who wants to do her PhD in France. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It would also be possible to apply for a student visa, but I think it's not possible to get a work contract with such a visa. Another solution could be to apply to a:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.consulfrance-washington.org/spip.php?article500&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt; Employer Sponsored visa / OFII&lt;/a&gt;. There does not seem to be anything specific to research in this case. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, to sum it up, I don't think there is a unified process to apply for a visa in Europe as a researcher, and each country has its own rules. Note that these visas are not automatically Schengen visa, and I've known the case of some extra-EU students, who obtained a visa in one Schengen country, and were not allowed to travel in other Schengen countries before becoming officially resident of the country. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1016" Date="2012-04-05T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10096	<question QuestionId="How to replicate others results quickly" Title="How to replicate others results quickly" Views="193" Tags="time-management,reproducible-research" " AnswerId="35LhgTEVA6EjIwil/h5euw==" Author="931" Date="2013-05-20T13:48:19.510" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;Lately, I've been getting the impression that before I can conduct cutting edge research, I have to first master state of the art methods/techniques.  Often, this requires spending (i.e. wasting) lots of time trying to replicate the results that others have already established (i.e. make sure that I can do what others have done first before moving on to other territory).  When I try to master a new technique, I often find that it is extremely difficult because&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Research papers don't seem to disclose enough details to replicate their results easily.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;There are no advisors/colleagues that are familiar with these methods&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Emailing the corresponding authors with questions about specific details about their research tend to go unanswered.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The only advice i've been given thus far is simply to read and re-read the research paper and dissect every little detail until I figure it out.  But are there any other general strategies I can use to replicate others' results more quickly?  In particular, I'm looking for strategies for replicating numerical results that require very careful implementations of mathematical algorithms.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to replicate others results quickly" AnswerId="35LhgTEVA6EjIwil/h5euw==" Author="49" Date="2013-05-21T00:07:21.290" Text="As a side note, it is why a publication based on numerics but without (attached or linked) working code shouldn't be consider real science.../>
<comment QuestionId="How to replicate others results quickly" AnswerId="35LhgTEVA6EjIwil/h5euw==" Author="285" Date="2013-05-20T14:57:22.927" Text="I've been in the same boat, as I'm sure many people have. Personally, if I can't get hold of the code, I don't attempt a reimplementation. For something non-trivial, it takes too long, and life is too short. Also, as you said, 1-3 apply. Certainly, 1 and 3 seem to apply nearly all the time. I'm tempted to ask another question along the lines of &quot;is it reasonable to be expected to duplicate another's research if no implementation and not enough detail is provided&quot;?/>
<comment QuestionId="How to replicate others results quickly" AnswerId="35LhgTEVA6EjIwil/h5euw==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-20T15:27:49.673" Text="That is **not** wasting time.  Hopefully this painful process teaches you, among other things, to write your own papers/code better than the papers/code you're trying to replicate./>

<answer QuestionId="How to replicate others results quickly" AnswerId="pPSLtfGtrTVu/dnKvmVzQw==" Author="669" Date="2013-05-20T19:42:48.433" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;The fact that you can't quickly and effortlessly do this is &lt;em&gt;exactly why this is not wasting lots of time&lt;/em&gt;, assuming that you do in fact mean to build upon this very same research.  You're learning how to solve problems in this arena, given an outline that you know works, but insufficient detail to actually implement it fully.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Other than that, for numerical results you simply need to do lots of testing to make sure at each stage the calculation comes out to be what you expect (and tests any important corner cases).  For example, if something's piecewise polynomial, and you drop three points at random into every piece, and it's accurate to within machine precision, you've almost surely got it right, and if it's not you've almost surely got it wrong.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now, once you're already well-versed in a field, you may write a paper which referees want you to compare to some other new result in the field.  Replicating someone else's poorly-described new methods really &lt;em&gt;can&lt;/em&gt; be a waste of time; you don't learn anything except that they left out a lot of fiddly details.  (Editors may be sympathetic and let you skip it or e.g. use a common dataset instead.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10113" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10113" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10113" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10113" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How to replicate others results quickly" AnswerId="aHwn0asD08saDGvFCcw2YQ==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-21T09:46:13.060" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I must agree with the answers posted above - it most certainly not a waste of time at all - my current supervisor explained to me that in a way, it is analogous to the saying &quot;Learning to walk, before you can run&quot; - if you can master what has been researched before, particularly learning the methodologies used - then you would have a greater chance of improving these methods and potentially further refining the results.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, consider that when the papers don't give much away, that this is a prime opportunity to develop your problem solving skills within the field that you are researching.  I am doing the same, with a unique Android app as part of my research, I am entirely self taught from learning how other apps work.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Don't give up - keep on persevering, it is worth it!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10133" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How to replicate others results quickly" AnswerId="k9e3Nky9q8BMqxc1/UHeGA==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-20T22:02:46.727" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;As JeffE points out, trying to reproduce existing results before embarking on new endeavors is &lt;strong&gt;not&lt;/strong&gt; a waste of time. It can be particularly useful, especially in tracking down issues that you have within your own code—or, perhaps, in the existing literature. My most-cited paper, and much of the research work currently ongoing within my group, came about precisely because I could &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; replicate an existing paper. As it turned out, there were some significant methodological problems in the existing literature, and this led to a fair bit of digging around, plus a lot of careful analysis to demonstrate what had happened and why. As I've also said, the issues we uncovered there indirectly led to a different line of inquiry that has already led to half a dozen additional manuscripts.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you are determined to speed up the process, however, you might try to consider simplified versions of the research cases presented that can validate what you're working on. For instance, can you find a &quot;prototype&quot; problem whose solution would be known with your method as well as the existing methods? Can you find one or two test cases which can test most of what you're looking for? Can you devise a new problem that compares the two better than the existing cases, and is also simpler to execute?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10123" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10123" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10123" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10123" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10123" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10123" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10123" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_101	<question QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" Title="How do you judge the quality of a journal" Views="3049" Tags="journals,publishing,reputation" " AnswerId="69jtPWbi0v9pL8BpMLaGFw==" Author="48" Date="2012-02-15T14:08:48.843" Score="64" Text="&lt;p&gt;A colleague and I recently submitted a paper to a journal with an impressive-sounding name, the &quot;International Journal of Artificial Intelligence and Computational Research&quot;. According to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.serialspublications.com/journals1.asp?jid=224&quot;&gt;their website&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;IJAICR is a referred [sic] journal in the field of computer science, artificial intelligence and soft computing methods.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It was accepted two days after we submitted it. That's too fast. We were suspicious. Although the journal said that all papers are peer-reviewed, we could not see how that was done in two days. Plus, we received no comments from the reviewers. Also, the submission guidelines didn't ask for a &quot;blind&quot; copy (without our names or any references to who we were). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But wait, there's more.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The acceptance letter asked us to send them US$300 to publish it. We did not. We've withdrawn our submission and will submit a new version of the paper to a more reputable journal in the coming months.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;How might we make a better choice of respectable journals before we submit next time?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="69jtPWbi0v9pL8BpMLaGFw==" Author="81" Date="2012-02-15T17:06:12.420" Text="I think this question is really about how to recognize &quot;vanity press&quot;.  Judging quality among respectable journals is a completely different question./>

This happenned to me and I only found out after I had been asked to pay a publication fee of $200. The review was also suspicously glowing and took only two weeks. The paper was accepted without modification. Very suspicious but very deflating after the intial excitement./>

<answer QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="+bd0cyCZgPtdldSm8BLJ3Q==" Author="94" Date="2012-02-15T14:43:30.130" Score="25" Text="&lt;p&gt;The best way is by word-of-mouth: ask around the department, ask your PhD advisor, ask people you've worked with. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If it is a specialist journal, and you are a specialist, then the next best way is to look at the previously published issues of the journal and see what kinds of articles they accept. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Failing that, the Australian Government's Research Council puts out a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.arc.gov.au/era/era_2012/era_journal_list.htm&quot;&gt;ranking of journals and conferences&lt;/a&gt; every now and then. It is not perfect, but should give a rough idea of where a journal places in the eyes of the bureaucrats &lt;code&gt;:-)&lt;/code&gt;. Note that &quot;new&quot; journals (journals that have not been active for more than X years) are not ranked, so omission from the list does not necessarily mean that the journal itself is not worthwhile. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="TtT46lS49fVdGV1mBbtchA==" Author="66" Date="2012-02-15T14:49:03.493" Score="70" Text="&lt;p&gt;The way I usually choose journals is by looking at where people I trust/follow publish, and where previous work was published. It is usually not too hard to compare the quality your work to the quality of the work you are citing, and chose a target based on that. Unless your field is highly mutli-disciplinary, you will see the same journals/conferences popping up again and again in your references; submit to one of those.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Before submitting, however, it is always important to look at a few articles from previous issues. This will give you a second gauge of quality for the journal and also let you pick up on any formatting and presentations quirks that might be present in the publication.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="TtT46lS49fVdGV1mBbtchA==" Author="284" Date="2012-02-26T08:17:27.000" Text="agree completely with that/>

<answer QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="cYqnbA5lJ6J3QfoU1R+XCw==" Author="43" Date="2012-02-15T14:49:21.167" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;First of all, I look at the publisher. If you don' find a lot of references to the publisher on the web, it is suspicious.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Then, I look at the editor in chief, and at the board of editors. If you don't find many big names here, this is again very suspicious.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Finally, google the journal name and look who is publishing in the journal. Most of the time it becomes clear if the journal is serious or not.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="tXody5bWL+ptVzDstunQBg==" Author="2700" Date="2012-11-12T10:03:02.750" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'm surprised nobody mentioned this yet, so I'm adding it as a separate answer:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Read some articles from the journal (in your subfield), and see how they feel like&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When you look at a journal and check that the 5 or 6 latest articles in your domain are of the &lt;em&gt;meh&lt;/em&gt; type, you probably don't want to publish there. If they make you feel &lt;em&gt;“oh, I never quite thought of that, it's clever… I see how I may use it”&lt;/em&gt;, go for it!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="OtawLq96kGuF6DrAwsJLGQ==" Author="324" Date="2012-11-12T09:10:00.373" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.journal-ranking.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Journal Ranking site (www.journal-ranking.com)&lt;/a&gt; aims to rank many (11K) journals, according to their measure of impact (mainly number of citation, but weighted according to the ranking of the citing journal), number of articles, etc. It also let you sort by field.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But again, this is only their point of view, and their way of measuring quality.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(and it only ranks journals listed in the ISI's SCI)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="LFW0LAi63eOSiOR1XwWfkw==" Author="25" Date="2012-02-17T06:46:10.530" Score="13" Text="&lt;p&gt;For some hard data I like &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.eigenfactor.org/&quot;&gt;eigenfactor&lt;/a&gt;, because I think there methodology makes a lot of sense.  The default settings are a bit odd, you want the AI score not EF score.  I also like the &quot;eigenfactor category&quot; under advanced search better than the &quot;ISI category&quot; that you can get on the main page.  Certainly it's better to have a more in-depth understanding, but also sometimes you just want a quick ballpark guesstimate of how good the journal is, and eigenfactor does that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="y6RsqWZefUlJACZrNPK3VA==" Author="6928" Date="2013-05-31T09:30:38.813" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;You can test them yourself. This procedure will speed up by your experience. There are signs during submission and during review which shows which journal is really good and which is not. But there is another way too: look at the objective information below. It is possible to judge a journal based on the COLLECTIVE information you obtain from these factors:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Their editorial. You don't know them? Ok pass to the next ones.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Their publishing country (India? no thanks unless the paper is not good or the journal is an exception).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Their publisher (yes good publishers usually select good journals, although some weak journals with a lot of money can again hire a good publisher)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The time passes since you submit and they respond&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The above factor SHOULD be considered along with the amount of manuscript they receive. Good journals receive thousands of manuscript a year, but still do not waste authors' time by keeping them waiting for too long before a rejection decision. Bad journals receive sporadic manuscripts and keep the authors wait for months until they tell the author their decision. It is a pain when you see some of them have &quot;lost&quot; you paper, or some of them reject your paper with a couple of lines of comment, after 6 months. Good journals do the same in less than 24 hours.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Indexing databases. Look where the journal is indexed in. ISI Web of Science? Medline? or what? The scam journals usually are not indexed in any accredited databases (not Google Scholar or Scopus). If a journal is accepted to be indexed in ISI or to a lesser degree, Medline, it is unlikely to be able to have low quality. Otherwise, ISI would have booted them out. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are other factors too. But these will give you 90% insight already.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10338" Date="2013-05-31T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10338" Date="2013-12-09T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10338" Date="2014-05-01T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="wM5nx+DI1zJ4yovGl/mtkg==" Author="587" Date="2012-04-05T08:38:49.320" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Look at the journals responsible for the references you cite in your own manuscript. Upside, these are the journals publishing relevant and credible work in your area.  Downside, there are plenty perfectly good journals that are newer, or less specialized, and so might be missed.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;BTW, a very fast review time with no reviews is suspicious.  But charging an article processing charge (APC) is not, in itself, a reason for worry.  That said, do look to see that you are getting the full open access you pay for if there is an APC (i.e. no transfer of copyright to the publisher and the article is released under a CC-BY license).  You can search for copyright policies by journal or publisher here: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sherpa.ac.uk/romeo/&quot;&gt;http://www.sherpa.ac.uk/romeo/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="GE1UZNfYRq1aEOrUhQXtZg==" Author="9838" Date="2013-12-05T19:42:07.633" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Generally, the scientific specialists' communities have traditionally identified journals having high editorial standards. That is the key: who are the editors and what are the standards. Are the breakthrough discoveries sent to that journal? From that, reputations are built and filtered down to preference and use by the community.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="ItECzCDDo36fT1XBenFi2g==" Author="7930" Date="2013-12-12T21:40:29.807" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I think that &quot;quality&quot; is a bit overrated, and that you should think most deeply about &quot;fit&quot; (i.e., how well your content matches the interests of a journal's reviewers and readership).  With that said, when I'm looking for the best journal to put an article, I have three methods:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Look at my cites for similar work to my manuscript, then look at where they published (similar to Artem's comment).  If your paper isn't citing related work, well... it probably has a pretty terrible lit review.  If you're citing sources out of your league for that paper (i.e., Science, Nature), find the publication list for that lab to find their fallback journals.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Ask greybeards I collaborate with where they would publish such a paper.  Good senior academics have a huge amount of expertise about the social networks and publishing networks in their fields.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Use journal rankings.  I find  &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.scimagojr.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Scimago&lt;/a&gt; to be the most convenient.  That also charts things like cites/paper over time, so you can see if a newer journal is growing or stagnant.  The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.arc.gov.au/era/era_2012/era_journal_list.htm&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Austrialian Research Counsel&lt;/a&gt; (mentioned by Willy Wong) is probably my #2 resource.  Thompson's ISI stuff is also useful, but I've found it sometimes has glaring omissions and has been less convenient to me (annoying to log in).  Conferences are harder to rank using indices.  &lt;a href=&quot;http://scholar.google.com/citations?view_op=top_venues&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Google&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://academic.research.microsoft.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Microsoft&lt;/a&gt; have ranking systems that catch those pretty well, at least for comparing citations within a topic.  However, given the choice, I'd still go with option #1 or #2.  I mainly use this approach for interdisciplinary research that doesn't have an obvious, natural target journal.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="14725" Date="2013-12-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="14725" Date="2014-01-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="14725" Date="2014-02-13T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="14725" Date="2013-12-30T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="ajWAjM+BwpZ/seM01V02wg==" Author="81" Date="2012-02-15T17:08:09.247" Score="54" Text="&lt;p&gt;You may want to check that the publisher is not on &lt;strong&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://scholarlyoa.com/individual-journals/&quot;&gt;Beall's List of Predatory, Open-Access Publishers&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Surprisingly, the publisher in question is not.  I've found Beall's list to be fairly comprehensive, but the vanity press industry seems to be booming.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Caveat: that list is just one guy's opinion.  But it resonates with my own experience.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="8T8g8uWB9DWNpUlzDbfXKQ==" Author="64" Date="2012-03-07T10:06:32.767" Score="21" Text="&lt;p&gt;&quot;How do you judge the quality of a journal?&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One answer is already known to you:  Submit a paper to it and see how it responds.  I once submitted a few papers to an online journal (no print equivalent) and the referee reports that I got clearly showed that they read and understood the paper and that they knew the subject well.  They even suggested ways how the paper could be improved.  The quality of the referees reflect the quality of the journal.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="8T8g8uWB9DWNpUlzDbfXKQ==" Author="141" Date="2012-08-19T08:46:43.497" Text="@LVK That's a fair point./>
<comment QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="8T8g8uWB9DWNpUlzDbfXKQ==" Author="1460" Date="2012-08-14T21:35:01.140" Text="I disagree with @Speldosa. All you know on the basis of one submission is that the journal has at least one editor who picked good referees for at least one paper. Another half of editors could be accepting junk for all you know. Multiple submissions increase the odds that your conclusion is correct, but is not this an extremely expensive experiment to undertake, given that you are paying with your research output? Especially when you have a lot of observational data already available: other papers published in the journal./>
<comment QuestionId="How do you judge the quality of a journal" AnswerId="8T8g8uWB9DWNpUlzDbfXKQ==" Author="141" Date="2012-06-24T09:21:40.163" Text="IMHO, this is the best answer here, even though you don't really have time to go through the process of testing every journal you might be interested of. However, if the peer-review process is good, then the journal is good. End of story./>

academia.stackexchange.com_1010	<question QuestionId="What preparatory steps should I be taking for admission into med school" Title="What preparatory steps should I be taking for admission into med school" Views="168" Tags="graduate-admissions" " AnswerId="eF+ljp2du4/AtUmWP6kelg==" Author="581" Date="2012-04-04T23:25:19.533" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;I've been maintaining a great GPA in a specialization undergraduate program, am planning on taking the MCAT this summer, and have been looking into some volunteering/internship opportunities. Are there any other special precautions that I should be taking to increase the likelihood of my acceptance into med school? Are med schools looking for anything in particular for admissions? An all-encompassing, comprehensive answer would be appreciated, but any advice or tips are appreciated :).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What preparatory steps should I be taking for admission into med school" AnswerId="eF+ljp2du4/AtUmWP6kelg==" Author="65" Date="2012-05-10T06:44:24.043" Text="Upvoted.  This is a straightforward question about admission to a post-graduate academic program; I think it's perfectly in scope.  Whether we lack the expertise to give a useful answer is a separate issue./>

<answer QuestionId="What preparatory steps should I be taking for admission into med school" AnswerId="vgLlW6LtMWrtxfY/plg3mw==" Author="73" Date="2012-05-10T14:22:24.907" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Speaking from (1) experience applying and talking to applications officers, and (2) knowing doctors who take part in the admissions process, I would suggest that the ideal medical student would appear as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Any major, but very high grades in all pre-med courses&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Very high MCAT score&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Experience working in a hospital &lt;em&gt;or&lt;/em&gt; medical research lab, with demonstrated results (good recommendations from doctors and published papers, respectively)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Very personable during the interview, well-liked by all interviewers&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;None of these should be a surprise; they just want awesome, academic students.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10100	<question QuestionId="Using a software screenshot in a paper" Title="Using a software screenshot in a paper" Views="228" Tags="writing,copyright,software,graphics" " AnswerId="KShqXml7+gVJgJum0I+2gg==" Author="3969" Date="2013-05-20T15:53:10.640" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;When writing a paper which, as an aside, talks about the design of a user interface on a particular piece of software, can one insert a (correctly labeled and referenced) screenshot of the software to help readers understand - or does that cause copyright issues? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example, I wouldn't use a photo unless I held the copyright, or a diagram - but I'm unsure of the legal position of a screenshot...&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10100" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10100" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10100" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10100" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10100" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10100" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Using a software screenshot in a paper" AnswerId="6jFxQrFlhDpFftdrdEqFyw==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-20T16:01:22.923" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Definitely, but one major issue will be resolution. A screen shot will typically yield a very low resoluton image which for most journals will be too low (recommendations are ypically 300 dpi in the final published figure size, which is usually impossible to achieve with screenshots. I would therefore recommend to make use of any possibility to zoom the window and then make a screen shot of the window as large as possible on the screen. If you are designing your user interface as you state in the question you could consider making a mock-up of the interface that is identical in every respect but which is based on higher resolution graphics, vectorized or bitmap based. Since you have access to all the original graphics elemnts this should not be difficult.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Using a software screenshot in a paper" AnswerId="6jFxQrFlhDpFftdrdEqFyw==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-20T16:55:27.753" Text="I disagree.  Screenshots should be printed at normal screen resolution, so that they look as much as possible **like the screen**./>
<comment QuestionId="Using a software screenshot in a paper" AnswerId="6jFxQrFlhDpFftdrdEqFyw==" Author="6787" Date="2013-05-20T18:41:32.390" Text="As a former professional printer, I highly recommend printing out that page with screenshot from your doc or PDF on a regular printer and see how it looks. On an iMac with a 1920x1080 desktop resolution, the 300dpi equivalent of a full screenshot is a crisp 6.4 x 3.6 inch image. If one has access to Photoshop this is achieved by Image-&gt;Image Size, untick &quot;Resample Image&quot;, then set resolution to 300. The resulting dimensions is the non-resampled image size at press-quality resolution./>
<comment QuestionId="Using a software screenshot in a paper" AnswerId="6jFxQrFlhDpFftdrdEqFyw==" Author="4461" Date="2013-05-20T16:58:02.163" Text="I've found that including screenshots in papers at normal screen resolution works fine in a two-column format, simply because a figure in that format is pretty small to begin with, and because screen resolutions are decent these days.  The one caveat I have is that text can be unreadable unless the program has the ability to increase the font size./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10102" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Using a software screenshot in a paper" AnswerId="+W1SyF9fX4Cs1vjZB2Ehaw==" Author="5944" Date="2013-05-20T19:49:21.840" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;Generally yes, you're allowed to use screenshots that you create yourself.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Depending on the publisher, they might ask for copyright approvals on the screenshots.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I believe that, as long as you yourself created the screenshot, you're the owner of it (just as if you take a photograph of something, you hold the copyright, not the creator of whatever you're photographing), but this is still, I believe, a legal grey area.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As mentioned, be sure that you provide a proper citation to the software.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Using a software screenshot in a paper" AnswerId="A7JS7djJlg0aLiKoOPiO+Q==" Author="4461" Date="2013-05-20T16:35:17.297" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;If you're displaying the screenshot as part of a paper on user interface, the use of the screenshot will almost certainly fall under &quot;fair use.&quot;  Make sure you cite the software properly, and you should be all set.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Using a software screenshot in a paper" AnswerId="A7JS7djJlg0aLiKoOPiO+Q==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-20T18:13:45.713" Text="If there are restrictions, you can always ask for permission to include the screenshot in your paper!/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10105" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10105" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Using a software screenshot in a paper" AnswerId="P/2r+7JqkRgXdVaUkLn6kA==" Author="5962" Date="2013-05-20T21:53:38.083" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;The answer, like many copyright questions, is complicated.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;First, the images of the software interface is almost certainly copyrighted. As a result, the exclusive rights to reproduce images of the applicatoin lie with the copyright holder (i.e., the creator of the software.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;However&lt;/em&gt;, as another answer has suggested, the use of a single screenshot of an application should almost certainly qualify as &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fair_Use&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Fair Use&lt;/a&gt; under US copyright law or something similar and analogous under other systems. In other words, it's a small and relative inconsequential reproduction that you can do without having to ask for permission.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;However&lt;/em&gt;, fair use is notoriously tricky and subjective. there is a multi-prong balancing test at the heart of fair use that is complicated and that makes it hard to know for sure whether a use if fair or not. As a result, many journals are risk averse and will systematically block many types of &quot;probably fair&quot; uses. I've had difficult conversations with production staff members and editors about the use of software screenshots before.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would say go ahead and try to have the conversation with your journal editor or production staff. The worst thing they can do is ask you to take it out.   This, of course, is what you would do preemptively now if you choose not to include it in the first place.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10122" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10122" Date="2013-05-21T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10104	<question QuestionId="Where to upload a reprint (post-print) of my publication" Title="Where to upload a reprint (post-print) of my publication" Views="140" Tags="publishing,repository,self-archiving" " AnswerId="QhEQKWxMWenCI4OdTxMBqA==" Author="7135" Date="2013-05-20T16:29:34.143" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I used to self-archive papers on my homepage in the institute where I was doing phd. I just noticed that my homepage and the reprints were removed -- that's normal, I'm not working in that institute anymore.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I can legally self-archive these papers. For example, J. Appl. Cryst. &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.iucr.org/services/authorrights.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;allows authors&lt;/a&gt; to post reprints&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;on their own personal website, on their employer's website/repository&#xA;  and on free public servers in their subject area.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What are the best &quot;free public servers&quot; to upload electronic reprints?&#xA;(IIUC arXiv is for pre-prints rather than post-prints).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Where to upload a reprint (post-print) of my publication" AnswerId="QhEQKWxMWenCI4OdTxMBqA==" Author="612" Date="2013-05-20T20:07:22.890" Text="As Piotr says in his answer, arXiv is definitely not just for pre-prints (it's not even primarily intended for pre-prints).  The arXiv calls them &quot;e-prints&quot; to avoid the issue of whether they are preprints, although this name has not really caught on more broadly./>

So the point is on how it is easy for Google to find it and how  it is likely to stay for a longer time./>

<answer QuestionId="Where to upload a reprint (post-print) of my publication" AnswerId="CZ4n93uF8HIrJld9uRYJsg==" Author="49" Date="2013-05-20T19:56:38.633" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;arXiv&lt;/a&gt; is not only for preprints (actually, updating after publication is highly encouraged). So if you can self-archive*) &lt;em&gt;and&lt;/em&gt; you have an intersection with an arXiv discipline, it is the best place to place it. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;*) The only objection to post-publication is in case where you are not allowed to self-archive and don't wan't to mess with it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For other disciplines, see &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/84/preprint-services-other-than-arxiv-for-other-fields&quot;&gt;Preprint services other than arXiv (for other fields)&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Or (maybe even better) just - putting them on &lt;a href=&quot;http://github.com&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;GitHub&lt;/a&gt; repository. It is a stable service + makes it easy to upload work with source code (tex + figures) (much alike arXiv, but on GitHub it is more convenient). Just make sure to link the pdf file in the &lt;code&gt;README.md&lt;/code&gt; and reference it properly (i.e. the full citation, the best with a DOI link) so to have its status clear. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Where to upload a reprint (post-print) of my publication" AnswerId="CZ4n93uF8HIrJld9uRYJsg==" Author="49" Date="2013-05-20T20:08:30.913" Text="@FedericoPoloni Good point, I've removed the Figshare part. On GitHub it is you who set the license. Open source (i.e. source is visible) does not carry any license _per se_ (AFAIK). Posting PDF without source there, AFAIK, does not differ from posting it on your homepage./>
<comment QuestionId="Where to upload a reprint (post-print) of my publication" AnswerId="CZ4n93uF8HIrJld9uRYJsg==" Author="958" Date="2013-05-20T20:05:13.357" Text="I don't think this is legally allowed. The Figshare terms of service state that &quot;All publicly stored research outputs are stored under Creative Commons Licenses&quot;; he does not have enough rights left to publish under one. As for Github, I seem to recall that you can only publish open source code there, although I can't find anything specific on the ToS now. A post-published self-archived pdf surely is not open source./>
<comment QuestionId="Where to upload a reprint (post-print) of my publication" AnswerId="CZ4n93uF8HIrJld9uRYJsg==" Author="7135" Date="2013-05-21T16:02:33.750" Text="@PiotrMigdal: Thanks for your answer. I've put the papers on Github for now./>

<comment QuestionId="Where to upload a reprint (post-print) of my publication" AnswerId="CZ4n93uF8HIrJld9uRYJsg==" Author="49" Date="2013-05-20T20:27:13.683" Text="@FaheemMitha Most likely BitBucket is as good as GitHub for this purpose./>

But I haven't tested it in practice (maybe I should?). Do you have any arguments why it shouldn't take it (e.g. some `no-index`/`no-follow`?)./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10107	<question QuestionId="When should a student attempt unsupervised research" Title="When should a student attempt unsupervised research" Views="1236" Tags="phd,research,advisor,collaboration" " AnswerId="s+CvwDJcsBhhTRMjfOzDBw==" Author="1190" Date="2013-05-20T17:19:32.623" Score="21" Text="&lt;p&gt;I just finished my masters and am currently working as a research assistant before starting a PhD in applied mathematics. I was doing some preliminary work for a possible project and derived some minor results which I find interesting, but in the end, we decided not to go ahead with the project.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I still find the minor results interesting and thought of digging a little bit deeper by myself. However, since the group is no longer interested in this, I would have to do this by myself, unsupervised. Is this a very bad thing? Or a good learning experience?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I had a bad experience doing unsupervised research (wasted a lot of time for no results). However, I know that as a PhD student, I must eventually publish first-authored papers. How do I know when to make the switch?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="When should a student attempt unsupervised research" AnswerId="s+CvwDJcsBhhTRMjfOzDBw==" Author="49" Date="2013-05-20T18:11:14.473" Text="You can work with your advisor _and_ get a first-authored paper./>

<answer QuestionId="When should a student attempt unsupervised research" AnswerId="l7r4L1Xc4HJ4+koxTgvqrQ==" Author="7075" Date="2013-05-20T19:09:41.497" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;My former Ph.D. advisor's philosophy is that a student should become a teacher of their supervisor. He seems to give the green light when the student&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;explains their own research problem clearly,&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;shows a clear sign of familiarity with all relevant work,&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;puts their work in context,&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;gives a convincing argument about why it's important and interesting,&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;looks they can make it, and, somewhat more importantly,&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;chose a topic that isn't too unfashionable to the extent that devoting their time during their Ph.D. student phase to that kind of topic is a career suicide.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I wrote my first paper when I was a second year grad student, and my first joint paper with my  former Ph.D. supervisor is after I got my degree. My friend who got his Ph.D. from the same advisor at the same time as me was also like this, and he's doing pretty well in academia. So probably all that matters when it comes to starting your own math research is if you're ready for it. And if you're ready, I don't think your advisor can talk you out of it anyway. At least, randome guys on the internet like us surely can't.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, I'd say if you're being honest to yourself and still confident that you know about your research topic better than your advisor, and if you can get him interested in your research, it should be fine.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="When should a student attempt unsupervised research" AnswerId="xgk5tQTWWlW+g6JFbGFF8Q==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-21T09:39:57.630" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;Performing unsupervised research is also a great way to develop the self-discipline needed for a PhD and developing your own research strategies.  This time could be considered a valuable time for personal and academic growth.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10132" Date="2013-10-14T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10132" Date="2013-05-22T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="When should a student attempt unsupervised research" AnswerId="dZ3QVJdZvccGNzRPV7iOng==" Author="643" Date="2013-05-20T18:11:58.480" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;It is not necessarily a bad thing to forge ahead on your own and it will certainly be a learning experience. It is definitely a good thing to try this, because it will demonstrate and help reinforce that you are an independent researcher, something which you need to be at the end of your PhD studies.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But this is not without some &lt;strong&gt;risk&lt;/strong&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Part of the role of the supervision that would otherwise be provided is to improve your skills as a researcher and writer of scientific texts. Without this guidance, your skills at the end of your PhD may not be as good as they could be.  You may have gaps in your knowledge that would need to be filled. The presentation of scientific material in your writing may end up being suboptimal, because you won't have someone to proposed better ways of writing. And worse still, your ideas may not end up being the best they could be, because you won't have someone questioning them and your assumptions, ultimately forcing you to produce better versions of your ideas.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I've seen it before. Some highly independent students I've seen in action fail to follow recognised mathematical conventions, produce new notations for existing concepts, miss key references and lack understanding of key concepts that would help improve their work, and so on.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Independence is a good trait, but try to take advantage of opportunities to receive guidance from your supervisor(s) while you can.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="When should a student attempt unsupervised research" AnswerId="dZ3QVJdZvccGNzRPV7iOng==" Author="643" Date="2013-05-20T19:50:15.670" Text="@YuichiroFujiwara: You are right. It is a description of some highly independent students, not all of them. I reworded a little./>
<comment QuestionId="When should a student attempt unsupervised research" AnswerId="dZ3QVJdZvccGNzRPV7iOng==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-20T19:36:30.353" Text="The risk Dave describes comes more from **not working with your advisor** than from **working on something without your advisor**.  See the difference?  You can (perhaps even _should_) work independently on X while working with your advisor on Y./>
<comment QuestionId="When should a student attempt unsupervised research" AnswerId="dZ3QVJdZvccGNzRPV7iOng==" Author="7075" Date="2013-05-20T19:38:00.643" Text="I don't think your description of highly independent students is extremely accurate. What you wrote seems to me describes myopic students who don't learn others' work by reading papers and attending conferences/seminars. Being independent doesn't mean you don't listen to others or ask for advice. In my obnoxiously arrogant opinion, it simply means **you** decide. You should take into account every piece of information you can get, including what your advisor says./>

<answer QuestionId="When should a student attempt unsupervised research" AnswerId="HCtYHjZ8X5BdWK3sArRv+Q==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-20T18:09:39.523" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Basically, the only restrictions are issues related to funding. If your funding is intended for you to work on a specific topic, then your primary efforts should be given to the designated topic. However, you can, if so motivated, pursue the research topic independently. In mathematics, this might not be such a huge issue, as the infrastructural demands are not so large (except for some applied math projects). However, in other disciplines, where this &quot;unsupervised research&quot; may require experimental supplies and other resources, this is a &lt;em&gt;much&lt;/em&gt; bigger issue. In the latter case, you &lt;strong&gt;must&lt;/strong&gt; obtain approval from the PI whose equipment, material, and other resources you will be using!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If your time is &quot;unrestricted,&quot; in the sense that it is not tied to any particular project or program, then you should talk with your supervisor to see if you can use some of your &quot;normal&quot; time to devote to the &quot;side&quot; project. If you can, great; if you can't, then again, this needs to be &quot;on the side&quot;—beyond your main project. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As for the question of doing &quot;first-authored&quot; research, well, that transition process, in many respects, &lt;em&gt;is&lt;/em&gt; the goal of the PhD! If you are to be a successful researcher, then during your doctoral studies you will learn how to do research independently, and eventually unsupervised. (Moreover, you will hopefully also have the chance to learn how to supervise others!)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10109" Date="2014-01-31T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10109" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10109" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="When should a student attempt unsupervised research" AnswerId="5Y1y8jNZAdznS7lMAGlS+g==" Author="6319" Date="2013-05-20T21:05:58.563" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Think of research as a learning paradigm, whenever you learn something new spend time asking yourself how you would develop it if what you just learned was the state of the art, and what interesting directions would be. As you learn more about the topic you can see whether you were right. This makes learning to do research a constant part of your life rather than something you are learning to do when you start your thesis or dissertation. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10119" Date="2013-05-20T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="When should a student attempt unsupervised research" AnswerId="7SaP0CDbHwY4TG0f59mJzQ==" Author="49" Date="2013-05-20T18:09:34.207" Score="16" Text="&lt;p&gt;It is a common thread - see &lt;a href=&quot;http://matt.might.net/articles/ways-to-fail-a-phd/&quot;&gt;&quot;Go rogue too soon/too late&quot; in 10 easy ways to fail a Ph.D.&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://chronicle.com/article/Going-Rogue/134896&quot;&gt;Going Rogue at The Chronicle of Higher Education&lt;/a&gt;. An excerpt from the first:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The advisor-advisee dynamic needs to shift over the course of a degree.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Early on, the advisor should be hands on, doling out specific topics and helping to craft early papers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Toward the end, the student should know more than the advisor about her topic. Once the inversion happens, she needs to &quot;go rogue&quot; and start choosing the topics to investigate and initiating the paper write-ups. She needs to do so even if her advisor is insisting she do something else.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The trick is getting the timing right.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Going rogue before the student knows how to choose good topics and write well will end in wasted paper submissions and a grumpy advisor.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;On the other hand, continuing to act only when ordered to act past a certain point will strain an advisor that expects to start seeing a &quot;return&quot; on an investment of time and hard-won grant money.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Advisors expect near-terminal Ph.D. students to be proto-professors with intimate knowledge of the challenges in their field. They should be capable of selecting and attacking research problems of appropriate size and scope.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Personally, I have a lot of experience with unsupervised research (yes, usually &lt;em&gt;wasted a lot of time for no results&lt;/em&gt;), starting from high school. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Sure, doing advisor's project is much safer (as, in some sense, (s)he is responsible for the big picture, references, judging which result is &lt;em&gt;good enough&lt;/em&gt;) and allows to forget about doubts (for good or bad) and concentrate on work.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, what I've discovered after 1.5 of my PhD (mostly &quot;going rogue&quot;) is that there are two important things:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;asking experts (or peers), and&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;day-to-day collaboration.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Sure, you can have an expert &lt;em&gt;and&lt;/em&gt; a collaborator in the same person of your advisor, but as long as you are not afraid of talking to other people and have some knowledge in the topic, it shouldn't be hard to ask experts appropriate questions.&#xA;When it comes to collaboration - it may be trickier (but not if you locally have people with an interest overlap).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On contrary, working alone for months on a theoretical problem, with little feedback, may be very hard (both technically and psychologically). &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/a/5790/49&quot;&gt;I've learnt it the hard way&lt;/a&gt;. It is not a problem for one research line, but it is when all research is done alone (may be inefficient and depressive, &lt;em&gt;perhaps&lt;/em&gt; unless you are in a &lt;em&gt;deep love&lt;/em&gt; with it). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_1012	<question QuestionId="How to present in lecture a paper that students have read (or should I not have them read it)" Title="How to present in lecture a paper that students have read (or should I not have them read it)" Views="381" Tags="teaching" " AnswerId="ARdZty9LJpjK6kPTGAoVfQ==" Author="586" Date="2012-04-05T06:46:55.890" Score="10" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would like to present some classic computer science papers in a class I am teaching.  I know teachers usually assign papers before the lecture, but I can't figure out how to present material they've already read and likely understood.  In the case of a highly technical paper, I'd go over the more technical portions, perhaps letting them know beforehand not to struggle with the proofs, programming examples, etc., but I'm thinking of less technical papers, such as:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://cm.bell-labs.com/who/ken/trust.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Reflections on Trusting Trust&lt;/a&gt; by Ken Thompson&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.catb.org/~esr/writings/homesteading/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;The Cathedral and the Bazaar&lt;/a&gt; by Eric S. Raymond&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cs.nott.ac.uk/~cah/G51ISS/Documents/NoSilverBullet.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;No Silver Bullet&lt;/a&gt; by Fred Brooks&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;While I don't need to use pure lecture format, I am not sure that discussion would work well, since some of the papers (such as &quot;Reflections on Trusting Trust&quot;) aren't really discussable, and my students lack the experience to discuss others (such as &quot;No Silver Bullet&quot;).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;EDIT: I was hoping not to task the students with extra prep, since they already have a lot of assignments to do, but, as some of you suggest, that may be the best way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How to present in lecture a paper that students have read (or should I not have them read it)" AnswerId="LYLi7a3F9eKbvbE1n0q8xQ==" Author="94" Date="2012-04-05T09:42:36.133" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;One possibility is to ask the &lt;em&gt;students&lt;/em&gt; to present. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;It gives an opportunity for the students to practice presenting &lt;em&gt;something&lt;/em&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sitting from the audience point-of-view with (I expect) expert knowledge, you will be at a great vantage point for judging whether the students fully comprehend the paper and whether they are focusing on the &quot;correct things&quot;. Sometimes students spend too much time tracking down irrelevant details and miss the big picture. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sometimes (depend on local culture etc.) students are more likely to engage in discussion and ask detailed questions if it is their peer doing the presentation. (The &quot;intimidated by the professor effect&quot;.) &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to present in lecture a paper that students have read (or should I not have them read it)" AnswerId="LYLi7a3F9eKbvbE1n0q8xQ==" Author="94" Date="2012-04-09T15:32:59.873" Text="@Suresh: very good point indeed! Though from my experience (as a student in those kind of situations), usually the degeneration correlates with _no one else having done the reading_ `:)` which I hope is already preempted in the context of this question./>

<answer QuestionId="How to present in lecture a paper that students have read (or should I not have them read it)" AnswerId="TN+6mQJ4HztarWvj/2M0xQ==" Author="601" Date="2012-04-06T23:36:04.363" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;I propose the presentation format as well but rather than have the students present from anything, maybe have a pool they can choose from or assign topics? With regards to the discussion format, sometimes it can devolve into only a few of the students talking spiritedly while the rest are confused or bored.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">
