<answer QuestionId="Should unreadability or sloppiness of students work be reflected in their evaluation" AnswerId="ptdueqZU/cQeetFPvI7Klw==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-22T08:28:17.037" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Ideally, no. The main problem when evaluating is expressed by a saying in my native language &quot;muddy writing, muddy thinking&quot;. Essentially, if you cannot decipher what is written, either because it is sloppy writing or poorly expressed, then one faces problems when grading. Students often complain about grading where they sense they are misinterpreted etc. This is when we cannot understand what they are writing. Often, I believe, we also give people the benefit of the doubt and grade more leniently than what the verbatim answer would state. This is, of course, never picked up by a student. Hence a catch 22.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What can we do? The problem lies in the examination. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;First, we can provide clear guidelines about clarity of language and writing. This should be pointed out long before the exam, in fact early in their education. A study of Swedish students showed that they learn two ways of writing in pre-university levels. In languages, focus is on grammar, spelling and language but not content; whereas in other subjects focus is on content and not language. When they arrive at the university they do not realize that both are important; we need to tell them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Second, we can chose other means of examination where those with poor hand-writing can do better. Examples can be many: from essays through take homes to verbal and of course highly depending on the course, contents, level etc. Examples of the means of grading is to have external graders (more resources!) or to do as one of my teachers did; ask students to request everyone writes the exam with the pencil, and then after the exam use a pen to add corrections to their own exame as the teacher went through the exam. The exam was then collected and graded by the teacher. I mention this as an example, fully realizing it would not work in every situation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So the answer for me is no, but our assessment is always tainted by many factors whether we want it or not. To reduce the element of subjectivity is what we would be looking for.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10156" Date="2013-05-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10156" Date="2013-05-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10156" Date="2013-05-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10156" Date="2013-05-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10156" Date="2013-05-23T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10156" Date="2013-05-22T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Should unreadability or sloppiness of students work be reflected in their evaluation" AnswerId="KyEelqqzbk/IzyZ2MsXfdQ==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-22T09:19:38.110" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;While I do agree with Peter Jansson's answer that we should make it completely clear to students what they need to do to have their work understood, I feel differently about the impacting on assessment.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In industry, the ability to write readable (which means maintainable) code is critical. The ability to write a really cool, super efficient block of logic which nobody can understand is simply producing a ticking time bomb which will explode as soon as someone else goes to edit it. Students need to know that you are not just being a 'stuffly old prof' but rather that there are certain expectations from the profession and they must live up to them. Coding is not just about making a solution - it's about making a solution which will not explode 12-18 months later.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the academic side, I also have students who have similar problems where they do not care much about being careful in their writing. I generally handle them like this:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If I can understand it, but it is difficult, then I will mark them based on the overall quality of their work. If it is difficult to understand then the quality of their work is not great. Even if they are far smarter than me, they should be able to write in such a way that they can be understood.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If I cannot understand it, then I simply fail them. They are responsible for showing me that they understand and if they do not do that, then I must fail them - this is my responsibility.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, yes, educate them. However, I would not let poor quality slide.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I try to remind my students of the story of the family. Every happy family is happy in the same way. Every unhappy family is unhappy in a different way. The students are usually lost at first, then I explain to them that for the family to be happy they must get 100 things right. But, get anyone of them wrong and the family is unhappy. If they want to be happy then they must get it all right.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Should unreadability or sloppiness of students work be reflected in their evaluation" AnswerId="WoDhcnMgn+VdWt1xvc61rg==" Author="7184" Date="2013-05-22T18:47:44.043" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am not a teacher, but I am in my second year of my associates working toward my bachelors. My opinion is that yes you should, it will only hurt them later in life. In high school I passed my classes with C or a C+, now in college I am getting As and Bs. The reason is not that I am magically smarter, it is that I apply myself at least twice as hard.&lt;br&gt;&#xA; There is so much information out there to learn anything, APA or MLA, and sites like &lt;em&gt;Grammar Girl&lt;/em&gt; and reference generators. I think spelling should and grammar should be graded hard, maybe not at the first of the semester.&lt;br&gt;&#xA; If they are bad at first, correct them and give them places to go for examples of the correct way(s) to do it. If by mid-term they have not figured it out then grade them hard. All work should flow; if it does not, let them know now because in their career they will not get a nice correction and time to fix it. I work my butt off in school and feel as if I get graded hard, but it is when the teacher gives good feedback that I learn and make the change. So giving them a grade lower than an A needs an explanation of what they need to fix.&lt;br&gt;&#xA; This is why we are seeing on job descriptions -Bachelors from a reputable University- teachers need to be hard so that the student walks away with a real education not just a piece of paper that cost them thousands of dollars.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10170" Date="2013-05-22T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>

academia.stackexchange.com_10173	<question QuestionId="Does membership of academic honour societies carry any professional weight  recognition" Title="Does membership of academic honour societies carry any professional weight  recognition" Views="454" Tags="cv" " AnswerId="qMJLnBcXxSB2DEx07FEDrA==" Author="4475" Date="2013-05-22T23:22:41.970" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;I understand &lt;strong&gt;honour societies&lt;/strong&gt; have been around for years and it is a tradition more prevalent in the western world to recognise outstanding academic talent. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The largest honour society is perhaps the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.goldenkey.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Golden Key&lt;/a&gt; which operates worldwide and has over 2 million members. It provides a range of services to members, including leadership training, networking and the opportunity to do good. Membership is by invitation only and only those who are in the top 15% of their class or high performing graduate students are eligible. The eligibility is based solely on academic performance.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I presume being invited to join a honour society is an 'honour' in itself, as the mere mention of this affiliation on the CV would indicate that you are a top achiever. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Question 1:&lt;/strong&gt; Does membership of honour society carry any professional weight?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(i.e. does it give any additional advantages?)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Note:&lt;/strong&gt; Honour society is not the same as professional society. The latter, as I understand it, is open to all persons in a particular field (irrespective of their academic achievement but as long as certain criteria are met, e.g. successful registration as a teacher to join a teacher's union).  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Question 2:&lt;/strong&gt; Are there other honour societies in addition to the Golden Key (which seems to be the most dominant one)? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;PS:&lt;/strong&gt; I am unsure of the tag, so putting CV. Please update!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Disclaimer:&lt;/strong&gt; I am not associated with Golden Key.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Does membership of academic honour societies carry any professional weight  recognition" AnswerId="qMJLnBcXxSB2DEx07FEDrA==" Author="4475" Date="2013-05-22T23:55:38.963" Text="I am not associated in any way with Golden Key. I have put a disclaimer./>
<comment QuestionId="Does membership of academic honour societies carry any professional weight  recognition" AnswerId="qMJLnBcXxSB2DEx07FEDrA==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-23T00:01:04.243" Text="Top 15% in your class is _very_ different from &quot;the best of the best&quot;./>
<comment QuestionId="Does membership of academic honour societies carry any professional weight  recognition" AnswerId="qMJLnBcXxSB2DEx07FEDrA==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-24T12:05:54.507" Text="Top 15% of your class is also very different from &quot;top achiever&quot;./>
<comment QuestionId="Does membership of academic honour societies carry any professional weight  recognition" AnswerId="qMJLnBcXxSB2DEx07FEDrA==" Author="4475" Date="2013-05-23T00:23:14.803" Text="Thanks. I have edited it to say 'top achiever'./>

<answer QuestionId="Does membership of academic honour societies carry any professional weight  recognition" AnswerId="ZXs4b5e+Ql71XV3eqRzz3w==" Author="5596" Date="2013-06-19T00:16:20.027" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Listing &quot;prestigious&quot; societies like Phi Beta Kappa or Tau Beta Pi is perfectly acceptable. While it probably won't do a whole lot of good, it also won't do any harm. Do avoid listing any societies where you have to pay dues or pay to be inducted: they are a double-whammy since they give the perception that 1) you are padding your CV with inconsequential honors, and 2) are exhibiting poor judgment by paying to do so.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10670" Date="2013-06-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10670" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10670" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Does membership of academic honour societies carry any professional weight  recognition" AnswerId="6vn4ihZIyTq1NlWRjAeqzg==" Author="612" Date="2013-05-24T04:50:31.277" Score="12" Text="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Does membership of honour society carry any professional weight?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;No, not in general.  At a very early stage in your career, for example when applying to graduate school, it may be useful as a quick indication that you have received high grades.  However, the grades themselves are more meaningful than the honor society membership, and in any case grades only matter so much.  It's worth mentioning the honor society on your CV, but it won't make a big difference.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Once you are more than a few years past undergraduate studies, neither grades nor honor societies matter.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

One exception is Phi Beta Kappa, which (unlike Golden Key) does not require paying a fee to be inducted. I would be suspicious of any honor society that requires payment for membership. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Does membership of academic honour societies carry any professional weight  recognition" AnswerId="7MX3HEYBOPxYa0RB3j1L/g==" Author="7134" Date="2013-05-23T13:41:47.943" Text="Alpha Chi is another. The significance of Phi Beta Kappa and Alpha Chi is as Aaron says, purely academic with no dues. Further, the cutoff point is top 10% rather than 15%. Additionally, chapters for these academic honor societies exist at more elite schools, ones where it's much more difficult to be a top performer./>
<comment QuestionId="Does membership of academic honour societies carry any professional weight  recognition" AnswerId="7MX3HEYBOPxYa0RB3j1L/g==" Author="6984" Date="2013-05-24T07:31:14.020" Text="Membership gets you nothing, except in two ways. (1) You can put it on your cv (not that helpful) and (2) if you are in academia, your college's/university's ability to induct students into PBK (i.e., &quot;having a chapter&quot;) is contingent on having a set number of PBK members on faculty./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10175	<question QuestionId="Criteria to give coauthorship to advisor" Title="Criteria to give coauthorship to advisor" Views="137" Tags="co-authors" " AnswerId="MtpIM+WMT0UOV0TWu3nloA==" Author="7196" Date="2013-05-23T00:42:50.747" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am doing my PhD in economics. <comment QuestionId="Criteria to give coauthorship to advisor" AnswerId="MtpIM+WMT0UOV0TWu3nloA==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-23T07:12:26.520" Text="I am very fortunate in this regard - my supervisors (principal and associate) are very involved in my project, but still, as they proofread the manuscripts, they are invited to be co authors./>
<comment QuestionId="Criteria to give coauthorship to advisor" AnswerId="MtpIM+WMT0UOV0TWu3nloA==" Author="26" Date="2013-05-24T11:53:38.277" Text="I never heard of criteria either when I was a Ph. D. student (or after), only that professors apparently expected to have their name on their students' papers. My advisor always refused this, on the grounds that he &quot;merely proofread the manuscript(s)&quot; (although extremely thoroughly)./>
<comment QuestionId="Criteria to give coauthorship to advisor" AnswerId="MtpIM+WMT0UOV0TWu3nloA==" Author="4360" Date="2013-05-23T01:08:18.173" Text="First you should check the documentation you signed at the beginning of your PhD program to make sure that you even have the choice of declining co-authorship. A lot of agreements are written with a clause that advisors are always co-authors. Also you need to maintain a positive relationship with your advisor, they expect something in return for their time spent on advising you./>
<comment QuestionId="Criteria to give coauthorship to advisor" AnswerId="MtpIM+WMT0UOV0TWu3nloA==" Author="73" Date="2013-05-23T02:39:36.940" Text="See also [Supervisors and Authorship](http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/644/supervisors-and-authorship)/>

In the US, I've never heard of a formal agreement that the advisor will co-author all papers.  I'd question the ethics of such an agreement.  Do you know of a university that publicly states such a policy?/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10177	<question QuestionId="What to include in a letter of support for an academic assessment" Title="What to include in a letter of support for an academic assessment" Views="224" Tags="writing,recommendation-letter" " AnswerId="DJ9ieJ75B1QRQl7EAbAgPQ==" Author="344" Date="2013-05-23T01:22:31.517" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have been asked to write a short note that includes comments about the impact and importance of a colleagues' work over the course of the past year - for a pre-tenure review.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I could discuss a notable recent publication, a conference he is organizing, inspiring discussions we have had over the past year, and his public outreach at a recent conference. But it is not clear how I do so in a way that most effectively supports his work, and would appreciate advice from more experienced academics who request and review such letters. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;How can I most effectively frame and focus these points while keeping the letter brief and genuine? In addition to these points, what are the key features of such a letter?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="What to include in a letter of support for an academic assessment" AnswerId="TI7msUfNvK2MwSYK43cB/A==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-23T07:06:19.490" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would suggest by starting with a general statement about your colleague as an academic (quality of work, productivity etc. relative to others, in general, in the specific sub-discipline) following that you could exemplify this with the points you mention. Tiyr second paragraph could almost be copied into such a letter but with some more detail. A second item may be to set the last year performance in perspective of the longer term. This seems not to be asked for but I think it is a valuable step to set the year's performance in perspective both relative to what has been achieved earlier and relative to what can be expected visavi the person's job siuation (teaching load, admin load etc.. For tenure, I suppose personal traits and activities within the department are not of interest since they would be known internally. Other wise such points should be included.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_1018	<question QuestionId="A major journal in my field is published by Elsevier How can we move the field to a less objectionable more open publisher" Title="A major journal in my field is published by Elsevier How can we move the field to a less objectionable more open publisher" Views="792" Tags="publishing,journals" " AnswerId="/HcLiQ2IWegWpXxw7QrbkA==" Author="590" Date="2012-04-05T11:09:14.610" Score="20" Text="&lt;p&gt;Many people complain about Elsevier and over eight thousand are &lt;a href=&quot;http://thecostofknowledge.com&quot;&gt;boycotting it&lt;/a&gt;, but actual solutions seem hard to find for certain fields- I'm thinking of research areas for which an Elsevier journal is very important and funds are not available to subsidize an open-access journal.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;How can we move an Elsevier-dependent research community to a less objectionable, more open publisher?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'll post a partial possible answer myself; I'm asking because I think we need more/better answers than mine.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="A major journal in my field is published by Elsevier How can we move the field to a less objectionable more open publisher" AnswerId="/HcLiQ2IWegWpXxw7QrbkA==" Author="590" Date="2012-04-05T11:55:39.357" Text="You seem to be referring to a strategy of encouraging support of existing alternative journals. That'll be very good for certain situations, and so the list you imagine indeed should be started somewhere, but above I was thinking of Elsevier journals that are central to a particular research community, so that it's unlikely most researchers will leave it without a concerted effort and broad agreement by the community- hence the partial answer I give below. As for the community wiki idea, I don't know stackexchange well enough to have good judgment about that- maybe you're right./>

<answer QuestionId="A major journal in my field is published by Elsevier How can we move the field to a less objectionable more open publisher" AnswerId="VuG9ykJzmIoywYrqkJSNPw==" Author="594" Date="2012-04-05T18:52:17.927" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;It occurs to me that in our field (vision science), Journal of Vision already is an open access alternative to Vision Research. I haven't noticed a big difference in quality or acceptance rates between the two journals, they publish at a similar rate (JoV=270, VR=252 articles in 2011) and their impact factors are within 0.5 of each other. Also, around a third of the VR editorial board are also on the JoV board, and Denis Levi is about to transition from VR editor in chief to JoV editor in chief. Given these similarities, I guess the fact that the whole field hasn't abandoned VR suggests that people still feel there is a place for it. Or, from the other perspective, the success of JoV shows that lots of people wanted an open access alternative, and it's great that they now have one. {reposted from Google+}&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="A major journal in my field is published by Elsevier How can we move the field to a less objectionable more open publisher" AnswerId="VuG9ykJzmIoywYrqkJSNPw==" Author="590" Date="2012-04-05T20:30:37.890" Text="Journal of Vision is open access but charges a fee. Many of those who prefer it to the alternatives may nonetheless not submit to it due to lack of funding. Therefore it's hard to conclude anything from the continued success of other journals.  It is more valid to compare two subscription journals, e.g. VR and Perception, one of which is published by Elsevier and one not. Again however, there is a major confound- the VR impact factor is lower, and many authors feel they must publish in the higher-impact journal to win grants or a permanent job./>

</answer>
<answer QuestionId="A major journal in my field is published by Elsevier How can we move the field to a less objectionable more open publisher" AnswerId="96LE7xkyxyX+C7svh8OlBA==" Author="590" Date="2012-04-05T11:50:15.617" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;First one must assess whether researchers in the area agree that the community should leave Elsevier. If there isn't strong support for leaving Elsevier, then any move is likely to fail, as it will probably involve a new venture (such as a new journal) requiring the support of many, many researchers in the area, perhaps as authors, editors, or readers pressuring their university to subscribe to the new journal. If the research community is not supportive, this may because they have very good reasons or it may be out of ignorance / lack of imagination of the alternatives. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Discussion of the possibilities in your researcher community serves to explore the options, educate, and potentially build support. You may be able to start a discussion of the issues on mailing lists, social media, or run a &lt;a href=&quot;http://openwetware.org/wiki/OpenVisionScience&quot;&gt;conference symposium/satellite&lt;/a&gt; related to this topic.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If there is community support, there are a few possibilities for actually making the move. In most (all?) cases, Elsevier owns the journal and its name, therefore one cannot simply switch publishers and keep the same journal name. As a work-around, moves have occurred when all or most of the members of editorial boards of Elsevier journals &lt;a href=&quot;http://oad.simmons.edu/oadwiki/Journal_declarations_of_independence&quot;&gt;resigned and started a new journal&lt;/a&gt;, usually issuing an open letter explaining their action and encouraging the community to submit to and subscribe to the new journal.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A new journal can use the traditional subscription model or be open access. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;With a subscription model, one can use a traditional publisher- a non-profit university press may be less objectionable than Elsevier or one of the other mega-profitable corporate publishers. I have &lt;a href=&quot;http://openwetware.org/wiki/OpenVisionScience#Publishing_Solutions-_subscription_model&quot;&gt;started a list of possible publishers&lt;/a&gt;. To get started with a new publisher, one must convince them that they will make enough from subscriptions for the new journal to be worth their while. This may be difficult, as new journals are frequently risky. It takes a few years for a journal to receive an impact factor, and may also take years to be indexed by the major databases, and many authors will only submit to journals that have already achieved these things.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;An open-access journal can use the author-pays model, in which case a large publisher can provide all the traditional services (manuscript submission software system and reviewing workflow management, layout, copyediting, production, webhosting, accounting, exporting to databases, DOI registration, proper metadata, etc.)  or it can be run on a shoestring, with academics handling everything perhaps with a few administrative staff. For research communities willing to submit all their manuscripts in LateX, this is quite feasible but for communities that demand layout (figures and text arranged to fit a standard page appearance and possibly typesetting) be done, this is more labor-intensive.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Several open-source software tools assist in publishing journals. Open Journal Systems is most like a traditional journal publishing platform but I hear it may be difficult for academics to use. Annotum is based on Wordpress and I believe it works by having authors write their manuscript directly in its software, so that it can guarantee that the paper will look exactly as you expect it (WYSIWYG). It is used by PLoS Currents and other journals. All of these tools could probably use more skilled programmmers contributing to the project.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am only a researcher, not a publisher, so perhaps not everything I have written here is correct. I think we researchers are in particular need of estimates of the person-hours needed to publish and manage a journal by various methods, so that a research community considering a move can budget appropriately / be comfortable knowing what they're getting into.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="A major journal in my field is published by Elsevier How can we move the field to a less objectionable more open publisher" AnswerId="96LE7xkyxyX+C7svh8OlBA==" Author="590" Date="2012-04-05T12:02:29.300" Text="Unfortunately you won't be able to get most scientists, e.g. in biomedicine, to use LaTeX. It may be easy for you and for math/CS/physics types, but not for your average doctor/psychologist/biologist. Many have never used any scripting or markup, e.g. html, in their lives, and are not willing to try it./>
<comment QuestionId="A major journal in my field is published by Elsevier How can we move the field to a less objectionable more open publisher" AnswerId="96LE7xkyxyX+C7svh8OlBA==" Author="65" Date="2012-04-05T11:57:00.303" Text="&quot;for communities that demand layout (figures and text arranged to fit a standard page appearance and possibly typesetting) be done, this is more labor-intensive&quot; — Um.  LaTeX can do that.  That's what LaTeX is *for*.  It's not even that hard./>
<comment QuestionId="A major journal in my field is published by Elsevier How can we move the field to a less objectionable more open publisher" AnswerId="96LE7xkyxyX+C7svh8OlBA==" Author="user107" Date="2012-04-05T13:24:13.317" Text="If you use a [WYSIWYM](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WYSIWYM) wrapper for LaTex (like the popular [Lyx](http://www.lyx.org/)), it will work no different from Microsoft Word./>
<comment QuestionId="A major journal in my field is published by Elsevier How can we move the field to a less objectionable more open publisher" AnswerId="96LE7xkyxyX+C7svh8OlBA==" Author="590" Date="2012-04-05T22:08:57.090" Text="Thanks for the Lyx tip- if it is very robust, then it should be suitable for some traditionally-not-LaTeX researcher communities! Although I'm sure there's some, probably including the author communities I'm involved in, that will say they absolutely positively need Word's Track Changes feature or something./>
<comment QuestionId="A major journal in my field is published by Elsevier How can we move the field to a less objectionable more open publisher" AnswerId="96LE7xkyxyX+C7svh8OlBA==" Author="856" Date="2014-03-30T00:16:41.210" Text="@user107 I assume you never really used Microsoft Word./>
<comment QuestionId="A major journal in my field is published by Elsevier How can we move the field to a less objectionable more open publisher" AnswerId="96LE7xkyxyX+C7svh8OlBA==" Author="65" Date="2012-04-05T12:09:02.583" Text="&quot;Doctor, doctor, it hurts when I do _this_.&quot;/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1019" Date="2014-03-28T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="A major journal in my field is published by Elsevier How can we move the field to a less objectionable more open publisher" AnswerId="OL20T0/S27u/iwGBz/gzrg==" Author="591" Date="2012-04-05T13:45:26.860" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;As a publisher who has launched an OA journal and seen what it takes to do so, I see the biggest problem for starting any journal being lack of an &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_factor&quot;&gt;Impact Factor&lt;/a&gt; (IF). I've polled authors at ECVP and about 90% said IF is what determined where they submitted. Everyone knows why this is, so why don't academics turn inward and try to undermine this reliance on IFs? Doing so would insert true competition into the journals market. Maybe academics have tried to do this, though I've never read of any real substantial attempts. I could be wrong. The second problem after IF and before funding is loyalty. Ed board members are often tied to multiple journals and in those first few years you really need those big names on your board to commission for the journal. Big names often care more about another journal or just don't care. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You need a publisher, be it nonprofit or profit, that can put in the work to promote the journal and help commission. Financially, OA journals are very easy to start. Subscription journals require more financial backing, which perhaps could be gotten through grants if you don't want to be tied to a commercial publisher. The answer is long and requires lots of discussion and more important, commitment. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="A major journal in my field is published by Elsevier How can we move the field to a less objectionable more open publisher" AnswerId="OL20T0/S27u/iwGBz/gzrg==" Author="590" Date="2012-04-05T21:48:50.030" Text="Thanks for this- I agree completely with the need to reduce the reliance on impact factor. Unfortunately, as long as IF is the only widely-recognized measure that is perceived to be correlated with journal quality, research administrators and bureaucrats and grant reviewers will continue to judge us by it. Some people are working to address this by developing alternative metrics.  Try #altmetrics on twitter, and total-impact.org for one example. Of course, the only real way to judge research is to read the paper, but no-one has time for that :) &#xA;&#xA;Alex/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10183	<question QuestionId="How to compose a great recommendation letter" Title="How to compose a great recommendation letter" Views="2213" Tags="research,recommendation-letter" " AnswerId="inB46w6tNIGz4x7IngtvuQ==" Author="7204" Date="2013-05-23T08:10:16.893" Score="20" Text="&lt;p&gt;I was asked to compose a recommendation/reference letter for a Computer Engineer that works as a Researcher in the Research Center i am supervisor. I dont know if Academia is the right site to post , but since the nature of the job is Research and people involved &quot;Research Engineers&quot; , i believe is the right place.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So , i need to write a great recommendation/reference letter, but the problem is i never wrote a letter of this kind before. I ve seen many of them , and even more on the web but the problem is that they all look &quot;copy-pasted&quot; and not written in a way that would make me believe that the author of this letter really spent time on it , believing in the skills of his employee and really wanted to recommend him.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I ve already wrote the letter , the best i could and i will like to ask about some parts of it , how they sound and if they could get any better.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1)&lt;/strong&gt; As a first paragraph  , i wrote who i am , the position i have in the Research Center and what is the purpose of this letter:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;my name is .. i am a .... &#xA;&#xA;The purpose of this letter, is to serve as a reference to my cooperation with Mr ...&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2)&lt;/strong&gt; In the second paragraph i wrote about the position of the person (Research Engineer) and for how long he worked with us:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;Mr. X  joined our team in the X Research Center as a full-time Research Engineer under an ongoing X month contract...&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;At this point i dont know how i could point out better the fact the the person was under a normal full-paid contract and not just given a &quot;European Grant&quot; to work with us. I wrote he is a &lt;code&gt;full-time&lt;/code&gt; , but still there are many people that join programs after studies that work for a few months as Engineers in Research Centers. In this case , i want to stress that he was working as normal Research Engineer , especially chosen for his skills and payed a normal salary for his position as Engineer. Maybe add something like &lt;code&gt;&quot;full payed contract&quot;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3)&lt;/strong&gt; In the 3rd paragraph i wrote under what framework the person worked(European project) and a few words where and how he was involved. I didnt want to go into great details here as i believe this stuff could be easily read from his great cv. Or is it wise to describe exactly what he did(Names of real-life applications that was part of developing etc). I pointed out that he was deeply involved in what he did , how well he integrated with the rest of the people how motivated he was and that he actively contributed in the project. Anything else i could add here?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;4)&lt;/strong&gt; As a last line i would like to show that i cant recommend him enough , but without getting &quot;too excited&quot;. I want it to be serious, i want it to leave no doubts. Also since the person is young , he is interested in continuing with post graduate studies , or working as a Researcher or even getting a computer engineer position in a private company. Is it ok if i mention all of them? Usually we recommend someone for one type of position. But his position , working as computer engineer doing research(aka Research Engineer) , leaves no doubt that he would be great as a phD student , as a researcher or as a software engineer. So i wrote:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;For all the aforementioned reasons I would like to highly recommend X , as a strong candidate for future postgraduate studies , research and employment offers.&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What do you think about it? How could i make it better and is there something i should change? If you dont like some part and you give me an alternative please point out why you dont like the part , as some times its a bit of personal taste and not that something is wrong. Would be great , if you could post some examples of letters you composed or parts of them , or an example from the web that you consider great.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thank you for reading!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How to compose a great recommendation letter" AnswerId="6r5rCWrh6I1ehjUkZtDWqA==" Author="79" Date="2013-05-23T18:33:27.417" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;There was a good link that I'd found on this topic, while applying to graduate school:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://cs.brown.edu/~sk/Memos/Grad-School-Recos/&quot;&gt;Advice to Graduate School Recommendation Letter Writers&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The above link is a pithy list of points to be kept in mind by new letter writers. As a summary, I'd like to highlight some sections of it that I've found repeated in other such articles as well:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Be Concrete&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;If you take away just one piece of concrete advice, let it be this.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The single biggest problem with most letters is that they are filled&#xA;  with abstract generalities and infinitives. If we don't know you or&#xA;  your institution, we can't judge what any of these statements mean&#xA;  relative to our standards. Always consider the illustrative anecdote:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;Due to deadline pressure, I asked him to grow a pumpkin in just one month. As you know it takes over 100 days to grow a pumpkin, but over the weekend he devised a new method to accelerate their growth. On Monday morning I arrived to find not just a pumpkin but a steaming, flavorful pie. &#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Anecdote about acts of raw coding are only so helpful in understanding&#xA;  research potential, but they're better than nothing (see the section&#xA;  on Corporate Letters, below). An extra book or paper they read, and&#xA;  demonstrated understanding of (again, be concrete about why you&#xA;  believe this), goes a long way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Corporate Letters&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;An important special case is the corporate letter: when you, the&#xA;  letter-writer, work in industry and have no academic affiliation. Many&#xA;  corporate letters (like many academic letters, but more so) tend to be&#xA;  vapid, clearly written in a different culture and for a different&#xA;  audience. Unless they actually did academic research with you, here&#xA;  are some suggestions for improving them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;A common mistake is to focus on teamwork. This is important even in&#xA;  academia, but often this is the primary focus of the letter, which&#xA;  makes it less valuable. Of course we care about it, but it's secondary&#xA;  to their technical skills.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;ol&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;Tell us if they learned something particularly quickly, mastered a&#xA;  complex technology, or solved a problem others were stuck on. Give&#xA;  us a paragraph of details.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;If you have a concrete reason to evaluate research potential, do so concretely. Otherwise, don't bother.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;Give us a brief bio-sketch, including educational qualifications.&#xA;  4.Put the applicant in context, and tell us the context. It's fine to relate it to your own student days, or to your experience hiring students.&#xA;  E.g.&#xA;  &lt;ul&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;Compared to the students I studied with at Cucumber and Melon University, and the ones I now recruit from there, I would put him in&#xA;  the top 10%.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ul&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10194" Date="2013-10-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10194" Date="2013-05-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10194" Date="2013-05-23T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10194" Date="2013-07-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10194" Date="2014-01-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10194" Date="2013-05-24T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How to compose a great recommendation letter" AnswerId="4b1KQD+TpbQAPwFZus6GGQ==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-23T11:08:58.670" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;This is what I would recommend and it is not far off from what you have outlined:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am assuming your will start the letter cordially to whomever will receive the letter (&quot;Dear so-and-so&quot; or &quot;To whom it may concern&quot;). I also assume you're writing on letter head where your name and contact information and date for the letter is written.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;1st part (paragraph)&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;First state that you write the letter on request by the applicant. Follow up by stating who you are in terms of your professional status (expertise) and your relation to the applicant. The purpose is to make the recipient aware of your standing relative to the applicant, it makes it easier to value your comments. This paragraph should obviously not be very long since it is not you who are to be evaluated, but still long enough to provide a fair picture of your qualifications.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;2nd part (one or more paragraphs)&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Outline the most important aspect of the applicants merits that are sought for the position, if it is a teaching job then etaching experience, if it is research then research related. It may end up more than one paragraph because you may need to discuss the research done (type of research past and present) in one paragraph and then follow up on the person's ability to attarct funding and colaboration in a second (depending on length). You also need to value the publications briefly in terms of journal impact factors and citations, in other words the quality of the published work.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;3rd part (one or more paragraphs)##&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You need to write about the personal side of the applicant, starting out with for example ability to collaborate and contribute to the research and work environment. This can be followed up bu more personal aspects and &quot;soft values&quot; that descfibes the persons pesronality at work and elsewhere. You obviously need to focius on aspects that may be relevant for evaluating the applicant as a colleague.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Final Statement&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Finish of by summing up the major points above and express your personal support for the person in terms of how the person would fit the announced position. You can for example tie back to your own expoerience and position and value in terms of how you see the applicant relative to others you have worked with and so on.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Final  Points to Consider&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The length of a letter can vary greatly. Honesty is what everyone expects. I think it is valuable to also mention weaknesses as long s they are done fairly and with insight. The employer will want to know the person, not just the glossy exterior. This part is always trickiest to write and also very personal so additional advice is hard to provide.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to compose a great recommendation letter" AnswerId="4b1KQD+TpbQAPwFZus6GGQ==" Author="4275" Date="2013-05-25T09:57:40.220" Text="Just a comment: in my field, one does not write about weaknesses. Anything remotely negative in the letter is a killer. Its unfortunate, but that's the tradition./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10184" Date="2013-05-23T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10184" Date="2013-05-23T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10199	<question QuestionId="Differences in opinion when teaching a course jointly with another instructor" Title="Differences in opinion when teaching a course jointly with another instructor" Views="142" Tags="professors,teaching,coursework" " AnswerId="hVqNqQU1s7ejHVcb66STfg==" Author="6144" Date="2013-05-24T09:00:34.617" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am working as a university lecturer in a local university in my country. I am sharing one course with another lecturer who has been teaching that course for approximately 3 years for now. A problem began when some of my students complained that they were not able to cope with the material. The dean was not willing to lose those students (as they pay a monthly tuition here); so he decided that myself and the other lecturer should switch groups.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Actually this situation has transformed in something worse. The other lecturer wants me to strictly follow the problems and solutions that he has on-line. I particularly do not agree with that situation mainly because I have a higher educational background, apart from research in my field of expertise.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have written a complaint to the academic coordinator, explaining my situation. I feel the students here are treated like some kind of stocks in a bursary market. The university loses money if they leave. What would be a good thing to do? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Differences in opinion when teaching a course jointly with another instructor" AnswerId="hVqNqQU1s7ejHVcb66STfg==" Author="6450" Date="2013-05-24T20:19:44.603" Text="I feel that the reason for not agreeing with the lecturer should be based on if his/her online exercises hinder students' learning, not whether you have a higher educational background./>
<comment QuestionId="Differences in opinion when teaching a course jointly with another instructor" AnswerId="hVqNqQU1s7ejHVcb66STfg==" Author="1424" Date="2013-05-24T09:46:22.510" Text="The title states that the teaching of this course is being done across two faculties. To which faculty do the students belong? Which faculty has oversight of the course? Yours, or your colleague's?/>
<comment QuestionId="Differences in opinion when teaching a course jointly with another instructor" AnswerId="hVqNqQU1s7ejHVcb66STfg==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-24T12:01:36.100" Text="I think in this context &quot;faculty&quot; refers to an individual instructor, not a larger group (what Americans would call a &quot;college&quot;)./>
<comment QuestionId="Differences in opinion when teaching a course jointly with another instructor" AnswerId="hVqNqQU1s7ejHVcb66STfg==" Author="4461" Date="2013-05-24T13:24:11.993" Text="This is a tough one.  I normally would suggest going with the flow coming into a class part-way through a term -- the students were presumably given a syllabus and it isn't really fair to change things mid-stream. Furthermore, the circumstance around your class swap are suspect enough, and if you go back to teaching as in the other class, I imagine your new students may complain, and then where does that leave you? It doesn't sound like a good situation altogether.../>
<comment QuestionId="Differences in opinion when teaching a course jointly with another instructor" AnswerId="hVqNqQU1s7ejHVcb66STfg==" Author="411" Date="2013-05-24T12:19:32.207" Text="Mea culpa. I had intended to have 'faculty member'./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10199" Date="2013-05-24T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10199" Date="2013-05-24T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Differences in opinion when teaching a course jointly with another instructor" AnswerId="m9e6pKI8zSDyx447ZwmWEg==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-24T14:57:16.730" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;There are some things which are unclear in your question. However, I'm going to make a few guesses and if any are wrong then you might want to disregard this answer altogether.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It sounds like you have more education but less teaching experience than the other instructor. If you are new to teaching, one very common issue that new teachers often overestimate students' abilities. If the other instructor has more teaching experience then you might be better off 'going with the flow' for this first semester.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another reason to go with the flow is, as Chris Gregg pointed out in his comment above, students once given a syllabus should not have it changed on them mid-stream. It's bad enough (for them) to have to deal with a change in instructor, they should not also have the syllabus changed on them as well. Consider what you could learn from the way the other instructor designed the course - we can learn things from those with less education than us.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't know what you mean by &lt;em&gt;treated like some kind of stocks in a bursary market&lt;/em&gt; but, of course, without students there is no point of teaching so, yes, they are important. Nobody wants a large group of students to leave.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, my suggestion is to try one semester following the other teacher's guidance and next semester consider taking everything you know, and everything you learned, and improve things.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Differences in opinion when teaching a course jointly with another instructor" AnswerId="m9e6pKI8zSDyx447ZwmWEg==" Author="6144" Date="2013-05-25T15:45:43.943" Text="thanks @earhling for you answer. The other lecturer and me, we both have the same time teaching, approximately 5 years in a row. I am not putting any changes in the curricula, but I am against that they are repeating the same exercise, with minor variance, over and over again. Also the other lecturer  thinks that the algorithmic approach for solving problems, Information Systems related field, is not necessary./>
<comment QuestionId="Differences in opinion when teaching a course jointly with another instructor" AnswerId="m9e6pKI8zSDyx447ZwmWEg==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-26T04:08:21.543" Text="@Layla Then you clearly have a difference in teaching philosophies. I would say that if you can change some material to what you think is best, without changing the syllabus (which might not be possible if you want to add something new) then you should. However, you might want to try teaching the 'other' way to see how it goes. I remember when I was learning to debate as an undergrad, the most interesting was when I had to argue the side I did not agree with at all. It really opened my eyes./>

academia.stackexchange.com_1020	<question QuestionId="What is a fair metric for assessing the citation impact of journals across disciplines" Title="What is a fair metric for assessing the citation impact of journals across disciplines" Views="242" Tags="bibliometrics" " AnswerId="1fwEV3H69+IvaO8Btk7Tow==" Author="62" Date="2012-04-05T01:21:38.833" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;To quote Thomsons &quot;a journal's &lt;a href=&quot;http://thomsonreuters.com/products_services/science/academic/impact_factor/&quot;&gt;Impact factor&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;is calculated by dividing the number of current year citations to the source items published in that journal during the previous two years.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I assume that disciplines vary in&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;average number of citations per paper&lt;/strong&gt;: Disciplines with fewer citations per paper will appear to have less impact.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;citation half-life&lt;/strong&gt;: Longer half-lives means under-estimation of impact relative to journals with shorter half-lives. The &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_factor&quot;&gt;Wikipedia article on impact factors&lt;/a&gt; summarises a study that found that &quot;the percentage of total citations occurring in the first two years after publication varies highly among disciplines from 1-3 percent in the mathematical and physical sciences to 5-8 percent in the biological sciences.&quot; (Nierop, 2009).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Google Scholar uses the five year &lt;strong&gt;h-index&lt;/strong&gt;. See this listing of &lt;a href=&quot;http://scholar.google.com/citations?hl=en&amp;amp;view_op=search_venues&amp;amp;vq=psychology+OR+psychological+OR+cognitive+OR+cognition&quot;&gt;top ranked journals with various psychology related keywords in their title&lt;/a&gt;. The five year h-index indicates the number of papers with an equivalent number of citations. E.g., a value of 20 indicates that 20 articles published in the last five years have received 20 or more citations.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, while the h-index might reduce the issue of different citation half-lives, it does not resolve it. And it does not address the issue of differential citation patterns across disciplines.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Question&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What index provides both a reliable and unbiased assessment of the citation based impact of a journal when comparisons are being performed across disciplines?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h3&gt;Reference&lt;/h3&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Erjen van Nierop (2009). &quot;Why do statistics journals have low impact factors?&quot;. Statistica Neerlandica 63 (1): 52–62. doi:10.1111/j.1467-9574.2008.00408.x.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What is a fair metric for assessing the citation impact of journals across disciplines" AnswerId="1fwEV3H69+IvaO8Btk7Tow==" Author="62" Date="2012-04-05T07:50:30.347" Text="The reason why I asked it here is because this is a real issue in some psychology departments where research output is being compared with academic output from other fields such as the biomedical sciences. But I'd be happy for the question to be migrated to academia.SE if it was preferred./>
<comment QuestionId="What is a fair metric for assessing the citation impact of journals across disciplines" AnswerId="1fwEV3H69+IvaO8Btk7Tow==" Author="62" Date="2012-04-05T07:34:09.353" Text="@ArtemKaznatcheev That sounds reasonable, and I imagine that discipline specific rankings is a common approach. My first thought was simply to think of a metric that is less influenced by citation half-life and discipline specific citation patterns./>
<comment QuestionId="What is a fair metric for assessing the citation impact of journals across disciplines" AnswerId="1fwEV3H69+IvaO8Btk7Tow==" Author="66" Date="2012-04-05T07:20:20.560" Text="Defining field boundaries is an extremely difficult problem. There is some cool work on this via statistical properties of random walks that makes nice definitions, [here](http://www.eigenfactor.org/map/maps.php). I recommend taking a look around that site. A naive metric might be: classify journals into their fields and then assign each a ranking p, meaning the journal is in top p% of its field by some standard metric (say eigenfactor, since I link to that site). Note that the website claims eigenfactor and article influence scores adjust for different fields, already./>
<comment QuestionId="What is a fair metric for assessing the citation impact of journals across disciplines" AnswerId="1fwEV3H69+IvaO8Btk7Tow==" Author="66" Date="2012-04-05T08:02:43.217" Text="I raised the [question of migration in chat](http://chat.stackexchange.com/transcript/message/4120282#4120282)./>

<answer QuestionId="What is a fair metric for assessing the citation impact of journals across disciplines" AnswerId="EoffBj++xy5w2wFV0b8Gvg==" Author="66" Date="2012-04-05T12:39:06.837" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Moving from comments:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Defining field boundaries is an extremely difficult problem. Once those boundaries are defined (or as they are being defined) it is also difficult to judge which field individual journals belong to. The technical problem is one of &quot;community-structure&quot; or cluster detection, and is a big problem in computer science.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For the specific case of journals and citations, there is some cool work on this via statistical properties of random walks that &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.eigenfactor.org/map/maps.php&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;makes nice definitions using the map-equation&lt;/a&gt;. However, these statistical methods sometimes produce oddities (I think I remember seeing Phys. Rev. Letters being classified as Chemistry based on the stats). It also doesn't always produce the fine-gaining desired, for instance eigenfactor seems to not have a Cognitive Science category, just a general Psychology category.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In general, I recommend taking a look around &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.eigenfactor.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;eigenfactor&lt;/a&gt;. Note that the website claims eigenfactor and article influence scores adjust for different fields, already (take a look at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.eigenfactor.org/whyeigenfactor.php&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;point #4&lt;/a&gt;). I am not sure how accurate this claim is, but I personally find their metric more reliable (not to mention more accessible!) than ISI Web of Science. I also think their approach is more developed than the freshly-pressed Google Scholar journal rankings based on h5-index. However, I would love to see eigenfactor and Google Scholar together. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you are unsatisfied with eigenfactor's rankings, then a naive metric might be: classify journals into their fields and then assign each a ranking p, meaning the journal is in top p% of its field by some standard metric.  This should give you a rough idea.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1021" Date="2012-04-05T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="What is a fair metric for assessing the citation impact of journals across disciplines" AnswerId="aDnwkGUJU+kC56156fn9UQ==" Author="65" Date="2012-04-05T20:11:45.330" Score="14" Text="&lt;p&gt;There is no such index.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Publication and citation standards vary significantly between disciplines and even sub-disciplines.  Without direct, deep knowledge of the standards in each community, it is simply impossible to compare impact of a journal in field X with the impact of a journal in field Y.  (Eigenfactor's extraordinary claims to the contrary require extraordinary evidence, which they don't provide.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Moreover, it's not clear why you should even try.  Any judgement about the relative importance of Journal of X versus Journal of Y necessarily requires a &lt;strong&gt;prior&lt;/strong&gt; judgement about the relative importance of &lt;em&gt;field&lt;/em&gt; X versus &lt;em&gt;field&lt;/em&gt; Y.  HC SVNT DRACONES.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="What is a fair metric for assessing the citation impact of journals across disciplines" AnswerId="dfAEk9hjDfvF1Wx4BxClkQ==" Author="739" Date="2013-11-15T22:03:28.797" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Here's an informal and difficult to quantify one: does it suffice to have a publication in this journal to get tenured? Or, in a reverse manner, can one get tenured without having published in a journal like this? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;In economics, you will get tenure in most reasonable places for publications in &lt;em&gt;Quarterly Journal of Economics, American Economic Review,&lt;/em&gt; or &lt;em&gt;Econometrica&lt;/em&gt;. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;In statistics, these would be &lt;em&gt;Annals of Statistics, Annals of Applied Statistics, Journal of the Royal Statistical Society Series B Methodology, the Journal of the American Statistical Association&lt;/em&gt;, and &lt;em&gt;Biometrika&lt;/em&gt;. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;These are the fields I am closely familiar with. I can imagine that in most natural sciences, a publication in &lt;em&gt;Nature&lt;/em&gt; or &lt;em&gt;Science&lt;/em&gt; would boost your chances quite a bit. Finance has a system of ranking journals, with a handful of highly coveted journals designated as A-journals.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Getting reliable statistics along these lines is of course impossible. If Google were a little smarter, it would scan the CVs of those tenured and untenured (those who moved to another university after the typical period of 5-6-7 years), grab their publication records, and see what the journals are that those who got tenured had published in that untenured hadn't.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10201	<question QuestionId="Publishing in one vs many journals" Title="Publishing in one vs many journals" Views="321" Tags="publishing,publications,journals" " AnswerId="oGeWLFYkQP30AD5QQDIoZw==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-24T11:57:11.183" Score="17" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have started publishing papers this year - 3 so far, of which 2 are in an international journal, the 3rd in a local journal.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My question is, is there any particular disadvantage with publishing the majority of papers in one or a very limited array of journals? Or is it a case that it makes no difference either way?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Publishing in one vs many journals" AnswerId="l9AL69KvnD4owqx/jUk1aA==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-24T12:33:47.807" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am sure opinions and traditions vary concerning this question. For me the quality of the journal (say, impact factor) is the most important, you try to get published in good journals. In some cases, the field may be so narrow that only one or a very few journals may be good. In such cases the selection may result in a single journal. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To publish in a variety of journals seems to be a means by itself for many but I think the reasons still vary. There may be advantages in getting published in many journals to show that the research has wider applications and is accepted more generally. It may be a way to avoid the suspicion that you have a back way into a single journal (not that that would be true). In some cases, you may select different journals because you know your ideas are not favoured by someone in a specific journal's editorial board (strategic reason).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So reasons for spreading the publications may vary quite substantially. The main point for me is, however, still that primarily the quality of the journal will decide. I would not chose a different journal just to get a new journal mentioned in my list of publications.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Publishing in one vs many journals" AnswerId="l9AL69KvnD4owqx/jUk1aA==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-24T12:37:23.660" Text="That is a great point of taking the quality of the journal over the quantity of journals.  That is something that is very good to know for up and coming researchers./>

<answer QuestionId="Publishing in one vs many journals" AnswerId="c0TCsA0TIxiYPGSLQbCGjw==" Author="4125" Date="2013-05-31T00:11:37.273" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I agree with @PeterJansson that impact factor is certainly an important factor in selecting a journal. But I would also think about who you want to reach with your paper. Although Google Scholar and similar search engines now ensure a much higher probability of finding your paper based on its title, abstract and keywords, it will only be found by people actively searching for terms associated with your work. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Most researchers still subscribe to specific journals in their field, even if only through e-mail alerts, so I target a journal also for its audience (while trying to select the highest impact factor from this subset). This is especially important if your work bridges several fields. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example, my research is about human-robot interaction, so I have to decide whether to publish an article in a journal that is read primarily by roboticists or social scientists/psychologists. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In this case, it is also vitally important to adjust the paper to its target demographic. Psychologists don't know (and likely don't care) about my implementation details while roboticists are more likely to be interested in nitty gritty details about the code and less about the nuances of the social psychology theory behind it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10330" Date="2013-05-31T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Publishing in one vs many journals" AnswerId="7HC1JNEDa1pO76kWdcjv1g==" Author="946" Date="2013-05-24T19:30:46.813" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;In my field (mathematics), the quality of journals is a quite fuzzy notion; we do not rely very much on metrics like the impact factor, but have a subjective and qualitative sense of prestige of journals. Inevitably, the way a given journal is regarded changes from one person to another. As a consequence, publishing in a variety of journals increases the odds that someone looking at your publication list will think &quot;whao, she published in X!&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another point is that if one publishes a large fraction of its research in one journal, people can wonder whether she has a friend in the editorial board that help her getting accepted there.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;All in all, it seems preferable (and possible, given the large amount of journal in the field) to publish in a variety of journal for hiring, promotion and more generally evaluation matters. Of course, the picture is certainly different in other fields.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10220" Date="2013-05-24T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10220" Date="2013-05-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10220" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10220" Date="2013-05-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10220" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>

Do they hope to get more students enrolled, or more public exposure for the university? Or do they do it out of the kindness of their hearts, or for some other reasons?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="What are the benefits for universitiesprofessors to record online courses" AnswerId="o0NphXDO2ic/OVlRbeqHXg==" Author="4461" Date="2013-05-24T12:56:12.687" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;I record my lectures (when possible) for the following reasons:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Easier access for students who can't attend class.  While I generally want students to come to class, there are valid reasons for being absent (e.g., I'm currently teaching classes to military members who often have duty that preempts class attendance).  I can also point students to a video to review if they ask me questions explicitly covered in class (and also for general review).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Open access.  I think it's pretty cool to live in a world where it is possible to get free access to videos that enhance knowledge.  I feel like I'm playing my little part by putting my lectures online.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Introspective review.  It can be extremely beneficial to review your own teaching methods, although I don't have time to do this for all of my classes.  I have gone back to particular sections to review, and I almost always find something I could improve upon.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;(minor) The America's Funniest Videos factor.  I've had clips that have been unintentionally hilarious, either because of something I've said, or because of something students have said. :)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Universities have their own reasons for putting classes online, and you've already listed a number of them.  I'd like to believe that most of the reasons are altruistic, with sites such as &lt;a href=&quot;http://ocw.mit.edu/index.htm&quot;&gt;MIT's OpenCourseWare&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://online.stanford.edu/about&quot;&gt;Stanford's Online Courses&lt;/a&gt; providing no-strings-attached courses for free.  I would also hope that someone is doing research on these types of course offerings, to see if they are really having benefits to the people that watch them.  I don't believe the bottom line at extremely selective schools will ever be hurt by offering free course material, but if they do start feeling the pinch I imagine they will change their models.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Sites like &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.coursera.org/&quot;&gt;Courseara&lt;/a&gt; are for profit and &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2013/04/08/coursera-begins-make-money&quot;&gt;starting to make money&lt;/a&gt; by offering to verify certificates of completion for a cost.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Why, then, some [Universities] charge enormous fees for attending courses?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The question of college expense is a can of worms that has as &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/search?q=why+is+college+so+expensive%3F&amp;amp;aq=f&amp;amp;oq=why+is+college+so+expensive%3F&amp;amp;aqs=chrome.0.57j60l3j59j62.4484j0&amp;amp;sourceid=chrome&amp;amp;ie=UTF-8&quot;&gt;many differing answers as there are people asking about it&lt;/a&gt;.  Selective colleges charge what they do because (1) it is expensive to run a brick-and-mortar college, and (2) the applications keep rising and kids can still get loans, grants, and other aid.  Obviously it is much more subtle than that, and it would take &lt;a href=&quot;http://freevideolectures.com/University/UC-Berkeley/Economics/Subject/Page1&quot;&gt;more than a few free economics courses&lt;/a&gt; to get to the bottom of it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What are the benefits for universitiesprofessors to record online courses" AnswerId="o0NphXDO2ic/OVlRbeqHXg==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-24T12:58:31.953" Text="so very true, bet me to writing the answer!  But yes, it also extends to secondary education, where teachers can teach remote students in a greater area (such as the Outback in Australia)./>
<comment QuestionId="What are the benefits for universitiesprofessors to record online courses" AnswerId="o0NphXDO2ic/OVlRbeqHXg==" Author="4461" Date="2013-05-24T13:03:10.087" Text="@DamienIgoe True, though there is something particularly romantic about the [School of the Air](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/School_of_the_Air)!/>
<comment QuestionId="What are the benefits for universitiesprofessors to record online courses" AnswerId="o0NphXDO2ic/OVlRbeqHXg==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-24T13:05:29.437" Text="that is very true, and having worked in one small part of that environment - it is a very enriching experience as an educator to be able to provide tuition to someone half the country away./>
<comment QuestionId="What are the benefits for universitiesprofessors to record online courses" AnswerId="o0NphXDO2ic/OVlRbeqHXg==" Author="7216" Date="2013-05-24T13:56:17.983" Text="Thanks for your reply, @ChrisGregg! Your personal reasons are very laudable, and I understand and support them. &#xA;&#xA;But from the point of view of university: it spends additional money on professors to record videos/prepare material for online course (not necessary directly, but it still pays for professor's time), and then puts it online for free, it is a loss of money which is not offset by the students paying fees - unless you increase them. But in this case I guess students will start to think twice before paying fees, considering the option that they can watch the lectures online for free./>
<comment QuestionId="What are the benefits for universitiesprofessors to record online courses" AnswerId="o0NphXDO2ic/OVlRbeqHXg==" Author="7216" Date="2013-05-24T13:57:24.303" Text="&gt;I don't believe the bottom line at extremely selective schools will ever be hurt.&#xA;&#xA;Yes, I tend to agree, but then it can lead to situation that only &quot;elite&quot; places remain. Why would you go to a smaller school if you can watch videos from top institutions for free?/>
<comment QuestionId="What are the benefits for universitiesprofessors to record online courses" AnswerId="o0NphXDO2ic/OVlRbeqHXg==" Author="4461" Date="2013-05-24T14:11:33.520" Text="@Max -- I think most of the online courses from places like MIT are simply taped lectures from already scheduled classes. Some do incur other costs (and of course there are hosting and equipment costs), and some courses are explicitly produced to be online. There is also something to be said for being a ground-breaker in the arena.  See, for example, [Stanford's Class2Go](https://class2go.stanford.edu/) initiative, which garnered a good bit of media attention when it was launched./>
<comment QuestionId="What are the benefits for universitiesprofessors to record online courses" AnswerId="o0NphXDO2ic/OVlRbeqHXg==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-24T21:57:28.660" Text="_Why would you go to a smaller school if you can watch videos from top institutions for free?_ —  Because nobody goes to college for the _lectures_./>

<answer QuestionId="What are the benefits for universitiesprofessors to record online courses" AnswerId="n7eGlL0G5TeVg3qI3bEh3A==" Author="6862" Date="2013-07-17T17:05:30.837" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;In addition to the good non-financial reasons mentioned, there is also a more financial reason - promoting your own book. I am sure this is not the main reason to give online courses, and having the book is not an explicit requirement, but it does provide a way to benefit financially.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example, Prof. Daphne Koller from Stanford and Prof. Yaser Abu Mostafa from CalTech both offer free online Machine Learning courses, and both have relatively recent books that are top best-sellers on Amazon.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

They may not be the PI on the grant which pays the salary as it may contain other universities as well. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In conversation and in email, what is the best term to use for your postdoc boss? Something doesn't seem correct with the term boss or manager, or even supervisor.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="What is the best way (terminology) for a postdoc (PDRA) to refer to their bosssupervisor" AnswerId="tlTcq4ZCOmwJKAEe92nhWA==" Author="1010" Date="2013-05-24T14:44:26.277" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;I've heard &quot;supervisor&quot;, &quot;advisor&quot; and &quot;mentor&quot;.  They can be clarified as &quot;postdoc advisor&quot;, etc, to avoid confusion with a Ph.D. advisor.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There's also the simpler &quot;I work with Professor Smith.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What is the best way (terminology) for a postdoc (PDRA) to refer to their bosssupervisor" AnswerId="tlTcq4ZCOmwJKAEe92nhWA==" Author="5955" Date="2013-05-26T08:00:15.847" Text="I don't like to use 'supervisor' or 'advisor', because people already quite often think I'm still a PhD student, and I don't want to contribute more to that impression.  In conversation, adding the word 'postdoc' sounds funny to me.&#xA;'Mentor' is a good suggestion though.  It wouldn't always work, but as it happens, in my case my 'boss' is also my mentor (two different roles), so I might start using that./>

<answer QuestionId="What is the best way (terminology) for a postdoc (PDRA) to refer to their bosssupervisor" AnswerId="DjWBnIqwwGjzfFIueJbx7g==" Author="929" Date="2013-05-24T14:17:38.657" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I think it is really up to you (both you and to some extent the &quot;boss&quot;). The term &quot;boss&quot; to me is too managerial. I don't like the sound of &quot;my PI&quot;, even if the boss is a PI, they are not really your PI. I prefer advisor over supervisor, I think it sounds more supporting.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That said, since you think it is an issue, just refer to the boss as Dr. Smith and then say you are a post doc for Dr. Smith.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10209" Date="2013-05-24T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="What is the best way (terminology) for a postdoc (PDRA) to refer to their bosssupervisor" AnswerId="E2BzgWg7m7vk6RBhxMWVOA==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-24T15:54:30.443" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would lean toward &quot;advisor,&quot; as that encapsulates the role best in normal circumstances. You should be an independent researcher as a postdoc, so you shouldn't need much more than advice from your PI. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I personally reserve the term mentor for someone who advises you about (and throughout) your career, not just for a particular project. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10210	<question QuestionId="Is there a website that lists for a set of at least 1000 journals OpenAccess fees for publishing an article" Title="Is there a website that lists for a set of at least 1000 journals OpenAccess fees for publishing an article" Views="104" Tags="publishing,medicine,fees" " AnswerId="Bi+FNsP/zpypC7C9vHLxNA==" Author="1537" Date="2013-05-24T14:20:12.943" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;Many journals now are open access only and every article published (authors) must pay a fee.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Sometimes, this info can be hard to find. The journals does not put it visibly on the front page (next to impact factor).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If I want to compare 80 journals in the medical field and their charges - it is not easy.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is there a site that would 'monitor' this and have data on many journals. (any list with 50+ journals and prices listed will be a good answer) (even if domain specific) (medicine domain is preferred)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is there a website that lists for a set of at least 1000 journals OpenAccess fees for publishing an article" AnswerId="Bi+FNsP/zpypC7C9vHLxNA==" Author="6450" Date="2013-05-24T20:25:23.717" Text="Most medical journals may be operating under a few publishers and it may be less difficult than you think. Here is a [list](http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/scholarlycommunication/oa_fees.html) that may provide some starting materials./>
<comment QuestionId="Is there a website that lists for a set of at least 1000 journals OpenAccess fees for publishing an article" AnswerId="Bi+FNsP/zpypC7C9vHLxNA==" Author="7262" Date="2013-05-29T03:55:55.663" Text="I would submit to whatever journal is the best fit for my paper. I don't know how to find the prices up front. But getting published is very important so if you can save up the money, publish your research./>

<answer QuestionId="Is there a website that lists for a set of at least 1000 journals OpenAccess fees for publishing an article" AnswerId="VfDpw09DfFvCI81QIXgYOw==" Author="705" Date="2013-05-28T04:40:11.407" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;Try &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sherpa.ac.uk/romeo/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;the Sherpa/RoMEO list&lt;/a&gt;, which is the most definitive list of open access journals that I know of.  It covers many different fields.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't know why you are set on 1000 journals.  You can only publish your paper in one journal.  What's important is not the number of journals, but finding one good journal that is a great fit for your paper.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">
