academia.stackexchange.com_10212	<question QuestionId="What do you call research that has no hypothesis" Title="What do you call research that has no hypothesis" Views="775" Tags="thesis" " AnswerId="T86RI0tlnJGMAHkq+wFPIA==" Author="7220" Date="2013-05-24T14:44:50.500" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Background:&lt;/strong&gt;&#xA;I'm just wondering - I'm writing my bachelor's &quot;thesis&quot; in information-systems management, which should in theory be a paper about a hypothesis I make, an experiment and an evaluation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have an &quot;experiment&quot; which is comparing reality of information-systems management to various theories of information-systems management.&#xA;I have my evaluation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But my &quot;thesis&quot;... is basically my assumption based on experience that says: &quot;theory is based on assumptions that practice do not always exist&quot;. And my &quot;experiment&quot; neither proves nor disproves this triviality, but is supposed to show how you can tailor the management theory for it to be useful under economic constraints to a real specific problem.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Question:&lt;/strong&gt; &#xA;What should I call this thing, since it isn't a thesis?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What do you call research that has no hypothesis" AnswerId="T86RI0tlnJGMAHkq+wFPIA==" Author="49" Date="2013-05-25T00:59:38.457" Text="&quot;thesis&quot; (a dissertation / requirement for a degree) != &quot;thesis&quot; (a proposition stated or put forward for consideration, especially one to be discussed and proved or to be maintained against objections)./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10212" Date="2013-05-24T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10212" Date="2013-05-24T00:00:00.000/>

From what you've written, your hypothesis is that &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;you can tailor the [information-systems] management theory for it to be useful under economic constraints to a real specific problem&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You might also be doing &lt;strong&gt;exploratory research&lt;/strong&gt;, or &lt;strong&gt;blue-skies research&lt;/strong&gt;, where you don't start with a research question, you start with a direction, subject or area, and go wandering off looking for interesting problems.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="What do you call research that has no hypothesis" AnswerId="ZlxTdOol3GUl6fpwVS+AmA==" Author="10920" Date="2014-01-23T12:29:15.130" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;If you have results but no hypothesis, create the hypothesis that explains your results.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;While may be &quot;theoretically not correct&quot;, it is not uncommon to create the hypothesis as the explanation of already obtained results, and only later perform more experiments that additionally prove and maybe help to correct / extend it. Many major discoveries originated this way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="16086" Date="2014-01-23T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10214	<question QuestionId="How do you record your lectures" Title="How do you record your lectures" Views="608" Tags="teaching" " AnswerId="CPsZWVQKtesEsim7Vggfrg==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-24T15:11:05.403" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;While reading &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/10202/what-are-the-benefits-for-universities-professors-to-record-online-courses&quot;&gt;this question&lt;/a&gt;, and specifically Chris Gregg's answer, I started to think about recording my lectures in order to help students review, help students who missed class, and generally provide a way for people to learn about the subjects I teach.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, how do teachers (with the same goal as I wrote) record their lectures? Do they simply ask someone to record them with a video camera? Do they go in and do more serious editing like you see in Coursera videos where the video transitions between the lecturer's face and slides being drawn on by the lecturer (as described &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/2853/device-for-writing-a-lecture-with-a-stylus-for-video-lecture-recording&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;)? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm curious what my options are, considering my university provides zero support for this idea of recording lectures.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How do you record your lectures" AnswerId="CPsZWVQKtesEsim7Vggfrg==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-27T09:55:20.217" Text="This looks related: [Using iMovie and Keynote to Make a Web-Based Keynote](http://www.insidehighered.com/blogs/student-affairs-and-technology/using-imovie-and-keynote-make-web-based-keynote)/>
<comment QuestionId="How do you record your lectures" AnswerId="CPsZWVQKtesEsim7Vggfrg==" Author="4209" Date="2014-02-14T04:17:50.380" Text="&quot;help students who missed class&quot; I think you meant to write, &quot;help students to miss class&quot;.  Because if you provide good video recordings of your lectures, many will elect to do just that, thinking they can skip class and just catch up online. If you're OK with that, then try it. I myself feel it's not good to encourage this at a brick and mortar college./>
<comment QuestionId="How do you record your lectures" AnswerId="CPsZWVQKtesEsim7Vggfrg==" Author="4461" Date="2013-05-24T15:45:38.497" Text="Thanks for the shout-out!  [This is what I said about the topic when it came up a couple of months ago](http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/9221/how-much-effort-it-takes-to-record-video-courses/9224#9224).  I don't edit at all, but I do provide slides separately because it's hard to read on the board when I'm presenting./>

<answer QuestionId="How do you record your lectures" AnswerId="QBUpMgUgydbQhy73v8h2wg==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-24T21:50:02.117" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;The system my department uses for large lecture classes captures two video feeds: One showing the lecturer and the screen, taken from a camera mounted on the ceiling, the other showing whatever is currently being projected onto the screen, captured on route to the projector.  (I normally lecture with a document camera, printer paper, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sharpie.com/Pages/GlobalLanding.aspx&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Sharpies&lt;/a&gt;, and the &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuisenaire_rods&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;occasional&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dice#Non-cubic&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;small&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tower_of_Hanoi&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;prop&lt;/a&gt;.)  Audio is captured separately from a microphone on the instructor's lapel.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My department's playback system allows the students to show either or both videos, at adjustable sizes, with synchronized playback, and to slow down or speed up playback.  The capturing system automatically locates transitions between slides (or, in my case, new pieces of paper) and provides navigation landmarks for the students.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The system is almost entirely automated.  In particular, the lecture videos are not edited at all.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I also provide detailed &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cs.uiuc.edu/~jeffe/teaching/algorithms/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;course notes&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10221" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10221" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How do you record your lectures" AnswerId="NzxbLONCJ1nGCh7/i0bAiA==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-24T15:44:22.890" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;If my lecture is done via a presentation (not my preferred method, but necessary for some classes), I record the audio of my lectures along with a &quot;video&quot; of the slides I use. I use Camtasia to record everything, so the only other thing I need is a microphone. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When I give lectures at the blackboard I don't record them. However, for those lectures I provide a fairly detailed set of course notes. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How do you record your lectures" AnswerId="GblHtNTfhYbLp0seOzBv8w==" Author="7221" Date="2013-05-24T16:19:14.833" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;My preference for teaching undergraduate courses (in physics) is:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Audio-record the lecture using a small MP3 player hung around my neck, and provide the file to students as a MP3 file&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Write coherent notes on the blackboard that students can use as the basis for their own notes&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I specifically do &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; do the following, which I believe is harmful to students' learning in such courses:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Provide detailed printed notes&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Use slides (except for occasional complex Figures and animations)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

You could then provide your lectures to more people. At Big Marker you can invite people to your online class. You could invite 100s or 1000s of people to your online lecture.&#xA;It's just an idea. I used Big Marker when I used to tutor groups of students online. It is very easy to use and you can even monetize your lectures. (Although it could be against university policy. Maybe not because they are your lectures.)&#xA;Good Luck!&#xA;Kim   &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10223	<question QuestionId="Should I mention my references university role (administrative) when listing" Title="Should I mention my references university role (administrative) when listing" Views="109" Tags="university,references" " AnswerId="Zxk2hjPNgDVnwLsWMUFV1g==" Author="user7224" Date="2013-05-25T02:00:10.393" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have a list of references in my CV. One of them happens to be the Dean of the graduate school and the other a Vice Chancellor. Both of these roles are administrative and their primary position is that of a Professor. Would listing these referees as&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;John H. Doeberg&#xA;Professor and Dean of the Graduate School&#xA;University of Foo&#xA;&#xA;Jane Q. Publicowski&#xA;Professor and Vice Chancellor of Academic Affairs&#xA;University of Bar&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;be better (give more credence/weight) than simply listing them as a Professor. I know that ultimately what they write in those letters is what matters, but for the purposes of this question, it can be safely assumed that both letters are going to be stellar recommendations.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10223" Date="2013-05-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10223" Date="2013-05-25T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Should I mention my references university role (administrative) when listing" AnswerId="IgCULSdnzYXEH6MNcwjQIA==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-25T04:31:00.943" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;The thing to remember here is that your reference letter writers will be providing official letters, and therefore will be including their full titles (presumably the letterhead will list this). In such a case, it doesn't really seem to make much sense to &quot;hide&quot; the status of the person writing the letter. Moreover, if the position is one which will include some administrative duties, a letter of reference from someone doing university administration might even be a plus.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10226" Date="2013-12-29T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Should I mention my references university role (administrative) when listing" AnswerId="UKgxrZgZhiALx8RVL4XeLw==" Author="346" Date="2013-05-25T03:26:14.633" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;You haven't said what the letters are for. If it's for a position based on academic credentials (whether in academia or industry), I doubt it makes much of a difference. If the position involves administrative responsibilities, then mentioning this would help, so the people requesting the letter would make sure to ask them. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10227	<question QuestionId="What does &quotFirst Class or 21 Honours degree&quot mean" Title="What does &quotFirst Class or 21 Honours degree&quot mean" Views="2254" Tags="phd,application" " AnswerId="hCk00Kg4RcptZlEjzcxCbg==" Author="7226" Date="2013-05-25T14:39:18.640" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;A PhD position for which I am planning to apply notes:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Applicants should have (or expect to achieve) a minimum of a First Class or 2.1 Honours degree.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The position is in the UK, but I live in another EU country. What does &quot;First Class or 2.1 Honours degree&quot; mean, and how do I know if I satisfy that condition?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The grades at my university are given as fail, 3, 4 and 5.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10227" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10227" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10227" Date="2013-05-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10227" Date="2013-05-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10227" Date="2013-05-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10227" Date="2013-05-26T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="What does &quotFirst Class or 21 Honours degree&quot mean" AnswerId="ZmTxnTcK56TS6bYoZepOBg==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-25T15:33:30.703" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;The &quot;definitions,&quot; such as they exist, of the different degrees, &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_undergraduate_degree_classification&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;are available from Wikipedia&lt;/a&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Essentially, &quot;first-class honours&quot; and &quot;2.1 (or 2:1) honours&quot; are the top two categories of honors degrees in the UK system—sort of like the &lt;em&gt;summa cum laude&lt;/em&gt; and &lt;em&gt;magna cum laude&lt;/em&gt; in American universities. Although the requirements for awarding them appear to be fairly uniform between schools (with the possible exception of Oxford and Cambridge—see dbmag9's comment below), given that each university may have different standards for how they &quot;translate&quot; degrees from other countries, your best bet is to contact the university's international office (or equivalent), to determine if they will consider your degree to be comparable.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What does &quotFirst Class or 21 Honours degree&quot mean" AnswerId="ZmTxnTcK56TS6bYoZepOBg==" Author="6899" Date="2013-05-26T10:07:46.687" Text="I wouldn't say that the requirements for a First or 2.1 'differ substantially' within the UK; it's pretty consistently 70% for a First and 60% for a 2.1. What might differ is the difficulty of achieving that normalised percentage, and how much work will have been involved in the degree generally./>
<comment QuestionId="What does &quotFirst Class or 21 Honours degree&quot mean" AnswerId="ZmTxnTcK56TS6bYoZepOBg==" Author="6879" Date="2013-05-27T18:44:04.763" Text="Don't be confused by the low percentages mentioned by dbmag9: results are typically normalised lower in the UK than many other places. Typically around 10–12% of our undergraduates manage a 1st, and around 30–40% a 2:1./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10231" Date="2013-05-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10231" Date="2013-05-26T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10231" Date="2013-12-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10231" Date="2013-12-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10231" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10231" Date="2013-05-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10231" Date="2013-05-26T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10228	<question QuestionId="Etiquette of publishing (continued) research after graduation with an MS degree" Title="Etiquette of publishing (continued) research after graduation with an MS degree" Views="238" Tags="publishing,masters,etiquette" " AnswerId="8rO+OPwk4DSM7zprgg8mxw==" Author="7227" Date="2013-05-25T15:09:28.790" Score="4" Text="&lt;h2&gt;Situation&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am soon (maybe...) going to graduate with a thesis-based MS in a technical field. The past year and a half has been incredibly frustrating from a research perspective, as my advisor has insisted on telling me exactly what and how to research, essentially prohibiting me from exploring any of my ideas which are not approved by him. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I believe this is because I unfortunately chose a research area for my MS directly related to his PhD work from some time ago.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have, for purposes of finishing my degree program, simply acquiesced to his requests in the hopes of finishing as this degree has dragged on for far longer than I want and my current goal is to simply be finished with school officially.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am currently working full-time (after working in research on campus for ~2.5 years) and have no intent to pursue a PhD in the near future and if so, absolutely not with my current advisor.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Question&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I do have personal interest in my research and can see myself exploring my own interests post-graduation, which could result in publishable material. I have no interest in giving my current advisor credit for any of this, should it happen. I also understand he likely would be pretty upset should I actually publish related to my MS work without his involvement.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Are there standard etiquette, unspoken rules, or things to be aware of, within either the academic world or research world which address this situation? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;I am posting this anonymously but will be able to clarify&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Etiquette of publishing (continued) research after graduation with an MS degree" AnswerId="8rO+OPwk4DSM7zprgg8mxw==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-25T19:17:34.930" Text="Did your advisor make a significant intellectual contribution to your work?  If so, you _cannot_ publish that work without him.  If not, it's your work; do whatever you like./>
<comment QuestionId="Etiquette of publishing (continued) research after graduation with an MS degree" AnswerId="8rO+OPwk4DSM7zprgg8mxw==" Author="7227" Date="2013-05-27T13:30:12.577" Text="@JeffE to my thesis work, I suppose. But to any research which I would be doing post-masters, no./>

<answer QuestionId="Etiquette of publishing (continued) research after graduation with an MS degree" AnswerId="HQljLWtA9HpUYgyagmb2ow==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-25T15:25:56.403" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;The big issue here is the following: will you need to have your master's thesis advisor write you a letter of recommendation in the near future? If so, then it will be potentially a big problem to publish material from your thesis without his involvement. This will provoke a response, which could be damaging to, for instance, job applications or graduate school admissions. So tread carefully before trying to publish the MS work.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;However,&lt;/em&gt; since your advisor has proscribed work in other directions as part of your thesis, you could certainly explore those on your own. In such a case—since it isn't an outgrowth of your thesis work, but essentially a &quot;parallel&quot; work, you wouldn't need to share co-author credit with him. This is especially true if you write the paper and direct the research yourself; in such cases, he has no real claim to being on the paper. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Etiquette of publishing (continued) research after graduation with an MS degree" AnswerId="HQljLWtA9HpUYgyagmb2ow==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-26T19:36:43.987" Text="This answer presupposes that advisors are automatically coauthors, which is not true in all fields./>
<comment QuestionId="Etiquette of publishing (continued) research after graduation with an MS degree" AnswerId="HQljLWtA9HpUYgyagmb2ow==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-27T03:28:29.120" Text="@JeffE: Not really: the only presupposition here is that the advisor is a control freak. Even if you're in a discipline where the student could publish independently, if the advisor is left out of the loop but finds out about it, I think the student will still be in a bad situation. Not necessarily in every situation, but definitely in this one./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10229	<question QuestionId="Can I have both my supervisors write reference letters" Title="Can I have both my supervisors write reference letters" Views="781" Tags="phd,application" " AnswerId="mPnm9/0aKycEb6B0GM3imA==" Author="7226" Date="2013-05-25T15:22:09.163" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;It seems like most PhD applications require at least two reference letter. One of my Master's thesis supervisors (a PhD) has written me a reference letter. Can I ask my other supervisor (a PhD student) to write me the second one, or would that be redundant?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The other alternative letter writers are all professors who have only seen me in class and can't really comment on my research potential.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10229" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10229" Date="2013-05-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10229" Date="2013-05-25T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Can I have both my supervisors write reference letters" AnswerId="m+W1niR2L/Vsfg9It8/vSA==" Author="6820" Date="2013-05-25T16:46:04.603" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;I've sat on my department's graduate studies committee during application season, and so I can provide at least one point of anecdata for how PhD application recommendation letters are used, at least in my tiny corner of the academy. YMMV.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;First, These letters are among the last things that are looked at. We don't have rigorous thresholds for grades, GRE scores, subject GRE scores, publications, etc. But all of those things are used to &quot;objectively&quot; sort the pool. First the obvious admits are skimmed off the top, and fellowship offers are made to some of them. This is the first place where letters are important, since quotes are mined from those letters to try and win funding for these students from the University (i.e., we entice the student with a prestigious award, and the department doesn't even have to pay for her!) The money quote is usually a ranking and/or direct comparison -- &lt;em&gt;&quot;In my twenty years at Giant State University, I've seen no more than 5 students of X's caliber. I would say her talents remind me of Y's at that age, who is now a professor at Prestigious U&quot;&lt;/em&gt; -- and this is why even a mediocre teaching letter is more useful for this purpose than a nice letter from a PhD student (who can not be counted on to have a reasonable intuition for another's future potential).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Second, we work our way down to the marginal cases; this is much more difficult since the marginal cases require a more holistic take on the application package. No one gets immediately thrown out just for bad grades or a bad subject GRE score, but we expect some explanation of a mitigating circumstance (not an excuse!) in the personal statement, and hopefully reflected in the letters as well. For example, if you were dinged in the first pass for a low GPA, we would like to see that it was a bad first year (and not a bad fifth...); that you are on an upswing. If you think you might be a marginal case for whatever reason, the letter from the PhD student might be helpful -- perhaps you don't have any publications, but the PhD student can vouch for your work and verify that you have something in preparation, or explain why your project failed (projects often fail!) but that nonetheless you mastered some state-of-the-art technique on the way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;On the other hand&lt;/em&gt; it is a big waving red flag if those things are then &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; pointed out by your actual boss (the PhD holding supervisor). If you think the student will write a &lt;em&gt;better&lt;/em&gt; letter, then you're probably best off having that student lobby on your behalf with the professor, to make sure the &lt;em&gt;professor's&lt;/em&gt; letter is strong, and then get a second letter from someone else.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would strongly recommend you do not ask for a letter from a non-academic unless it was an actual research position (and even then, these can be iffy if the supervisor has no letter-writing experience). On occasion we see glowing letters from a student's supervisor at their summer construction job, or a call center for a political campaign. Well-rounded students are great, but such letters are almost useless.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Can I have both my supervisors write reference letters" AnswerId="m+W1niR2L/Vsfg9It8/vSA==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-26T05:11:30.123" Text="_These letters are among the last things that are looked at._ — Then your admissions procedures are **very** different from mine.  We don't admit _anyone_ without strong letters./>
<comment QuestionId="Can I have both my supervisors write reference letters" AnswerId="m+W1niR2L/Vsfg9It8/vSA==" Author="5955" Date="2013-05-26T07:52:15.233" Text="@JeffE:  I understood that sentence as meaning that other factors are first used as a filter, rather than that they actually admit anyone without looking at their letters./>
<comment QuestionId="Can I have both my supervisors write reference letters" AnswerId="m+W1niR2L/Vsfg9It8/vSA==" Author="6820" Date="2013-05-27T02:53:11.237" Text="Fair enough, @JeffE; although we should be careful with what we mean by &quot;strong letters.&quot; I've certainly seen students accepted who had steller credentials, but I thought the letters were &quot;weak&quot; in the sense that the writer had no idea how to write a reference (or the student made the mistake of asking a famous person who has never actually interacted with them). We certainly would be wary of students, regardless of credentials, if the letters were negative in their content. This is not what I typically mean by a &quot;weak letter&quot;./>
<comment QuestionId="Can I have both my supervisors write reference letters" AnswerId="m+W1niR2L/Vsfg9It8/vSA==" Author="6820" Date="2013-05-27T02:57:41.183" Text="Also it might help to clarify that I'm not at a &quot;top&quot; program, so I have no idea if this is a cultural difference (I'm not in CS), or a &quot;taking what we can get&quot; heuristic that has been developed./>
<comment QuestionId="Can I have both my supervisors write reference letters" AnswerId="m+W1niR2L/Vsfg9It8/vSA==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-25T19:19:19.343" Text="I wouldn't restrict things to &quot;actual research positions.&quot; For example, in engineering, I would give a letter from a professional engineer substantial weight. In fact, some of the _best_ letters I've seen have come from non-academics. (Writing good letters, furthermore, is not the exclusive province of academics! And some academics can't write very good letters, either.)/>
<comment QuestionId="Can I have both my supervisors write reference letters" AnswerId="m+W1niR2L/Vsfg9It8/vSA==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-26T19:28:56.567" Text="@TaraB: There's a big difference between &quot;among the last&quot; and &quot;not the first&quot;./>

<answer QuestionId="Can I have both my supervisors write reference letters" AnswerId="6ZwpTQooqZUMBLBYOrb9aw==" Author="6144" Date="2013-05-25T16:21:08.340" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;As it was mentioned before, you can obtain reference letters from your supervisors, in case that you have done some internship job for obtaining your master´s.&#xA;Also you can talk directly with one of your past professors, and explain them about your research interests (try to check first which professors have the same research interests). Then you can ask, in a nice way, if they can give you a hand with a recommendation letter. Most of the time they will agree to help you with that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Can I have both my supervisors write reference letters" AnswerId="bVd8ndk8Bcbir/nBUBdrSA==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-25T15:39:06.277" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;The main point of the letters of recommendation are to comment on your abilities, and to place them in the context of other people the recommender has known and worked with. The better they can comment, and the larger the number of people the recommender has worked with and therefore can compare you to, the better the recommendation will likely be.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For this reason, it is not nearly as helpful to get a letter from a PhD student as from someone who is more experienced and has likely worked with more master's students. On the other hand, if the option is to get a letter who can &lt;em&gt;only&lt;/em&gt; comment on your class work, I would opt for including the PhD student's recommendation letter.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, if you have had a non-academic person (perhaps an internship supervisor or similar) in a related discipline who could comment on your work, this might be a suitable alternative. (See wsc's answer below.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_1023	<question QuestionId="Etiquette to take external help" Title="Etiquette to take external help" Views="196" Tags="graduate-school,advisor,etiquette" " AnswerId="8/Mqi8RIbduhXBzy+cm6RQ==" Author="user107" Date="2012-04-05T13:16:45.510" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;Assume that the student (during his PhD) is faced with a problem which he and his advisor are both completely new to; The advisor is &lt;strong&gt;trying to&lt;/strong&gt; help the student but owing to his lack of experience/knowledge/intuition in the field, is unable to help much, What is the etiquette for the student to seek external help (particularly professors who have dealt with such problems and maybe their grad students).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Is it necessary to inform your advisor before going to other professors for help?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;How should one introduce the subject of external help when the advisor is clearly interested in tackling the problem without any help? &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Etiquette to take external help" AnswerId="8/Mqi8RIbduhXBzy+cm6RQ==" Author="96" Date="2012-04-05T16:53:23.110" Text="Isn't this just the sort of thing that subsidiary (secondary) supervisors are suited for?/>

<answer QuestionId="Etiquette to take external help" AnswerId="mqPqsQbvQX1XvDz9wT/+aA==" Author="12" Date="2012-04-05T17:48:57.120" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;You absolutely should inform your advisor that you are going to seek external help, even if they are against it. They are partly responsible for your studies and should know what's going on.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You could try introducing the subject as a collaboration rather than seeking help. If the person you want to approach has written a paper on the subject for example, you could say that it would be beneficial for your work to collaborate with them. As long as you at least create the impression that you're looking for interaction on the same level rather than just getting advice, I don't think you would have too much trouble convincing your advisor.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1027" Date="2012-04-05T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1027" Date="2012-04-05T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1027" Date="2012-04-24T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1027" Date="2012-04-06T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Etiquette to take external help" AnswerId="8rx3nA3JlT2L3HBTh1HXJA==" Author="612" Date="2012-04-07T21:49:39.597" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;The cardinal rule of interacting with advisors is that if you don't generally trust your advisor's advice, then you need a new advisor.  So you should start with the idea that your advisor's approach to any given situation is probably worth trying, and only give up on it if it's clearly not working out or seems contrary to what everyone else is saying.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Beyond that, I'm sure it varies between fields.  I wouldn't presume to offer advice to someone in a biology lab on how to sort this issue out, for example.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The most important thing, which you absolutely must do no matter what, is to inform your advisor in detail of any help you receive.  This is a matter of intellectual honesty, while everything else is a matter of convention or wise strategy.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What you want to avoid is the following scenario: you meet with X, then meet with Y and explain what X said, then meet with X and convey Y's response to X's ideas, then meet with Y again and relay information back from X, etc.  If you try this and are a little vague about the line between your own ideas and what you learned in your last meeting, then you can pull it off for a while, but eventually you'll be in big trouble when X and Y talk.  Even if you never actually lied, but just let people assume you were contributing more than you actually did, they'll be very unhappy if they decide you weren't contributing enough.  [And this can be a particular danger for students: if someone says something cryptic and then you figure it out later, is that because you are adding new ideas and insights, or because you are catching up to where the expert already was?  It can be hard for a beginner to judge, and this potential for confusion is a valid worry for advisors.]&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As to how to introduce the idea to an advisor who resists getting outside help, the main thing is to understand why.  Is it because your advisor feels this is an important learning experience for you?  Is the advisor convinced that the problem is not as difficult as you fear?  (And, if so, can you make a compelling case that it is?)  There are also more worrisome scenarios.  For example, maybe the local expert in this area is notorious for competing with or undermining students, or has a bad relationship with your advisor.  Your advisor may be reluctant to say this explicitly, so if he/she seems to be ruling out a natural collaborator for unclear reasons, then you should ask about other people you might talk with instead.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1048" Date="2012-04-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1048" Date="2012-04-24T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1048" Date="2012-04-07T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1048" Date="2014-04-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1048" Date="2013-12-29T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10235	<question QuestionId="Identifying students purposes and institutions purposes" Title="Identifying students purposes and institutions purposes" Views="146" Tags="teaching,university,students" " AnswerId="TiNxPpCBHVM+21353yn7uA==" Author="7229" Date="2013-05-25T19:01:45.847" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I don't necessarily consider it a hardship to teach calculus or the like to students whose preparation in prerequisites is weak, but but I am offended by the practice of making it a personal policy to treat learning the material ONLY as a price paid to get a grade to put on one's resume, rather than as the thing they're there for.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;I'm wondering how to identify instances of such behavior quickly when they occur.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;How can one identify institutions that tolerate or encourage my position as outlined in my first paragraph above, and those that are hostile toward it?  I think the latter---where that hostility may exist---often include respectable institutions in which lots of students want to get degrees in law or business or the like.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Identifying students purposes and institutions purposes" AnswerId="TiNxPpCBHVM+21353yn7uA==" Author="1482" Date="2014-05-01T00:04:30.303" Text="Why would it be useful to &quot;identify instances of such behavior quickly when they occur?&quot; I suppose you could begin the first class meeting by asking for a show of hands: how many people wouldn't be here today if calculus wasn't a requirement for their major? I'd guess that 80% of your students would raise their hands. Then what?/>

<answer QuestionId="Identifying students purposes and institutions purposes" AnswerId="QVibjZmWU7Ut1Ju2BQXRhQ==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-26T04:04:17.607" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;I understand that you are offended by students who do not take your subject as seriously as you do but that is just the way some students are.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are students who are really interested and there are those who are not. In the case of calculus, if a student is required to take it for their non-math major then you will certainly have students who just want the grade. One way around this is to only teach elective classes but that will not work for everyone (I'm not sure it would work for any teacher).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Still, your questions are clear. How do you find the students who don't really care? I find that they usually bubble to the surface quite quickly. I tend to be quite interactive with my students, asking lots of questions. I also give them additional 'required' reading. Even the required reading doesn't get read by the students who just want to pass and be done with it. So, those students who actually read the material and can answer it meaningfully in class are the students you are looking for.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now, as for identifying institutions I will say that I have read a lot and talked to a lot of teachers and one thing EVERY serious teacher wants is to teach a class of highly motivated students who care deeply for their studies. This is simply unrealistic and I have never heard of a teacher who actually achieves that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think the better question to ask is: &lt;strong&gt;How can I motivate a deep love of my subject in my students?&lt;/strong&gt; By stimulating their desires, you will naturally end up with what you want. However, this is not easy and it takes a lot of time and effort. However, you seem like a serious teacher, so perhaps you can make the investment. Certainly the results, if you succeed, would likely be very rewarding for you.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My perspective is that a great teacher has no bad students. By this, I mean that a great teacher is able to motivate their students to &lt;em&gt;want&lt;/em&gt; to learn the material. By this measure I am not a great teacher, but I keep trying.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Identifying students purposes and institutions purposes" AnswerId="QVibjZmWU7Ut1Ju2BQXRhQ==" Author="285" Date="2013-05-26T14:54:37.110" Text="@earthling I think you misunderstood my question. I quoted the end of your para, which said it was unrealistic to teach a class of highly motivated students etc., and then asked whether even a grad class cannot satisfy those criteria. Good grad students in my experience are highly motivated./>
<comment QuestionId="Identifying students purposes and institutions purposes" AnswerId="QVibjZmWU7Ut1Ju2BQXRhQ==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-26T14:57:41.860" Text="@FaheemMitha I did misunderstand...should be asleep already. From the graduate level classes I've taught and the teachers I've spoken with....my answers are still the same - it is VERY hard to get all the students motivated, but I do believe it is worth while to continually try to accomplish just that./>
<comment QuestionId="Identifying students purposes and institutions purposes" AnswerId="QVibjZmWU7Ut1Ju2BQXRhQ==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-26T06:51:39.643" Text="@JeffE Yes, I agree that it is a bit extreme. However, extremity aside, my point is that it is the teacher's responsibility to do what he/she can to motivate the student(s). To the extent we are unsuccessful in our motivational efforts, I think we have failed (at least partially) to fulfill our maximum potential as educators./>
<comment QuestionId="Identifying students purposes and institutions purposes" AnswerId="QVibjZmWU7Ut1Ju2BQXRhQ==" Author="7229" Date="2013-05-26T16:18:24.593" Text="My concern here was not mainly to inspire a deep love of the subject (that comes later) but rather to quickly inform those who regard learning the subject as merely a price paid to get a grade, that my obligation to them is to give them an opportunity to do something worthwhile instead./>
<comment QuestionId="Identifying students purposes and institutions purposes" AnswerId="QVibjZmWU7Ut1Ju2BQXRhQ==" Author="285" Date="2013-05-26T10:46:33.093" Text="&quot;This is simply unrealistic and I have never heard of a teacher who actually achieves that.&quot; Not even in grad school courses?/>
<comment QuestionId="Identifying students purposes and institutions purposes" AnswerId="QVibjZmWU7Ut1Ju2BQXRhQ==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-26T14:26:22.253" Text="@FaheemMitha So, are you saying we should stop trying? Should we say we are good enough and stop trying to motivate those students who seem unmotivated?/>
<comment QuestionId="Identifying students purposes and institutions purposes" AnswerId="QVibjZmWU7Ut1Ju2BQXRhQ==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-26T05:09:15.610" Text="_My perspective is that a great teacher has no bad students_ — This is a little extreme, unless you believe that there are no great teachers./>

<answer QuestionId="Identifying students purposes and institutions purposes" AnswerId="CTIa7BUqL/jrqf9xfYRAVQ==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-25T19:49:56.903" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I don't think there's an easy eay to identify this behavior without students directly approaching you and making it clear through questions like the ever-popular: &quot;Will this be on the exam?&quot; and grade-grubbing for every possible point. Without obvious signals, it's not really clear who's in it for a grade and who's there to learn—and it would be imprudent to try to prognosticate. The results may surprise you!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As far as an institutional perspective, I again don't know if there's a way to really lay things at the feet of the institution for &quot;encouraging&quot; such behavior. It can vary a lot from department to department, and even faculty member to faculty member. However, one issue can be to see how seriously the department you're interested in takes teaching duties. Is it something people are doing their best to get out of, or are they trying to do the best job they can with it? Does the department encourage &quot;out-of-the-box&quot; thinking in how to teach classes, or is it just something to get over and done with each semester?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But a lot of it also relies on your attitude. If you make it clear to the students that you're serious about them &lt;em&gt;learning&lt;/em&gt;, rather than just &lt;em&gt;regurgitating&lt;/em&gt; for the purpose of an exam, the students who stick with you will probably be more motivated than if they don't think you are invested in their learning. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10236" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10236" Date="2013-05-26T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10236" Date="2013-05-26T00:00:00.000/>

Of course your CV should include these adjunct roles as well, they just aren't your main affiliation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have developed a more intimate relationship with either the two institutions you teach part time at (like say you've been an adjunct for many years) you might consider listing them as an affiliation. Those part time adjunct gigs though don't typically support research activities that would result in outside roles such as a reviewer (for anything) or even being considered a specialist in the field.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10239	<question QuestionId="Do media interviews enhance or potentially spoil academic reputations" Title="Do media interviews enhance or potentially spoil academic reputations" Views="166" Tags="career,interview" " AnswerId="vGSf0zftsDChrf687xnAJA==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-26T10:14:20.297" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;During my research, asides from getting papers published, I have been interviewed for the radio and newspapers. My question is, are too many media 'appearances' a potential hindrance to someone early in their academic career?  Or is it also a case of 'all publicity is good'?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My main concern is being misquoted, which thankfully has not happened, though they exaggerated one (minor) point a tad.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10239" Date="2014-01-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10239" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10239" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10239" Date="2013-05-26T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Do media interviews enhance or potentially spoil academic reputations" AnswerId="WPG6pGV/7bRepPRQNZ3bwQ==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-26T10:38:00.933" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;The simple answer is that it depends on in what context the appearance occurs.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you become visible as an expert in your field your appearances will build your reputation among the public as an expert. As such you will gain a positive (trustworthy) reputation which I am sure will be seen as positive in many respects. The university will gain credit by having employees appear as experts In my country all faculty also are mandated to convey science to the general public and appearances in media is one way to do this. So my guess is that the department and the university as well s your own discipline will see this as beneficial.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Obviously, if you appear with politically incorrect views it will all be negative. Another problem that I am sure will appear is jealousy from colleagues who do not appear in media. In the end your success depends on how you get portrayed in the media. My university runs media training to ensure that faculty represent the university in an appropriate way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In the end positive media visibility is not likely to strongly affect your research career in terms increased funding, the systems should not really be influenced by it but we all al human. Media visibility will mainly affect the way you, your discipline, the university etc. is perceived by the public. It may, for example, influence the way politicians distribute research funding.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, media interviews can potentially both enhance or spoil a career depending on the context in which you appear. I believe it is important to know how media works and universities often have programs (and sometimes also rules) to help in such contacts. Depending on the type of question to which you are requested to respond you need to be able to assess how answers will be used or perceived. If the interviews are on non-controversial topics, it is probably not problematic but if you are approached on a burning issue, be aware and be savy&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Do media interviews enhance or potentially spoil academic reputations" AnswerId="WPG6pGV/7bRepPRQNZ3bwQ==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-26T19:35:06.887" Text="_In the end positive media visibilty is not likely to strongly affect your research career_ — I disagree.  The PhD students you work with have a _very_ strong effect on your research career, and publicly visible researchers attract significantly more PhD applicants./>
<comment QuestionId="Do media interviews enhance or potentially spoil academic reputations" AnswerId="WPG6pGV/7bRepPRQNZ3bwQ==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-26T10:42:57.973" Text="Excellent points - it is sometimes a bit of a minefield when it comes to these kind of things. It is a case of stcking to the topic and the facts of the topic./>

Some people told me that a master degree is very beneficial for my long-term career development. Unfortunately I do not think I can get into any good master program because of my terrible undergrad gpa + no academic references. A postgraduate certificate program requires nothing. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My question is, what is your point of view on postgraduate certificate in software engineering? Is it just a joke comparing to master degrees? What about starting salary?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Postgraduate certificationdiploma in software engineering" AnswerId="E23WtU8OxTe36kYtUH6hLQ==" Author="546" Date="2013-05-27T06:58:22.410" Text="This site is for Academia. I took out the off-topic phrase in the question./>

<answer QuestionId="Postgraduate certificationdiploma in software engineering" AnswerId="Azp8JXu6VBq+3hxS9bz23w==" Author="546" Date="2013-05-27T03:49:34.297" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;Short term wise, the postgraduate certificate will help you to find a better job with a higher salary because the certificate shows that you have some skill printed on the certificate. However, whatever the technology you learn while getting the certificate could become obsolete in a few years.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Long term wise, the master degree proves that you know more fundamentals than just a bachelor. It may not help you that much when looking for a job with better salary. Some employers would think you don't have the skills they want immediately. However, you'll learn those needed skills faster and better because you know more fundamentals.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you want to find a job as of now, you want to have certificates. If you want to be an excellent software engineer in the future, you should get a master degree&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

As you probably know there are commonalities between programming languages such as input/output, conditionals, loops, etc. the difference lies in how they are each implemented. However, by knowing one language(i.e. Java) you could learn another(i.e. C#) efficiently and in a shorter time. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is also true that some employers might think you're overqualified since you have a Masters but others will recognize the added value your advanced knowledge could bring their company and the compensation may even reflect that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10244	<question QuestionId="Should I add references to conference presentations" Title="Should I add references to conference presentations" Views="960" Tags="conference,citations,presentation,references" " AnswerId="k+Tue3LL+kg9X/OSE76zYw==" Author="532" Date="2013-05-27T03:54:24.227" Score="17" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am preparing a CS conference presentation and wondering how can I handle the references. I am thinking about three different possibilities:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Ignore them!&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Just list them at the end of the presentation&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;List them &lt;em&gt;and&lt;/em&gt; cite them within the presentation. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I chose the first option since anyone interested can go and check the whole set of references in the actual paper.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Does this mean not crediting the others for their work? How this is usually handled in CS conferences?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Should I add references to conference presentations" AnswerId="iuARZnMB1p0mYCUjJcfFlw==" Author="5674" Date="2013-05-27T05:31:40.727" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;I don't know if there is a specific way within the CS community but the way most established seniors seem to do in my field is to note down the reference at the bottom of the slide where they refer to someone's results/figures. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think this is a better approach than to list them all in the end, because the audience gets the reference together with the content, that way you don't have to puzzle the references and the content 6 months after you attended the presentation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If the people you are referring to are people you have had collaborations or communication with, it would not hurt to have them listed in a &quot;thanks to&quot; or more formally &quot;acknowledgements&quot; slide. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Hope it helps&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10245" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10245" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10245" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Should I add references to conference presentations" AnswerId="JcrbTwMN0T3W/8ODklqzGw==" Author="958" Date="2013-05-27T10:42:30.060" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;Applied mathematician here; my solution is putting them on the same slide as the material. I use formats such as [Someone '99], [Lin WW, '00] (initials are almost mandatory for some common surnames), [Doe &lt;em&gt;et al&lt;/em&gt;, book '04], [P and SomeoneElse, preprint '12] (my name is always abbreviated to an initial, which is a common convention). I find it a good compromise between clarity and shortness: I don't need to include a full sentence, but only the names in brackets.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can use a different color or font to differentiate them visually from the text --- preferably something light but readable, a color that does not attract much attention.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I use them sparingly nevertheless --- overall I have typically less than 10 such citations in a 15-20 slide talk.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This makes immediately clear whether I think that a theorem is new/mine or not. Its original authors could be in the audience, so I think it's important to acknowledge them properly.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If your slides are already so cramped that these citations won't fit, then you have a much bigger problem. :)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10257" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10257" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10257" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10257" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Should I add references to conference presentations" AnswerId="2U1ED5ywHMbtu5N7Aqx/qg==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-27T07:28:59.910" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;Not including citations would be a very bad idea, asides from the reasons given above, there is a risk that someone would claim that you are plagiarising their work - even though you aren't.  I have seen this happen before.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Perhaps place an in-slide (akin to in-text) reference on each slide and a slide at the end with the references, or if possible, make a clear citation to the main reference used on the slides where necessary.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10248" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10248" Date="2014-01-31T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10248" Date="2014-01-10T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10248" Date="2013-10-02T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Should I add references to conference presentations" AnswerId="YfQfevdJspdu5e9Qri4cyA==" Author="7116" Date="2013-05-27T11:05:00.363" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;As a policy, it is a far better idea to always add a relevant citation, in small font, below every figure, formula, quotation, etc, that is not yours and which you are building upon. I do this even in lectures, which students always get after.&#xA;The cost of adding a citation in small font is really small, but by not doing it you &lt;em&gt;risk&lt;/em&gt; exposing yourself to unnecessary troubles because you &lt;em&gt;might&lt;/em&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;give the impression of being careless or oblivious about the work of others&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;enrage the occasional professor attending your lecture, when s/he sees her/his work is not acknowledge&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;create unnecessary tensions with colleagues&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;be accused of plagiarism&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Do yourself a favor: cite even in presentations.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10258" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10258" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10258" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10258" Date="2013-09-30T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Should I add references to conference presentations" AnswerId="TPpz0wYSD0pOu/S/piDTOw==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-27T05:44:46.347" Score="14" Text="&lt;p&gt;If the slides you're using are going to have &quot;independent life,&quot;—in other words, if you're going to make them available separately from the conference paper (on your website, for instance), then the citations should be included as part of the presentation. I would follow posdef's example and place the citations on the same slide as where it's needed; this will save the reader from having to flip back and forth between different parts of the presentation or between the presentation and the paper. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Not including the citations is a bad idea, because it means you are potentially failing to give people the credit they deserve for ideas that were originally theirs. Even though it's &quot;just&quot; a conference presentation doesn't mean that the rules of crediting people for their work should be ignored. (Citing the work of others is also the right thing to do from the perspective of &quot;playing nice with others.&quot; Taking credit for other people's work can make them leerier of working with you.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10246" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10246" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10246" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10246" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10246" Date="2014-01-10T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10246" Date="2014-01-31T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10246" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10247	<question QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" Title="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" Views="1299" Tags="publishing,research,public-domain" " AnswerId="87R5+nvqZ3cUOmEg9Gu98w==" Author="4360" Date="2013-05-27T06:29:11.613" Score="35" Text="&lt;p&gt;While researching a topic area I have come across a number of papers that claim to improve on the state of the art and have been published at respected outlets (e.g. CVPR, ICIP). These papers are often written in a way that obscures some of the details and their methods can be lacking in detail. Upon contacting these authors for more information and asking if they would kindly make their source code available they stop replying or decline the offer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Why are computer science researchers reluctant to share their code?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would have expected that disseminating your source code would have positive effects for the author, e.g., greater recognition and visibility within the community and more citations.  What am I missing?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;For the future, what are some better ways to approach fellow researchers that will result in greater success at getting a copy of their source code?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="87R5+nvqZ3cUOmEg9Gu98w==" Author="5669" Date="2013-05-28T09:06:04.740" Text="You may want to take a look at Collective Mind initiative: http://www.hipeac.net/system/files/grigori.pdf and corresponding publication model http://ctuning.org/cm-journal/>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="87R5+nvqZ3cUOmEg9Gu98w==" Author="285" Date="2013-05-28T16:06:26.650" Text="I could post an answer, but it would something like - how could we change things so that more people will publish their source code? Would that be acceptable, or does it belong to a different question?/>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="87R5+nvqZ3cUOmEg9Gu98w==" Author="705" Date="2013-05-28T16:08:09.067" Text="@FaheemMitha, that sounds like a different question to me -- but a good one.  Why don't you post a different question asking how to change things so that more CS researchers will share their source code?/>

<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="87R5+nvqZ3cUOmEg9Gu98w==" Author="2827" Date="2013-05-29T08:21:25.847" Text="The fix for this problem is simple, make CS research (and research in general) better funded.  The problem is there is no support for the cost of getting research code to a level of quality where maintenance costs are supportable./>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="87R5+nvqZ3cUOmEg9Gu98w==" Author="4360" Date="2013-05-29T11:13:34.783" Text="@DikranMarsupial I'm not convinced that throwing more money at researchers will improve the situation as they have limited time. I don't think that distributing high quality code is the issue, it's just an excuse people use. Releasing bad code is better than releasing none./>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="87R5+nvqZ3cUOmEg9Gu98w==" Author="2827" Date="2013-05-29T11:57:23.993" Text="additional funds will solve the problem as it means that either they can hire somebody to maintain the code or they can be bought out of other duties to release the time to do it themselves.  I like releasing code, and have done so in the past, the reason I don't release more is that I don't have the time for maintenance, that I know from experience is necessary.  I disagree that bad code is better than none, I wasted several weeks earlier this year trying to get someone else's research code to work, to no avail.  Of course the authors were of limited help as they have the same problems I do./>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="87R5+nvqZ3cUOmEg9Gu98w==" Author="2827" Date="2013-05-29T11:59:20.533" Text="I should add, my wife is quite active in providing code and is driven to distraction by the volume of user requests for help, bug fixes, extensions etc.  In my case there is a limited audience for my software, if you are in a field where there is a large audience, the cost of maintenance is *far* from trivial./>

<answer QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="mDBGP1u4c6hgKC0EyJCtBQ==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-27T07:32:09.577" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am not a CS researcher per se, but I am writing Android code for my research in Atmospheric Physics, so my view is somewhat limited.  However, I can say from my own experience that much of the code that I am developing and testing is part of a greater project that the team I am part of is developing. It is a mix of the rules I am bound by and the need to keep a portion of code under wraps for the time being.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10249" Date="2013-05-28T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10249" Date="2013-05-28T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="40RrZ0Frdy2+LAaVfG3pMQ==" Author="705" Date="2013-05-28T04:59:46.483" Score="18" Text="&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Why researchers might be reluctant to share their code:&lt;/strong&gt; In my experience, there are two common reasons why some/many researchers do not share their code.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;First, the code may give the researchers an important advantage for follow-on work.  It may help them get a step ahead of other researchers and publish follow-on research faster.  If the researchers have plans to do follow-on research, keeping their code secret gives them a competitive advantage and helps them avoid getting scooped by someone else.  (This may be good, or it may be bad; I'm not taking a position on that.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Second, a lot of research code is, well, research-quality.  The researchers probably thought it was good enough to test the paper's hypotheses, but that's all.  It may have many known problems; it may not have any documentation; it might be tricky to use; it might compile on only one platform; and so forth.  All of these may make it hard for someone else to use.  Or, it may take a bunch of work to explain how to someone else how to use the code.  Also, the code might be a prototype, but not production-quality.  It's not unusual to take shortcuts while coding: shortcuts that don't affect the research results and are fine in the context of a research paper, but that would be unacceptable for deployed production-quality code.  Some people are perfectionists, and don't like the idea of sharing code with known weaknesses or where they took shortcuts; they don't want to be embarrassed when others see the code.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The second reason is probably the more important one; it is very common.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;How to approach researchers:&lt;/strong&gt; My suggestion is to re-focus your interactions with those researchers.  What are your real goals?  Your real goals are to understand their algorithms better.  So, start from that perspective, and act accordingly.  If there are some parts in the paper that are hard to follow or ambiguous, start by reading and re-reading their paper, to see if there are some details you might have missed.  Think hard about how to fill in any missing gaps.  Make a serious effort on your own, first.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you are at a research level, and you've put in a serious effort to understand, and you still don't understand ... email the authors and ask them for clarification on the specific point(s) that you think are unclear.  Don't bother authors unnecessarily -- but if you show interest in their work and have a good question, many authors are happy to respond. They're just grateful that someone is reading their papers and interested enough in their work to study their work carefully and ask insightful questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But do make sure you are asking good questions.  Don't be lazy and ask the authors to clear up something that you could have figured out on your own with more thought.  Authors can sense that, and will write you off as a pest, not a valued colleague.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Very important:&lt;/strong&gt; Please understand that my answer explaining why researchers might not share their code is intended as a &lt;em&gt;descriptive&lt;/em&gt; answer, not a &lt;em&gt;prescriptive&lt;/em&gt; answer.  I am emphatically not making any judgements about whether their reasons are good ones, or whether researchers are right (or wrong) to think this way.  I'm not taking a position on whether researchers &lt;em&gt;should&lt;/em&gt; share their code or not; I'm just describing how some researchers &lt;em&gt;do&lt;/em&gt; behave.  What they &lt;em&gt;ought&lt;/em&gt; to do is an entirely different ball of wax.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The original poster asked for help understanding why many researchers do not share their code, and that's what I'm responding to.  Arguments about whether these reasons are good ones are subjective and off-topic for this question; if you want to have that debate, post a separate question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;And please, I urge you to use some empathy here.  Regardless of whether you think researchers are in right or wrong not to share their code in these circumstances, please understand that many researchers &lt;em&gt;do&lt;/em&gt; have reasons that feel valid and appropriate to them.  Try to understand their mindset before reflexively criticizing them.  I'm not trying to say that their reasons are necessarily right and good for the field.  I'm just saying that, if you want to persuade people to change their practices, it's important to first understand the motivations and structural forces that have influenced their current actions, before you launch into trying to browbeat them into acting differently.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Appendix: I definitely second Jan Gorzny's recommendation to read the article in SIAM News that he cites.  It is informative.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="40RrZ0Frdy2+LAaVfG3pMQ==" Author="546" Date="2013-05-28T05:14:47.603" Text="I appreciate the candidness and secerity of this answer./>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="40RrZ0Frdy2+LAaVfG3pMQ==" Author="4125" Date="2013-05-31T00:21:51.493" Text="+1 Most of the code is written to a deadline, be it a PhD student trying to finish up or a post doc getting a deliverable done in time. I know many people (myself firmly included) who would be embarrassed to be judged on their code quality rather than the actual research it supports./>
