<answer QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="ss3ByAQytmN+NRmeL/FkXg==" Author="787" Date="2013-05-27T09:18:57.067" Score="18" Text="&lt;p&gt;Stephen, I have just the same experience as you do, and my explanation is that the benefit/cost ratio is too low.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Packing a piece of software, so that it can be usable by another person, is difficult - often even more difficult than writing it in the first place. It requires, among others:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;writing documentation and installation instructions,&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;making sure the code is runnable on a variety of computers and operating systems (I code on Ubuntu, but you may code on Windows, so I have to get a Windows virtual machine to make sure it works there too), &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;answering maintenance questions of the form &quot;why do I get this and that compilation error when I compile your program on the new version of Ubuntu&quot; (go figure. Maybe the new version of Ubuntu dropped some library required by the code? who knows).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;taking care of 3rd-party dependencies (my code may work fine, but it depends on some 3rd-party jar file whose author decided to remove from the web).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Additionally, I should be available to answer questions and fix bugs, several years after I graduate, when I already work full-time in another place, and have small kids.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;And all this, without getting any special payment or academic credit for all that effort.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One possible solution I recently thought of is, to create a new journal, &lt;strong&gt;Journal of Reproducible Computer Science&lt;/strong&gt;, that will accept only publications whose experiments can be repeated easily.  Here are some of my thoughts about such a journal:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Submitted papers must have a detailed &lt;strong&gt;reproduction&lt;/strong&gt; section, with (at least) the following sub-sections:&#xA; - &lt;em&gt;pre-requisites&lt;/em&gt; - what systems, 3rd-party software, etc., are required to repeat the experiment;&#xA; - &lt;em&gt;instructions&lt;/em&gt; - detailed instructions on how to repeat the experiment. &#xA; - &lt;em&gt;licenses&lt;/em&gt; - either open-source or closed-source license, but must allow free usage for research purposes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The review process requires each of 3 different reviewers, from different backgrounds, to go through this section, using different computers and operating systems.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;After the review process, if the paper is accepted for publication, there will be another &lt;strong&gt;pre-publication step&lt;/strong&gt;, which will last for a year. During this step, the paper will be available to all the readers, and they will have the option to repeat the experiment and also contact the author in case there are any problems. Only after this year, the paper will be finally published.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This journal will enable researchers to get credit for the difficult and important work of making their code usable to others.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;EDIT: I now see that someone already thought about this! &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.scienceexchange.com/reproducibility&quot;&gt;https://www.scienceexchange.com/reproducibility&lt;/a&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&quot;Science Exchange, PLOS ONE, figshare, and Mendeley have launched the Reproducibility Initiative to address this problem. It’s time to start rewarding the people who take the extra time to do the most careful and reproducible work. Current academic incentives place an emphasis on novelty, which comes at the expense of rigor. Studies submitted to the Initiative join a pool of research, which will be selectively replicated as funding becomes available. The Initiative operates on an opt-in basis because we believe that the scientific consensus on the most robust, as opposed to simply the most cited, work is a valuable signal to help identify high quality reproducible findings that can be reliably built upon to advance scientific understanding.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="ss3ByAQytmN+NRmeL/FkXg==" Author="705" Date="2013-05-28T04:49:49.757" Text="@Spidey, Erel's answer is completely accurate.  He does describe a mindset that many researchers do have.  That mindset might be a good one, or might be bad for the field -- but regardless, what matter is that many researchers do share that mindset, and act accordingly.  The original poster asked for an explanation of why many researchers have decided not to share their code; Erel has given an accurate description of why some/many researchers have decided to do so.  You can agree or disagree with whether they've made the best choice, but that's not the question here./>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="ss3ByAQytmN+NRmeL/FkXg==" Author="7236" Date="2013-05-31T19:46:30.233" Text="@Espanta: One step at a time. First, share the code. Then we go thinking about peer reviewing the code./>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="ss3ByAQytmN+NRmeL/FkXg==" Author="6393" Date="2013-05-31T11:26:51.713" Text="@ErelSegalHalevi: Your dream of having reproducible papers is very nice. But think about publication time. Currently it takes about 6-18 month to publish a paper. Publishing in that journal may take 2-3 years if non-paid reviewers (usually professors) are needed to read all your documentation, learn used language, install tools, troubleshoot the code, and run to check if everything is okay. It sound more practical to use a cloud instance, load the code, and enable reviewers/readers to access your loaded code rather than doing all by themselves. Doing so, increase trust too./>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="ss3ByAQytmN+NRmeL/FkXg==" Author="7236" Date="2013-05-27T16:28:15.363" Text="@ErelSegalHalevi It's much worse for the reputation to hide the implementation details. IMHO, it basically means &quot;believe me&quot;. That's not how science works. Hiding the code violates the most important law of making science: falseability. You can't invalidate a work if you don't have access to it. The author can hide behind this black curtain denying whatever attempt to reproduce/invalidate his paper by saying it's not identical to his method./>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="ss3ByAQytmN+NRmeL/FkXg==" Author="7236" Date="2013-05-27T13:03:58.983" Text="I don't think that's a valid answer. You can just document your setup or even just distribute the code. Even if I can't run, I can learn lots by just inspecting it./>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="ss3ByAQytmN+NRmeL/FkXg==" Author="7236" Date="2013-05-28T13:11:52.283" Text="@D.W. You are 100% right. I meant to say it's not a valid reason not to share./>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="ss3ByAQytmN+NRmeL/FkXg==" Author="5669" Date="2013-05-28T09:04:28.140" Text="There's a lot of research in this area made by G.Fursin : he tries to make the CS reproducible. See presentation at http://www.hipeac.net/system/files/grigori.pdf for example.&#xA;He also tries to push a new publication model http://ctuning.org/cm-journal/>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="ss3ByAQytmN+NRmeL/FkXg==" Author="6785" Date="2013-05-28T08:14:47.413" Text="+1 for &quot;Journal of Reproducible Computer Science&quot;, which makes for interesting googling, by the way. But as a developer I think your requirements for packing the code are much too strong. Anyone who knows the phrase &quot;bit rot&quot; will know that it's unreasonable to expect someone else to maintain code which was simply created to demonstrate a point./>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="ss3ByAQytmN+NRmeL/FkXg==" Author="787" Date="2013-05-28T07:24:34.510" Text="@Spidey, I agree that it would be much better for science to have all code published. That's why I suggested a way to encourage authors to publish their code./>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="ss3ByAQytmN+NRmeL/FkXg==" Author="787" Date="2013-05-27T13:15:25.373" Text="I also thought this way, but over time I learned that when you release your code to the public, you inevitable have some responsibility over it. If the code isn't well-documented, if it doesn't compile, if it doesn't run - people will hold you responsible, and it might be bad for your reputation./>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="ss3ByAQytmN+NRmeL/FkXg==" Author="4461" Date="2013-05-27T15:16:55.360" Text="*Submitted papers must have a detailed reproduction section* -- a similar idea has been bandied about in the computer architecture community for a few years, but it involves providing a working virtual machine with the code installed and ready. You boot the virtual machine and away you go./>
<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="ss3ByAQytmN+NRmeL/FkXg==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-27T14:16:57.627" Text="I agree that if your code doesn't compile or doesn't run it might be bad for your reputation but I think it's reasonable to turn down requests to change/fix your code if you are simply publishing it. If you're managing an open source project that's different but why would publishing source code require more than simply answering questions (as would any publication)?/>

<answer QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="3WUzoh0QjKyNNxOS9e1kAw==" Author="1174" Date="2013-05-28T01:07:28.133" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.siam.org/news/news.php?id=2064&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;This article&lt;/a&gt; in SIAM News sheds some light on the first question, so it might be worth a look.  It argues, for a mathematical audience, why researchers &lt;em&gt;ought&lt;/em&gt; to publish their source code, and lists many of the reasons you might hear why researchers do not share their source code.  It does so by a clever analogy, one that compares the sharing of mathematical proofs to the sharing of  source code.  Take a look; it has quite an extensive list of reasons why researchers might prefer not to share their source code (as well as some responses arguing that those reasons are not good ones).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here's a citation:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Top Ten Reasons To Not Share Your Code (and why you should anyway). Randall J. LeVeque.  SIAM News, April 1, 2013.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="fPEo935PTyHRXS83r/s03A==" Author="6393" Date="2013-05-27T08:19:44.240" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;In sharing code there are several issues:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The first issue is the copyright matters, since some of CS researches/projects are funded by certain industrialists/funding organizations that discourage sharing sensitive information such as algorithms, code, or software while publishing in public periodicals.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Indeed, there are papers based on certain data (collected from code execution) that unfortunately are manually modified by the authors. If they share the code, catching their mistake/error/modifications becomes very easy leading to failure in either their MS/PhD or research project which is undesirable.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;In CS research and especially publication, developing code, particularly a lengthy, complex code is a non-trivial task and in most of the cases is considered money-making and paper-generating asset. By sharing the code to the public, they are unveiling facts in very much detail which may degrade their contribution in future researches. Also they may not be the only one who can regenerate article and make credit of that particular research and code. In most of the cases, master students pick an algorithm or method, slightly change it and submit a thesis and paper based on it, that may contradict with the findings and claims of the first author. Remember &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Herndon&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Thoma Herdon&lt;/a&gt; a graduate students who criticized findings of two eminent economist of Harvard university(&lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Growth_in_a_Time_of_Debt&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt; is the link ). If the codes in CS are revealed the consequences are likely catastrophic (it might not be too many cases, but if happens it will be catastrophic).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Codes are vital property to most of the researchers to conduct experiment and research. If you have a code, you can simply play with it and modify it to generate new set of findings that might be more valuable than the initial findings. Without having authorship of the initial author, there is no credit to them.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, Elsevier recently introduced a new feature using COLLAGE called &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.elsevier.com/physical-sciences/computer-science/executable-papers&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Executabale Papers&lt;/a&gt; that is currently available for &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/journal/00978493&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Computers &amp;amp; Graphics&lt;/a&gt; journal by which codes and data are available and researchers can modify the code and input values to play with. Here is the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.elsevier.com/physical-sciences/computer-science/executable-papers&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;link&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Hope it helps.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;">

Like JeffE said, you're accusing CS if you're suggesting these are valid answers to OP's question. You must present evidence. Oh, you collected evidence by your code and manipulated it? That's how CS works, huh?/>

Simple as that. You can still research and sell your workforce to anyone, but what good does it make to tell the science community of your achievement if no one is able to reproduce it?/>

<comment QuestionId="Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing" AnswerId="fPEo935PTyHRXS83r/s03A==" Author="6393" Date="2013-05-31T11:12:09.517" Text="Yo must share data, but not necessarily code. In journals, reviewers asked to evaluate if the authors provide sufficient info to replicate the work. Code is not the only thing for research replication. There are many others that impact on results which varies from domain to domain. e.g., for cloud-based apps running on mobile devices, there are very large number of metrics like device and cloud type, prog.language, mobile-cloud distance, data collection time, network quality and many more. So replication of work is not easy in all domains; authors art is to establish trust in his paper./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10251	<question QuestionId="How to find out the editorial times (for article review) of CS journals" Title="How to find out the editorial times (for article review) of CS journals" Views="265" Tags="publications,peer-review" " AnswerId="nqOt0JAIhrz+y5JMZqv6SA==" Author="6393" Date="2013-05-27T08:24:25.793" Score="17" Text="&lt;p&gt;Elsevier has recently lunched a tool called &lt;a href=&quot;http://journalfinder.elsevier.com/&quot;&gt;Journal Finder&lt;/a&gt; by which researchers can use paper's title and abstract, and field of study to find a suitable journal for their manuscript. Here is the sample &#xA;&lt;img src=&quot;http://i.stack.imgur.com/WrOoZ.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;enter image description here&quot;&gt; in which the editorial time is 12 weeks. They surely maintain database for their own, but is there any other source we can do this for other non-Elsevier journals, like IEEE or ACM? I know WoS provides some information about it, but WoS's database accuracy is not yet clear to me since I have seen lots of inaccurate information in WoS reports (for instance, number of &quot;review article&quot; published is often inaccurate).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to find out the editorial times (for article review) of CS journals" AnswerId="nqOt0JAIhrz+y5JMZqv6SA==" Author="6393" Date="2013-05-28T06:02:24.930" Text="@aeismail: maybe other disciplines have such features. Because I am unable to find such data on the Internet for my own need, I though maybe I can get some help. Looking for the answer/>
<comment QuestionId="How to find out the editorial times (for article review) of CS journals" AnswerId="nqOt0JAIhrz+y5JMZqv6SA==" Author="958" Date="2013-12-23T10:13:37.163" Text="Many journals have started using &quot;reject &amp; resubmit&quot; very liberally as an answer instead of &quot;major revisions&quot;, for the only reason that it makes processing times look artificially faster. I feel that if we publish these statistics and rely on them, we will just encourage this scammy strategy. The correct term of comparison here should be &quot;time between first submission and acceptance&quot;, not &quot;time between last submission and acceptance&quot;./>

<answer QuestionId="How to find out the editorial times (for article review) of CS journals" AnswerId="sxjvsJFB57N6JBfyLAdEdg==" Author="6393" Date="2014-02-19T16:56:29.027" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;Elsevier has recently launched a new toolbox including lots of useful information about journals. If you visit any Elsevier journal's homepage (I assume it works for all Elsevier journals], you will see the following box there,&#xA;&lt;img src=&quot;http://i.stack.imgur.com/atJQI.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;enter image description here&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Click on it and select 'Speed' link and it takes you to another page like &lt;a href=&quot;http://journalinsights.elsevier.com/journals/1084-8045/speed&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt; (example for JNCA journal). The following information let you know the latest turn around time of this particular journal.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://i.stack.imgur.com/IeJsf.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;enter image description here&quot;&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Hope other journals start similar approach.&#xA;Thanks and hope you find this post useful.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


</answer>

academia.stackexchange.com_10253	<question QuestionId="mailing list for local conferences" Title="mailing list for local conferences" Views="54" Tags="conference" " AnswerId="aQAHVhYges77aXVzi0Stgg==" Author="787" Date="2013-05-27T09:22:07.327" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Often I learn about conferences, even in my own country, when it is too late to submit papers. Is there a mailing list, or another way to get information about conferences in a specific location and domain?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;EDIT: I am mainly interested in computer science and game theory.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="mailing list for local conferences" AnswerId="aQAHVhYges77aXVzi0Stgg==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-27T09:32:07.620" Text="Many fields have mailing lists (listservers) to distribute information. To help you,it would therefore be necessary to know your specialization or general field. There is no service that would safely provide information for all research fields./>

<answer QuestionId="mailing list for local conferences" AnswerId="bL7OVydBN6z3QQYicZD9FA==" Author="7198" Date="2013-05-27T10:04:19.157" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;You can use &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.conferencealerts.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.conferencealerts.com/&lt;/a&gt; to locate academic conferences in your desired country. These listings are sorted by a &lt;strong&gt;topic or country&lt;/strong&gt; which you can select on the first page. Once chosen you will get a list of the various conferences &lt;strong&gt;organized by month&lt;/strong&gt;. Moreover, you have the option of subscribing and thus receiving &lt;strong&gt;email announcements&lt;/strong&gt; about those events.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10256" Date="2014-04-02T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="mailing list for local conferences" AnswerId="jHeBXXsHes8jewbEPicHtg==" Author="643" Date="2013-05-27T09:37:07.773" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;There is a wiki devoted to call for papers (&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.wikicfp.com/cfp/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.wikicfp.com/cfp/&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Googling can help you find earlier editions of conferences and so forth. Make a list of the ones relevant for you and when they occur – each edition of a conference will occur at the same time of year. Keep this list on your wall, perhaps sorted by month of conference (or better, month of deadline). Google will help find the current edition.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10259	<question QuestionId="White Paper &amp MS in Mechanical Engineering" Title="White Paper &amp MS in Mechanical Engineering" Views="195" Tags="research,publications" " AnswerId="f4iZ+0o+9dm8J2REs3MtVQ==" Author="user6392" Date="2013-05-27T11:08:37.697" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am a Mechanical Engineering student &amp;amp; want to pursue Master of Science with specialization in Design/CAD. Recently I have come across white papers on website of some companies about their products. My friend told me that publishing a white paper would be beneficial for my MS applications. So I wanted to know:&#xA;1. What exactly is the scope of a white paper?&#xA;2. What sort of topic/information must one put in the paper?&#xA;3. How to publish a white paper (I mean is there a Journal for white papers or any other standard)?&#xA;4. How much effect does it have in showing my research aptitude compared to a scientific publication/ research paper?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10259" Date="2013-05-27T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="White Paper &amp MS in Mechanical Engineering" AnswerId="3RIW3ef0dokMd7ohoaTnuw==" Author="7262" Date="2013-05-29T03:38:47.620" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;In the research field a white paper is not so important. However, if you plan to work in an applied field,a white paper is valued highly because it shows you are aware of the current issues in your field. In general, white papers are issue-oriented.&#xA;For example, in the field of architecture &quot;green&quot; building materials are valued over traditional. But why? A white paper could present facts on &quot;green&quot; building materials versus traditional materials in terms of cost and performance. Other factors could also be weighed such as customer preference. Therefore, when the executives of a firm read the white paper it could help them make a major decision on materials they will buy in the future.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;See below the definition of white paper:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;White papers in business-to-business (B2B) marketing&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Since the early 1990s, the term white paper has been applied to documents used as B2B marketing or sales tools. Far more commercial white papers are now produced for B2B vendors than political white papers for governments[citation needed].&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;B2B white papers are long-form content designed to promote the products or services from a specific company. As a marketing tool, these papers use selected facts and logical arguments to build a case favorable to the company sponsoring the document. B2B white papers are often used to generate sales leads, establish thought leadership, make a business case, or inform and persuade prospective customers, channel partners, journalists, analysts, or investors.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Many B2B white papers argue that one particular technology, product or method is superior for solving a specific business problem. They may also present research findings, list a set of questions or tips about a certain business issue, or highlight a particular product or service from a vendor.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="White Paper &amp MS in Mechanical Engineering" AnswerId="3RIW3ef0dokMd7ohoaTnuw==" Author="222" Date="2013-05-29T06:01:48.013" Text="Please do not sign your posts, especially not with a link to your website included; every post you make is already linked to your account. [Self-promotion is frowned upon on the Stack Exchange network](http://academia.stackexchange.com/faq#promotion). Just stick to the relevant material in each post, and put a link to your website in your profile page if you want./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10293" Date="2013-06-10T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10293" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>

Actually I would like to submit one paper in the conferences that they organized, but I am a little dubious about it. My main concern is to know if it would be a good idea to submit to that conference.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Could anybody give me his straight opinion about those congresses that they organized? do they seem good enough?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;thanks&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How to know if these congresses (ie organized by ISCA) are good" AnswerId="Eug3TKBBq/EC1NU52m1HoQ==" Author="643" Date="2013-05-27T14:30:02.750" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Consulting the &lt;a href=&quot;http://core.edu.au/cms/images/downloads/conference/08sort%20acronymERA2010_conference_list.pdf&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Australian Computer Science Conference Ranking&lt;/a&gt; reveals that one of their conferences, CATA, is ranked C. I did not check any others.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Indicators   that the conferences are not good include: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The conference is extremely broad. CATA covers topics including Algorithms, Programming Languages, and Multimedia. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The conference is in an exotic location (e.g. Hawaii).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;People involved in the conference are not the leaders in their field.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Conference is not well established.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Conference does not appear in the Conference Ranking list, even though it has been around for a long time.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note that conferences satisfying some or all of these criteria are not necessarily poorly ranked.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to know if these congresses (ie organized by ISCA) are good" AnswerId="Eug3TKBBq/EC1NU52m1HoQ==" Author="746" Date="2013-05-28T04:46:00.527" Text="How is an exotic location an indicator of anything? The top software engineering and HCI conferences tend to alternate between the US and an &quot;exotic&quot; location./>
<comment QuestionId="How to know if these congresses (ie organized by ISCA) are good" AnswerId="Eug3TKBBq/EC1NU52m1HoQ==" Author="3" Date="2013-05-28T12:38:14.870" Text="My (limited) experience suggests that conferences that are in &quot;tourist&quot; destinations tend to be less productive, as more people are distracted with things other than the conference. Also, good conferences do not need a gimmick of a tourist hotspot to attract presenters. Of course this is just a general observation, and isn't a hard rule to suggest *all conferences* at tourist locations are bad./>
<comment QuestionId="How to know if these congresses (ie organized by ISCA) are good" AnswerId="Eug3TKBBq/EC1NU52m1HoQ==" Author="6144" Date="2013-05-29T04:52:42.500" Text="thank you for your advice @DaveClarke, one question, do you know other computer science conference rankings apart of the one that you mentioned?/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10266	<question QuestionId="Typical experiences of transgender people in academia" Title="Typical experiences of transgender people in academia" Views="513" Tags="job,university,personal-advice" " AnswerId="ehO8LvTIT8IOIYaW40daWQ==" Author="8469" Date="2013-05-28T00:07:44.977" Score="35" Text="&lt;p&gt;I've recently come to accept that I'm transgender (MtF, male-to-female).  I won't go into the exact details of this as it's personal, but I have a &quot;girl mode&quot; where I identify as a female.  I'm also a researcher/lecturer at a respectable university.  I'm yet to reveal this side of myself at work, but it's not impossible that my colleagues or students will run into me in girl mode e.g. at the mall.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Question&lt;/strong&gt;: What are typical experiences of openly transgender academics?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'd be particularly interesting in examples of successful academics who are openly transgender.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I know there are both legal protections and university policies which prohibit discrimination based on being transgender, but no policy can make people like you.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Typical experiences of transgender people in academia" AnswerId="ehO8LvTIT8IOIYaW40daWQ==" Author="4249" Date="2014-03-03T14:04:16.240" Text="I am assuming you are asking about the US, or at least &quot;top&quot; academic countries such as the US, Canada, Australia, Central Europe? Could you specify? I have an example from an Eastern European country where a person was unable to get official transcripts re-issued under the new name after a gender-change operation. I think all the info is really relevant, but I assume there would be a big difference between e.g. the US and a country where seeing a dark-skinned man on the street  is an exciting and unusual event (really not trying to offend anybody, just speaking from experience)./>
<comment QuestionId="Typical experiences of transgender people in academia" AnswerId="ehO8LvTIT8IOIYaW40daWQ==" Author="4429" Date="2013-05-28T01:37:52.867" Text="Raewyn Connell is an incredibly important Australian sociologist who identifies as a transsexual woman.  I'm not sure her experiences as an academic could be considered typical, as she was appointed Chair very early in her career and has published many works of national or disciplinary significance.  Scholars have concentrated on the fruitful elements of her scholarly biography (genealogy of her concept of structure, for example), rather than studying Connell as a biographic subject./>

<answer QuestionId="Typical experiences of transgender people in academia" AnswerId="hkNqaVMY/pILNNcgXqehTA==" Author="7301" Date="2013-05-31T23:21:59.340" Score="14" Text="&lt;p&gt;Jennifer Finney Boylan, Professor of English and Department Chair, Colby College, Maine.  Jenny wrote &quot;She's Not There&quot; and other great books.  My heroine (happily married to a woman)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Dr. Lynn Conway.  Lynn invented both VLSI and superscalar architectures.  Professor Emeritus, University of Michigan.  My heroine (happily married to a man)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Dr. Deirdre McCluskey, University of Chicago, Professor of Economics.  Very famous economist from Milton Friedman's old school.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Want more??  You are in the SAFEST profession to DO the transition!!  Read Jenny books and Lynn's website and you'll learn how to do it, step by step.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Typical experiences of transgender people in academia" AnswerId="qNp9u1vnSU1dg9DcGfB07w==" Author="12473" Date="2014-03-03T00:44:50.537" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;In my undergraduate institution there was a transgender logician graduate student. He taught me category theory. As far as I remember none of us had ever any problems with his regular mini-skirt outfit. In my graduate institution there was a graduate student who changed gender and made it known to everybody (faculty and students). Again, there were no issues that I've heard of, the relationship of that person with their supervisor remained very good (as far as I can tell) and the person went on to a very good job later on. Keep in mind that I did my undergraduate and graduate degree in fairly &quot;liberal&quot; places. Overall my experience was that if you let people know, but then move on with you regular life then it doesn't become an issue. Also it is not unlikely that some of your colleagues already &quot;know&quot;. I guess there is always an amount of risk involved with full disclosure. Keep in mind that people shouldn't judge you on what you do in your private time. Another factor is if you already have tenure, and if you don't and things go bad if you will try to explain them by your transition?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Typical experiences of transgender people in academia" AnswerId="qNp9u1vnSU1dg9DcGfB07w==" Author="5955" Date="2014-03-03T10:03:22.487" Text="If the logician was actually transgender (as opposed to 'transvestite' - I put the term in quote marks because I don't know if anyone actually refers to themselves in this way, but it refers to dressing as the other gender, as opposed to identifying as a different gender than the one assigned at birth), then you may not be being as accepting as you think by still referring to them as 'he'./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="17648" Date="2014-03-03T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10271	<question QuestionId="Can one publish papers which give an improved presentation of old results" Title="Can one publish papers which give an improved presentation of old results" Views="381" Tags="publishing,journals" " AnswerId="8dZAou9CQISzEOGhyfL5Ew==" Author="6110" Date="2013-05-28T14:27:10.767" Score="20" Text="&lt;p&gt;A colleague of mine (I'm in mathematics) has shown me a splendid note. He took some of the results from a confusing, hard to read, and important paper from the 1970's, which have not yet appeared in book form, and gave them much cleaner and simpler proofs, and explained them in a very clear way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I urged him to publish his writeup, and to submit it to a very good journal. But he feels that, because the results are not (strictly speaking) new, the paper would be unlikely to be accepted.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Certainly I feel that work such as his is extremely valuable, and I think the mathematical community ought to encourage more of it. Was I right to encourage him to publish? Or was his pessimism more on target?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Can one publish papers which give an improved presentation of old results" AnswerId="8dZAou9CQISzEOGhyfL5Ew==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-28T15:21:54.137" Text="[Yes.](http://www.cs.uiuc.edu/~jeffe/pubs/parshort.html)/>

And if proper attribution is given and the relationship between the old and new work clearly explained, then this should be publishable, assuming that the results are still interesting for the wider community.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10273	<question QuestionId="Do I have a chance to get into a great cs grad school" Title="Do I have a chance to get into a great cs grad school" Views="322" Tags="graduate-admissions" " AnswerId="B06osczYjnO/nYVJ7JuLFA==" Author="7251" Date="2013-05-28T14:37:07.790" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am an undergrad from India from a good university( not IIT,NIT).&#xA;Our GPA is calculated on a different percentage scale and mine is 73-75%&#xA;which is a very good score according to our system.&#xA;My GRE score=1600.&#xA;I have an internship at a major company.&#xA;I am thinking of writing a research paper but have no research experience. &#xA;Do I have a chance at the top colleges like UC Berkeley,or Michigan or even Carnegie Mellon?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10273" Date="2013-08-08T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10273" Date="2013-05-28T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Do I have a chance to get into a great cs grad school" AnswerId="LzSRbnnXFOSle/HguiO7Vw==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-28T20:45:05.807" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Maybe.&lt;/strong&gt;  There's really no way to tell without looking at your complete application.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you applied to my department's research MS program, your good grades and GRE scores would &lt;em&gt;probably&lt;/em&gt; attract enough attention that someone would actually review your application.  Most of our MS applications are rejected without review.  But that's as far as grades and test scores will get you.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Since you claim not to come from an IIT or NIT, there might be some question about how good your university is.  If we've never admitted someone from your school before, we don't know how to calibrate your grades or recommendation letters.  Every year we seem to get applications from two or three new schools in India that even our Indian faculty and graduate students don't recognize.  We do sometimes admit one or two &lt;em&gt;truly outstanding&lt;/em&gt; students from unknown schools as a way of gathering data.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Having an internship is definitely good, especially if you did something creative and independent, and not just &quot;My boss told me to implement this thing, so I did.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But the admission decision would really depend on your research statement (or &quot;statement of purpose&quot;) and your recommendation letters.  As I &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/a/2722/65&quot;&gt;have&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/a/7601/65&quot;&gt;written&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/a/974/65&quot;&gt;many&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/a/9877/65&quot;&gt;times&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/a/5349/65&quot;&gt;before&lt;/a&gt;, graduate admissions committees at top departments are looking for &lt;b&gt;potential for research excellence&lt;/b&gt;.  My committee would judge that potential from the content of your statements and letters, and from the credibility of your letter-writers.  Research &lt;em&gt;experience&lt;/em&gt; is certainly helpful, but it's not necessary, especially for an MS.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;This is really an question for your letter writers.&lt;/strong&gt;  Ask them directly if they can write strong and substantial letters &lt;em&gt;that focus on your research potential&lt;/em&gt;.  If they look uncomfortable (or they don't know what &quot;research potential&quot; means), you should probably aim a bit lower.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

Just having good or even excellent grades is not enough. At least, you need to have very strong recommendation letters and preferably some undergraduate research experience. I would suggest applying not only to top schools but also to second tier schools.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10275	<question QuestionId="PhD Transfer from other country to US" Title="PhD Transfer from other country to US" Views="237" Tags="phd" " AnswerId="uWvWKAXoZbVGKTHJ4RG4+g==" Author="7249" Date="2013-05-28T15:53:19.707" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;In this application cycle, I got a PhD offer from Nanyang Technology University at Singapore and will study in the field of programming language. However, I recently received a mail from my supervisor which is said that he will soon leave NTU for some reasons. After searching the faculty list of NTU I found there is no other professor who works in programming language. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't want to compromise on the topic I will do during my PhD. Maybe it is a good choice for me to find a matching supervisor in some other universities.&#xA;But I have to go to NTU to do my PhD because I have no alternative choice now since this application cycle is ended.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What I want to know is that is it possible to transfer my PhD from singapore to US if I re-apply for some American universities after my current supervisor's leave?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Any advise will be so much appreciate for that I somehow don't know what to do.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="PhD Transfer from other country to US" AnswerId="kvxEJs7ECPabdP55/hjACg==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-28T19:29:19.877" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;In general, it is difficult to &lt;em&gt;transfer&lt;/em&gt; between universities in different countries &lt;em&gt;unless&lt;/em&gt; one is moving with the thesis advisor. This is in part because of funding rules: usually, money in one country cannot be used to fund graduate students working or studying in another country. (In the US, for instance, graduate fellowships are normally valid only at US universities.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you were to attempt to transfer on your own, the most likely scenario is that you would be expected to start the PhD over; depending on the department, they may not recognize coursework completed at your old school, or at best may choose to give you placement out of the equivalent courses, but still expect you to complete additional electives. It would be even more challenging to move your project over, if funding isn't available to work on the same project.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Since you are just starting, perhaps it would be possible to complete a master's degree in Singapore, and then try to transfer to another university for the doctoral studies. (I'm not sure how doctoral programs in CS handle an international master's. In my department, though, students with master's from abroad were still expected to complete the &quot;core&quot; coursework requirements.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10281" Date="2013-05-28T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10281" Date="2013-05-28T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10281" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10281" Date="2013-05-28T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10281" Date="2013-05-28T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="PhD Transfer from other country to US" AnswerId="Zb3+F56tnOmnAswqTM+p6A==" Author="643" Date="2013-05-28T16:02:18.250" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;It certainly is possible, even across countries. Some of my students are following me on my move from Belgium to Sweden. To ensure that this was possible, I needed to enquire with the administration on both the source and target of the move. There were some restrictions on both sides – for instance, if a student is too close to finishing, both sides are reluctant to let the move happen.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10277	<question QuestionId="How can we change things so more researchers are willing to share their source code" Title="How can we change things so more researchers are willing to share their source code" Views="159" Tags="research,code" " AnswerId="RCetCNzucFzmMxxB2C7QaQ==" Author="285" Date="2013-05-28T16:18:09.843" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;This is a followup to  &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/q/10247/285&quot;&gt;Why are CS researchers reluctant to share code and what techniques can I use to encourage sharing?&lt;/a&gt;. That question specifically asked how one can succeed in obtaining researcher's source code. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As discussed in the answers to that question, the reasons largely boil down to competitive advantage and people thinking their code is not good enough. The former issue is difficult to address. However, one could try to address the latter issue, making the reasonable assumption that this behavior stems from the surrounding academic culture. There may be additional aspects of the academic culture that discourage code sharing, and which do not relate to competitive advantage.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, one could instead ask the general questions what concrete actions one can take to change this culture? Or, to put it a little differently, how can I help change the academic world so that more researchers are willing to share their source code?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How can we change things so more researchers are willing to share their source code" AnswerId="RCetCNzucFzmMxxB2C7QaQ==" Author="5944" Date="2013-05-28T20:56:32.583" Text="The easiest thing to do, as an individual, is to release all of your own code as open source software on public repositories, then write it as a footnote or reference in your paper./>
<comment QuestionId="How can we change things so more researchers are willing to share their source code" AnswerId="RCetCNzucFzmMxxB2C7QaQ==" Author="958" Date="2013-05-28T18:45:22.863" Text="An interesting read on this topic from SIAM news: http://www.siam.org/news/news.php?id=2064/>
<comment QuestionId="How can we change things so more researchers are willing to share their source code" AnswerId="RCetCNzucFzmMxxB2C7QaQ==" Author="285" Date="2013-05-28T16:35:04.297" Text="@D.W. &quot;That question&quot; in the first para referred to the question that was asked earlier, and referenced here./>
<comment QuestionId="How can we change things so more researchers are willing to share their source code" AnswerId="RCetCNzucFzmMxxB2C7QaQ==" Author="705" Date="2013-05-28T16:37:53.390" Text="Oops, sorry, Faheem, my mistake!/>

<answer QuestionId="How can we change things so more researchers are willing to share their source code" AnswerId="xNSz/2dbb7sQxKn7ekqGXw==" Author="3" Date="2013-05-28T16:54:41.350" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;IMO talk about &quot;cultural&quot; impediments are overstated. Academics are as rational agents as any, and currently the academic system (mainly publish/get grants or perish) provides little &lt;strong&gt;incentive&lt;/strong&gt; to publishing the code or making analysis entirely reproducible. Some fields have started intiatives to encourage this by making either analysis and publicly releasing data mandatory or strongly recommended for publication (e.g. &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ucema.edu.ar/journal-applied-economics&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;The Journal of Applied Economics&lt;/a&gt;) or for funding (e.g. &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nij.gov/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;NIJ&lt;/a&gt; grants frequently have stipulations to post the data to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.icpsr.umich.edu/icpsrweb/landing.jsp&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;ICPSR&lt;/a&gt;). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Greater awareness of technical computing skills necessary for reproducible analysis will help (see &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.econ.uiuc.edu/~roger/research/repro/JAE-RER.pdf&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Koeneker &amp;amp; Zeileis, 2009&lt;/a&gt;), but on its own won't spurn greater compliance, even if the already discussed negatives are largely mitigated. It still will be more work to publish the code than to not publish the code. When it helps your tenure case, then it will become more commonplace.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10279" Date="2013-05-28T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10279" Date="2013-06-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10279" Date="2013-12-19T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How can we change things so more researchers are willing to share their source code" AnswerId="2Us1XnrPFj3YtXPUJqrdjw==" Author="705" Date="2013-05-28T16:36:10.270" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;In the long term, this will only happen if you change the culture (just as you say).  How do you change the culture of a field?  Very slowly, and only with enormous effort.  You talk to other researchers.  You articulate your values, and seek allies who share your values.  You patiently make the case to your fellow colleagues, perhaps by writing opinion pieces.  You don't harangue or attack them; instead, you gently lay out the reasons why it is good for science and good for them to share their code.  Remember, in all likelihood you all share the same common values: the love and dedication of science and the pursuit of truth.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You lead, by acting as a model for how you would like others to behave.  You do what &lt;em&gt;you&lt;/em&gt; think is right, and set a good example.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You try to persuade referees and program committees to value and reward researchers who do share their source code.  Recognize the amount of extra effort this takes, and (if you believe it is valuable) reward it accordingly: bump up your rating of their paper correspondingly, and make the case why others to do so.  When you write letters of reference or evaluation for another researcher, if they share their source code, give them kudos and explain why the hiring or promotion committee should view this positively.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Ultimately, this is not something that a single individual can change.  Only the entire community, acting as a whole, can make this kind of change.  Individuals can catalyze and facilitate that change, but like any other kind of reform, it takes extraordinary patience and effort, as well as buy-in from your colleagues.  It's not unusual for this kind of change to take a generation or two.  But keep your chin up: remember, you're doing this because you believe it is good for science and good for your field!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How can we change things so more researchers are willing to share their source code" AnswerId="2Us1XnrPFj3YtXPUJqrdjw==" Author="705" Date="2013-05-28T16:51:13.950" Text="@FaheemMitha, indeed, it's a daunting task, if looked at from a broad perspective.  For concrete actions, see the earlier part of my answer (talking to fellow researchers, setting an example, rewarding other researchers who do share their source code, etc.)./>
<comment QuestionId="How can we change things so more researchers are willing to share their source code" AnswerId="2Us1XnrPFj3YtXPUJqrdjw==" Author="285" Date="2013-05-28T16:41:13.010" Text="&quot;Only the entire community, acting as a whole, can make this kind of change.&quot; I'm not sure how this would work. I just had in mind concrete actions an individual could take./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10278" Date="2013-06-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10278" Date="2013-05-28T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10278" Date="2013-05-28T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10278" Date="2013-05-28T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How can we change things so more researchers are willing to share their source code" AnswerId="SWUu/X0g/B8EvcWNWpKI/w==" Author="6308" Date="2013-05-28T18:55:23.423" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Researchers are unwilling to share their code because it's a lot of extra work -- for which there is little or no recompense. When I write some to simulate an experiment or an algorithm to verify numerically the result of a calculation, it is not production-ready code that can be  easily run in another environment: at the very least another researcher needs Matlab or Mathematica, they need whatever special toolboxes or auxiliary code I am using, they need the data files in the right place on the hard drive, they need to understand how to program themselves so that when some small glitch arises, they can deal with it. When I try to run my own code from a year ago, it almost needs some massaging: perhaps a needed file has been moved from one directory to another, perhaps a toolbox has had its code base &quot;updated&quot; and no longer works exactly the same way. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So -- here's what usually happens. Someone contacts me and wants to try out my code. I warn them of all the above issues, but they insist that they know what they are doing and will get back to me with any problems. I spend 2 or 3 hours preparing things, checking stuff out so that they will have an easier time, explaining to them how to put things together so that it will all work. I mail it to them. And I never hear back. It happened again last month. So -- how likely am I to &quot;share&quot; code in the future? Just a little bit less likely than last month. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now to the question: how can you get researchers to share their code? First, when you ask, follow through - don't &quot;take the code and disappear.&quot; Second, try to get the researcher interested in &lt;em&gt;why&lt;/em&gt; you want the code, what you might do with it. Third, the burden is on you to take research-style code (poorly commented, bad error checking, disorganized structure) and to make it do something. Fourth, return something: when you do make some progress, let the researcher know. Fifth, don't ask for impossible things: can I compile the code for your machine (that's different from mine)? (Hint: no). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How can we change things so more researchers are willing to share their source code" AnswerId="SWUu/X0g/B8EvcWNWpKI/w==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-28T20:28:32.743" Text="_And I never hear back._ — Why should you?  I mean sure, maybe it would be _nice_ if people told you whenever they found your work useful, but _expecting_ people to tell you when they find your work useful is unreasonable./>
<comment QuestionId="How can we change things so more researchers are willing to share their source code" AnswerId="SWUu/X0g/B8EvcWNWpKI/w==" Author="285" Date="2013-05-28T20:08:30.150" Text="Thanks for the feedback, bill. While I meant the question to be what one can do to change the culture towards a more sharing culture in a general way, you make good points. One comment - if you are sharing your code with one individual by email, why not make it generally available via hosting sites like github or bitbucket? I think one issue that is not clear is - is it reasonable to publish ones code as is (meaning, put it on github etc.), even if one does not consider its quality suitable for third parties? If so, this would presumably come with an explicit disavowal of any support burden./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10282	<question QuestionId="What are good principles for creating figures" Title="What are good principles for creating figures" Views="509" Tags="writing,graphics" " AnswerId="iyeNh3k/yZur98Rc878UGA==" Author="319" Date="2013-05-28T20:37:45.807" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;This thought came into mind when I was reading &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nature.com/nmeth/journal/v10/n5/full/nmeth.2444.html&quot;&gt;Points of view: Elements of visual style&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;While there are a lot of questions on software and strategies to make and edit figures, I am more curious about what are the things to consider (design rules) while laying out figures. Factors that come to mind include typography, color template, and proportion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="What are good principles for creating figures" AnswerId="hitiZEsZiiRPoQjiIdLSJA==" Author="495" Date="2013-05-28T22:01:31.527" Score="14" Text="&lt;p&gt;There are many books on this subject, as &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/a/10285/495&quot;&gt;Peter Jansson&lt;/a&gt; points out, as it is something of an Art/Science in its own right. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, if you don't feel like buying and reading one or more books on the subject, here are a few basic things that I consider both important, and easy to follow:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Consistency&lt;/strong&gt;: While people can generally argue for hours over the merits of one colour scheme over the other, what is more important is that you use a consistent one for all your figures. Same goes for fonts and line styles. Also, if you're going to use blue squares to represent some &lt;em&gt;thing&lt;/em&gt; in a figure, be sure to use blue squares for nothing else throughout your entire paper.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Conciseness&lt;/strong&gt;: Try to reduce each figure to making a single point, i.e. try to think in terms of &quot;what is this figure trying to say&quot;. It's tempting to pack more and more data into a single figure, but in the end this will usually dilute the message. One figure, one statement.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Clarity&lt;/strong&gt;: Once you've decided what it is that your figure will say, remove anything from it that does not contribute to this single statement. E.g. do you really need every data point/curve you've drawn? If your statement refers to part of a flow chart or class diagram, do you really need all the other, less relevant boxes/labels/methods there too? Also, if the salient feature of your figure is not immediately clear, don't shy away from adding an arrow or something to highlight it.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Completeness&lt;/strong&gt;: Holding the balance to clarity's minimalism, make sure there is also nothing &lt;em&gt;missing&lt;/em&gt; from the figure which is needed for the statement you want to make. Figure axes labels are a favourite. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Funny how they all start with &quot;C&quot;. This is &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; intentional.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What are good principles for creating figures" AnswerId="hitiZEsZiiRPoQjiIdLSJA==" Author="4125" Date="2013-06-04T12:38:17.870" Text="I'd add **Conformity** (just to keep with the 'C'): If there are certain accepted standards in general or your field, don't go changing them unless you have a really good reason. For example, don't come up with your own flowchart symbols./>

<answer QuestionId="What are good principles for creating figures" AnswerId="kYfsmh5ym2g18LmWLy4lCQ==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-28T20:57:40.083" Score="14" Text="&lt;p&gt;There are many aspects of designing figures/illustrations that are covered extremely well by the books written by &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.edwardtufte.com/tufte/&quot;&gt;Edward Tufte&lt;/a&gt;. I would strongly recommend his &lt;em&gt;The Visual Display of Quantitative Information&lt;/em&gt; as a starting point. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some basic notions are to strive for simplicity and clarity. This may seem very obvious but there are many pitfalls and Tufte provides good examples and ways to think about even simple graphics. Design issues such as fonts, line weight, color etc. and thinking about what it is that should be conveyed in a graphic helps to understand how to design efficient graphics. There is a defintion of graphical excellence by Tufte that says that an illustration that provides the reader with as many thoughts as possible in as short a time as possible by using as little ink as possible consitutes such excellence. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Obviously it is impossible to provide a full answer here particularly since it would repeat what is already in print. My personal view is that the book mentioned above is a good foundation to start critically view and discuss illustrations you encounter. Discussing with peers can be very useful. At the same time there is also much tradition in graphics so new ideas may not necessarily fall into fertile soil rigt away.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What are good principles for creating figures" AnswerId="kYfsmh5ym2g18LmWLy4lCQ==" Author="4125" Date="2013-06-04T12:38:55.577" Text="+1 Tufte is the standard bible for diagram design/>

<answer QuestionId="What are good principles for creating figures" AnswerId="j/7CSAj37lnsZWDbv+Lxww==" Author="5944" Date="2013-05-29T00:28:04.833" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I rather like the framework presented by Dan Roam in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.danroam.com/the-back-of-the-napkin/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;&quot;The Back of a Napkin&quot;&lt;/a&gt; as a guide for  S (simple/elaborate) Q (quality/quantity) V (vision/execution) I (individual/comparison) Δ (change/as-is) and the who/what (portrait), how much(chart), where (map), when (timeline), how (flowchart), why (plot).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In general, these two dimensions (technically 3 dimensions but some aren't used) are presented in a matrix to demonstrate the basic forms of diagrams you can use for communicating concepts. The book is a little more high-level than many books on this topic for scientific presentation but I think it's important to be able to select the right picture for your message.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Once you get down to nitty-gritty details, then Justin Zobel's &lt;a href=&quot;http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/1852338024&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;&quot;Writing for Computer Science&quot;&lt;/a&gt; has a number of really good specific pieces of advice for how to lay out diagrams and tables, including how to typeset them so that people remember how to find them and how to make it so that tables don't look all crowded. The book's title says &quot;computer science&quot; but much of the advice is reasonably general to most quantitative research fields.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10288" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10288" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10288" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10288" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10284	<question QuestionId="What are the reasons for Journals to reject any manuscript that has already been deposited into a Preprint server" Title="What are the reasons for Journals to reject any manuscript that has already been deposited into a Preprint server" Views="233" Tags="paper-submission,preprint" " AnswerId="O8nTyIWzgdKVFy/9CfAhZg==" Author="319" Date="2013-05-28T20:54:42.697" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;As it can be appreciated from this &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_academic_journals_by_preprint_policy&quot;&gt;list of journals with varying preprint policies&lt;/a&gt;, certain journals consider a preprint to be &quot;prior publication&quot;. In other fields like Chemistry, there is a strong policy against preprints.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm curious about those reasons, if there are other reasons, and if they hold weight.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What are the reasons for Journals to reject any manuscript that has already been deposited into a Preprint server" AnswerId="O8nTyIWzgdKVFy/9CfAhZg==" Author="725" Date="2013-06-02T13:30:10.133" Text="@NateEldredge: ... or that they at least hope to be able to convince people that it is this way - even if they know very well that it doesn't work out... ;-)/>

<comment QuestionId="What are the reasons for Journals to reject any manuscript that has already been deposited into a Preprint server" AnswerId="O8nTyIWzgdKVFy/9CfAhZg==" Author="725" Date="2013-06-02T13:26:45.887" Text="... <comment QuestionId="What are the reasons for Journals to reject any manuscript that has already been deposited into a Preprint server" AnswerId="O8nTyIWzgdKVFy/9CfAhZg==" Author="725" Date="2013-06-02T13:26:17.823" Text="@NateEldredge: for sure this seems to be a valid reason. But does it actually work out? IMHO they cannot ensure this is the only way to read the paper: there are inter-library networks, you know your colleagues, email the authors (which are usually allowed to share their manuscripts with colleagues), in some legislations there are rights to share that the author will always retain, etc. My guess is that a large number of these subscriptions is still there by inertia from the paper-journal times. For the electronic subscriptions I see a movement towards e.g. nation-wide access. .../>

<answer QuestionId="What are the reasons for Journals to reject any manuscript that has already been deposited into a Preprint server" AnswerId="T54jszGAB8tBdSd7wfolNg==" Author="725" Date="2013-06-02T13:14:30.733" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;A a chemist, I'm very well aware of this. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here's the &lt;a href=&quot;http://pubs.acs.org/meetingpreprints/preprints.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;ACS Journal Editors' Policy on Preprints&lt;/a&gt;' point of view about the disadvantages of preprint servers:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The disadvantages of preprint servers include: the potential for flooding the literature with trivial and repetitious publications, thus making extraction of reliable and valuable information more difficult; absence of peer review; possible premature disclosure with inadequate experimental details or supporting data; premature claims of priority; potential lack of proper references and credit to prior work; abuse of multiple revisions or updates; possible lack of duration and long term archiving.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Personally, I find the two concerns about &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;premature claims of priority&quot; and &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;abuse of multiple revisions or updates&quot; &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;the most relevant points. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;flooding literature with trivial publications&quot; is IMHO an issue with and without preprint servers, &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;repetitious publications&quot; for me fall into the same category, as do&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;inadequate experimental details or supporting data&quot;.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;absence of peer review&quot; is clearly visible with papers from preprint servers - which is IMHO an advantage over journals where the peer review is uncritical.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;long term archiving&quot; depends IMHO more on the responsible organization behind the server (I'm not any more concerned that arXiv could shut down than e.g. Langmuir, Analyst or Analytical and Bioanalytical Chemistry)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There have been &quot;experiments&quot; with preprint servers for chemistry some 10 years ago &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.iupac.org/publications/ci/2002/2404/preprint.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;[1]&lt;/a&gt; but AFAIK they did not develop the momentum e.g. arXiv has, and they seem to have died meanwhile.&lt;br&gt;&#xA;See also: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.asist.org/Publications/JASIS/Best_Jasist/2004Brown.pdf&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Cecelia Brown: The Role of Electronic Preprints in Chemical&#xA;Communication: Analysis of Citation, Usage, and Acceptance in the Journal Literature, Journal of the American Society for Information Science and Technology 54.5 (2003): 362-371.&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&#xA;(the discussed server seems to be down - or at least I can't get a response).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Personal point of view on the problem&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The possibility to be able to publish a manuscript on a preprint server &lt;em&gt;before&lt;/em&gt; submitting it to a journal is not as imortant for me personally as the possibility to make the final contents of the paper publicly accessible. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thus I can live quite well with not being allowed to submit manuscripts that are already available on preprint servers as long as I'm allowed to also publish the manuscript (preferrably the final version after peer-review) after I submitted it to the journal.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;either at a preprint server &lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/abs/1301.0264&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;(arXiv)&lt;/a&gt;, or&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;on institutional, &lt;a href=&quot;http://softclassval.r-forge.r-project.org/2011/2011-07-01-ABC-Glioma-paper.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;personal or project web pages&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;(preferrably &lt;a href=&quot;http://softclassval.r-forge.r-project.org/2013/2013-01-03-ChemomIntellLabSystTheorypaper.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;both&lt;/a&gt;, of course)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10404" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10404" Date="2013-06-02T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10404" Date="2013-06-02T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10404" Date="2013-06-02T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="What are the reasons for Journals to reject any manuscript that has already been deposited into a Preprint server" AnswerId="MvzD2sU+CEn4HXV/PP7AGg==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-02T14:45:15.983" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;One key issue to keep in mind when comparing different fields is the scale of money involved.  For example, according to their &lt;a href=&quot;http://portal.acs.org/portal/PublicWebSite/about/aboutacs/financial/CNBP_032302&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;financial statement&lt;/a&gt;, in 2012 the American Chemical Society received $421 million in revenue for electronic services, including both journals and the Chemical Abstracts Service.  That's a staggering amount of money for a scholarly society.  (For comparison, the American Mathematical Society's &lt;a href=&quot;http://portal.acs.org/portal/PublicWebSite/about/aboutacs/financial/CNBP_032302&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;2011 revenue&lt;/a&gt; from Math Reviews and journals was $15.5 million.)  The ACS is the gatekeeper for publications and data that are worth a fortune to industry, so they have a powerful incentive to maintain that control.  It's no coincidence that they are much less friendly towards open access, the arXiv, etc. than corresponding groups in mathematics or physics are.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What are the reasons for Journals to reject any manuscript that has already been deposited into a Preprint server" AnswerId="MvzD2sU+CEn4HXV/PP7AGg==" Author="725" Date="2013-06-04T13:49:59.443" Text="Note however that this experiment of running a chemistry preprint server was actually initiated at an ACS meeting. I don't know what it died of (probably it wasn't widely used - I've never heard of it before I came across it yesterday) and I don't know how separate ACS publishing and ACS as a scientific society are, but my guess is that ACS publishing is still a branch of the ACS, so a political decision to go towards preprints would affect ACS as journal publisher. So I'd say that it probably also reflects a standpoint of the scientific society (at least in not being a pressing issue).../>
<comment QuestionId="What are the reasons for Journals to reject any manuscript that has already been deposited into a Preprint server" AnswerId="MvzD2sU+CEn4HXV/PP7AGg==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-03T09:56:13.790" Text="This sounded plausible at first. But I realized that IEEE, which publishes 30% of the world's literature in the electrical and electronics engineering and computer science fields, is not unfriendly towards open access or arXiv. If anything, they *promote* OA. As for arXiv, IEEE Information Society even *encourages* use of it at the time of submission. Other IEEE societies might have similar policies about arXiv. Is there some supporting evidence for your claim that it is no coincidence that they are much less friendly towards open access, arXiv, etc.? I think this might just be a coincidence./>
<comment QuestionId="What are the reasons for Journals to reject any manuscript that has already been deposited into a Preprint server" AnswerId="MvzD2sU+CEn4HXV/PP7AGg==" Author="725" Date="2013-06-04T13:54:19.310" Text="... Note also that ACS journals are more restrictive here than Elsevier's or Springer's policies for chemistry journals. - Which are possibly more independent of the politics of scientific societies (although some of their  journals are the official journals of some societies). And of course, they may have been moved by pressure from more preprint-friendly sciences like mathematics./>
<comment QuestionId="What are the reasons for Journals to reject any manuscript that has already been deposited into a Preprint server" AnswerId="MvzD2sU+CEn4HXV/PP7AGg==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-03T13:16:07.450" Text="I think the Information Theory Society is far more arXiv-friendly than the rest of the IEEE, but financially the IEEE is much more like the AMS than the ACS if normalized for membership size.  For example, publication and online services revenue per member: $421 million/163000 = $2600/member for ACS, $132 million/425000 = $310/member for IEEE, and $15.5 million/30000 = $520/member for AMS.  I certainly don't think the finances determine everything, and it's not clear how to interpret them anyway (total size, normalized per member, etc.), but I think it's unlikely to be a total coincidence./>
<comment QuestionId="What are the reasons for Journals to reject any manuscript that has already been deposited into a Preprint server" AnswerId="MvzD2sU+CEn4HXV/PP7AGg==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-04T00:39:31.613" Text="It's speculation on my part./>
<comment QuestionId="What are the reasons for Journals to reject any manuscript that has already been deposited into a Preprint server" AnswerId="MvzD2sU+CEn4HXV/PP7AGg==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-03T14:06:10.503" Text="I see. I don't know if the normalization makes sense in this context. But that may have something to do with it. Either way, what I asked wasn't if my observation on IEEE was correct. I wanted to know if your claim was based on fact (e.g., ACS's official statement that they're against arXiv for financial reasons, which I don't think is necessarily illogical or obviously unethical) or it was your speculation. If it was your speculation, that's fine. It does make sense. If there is a problem, I'd say it might be interpreted as a rude speculation that ACS is not entirely honest about the reasons./>

<answer QuestionId="What are the reasons for Journals to reject any manuscript that has already been deposited into a Preprint server" AnswerId="hOssJubRMzJc6ZZ15E8ysA==" Author="1537" Date="2013-05-31T15:44:51.323" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;There are commercial reasons for journals to be the only place where the article can be obtained. (advertising on the site or in the print journal). So simply violating their policy (if stated clearly) is one valid rejection reason.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(I personally disagree with this reason but such is life)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">
