academia.stackexchange.com_10289	<question QuestionId="Does submitting an enrollment intent mean that I am commiting" Title="Does submitting an enrollment intent mean that I am commiting" Views="338" Tags="graduate-school,graduate-admissions" " AnswerId="URRYbPjgNsn1zLUSlIE87w==" Author="7261" Date="2013-05-29T02:22:34.213" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;I recently got accepted into two universities for the Fall 2013, and both of them asked for me to submit the enrollment intent. I submitted the intent for one of them but then one of my friends said that since I did that, it means I HAVE to go there. But I am still deciding where I want to go. The other university has asked me to send in the form within 2 weeks otherwise I would loose a seat. So let's say if I send an intent to them too, would I be able to pick which one I want to attend when I make my final decision in a few weeks?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Does submitting an enrollment intent mean that I am commiting" AnswerId="URRYbPjgNsn1zLUSlIE87w==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-29T04:47:15.543" Text="_I submitted the intent for one... but I am still deciding where I want to go_ — **Don't do that.**/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10289" Date="2013-06-10T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10289" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10289" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10289" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10289" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Does submitting an enrollment intent mean that I am commiting" AnswerId="iA+qZE4hMJPfM10QC3loSQ==" Author="1010" Date="2013-05-29T03:18:48.540" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;Universities typically consider such intent statements to be binding.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you submit these statements to multiple universities, they will all hold seats for you, seats which could otherwise go to someone from their waiting list.  This hurts those other applicants.  It is also a serious inconvenience to the department's admissions committee, as they need to meet their enrollment targets as closely as possible; failure to do so can affect their funding, and in extreme cases, the survival of the graduate program.  So this is at least inconsiderate on your part, and arguably unethical.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If the institutions find out that you have done this, it is possible that they may rescind their acceptances; this is uncommon but has been known to happen.  In addition, you would certainly forfeit any deposits that you paid.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;At the undergraduate level, where deposits are almost always required (in the US), this practice is called &quot;double depositing&quot;.  The National Association for College Admission Counseling, in their &quot;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nacacnet.org/research/PublicationsResources/Marketplace/Documents/GCAP2011_Web.pdf&quot;&gt;Guide to the College Admission Process&lt;/a&gt;&quot;, says:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Colleges view dual or multiple deposits by students&#xA;  as serious violations of trust and may revoke a previous&#xA;  offer of admission from any student who is found to have&#xA;  sent tuition deposits to more than one college.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My advice is this: at this point, you should plan on attending the university X to which you've announced your intent.  However, if you are absolutely convinced that doing so would be a &lt;em&gt;huge mistake&lt;/em&gt; (not merely that you think Y is a little bit better), then you could contact the admissions committee at X, explain your reasons, apologize, and ask to be released from your agreement.  If you do this, you should do it as soon as possible (ideally within days - don't stew about it for two weeks), and know that it will probably burn your bridges with X, as well as forfeiting your deposit.  If X says it's all right (they probably will - if you don't want to be there, they don't want you there), then you could send your intent to Y.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some people might argue that you are also ethically obligated to inform Y of the situation.  I think it's kind of a gray area, myself.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You might also discuss the matter with an advisor or other professor at your current institution.  They might offer some perspective on X that would help reassure you.  In general, most people say that it isn't so crucial which institution you attend, within reason - your own skills and motivation are a much greater factor in your success.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10290" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10290" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10290" Date="2013-10-12T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10290" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10290" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10290" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10290" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10297	<question QuestionId="Journals selection - alternative criteria to impact factor" Title="Journals selection - alternative criteria to impact factor" Views="327" Tags="journals,time-management,impact-factor" " AnswerId="QwkvF0l8xGhTtFX23BM5hg==" Author="636" Date="2013-05-29T07:59:57.360" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;While trying to select the journals I can submit my present work and future work, I realize the time between the date the authors send the article to the journal and when the revised article is submitted. Usually this is something between 6 months and more than 12 months.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Althought I am focusing on the Impact Factor (IF) to select journals, I think that 12 months to have a feedback that might include &quot;add more variables analysis&quot;,&quot;this article will be more valuable if you test also model x,y and z&quot;, can have a huge impact on you work. It will make you stop what you are currently doing and possible spend up to 2 months making the changes. This might make a big mess on your work if you have deadlines to respect, however this happens to everyone in academia.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My question is, besides the IF journal based selection, how can we select a journal with enought quality with lower IF? What alternative criteria should one use to select the journal? Should we choose newly created Journals?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Journals selection - alternative criteria to impact factor" AnswerId="pa5B6H8EJilQ8Enfm56hnQ==" Author="4394" Date="2013-07-30T15:28:51.377" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Many good suggestions have been given in the answers by Benoît Kloeckner and Dikran Marsupial. I would like to add to these answers by including the following.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Most journals are fairly specialized. The impact factor (IF) tells us how much a given paper published in a specific is referenced on average. So although it may be important to publish in high IF journals it is also (I would say more) important to make sure the paper is seen and read. A high IF journal ensures that this happens to some extent. But, sometimes ones subdiscipline is poorly represented in such a journal and it may turn out that a lower ranked journal may be the major outlet for papers in the discipline. Knowing where people publish their papers is therefore a good guide to the palette or possiblities. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Therefore, take a careful look at where papers you refer to are published and try to assess where your &quot;audience&quot; is likely to look. Such journals are also likely to provide very good insightful reviews. So when you look at journals try to look at your possibilities from all directions and assess the best journal based on all of the suggestions made in the answers here.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="11525" Date="2013-07-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="11525" Date="2013-07-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="11525" Date="2013-07-31T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="11525" Date="2013-07-31T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="11525" Date="2014-01-20T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Journals selection - alternative criteria to impact factor" AnswerId="jvJ/qwaoZo/95g+4jccCFw==" Author="946" Date="2013-05-30T07:57:07.150" Score="10" Text="&lt;p&gt;I largely prefer to talk with people about what they think of the various journals, see who is in the editorial board, and look at what they publish to determine which journals I consider as good. IF can be very biased even at the scale of a journal (Chaos, Soliton and Fractals had a pretty decent IF...)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Other criteria include price and politics of the publisher (e.g. see the cost of knowledge pledge and the blog posts around it), quality of the publishers work (do you have to check proofs in three days with no indication of what has been changed in your paper?), dissemination (is the journal subscribed by a lot of libraries? is it open access? Is it read by many people?), editorial standards (ranges from &quot;any editor do what she wants and takes decisions alone&quot; to &quot;all the editorial board must approve a paper for it to be published, and the name of the handling editor appears on the paper&quot;). All of them may be difficult to determine, that is why talking with other people in your field about journals is important.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Journals selection - alternative criteria to impact factor" AnswerId="jvJ/qwaoZo/95g+4jccCFw==" Author="49" Date="2013-05-30T15:57:24.763" Text="...and: does it allow posting preprint on arXiv (see site with journal statuses: http://www.sherpa.ac.uk/romeo/)./>

<answer QuestionId="Journals selection - alternative criteria to impact factor" AnswerId="HntBFLneC9MHeEboTLCiYA==" Author="2827" Date="2013-05-29T08:14:26.927" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;Sadly, the published times between when a paper is submitted, revised and published should be taken with a pinch of salt.  Some journals these days have changed the review process so that there is no longer a &quot;revise and resubmit&quot; option, and instead the paper is rejected but with an encouragement to resubmit a revised manuscript as a new paper.  This means the &quot;submitted&quot; date on the published paper is the date of the submission of the &lt;em&gt;accepted&lt;/em&gt; version, not the initial submission of the paper.  I personally think this is unethical and no longer review for journals that have this policy as I think it is unfair on the authors, firstly because it deceives them into thinking the journal has a more rapid review process than it actually does, but more importantly because it deprives the authors on priority on their discovery.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So as well as IF, I would say that the review process is a factor to consider.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A good way to choose a journal is to see where the leading figures in your field publish their papers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_103	<question QuestionId="Advice and tools for hosting an online journal club" Title="Advice and tools for hosting an online journal club" Views="431" Tags="reading,collaboration" " AnswerId="acIzCIXjKyNdy2Oni3S9HQ==" Author="66" Date="2012-02-15T14:44:14.903" Score="17" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have some experience with hosting reading groups/journals clubs in an off-line setting. Usually we meet every week in a room and discuss the paper for that week. However, recently some colleagues and I (~7 people) are trying to catch up on a specific topic quickly, and we want to hold a short reading group/journal club. Unfortunately, some of my colleagues are at other universities, and cannot physically attend meetings.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Do you have any advice or suggestions for tools to hold an online reading group?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My first instinct was G+ Hangout (especially with the new beta features they are making available right now). Skype is also an option, but last I checked required a fee for group video chat. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The preferred features are:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Talk to (and preferably see) each other&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Have access to some sort of shared whiteboard&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Easy to use and set up&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Advice and tools for hosting an online journal club" AnswerId="acIzCIXjKyNdy2Oni3S9HQ==" Author="94" Date="2012-02-15T14:46:48.347" Text="Google+ seems to work okay, at least [for seminars](http://qplus.burgarth.de/)./>

<comment QuestionId="Advice and tools for hosting an online journal club" AnswerId="acIzCIXjKyNdy2Oni3S9HQ==" Author="94" Date="2012-02-15T14:58:13.107" Text="True, the one possible downside to G+ hangout is that if multiple users started talking at once, the &quot;autofocus&quot; of the camera to the speaker gets confused. For seminars this is much less an issue; it will be okay also if you strictly enforce a rule of one person talking at one time. But this detracts a bit from the reading group environment./>

<answer QuestionId="Advice and tools for hosting an online journal club" AnswerId="hVW9c0RpyQeU1Mi861yQ9Q==" Author="206" Date="2012-02-22T12:41:57.857" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://plus.google.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Google+&lt;/a&gt; comes with great communication tools called Hangout. Shared documents and even presentations can be achieved with. There is no real setup process involved but getting an account at Google.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another option could be &lt;a href=&quot;http://moodle.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Moodle&lt;/a&gt; which has more features on relevant for teaching courses online and maybe less emphasis on direct communication.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Advice and tools for hosting an online journal club" AnswerId="WoFv3EXILPLqASqpjtHn/Q==" Author="77" Date="2012-02-22T13:23:56.027" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;There's an online &lt;a href=&quot;http://astrojournalclub.wordpress.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Astronomy Journal Club&lt;/a&gt; hosted on Wordpress.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here's my main advice: make the process as &lt;strong&gt;frictionless&lt;/strong&gt; as possible. Grad students tend to have very busy lives, and journal clubs will inevitably have high dropout rates unless they have some motivation (even through guilt) to stay in and to continue participating. Keep them updated through some service that they'll constantly check even if they aren't doing science (emails end up annoying people, but Facebook, Reddit, and Google Plus might work). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It's also probably easier to convince people to set an online journal club when the journal club is about some specialized subject that only a small number of people at any particular university know about (and if they have a strong urge to talk about the subject with people from other universities).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Finally, if there's an academic conference for grad students (for my area, for example, it would be &lt;a href=&quot;http://abgradcon.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;AbGradCon&lt;/a&gt;), discuss it with people there! Journal clubs are an excellent way to keep in touch with grad students at other universities.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Advice and tools for hosting an online journal club" AnswerId="WoFv3EXILPLqASqpjtHn/Q==" Author="77" Date="2012-03-05T01:20:52.007" Text="Yeah - what about a Facebook group? Or Facebook/Wordpress integration if that is still possible?/>
<comment QuestionId="Advice and tools for hosting an online journal club" AnswerId="WoFv3EXILPLqASqpjtHn/Q==" Author="66" Date="2012-03-04T22:10:00.553" Text="I've tried the wordpress route for our [in-person reading group](http://egtheory.wordpress.com/) but it is almost impossible to get people to contribute. I definitely agree that you need to keep things frictionless and somehow appealing./>

</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Advice and tools for hosting an online journal club" AnswerId="WzBMLoRu2hvoOT3l9MdBfA==" Author="43" Date="2012-02-15T14:56:03.577" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;You can find many softwares or online services for that purpose : blackboard IM, tinychat, etc.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10300	<question QuestionId="Should recommenders be from the same discipline as the program ones applying to" Title="Should recommenders be from the same discipline as the program ones applying to" Views="239" Tags="graduate-school,graduate-admissions,recommendation-letter" " AnswerId="6J0oPMdk4L9asv6ySO/rDg==" Author="7265" Date="2013-05-29T11:04:33.943" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;If I want to go to graduate school to study physics and am a math major, how bad is it to have recommendation letters from math professors, mostly? The problem is that I just have four physics courses and after being picky about professors, I might not end up with all physics professors. Further, math professors know me better.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, will it hurt if my recommenders are more mathematicians than physicists? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10300" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10300" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10300" Date="2013-08-08T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10300" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10300" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10300" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Should recommenders be from the same discipline as the program ones applying to" AnswerId="f43EFYuokgmlvIPsYh8W+g==" Author="7270" Date="2013-05-29T12:54:39.140" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;The answer to your question is no, it won't hurt.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;How you prepare your application, however, will likely depend on the type of research you want to do while working on your PhD. For your case, if you want to pursue theoretical research, then I think recommendation letters from mathematicians will be a good asset.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If, on the other hand, you want to work in experimental physics, then I still don't think it would hurt, but I would work extra hard at highlighting relevant skills and experiences, such as experience working in a machine shop or with electronics, in other parts of your application.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You still want your references to be good judges of academic performance, however. By academic, I mean that they should work in academia or be experts in research, critical thinking, and other important academic traits in your field. A life-long high school teacher, for example, may not be a good choice.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To summarize, having letters of recommendation from academics outside of your major field should not hurt your chances of getting into graduate school. The letters should speak to your character, work ethic, and natural abilities, not to the skills you possess. Those can be highlighted in your application.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Qualifications: I'm a senior (sixth-year) graduate student in a physics-related field and frequently assist my advisor in taking on new graduate students. We've taken on people with engineering, physics, materials science, and &lt;strong&gt;mathematics&lt;/strong&gt; backgrounds.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Should recommenders be from the same discipline as the program ones applying to" AnswerId="f43EFYuokgmlvIPsYh8W+g==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-30T23:14:13.337" Text="This helps me significantly as well, as I will be seeking recommendations from CS as well as Physics academics./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10304" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10304" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10304" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Should recommenders be from the same discipline as the program ones applying to" AnswerId="F40YIMbZB+hrVqn2+AEtlQ==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-29T20:22:31.337" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;To point out one pitfall in kmdouglass's answer, there is one situation in which getting letters from out-of-discipline people &lt;em&gt;can&lt;/em&gt; affect an applicant's chances: if the letter writers do not directly support the candidate's application to the specific discipline. In other words, if you're a mathematician applying to physics programs, your math professors should be explaining why you will be a great &lt;em&gt;physics&lt;/em&gt; graduate student, not a great &lt;em&gt;math&lt;/em&gt; graduate student. (Or why you will be a great graduate student in &lt;em&gt;any&lt;/em&gt; department.) &quot;Dissonance&quot; between the letters of recommendation and where you're applying could make some reviewers question if you're seriously interested in applying to physics departments, which could hurt your chances (albeit perhaps only slightly).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10311" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10311" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Should recommenders be from the same discipline as the program ones applying to" AnswerId="pe+LnCOf4/ippjIjRCCLaQ==" Author="1429" Date="2013-05-29T23:41:17.660" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would like to speak to this issue in terms of applying to &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;interdisciplinary&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; programs like information science, HCI, communication etc. It matters little what the specific home department the professor belongs to as long as they can point out 2 things - 1. How are you as a potential researcher in &lt;em&gt;that&lt;/em&gt; particular discipline that you are applying to and 2. How can they (the recommenders) recommend you in context to &lt;strong&gt;(1)&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For instance, in my case, my recommenders came from civil engineering, statistics and computer science and I was applying to an information science department. I don't know what their recommendations contained but they could very well certify that I was doing &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;interdisciplinary&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; work corresponding to most areas in information science during my masters degree.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10312" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10301	<question QuestionId="What strategies can bring technology resistant faculty on-board" Title="What strategies can bring technology resistant faculty on-board" Views="251" Tags="technology" " AnswerId="gUUbw0tFiNHI367F61k2Xg==" Author="7198" Date="2013-05-29T11:24:10.247" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;Faculty tend to fall into these groups:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;early adopters&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;hesitant but willing&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;refusing to adopt b/c no time&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;refusing to adopt b/c not technically inclined&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would like to know what strategies I can use to bring the &lt;strong&gt;3rd &amp;amp; 4th group&lt;/strong&gt; on-board.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;h2&gt;Context&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A new learning management system has been adopted where instructors are encouraged to post their slides/lecture materials online.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="What strategies can bring technology resistant faculty on-board" AnswerId="Q5HhMtogqejhf7p5IDO6Hg==" Author="346" Date="2013-05-29T15:58:11.157" Score="13" Text="&lt;p&gt;The question has a hidden assumption: that the technology has no problems and it's merely the faculty that need to be convinced. Having used a few different learning management systems (Canvas, Moodle, Blackboard, homegrown stuff), I can tell you that this is rarely true. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The people resistant to change are probably resisting because they've seen different incarnations of this technology come and go, and find it annoying to have to keep learning a new system &lt;em&gt;that doesn't present any significant advantages over what they're doing&lt;/em&gt;. The &lt;em&gt;significant&lt;/em&gt; part is important. There's a cost to making a change, so the new system can't just be as good. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So I'll add to Chris's excellent suggestions as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;make it seamless not just to import, but to &lt;strong&gt;export&lt;/strong&gt; easily. In the world of online software, it's important not to have things be gated. I want assurances that if your new system goes away tomorrow, to be replaced by the next new system, that I can easily transfer material from the old system to the new with a few clicks. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;demonstrate why this new system isn't going away in a year to be replaced by something else. How you do that is up to you and depends on the system you're pushing. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Bottom line: the perceived attitude in the question is that the faculty are at fault for not adopting new technology, but the truth is that most new tech is crappy and short-lived, and it's natural to want to wait things out. So you have convince people that the new approach is not crappy and will last. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What strategies can bring technology resistant faculty on-board" AnswerId="Q5HhMtogqejhf7p5IDO6Hg==" Author="6108" Date="2013-05-30T02:27:24.913" Text="Exactly. The system I'm told to use (which I do use, grudgingly) for uploading homework assignments, etc., makes it way more difficult than just slapping together a simple webpage with links would be, with less control over the final layout, and no apparent advantages. And who wouldn't shudder at the phrase &quot;learning management system&quot;?/>

<answer QuestionId="What strategies can bring technology resistant faculty on-board" AnswerId="0SUOIlKdeN0ilxvcQCPl3w==" Author="6110" Date="2013-05-29T16:30:38.393" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I can think of three strategies, which complement each other:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Win Group 2 over first.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If there are external reasons for using the technology, make them clear. For example, you might not persuade faculty that using this software is intrinsically a good idea, but you &lt;em&gt;might&lt;/em&gt; be able to persuade them that making the dean happy is reason enough.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Take the time to listen to their objections. They will be more willing to listen to you if they feel that you have listened to them, understood them, and respected them.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What strategies can bring technology resistant faculty on-board" AnswerId="0SUOIlKdeN0ilxvcQCPl3w==" Author="7198" Date="2013-05-30T02:41:31.837" Text="True, listening is key when implementing any change./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10308" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10308" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10308" Date="2013-05-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10308" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="What strategies can bring technology resistant faculty on-board" AnswerId="IeaDGGGJMjR5SkQJzkTJHw==" Author="4461" Date="2013-05-29T12:20:19.580" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;First of all, you need to make it exceedingly easy for the Luddites to put their material online.  If it is hard to do, or if it takes a particular skill other than &quot;go to this website and click a few links&quot; than you're going to have a hard time ever convincing them to get onboard.  If they absolutely need to be trained, you may have to have a mandatory training session where they get their first set of lectures or whatever online (but don't expect any other forthcoming material to be posted without more prodding--then again, they may see the light if it is easy enough and they can see the results online).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'd suggest one or more of the following four suggestions, in order of preference:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Ask for student volunteers to help these faculty put their material online.  Whether these are TAs for the class, or paid/hired students not already assigned, or strictly volunteers is up to you and budgeting concerns.  You may have to continue this process for subsequent classes if the faculty aren't willing to learn how to do it themselves.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Automate the system (which goes back to my original comment).  If paper is involved, have someone set up a scanner to handle loose-leaf material, or via a photocopier/scanner.  If it is just soft-copy document uploading, this can be automated with a drop box on a shared drive -- just drag materials into the box and it ends up online.  This won't make for a particularly organized system, but at least the material will be online.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Wait them out and let attrition work its magic.  You may always have reluctant faculty, but as older Luddites retire you should find this less of a problem.  If there are only a few faculty that don't want to come onboard, this is definitely the easiest method, and you're really not losing too much by waiting.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Make posting the material mandatory.  I can almost guarantee this won't be possible for tenured faculty, but maybe you can provide some incentive rather than simply encouraging them to put the material online.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't think you'll get very far with a simple plea for coming into the 21st Century -- if they are refusing to adopt, they probably feel they are too busy, or don't like the whole idea of it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What strategies can bring technology resistant faculty on-board" AnswerId="IeaDGGGJMjR5SkQJzkTJHw==" Author="73" Date="2013-05-29T16:37:42.967" Text="@techmsi - As a general rule of thumb, avoid selecting a particular answer as &quot;correct&quot; for at least a day or two after posting. New answers may still be posted that are better than the ones already here, and by marking as &quot;accepted&quot; you discourage new answers./>
<comment QuestionId="What strategies can bring technology resistant faculty on-board" AnswerId="IeaDGGGJMjR5SkQJzkTJHw==" Author="6110" Date="2013-05-29T16:41:46.280" Text="I disagree with (1); it seems to suggest that &quot;luddites&quot; are lazy, which might not be the case. I have declined to use related systems in the past, and it was because I was not persuaded that they were a valuable use of time -- either my own or someone else's./>
<comment QuestionId="What strategies can bring technology resistant faculty on-board" AnswerId="IeaDGGGJMjR5SkQJzkTJHw==" Author="7198" Date="2013-05-29T12:38:43.003" Text="Excellent suggestions. Thank you. I like the idea of volunteers but my concern is that those faculty members won't know how to post the materials themselves and will always need help from others./>

I can see how in cases like your example, that would be an incorrect assumption, but without more context to the question, I assumed that &quot;refusing to adopt&quot; could be overcome with help to put the material online./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10314	<question QuestionId="PhD Admissions Importance: Research vs Grades" Title="PhD Admissions Importance: Research vs Grades" Views="775" Tags="graduate-admissions,research-undergraduate,computer-science" " AnswerId="SHW4XODkbyPKMzTq4sIlgA==" Author="5658" Date="2013-05-30T04:25:18.373" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have read and been told that research is the single most important factor for applying for PhD programs in STEM fields. But, I also hear that GPA and GRE scores are the first cutting point for adcoms. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What is actually more important, grades or research? Will committees look at applicants with low GPAs?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In my scenario, I have a ~3.4 GPA overall, ~3.7 in Major (CS). This is not stellar. But what I do have is 1 first-author conference publication (Best Paper Award at conference) and 1 first-author journal publication as a Junior, with more other work/papers in progress. And my GREs are 158V/170Q/4.5W.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm very interested in top schools, but I'm worried my GPA will hold me back.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Will admissions throw away my application at sight of my GPA? Or will they take the time to review my whole application?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="PhD Admissions Importance: Research vs Grades" AnswerId="SHW4XODkbyPKMzTq4sIlgA==" Author="12658" Date="2014-03-05T06:39:07.917" Text="That is quite amazing and you should hopefully not have too much trouble getting into the graduate school of your choice (did you, by the way?) I had little trouble making the high GPA, but any kind of success in research still eluded me for a long time./>

<answer QuestionId="PhD Admissions Importance: Research vs Grades" AnswerId="V/sCa1/dPEGbrLLVOl0hsQ==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-30T05:31:53.770" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;Graduate admissions committees should, in principle, be able to review all of the applications they receive in full; this is not like undergraduate admissions, where a small team may be responsible for 10,000 or 20,000 applications. That said, some of the larger graduate departments may receive several hundred applications per year, and it may be necessary to do a preliminary screening before deciding which applications will be examined in further detail. However, what gets through such a screen can vary strongly from school to school and department to department. For instance, if you're at a school whose alumni regularly go on to graduate schools and have a track record of success, that can also be a &quot;plus&quot; factor. If you're near the top of your class, that can also mitigate &quot;weak&quot; grades somewhat (because it indicates that your school resists grade inflation). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would hope that graduate admissions flag applications with publications listed, but it depends on whether or not the database reports that summarize applications actually can do a screen for the presence of publications. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Your specific case, however, is unfortunately in the &quot;no man's land&quot;—not a clear &quot;read no matter what,&quot; but also not an automatic &quot;throw away,&quot; either. It is probable that you will have a tough time if you look only at &quot;top 5&quot; or &quot;top 10&quot; departments, but you should be able to get considered by many good programs.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="PhD Admissions Importance: Research vs Grades" AnswerId="V/sCa1/dPEGbrLLVOl0hsQ==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-30T14:01:03.510" Text="Are you joking?  A best paper award at a good conference is enough to land a good _postdoc_ in CS.  This is not just a &quot;read no matter what&quot;, but a likely &quot;_admit_ no matter what&quot;./>
<comment QuestionId="PhD Admissions Importance: Research vs Grades" AnswerId="V/sCa1/dPEGbrLLVOl0hsQ==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-30T20:28:26.823" Text="If a top school is using a screen of GPA and GRE, this person might have a hard time. If they read the full application, then yes, it's a likely admit./>
<comment QuestionId="PhD Admissions Importance: Research vs Grades" AnswerId="V/sCa1/dPEGbrLLVOl0hsQ==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-30T23:32:23.080" Text="I'm on the admissions committee of a top-5 CS department./>

While teaching still is enjoyable, I feel with the near completion of my PhD (in physics), that I am ready for a new challenge in academia.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have no illusions though, it will be challenging to even get into academia.  I know I also have to be published (have 3 peer reviewed papers published).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;How should the skills developed in high school teaching be touted to be relevant for academic postions?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="progressing from high school teaching into academia" AnswerId="8JRxL3r5rU9DQrR9H/3tLQ==" Author="7287" Date="2013-05-30T20:51:07.477" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;If you are near completing your PhD, then I assume you also have some papers coming out soon. If not, then your dissertation will probably be worth 3 papers, so I wouldn't worry too much about that part.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Conveying information to an audience with varied skills and backgrounds is always a valuable thing in academia. Whether in written manuscripts or conference presentations, this is usually the problem to be solved. My advisor was fond of constructing lectures, no matter the audience, as if they were to be given to college freshmen. I'd say a lot of freshmen are not too different from high school students.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A successful PhD defense signifies that you have the ability to do novel work in your field, but your teaching skills will enable you to tell others about it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_1032	<question QuestionId="What is the usual role of a faculty senate Does it typically have any real power or is it a rubber-stamp for the administrators" Title="What is the usual role of a faculty senate Does it typically have any real power or is it a rubber-stamp for the administrators" Views="216" Tags="professors" " AnswerId="hLC3ciuRNA0fvHRw7jnj2w==" Author="590" Date="2012-04-06T00:18:52.943" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;Although the presence of a senate suggests that universities nominally are governed somewhat by their faculty, it is frequently stated that there has been a trend towards greater managerialism, which has perhaps undermined the powers of faculty regarding university governance.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What current powers does a faculty senate typically have, or is it mostly a rubber-stamp for the administrators?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1032" Date="2013-08-07T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1032" Date="2012-04-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1032" Date="2012-05-09T00:00:00.000/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1032" Date="2014-02-12T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="What is the usual role of a faculty senate Does it typically have any real power or is it a rubber-stamp for the administrators" AnswerId="Jrf+q97aZXSXmD5zwsJbWA==" Author="384" Date="2012-05-12T12:14:31.137" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;I've been on the Senate and on the Faculty Board of Studies in my university.  Basically, boards like these are about communication, to make sure there is some oversight by academics of administrative decisions.  They do have veto rights, and on rare occasion these may be exercised. Individuals on them have an opportunity to bring things to the attention of academic executives.  How happy they seem about an idea also gives the executive an idea of how much trouble an idea will be to implement.  They also learn things about what is happening in the university or faculty which they can bring back to their department.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;How useful a board is and how much communication is really done depends on both established culture and individual initiative.  But the mechanisms are usually there in the university's charter for these groups to actually to be quite useful.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What is the usual role of a faculty senate Does it typically have any real power or is it a rubber-stamp for the administrators" AnswerId="Jrf+q97aZXSXmD5zwsJbWA==" Author="980" Date="2014-03-28T19:31:26.480" Text="I am (happily) surprised to hear that at some universities faculty senates have veto rights. In my university, apart from tenure decisions (which still must be approved by the Provost!), the faculty senate is _purely_advisory_./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1535" Date="2014-03-28T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1535" Date="2014-03-28T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1535" Date="2012-05-13T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="What is the usual role of a faculty senate Does it typically have any real power or is it a rubber-stamp for the administrators" AnswerId="bm81WTKl5ZCf8Kf4X9/ogg==" Author="817" Date="2012-05-09T15:47:41.100" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;This question seems a bit wide to answer.  Are you interested in public or private schools?  Junior college or peer 1 research level?  US or elsewhere?  Let me answer from the prospective of a 4-year US state institution.  Generally senates seem to be what the faculty make of them, they can choose to become a rubber stamp, or choose to act...  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;A. The senate functions as a voice of the faculty&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;By filtering and focusing the concerns of the faculty, the senate functions as a key voice of the faculty.  A voice selected or elected by departments across the campus. The senate can conduct dialog with the administration, offer press releases, lobby with legislators, join in with other institutions to tackle larger issues... Whether or not they are listened to, faculty member should speak together often about the central issues at the institution.   &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;B. Determination of General Educational Policy&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Traditionally the senate allows the different disciplines to discuss joint concerns, such as the general education policy, starting new programs, ...  They are rarely the final voice (or even the key voice) in these issues, but they are an important one.  Anytime an educational goal has been set, it is the faculty who should determine the curriculum, these decisions usually pass through a senate body.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;C. Maintaining the Faculty &quot;handbook&quot;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This may be given different names at different institutions, but the subset of policies and procedures related to tenure, promotion, post tenure review, usually fall under faculty review. Core parts are usually decided by the institutions board, but many of the details of faculty evaluations, ... are often decided by the faculty.  Even when they are not, the Senate provides a united voice to address these issues.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;D. Protect the Faculty's Interests&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example, the Senate should (to the best of their ability) be involved in suggestion priorities for budgeting (whether listened to or not); in suggesting standards for academic freedom (and explaining to its member what it is, and what it is not); when necessary, the Senate should be ready to stand up for individual faculty when the institutions polices have been incorrectly applied;  ...&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1503" Date="2012-05-09T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1503" Date="2014-03-28T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1503" Date="2012-05-09T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1503" Date="2012-05-13T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10320	<question QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" Title="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" Views="1630" Tags="publishing,thesis,writing,graphics" " AnswerId="ZValVjxkEcdIH9sl9CFGIA==" Author="7281" Date="2013-05-30T12:57:57.463" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'm doing an astrophysics thesis with a lot of programming in Python. I'm currently using gnuplot for my plots, but I wonder if this is actually looking quite professional. Are there other options which look better and are still easy to use?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Here an example of a figure in my thesis:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://i.stack.imgur.com/pappK.png&quot; alt=&quot;Example Figure&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The vertical line I got with the following command:   &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;set arrow from 4861.3,-1200 to 4861.3,2000 nohead lc 2  &#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I know it reaches out of the figure, but I use this command for all of my script and I know only at the end what the upper and lower boundary of the y-axis will be. Every peak is different.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="ZValVjxkEcdIH9sl9CFGIA==" Author="285" Date="2013-06-01T10:26:32.667" Text="See my comment [here](http://academia.stackexchange.com/a/10033/285)./>

If you do, then you can probably post it and ask, &quot;What can I do to improve this plot?&quot; and solicit specific advice rather than just asking about alternative software packages that may or may not help you./>

<comment QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="ZValVjxkEcdIH9sl9CFGIA==" Author="49" Date="2013-05-31T15:04:27.100" Text="@JanosBraem Questions &quot;Is GNUPlot able to generate publication-quality plots?&quot; and &quot;Is this plot (generated by GNUPlot) publication-quality?&quot; are very different. And the later may be unsuitable for StackExchange sites as &quot;too localized&quot; or &quot;off-topic&quot; (as it is about tweaking plot, what has a lot to do with other sites, SE sites, but not - academia)./>
<comment QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="ZValVjxkEcdIH9sl9CFGIA==" Author="669" Date="2013-05-31T17:02:17.250" Text="If you know _where_ the peak is, how come you don't know how high it is?  Why use an arrow without a head instead of plotting a new line of data with two points?  There are problems with the graph--legends should be larger than tick labels, line width could maybe be a bit thicker, having stuff like u($1/(1.9072)):2 (or even the file name) is not very professional-looking.  But these are all fixable with a bit of effort without using something other than Gnuplot./>
<comment QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="ZValVjxkEcdIH9sl9CFGIA==" Author="7116" Date="2013-05-30T13:11:04.343" Text="Gnuplot is *the* choice of plotting tool. Go ahead, be good at it and there will be little chance you go wrong. There are plenty of resources in the internet (e.g. [Gnuplotting](http://www.gnuplotting.org/)), and also Janert's book, [Gnuplot in action](http://www.manning.com/janert/). Good luck!/>

But with the hints and tips here I'm convinced that with some approvements Gnuplot also suits for publication./>

<answer QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="8V2bOJ39C2MAe2rVPaGf0Q==" Author="1010" Date="2013-05-31T14:06:07.517" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;For the plot you've shown, I have a couple of suggestions to make it look more &quot;professional&quot;.  (Maybe you're already doing some of these in the actual document.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Use a vector-based file format; your lines will look smoother, up to the resolution of your printer.  I suggest &lt;code&gt;set terminal pdf&lt;/code&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Set a meaningful title for the curve: &lt;code&gt;plot &quot;tkrs.txt&quot; using ... title &quot;Dilithium flux density&quot;&lt;/code&gt;.  Or omit it completely: &lt;code&gt;plot &quot;tkrs.txt&quot; using ... notitle&lt;/code&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If plotting a mathematical function (rather than a dataset), &lt;code&gt;set samples 5000&lt;/code&gt; or something similarly high for your final output.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Try to choose a font for the labels that matches the paper's text as closely as possible.  See &lt;code&gt;help term pdf&lt;/code&gt; for more info, and other interesting tweaks.  You can also use non-ASCII characters (e.g. &lt;code&gt;Å&lt;/code&gt; instead of &lt;code&gt;angstrom&lt;/code&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Set the plot to a size and aspect ratio that fits nicely on the page, preferably so that your word processor (or LaTeX) doesn't have to rescale it.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;For your vertical line, you could cheat and use a parametric function, so that it will be clipped to the boundaries of the plot.  It's a little tricky because if you make the line extra long, by default the plot will be rescaled to fit all of it.  But there is a way to avoid this:&lt;pre&gt;&#xA;set xrange [ ] writeback&#xA;set yrange [ ] writeback&#xA;plot &quot;tkrs.txt&quot; ...&#xA;set parametric&#xA;set trange [-1200:10000]&#xA;set xrange restore&#xA;set yrange restore&#xA;replot t, 4861.3 notitle&#xA;&lt;/pre&gt;    &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="8V2bOJ39C2MAe2rVPaGf0Q==" Author="7281" Date="2013-05-31T14:14:20.863" Text="Thx a lot for the hints, I'll try them all next week./>

<answer QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="iCzxzqI/h1lXypcMyKIxAA==" Author="669" Date="2013-05-30T17:52:26.600" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;It is difficult to produce professional-looking output from Gnuplot (even harder than it is from Matlab, which I also wouldn't recommend).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Since you're already using Python, &lt;a href=&quot;http://matplotlib.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;matplotlib&lt;/a&gt; is the obvious choice.  You you can even make a decent attempt at producing &lt;a href=&quot;http://neuroscience.telenczuk.pl/?p=331&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;full figures&lt;/a&gt;, not just one panel.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Typically astrophysics doesn't have much reference to astronomy these days.  However, if your thesis does, you might also want to check out &lt;a href=&quot;http://aplpy.github.io/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;APLpy&lt;/a&gt; which adds on to matplotlib.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="iCzxzqI/h1lXypcMyKIxAA==" Author="7116" Date="2013-05-30T20:07:35.823" Text="you say: &quot;It is difficult to produce professional-looking output from Gnuplot&quot;. I beg to disagree, Gnuplot is excellent if you use it with care, at least for two-dimensional plots./>
<comment QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="iCzxzqI/h1lXypcMyKIxAA==" Author="669" Date="2013-05-31T16:46:42.423" Text="@PaulHiemstra - All of them are badly aliased.  In the first one, the axis labels are too small--all the text is, really--and the erf label is too close to the border.  In the second one, the tick labels are not helping anything and the arrow looks cartoonish.  The third one is good; only the tick labels are too long.  The fourth is just ugly; you need less space and wavy lines not just slashes to indicate space, and you need it on the graph line as well.  The fifth has bad axis label spacing (including tick labels), and the smoothing has introduced a shift in the data.  You get the idea./>
<comment QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="iCzxzqI/h1lXypcMyKIxAA==" Author="669" Date="2013-05-31T16:52:32.280" Text="@PaulHiemstra - That said, I've also seen worse, but the nice-looking ones don't look easy, and the easy-looking ones don't look that nice.  And the examples don't cover things that gnuplot doesn't do that well like line symbols (e.g. setting line width of your box symbol).  Then again, sometimes you don't want your figures to be a work of art but just to get the point across, and then you can usually get something acceptable without changing too many defaults./>
<comment QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="iCzxzqI/h1lXypcMyKIxAA==" Author="669" Date="2013-05-30T20:15:25.270" Text="@MarcusAntoninus - Just for reference, I view the graphs in http://www.phyast.pitt.edu/~zov1/ as borderline in terms of publication-quality./>

I've seen worse in publications./>
<comment QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="iCzxzqI/h1lXypcMyKIxAA==" Author="669" Date="2013-05-30T20:12:37.363" Text="@MarcusAntoninus - What is the difference between &quot;difficult&quot; and &quot;with care&quot;?/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10326" Date="2013-06-23T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="72ym+mddpcJOu/pgmEIXMg==" Author="4394" Date="2013-05-30T15:55:18.540" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;The choice of plotting choice will depend on several factors. First, it is important to state that there are many options, from GNUPlot, through commercial plotting packages such as Grapher and Origin, plotting capabilities of Matlab and R to plotting using specific packages such as pgfplots (LaTeX) or graphics packages accompanying programming languages (e.g. &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nova.edu/ocean/psplot/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;PSPlot&lt;/a&gt;). What you chose will depend on other factors such as what your peers use, what you may have become familiar with and perhaps what you can afford (thinking of open source vs. commercial).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My personal experience has been that there is no single software that can do everything and so for me the key has been to identify what I need done and to minimize the number of software I need to accomplish it. This has led me to choices that are not common to my peers and has also left me to find my own solutions, not dreawing so much from other pesons experience (thank heavens for sites such as stackexchange)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So stick to what you know as long as it can do what you want but always keep an eye out for new solutions and try to figure out what others are doing that may impress you.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10323" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10323" Date="2013-05-30T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="h7kc5US+adJebKZjYFr28A==" Author="3890" Date="2013-05-30T13:40:02.290" Score="13" Text="&lt;p&gt;If you do the programming in Python, you could also do the plotting in Python with &lt;a href=&quot;http://matplotlib.org&quot;&gt;matplotlib&lt;/a&gt;. With a little adjustment of the plotting parameters, it is possible to produce publication-quality plots with this software.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Alternatively, if you need fancy annotations etc., I can recommend the &lt;a href=&quot;http://pgfplots.sourceforge.net&quot;&gt;pgfplots&lt;/a&gt; package for tikz/LaTeX. You could export data from your Python program to a csv file, and then use that as data source for plotting with pgfplots. If you are also using TeX for the main text, it allows to to produce graphics which nicely fit the formating of the text.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="h7kc5US+adJebKZjYFr28A==" Author="102" Date="2013-05-30T14:02:40.493" Text="+1 for pgfplots, it's so easy to use!/>
<comment QuestionId="Gnuplot in thesis and articles or not" AnswerId="h7kc5US+adJebKZjYFr28A==" Author="257" Date="2013-06-01T10:17:31.757" Text="With matplotlib you can also generate figures with LaTeX text and formulas in them/>

I mean I have found templates for cover letters, but not for application letters. Is there any format for this? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thanks&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="differences between cover letter and application letter" AnswerId="sHp8jG3YPqLl792ixOptmw==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-30T21:16:18.853" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Good question, and has been something that I have been thinking about also.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Digging around, I found a few articles that may be of assistance, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ehow.com/info_8065585_application-letter-same-cover-letter.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;This eHow article&lt;/a&gt; (Even though it is more trained towards work, rather than academia), and &lt;a href=&quot;http://jobsearch.about.com/od/cover-letters/tp/types-of-cover-letters.htm&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;thi about.com article&lt;/a&gt;.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Both links state that there are subtle differences - specifically, an application latter explains what qualifies you for the position/study, and the cover letter goes into more detail as to what qualifies you and explains your interests in the position/study.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I hope this helps (and best wishes with your application and studies!)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Can I publish research in a peer-reviewed journal if parts of it have previously been published in a self published book" AnswerId="R6uvIluzx1cZJW+TcgsDrQ==" Author="1537" Date="2013-05-31T15:57:36.023" Text="Some journals may say no. If you decide to do so - the existence of prior published product should be clearly stated in the cover letter and the book should be referenced by the article./>

<answer QuestionId="Can I publish research in a peer-reviewed journal if parts of it have previously been published in a self published book" AnswerId="AE1LEfbwvzRClmR2tfsxJQ==" Author="1010" Date="2013-05-31T03:46:06.030" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;I didn't find any formal policies addressing this specific case, but my intuition is that it would probably be all right.  It could be analogous to publishing sections of a thesis, which is generally accepted.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have a journal in mind for the paper, you could contact the editors and ask their position on the issue.  If and when you eventually submit the paper, you should include a note to the editor explaining the situation, and probably mention this in the text of the paper as well.  If you disclose everything, there won't be any ethical issue; the editor can make the decision, and I expect there would be some good journals that won't have a problem with it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Factors that might be relevant:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Was the book offered for sale publicly, or distributed privately among colleagues?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;How many copies were produced/sold?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Did you retain the copyright on the book?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10334	<question QuestionId="Path to a good grad school" Title="Path to a good grad school" Views="699" Tags="graduate-school,graduate-admissions,mathematics" " AnswerId="nfYh5+CEd4FVZtA2qcJi+w==" Author="7310" Date="2013-05-31T04:54:10.477" Score="14" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'm a high school senior about to graduate in 1 month. I have a strong passion in math, and I want to be a mathematician. What is the best path to getting into a top grad school? How many REU's should I try to do? Any publications? How about graduate level courses? Do you need a 4.0 in undergrad? I'm also self studying as much math as I can, from Artin's Algebra, Munkre's topology, and baby Rudin. How much math should I know by the time I apply for grad school? I would greatly appreciate your feedback!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Path to a good grad school" AnswerId="nfYh5+CEd4FVZtA2qcJi+w==" Author="6442" Date="2013-06-09T20:54:04.527" Text="You should include basic geometry and complex analysis books in your otherwise excellent list.  Geometry: Tu An Introduction to Manifolds.  Complex Analysis: Brown &amp; Churchill Complex Variables and Applications./>

<answer QuestionId="Path to a good grad school" AnswerId="u5KRoba6d5OofDs1sVupTw==" Author="65" Date="2013-05-31T15:16:11.600" Score="12" Text="&lt;p&gt;Let me add one point to Zach's answer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Your primary goal should be to &lt;strong&gt;collect strong references&lt;/strong&gt;.  Admission committees in top departments are looking for evidence of research potential.  Aside from actual published research, the most compelling evidence is a strong letter from a well-known active researcher, who writes about your research potential in specific and credible detail, based on direct personal interaction.  To get those letters, you need to engage with professors as a &lt;em&gt;potential colleague&lt;/em&gt;, not just as a &lt;em&gt;student&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Yes, take advanced and graduate-level math classes, but don't &lt;em&gt;just&lt;/em&gt; sit in the back and quietly get As.  Ask (and answer) intelligent questions in class and in office hours.  Don't limit your questions (in office hours) to course material.  Ask about undergraduate research opportunities (&lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; just REUs) with the explicit goal of peer-reviewed publishable research (&lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; just reports on some REU website).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Keep in mind that becoming a published mathematician can take several years of effort, and there's no guarantee that you'll get there before you graduate.  But the sooner you start, the closer you'll get, and the more chances you'll have to impress the faculty you work with.  &lt;strong&gt;So start &lt;em&gt;now&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The first three profs you ask may tell you that publishing mathematics research as an undergraduate is impossible, because you need to take a five more years of classes before you can even understand the problem.  They're wrong; ask a fourth.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Path to a good grad school" AnswerId="u5KRoba6d5OofDs1sVupTw==" Author="7291" Date="2013-05-31T15:56:25.480" Text="Sort of along the same thread, let me also say that I wish I had gone to more seminars and talked to professors. It will help you figure out what's going on in the math world. I found that when I started applying for schools, I really didn't know what was actually going on. What did people really research? What topics were hot? I had no idea, and I think it really hurt my applications. It's difficult to talk about where you want to go with research if you don't know where active research is happening./>

<answer QuestionId="Path to a good grad school" AnswerId="CBOpy6fOrvAlinwLwJzwGw==" Author="7291" Date="2013-05-31T05:40:51.110" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;Here are my suggestions, having just finished a year of graduate school in math. It's therefore mostly anecdotal and should be taken lightly!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;REUs:&lt;/strong&gt; Try to do as many as you can! You get to meet other people who like math, learn new stuff, practice struggling with research, travel a bit, and get some cash to boot. They also, of course, look good on applications. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Publications:&lt;/strong&gt; I don't personally have any publications. I wrote a few papers during my REUs and projects, but they were only published on the REU websites. So they're not necessary to get in. However, I did have a great deal of trouble getting acceptances. Maybe a publication would have helped, but I think it's very rare for an undergraduate to actually publish a paper.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Graduate Courses:&lt;/strong&gt; I took several of these as an undergraduate. I enjoyed them, but realize now that I should have taken them a little more seriously! I've forgotten a great deal of what I saw in them. However, I have noticed that I'm quite strong in the area I took graduate courses in compared to my peers. So they definitely give you an edge! However, don't become too obsessed with loading up with graduate courses. Three of them is quite a lot of work, if you give them justice. Since most graduate courses are graded very lightly, you can make high marks in them without putting forth as much effort as you would in an undergraduate course! (At least, this was how it worked at my undergraduate institution.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That said, keep in mind that some of your time in college should be spent having fun, too. Don't become a math robot just yet! You have time for that in grad school. :)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Reading Textbooks:&lt;/strong&gt; The fact you're already reading the &quot;core&quot; undergraduate books before even entering the university puts you far, far ahead of the curve. Many people won't learn those things until sophomore or junior year. I certainly didn't. Make sure you're doing the bulk of the exercises in those books, especially Rudin. Try to prove statements you come across without looking at their proofs. I feel that this is where most of the learning happens. You can easily read things and not understand them, so just watch out! Other than that, finish those books and then you should be set to take the advanced undergraduate/first year graduate courses at your institution.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The Math Subject GRE:&lt;/strong&gt; I hate this thing and did very poorly on it. You'll blow the math portion of the general GRE out of the water. It's easy stuff for any math major. However, if you don't spend a little time reviewing, you can really mess up the subject test, since it's timed and covers things you might not have thought about for several years. The topics are almost completely disjoint from what a student taking graduate courses has been doing. Look at a few practice tests, identify what sorts of questions are asked, and train yourself to quickly answer such questions. Speed is key. You don't want the subject GRE to be a weak point on your application, especially since it's an easily prevented weak point.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, do REUs, take graduate courses, don't sweat not having publications (but if you can get some do), and study for the subject GRE!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Path to a good grad school" AnswerId="bhpyNV5GgyrIPqIwlYqmBA==" Author="user7628" Date="2013-07-06T16:55:47.273" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Some advice first:&lt;/strong&gt; Ultimately you may change your mind about what you want to do in your academic life (and you probably will, which is to be expected) so what I would do is make sure I have a back-up plan. By &quot;back-up plan&quot; I mean whatever field you may choose, make sure it coincides with another existing field (in some obvious, explicit way). That way, if you do end up hating say analytic number theory and you want to specialize in algebraic geometry instead, the path would be continuous, and you wouldn't face too many rough patches. Since you're passionate about math, I'm assuming you have a very, very rough idea of what you may want to specialize in grad school (applied math seems out the window). If not, that's okay. You've got years to think about that. If the answer is yes, then in addition to the core classes (abstract algebra, points-set topology, real analysis are the norm), you should self-study additional books that pertain to your field of interest. If you like number theory, start with Alan Baker's book. If you like geometry, start with Pedoe's book. And so on and so forth. In the meanwhile I'll give you an outline of what I think is the &quot;Ideal&quot; student's path towards a top grad school (for these purposes, I'm going to say all of the schools in the top 10 programs). This will be completely subjective of course, so disclaimer: don't get on my case. I'm also going to completely ignore the general education requirements and just focus on the math part. Since I'm not a believer in REUs I won't mention anything about that. I don't think they're a good reflection of research ability because not too many of them are exceptional. (i.e no first authorship. No grad school is going to believe you made progress on the Hodge conjecture if you say that on your personal statement. You'd only be BS'ing yourself). Moving on :-)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Freshman year&lt;/strong&gt;: Get your core classes over with. You'll probably be able to finish half of them in this time assuming you declare your major this early and you petition your academic adviser to take more than what the norm is (and if you can prove your competency in the subjects you've listed). They may be able to waive the prerequisites and make an exception for you. In the meanwhile, don't be a stool in class and just get A's. Ask and answer questions regarding your coursework. Go beyond that and take advantage of your professors' office hours. Don't worry if you think you're intruding: it's part of the job description, and they'll probably like the enthusiasm. Talk to them about doing research (it's definitely &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; too early) in an area of interest. Provide your relevant mathematical background so that they may guide you. Ask them what other professors you should talk to if you want to do undergrad research in X, Y, or Z. Collect as much information and ask as many questions as possible. In the meanwhile, maintain a consistent average (3.8+ would probably be favorable). If all goes well, you should be able to get started (or at least have a topic and someone to work with) by the beginning of your sophomore year. If you wanna have fun, you should take the Putnam exam (I don't know how relevant scores are to grad admissions) and see how well you do. If you somehow become a Putnam Fellow, that's going to significantly increase your chances (for bureaucracy reasons probably since the Putnam exam and research mathematics require different tool sets). Still, you can only take this exam a maximum of 4 times in your undergrad years (once for every year). So I'd take advantage of that. If your university has an honors program that results in a senior thesis, I'd take advantage of that as well. Sometimes very exceptional theses get published in journals and that'd be a good credential to have.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Sophomore year&lt;/strong&gt;: By the end of this year you should be well done by your core requirements (assuming you're persistent and keep petitioning to take more and more credit hours). More importantly, at the end of this year you should have a very rough idea of what you may want to study in grad school. But it should be more concise than whatever you're thinking about now. At this point you should also think about starting at least 2 more research projects (the reason is, you need at most 3 letters of recommendation for places like Princeton). If you can get 3 letters of rec. from professors who know you well (i.e the ones you worked with in your 3 research projects) that'll look very favorably on your application. Once again, take the Putnam. Maintain your GPA as close to a 4.0 as possible. You know, the usual.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Junior year&lt;/strong&gt;: Now would be a good time to start taking grad-level classes. Try to coincide these classes with your area of interest. If you like algebraic geometry, take a class on that and see how you like it. You should know the drill by now. If you're still working on these projects (and you probably will be) don't lose focus. If a publication seems like a pipe dream, that's okay. &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;Publications are not expected of undergrads&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;. But it would look great of course. If you have not already, you should think about which grad schools you may want to apply to. Again, maintain that high GPA and take the Putnam to ease your sure to be troubled mind. By the end of Junior year, you should start studying for the GRE and the GRE Subject test. If you happen to have done extremely well on the Putnam (i.e became a Putnam Fellow or scored in the top 100) you'll probably find the studying part trivial as you've had much practice with problem solving and adeptness. Of course don't get cocky: you should still review anyway.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Senior year&lt;/strong&gt;: Take the GRE and the GRE Subject test. Kick ass at them. Try to finish up your 3 research projects if you have not already and prepare to submit them to a peer-reviewed journal. The process may take time so don't be discouraged if you're still not finished by the time you apply. Be sure to do well on your senior thesis as well assuming your university offers them. Get those amazing letters of rec. from the 3 - 4 year relationship you've established with your professors. Go overload on those grad classes (or self-study) and work at optimum. Get acquainted with your potential field. After all is said and done, write up your CV, do your applications, and send them in. After that, take a sigh of relief, put up your feet, and relax. Take the Putnam for the final time. Enjoy your remaining months in college before you're off doing your PhD.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If all goes well, you'll get published, you'll get praised, and you'll get into your schools of choice.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Path to a good grad school" AnswerId="bhpyNV5GgyrIPqIwlYqmBA==" Author="65" Date="2013-07-07T15:18:38.377" Text="Presumably, Claire Voisin's letter would clarify her coauthor's contribution to the work.  (Then again, if the committee really thinks Claire Voisin might be so unethical that she would offer co-authorship to someone who didn't make a significant intellectual contribution, they wouldn't trust her letter, either.)/>
<comment QuestionId="Path to a good grad school" AnswerId="bhpyNV5GgyrIPqIwlYqmBA==" Author="65" Date="2013-07-06T19:40:43.497" Text="_No grad school is going to believe you made progress on the Hodge conjecture if you say that on your personal statement_ — They don't have to believe you; they can just read the ArXiv preprint.  No preprint?  No progress./>
<comment QuestionId="Path to a good grad school" AnswerId="bhpyNV5GgyrIPqIwlYqmBA==" Author="user7628" Date="2013-07-06T19:53:27.190" Text="Right, but in this context I meant it in terms of whoever you were working with. Say the paper is verified and you take all the credit for it. I meant that a committee probably won't give you credit over say, Claire Voisin, if you claim that you were the reason most of that progress was made. Unless you were very, very brilliant of course :-) but this was all hypothetical on my part./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10337	<question QuestionId="Is it necessary to send a corrigendum Does it make my paper look ugly" Title="Is it necessary to send a corrigendum Does it make my paper look ugly" Views="454" Tags="publications,proofreading" " AnswerId="jdY+NooXkcywjbfAU34tUA==" Author="6928" Date="2013-05-31T09:03:00.723" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have a paper which is accepted without any minor or major revisions in a good journal (lucky me). It is fully published. Since I had no chance to revise it, many small mistakes slipped into the proof. During proofreading I tried my best to catch any mistake and correct it. But these were two problems: 1) There were too many small mistakes so at least one of them slided my attention. 2) I couldn't ask the copy-editor to remove a whole &quot;sentence&quot;. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If I had the chance to revise it, I would easily fix that up. But now the erroneous sentence is there in my beloved paper. It is now fully published (as online and hard copy). I am tempted to send a corrigendum on that paper, saying that the line is incorrect and should not be there. But on the other hand am afraid that it would make my paper look not-perfect or even ugly.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Do you suggest me sending a corrigendum? Or should I wait until someone notices that and writes a letter to the editor and then I answer in a reply to that letter, saying that &quot;yes you are right, that sentence should not be there in the first place&quot;? And if no one noticed that, I leave that error alone.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Which other ideas do you have about this?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thanks a lot. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is it necessary to send a corrigendum Does it make my paper look ugly" AnswerId="jdY+NooXkcywjbfAU34tUA==" Author="6928" Date="2013-05-31T10:08:35.190" Text="You know, reading it again I saw I have not even suggested that incorrect method as something &quot;used&quot; in our study. Although it might incorrectly imply so, but the sentence is written in a way that it is not indicative of the &quot;use&quot; of the incorrect method by us. So I think I should leave it, as it has no harm. Not even incorrect./>
<comment QuestionId="Is it necessary to send a corrigendum Does it make my paper look ugly" AnswerId="jdY+NooXkcywjbfAU34tUA==" Author="7283" Date="2013-05-31T09:27:28.653" Text="does the error affect your results or conclusion in any way? Does it prevent anyone from repeating the work and ending up with the same conclusion?/>
<comment QuestionId="Is it necessary to send a corrigendum Does it make my paper look ugly" AnswerId="jdY+NooXkcywjbfAU34tUA==" Author="6928" Date="2013-05-31T09:42:45.920" Text="Thanks. Fortunately no. I have stated some method of measurement incorrectly. I have stated the routine method for measuring something, while we had actually used another method (which is again common). The original method is as well reported some paragraphs above!! Existence of that sentence would not damage any results or conclusions at all, but does not accord with reality and also with the original method which is reported in a couple of paragraphs above!! This is what I am concerned about. So what do you think? I might ask the same from journal's editor too. But would appreciate ideas./>
<comment QuestionId="Is it necessary to send a corrigendum Does it make my paper look ugly" AnswerId="jdY+NooXkcywjbfAU34tUA==" Author="6928" Date="2013-05-31T09:43:37.457" Text="And no it does not prevent anyone from repeating the work. That measurement can be done in any of the two ways (both reported in my paper!). And both would give the same result./>
