<answer QuestionId="Is it necessary to send a corrigendum Does it make my paper look ugly" AnswerId="MUY9x3kQgAen/zumJauz1w==" Author="94" Date="2013-05-31T12:33:58.273" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;Given your clarifications &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/10337/is-it-necessary-to-send-a-corrigendum-does-it-make-my-paper-look-ugly#comment18761_10337&quot;&gt;1&lt;/a&gt;, &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/10337/is-it-necessary-to-send-a-corrigendum-does-it-make-my-paper-look-ugly#comment18762_10337&quot;&gt;2&lt;/a&gt;, and &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/10337/is-it-necessary-to-send-a-corrigendum-does-it-make-my-paper-look-ugly#comment18763_10337&quot;&gt;3&lt;/a&gt;, I would suggest leaving it alone. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The modern trend is for the &lt;em&gt;corrigenda&lt;/em&gt; and the &lt;em&gt;errata&lt;/em&gt; to be used more for &quot;serious&quot; stuff, and less so for &quot;cosmetic&quot; changes. The guideline, for example, given by the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.apsstylemanual.org/formattingAPSJournalArticles/corrigendum.htm&quot;&gt;American Physiological Society&lt;/a&gt; is:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;if the author determines that it is scientifically necessary&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;While &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nature.com/authors/policies/corrections.html&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Nature&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/a&gt; uses the following definition for a corrigendum:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Corrigendum.&lt;/em&gt; Notification of an important error made by the author(s) that affects the publication record or the scientific integrity of the paper, or the reputation of the authors or the journal. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Unless the venue in which you published your work states otherwise in their publication guidelines, a stray sentence that is not factually false, does not invalidate your claims, and does not impinge on the efforts of other researchers to reproduce your work is likely not &quot;scientifically necessary.&quot; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Even if you insist on perfection, you should also be aware how corrigenda are viewed by other researchers in your field. If in your field the prevailing view is that corrigenda are used for &quot;scientifically necessary&quot; changes to your article, then you need to be prepared to answer questions about your correction in the future (usually of the form, &quot;Why is there a corrigendum issued for your paper? Are you &lt;em&gt;sure&lt;/em&gt; it doesn't change your conclusions?&quot;) &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Lastly, a minor point is that if you published in a journal which charges publication fees, quite often your corrigendum will come with a not-so-small price-tag also. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is it necessary to send a corrigendum Does it make my paper look ugly" AnswerId="MUY9x3kQgAen/zumJauz1w==" Author="6928" Date="2013-05-31T13:48:42.487" Text="This journal publishes so rapidly and is very busy. They receive tons of manuscript. So I am confident many other published papers might have such small issues (especially those few which are accepted as is)./>

About the fee, no the journal charges no fees at all. So a corrigendum would not hurt my pocket. :)/>
<comment QuestionId="Is it necessary to send a corrigendum Does it make my paper look ugly" AnswerId="MUY9x3kQgAen/zumJauz1w==" Author="6928" Date="2013-05-31T13:44:48.483" Text="Many thanks. That made my day! Actually it is trivial but I am perfectionist and that sentence sounds stupid in the middle of a good paper (so a threat to my own reputation and also for the journal's rep)(of course a tiny trivial threat). On the other hand, it is so small that a corrigendum would be a waste of one paper. But about the reputation of the journal, I am not sure. I don't know if a small error affects reputation of the journal or not. A small error that nobody has recognized thus far (my colleagues, editors, reviewers [it is accepted as is]).../>

<answer QuestionId="Maximizing opportunities to be admitted in top schools" AnswerId="wRKKyLM0gOcm9q/UH1ICKw==" Author="929" Date="2012-06-05T14:01:54.100" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;Your approach is wrong and will be a hindrance in maximizing your chances for acceptance. No school wants to accept someone who only wants to go to their school because of its ranking. You need to tailor your application to demonstrate why you want to go to the particular school. Once you have identified some schools/supervisors, ideally one of your recommendation writers can introduce you. You then need to build on that relationship. Talk to them about how your work fits in with their past and current work. As your relationship with the potential supervisors builds, figure out how they fit into the department. They will likely have the inside knowledge needed for writing a really good application.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10340	<question QuestionId="Is it illegal to share scientific publications not in the public domain" Title="Is it illegal to share scientific publications not in the public domain" Views="363" Tags="journals,publishers,open-access,open-science,public-domain" " AnswerId="ASZmlMfoco2CamIgl6V0XA==" Author="1243" Date="2013-05-31T10:18:15.360" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;Back in my university days, I got into the habit of saving papers I had to read to my hard disk. At first I did this simply to organize them more conveniently, and have quicker access to them. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, my reasons for saving those papers to disk gradually changed as graduation approached. In the end, I saved &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;a lot&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; of papers, because at one point I realized that I had unrestricted, unlimited, free access to an absolutely fantastic source of richness, and that soon after graduation, I'd lose all of that.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Years later, I now frequently end up in discussions, or get asked questions, or otherwise end up at a point where a common access to one of those papers really helps to progress the discussion. I often just send that paper around without thinking twice about it, more because I believe that's how science should work than anything else. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I believe most of those papers are however &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; in the public domain, meaning, people not associated with a university or other institution that has access, can &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; access the paper without some payment to its official publisher.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So is any of this legal? If not, what are the possible repercussions for me personally, and for the people I sent it to? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I realize this is a touchy issue, and there are many initiatives to open scientific publications up for the general public. A related question would be: do these initiatives (like &lt;a href=&quot;http://science.okfn.org/tools-for-open-science/&quot;&gt;all of these&lt;/a&gt;) exist partly because of this reason? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Is it illegal to share scientific publications not in the public domain" AnswerId="SVgDZN12CIswhJxkkcOnNw==" Author="725" Date="2013-06-02T13:45:15.750" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;As your user page indicates that you are in Germany, you may be interested in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/urhg/__53.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;§53 UrhG&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;(2) Zulässig ist, einzelne Vervielfältigungsstücke eines Werkes herzustellen oder herstellen zu lassen&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;ol&gt;&#xA;  &lt;li&gt;zum eigenen wissenschaftlichen Gebrauch, wenn und soweit die Vervielfältigung zu diesem Zweck geboten ist und sie keinen gewerblichen Zwecken dient,&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(Rough translation:&lt;br&gt;&#xA;&lt;em&gt;(2) it is permitted to make or let be made single copies of a work&lt;br&gt;&#xA;  1. for personal scientific use, if and as far as copying is needed for this reason and is  not for commercial reasons,&lt;/em&gt;&lt;br&gt;&#xA;)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;which is a kind of continental european fair use policy.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Working in science I think that putting papers I read in a personal private archive is needed - if only to be able to answer specific claims or questions about papers I cite in my papers, presentations, .... &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is it illegal to share scientific publications not in the public domain" AnswerId="SVgDZN12CIswhJxkkcOnNw==" Author="725" Date="2013-06-03T21:20:58.207" Text="@silvado: No idea, I'd be inclined to read it that way, but I'm chemist, no laywer. I usually interpret it the way that it is OK if I nicely ask our librarian whether she can email me the paper to which I should have access in general but don't have from my office. However, §53 UrhG is longer and has a quite substantial list of exceptions. Note that we pay for every sheet of printer paper, every copying machine, scanner,  etc. fees that go into an authors' fund, so in a way you anyways pay for the copy./>
<comment QuestionId="Is it illegal to share scientific publications not in the public domain" AnswerId="SVgDZN12CIswhJxkkcOnNw==" Author="3890" Date="2013-06-03T13:40:28.640" Text="Good point - I wonder whether the case &quot;herstellen zu lassen&quot; / &quot;let be made&quot; would apply to the situation where a colleague asks me to send him a copy of a paper I happen to have in my archive?/>
<comment QuestionId="Is it illegal to share scientific publications not in the public domain" AnswerId="SVgDZN12CIswhJxkkcOnNw==" Author="3890" Date="2013-06-04T08:43:09.660" Text="Right, the copying fees should cover that. It's also a nice money source for academic authors: http://academia.stackexchange.com/a/8701/3890 ./>

<answer QuestionId="Is it illegal to share scientific publications not in the public domain" AnswerId="VXHx3b5HvUkIaiQWo1NgrQ==" Author="4461" Date="2013-05-31T10:44:33.640" Score="8" Text="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;So is any of this legal?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Unless your sharing falls under &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fair_use&quot;&gt;fair use&lt;/a&gt; in your particular country (and with the Internet, sharing online is a tricky business anyway), you should not share the papers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you want to share the papers, linking to the original source is the best option, and &lt;a href=&quot;http://scholar.google.com/&quot;&gt;Google Scholar&lt;/a&gt; or other online repositories can get you pretty far with a lot of material.  If you can't find an online source, you are limited to providing a cite and hope that whoever wants to find the article can use their library to source it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;If not, what are the possible repercussions for me personally, and for the people I sent it to?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Practically?  Unless you are sharing the files openly to a broad audience (i.e., so they are available online), no one is going to track you down to sue you.  I would avoid linking directly to articles that aren't behind a paywall, but emailing them to people you are collaborating with is unlikely to cause you any trouble.   &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is it illegal to share scientific publications not in the public domain" AnswerId="VXHx3b5HvUkIaiQWo1NgrQ==" Author="94" Date="2013-05-31T13:58:16.230" Text="@RodyOldenhuis: international copyright law is _always_ a thorny business. I don't think there would even be a universal answer to your follow-up: it would at least in part depend on the copyright treaties signed by the countries and on the commercial presence of the publishers in the various countries involved.../>
<comment QuestionId="Is it illegal to share scientific publications not in the public domain" AnswerId="VXHx3b5HvUkIaiQWo1NgrQ==" Author="1243" Date="2013-05-31T11:53:00.037" Text="wow...that doesn't sound very strict at all...But I can't help but wonder: fair-using a paper published in a US journal in another country, is that  subject to the laws *of that country* or to the US fair use doctrine? (I'm really not a legal talent...)/>
<comment QuestionId="Is it illegal to share scientific publications not in the public domain" AnswerId="VXHx3b5HvUkIaiQWo1NgrQ==" Author="1243" Date="2013-05-31T10:53:07.107" Text="&quot;[illegal, but] no one is going to track you down to sue you&quot;...sound like &quot;legal&quot; to me :)/>
<comment QuestionId="Is it illegal to share scientific publications not in the public domain" AnswerId="VXHx3b5HvUkIaiQWo1NgrQ==" Author="25" Date="2013-06-02T15:33:45.683" Text="You've made a moral claim (&quot;should not&quot;) where I was expecting a legal one (&quot;it is illegal to&quot;)./>
<comment QuestionId="Is it illegal to share scientific publications not in the public domain" AnswerId="VXHx3b5HvUkIaiQWo1NgrQ==" Author="4461" Date="2013-05-31T11:13:16.677" Text="@RodyOldenhuis Interestingly, there is a good bit of leniency in the U.S. Fair Use law for research: [&quot;...the fair use of a copyrighted work, including such use...for purposes such as criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching (including multiple copies for classroom use), scholarship, or research, is not an infringement of copyright.&quot;](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fair_use#Fair_use_under_United_States_law)/>

</answer>

academia.stackexchange.com_10343	<question QuestionId="Motivating students to push their limits" Title="Motivating students to push their limits" Views="296" Tags="teaching,motivation" " AnswerId="Rm6YeI1uwc1J3skXEjxSag==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-05-31T12:19:33.973" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;I think I must be stranger than usual sometimes, I always seem to take on topics that are somewhat more difficult than the mainstream, in very trying conditions - but the outcomes are very much worth it (not for me per se, but the benefits for everyone, potentially).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I try to instill this in my students, by 'gently' mentoring them and encouraging them to push their own limits a little further each time.  Also, I teach them that 'failure' is just another step to success.  For the most part, my students take on the challenges and the work, ideas and enthusiasm from them, frankly humbles me.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, I am always wishing to learn new techniques to encourage my students to push, and even exceed their limits.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What strategies are most effective for encouraging students (and colleagues for that matter) to take on the difficult topics?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10343" Date="2013-05-31T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10343" Date="2013-05-31T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10343" Date="2013-05-31T00:00:00.000/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10343" Date="2013-10-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10343" Date="2013-05-31T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10343" Date="2013-06-01T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Motivating students to push their limits" AnswerId="IQFASqwCqfB91QigH0mDcg==" Author="7116" Date="2013-05-31T14:25:46.127" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;As a reflection on my own experience as a teacher, I am convinced that motivation is not a static, unchangeable property of particular students, but it is a multifaceted concept, a variable state of mind, created through the interaction of the student with the subject matter in a particular environment (teacher, group, topic, etc). A good teacher arouses the motivation indirectly, by creating the right environment for learning. The students' effort ensues almost magically.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;See this interesting article:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Linnenbrink, Elizabeth A., and Paul R. Pintrich. &quot;Motivation as an enabler for academic success.&quot; School Psychology Review 31.3 (2002): 313-327.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Motivating students to push their limits" AnswerId="IQFASqwCqfB91QigH0mDcg==" Author="705" Date="2013-06-02T06:27:13.103" Text="This answer might be 100% accurate, but it somehow didn't give any useful suggestions for how to achieve that goal.  &quot;A good teacher arouses the motivation indirectly&quot; - OK, how?  What techniques work, and what don't?/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10346" Date="2013-10-26T00:00:00.000/>

</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Motivating students to push their limits" AnswerId="QsGrOhgi6aq213GcYamwjw==" Author="7921" Date="2013-10-25T23:38:18.097" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;The most important aspect is the teacher's attitude. It sounds as though your students are already benefiting from yours.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As @Cinco says above,&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;motivation is not a static, unchangeable property of particular students... A good teacher arouses the motivation indirectly, by creating the right environment for learning.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Based on my experiences with some awesome professors, I will say DO&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;hold your students to high academic standards.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;assume that the students are capable of doing more than they are currently doing.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;show them how the subject you are teaching is relevant to them.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;be enthusiastic.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;recognize their great work, and always expect more and better in the future.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Perhaps most importantly, &lt;em&gt;have fun!&lt;/em&gt; Enjoyment is contagious, and a good professor can make it fun to learn about anything. A &lt;em&gt;great&lt;/em&gt; professor can make it fun to struggle and push against the limits of our abilities.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(Sorry, this is rather subjective...it is hard to quantify what makes a great teacher!)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10347	<question QuestionId="How to engage students in oral presentations" Title="How to engage students in oral presentations" Views="197" Tags="teaching,university,undergraduate,education" " AnswerId="Bghs+ZVWKwFKaGihGwK15g==" Author="406" Date="2013-05-31T14:58:47.463" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Paper-based exams are not fully representative of knowledge, and it is good to consider oral presentations of students as a factor for the final grade to some extent. This is somehow the case in graduate courses, where the number of students is lesser, but how to follow this strategy for crowded classroom of inexperienced undergraduate students. I mean a classroom of 50+ size with students who do not have experience in scientific discussion!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10347" Date="2013-06-23T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10347" Date="2014-01-03T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10347" Date="2013-06-02T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="How to engage students in oral presentations" AnswerId="dA9lZjvTnvTgAKWHtf+q+Q==" Author="1429" Date="2013-05-31T19:43:16.777" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would like to add to earthling's answer. If you have &lt;strong&gt;teaching assistants&lt;/strong&gt;, please do make good use of them in this aspect. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As a TA, I have had excellent experiences in mentoring undergraduates to prepare research presentations, final papers, projects and proposals for these papers and project. Of course, we were generally in a class of 120-160 students so that speaks to a classroom scale higher than what you are suggesting. There were 3 graduate TA's, usually and we each had about 50 students to mentor. We found that we could devote significant amounts of time to each student when we met them on a one-on-one basis. Of course, the professor also met them one-on-one and there were a couple of rounds of iteration of their final presentations - which was very, very useful for the professors, the TA's and the students. As mentioned previously, it was a time sink, but very well worth it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10360" Date="2013-06-01T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10360" Date="2013-06-23T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How to engage students in oral presentations" AnswerId="z4OosbmkHCsi0DyHwabDyA==" Author="2692" Date="2013-05-31T15:35:18.650" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I've had classes of this size where I have each student do an individual presentation. It is &lt;strong&gt;very&lt;/strong&gt; time consuming but I also feel it can be &lt;strong&gt;very&lt;/strong&gt; worthwhile.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you give each student 10 minutes to present some information and you have 50 students then you will have 12-13 hours for presentations (allowing 15 minutes total per student including Q&amp;amp;A, changing students, etc.) If you teach in 2-hour sessions then it will consume 6-7 sessions. If you have 30-32 sessions per semester it is doable but it also removes a significant chunk of time from lecturing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In my case, I lectured for several weeks (giving the students time to do their research and giving them the foundations they needed for their presentations) and then had the students give their presentations. Then I continued lecturing with other assessments later on. The module was not about presentation skills but I do feel that in each subject, we need to teach the students some general skills (structuring an argument, how to format text, how to research, giving a presentation, etc.) in addition to the module content.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The students ended up understanding the material quite well when judged by their presentations and I found many of them quite eager to learn how they could improve their presentation skills. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In the end, I was happy with the overall results and plan to do it again.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10349" Date="2013-06-01T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10349" Date="2013-09-27T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_1035	<question QuestionId="Do letters of recommendation typically include a biography of the writer" Title="Do letters of recommendation typically include a biography of the writer" Views="858" Tags="graduate-admissions,recommendation-letter" " AnswerId="UHqD0eIg4HYuzW3bMvN2zw==" Author="600" Date="2012-04-06T23:35:56.260" Score="10" Text="&lt;p&gt;A student asked me to write a letter of recommendation for graduate school admission in London and the student insisted that I include a short biography describing my job title and qualifications. I find this information is a little out of place. First, my degree is in progress, so I do not have any impressive qualifications. Second, I think such letters are intended to introduce the applicant, not the writer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Is this common practice to include a biography of the writer in letters of recommendation?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Where does this information typically appear in the document? In the opening paragraph? As a separate, attached document?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Do letters of recommendation typically include a biography of the writer" AnswerId="UHqD0eIg4HYuzW3bMvN2zw==" Author="13" Date="2012-04-07T18:25:12.903" Text="On a side note, have you considered telling the student to get a recommendation letter from a more senior faculty member?  Not that I have anything against graduate students, but I suspect a letter from them is not taken as seriously as one from a faculty member (maybe not by everyone, but some is enough).  You can tell this faculty member what to write (or at least your impressions of the student)./>
<comment QuestionId="Do letters of recommendation typically include a biography of the writer" AnswerId="UHqD0eIg4HYuzW3bMvN2zw==" Author="612" Date="2012-04-07T20:26:31.433" Text="Ben's comment is an important point.  One option is to co-sign the letter with a faculty member, where the reader's understanding will be that you are describing the situation and the faculty member is vouching for your judgement.  At the very least, you need to have someone more senior read the letter before you send it, since it's easy for an inexperienced letter writer to write something that is intended to help but turns out to be ineffective./>

<answer QuestionId="Do letters of recommendation typically include a biography of the writer" AnswerId="cDUe3wIF69olGYzcXitd8w==" Author="13" Date="2012-04-07T18:31:17.700" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would regard a separate biography as a bit odd; it's normal to sign with your current title (so I sign &quot;Ben Webster, Assistant Professor of Mathematics&quot;) and of course, write on letterhead, so your current position is clear. In terms on context on how many students you've evaluated, you can slip that into various points in the letter.  I would just stick a sentence into the second paragraph; one can unobtrusively give a short explanation of who you are mixed with the standard explanation of how you know the student.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Do letters of recommendation typically include a biography of the writer" AnswerId="hB/TnYw1uRjZgzQjscCCfw==" Author="65" Date="2012-04-07T05:30:22.413" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;Yes, this is relatively common. (In my opinion, not common enough.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Recommendation letters carry more weight if he reader knows the writer's qualifications.  In particular, letters about qualification for graduate school carry more weight if the reader has some sense of the writer's track record for judging students' research ability.  (This is why letters from senior faculty are more valued — not because of their vast research experience, but because they've presumably seen and evaluated more students.)  The best way for the reader to understand your track record is to &lt;em&gt;tell them&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But briefly, because as you suggest, the letter isn't about you.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't think there's a standard way to do this.  Some people put their bio early in the letter, say in the second paragraph (because the first paragraph is the actual recommendation).  I put mine in a footnote on the last page.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Do letters of recommendation typically include a biography of the writer" AnswerId="hB/TnYw1uRjZgzQjscCCfw==" Author="612" Date="2012-04-07T20:22:14.980" Text="I'd strongly recommend putting it at the end.  At the end, it can come across as useful in a humble way (&quot;I know you may not have heard of me, so here's some background&quot;), while it can seem more offensive near the beginning (&quot;Before I go into detail about the student I am recommending, let me first recount how great I am&quot;)./>
<comment QuestionId="Do letters of recommendation typically include a biography of the writer" AnswerId="hB/TnYw1uRjZgzQjscCCfw==" Author="53" Date="2012-04-07T21:41:56.720" Text="I'd agree with most of this—establishing your qualifications as a letter writer is important, but your primary mission is to recommend the candidate, not tell them all about yourself./>

<answer QuestionId="Do letters of recommendation typically include a biography of the writer" AnswerId="3w9T1hWm5PHOmtm/MST/jg==" Author="384" Date="2012-04-08T20:11:36.617" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;You are right, the point of the letter is &lt;strong&gt;entirely&lt;/strong&gt; the candidate, any sentence(s) about yourself should be entirely to the point of facilitating communication about the candidate. I was told in school that all histories tell you as much about the culture that wrote them as the culture they describe, so you need to take both into account when you read them. I suppose this is true of reference letters as well. It's like introducing yourself before you ask an academic you don't know a question one-on-one over coffee at a conference – sometimes there's no need, but sometimes it's essential to framing the question &amp;amp; making the most of the other person's time &amp;amp; answer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have never been explicitly asked for a biography beyond &quot;how do you know the candidate, for how long, and in what capacity&quot;.  However, the UK is under a lot of legal pressure concerning letters of reference because some are so much better than others, not necessarily due to the candidate, but possibly due to how knowledgeable the writer is about writing letters.  Possibly candidates deserve some credit for picking good letter writers, but this could be hard particularly for very junior candidates.  So  having guidance for writing a letter is useful, it's letting all letter writers know good practice by previous letter writers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Personally I include biographical information (not a full biography) where I think it may be helpful and when I am trying to write a strong letter. Similarly, I also give information about our institution where I think it might not be known and be helpful.   Examples: if I am writing a US institution from the UK, I let them know that I have attended US institutions &amp;amp; know what their programmes are like. Sometimes if I know someone well in the department I may point that out in the letter so that whoever is doing the search has the option of going to ask that person how seriously to take my opinion if they want to.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I put this at the end of the first paragraph or possibly as a stand-alone second paragraph, in advance of offering my verbose opinion of the candidate, so that the reader can have that information in mind when they see what my opinion is. The first sentence of the first paragraph says who the letter is for &amp;amp; for what position.  The second sentence is my one-sentence summary of my recommendation. The third (or the second paragraph) is in what capacity I am writing the letter.  That's where biographical details might be useful. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1063" Date="2012-04-08T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1063" Date="2012-10-04T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1063" Date="2012-04-29T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1063" Date="2012-04-08T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="1063" Date="2012-04-23T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>

academia.stackexchange.com_10352	<question QuestionId="How to find the best journal to submit a paper to (when having written the title abstact and full text)" Title="How to find the best journal to submit a paper to (when having written the title abstact and full text)" Views="362" Tags="publishing,journals" " AnswerId="mh5+sT4GeFo3E2W9Mvo+Sg==" Author="1537" Date="2013-05-31T15:52:40.540" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;Consider a case of a new researcher that does not know well all possible journals and has no access to human advice (from colleagues). (please do not comment that this is the best - out of scope of the question!)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Or one journal rejected the paper and the author is looking for outside the box candidates.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Possible examples:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;1.&#xA;E.g., in medicine, one can use this tool (ETBLAST) by submitting full text of the article &#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;http://etest.vbi.vt.edu/etblast3/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://etest.vbi.vt.edu/etblast3/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Some journals even require top 3 similar papers (found by ETBLAST) to be pasted into a form during submission (making sure authors well addressed related literature). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;2.&#xA;Or Elsevier JournalFinder service.&lt;a href=&quot;http://journalfinder.elsevier.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://journalfinder.elsevier.com/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to find the best journal to submit a paper to (when having written the title abstact and full text)" AnswerId="mh5+sT4GeFo3E2W9Mvo+Sg==" Author="12314" Date="2014-03-07T11:19:22.897" Text="I just tried Elsevier's tool, out of curiosity, and it returned &quot;Journal of Archaelogical Science&quot; and &quot;Archives of Geriatrics and Gerontology&quot; as two of the top five journals to submit an article about theoretical syntax. The moral of the story: check those suggestions with an actual human being that knows the field./>
<comment QuestionId="How to find the best journal to submit a paper to (when having written the title abstact and full text)" AnswerId="mh5+sT4GeFo3E2W9Mvo+Sg==" Author="7173" Date="2014-03-07T09:34:31.047" Text="Not applicable to your current situation, but note that it is often a good idea to decide the journal in advance. This allows you to structure the text as is usual in their articles and additionally stress some points that they seem to value in the text. This is particularly relevant for special issues./>
<comment QuestionId="How to find the best journal to submit a paper to (when having written the title abstact and full text)" AnswerId="mh5+sT4GeFo3E2W9Mvo+Sg==" Author="7219" Date="2013-08-06T20:32:33.713" Text="I don't fully agree with the above comments. I tend to cite lots of high impact journals but it doesn't imply that my work is that ground-breaking to be accepted by those. Better to be realistic and choose some less prestigious journal for a start./>
<comment QuestionId="How to find the best journal to submit a paper to (when having written the title abstact and full text)" AnswerId="mh5+sT4GeFo3E2W9Mvo+Sg==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-02T03:04:16.730" Text="1. Read your own bibliography.  2. Submit to the journal you cited most often.  (Presumably you read lots of papers _before_ you wrote yours.)/>
<comment QuestionId="How to find the best journal to submit a paper to (when having written the title abstact and full text)" AnswerId="mh5+sT4GeFo3E2W9Mvo+Sg==" Author="102" Date="2013-05-31T16:02:15.207" Text="1. Read lots of papers. 2. Submit to journal containing the most articles you preferred./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10352" Date="2013-06-15T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10352" Date="2013-06-02T00:00:00.000/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10352" Date="2013-06-01T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10352" Date="2013-06-02T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How to find the best journal to submit a paper to (when having written the title abstact and full text)" AnswerId="mPKvRxEbPr+qYbiQefAxHQ==" Author="12712" Date="2014-03-07T07:47:38.350" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;Presumably you have included references in your article! Just check which journals you tend to cite most (or at least twice each in your article). Those must be good and relevant enough (since you cite the work published there in the context of your own work). Then check their guidelines to be sure (possible length constraints, level of detail, etc.) &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you do not want to go to the most prestigious journals because you fear your work is not groundbreaking enough, or because you want an easy ride, or, as you said, because they rejected your article already, here is a relevant rule-of-thumb: do not publish in a journal which you would never cite for whatever reason. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="17882" Date="2014-03-07T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="17882" Date="2014-03-07T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How to find the best journal to submit a paper to (when having written the title abstact and full text)" AnswerId="W4TeROZ0TOzKoCQ8s/Zu/g==" Author="705" Date="2013-06-02T06:25:20.610" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;You need to know your field.  Part of knowing your field is reading lots of papers.  This should give you an idea of what kinds of papers each of the major journals publishes, and what journal may be best suited to you.  If you're a good researchers, you ought to already know what are the main journals that publish research in your area.  If you don't already know that, then maybe you need to spend more time reading published work first.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In particular, the best way to figure out if a particular journal is a good fit for your paper is to read a bunch of papers published at that journal.  That will give you a pretty good sense.  You can use the &quot;call for papers&quot; as a further sanity check, but nothing substitutes for reading what else they have published.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is no shortcut.  If you are a knowledgeable about your field, a random webpage is not going to know your field better than you do.  If you are not knowledgeable about your field, then the first thing you need to do is to fix that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

Is there any reason / explicit convention which should stop one from presenting light coloured text on a dark background?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Scientific presentations - black or white" AnswerId="NrDhvXXKuAMvLP13fACvkw==" Author="739" Date="2013-05-31T21:55:29.587" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Most private companies have their specific color schemes and logos that must be shown on every slide. That's just the way it goes in industry. So it's just a matter of hitting the right conference :). I am pretty sure that at communication science conventions, you won't see any single white background presentation (or black background, for that matter).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Ideally, the color scheme should be a nice touch to your presentation, not a decisive point. The content should play the more important role, and the font size is arguably more important than the color it shows in: if nobody can read your font 6, what's the point of the slide? On some ways to make your presentations more effective without using multiple nested hierarchies of bullet points, see &lt;a href=&quot;http://abcnews.go.com/images/us/how_to_win_in_anbar_v4.pdf&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;this multiple award winning one&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Scientific presentations - black or white" AnswerId="NrDhvXXKuAMvLP13fACvkw==" Author="725" Date="2013-06-02T12:05:53.197" Text="My company has two official presentation styles: a bright on dark background and a dark on bright background one./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10364" Date="2013-06-01T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Scientific presentations - black or white" AnswerId="6REBjRmMmJgdgUOG7GmglA==" Author="669" Date="2013-05-31T17:31:33.630" Score="14" Text="&lt;p&gt;Conferences tend to take place indoors in dimly-lit rooms.  Dimly-lit rooms are a good place to fall asleep.  Using a white background helps avoid this.  Also, dark text/lines on a white background are easier to read (I've seen more than one study showing this).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you are going to be showing a lot of astronomy or fluorescence biology images, where the image is mostly black with some interesting colorful things in it, you probably want a black or dark background for at least those slides; at some point you should just switch over.  Also, if it is essential to understanding for the viewer to discriminate many shades of color, it's easier with a black background because you can use a wide variety of discriminable pastel colors that would be washed out to invisibility on a white background. You can't even use saturated yellow or cyan on a white background and expect it to be seen.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But for most scientific presentations there are good reasons for a light colored background.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Scientific presentations - black or white" AnswerId="Z2Ws1awzAEIrXofVXJlf4g==" Author="1429" Date="2013-05-31T18:06:32.497" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;In HCI/information science many conference presentations, especially in the best conferences like CHI or CSCW, tend to have nice colored backgrounds. I would even argue that in certain sub-fields of HCI or information science, just having a vanilla black or white colored background tends to be the exception rather than the norm.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://jeffhuang.com/best_paper_awards.html#chi&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;This&lt;/a&gt; is a brilliant compilation of best paper awards in many sub-disciplines of computer science. A simple google search will often yield the conference presentations and slides of them. Under CHI, you will find that very often, the slides are rather innovative when it comes to the color scheme.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10358" Date="2013-05-31T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Scientific presentations - black or white" AnswerId="MmICAQaTu21SKhOg01jbqQ==" Author="725" Date="2013-06-02T12:04:30.647" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Whether light foreground on dark background or vice versa is easier to see depends on the light conditions of the presentation room.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Projectors are still not very powerful: the white of a projector will usually not stand out even against a comparably dim room illumination.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If it is really dark, bright foreground on dark background allows to show more shades of colour and brightness. Because the projectors are not too powerful, the risk of uncomfortably bright foreground is not very high.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If the room is not really dark, bright foreground on dark background may be very hard to see, as the eyes adapt to the overall light conditions and few projectors are powerful enough to make white text on a black (= grey because of surrounding illumination) stand out enough to be easily readable.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note how the projectors becoming more powerful allowed a transition from white-on-black in really dark rooms (which were needed because the white was not that bright) to black-on-white in rooms with a dimmed overall illumination. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10403" Date="2013-06-02T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10355	<question QuestionId="Do graduate school admissions appreciate individual &quotfree time&quot study" Title="Do graduate school admissions appreciate individual &quotfree time&quot study" Views="449" Tags="graduate-admissions,mathematics,computer-science" " AnswerId="EFU8xQZTbAjO0fMG1pKD9w==" Author="7295" Date="2013-05-31T17:16:47.370" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am a year away from completing an undergrad degree in Computer Science and I find myself increasingly interested in more advanced subjects from pure mathematics that sometimes lie outside the scope of my major, and I think I would enjoy doing graduate work in pure math. But I feel like the amount of formal education I've had the opportunity to have in my undergrad isn't quite sufficient for graduate work in math.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If I were to go and buy a book or two on some subject I'd like to learn more about that I can't take a course on (say, Abstract Algebra or Number Theory), and spend this summer getting comfortable with it, is it likely that a graduate admission committee take my efforts into account?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My situation is worded specific to a CS --&gt; Pure Math trajectory, but it's part of a more general question. Do graduate school admissions take into account personal study, or do they only care about formal university education?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Do graduate school admissions appreciate individual &quotfree time&quot study" AnswerId="ril+Xom3oP+kxJaJiGqCRg==" Author="1429" Date="2013-05-31T19:39:10.810" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have limited knowledge about this and I speak from experience as a graduate student who has gone through a similar situation &lt;em&gt;(from the outside)&lt;/em&gt; as well as being the student representative on our graduate admissions committee &lt;em&gt;(on the inside)&lt;/em&gt;. Obviously, a professor or academic with much more experience than I have can attest to this in better ways.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In &lt;strong&gt;general,&lt;/strong&gt; formal education is given preference. Grades in relevant courses are given more importance than others. Note that there is a lot of competition for slots in a PhD program. Self study is a very fuzzy area and there is little scope for the graduate admissions committee to evaluate it. There exists of course, two mutually non-exclusive ways exceptions to this general norm:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;A respected recommender in the area attests to the fact that you did engage in significant amounts of self study and that has contributed to your overall knowledge.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;You do self study. Then you do research based on it. Then you publish in a non trivial journal or conference. That automatically attests to your knowledge in certain ways.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Otherwise, ask yourself this, why would graduate admissions committees believe you, especially when there is usually bound to be a few more well qualified applicants with good scores in relevant courses?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Do graduate school admissions appreciate individual &quotfree time&quot study" AnswerId="ril+Xom3oP+kxJaJiGqCRg==" Author="53" Date="2013-05-31T21:25:45.540" Text="This says pretty much everything I wanted to say on the topic./>

<answer QuestionId="Do graduate school admissions appreciate individual &quotfree time&quot study" AnswerId="59cJJT3t9ORjo5LluZf2ZA==" Author="980" Date="2014-02-15T18:05:55.320" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;The other answers are of course reasonable, but my own viewpoint, perhaps an outlier, is that energetic/extensive self-study is a much more positive indicator about motivation and self-discipline and genuine interest than course attendance with good grades.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Yes, there is the obvious point mentioned in other answers: how to measure or certify self-study? The GRE subject test is very iffy, in a variety of aspects. Thus, the ideal circumstance is coursework &lt;em&gt;and&lt;/em&gt; self-study, to have certifiable conventional (&quot;passive&quot;) education as well as demonstrating initiative and interest. Further, very often the available undergrad curriculum really doesn't prepare people for grad school, so I'd strongly recommend substantial self-study in any case. Perhaps best under the aegis of math faculty who can provide some certification in letters of recommendation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The thing that &lt;em&gt;might&lt;/em&gt; be missing from self-study, if that's all one has as mathematics background, is the &quot;regular drill&quot; on basic reflexes that, in any case, routine coursework does cultivate. If one has to stop and think too much, the slowdown/cognitive-load can make routine things effectively impossible.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, beware, the usual first year-or-two of math grad school include &quot;routine&quot; coursework and exams that do presume a &quot;standard&quot; undergrad background, including routine drill on a fairly standard body of material. With an extremely thin or idiosyncratic background, one must play a lot of catch-up. This can have several bad effects: may give the impression of incapability, may make you tired and discouraged, may stifle natural interest. So &quot;brace yourself&quot; if that's the path you find yourself on.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="17000" Date="2014-02-15T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="17000" Date="2014-02-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="17000" Date="2014-02-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="17000" Date="2014-02-15T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Do graduate school admissions appreciate individual &quotfree time&quot study" AnswerId="flYiGlwqQfAdl6JRWwn/cw==" Author="6110" Date="2013-06-01T14:11:12.407" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;If possible, I would recommend first seeking out a math professor at your university, preferably someone you know and who holds you in high regard. If you are home for the summer, e-mail would suffice, but an in person meeting would work much better.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Anyway, explain your plans, and:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Ask the professor's advice about your self-study plan (maybe the prof has different suggestions)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Ask if he or she would be willing to evaluate your progress at the end of the summer (e.g., you show up to his/her office and take an informal oral exam), and to write you a rec letter if you've done a good job.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Good luck!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Do graduate school admissions appreciate individual &quotfree time&quot study" AnswerId="flYiGlwqQfAdl6JRWwn/cw==" Author="7308" Date="2013-06-02T00:54:21.133" Text="I strongly agree with this comment. My husband is a math professor, and if you approached him in this manner (&quot;I just love math, would you please go through this number theory book with me?&quot;) he would *leap* at the opportunity to do independent study with you.  People like you are why professors go into academia. :)/>

<answer QuestionId="Do graduate school admissions appreciate individual &quotfree time&quot study" AnswerId="HXzpoq6tLN+YXGOr0nNqGw==" Author="10739" Date="2014-02-15T17:23:23.410" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;Another option for the special case you describe is to take the math subject GRE after your self studies. This would validate your knowledge of the undergraduate curriculum in pure maths. They might take into account that you did not take any of the courses (you probably won't get the same score you would have gotten as a math major, because you don't know real analysis, topology, etc.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10357	<question QuestionId="Find out authors name in foreign writing system (Chinese etc)" Title="Find out authors name in foreign writing system (Chinese etc)" Views="199" Tags="research,bibliography,language,quotation" " AnswerId="mce9dz5WjhYz1of+llTacg==" Author="7297" Date="2013-05-31T17:37:06.467" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have some literature written by Chinese authors who I would like to attribute in my bibliography with their names in Chinese characters (汉字). The problem is that, as the literature itself is not in Chinese, their names appear only in their romanized form (Pīnyīn or Wade–Giles).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What resources can I use to find out the correct characters for their names, e. g. library catalogues with both forms given, author lists, etc.?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am not only looking for Chinese names but Japanese ones as well.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;UPDATE:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Examples include:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Pao, Erh-li / Ying Cheng (1982): &lt;em&gt;Wörterbuch der chinesischen Redensarten. Chinesisch–deutsch; Tetragramme des modernen Chinesisch&lt;/em&gt; [= 漢語成語]. Berlin, New York: de Gruyter.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Huang, Yankai (1964): A dictionary of Chinese idiomatic phrases. Hong Kong: Eton Press.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Hisa, Michitaro (1896): Some Japanized Chinese Proverbs. In: &lt;em&gt;The Journal of American Folklore&lt;/em&gt; 9, 33, pp. 132–138.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10357" Date="2013-06-01T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10357" Date="2013-06-01T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10357" Date="2013-05-31T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10357" Date="2013-05-31T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Find out authors name in foreign writing system (Chinese etc)" AnswerId="zya3LA/Am9HZI0NUsJU7lA==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-01T16:25:58.670" Score="3" Text="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;I am aware of this&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you're already aware of the transliteration problem but still asking the question, then I assume you have other information about the authors to help identify them, e.g., affiliations. If that's the case, I'm curious why you don't use the most useful searchable database, namely &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://www.google.com/&lt;/a&gt; Depending on how much information you have (and possibly how proficient in the target languages), you'll eventually be able to identify them in their native languages unless you're talking about very obscure or older-than-the-internet authors. Since the authors you want to identify wrote something in foreign languages, I think chances are they have personal or official websites that have their names both in Latin alphabet and in their native languages. If they don't, you may find some pages that help you identify them in their native languages.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't get why you think a database on literature is particularly useful for that purpose either. You can use any available resource. For instance, if the authors you want to identify are active Japanese researchers, you can search them in one of the researcher databases found here: &lt;a href=&quot;http://read.jst.go.jp/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://read.jst.go.jp/&lt;/a&gt; (in Japanese) &lt;a href=&quot;http://read.jst.go.jp/index_e.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://read.jst.go.jp/index_e.html&lt;/a&gt; (in English). (The English version is the first hit on google for &quot;japanese researcher database&quot; by the way. You'd run into these sites very frequently if you google Japanese researchers, too.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Anyway, as an example, assume you want to know, say, the Japanese spelling of my former Ph.D. supervisor Masakazu Jimbo at Nagoya University. And you want to avoid navigating the internet in Japanese as much as possible while searching. Then, you go to &lt;a href=&quot;http://researchmap.jp/?lang=english&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;the English version of Read &amp;amp; Researchmap&lt;/a&gt;, click &quot;Researcher Search&quot; to get to &lt;a href=&quot;http://researchmap.jp/search/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;the researcher search page&lt;/a&gt;, and do the usual search with the information you have (i.e., the name is spelled Masakazu Jimbo and he's at Nagoya University). You'll be directed to &lt;a href=&quot;http://researchmap.jp/read0164386&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;his information in English&lt;/a&gt;. Then you switch to &lt;a href=&quot;http://researchmap.jp/read0164386/?lang=japanese&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;the original Japanese page&lt;/a&gt; by clicking 日本語 to check how to spell his name in Japanese.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Of course, you don't need to use the Read &amp;amp; Researchmap to know his name in Japanese. You can simply google him. If you know publication titles and his name in Latin alphabet, you can surely locate his personal website, where you can see how to spell his name in Japanese.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Exactly what kind of situation are you in? You talk about literature, so I assumed you wanted to cite/quote works by Chinese and/or Japanese authors. And you say those works are not in their native languages, which, I assume, means that you know more about the authors than just their transliterated names (unless you're trying to cite/quote them without reading them). Was the additional information you have not enough to identify them through google? Are libraries' databases and such on books etc. really the only kind you can identify them with what you already know about them? Maybe, they're from 19th centuries or something or way too obscure for the internet to be of use? Or is this question &quot;What resources can I use to find out the correct characters for their names?&quot; asked as a very very broad inquiry for Internet Search 101? If that's the case, it's too broad to answer because you don't tell us what you already know about the authors and why you can't identify them through usual means like google.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Find out authors name in foreign writing system (Chinese etc)" AnswerId="zya3LA/Am9HZI0NUsJU7lA==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-01T17:15:38.643" Text="I'm repeating myself, but are you citing/quoting them without reading them? What does the 1982 book say about the authors' affiliations etc., for example? Was it not enough to find the original spellings in some way? The third one seems tough, but a casual googling tells me he's most likely the guy who co-authored &quot;Lyrics of Li-Tʻai-Po,&quot; where you can find his brief bio. How about asking Doshisha University (同志社大学) about him? They may have a record of their past faculty and even keep his publication list or something, so you can be sure this Michitaro Hisa is indeed the one you're looking for./>
<comment QuestionId="Find out authors name in foreign writing system (Chinese etc)" AnswerId="zya3LA/Am9HZI0NUsJU7lA==" Author="7297" Date="2013-06-01T18:03:53.090" Text="Actually, what I expected _was_ tedious legwork (as encountered), yet I had not given up the hope for an easier way—sometimes it is out there and one just does not happen to know about it. But this is exactly what I feared. Thanks for your efforts, nevertheless./>
<comment QuestionId="Find out authors name in foreign writing system (Chinese etc)" AnswerId="zya3LA/Am9HZI0NUsJU7lA==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-01T17:53:39.277" Text="@brian-ammon I don't understand why you would even think it wouldn't require tedious legwork to find the original spelling of the author of a 120 years old paper from Far East... Anyway, if you're saying you're not that serious about it, I don't know how to reliably resolve Asian names back to their originals without much effort./>
<comment QuestionId="Find out authors name in foreign writing system (Chinese etc)" AnswerId="zya3LA/Am9HZI0NUsJU7lA==" Author="7297" Date="2013-06-01T17:31:22.497" Text="The methods you describe are the ones I have already been using and have found them to be—in some cases at least—quite tedious. As the paper I am writing is extremely short and as I am not _required_ to give the correct name forms (I just thought it to be a courtesy to my supervisor), the thought of contacting the (former) universities seems a little overblown to me. What I originally had in mind when I was asking this question was more sources like WorldCat with (sometimes) both forms given: http://www.worldcat.org/title/chinese-proverbs-with-bilingual-text/oclc/34719722/>

<answer QuestionId="Find out authors name in foreign writing system (Chinese etc)" AnswerId="M085jCi/tBEMu8LJUxCOAg==" Author="546" Date="2013-06-01T02:49:32.870" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I don't know much about other languages. I'll answer the question in Chinese case since I am a native Chinese speaker.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The literature you have is not in Chinese. The best way is to contact the authors. They will give you the correct answer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As far as I know, there is no such reliable resources at the moment. There is no unique and consistent way of translation between English name and Chinese name. As you already know, Pīnyīn and  Wade–Giles are two of them. I don't think there is one-to-one correspondence relation. There are other issues, such as traditional Chinese character and simplified character. You won't know the correct answer unless the author tells you.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you have no way to contact them, try their collegues or others who might know. Don't use the Chniese name unless you are sure. Use whatever the name appears in the literature if you are not sure.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Find out authors name in foreign writing system (Chinese etc)" AnswerId="M085jCi/tBEMu8LJUxCOAg==" Author="546" Date="2013-06-01T11:55:29.980" Text="@brian-ammon A complete list would be a huge effort if not impossible. For example, &quot;Wong Ping&quot; can correspond to at least 100 names in Chinese. Not to mention three character names. You can calculate the number of possible combinations./>
<comment QuestionId="Find out authors name in foreign writing system (Chinese etc)" AnswerId="M085jCi/tBEMu8LJUxCOAg==" Author="7297" Date="2013-06-01T11:47:44.750" Text="I am aware of this, and this is precisely why I am asking for a catalogue of some kind where publications by foreign authors are listed in romanized as well as native forms. WorldCat sometimes lists the original name in some cases (cf. [http://www.worldcat.org/title/chinese-proverbs-with-bilingual-text/oclc/34719722]) but the list is far from being complete, so I hoped someone would have found something similar./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10366" Date="2013-06-01T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10366" Date="2013-06-01T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Find out authors name in foreign writing system (Chinese etc)" AnswerId="Z0BxolqPi5TEFNK52sUdAQ==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-01T04:04:20.930" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Transliteration between major East Asian languages and Latin alphabet orthography is not a bijection, which means that the exact same spelling of an Asian name in Latin alphabet can correspond to many different spellings in their native language and vice versa. It's somewhat similar to how you can't tell if it's &quot;principal&quot; or &quot;principle&quot; by just hearing the sound /prɪnsəpəl/. In this example, pronunciations and spellings are not a bijection.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This problem is particularly severe for certain names such as typical Chinese names, so some journals allow Asian authors to write their names in their native languages to mitigate the difficulty in identifying a researcher. For instance, see this editorial by American Physical Society: &lt;a href=&quot;http://pra.aps.org/PhysRevLett.99.230001&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Which Wei Wang?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I was born, raised, and educated all the way up to my Ph.D. in Japan. But I can't tell how my namesakes in Latin alphabet would spell their names in Japanese because they may not be namesakes in our native language. The exact spelling in Latin alphabet may not always mean the same pronunciation in Japanese either.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, there is no easy resource to resolve names in Latin alphabet back to their original spellings. Sometimes you might be able to make a fairly reliable educated guess if you're as proficient in the Asian languages as native speakers. But you'd run into the Asian version of Steven vs. Stephan and Erica vs. Erika. So, I'd recommend you ask the person(s) directly unless you have definite evidence such as a copy of a recent paper written by them in their native language.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Find out authors name in foreign writing system (Chinese etc)" AnswerId="Z0BxolqPi5TEFNK52sUdAQ==" Author="546" Date="2013-06-01T04:10:08.400" Text="Now I learn that Japanese is about the same./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10368" Date="2013-06-01T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>

<comment QuestionId="Is there a &quotscientific&quot online source for famous direct qoutes" AnswerId="j6VcnrGvyEALm4mRxYaRUQ==" Author="705" Date="2013-06-02T06:22:14.960" Text="Be careful; it's easy for these to come off as &quot;cutesy&quot; or overly contrived.  If you have to search in a quotes database, odds are that including the quote is more likely to look tacky than insightful.  I'm not saying a judicious use of a great quote can never be appropriate; just that it's easier to fall short than to impress readers./>

Would I be required to retake some graduate courses in the PhD program? This would add only one year to my degree from my current uni as opposed to the two from doing a BS and MS separately. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A bit of background information: I am a dual enrollment US student who has completed two years worth of college courses, and so I'll be entering as a freshman with junior standing taking upper division undergrad math courses. Thus, a standalone BS would take me only two years, leaving me to graduate at age 20. Is this too young to start applying to grad school?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, I plan to do an undergrad thesis; is one year of familiarizing myself with the faculty too little to choose an adviser? I'm not even sure which math I would want to write about. Will three semesters of intro analysis and intro algebra grad courses be enough to decide on the thesis for my fourth semester?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

BTW, I've been studying more advanced topics on my own since summer break started because I already know that calculus 1-3 is nothing compared to higher level mathematics./>

Ask around -- come to the office hours of the profs offering these courses; profs LOVE curious minds (I used to :) )... especially given how few American students are really interested in math./>
<comment QuestionId="Is a combined BSMS in math a good idea for pursuit of PhD" AnswerId="tzhdOutXfhu8RkK8TnR5AA==" Author="739" Date="2013-05-31T21:46:54.800" Text="Mathematics is HUGE. You cannot call yourself a mathematician if you have not mastered (i) complex analysis and (ii) abstract algebra. Before then, there is no point in trying to decide what to do next, as most other topics will have bits and pieces of these two. If all you have had is calculus (without proofs, in the worst US route mem tradition), then you have a long road ahead of you. (Disclaimer: I had my abstract algebra and complex analysis in high school in Russia, which was enough to impress my measure theory teacher in my Ph.D. program by reproducing a proof from my 10th grade class.)/>

<answer QuestionId="Is a combined BSMS in math a good idea for pursuit of PhD" AnswerId="ZNa+nL95ePYNzKSXE2ELDA==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-01T05:25:33.857" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I finished my undergraduate degree at 20, and I know a number of others who have finished undergraduate considerably younger than I did. So, no, 20/21 is &lt;strong&gt;definitely&lt;/strong&gt; not too young to apply for and begin a graduate degree program.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Since you list yourself as a US college student, here are a few questions to ask yourself before embarking on a dual-degree program:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Who is going to pay for the MS part of the program? You may not want to have to pay out of pocket the extra costs of the master's, when it would normally be covered if you picked it up &quot;on the way&quot; in the PhD program.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Are you happy with your choices for a research advisor for your master's thesis? (No point in being miserable by working for the wrong advisor—even if it is a semester or two, a miserable time is not what you want.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Where do graduates of your school's master's program end up for PhD programs? Are these schools you'd want to go to? (You can ask the same question of the bachelor's program, of course.)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Who will write your letters of recommendation? Do you have people who know your work beyond the classroom well enough to recommend you for external graduate programs? If not, this may vote in favor of staying for the master's program. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Do you have to make a decision about which program to do before you apply for external programs? No point in making a tough choice if you can keep it as a &quot;fallback&quot; option.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As for topics and coursework, I will leave those answers to the mathematicians.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10369	<question QuestionId="Do you have to have a PhD to be a PI on a grant for your own funding" Title="Do you have to have a PhD to be a PI on a grant for your own funding" Views="273" Tags="funding" " AnswerId="Au2rMyrbrymI2tAkHaI0Jg==" Author="6026" Date="2013-06-01T05:17:50.240" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;Do you have to have a PhD in order to become a PI on a grant for your own funding?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What if you only have a Bachelor's or a Master's degree, and are not even working towards a PhD?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Do you have to have a PhD to be a PI on a grant for your own funding" AnswerId="Au2rMyrbrymI2tAkHaI0Jg==" Author="1010" Date="2013-06-01T05:24:05.160" Text="Since there are many funding agencies, I doubt this question has a single answer.  My guess is that most agencies have no explicit rule that a PI must have a PhD, but that someone without one would have a *much* harder time making the case that they are qualified to supervise the research./>

<answer QuestionId="Do you have to have a PhD to be a PI on a grant for your own funding" AnswerId="7gl58g6AffsumhlpuyyHig==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-01T14:25:05.717" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;As Nate Eldredge points out, who qualifies as an eligible PI varies widely between different programs. However, in general, one important distinction can usually be cited: you must be a &lt;em&gt;professional&lt;/em&gt; researcher (as opposed to a student or trainee) to be eligible to submit a direct grant. Students would normally need to have their advisors submit the grant proposals on their behalf. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You need to consult the specific rules of the grant you're interested in applying for. Moreover, if you are at an institution that often applies for grants, you should check with the local grants administration office for more guidance. They may have internal policies regarding for whom they will submit grants.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is also important to note that different countries and different agencies have varying standards. Here in Germany, for instance, you &lt;em&gt;must&lt;/em&gt; have the equivalent of a doctoral degree to be eligible to be the coordinating Principal Investigator of a proposal. You can participate as a team member without a doctoral degree, but not be a principal investigator.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10376" Date="2013-06-02T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10376" Date="2013-06-02T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Do you have to have a PhD to be a PI on a grant for your own funding" AnswerId="ZYdeyzKyBOHDN0APocn04Q==" Author="118" Date="2013-06-02T05:55:44.733" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;It very much depends on the grant in question. For example, while most grants in the United States need a PhD (and often university rules dictate more than a PhD, like not giving grant-writing privileges to adjuncts), there are often smaller grant programs that expressly allow non-PhD PIs.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example, my university has a translational research program that has pilot project grants, to help researchers generate the preliminary data that is so important for major grant submissions. Whole the $5,000 and $50,000 tiers are restricted to non-adjunct faculty, there is also a $2,000 tier that merely requires a faculty mentor on the project, and is specifically targeted toward graduate student PIs.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

Consider a quote from Duke's Office of Research Administration: &quot;Adjunct faculty cannot apply for grants through Duke without central (Dean's office) permission since Duke is committing resources and adjunct faculty have no real ownership over those resources. If you wish to apply for a grant, speak to your department chair before you begin working on it.&quot;/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10379	<question QuestionId="Graduate Student Co-authorship Etiquette (Dissemination of Student Papers Not For Publication)" Title="Graduate Student Co-authorship Etiquette (Dissemination of Student Papers Not For Publication)" Views="326" Tags="graduate-school,etiquette,authorship" " AnswerId="10YNO9cfbQzT7T/s8gu1YQ==" Author="7307" Date="2013-06-01T20:32:08.493" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I recently finished my masters degree and co-authored a lengthy paper (It was my idea and I took the lead on the research and writing). The paper is not for publication but provides valuable information and research for the the department faculty and dean.The paper is a program development proposal that our academic department would like to implement. Our group discussed sending the paper to the Dean in conversation with her, and one of the co-authors brought it up with her again at the end of the semester and offered to send it to her individually without consulting our group.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm okay with her sending it, however, I felt that she acted independently and did not consider the time-lines of the other co-authors for doing final edits, or offer to CC us when she sent it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My name comes last on the paper (alphabetically) even though I wrote and researched more than the other two authors combined. I have the sense that my co-author is taking more credit than she is due on this project since her name comes first and because she acted independently.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I requested that I be provided an opportunity to review the paper and to be CC'd on any future sharing of our work with others.I think my co-author was offended. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am interested in asking my two co-authors if it is okay to have my name as the first author on this paper (then she can send it).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please advise if I am being petty or if this is a reasonable concern on my part. I would like for the Dean and faculty to remember my contributions. The co-author who offered to send it has already made her mark on the program in other ways and I am not sure I have stood out as much. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Graduate Student Co-authorship Etiquette (Dissemination of Student Papers Not For Publication)" AnswerId="10YNO9cfbQzT7T/s8gu1YQ==" Author="705" Date="2013-06-04T15:35:15.577" Text="@karina, seems like a reasonable plan to me.  One suggestion: if the Dean agrees to write you a letter of recommendation, I suggest that you be proactive about telling the Dean about all of your accomplishments and contributions, including what you contributed to the paper.  Don't wait for the Dean to ask; give her all the information up front.  (I usually suggest you give recommenders a &quot;brag sheet&quot; or a short summary of some of your accomplishments you are proudest of.  This helps them write a stronger letter for you.  It is one time when you should not be humble.)/>
<comment QuestionId="Graduate Student Co-authorship Etiquette (Dissemination of Student Papers Not For Publication)" AnswerId="10YNO9cfbQzT7T/s8gu1YQ==" Author="7307" Date="2013-06-03T19:17:32.843" Text="Dear scaaahu, I'm not sure who you mean (the Dean?). The Dean wanted the paper. I have decided how to handle the situation. I am not going to worry about having my name first. The pros do not make up for the potential cons of seeming petty or offending my co-authors. I think I will be asking for a recommendation from the Dean, and if she wants to know what I contributed to the paper I will tell her then./>
<comment QuestionId="Graduate Student Co-authorship Etiquette (Dissemination of Student Papers Not For Publication)" AnswerId="10YNO9cfbQzT7T/s8gu1YQ==" Author="546" Date="2013-06-02T04:45:17.340" Text="_Our group discussed sending the paper to the Dean in conversation with her,_ What was her response then?/>
<comment QuestionId="Graduate Student Co-authorship Etiquette (Dissemination of Student Papers Not For Publication)" AnswerId="10YNO9cfbQzT7T/s8gu1YQ==" Author="546" Date="2013-06-04T02:18:54.110" Text="Yes, I mean the dean. You did not explain why you and other coauthors did not act soon - send the paper to the dean. Had you sent the dean the paper right after the dean wanted, none of this would have happened. Why waited until the end of the semester?/>
