<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10379" Date="2013-09-14T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Graduate Student Co-authorship Etiquette (Dissemination of Student Papers Not For Publication)" AnswerId="UmgF/xzg5T02JL0UqsKx7w==" Author="705" Date="2013-06-02T06:15:55.370" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;I understand why you are a little peeved that she offered to send it to the Dean without checking with you first, but I think you need to swallow your frustration on that point.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Instead, you need to figure out what your goals are.  Right now you are reacting: you are letting your emotions control your reactions.  Instead, you should figure out what end goal you want to achieve.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Do you want to make sure that the paper is in good enough shape, before it is sent to the Dean?  Then negotiate a timeline with your co-authors.  This might mean you both have to give a little: you might have to work extra hard to get your revisions in; and they might have to be willing to delay sending the paper a little bit until you've all had a chance to revise to your satisfaction.  That's a perfectly reasonable request.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Do you want to be listed as first author?  If so, why?  You said the paper is not going to be published.  So why do you care?  If you think your contribution means it is appropriate for you to be first author, and you care about it, then raise the point with your co-author.  But approach it with humility and gentleness.  Remember that we're human; we have a tendency to overestimate our own contribution and underestimate others, so you need to correct for that.  Also, definitely do &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; ask to be first author as a way of getting revenge; that is petty and beneath you.  Take the high road.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;And, take this as a lesson.  Generally, it is best to discuss authorship early in the project, not wait until the very end.  In my collaborations, there is often an understanding from the start about who is the lead on the project; the expectation is that the lead has the overall responsibility and will most likely put in the most work, and in return will likely end up as first author.  These discussions about authorship are often easier to happen earlier than later.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Anyway, bottom line: Figure out what you want to achieve (what you want the end state to look like).  Then, figure out how to ask for that.  Set aside your emotions and your negative reactions to your co-author's initiative in moving things forward without checking with you first, and focus on what end state you want to achieve.  I suspect you might find that you share pretty much the same goals as your co-author, and there's no need to get upset or strain your relations with her.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Graduate Student Co-authorship Etiquette (Dissemination of Student Papers Not For Publication)" AnswerId="UmgF/xzg5T02JL0UqsKx7w==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-02T06:24:10.733" Text="I think this might be one of those cases where it wasn't clear up front who the lead would be. However, if the coauthors aren't in the same group, it __would__ be good for the coauthors to copy each other regarding future dissemination of the proposal./>
<comment QuestionId="Graduate Student Co-authorship Etiquette (Dissemination of Student Papers Not For Publication)" AnswerId="UmgF/xzg5T02JL0UqsKx7w==" Author="7307" Date="2013-06-05T17:41:16.187" Text="Thank you for your responses. The paper has been turned in but I have not heard anything back./>
<comment QuestionId="Graduate Student Co-authorship Etiquette (Dissemination of Student Papers Not For Publication)" AnswerId="UmgF/xzg5T02JL0UqsKx7w==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-02T09:43:59.610" Text="That's also possible. How you say something is just as important as what you say./>
<comment QuestionId="Graduate Student Co-authorship Etiquette (Dissemination of Student Papers Not For Publication)" AnswerId="UmgF/xzg5T02JL0UqsKx7w==" Author="7307" Date="2013-06-03T19:21:36.280" Text="@D.W. that is entirely possible. I was unemotional but in retrospect I could have softened the request had I made the effort to do so. Thanks for your feedback!/>
<comment QuestionId="Graduate Student Co-authorship Etiquette (Dissemination of Student Papers Not For Publication)" AnswerId="UmgF/xzg5T02JL0UqsKx7w==" Author="705" Date="2013-06-02T06:30:39.553" Text="@aeismail, that's perfectly reasonable -- but reading between the lines, it is possible that her co-author was offended not by the perfectly reasonable request to be Cc:ed, but by other elements of the communication (e.g., tone, allowing frustration to show through, etc.)./>

<answer QuestionId="Graduate Student Co-authorship Etiquette (Dissemination of Student Papers Not For Publication)" AnswerId="RbX6IKmdUeO45e6vWixv/A==" Author="4394" Date="2013-09-14T20:39:24.673" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;D.W.'s answer is great advice. I just want to add something for the (your) future.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What counts in the end if you intend to continue in academia are hard publications. Since this seems to be a soft &quot;publication&quot;, I think you should ask yourself; can the material be re-written and actually published? If the answer is yes, then you have to ask yourself, should you take on the job as first author (you have already done a lot). Most often the one who takes the initiative will be spearheading the work.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="12689" Date="2013-09-14T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10381	<question QuestionId="Is it possible to recover after a career setback such as this" Title="Is it possible to recover after a career setback such as this" Views="5338" Tags="research,career-path,mathematics,personal-advice" " AnswerId="TMFcZ7CK00SzkfUxcVst0w==" Author="7308" Date="2013-06-01T22:30:39.127" Score="101" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'm sorry, I'm not a mathematician--I'm the wife of a very frustrated and depressed mathematician. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My husband got a math PhD in 2009, and could not get a research post-doc in his chosen field.  We had young children at that point, and he spent two years as a lecturer, applied for hundreds of jobs, and finally took a tenure-track job at a teaching university. Now, he honestly believes that a research position is impossible for him.  He loves to teach, but hates the endless grind of &quot;administrivia&quot;, the low pay, and the mental laziness of the students he's required to teach. (I wish I could give more details, but his research area was a fairly small community, and I don't want to give any aspect of his identity away.) &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I hate watching this brilliant man say things like, &quot;Well, since I didn't get a post-doc, I'm stuck on this path, and there's nothing I can do to get out of it.&quot;  I hate watching him spiral into depression.  I am insisting on him getting counseling, but he refuses to take anyone's encouragement that other jobs are possible, saying things like, &quot;You just don't know the academic world.  If I go to the NSA, no one will hire me in an academic position.  If I become an actuary (because we do need more money) then all of my time will be sucked into studying for exams, and I still won't be able to do research.&quot; In his mind, no one in our circle of loved ones has the authority or experience to give him accurate encouragement.  So I'm looking to anonymous strangers at this point. :(  Is a research position possible after spending time at a teaching university?  Would he be able to get back into academia if he had to leave to do actuarial work/industry/something that helps pay the bills? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I wanted to give a brief update. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To begin with, THANK YOU to everyone who replied.  My husband's eyes lit up after seeing that 1) This was a fairly common problem, and not somehow indicative of his skill level;  2) There were solutions, other than being miserable; and 3) The solutions did not a) condemn him to a life of administrivia, or b) require him to leave academia all together.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;After getting the &lt;em&gt;hope&lt;/em&gt; he needed from you guys, he spoke with a mentor of his from undergrad, and was given incredibly specific guidance on where to go from here.  His teaching load is so heavy, (4/4 or 4/3) and the mentor gave him a few places to apply to in his field where the teaching load is more conducive to &lt;em&gt;some&lt;/em&gt; research, but is not at a research-specific university.   (3/3 or even 3/2!!!) He plans on speaking to his advisor, getting some &lt;em&gt;glowing&lt;/em&gt; letters of recommendation, and starting a job search soon.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thanks so much.  It was nice to see his face light up again. &amp;lt;3 &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Is it possible to recover after a career setback such as this" AnswerId="eMnNalNnufZA6axjXTAlJA==" Author="705" Date="2013-06-02T06:09:14.580" Score="14" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'm going to disagree a little bit with the other answers.  This is a frustrating situation.  Unfortunately, as Anonymous stated, the number of qualified mathematicians exceeds the number of academic research positions.  This makes a difficult position.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I fear your husband might have accurately assessed the situation.  While I appreciate the suggestion others made of continuing to do research on his own time, this is very difficult.  If you have a full-time non-research position and a family, that doesn't leave a lot of time for research -- so it's very hard to sustain a level of research output that will be competitive with the competition.  Also, others who do have a research faculty position may have students and collaborators, which further boosts their research output; your husband won't have that advantage.  So, while in principle your husband could continue research on his own time to try to build a research portfolio in hopes that this leads to a tenure-track academic research position, in practice your husband is at a disadvantage.  He would be climbing up a steep hill.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My suggestion would be for him to get advice from someone more senior who he respects.  Is it worth his time for him to continue his research on his own time, and continue applying to hundreds of research positions each year for the next few years?  Maybe, or maybe it's a waste of time.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Alternatively, perhaps he might consider other career alternatives.  Rather than being entirely set on an academic research position, maybe he should consider other career paths.  Even if he has his mind set on an academic research position right now, I suspect there are a number of other directions where he could be happy.  Maybe he should consider the actuarial path, or consider a NSA job?  Or consider Wall Street (a job in the financial sector)?  Maybe he could teach himself computer programming on his own time and pursue a job in the computing industry?  Perhaps there are other opportunities.  This kind of change is scary and requires some courage, which is undoubtedly especially difficult when you are depressed: your support will undoubtedly be helpful to him.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A third option is to find things to love in his current teaching position.  I certainly sympathize with the trials; they are real, and a drag, to be sure.  On the other hand, there's a lot to love about teaching, too.  You get to help young students discover the beauty of mathematics: even if it's just one out of a class of 30 students who finds a real passion, that can be very satisfying and rewarding.  Unfortunately, the administrivia and the laziness of students is a constant in academia and would probably be present even if he found a research position; the trick with dealing with them is to find other things in his life that are rewarding and satisfying, and focus on them.  For instance, perhaps he might enjoy doing math research in his own time, not with the goal or any illusions that it will lead to any research position, but entirely for its own sake: for the love and pleasure and beauty of it.  Or maybe he might offer to set up a special enrichment seminar or program for students who do love math to learn more: maybe run a program to prepare for the Putnam exam or Math Olympiad.  If he offers to do this on his own time, as an overload, I imagine his department chair would jump at the opportunity, and it might provide a chance to do something rewarding and fulfilling for him and be a great inspiration to a few students.  Or maybe he might find something else in his job that is rewarding and worth doing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is it possible to recover after a career setback such as this" AnswerId="eMnNalNnufZA6axjXTAlJA==" Author="7308" Date="2013-06-02T18:26:08.963" Text="He actually applied to the NSA and made it through a good deal of the rigor, before being offered a tenure-track job with a teaching university.  The NSA and actuarial work are both options still on the table.  When the post-doc didn't go through, his advisor offered to connect him to someone in the financial sector.  The truth is that he does have lots of options.  I think the worst thing he's had to deal with is a lack of credible information on whether the research option was dead or not.  Thank you./>
<comment QuestionId="Is it possible to recover after a career setback such as this" AnswerId="eMnNalNnufZA6axjXTAlJA==" Author="2692" Date="2013-06-02T07:41:01.217" Text="Very true on this point: _administrivia and the laziness of students is a constant in academia_ - teachers often think it is only the students at _this_ school who are lazy...yet many students are like this./>

<answer QuestionId="Is it possible to recover after a career setback such as this" AnswerId="NvNeaU0x734ya8dh1cuiZw==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-01T23:44:26.613" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am in a very similar situation as your husband, as a high school teacher very much wishing to be in research.  So, I can empathise with your husband's and your dilemma (as it definitely affects family and friends as well).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Everyone's situation is different, but I can tell you how I cope in general.  Knowing that postdocs are few and far between, I cope by continuing my own research as much as I can in the spare time I have - getting papers published and continuing to build my research profile.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Research positions are indeed possible after teaching, but as an insurance I would advise still publishing work and developing his research profile.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I hope this helps (and I hope good luck finds you and your husband).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is it possible to recover after a career setback such as this" AnswerId="NvNeaU0x734ya8dh1cuiZw==" Author="7308" Date="2013-06-02T00:24:16.310" Text="Thank you so much, and I hope your research pays off as well. :)  It absolutely does help./>

<answer QuestionId="Is it possible to recover after a career setback such as this" AnswerId="Eeb62N/tc+gPgr+MotGuqQ==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-02T06:22:08.413" Score="45" Text="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Is a research position possible after spending time at a teaching university? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Yes, it's possible.  There's a mild stigma to applying from a teaching university, since it advertises lack of success getting a research job in the past.  Because of the high ratio of candidates to positions, academic hiring is often risk averse and the perception that nobody else wants a candidate will worry search committees.  However, this can be overcome.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One thing to keep in mind is that the past difficulties could simply have been bad luck.  Even very strong candidates typically do not get many job offers, and bad luck can easily change &quot;a few&quot; into &quot;zero&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It's possible to strengthen one's application by writing additional papers, but this generally requires &lt;em&gt;better&lt;/em&gt; papers or more papers &lt;em&gt;per year&lt;/em&gt;, since search committees will normalize for time: if you've spent longer they will expect more.  However, the focus is more on the future than the past.  If you have a productive few years and show signs of maintaining that productivity in the future, it can make up for fallow periods in the past.  If you quit publishing, then the chances of a research job will rapidly drop to zero until you resume publishing.  (There are a lot of people who would like to do research but aren't prepared to actually do it, since they aren't up on the current research literature.  You can't get a research job unless you demonstrate that you aren't one of these people.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In an ideal world, search committees would also normalize for the applicants' circumstances.  For example, research productivity at a teaching university would be viewed as evidence that the candidate would be even more productive at a research university.  Unfortunately, in practice these effects are often underestimated or not taken into account at all.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One possibility is that there's something wrong with your husband's application.  For example, maybe his research statement is not compelling, or one of his letter writers is insufficiently supportive, or maybe one of them does not know how to write an effective letter of recommendation.  (You'd think that should never happen, but some well-established mathematicians simply do not know how to write effective recommendation letters.  If his thesis advisor is one of them, and the other letter writers are less energetic since they assume the advisor will make a strong case, then it could be really bad for his job search.)  I'd guess that 5-10% of job applicants have something seriously wrong with their application that they seem totally unaware of.  This is a low fraction, so your husband probably isn't one of them, but if possible he should discuss all aspects of his application with a trusted mentor who has guided numerous students to the sort of job your husband would like.  Sadly, he may not have such a mentor, but it's good to keep an eye out for one.  For example, if he strikes up a conversation at a conference with a senior mathematician who seems approachable, it's worth asking for job search advice.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;He thought a hiring committee would scoff at the lower output of papers done by someone in a teaching job vs. someone churning out problems in a research post-doc. He even wondered if not having &quot;XYZ Awesome Post-Doc&quot; on his CV would trump any research he did.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Lower productivity because of other duties is a serious factor here.  The CV prestige issue is real but considerably less important: prestige might serve as a tie breaker but won't get anyone a job if their actual accomplishments aren't commensurate.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Letters of recommendation will be by far the most important factor.  What your husband needs is really strong letters that address his circumstances, talk about how impressive his research is and why, and explicitly make the case that he belongs at a research university.  Letter writers generally recycle letters from year to year with some updates to incorporate recent papers.  If his letters are not updated to address the teaching/research university issue, then they will not help him.  In particular, if they don't say in strong terms that he ought to be at a research university, then they'll be viewed as damning him with faint praise.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is something he can discuss with each letter writer, along these lines: &quot;As you know, I've been working at University X for the last couple of years.  It's great to be in a tenure-track job, but I'd really like to work at a research university.  To move to one, I'll need letters of recommendation that address this issue and make a strong case that I should be at a research university.  Would you be comfortable writing such a letter for me?  Of course I'll understand if you can't write one, since I know I'm asking a lot, but I'd rather ask someone else than waste everyone's time with an application that doesn't have the support it needs.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is an awkward conversation, but it's much better to ask than to leave it to chance.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Would he be able to get back into academia if he had to leave to do actuarial work/industry/something that helps pay the bills?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It's possible he could get another teaching-oriented job, although it's by no means a sure thing.  It would help a lot if he could spin the other work as informing his teaching.  For example, he could teach actuarial mathematics or incorporate realistic industrial applications.  In that case the non-academic experience could be an advantage; otherwise applying from outside academia would put him at a moderate disadvantage.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Unfortunately, the chances of getting a research-oriented academic job from industry are low (assuming the industrial job is not at a prestigious research lab like Bell Labs).  There are people who have done it, but it's not likely or easy.  Few people can maintain a high-quality research program on the side with no support while holding a full-time job, and this is necessary for returning to a research university.  In particular, there's virtually no chance of returning based solely on having done research in the past, without having actively continued in the meantime.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The way it typically plays out is that you reluctantly go to industry intending to maintain your research and keep applying for academic jobs.  For the first year or two, you complete and write up work you began in academia, and it feels like everything is going well, but your job applications don't do any better than they had before: you've got a more substantial research track record, but your industrial position emphasizes your inability to get a job in the past.  Still, you figure that accumulating more papers will eventually tip the balance in your favor.  Unfortunately, the next few years don't go as well.  It's hard to find the time for research, you have few people to talk to or derive inspiration from, and progress is slow.  However, you're gradually getting somewhere, so you figure it will just take a little longer.  A few years after that, you start to lose your resolve to do research at all.  Even if your applications were successful, would you really want to take a 50% pay cut, give up your job security, and move to another city to restart your career?  And it's hard to keep your focus on an incredibly time-consuming hobby that seems like it may never lead anywhere professionally.  You quit applying to anything but dream jobs you're pretty sure you won't get, and eventually you give up on them as well.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The good news is that this path doesn't generally end in depression, but rather the discovery that there are plenty of fulfilling life paths outside of research universities.  It's by no means a bad outcome.  However, leaving academia for industry can be really stressful if you want to return to a research university, since you have to either give up or work like hell to maintain your research program.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

Everything you write really rings true to me.  The answer is grounded in the hard realities -- but also encouraging.  Anyway, I just wanted to post a note of appreciation for these words of wisdom./>

<answer QuestionId="Is it possible to recover after a career setback such as this" AnswerId="4HQwfF7967KlMGyuzx655A==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-02T01:25:19.650" Score="16" Text="&lt;p&gt;Yes. It is possible. Because I know this guy who had been in exactly the same situation except that he got his math Ph.D. a few years earlier than your husband, and got a job at a reputable research university. If he's somehow believing that a prestigious postdoc position is necessary, I know a person who ended up in a gratuitous position for a short while and then landed on a very prestigious postdoc job in math. In both cases, they had strong publication records and also convinced other researchers in the same fields that they are something.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Of course, there must be way more math Ph.D.'s who wanted jobs at research universities but got stuck somewhere else than those who succeeded. So, it's true that, statistically speaking, chances are very slim, especially if he himself doesn't think he can make it. But there are things he's in control of, and he can make the probability fatter. Do good research, publish it, and show others what you're made of.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Ah, I almost forgot. If he's looking for a job this year in combinatorics, information theory, coding theory or quantum information science, well, sorry, but he should wait another year. There is a talking duckling in California looking for that sort of job this year, and that duckling should get it. I know your kids are super cute, and they want their dad to be happy, too. But this duckling is even cuter. If your husband's field is different, then no problem. Kick his butt and tell him to apply to as many jobs as possible with his awesome publication list he's going to develop and strong recommendation letters he's going to get (unless his depression needs a professional help. In that case, that should be fixed first, I think). Good luck!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Is it possible to recover after a career setback such as this" AnswerId="tbFMM7OC0+S6K8dlXRL6qg==" Author="6110" Date="2013-06-02T00:02:01.733" Score="55" Text="&lt;p&gt;The situation you describe is unfortunately common. It is an unfortunate reality that the number of people well qualified for research jobs is greater than the number of jobs.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A few notes:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Hiring committees will be looking for good publications, and for recommendation letters coming from leaders in the field attesting to your husband's impact and further potential. If he continues to do good research, publish it in well-known venues, and speak about it at conferences, then he has a good chance. If not, then unfortunately he is competing with people who are.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Most of the complaints you mention are common at research jobs as well. I teach at a large state university, where we have our share of poorly prepared students, and/or students who are just going through the motions. Indeed a Harvard professor once quipped to me that &quot;we have remedial classes here, too&quot;. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;I do know people who have successfully moved from one teaching position to a different teaching position, and been much happier afterwards. Some departments have more motivated students, pay better, and/or do a better job of keeping the paperwork down, and your husband could look for one of these.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;I know people who have taken a variety of non-academic mathematical jobs, and for the most part they are quite happy with them!&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The bottom line is that your husband can probably get a research job &lt;em&gt;if&lt;/em&gt; he can sustain a very strong research program during the interim. Otherwise, there are likely to be appealing alternatives as well.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Good luck!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Is it possible to recover after a career setback such as this" AnswerId="YzBSPbpWzlu259aNEtaojA==" Author="7312" Date="2013-06-02T06:04:27.303" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I've not read other opinions however here is mine, &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Since your husband wants to do research in Math, he is lucky, because he does not require high end instruments to do his stuff. So he basically can do research wherever and whenever he wants, meaning, he need not be in a specific place to do his research. In the mean time he can get employed in a place where he can earn money using his skills. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So while his research is done at home, he can work elsewhere till he feels that his research has matured enough to require a lot of attention. Once his work is publicized I'm sure there will be a lot of people to come forward and assist. Some of us developers use and believe in open technology as the future, hence we publish whatever we do for the benefit of the world. He can create a blog to update the world about his research.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;He can use social media to find and meet people with similar interests or even conduct teaching sessions to people whom &lt;em&gt;he&lt;/em&gt; wants to teach for a fee or for free. Example Google hangouts. Using the internet will give him better exposure than the closed walls of any university. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I help my father with his automobile business and then follow my passion at home, I don't know if any of my work is worthy of being called research but bits  of it I publicize is certainly helping people who wants to learn :) . &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is it possible to recover after a career setback such as this" AnswerId="YzBSPbpWzlu259aNEtaojA==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-02T21:28:02.210" Text="_Once his work is publicized I'm sure there will be a lot of people to come forward and assist._ — I think this is overly optimistic.  Of course, if the work is a truly groundbreaking, then lots of people will come forward to collaborate (not &quot;assist&quot;).  But **very** little research is truly groundbreaking, and people are busy./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10391" Date="2013-06-03T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10384	<question QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" Title="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" Views="315" Tags="publishing,citations" " AnswerId="QxlkFW/q3Dra4B6hZJTrEg==" Author="7309" Date="2013-06-01T23:57:11.577" Score="13" Text="&lt;p&gt;In my lab, a few of us submitted our papers independently to a conference last week. We all had referenced each other's work in our papers. I have a concern if this is a bad practice in academia. It also looks like a bad habit that has festered in our lab: the last two PhDs who passed out from our lab have a total of 15 citations for their papers, of which 13 are from within our community itself.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is this practice of repeatedly citing from one's own micro-community acceptable? It seems unavoidable, as we are all working together, familiarizing with each other's work and trying to build on them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="QxlkFW/q3Dra4B6hZJTrEg==" Author="7309" Date="2013-06-02T09:51:15.193" Text="@EpiGrad: One of these PhDs graduated last year and another this year, each after six years in PhD. I am in my third year myself./>
<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="QxlkFW/q3Dra4B6hZJTrEg==" Author="7309" Date="2013-06-02T09:49:25.967" Text="@eykanal: The title is alright, but I would like to state &quot;suicite&quot; is etymologically driven and has no malicious intent./>
<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="QxlkFW/q3Dra4B6hZJTrEg==" Author="705" Date="2013-06-04T19:21:25.973" Text="I find the question confusing.  Can you edit it to be more explicit? Are you saying that most of the references in your recently-submitted papers are to each other? When you cited each other's papers, were those papers as relevant as everything else you cited? Would you have cited them, if they weren't from your group?  When you mention the 13 of 15 statistic, does that mean that they wrote a paper/dissertation where 13 of the 15 citations are to papers in their own team; or do you mean that only 15 other papers have cited their work, and 13 of those citations come from within their own team?/>
<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="QxlkFW/q3Dra4B6hZJTrEg==" Author="118" Date="2013-06-02T07:09:45.067" Text="How recently were those two PhDs graduated? I suspect &quot;organic&quot; external citations appear much more slowly than internal citations from people who are both working in the same area, and already know of the author's work. You all get to skip the &quot;discovery&quot; step./>
<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="QxlkFW/q3Dra4B6hZJTrEg==" Author="73" Date="2013-06-02T02:38:30.357" Text="I changed the title, as a number of users expressed concern that &quot;suicite&quot; isn't the appropriate term to use here. <answer QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="RyRsk46GZlveiIzAmlks8g==" Author="6588" Date="2013-06-04T17:11:08.143" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;If your lab is the leader in a certain field, you would be aware of it.&#xA;If your colleagues are pure geniuses, you also would be aware of it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In both cases you won't be here to ask about it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In others cases, extreme repetition is not a good sign. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(Keep in mind that little repetition is good as it shows interest in a field, but 13 in 15 is a red flag, a big bad red flag with a big bad skull on it)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10450" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="H3ZOGyCx92i17hkzIFKF8A==" Author="1429" Date="2013-06-02T01:40:29.377" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;While I am &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; insinuating in any way that your lab does this in a malicious and self serving way, this reminds me of the notion of &lt;a href=&quot;http://scholarlykitchen.sspnet.org/2012/04/10/emergence-of-a-citation-cartel/&quot;&gt;citation cartels&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Its quite possible that this is an artifact of the research itself and its quite alright to self-cite (or group-cite) a few papers especially when one work builds upon the other. However, there must be more papers in the research community outside your own lab that must be citable? Surely, not 86.6% citations must be from within?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Speaking from my &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;limited&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; experience, if I were a reviewer and I saw papers with this kind of a pattern, I would certainly suggest the authors to include specific, relevant papers (which I have knowledge about) from outside their own lab in the literature review. I might of course be completely wrong and someone else with more experience in academia might have a different opinion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="H3ZOGyCx92i17hkzIFKF8A==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-02T02:55:47.257" Text="Also, even if OP means 13 &quot;references&quot; out of the 15 were their lab's papers, I still find it surprising that a referee would ask you to cite papers that they haven't read or even know. It may just be me, but to me it sounds so rude to question if the author did their homework when the referee can't give any concrete evidence. If the referee gives a concrete example, then it's either that the author's fault or that the referee's recommendation is wrong. Either way, the author can prove themselves right or revise the manuscript accordingly./>
<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="H3ZOGyCx92i17hkzIFKF8A==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-02T02:48:49.770" Text="Hmm? OP said one paper from their lab got 15 citations in total, 13 of which come from the same lab and 2 of which are from strangers, so to speak, right? Do referees in your field say your paper sucks and tell you to look at other relevant topics next time simply because your past paper got only citations from within your group? Without evaluating the merit by reading the content??/>
<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="H3ZOGyCx92i17hkzIFKF8A==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-02T03:39:00.193" Text="Oh, and I'm not saying I doubt you. It's just surprising that you can say the author didn't do their homework when you don't have evidence like specific papers you know they missed. In my experience, such claim should be based on concrete evidence just like any claim the author makes in a paper or at least some very convincing reason. Maybe too short a reference list qualifies as convincing indirect evidence?/>
<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="H3ZOGyCx92i17hkzIFKF8A==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-02T03:56:46.593" Text="I just noticed the edit you made 5 minutes ago. So, you're claiming you would be able to find specific, relevant papers the author missed if 13 out of 15 are from the author's community. I don't know how you can be so sure, but probably that's how things work in your field. I understand 13 out of 15 is unusual though. Anyway, maybe the research topics of OP's labs have a large community like yours./>
<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="H3ZOGyCx92i17hkzIFKF8A==" Author="1429" Date="2013-06-02T02:36:50.870" Text="No, I am not confusing it. References in one paper are citations to those specific papers. My grammar might be off though. Often, when going through the review process I get directives from reviewers which ask me to look at other specific papers which might be relevant etc. I don't think there is anything wrong in that and is quite a common practice, at least in my field. I would be a tad wary though of papers which have such high proportions of self citations or related citations and which (if I knew them) did not cite other works in the field./>
<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="H3ZOGyCx92i17hkzIFKF8A==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-02T02:07:11.627" Text="Aren't you confusing &quot;citations (from others)&quot; with &quot;reference items (you put at the end of your paper)&quot;? Either way, are you serious? I mean, would you write a report that says, &quot;Cite more papers that are relevant to this result. I don't know which or where you can find though&quot;? That's the most annoying kind of report. Wait. There's even worse. But your report should be based only on facts and the content of the manuscript. I agree 86% must be unusual. But &quot;Whoa, whoa, that looks kinda fishy, you know what I'm sayin'?&quot; isn't going to fly in science, at least without evidence, I don't think.../>
<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="H3ZOGyCx92i17hkzIFKF8A==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-02T09:24:33.060" Text="Please take extended discussion to chat./>
<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="H3ZOGyCx92i17hkzIFKF8A==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-02T03:31:27.967" Text="Like I said, if it's &quot;specific&quot; papers, then you can recommend the author include them in their reference list. The author can read them and refute or follow the recommendation. But if it's just a vague intuition that there are papers the author must've missed when you have no idea what they are or where the author might be able to find them, it's just your gut feeling. Also, I repeat myself here, but doesn't OP mean one paper &quot;received&quot; 13 citations from their lab? I think you're talking about &quot;citing&quot; 13 papers from the lab when there are only 15 items in the reference list./>
<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="H3ZOGyCx92i17hkzIFKF8A==" Author="1429" Date="2013-06-02T03:20:56.820" Text="Pure mathematics might be a different ballgame but when you work in nasty interdisciplinary work like I do, having a limited range of citations can be quite a drawback. As I mentioned previously, it is a common practice in HCI or information science for referees to recommend certain papers for citation in your article. e.g. Right now, I have 2 papers in publication and referees recommended 6 new and specific articles for citation. I should make it clear that what I meant was that referees often ask to cite specific papers and not generically say that you need to cite more papers./>
<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="H3ZOGyCx92i17hkzIFKF8A==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-02T03:03:00.403" Text="But if you just say it looks too few to you, it's neither falsifiable nor verifiable. It's your totally subjective opinion based only on your gut feeling... If such a logic is ok, you can say authors' data/proof looks wrong so it should be wrong simply because it doesn't follow your intuition. Besides, I've seen papers citing only a few papers (in math, btw). I've never been asked to cite papers that may not exist either... It may be very common in your field, though. Interesting./>

<answer QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="PwHfOKXTne9mgJqbKul2Gg==" Author="705" Date="2013-06-02T05:55:15.510" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;If I saw a pattern of only or mostly citing work from your own team, it would make me suspect that the authors have poor awareness of related work.  How likely is it that there is no other relevant work being done by anyone else in the literature?  Nothing else that has any relevance whatsoever (techniques, methods, related results, inspiration)?  That's awfully hard to believe.  It would make me suspect that the authors are either ignorant about the field, or are doing a poor job of citing related work.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It's not clear to me what you meant by the 13 of 15 statistic.  If you mean that they wrote a paper or dissertation where 13 of the 15 papers cited in the related work section is to people within their same group, yes, I would tend to look down on that.  It isn't &lt;em&gt;necessarily&lt;/em&gt; wrong, but it would certainly make me ask some pointed questions and make me suspect that there is something wrong.  It is important to be a good scholar and to understand other work in your field.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Maybe you've heard the saying: &quot;a week in the lab can save a day in the library&quot;.  (This is not a recommendation!)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="PwHfOKXTne9mgJqbKul2Gg==" Author="3890" Date="2013-06-04T18:56:45.217" Text="I'd also have this concern if a substantial portion of the references in a paper are to papers of the own group. But this doesn't seem to be an issue here./>

<answer QuestionId="Is the practice of lab members extensively citing each others work looked down upon in academia" AnswerId="Cw/gCwB9pZqF7xcgsm+iYg==" Author="669" Date="2013-06-02T05:44:16.677" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;It is only bad practice if the work is not particularly relevant, or if you cite your own group's papers instead of other relevant work.  The point of citations is to lead the reader to other related work necessary for some aspect of the paper (result, context, etc.).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That said, it is worth examining why those papers aren't getting cited.  Maybe nobody else is working in a sufficiently related area but it's critical background for the rest of what the lab is doing--then I wouldn't worry about it.  But if other people &lt;em&gt;are&lt;/em&gt; working in the area (e.g. to the point that you might worry that if you take too long that someone else will publish the same results you're trying to get), it can be a sign that the results either aren't contributing to the field much, that the style of presentation isn't good enough for others to really understand what you're saying, or that the lab members aren't going to enough conferences to present.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10388" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_1039	<question QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" Title="Being harassed by a department chair" Views="1587" Tags="professors" " AnswerId="lJMwlUQHJ6AxMA/ffxrM2w==" Author="604" Date="2012-04-07T04:47:05.447" Score="19" Text="&lt;p&gt;How do you cope when a department chair is all out to cause you problems? Especially when he is doing it for personal reasons that I have no control over (e.g. gender, skin color, nationality, religion, sexual orientation, accent, etc). My chair hates me, so he harasses me with bad teaching loads, too many preps, assigning me one class at 8am on one campus and another class at 8pm on a separate campus three hours away, making me teach every day when others teach only twice a week, denying me funding to go to conferences, not permitting me to go on a sabbatical, etc etc etc. He is highly unethical. I suspect he discards good teaching ratings I get and pencils in bad teaching ratings but I have no way to prove it. He makes up untrue anonymous complaints from anonymous students and anonymous complaints from anonymous faculty / staff. When a particular person is not hired and everyone wanted to hire that person, he whispers to everyone that I am the one who voted against hiring. He tries to turn everyone against me. When anything even remotely goes wrong, he blames me.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;He has the Dean in his pocket. He is also the chair of the faculty senate, childhood friends with the university president, brother-in-law of the provost. He is not the research type - he has one of those Ed.D. degrees and is a career administrator who has been the department chair for 17 years now. When I was hired, he was on medical leave, so he had no say in my hiring decision. He is also the only person in the department who does not teach or do research related to the department. He is a politician - former mayor of a small city - so much more astute and politically shrewd than I can ever be. He is dishonest, a blatant cheat and a frequent liar, so sitting down with him definitely never helped. He has superb contacts within the town and in state politics. Short of finding a new job, is there anything I can do? I cannot leave this university for personal reasons relating to the two-body problem, family whose help I need to take care of a severely handicapped child and other personal reasons.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="lJMwlUQHJ6AxMA/ffxrM2w==" Author="621" Date="2012-04-09T09:04:47.433" Text="Gather evidence, enlist allies, get ready to connfront him!/>

<answer QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="yTTmxVTfRXWf87f0knrvQQ==" Author="384" Date="2012-04-08T19:49:58.203" Score="13" Text="&lt;p&gt;If you are dealing with a bully who is insecure and threatened by you, direct negotiation will only result in your being manipulated further.  Read the available on-line literature on adult bullying.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Making friends with other powerful people (e.g. superordinates of your boss) is effective, eventually you might become someone that the bully wants &quot;on side&quot; and their overt behaviour will just flip like a light switch.  If you can document all your claims e.g. some members of a department having twice the teaching load for no clear, publicly-stated policy reason, you may have legal recourse &amp;amp; be able to get a more level playing field to try to prove your academic merit on (have you talked to HR?)  But if things are as &quot;sewn up&quot; as you say, and there is no help from HR or another campus organisation, then the best thing is to change job.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="yTTmxVTfRXWf87f0knrvQQ==" Author="612" Date="2012-04-10T17:29:47.597" Text="Do you have any suggestions for reading about adult bullying?  I don't know much about this but would like to learn more.  Thanks!/>
<comment QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="yTTmxVTfRXWf87f0knrvQQ==" Author="1520" Date="2012-08-28T14:48:10.240" Text="@AnonymousMathematician: an online blog [here](http://bulliedacademics.blogspot.co.uk/)/>
<comment QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="yTTmxVTfRXWf87f0knrvQQ==" Author="9117" Date="2014-03-18T20:38:56.417" Text="I've found the book &quot;It's all your fault! 12 tips for managing people who blame others for everything&quot; by Bill Eddy incredibly helpful. It can be bought for next to nothing on Kindle and it brought me great insight and understanding. http://www.amazon.com/Its-All-Your-Fault-Everything/dp/0981509037/>
<comment QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="yTTmxVTfRXWf87f0knrvQQ==" Author="65" Date="2012-04-10T09:48:00.790" Text="+1 for the warning about further manipulation./>
<comment QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="yTTmxVTfRXWf87f0knrvQQ==" Author="384" Date="2012-04-11T23:39:23.550" Text="I'm afraid I just did Google &amp; Google scholar searches on it when I had a younger colleague draw my attention to a situation that I realised, while extreme, was far too familiar.  The only papers I found worth putting in my citation index were on school-age bullying, but the gist of the Psychology Today etc. articles on adults were enough to help me help my colleague(s).  It seems to be an under-researched area, which is ironic since understanding it would probably benefit the childhood problem as well./>

See the US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission website (http://www.eeoc.gov/) for more information.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="9tU+PAaew6Fwhh1trZ7ahA==" Author="346" Date="2012-04-09T00:04:17.997" Score="19" Text="&lt;p&gt;Just to add to the other excellent comments: while I have no personal experience that might be of value in your situation, I think that there is one thing you MUST do on a continuing basis regardless of everything else. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Document every instance where you feel this person is abusing their authority in relation to you&lt;/strong&gt;. Accumulate as much evidence you can on each case, and build up a case file. Even if you don't go on the offensive, you'll need this if the chair starts trying direct confrontation and provocation (instead of the passive aggressive bullying that's going on right now)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="9tU+PAaew6Fwhh1trZ7ahA==" Author="269" Date="2012-04-09T06:02:04.667" Text="Agreed.  Also store your records off-campus./>

<answer QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="HeFbvyZ7Yt6f/YX/qzk4QA==" Author="612" Date="2012-04-07T14:41:06.670" Score="26" Text="&lt;p&gt;I agree with JeffE that leaving is the best solution, but it may not be an option.  One key question is whether you have tenure: if not, you're presumably doomed (if the chair's behavior is as bad as you fear) and you will need to find another job anyway.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Assuming you have reasonable job security, I'd sit down with the chair and ask what he envisions.  Don't complain, argue, or try to present your side.  Instead, you could start by acknowledging that the two of you have unfortunately gotten off to a rough start in your working relationship, and that because of his stature and leadership role it's important for you to earn his respect, so you'd like his advice on how to improve the situation.  Your goal is to learn, not to debate.  Don't explicitly agree to any facts that aren't true, but you don't have to fact check everything he says, and you shouldn't dispute his perspective or opinions in this conversation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One possibility is that he is an insecure jerk who wants you to submit to his power and authority.  If you do so, and let him boss you around a little without complaining, then he may treat you somewhat better.  [This is assuming he can't treat you any worse than he already is.  If you fear things could get worse, then be careful, but your question suggests you don't have a lot to lose.]&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another possibility is that he just doesn't want you around, and there's simply nothing you can do to get on his good side.  In that case, maybe he could help you transfer to another related department, for example.  Of course, you can't even bring this up unless you have some job security, since otherwise you have no leverage at all.  And it's important to do it in a face-saving way.  There's no way it will happen if it looks like he is getting rid of a problem employee (the administration and the other department will not accept that as a valid reason for such a transfer), and obviously he won't cooperate if the stated reason is getting you out from the control of an irresponsible chair.  Instead, you'd have to give it a positive spin: helping your career by giving you a chance to develop in a slightly different research direction, building ties between departments and fostering interdisciplinary connections, etc.  It may be galling, but you need to set this up in a way that makes it look like your chair is doing something valuable for the university by helping to arrange it.  If you can get your chair enthusiastic about this, and if there's another plausible department, then the chair's influence within the university might really help you.  And don't be too restrictive in ruling out possible departments: there might not be any appropriate match, but I know of a couple of cases in which people have successfully resolved personality conflicts by moving to departments that were a bit further afield than one might expect (engineering vs. science, for example).  If you've got tenure, then the university has a powerful incentive to fix this conflict, even if it means letting you sit in an odd department.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Leaving the university is radically different from switching departments, and you should not ask the chair for help in doing that.  Within the university, your chair's standing with the administration will play a major role in what opportunities are available.  Outside the university, your chair probably can't help you very much, but could certainly hurt you, so it's not worth the risk.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The worst case scenario is that your chair hates you and wants to hurt your career, regardless of which department you are in.  In that case, there's nothing you can do if your chair has the full support of the administration, and you'll have to either leave the university or wait for the chair to retire.  However, you shouldn't give up all hope until you've exhausted options like submitting or transferring.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="dKcD3c1gEgg0hMJVgHks4A==" Author="1520" Date="2012-08-28T10:49:21.333" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;This is a very interesting question, and I am surprised that there's no more about &quot;bullying&quot; in the SO academia community (I hope this will change fast).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As anonymous and new user, I can share some experience:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;1) If someone (higher in grade) bullies or harasses you, it's sad to say, but that means that you are not seen as doing a valuable contribution to the department. Not a &quot;maybe&quot;, not a &quot;perhaps&quot;: that is just what it is. This assumption could be right or wrong, but any dean/chair/professor wants to have a supportive (adoring?) team. So either you adapt to the system, or you will make your life very miserable: make your contributions very clear, boast about your workload or find another place. Bullies like strong (and loud) voices.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;2) Do not confront the bullying person: it's anyway an unfair battle, since they're managers and higher-ranked anyway.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;3) Be blatantly open with what you do, aka &quot;blow your own trumpet&quot;: when you start doing it, others reply as well, and you start realising that your &quot;case&quot; is no worse or better than somebody else's.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;MISTAKES TO BE AVOIDED:&lt;/strong&gt;&#xA;I think that the worst mistake to be done in these cases is moaning about the issue, or using &quot;allies&quot; to make the case, or asking the unions to do something about it. Moaning won't solve your case, but just make your stomach more acid; internal allies will not either: having allies and support is generally a good thing, but I realised that I was just &quot;using&quot; them to reinforce my assumptions and beliefs (ending up in a infinite loop of self-commiseration); unions will just use a pre-defined strategy that will be well known in advance by the bully.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;REMEDIES:&lt;/strong&gt;&#xA;Since you do not want to change your affiliation (but sadly this is the only real way to solve the issue, I am afraid), my take on the issue is to be honest with yourself, and ask whether your workload could be worse, or if you could make a request to avoid some teaching times by using some reasonable excuses, and in general stopping being negative about the person. The latter is tough but again, if you're being (overtly or secretly) negative, the bully will make your life even worse.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;RESOURCES:&lt;/strong&gt;&#xA;An excellent blog on the matter, and an &quot;external&quot; voice to talk to (yes! they talk and listen to you, also privately...) but in the UK: &lt;a href=&quot;http://bulliedacademics.blogspot.co.uk/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://bulliedacademics.blogspot.co.uk/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="dKcD3c1gEgg0hMJVgHks4A==" Author="1520" Date="2012-08-28T13:29:32.397" Text="me? i left the institution/>
<comment QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="dKcD3c1gEgg0hMJVgHks4A==" Author="65" Date="2012-08-28T14:22:58.940" Text="The last sentence is especially disturbing.  Yes, it's healthy to be positive and forgiving, but _not_ because negativity will make the bully think less of of their victim./>
<comment QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="dKcD3c1gEgg0hMJVgHks4A==" Author="1520" Date="2012-08-28T14:24:43.507" Text="dear @JeffE, what to say? I have been through it, and before that, I shared your opinions. I fought. Hard. Found allies who were brutally honest, but who were also scared to take the next step forward with me (a formal complaint). Tried to overcome the system, met the oppressor many times in his &quot;cave&quot;, filed formal complaints. In order not to sink others I fled/>
<comment QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="dKcD3c1gEgg0hMJVgHks4A==" Author="65" Date="2012-08-28T14:27:56.937" Text="I think you did the right thing, by finding allies, by fighting hard, and by leaving.  None of that is easy./>
<comment QuestionId="Being harassed by a department chair" AnswerId="dKcD3c1gEgg0hMJVgHks4A==" Author="65" Date="2012-08-28T14:16:35.703" Text="I have to strongly disagree with this answer.  The initial point is correct—if you are being abused, you are not valued.  But the proper response to abuse is not to &quot;get used to it&quot;; this is a merely a recipe for continued abuse.  Allies are a *must* in this situation, just as they are in any other stressful, emotionally charged situation.  Trying to tough it out alone is dangerous and usually unnecessary.  But it is important to find allies who are well-informed and brutally honest—the last thing you need is an echo chamber./>

I will be 35 when I start my PhD in Computer Science/Machine Learning, and probably I will finish it around the age of 40.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Will I be banished from academic positions considering a possible PostDoc time and what about industry positions ? If you're worried, just don't put your date of birth on your CV.  Most people don't.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Hiring committees just don't care how old you are.  All that matters is the quality and impact of your research.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10398	<question QuestionId="How is a Masters different from the first two years of a PhD in the same field" Title="How is a Masters different from the first two years of a PhD in the same field" Views="210" Tags="phd,masters" " AnswerId="V4H5YJUOz10XsK20izRgAA==" Author="6803" Date="2013-06-02T08:07:55.590" Score="-1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'm interested in Neuroscience research but haven't quite made up my mind about what sub-field I want to specialize in. I think taking courses from various sub-fields will help me take a decision. Should I go for a Masters first or a PhD directly? If I go for a PhD, will I have enough time at the beginning of my PhD to explore different areas and then choose a supervisor, say after around 2 years into the program?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How is a Masters different from the first two years of a PhD in the same field" AnswerId="V4H5YJUOz10XsK20izRgAA==" Author="6942" Date="2013-06-02T09:29:32.867" Text="possibly, but there people gave quite generalized answers, whereas I think warmzombie is looking for a more specialized answer in Neuroscience/>

<answer QuestionId="How is a Masters different from the first two years of a PhD in the same field" AnswerId="TtTEdYcxnv9i5Cemk2uIqA==" Author="6942" Date="2013-06-02T09:34:15.250" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;There are two different types of Masters - taught masters and research masters.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In England, a research masters allows you to work, on rotation, around 3 labs in the year, and you can pick and choose from different sub-fields. This is hugely beneficial because it exposes you to different sub-fields, but more importantly because it exposes you to different work dynamics and environments, allow you to cope better in your PhD; furthermore, you'll make more contacts (which is all that matters in research - reputation and recommendations) and learn from different people. It'll give you the confidence to know, during your PhD, whether you are right or wrong.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The downside is that it takes you one more year and there is no guarantee you'll get a PhD after, and there is also the extra cost - most funding bodies do not fund a one year masters. However, if you apply for a 4-year Masters with PhD, funding options are more generous.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I can only speak for England, unsure about other countries, but the same principles apply. (my own opinion is that MRes is good if you can afford it)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How is a Masters different from the first two years of a PhD in the same field" AnswerId="TtTEdYcxnv9i5Cemk2uIqA==" Author="6942" Date="2013-06-02T14:01:33.167" Text="No, in the UK, you stick with one lab. There might be collaborations between labs, but there is no rotations./>
<comment QuestionId="How is a Masters different from the first two years of a PhD in the same field" AnswerId="TtTEdYcxnv9i5Cemk2uIqA==" Author="546" Date="2013-06-02T13:55:14.653" Text="In UK, would PhD students have lab rotation opportunity?/>
<comment QuestionId="How is a Masters different from the first two years of a PhD in the same field" AnswerId="TtTEdYcxnv9i5Cemk2uIqA==" Author="6942" Date="2013-06-02T11:13:57.263" Text="My answer is pretty much specific to life sciences, if it turns out that it isn't and other fields share the same structure (the lab rotations) then I've learnt something new today. (I would appreciate it if you can tell me other fields that have lab rotations - because I honestly wouldn't have a clue)/>
<comment QuestionId="How is a Masters different from the first two years of a PhD in the same field" AnswerId="TtTEdYcxnv9i5Cemk2uIqA==" Author="6942" Date="2013-06-02T11:05:35.800" Text="Correct me if I am wrong, but I always imagine different fields having different course structures, and all I tried to do is answer it in the life sciences perspective, rather than say, computer science. If you don't like the answer, just vote it down./>
<comment QuestionId="How is a Masters different from the first two years of a PhD in the same field" AnswerId="TtTEdYcxnv9i5Cemk2uIqA==" Author="6942" Date="2013-06-02T10:21:53.567" Text="The question on the other page asks about Mathematics, and this is on life sciences?&#xA;&#xA;Anyways, I've answered it and if the question is a duplicate, not my problem./>

</answer>
</question>

<answer QuestionId="How do you cite articles from a &quotdatabase&quot" AnswerId="3Xl4tBXxLuy2CKwk/p31rw==" Author="725" Date="2013-06-02T11:29:55.917" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;The first two sources of information about such questions are &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The publisher of the database may have specified how they want to be cited.&lt;br&gt;&#xA;In fact, The Cochrane Collaboration has such guidelines:&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cochrane.org/policy-manual/2211-how-cite-our-products&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Cochrane Policy Manual: How to cite our products&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cochrane.org/cochrane-reviews/citing-our-products&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Cochrane Reviews: How to cite Cochrane Collaboration products&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The APA style guide may have said something already about this data base.&lt;br&gt;&#xA;This is also the case:&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.apastyle.org/apastyle/2012/01/how-to-cite-cochrane-reviews-in-apa-style.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;How to Cite Cochrane Reviews in APA Style&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&#xA;They explain how a journal article style should be used with year as volume and monthly issue:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Singh, J., Kour, K., &amp;amp; Jayaram Mahesh, B. (2012). Acetylcholinesterase &#xA;  inhibitors for schizophrenia. Cochrane Database of Systematic &#xA;  Reviews, 2012(1), 1–101. doi:10.1002/14651858.CD007967.pub2&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/ul&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If these would not have lead to the required information, a more general idea is:&lt;br&gt;&#xA;Following the DOI of your example, I end up at a page of the Cochrane library that also has a tab &lt;a href=&quot;http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD000448.pub3/citedby&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;&quot;Cited by&quot;&lt;/a&gt;. You could have a look there how other people actually cite the report.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If all this had failed, I'd propably have gone for a technical report style citation.  &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Should I add descriptions of courses taught on my CV" AnswerId="CNaUBFkyVPVsMj+y/hoeAQ==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-02T15:49:46.543" Score="10" Text="&lt;p&gt;A brief description of the courses you've taught is never remiss, as it helps reviewers place your teaching work into context. This is especially important for teaching-primary positions. However, for many positions, you also have the ability (or requirement) to submit a &quot;teaching statement.&quot; This would be a place, for instance, where you could discuss your unique projects. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What I would certainly want people to know about in the courses I taught:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Full course name&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Whether they were required or elective&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The intended audience (e.g., &quot;freshmen&quot; or &quot;upper-year undergraduates and graduates in the major&quot;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;How long (how many times) you taught the course&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Did you have sole responsibility, or was it co-taught&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Format of the class (lecture, seminar, laboratory, etc.)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;A brief description of the course, if its nature cannot be inferred from the title (for example, &quot;Introduction to US History to 1865&quot; doesn't need an explanation; &quot;The Critical Period&quot; would.) &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Other information could be listed on a &quot;courses taught&quot; appendix, but I might not necessarily include it directly in the CV.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Should I add descriptions of courses taught on my CV" AnswerId="CNaUBFkyVPVsMj+y/hoeAQ==" Author="7317" Date="2013-06-03T22:36:05.100" Text="Do you think it would be better to list the courses and their descriptions right under the university position, or as an appendix?/>
<comment QuestionId="Should I add descriptions of courses taught on my CV" AnswerId="CNaUBFkyVPVsMj+y/hoeAQ==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-03T22:50:01.643" Text="Personally, I list them under a separate section of my CV. Basically, the more courses you have, the more important it is to separate it out (in the interests of clarity, organization, and readability.)/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10411	<question QuestionId="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" Title="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" Views="371" Tags="publishing,citations,reference-request" " AnswerId="OvGiJSw2YqZQx0+eDjUBIg==" Author="7328" Date="2013-06-02T19:32:00.080" Score="14" Text="&lt;p&gt;When learning a new subject, I would frequently use lecture notes found somewhere in the Internet. When writing a paper (or a master thesis, as in my case, but the rules should be similar, I believe) one should give some reference for used results which are not common knowledge, if I understand correctly. This make me wonder: what do I do if I want to reference a result I found in some notes?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The natural thing to do would be to just add these notes to bibliography. What format would be preferable for this? Note that there will generally not be much publishing information, perhaps not even a definite year and place. (A BibTeX template would be .)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Secondly, is it OK to cite such materials as a reference?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" AnswerId="OvGiJSw2YqZQx0+eDjUBIg==" Author="94" Date="2013-06-03T13:39:37.160" Text="@Vahid: though in most cases when that happens, either the results are tangential or the results are reproduced in full./>
<comment QuestionId="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" AnswerId="OvGiJSw2YqZQx0+eDjUBIg==" Author="6618" Date="2013-06-02T20:54:28.840" Text="I think this question should be asked on academia.SE./>
<comment QuestionId="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" AnswerId="OvGiJSw2YqZQx0+eDjUBIg==" Author="darij grinberg" Date="2013-06-02T19:46:12.593" Text="&quot;Secondly, is it OK to cite such materials as a reference?&quot; Absolutely, but try to make sure the link will still be usable in a few years' time. (One approach is to ask the author via email to put them on arXiv.) Also, add the date of the publication to your reference, or it might become ambiguous./>
<comment QuestionId="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" AnswerId="OvGiJSw2YqZQx0+eDjUBIg==" Author="Ｊ. M." <answer QuestionId="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" AnswerId="/7popEWthDb9u6yaZ+Edhg==" Author="3890" Date="2013-06-03T13:36:03.137" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;From a general point of view, lecture notes are &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gray_literature&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;gray literature&lt;/a&gt;, meaning they might &lt;strong&gt;lack standard bibliographic metadata&lt;/strong&gt; (you mentioned the year and place), may be harder to track down for readers, or not long-term available. Thus, one should generally &lt;strong&gt;prefer to cite conventional literature&lt;/strong&gt; (such as books or articles in journals) over gray literature.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For a masters thesis, it should be fine to cite gray literature, but do check with your advisor. When you do so, you might as well discuss the format he'd recommend for citation. If you found the lecture notes online, one idea would be to &lt;strong&gt;cite it as online source&lt;/strong&gt;, where key metadata would be the URL and the date of access.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In contrast to a masters thesis, many publishers &lt;strong&gt;discourage or forbid the citation of gray literature&lt;/strong&gt; for journal papers. So if you want to make a paper from the thesis and the citation is essential, you would have to find the original source.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10426" Date="2013-06-03T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10426" Date="2013-06-03T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" AnswerId="ZJSOszz+Vt0gytPZ8Nqn6Q==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-03T01:24:13.370" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;You should make a good-faith effort to find and cite original source of the results (to give proper credit).  You should only cite the lecture notes if (1) they &lt;em&gt;are&lt;/em&gt; the original source, or (2) the original source is inaccessible, either literally (out of print or unpublished) or figuratively (written in a foreign language, with excessive generality or formality, or just badly).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Finding the original source may require significantly more scholarly diligence on your part than the author of the lecture notes, since most lecture-note authors (including myself) are fairly sloppy with references.  Such is life.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" AnswerId="ZJSOszz+Vt0gytPZ8Nqn6Q==" Author="94" Date="2013-06-03T10:55:50.983" Text="If the lecture notes contain the proofs in full, I don't see why one must find the original source./>
<comment QuestionId="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" AnswerId="ZJSOszz+Vt0gytPZ8Nqn6Q==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-03T14:02:01.543" Text="@WillieWong: Most of the scientific community agrees with you, to its detriment./>
<comment QuestionId="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" AnswerId="ZJSOszz+Vt0gytPZ8Nqn6Q==" Author="94" Date="2013-06-03T13:37:20.323" Text="@paulgarrett: I never said that one _mustn't_ find the original source. I merely disagree with the notion that one _must_ find the original source. If one can track down the original source, great! But having spent some time (out of personal interest) trying to track down, historically, the original instance of Widget X, I am inclined to be very, very relaxed about what constitutes a &quot;good-faith effort&quot;. I especially will not demand a masters student to dig through the literature by himself for the first instance of Obscure Technical Lemma 3.1.52..../>
<comment QuestionId="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" AnswerId="ZJSOszz+Vt0gytPZ8Nqn6Q==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-03T13:17:56.200" Text="@WillieWong: why not _both_? Not too burdensome to tell both a _helpful_ source, as well as &quot;origin&quot; source. Delicate, yes, to say &quot;don't try to read this, but cite it&quot;? :)/>
<comment QuestionId="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" AnswerId="ZJSOszz+Vt0gytPZ8Nqn6Q==" Author="94" Date="2013-06-03T13:15:16.887" Text="@paulgarrett: With the exception of parts of the introductory paragraphs, where it has become the norm to give a historical overview of the field, in which case historical primacy would be King, I would in fact argue that for the benefit of the readers the moral imperative should be to cite the resource that contains the best exposition of the technical result needed./>
<comment QuestionId="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" AnswerId="ZJSOszz+Vt0gytPZ8Nqn6Q==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-03T13:01:53.203" Text="@WillieWong: surely it's good to give credit where credit is due. It is possible to over-do it, I suppose, but I think textbooks (not to mention lecture notes) err too much in neglect rather than over-footnoting./>

<answer QuestionId="How to cite lecture notes (and should I even do this)" AnswerId="igr8S6U66V2Fdu+2/OTMyA==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-03T01:01:47.840" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;To my taste, citations are fulfilling several purposes, some of which may not be fulfillable simultaneously. So, one should be honest about where one found a result, even if the source is not widely available. Thus, cite (in the best, most usable form possible) the lecture notes. Still, yes, &lt;em&gt;accessible&lt;/em&gt; sources meet another criterion, namely, helping readers reproduce/understand your results.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Edit: in light of various comments and other answers... another purpose served by spending &lt;em&gt;some&lt;/em&gt; (not unlimited) time finding original sources (even while being honest about the source one actually &lt;em&gt;used&lt;/em&gt; or _learned_from_) is to give at least a lower bound for the age (and locale of origin) of the idea. Nevertheless, at the same time, it certainly &lt;em&gt;can&lt;/em&gt; happen that a much later exposition does a much better job of explaining... after all, benefiting from hindsight.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Yet another reason to exert some effort to credit original sources is to dampen a bit a tendency that otherwise can dominate, namely, some form of &quot;Great Man/Woman&quot; syndrome, in which a very few people are portrayed as being responsible for nearly all good, big ideas.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10412" Date="2013-06-03T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10412" Date="2013-06-03T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10412" Date="2013-06-03T00:00:00.000/>
