academia.stackexchange.com_10415	<question QuestionId="How to get an edu email" Title="How to get an edu email" Views="913" Tags="email" " AnswerId="t/gtxiMR2JRoZlI7wi3ATw==" Author="7305" Date="2013-06-03T06:53:21.497" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am a hobbyist mathematician in China. I study maths by myself and make some course videos to teach commutative algebra, functional analysis and other topics at the internet just as the Khan Academy and MIT open courses. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now I need an edu email to go into some places such as researchgate and arxiv. Does any organisation like this: I show some material such as videos and papers to them, then they think you are no weaker than some college teachers at least and give me an edu email? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to get an edu email" AnswerId="t/gtxiMR2JRoZlI7wi3ATw==" Author="7305" Date="2013-06-07T07:04:31.890" Text="Thanks, but I want to find some specific places with  their short introductions./>
<comment QuestionId="How to get an edu email" AnswerId="t/gtxiMR2JRoZlI7wi3ATw==" Author="94" Date="2013-06-03T10:53:32.053" Text="BTW, as mentioned in the arXiv link I just gave, having an academic affiliation is not a sufficient condition for gaining automatic endorsements. That is to say, a `.edu` address gained from the methods linked to by @ChrisGregg may very well be useless for the OP's intended use./>
<comment QuestionId="How to get an edu email" AnswerId="t/gtxiMR2JRoZlI7wi3ATw==" Author="7466" Date="2013-06-20T06:11:26.893" Text="You can soemtimes join Reseachgate without an academic affiliation on the basis of your CV with qualifications and publications. You should work on producing some publications to pass peer-review. I think it would also help to not use a single word pseudonym. If you must use a &quot;nom de plume&quot; make it a realistic sounding name./>
<comment QuestionId="How to get an edu email" AnswerId="t/gtxiMR2JRoZlI7wi3ATw==" Author="4461" Date="2013-06-03T09:49:41.363" Text="[Google is your friend.](https://www.google.com/search?q=how+to+get+an+.edu+email&amp;aq=f&amp;oq=how+to+get+an+.edu+email&amp;aqs=chrome.0.57j0j62l3.4376j0&amp;sourceid=chrome&amp;ie=UTF-8)/>
<comment QuestionId="How to get an edu email" AnswerId="t/gtxiMR2JRoZlI7wi3ATw==" Author="94" Date="2013-06-03T10:48:17.460" Text="For arXiv, you certainly do _not_ need an e-mail address affiliated to a university. You just need to have [endorsements](http://arxiv.org/help/endorsement). Getting an academic to endorse your paper is likely a lesser threshold than what you tried to describe (obtaining an affiliation to get an academic e-mail address)./>

<answer QuestionId="How to get an edu email" AnswerId="ISs9kNJNUYe6gA5okOgtfg==" Author="62" Date="2013-06-03T07:17:30.640" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Of course, becoming a student or staff member is one way to get a university email.&#xA;Some institutions provide alumni email.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Many universities have various unpaid affiliates. Such affiliates are sometimes eligible for a  university email. However, such affiliates are often expected to contribute to the school, faculty, or university. For example, you might publish with the university as your affiliation or you might give occasional lectures or you might supervise a research student. These sorts of affiliations are typically obtained by building up a relationship with some academics in a given department and making enquiries.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How to get an edu email" AnswerId="QwixUIymfg+gMahIlT+52g==" Author="2700" Date="2013-06-03T07:39:29.930" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;As a researcher whose is that of a very small university in Europe, whose domain name and institutional email addresses do not end in &lt;code&gt;.edu&lt;/code&gt; (nor in &lt;code&gt;.ac.uk&lt;/code&gt; or any other recognizable pattern): &lt;strong&gt;any website that uses email domains as filters has a fallback mechanism&lt;/strong&gt; (or exception handler) that you can reach if your own email address doesn't fit into the patterns they recognize. It may take some explaining, though…&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10419	<question QuestionId="What is the difference between department and faculty" Title="What is the difference between department and faculty" Views="2422" Tags="university" " AnswerId="rxBFyA5jod62/t5uUUtj6g==" Author="406" Date="2013-06-03T10:05:44.513" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;Some universities have independent &lt;code&gt;departments&lt;/code&gt;, but some put departments under supervision of a faculty. For instance, a university has fifty independent departments, but another has 5 faculties containing departments. In the former, the Dean of Faculty is intermediate between the department chairs and the university administration.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I understand that most of these structures come from the university history, but how these structures affect the department performance, and why universities prefer different structures, instead of a standard one (which should be most efficient).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example, what is the different of &lt;code&gt;Department of Computer Science&lt;/code&gt; in one university, and &lt;code&gt;Department of Computer Science&lt;/code&gt; in another university which is part of &lt;code&gt;Faculty of Engineering&lt;/code&gt;? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What is the difference between department and faculty" AnswerId="rxBFyA5jod62/t5uUUtj6g==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-03T14:07:32.503" Text="As a rule, universities in the US don't have sub-organizations called &quot;faculties&quot;; we generally call them &quot;colleges&quot;.  The academic employees (instructors, researchers, and academic administrators) constitute *the* faculty./>
<comment QuestionId="What is the difference between department and faculty" AnswerId="rxBFyA5jod62/t5uUUtj6g==" Author="406" Date="2013-06-03T16:33:28.970" Text="@JeffE I know that in the US terminology, `college` or `school` are used; but my question, in general, is about the pros and cons of having such sub-organizations, regardless of their names./>

<answer QuestionId="What is the difference between department and faculty" AnswerId="zlijP1VmG89DqDEdr8CMbA==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-03T11:37:56.017" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;The distinction between &quot;faculty,&quot; &quot;department,&quot; and &quot;school&quot; depends a lot on where you are. As Peter suggests in his answer, a faculty can be a collection of &quot;departments.&quot; However, a faculty in Germany (for instance) consists of a number of &quot;chairs,&quot; each of which is closer to a professorship in a department than an actual &quot;department.&quot; Thus, the faculty is effectively halfway between the American &quot;department&quot; and &quot;faculty&quot; in its function, as it combines some of the hierarchy and responsibilities of each.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The reason for having multiple subdivisions is that there are often many university functions—including personnel and budget decisions, facilities management, teaching, and so on—that can vary widely across the entire university, but significantly less among certain departments that have a similar focus. For these departments, it makes sense to combine these duties in a central administration, rather than duplicate the effort across multiple departments. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10424" Date="2013-09-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10424" Date="2013-06-15T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10424" Date="2013-06-03T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10424" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10424" Date="2013-06-03T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10424" Date="2013-06-03T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10424" Date="2013-06-03T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="What is the difference between department and faculty" AnswerId="CSu07fHzOpfq2T1ofOsSxw==" Author="5944" Date="2013-06-03T17:15:11.687" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Sometimes using one word or another is seen as more prestigious or as more independent than another. In one place I was at, they made a big deal of changing their name from &quot;Department of Computer Science&quot; to &quot;School of Computer Science&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Similarly, some people perceive one Faculty as more prestigious for the purposes of undergraduate recruiting. In many Universities in North America, computer science moved from &quot;science&quot; to &quot;engineering&quot; and my father perceived that computer science departments in &quot;engineering&quot; were more promising than those in &quot;science&quot; (as at the time engineers made more money and had more job opportunities than scientists). Of course, the real reason that this happens is often a question of autonomy, funding, and mutual interests behind the scenes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In the end, the question of &quot;For example, what is the difference of Department of Computer Science in one university, and Department of Computer Science in another university which is part of Faculty of Engineering?&quot; is very, very difficult to answer and I would argue that the differences are much more dependent on the actual &quot;department&quot; than on what faculty/college/administrative area it's under. In North America, most departments (especially computer science departments) are relatively autonomous and do not rely heavily on their college for assistance - it's simply a bureaucratic layer through which funds go through.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10431" Date="2013-06-03T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10431" Date="2013-06-15T00:00:00.000/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10431" Date="2013-06-03T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10431" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="What is the difference between department and faculty" AnswerId="1Cu+yhEqFhYwUU4ojUC3SA==" Author="4394" Date="2013-06-03T11:11:46.483" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;The faculty is a collection of departments. In my system we have the Faculty of Sciences, Law, Humanities, and Social Sciences. In addirions there can be Faculty of Theology, Arts, Languages, Educational Science, Medicine, Pharmacy and probably many others. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The term Faculty is known from the University in Paris already in medieval times. It was a way in which major fields distinguished themeselves from a genral body of learning. The faculties of Philosophy, Law, Theology and Medicine can be found back to the 13th century. As the universities grew and knowledge became more specialized departments started to form within these faculties and we now have the system of faculties as an administrative level in many university systems. Departments are, however, relatively modern creations from the late 19th century.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10420	<question QuestionId="Academic bullies" Title="Academic bullies" Views="330" Tags="etiquette,personal-advice" " AnswerId="xJ3tpV0CrYIaURSCBbc6Rw==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-03T10:27:07.743" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;A question if I may, about appropriate methods of dealing with academic bullies (or as one of my students call them &quot;wannabe nemesis&quot;).  What would be the best, most dignified way to 'overcome' them, while protecting your own research interests andreputation?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To clarify what I mean by an academic bully - first and foremost, I am not referring to those that offer critiques in any constructive forms (even in an aggressive manner), I am referring to the academics that who, for whatever reason (usually due to disgreeing with research findings or feeling threatened by 'newcomers' to the research field), decide to go on the offensive with insults, threats, and the like.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Finally, I am referring to, if the communication is direct (by email. letter or in person).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Academic bullies" AnswerId="uT7ApehpsZFpU8Eeq1D2Kg==" Author="4394" Date="2013-06-03T10:57:57.317" Score="12" Text="&lt;p&gt;As you point out there is usually some personal (psychological) reason for such behaviour, particularly if it is repeated/continuous. I believe the first thing to do is to avoid to go by insinct and &quot;fight back&quot;. Obviously the correct response will rely on the type of communication/accusation but keeping a calm and cool tone is the best. Keep all replies very short and avoid emotional touches at all costs. &quot;Thank your for your opinion.&quot; (or something along those lines) is enough to have provided a response while practically ending the correspondence since there is nothing more to reply to. To try to &quot;kill&quot; the conversation by not providing fuel is the way to go. In verbal communications a simple &quot;OK&quot; can be enough. Then try to walk away at the first opportunity.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Bad behaviour is otherwise best fought with good science and academic professionality and one must try to find moral support in situations like this so that ones self-confidence is not shattered. There are many destructive behaviours that affect us, some temporary some part of (or deficiency in) a personality. There is however, no reason to go into mud-slinging with such persons unless they express clearly unethical opinions but then the question is at a different level.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Academic bullies" AnswerId="uT7ApehpsZFpU8Eeq1D2Kg==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-03T11:09:07.000" Text="it also helps as well, when you are able to get support from colleagues and/or organisations./>

But I have some concerns. How should I choose which courses to take.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If some &lt;em&gt;internationally &lt;strong&gt;known&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; professor gives an introductory course e.g. Introduction to Algorithms and if another &lt;em&gt;internationally &lt;strong&gt;unknown&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; one offers advanced graduate course, which one should I choose first ? Consider the future recommendation letters to United States schools I would expect from them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Planning nondegree classes" AnswerId="IM4dAcqZJTBJrtPi9TfuMw==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-03T14:05:00.963" Text="Take the graduate-level class **and** do an independent study project with the well-known professor./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10423" Date="2013-06-10T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Planning nondegree classes" AnswerId="5K2ujd8N53WaxY64k7O1lg==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-03T11:41:53.287" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;The reputation of the faculty member helps somewhat, but is nowhere near as useful as the &lt;em&gt;quality of the recommendation letter.&lt;/em&gt; A letter from a famous person who doesn't really know you outside of the classroom (or doesn't know you at all) isn't nearly as helpful as an in-depth evaluation from someone you know well, and who knows you well.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, I find the notion that you would taking an introductory course versus an advanced elective somewhat concerning. In general, if you are looking to buttress a graduate-school application, evidence that you can handle graduate-level work in the field matters far more than having a Big Name write you a weak letter. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10427	<question QuestionId="PhD funding source for international student in the UK" Title="PhD funding source for international student in the UK" Views="259" Tags="phd,funding,scholarships" " AnswerId="AnItREXHWjS+nMZ/Kt7i6Q==" Author="6064" Date="2013-06-03T15:05:03.060" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I will start my PhD in computer science at a UK university soon. <answer QuestionId="PhD funding source for international student in the UK" AnswerId="OS9CuhdLAlurV6xm1jEVtw==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-03T17:17:54.240" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;Your best bet is probably to check if there are fellowships available for study abroad from your home country. However, depending on where you're from, there may be special programs available. For instance, there are &lt;a href=&quot;http://cscuk.dfid.gov.uk/apply/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Commonwealth Scholarships&lt;/a&gt; available for people living in members of the British Commonwealth.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are some databases of UK awards for general students: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.educationuk.org/nc?pagename=GLOBAL%2FSearchLayoutTemplate&amp;amp;c=Page&amp;amp;SearchResultType=scholarship&amp;amp;cid=1262432674923&amp;amp;activeFinderCombo=2&amp;amp;checkVal=1&amp;amp;finderSearchType=finder&amp;amp;finderIndex=2&amp;amp;SearchTerm=&amp;amp;Subject=Please+Select&amp;amp;Country+of+residence=International+%28outside+European+Union%29&amp;amp;Level+of+study=Postgraduate&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;, for instance, is a list of postgraduate scholarships available to citizens of any country.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10428	<question QuestionId="How much value do papers without new scientific information have ie seminar papers such as overviews of or examples for current methods in CS" Title="How much value do papers without new scientific information have ie seminar papers such as overviews of or examples for current methods in CS" Views="201" Tags="computer-science,seminars" " AnswerId="10E/1GXCIyiYWZY8/ijbdA==" Author="6690" Date="2013-06-03T15:08:04.153" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;So I wrote a seminar paper in grad school (MSc) with examples on how companies use method x to improve their security. It includes zero &lt;em&gt;original&lt;/em&gt; research, no new methods and it would never ever be published in a journal, because the substance is really not there.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It gives a theoretical background of the problems itself and then different current examples from 2 companies that I researched over the internet and a conclusion. Thus, not only academic sources but also other sources (companies) are used and it basically shows the &lt;strong&gt;application of academic concepts&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Other researchers could use this paper to potentially find ways on how to dig deeper and how to address some problems specifically, but I did not point something like that out myself.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;My question:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Does this count as research and does it make sense to hand those kind of papers to PhD admission departments?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How much value do papers without new scientific information have ie seminar papers such as overviews of or examples for current methods in CS" AnswerId="jeuJXD0QJnH9MIO8FPEXFw==" Author="7116" Date="2013-06-03T15:22:51.727" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would say yes, it is good to show this if you are planning to apply for grad school as a way to show your capability for conducting research, your interest, knowledge of the topic and dedication. It might, or not, give a potential adviser a hint of your capability. Then, if the paper is or not mature or appropriate for a peer-reviewed journal would not, in principle, be an issue for the purpose you mention.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

Definitely do submit your work as part of your PhD application, perhaps with a focus on the methodology that you used and an evaluation of the method.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How much value do papers without new scientific information have ie seminar papers such as overviews of or examples for current methods in CS" AnswerId="Wim6DbK/d+UBYgIDglQlZw==" Author="546" Date="2013-06-04T08:43:03.170" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;In the Definition section of &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Research&lt;/a&gt; Wiki page,&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;A broad definition of research is given by Martyn Shuttleworth - &quot;In the broadest sense of the word, the definition of research includes any gathering of data, information and facts for the advancement of knowledge&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think your paper counts as research. I would hand those kind of papers to PhD admission departments if I were you. At the very least, the paper shows that you have the research potential even if it contains no original idea or new methods.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, you need to make sure the paper is of good quality. If the quality is poor, it could have negative effects. You probably want some experts (like your advisor) review it before you send it out.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10438" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="How much value do papers without new scientific information have ie seminar papers such as overviews of or examples for current methods in CS" AnswerId="i+iD/7VNwzAwi8tnBSlThQ==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-03T15:43:43.120" Score="10" Text="&lt;p&gt;This is akin to a &lt;em&gt;review article&lt;/em&gt;, in the sense that you're interpreting and reporting on existing work, rather than creating something new. There's nothing wrong with a review article, and many scientists do write them during their careers (but usually not before they've started a doctoral program!). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That said, while I believe that it is not nearly as good as a &quot;standard&quot; research paper in establishing one's capabilities to do &lt;em&gt;original&lt;/em&gt; research, it may have some merit. If the schools to which you are applying allow you to submit additional documentation, then you could consider sending it in, if you believe it is of sufficient quality.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10440	<question QuestionId="Should I tell my supervisor that I will consult someone else" Title="Should I tell my supervisor that I will consult someone else" Views="1013" Tags="phd,etiquette,supervisors" " AnswerId="070G6bL8PYZKNUfjkTv9jQ==" Author="4018" Date="2013-06-04T10:12:57.033" Score="13" Text="&lt;p&gt;I need an specific advice on a specific area (not the main one) in my PhD research (e.g. is it a good idea to include the factor x in the review and analysis of the topic y?).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As far as I know, my supervisor is not an 'expert' in this specific area.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think that someone else, who has recently done a PhD in my department and has &lt;em&gt;good connections&lt;/em&gt; with my supervisor, is an expert in that area and can help.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In academic etiquette: should I make my supervisor aware that I am asking an advice from that person?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10440" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Should I tell my supervisor that I will consult someone else" AnswerId="rech5pYsb1pMAMzLKAPoEg==" Author="1429" Date="2013-06-04T22:14:47.787" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;Yes. I am a graduate student and I have done this quite a number of times. Usually its no problem. In fact my advisers have always encouraged reaching out to various people in their specializations to ask for advice.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What I do is bring up the topic and then say something like &quot;What do you feel about me reaching out to Dr. XX or Prof. YY about feedback regarding this analysis? Or this writing?&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Usually, they are very happy to agree or suggest alternatives. I recommend that you try this approach and see what comes of it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Should I tell my supervisor that I will consult someone else" AnswerId="r8AzzFJzpAjV0RSKjOJ3/A==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-04T12:44:37.747" Score="16" Text="&lt;p&gt;Yes.  In the same tone that you use to describe finding a helpful book in the library.  Consulting experts, whether in the flesh or through their published work, is a normal and expected part of doing research.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The tone of your question suggests that you are worried that your advisor might be insulted by not being consulted first.  If this is a real concern, you need a new advisor.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Should I tell my supervisor that I will consult someone else" AnswerId="4Ztm+GJSSfsyWCSfa7pnzA==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-04T10:21:34.153" Score="20" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would approach your supervisor with request for advice and depending on what the problem is, (s)he may recommend you speak to some other scholarly expert in the field. If (s)he doesn't, you could suggest yourself that it might be an idea to speak to some expert. Your supervisor and you could work out a viable solution.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This has happened to me numerous times during my PhD - the nature of the project meant that other scholars had to be consulted.  My supervisor had no problems with this, but I made sure that I always let him know, and in many cases, he had recommended I speak to other scholars and was also able to recommend various experts.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is always polite to keep your supervisor in the loop.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10444	<question QuestionId="Waiting after a review" Title="Waiting after a review" Views="275" Tags="journals,paper-submission" " AnswerId="rtPtbV6AFHVqAhBKRbZMOQ==" Author="7345" Date="2013-06-04T14:08:23.207" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Regarding&#xA;&lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/900/when-how-should-i-ask-about-a-manuscripts-status-in-review/10443#10443&quot;&gt;this question on when to ask about a manuscript's status in review&lt;/a&gt;&#xA;I wonder (since it is happening to me): What does it mean when a paper is &quot;with editor&quot; for two months after a first review?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Waiting after a review" AnswerId="rtPtbV6AFHVqAhBKRbZMOQ==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-04T14:35:35.293" Text="Seems a bit too broad because it can mean a lot of things. It would help if you could be a little more specific. For example, you may specify which field the topic of your paper belongs to (e.g., it can be math, comp sci etc.) and how the first round review went (e.g., it may be conditionally accepted. Or maybe you're asked to revise the manuscript extensively.) Did you receive the decision letter after the first round and resubmit it? Or is it just the status has changed to &quot;with editor&quot; from &quot;under review&quot; or the like?/>
<comment QuestionId="Waiting after a review" AnswerId="rtPtbV6AFHVqAhBKRbZMOQ==" Author="5944" Date="2013-06-04T18:19:58.803" Text="Related. http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/900/when-how-should-i-ask-about-a-manuscripts-status-in-review/>
<comment QuestionId="Waiting after a review" AnswerId="rtPtbV6AFHVqAhBKRbZMOQ==" Author="7345" Date="2013-06-04T14:39:17.143" Text="&quot;Or maybe you're asked to revise the manuscript extensively&quot; That is!/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10444" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10444" Date="2013-08-28T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10444" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10444" Date="2013-08-29T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Waiting after a review" AnswerId="YXwflXErcktaSd6BOPGXLQ==" Author="2700" Date="2013-08-28T09:23:41.163" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;It most likely means that your manuscript is undergoing a second round of review, after you made revisions to it. In most fields, two months is not overly long time to wait for reviews, especially if you made large modifications to the manuscript, or if the editor is not sure what to do and asked for an additional referee’s opinion (or adjudicating referee, in some cases).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can, however, write a nice email to the editor enquiring about the status of your manuscript.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Waiting after a review" AnswerId="5BUUiHHGVxzYChQTPH3DHg==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-04T15:07:15.327" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;So, after the first round of review, you were asked to revise your manuscript extensively. And you made changes accordingly and resubmitted a revised version. Two months has passed since then, but it doesn't seem like the revised manuscript has been sent out for external review because the status of your submission you can see online hasn't been changed and is still &quot;with editor.&quot; (Edit: I know some journals use &quot;being handled by editor&quot; or something similar at any stage of the review process except when the manuscript is with the author. You're sure it wasn't &quot;with editor&quot; during the first round review, right?)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If that's the case, most likely it means the editor is having hard time finding referees for the second round or maybe simply taking their sweet time examining your resubmission. Or possibly they forgot about your submission so you need to remind them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't know what the norm is in your field. But if I were you, I'd send a short and polite email to the journal to ask what is up with your paper, probably after waiting a bit more. If it doesn't work, I'd send another polite email to someone else working for the journal. In any case, you should understand that the editor is a volunteer (unless you're submitting to a journal with fulltime editors like Nature, Science, PRL etc.), and sometimes it takes a while to handle your submission for various legitimate reasons. So be polite when asking what's going on.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Edit: And the best way to know if two months is too long is to ask experienced researchers in your field like your advisor if you're a student.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Waiting after a review" AnswerId="5BUUiHHGVxzYChQTPH3DHg==" Author="7345" Date="2013-06-04T16:07:28.377" Text="I'll observe your tips. Thank you./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10446" Date="2013-10-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10446" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10446" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Waiting after a review" AnswerId="h3/Lm9xFSEigZPsnI1e0ew==" Author="1010" Date="2013-06-04T14:32:58.477" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;There's no way to know for sure except to ask the editor.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you mean that the editor received the first review from a referee two months ago, it may be that the editor has not yet decided what to do with the paper, based on the review.  Another possibility is that the editor wants a second review, and has not yet found a referee for it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Waiting after a review" AnswerId="h3/Lm9xFSEigZPsnI1e0ew==" Author="7345" Date="2013-06-04T14:37:58.967" Text="The situation is that I sent a second version two months ago after a first referee's review. I'm sorry if I didn't express it correctly./>

</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10448	<question QuestionId="How do you comment on rapid improvement in a students performance" Title="How do you comment on rapid improvement in a students performance" Views="424" Tags="recommendation-letter" " AnswerId="2YkazJf9aHK09k3wsSL5ag==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-04T16:58:33.387" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;Sometimes, it can happen that a graduate student who is struggling on a project finally sees everything &quot;click,&quot; and becomes far more productive. It might be due to a change in attitude, an improved work ethic, serendipitous success, or some combination of all of the above.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In writing recommendations, how do you comment on the student's rapid turnaround, without making the previous state of the work (in which the student &lt;em&gt;was&lt;/em&gt; working, and clearly understood what needed to be done, but didn't have the results to show for it) seem like it was a weakness or liability &lt;em&gt;on the part of the student&lt;/em&gt;. Given how real signs of weakness can cause problems for people reviewing the letters, how do you call attention to the fact that the student underwent such a startling transformation, while acknowledging the previous struggles and not harming the student's chances?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How do you comment on rapid improvement in a students performance" AnswerId="2YkazJf9aHK09k3wsSL5ag==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-04T21:44:40.953" Text="_without making the previous state of the work...seem like it was a weakness or liability._ — Sorry?  It _was_ a weakness and a liability!  Recognizing and overcoming one's own weaknesses is a **strong** indicator of success. Why would you want to hide that?/>
<comment QuestionId="How do you comment on rapid improvement in a students performance" AnswerId="2YkazJf9aHK09k3wsSL5ag==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-05T08:46:28.057" Text="I want to convey that the issue was not the fault of the student's. But I want to avoid leaving the impression that the student wasn't working hard enough, which isn't the case./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-06-05T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-06-05T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-06-05T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-06-05T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-10-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-06-05T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10448" Date="2013-06-05T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="How do you comment on rapid improvement in a students performance" AnswerId="hz6bYdRTLy+IDKQFrrG3ww==" Author="4461" Date="2013-06-05T05:08:13.230" Score="12" Text="&lt;p&gt;I agree with JeffE's comment -- this is an opportunity to show fantastic improvement, which looks great in a letter.  If the improvement really was because of &quot;serendipitous success,&quot; it seems that it would be difficult to sustain, unless it happens that the groundbreaking work was so monumental that it is prize-worthy (and even then, &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/Louis_Pasteur&quot;&gt;chance favors only the prepared mind&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If I'm writing a positive letter (which is almost always the case--I'll try to convince a student that I'm not the correct person if I feel I won't be able to justify a strong letter), my goal is to convince the letter-reader that I'd hire/accept the person &lt;em&gt;now&lt;/em&gt;, and why.  Something like the following might fit this case:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;I have been particularly impressed by X's recent work on her project, &lt;em&gt;Nuclear Powered Time Travel via a Modified Consumer Vehicle&lt;/em&gt;.  Despite a frustrating set of circumstances that returned limited results in the early stages of the project, her hard work and persistence led to a breakthrough that she is currently preparing for submission to &lt;em&gt;The Twin Paradox Journal&lt;/em&gt;, and will undoubtedly lead to further successful results.  Specifically, she was finally able to properly shield the flux-capacitor plutonium containment compartment in her design, reducing temporal errors by 99% and leading to far greater box office returns.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If the student's previous attitude, or struggles don't put her in a particularly good light, don't include them explicitly.  Again, it goes back to &lt;em&gt;would I hire or accept the student now?&lt;/em&gt;  If you believe that by not including the specifics you're not being honest, then maybe you wouldn't feel comfortable with such a positive letter anyway.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10462" Date="2013-06-10T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10462" Date="2013-06-05T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10451	<question QuestionId="Is it advisable to upload theses to the arXiv" Title="Is it advisable to upload theses to the arXiv" Views="540" Tags="thesis,arxiv" " AnswerId="VbrKZowvTrZdVcUYZs++9Q==" Author="820" Date="2013-06-04T17:37:06.720" Score="12" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'm currently uploading my MRes thesis to my university website, but I have some doubts regarding the permanence of the link as it may change after I graduate. I do not have many illusions over who may want to read my thesis in the future, but I would like to have a link to give to people or to put on papers in the future without fear of the link breaking in the near/mid/far future. Additionally, I know that having it available in a place spiders are more likely to look makes it (marginally) more visible to web searches and thus more discoverable.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A &lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/find/all/1/all%3a+AND+PhD+thesis/0/1/0/all/0/1&quot;&gt;quick search&lt;/a&gt; turns up a good bunch of PhD theses, but it doesn't say how many there aren't very many &lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/find/all/1/all%3a+AND+MSc+thesis/0/1/0/all/0/1&quot;&gt;MSc&lt;/a&gt; or &lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/find/all/1/all%3a+AND+BSc+thesis/0/1/0/all/0/1&quot;&gt;BSc&lt;/a&gt; theses in there. My reading on this is that it is OK but by no means a standard practice.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Before I upload it though, I would like to know if there are reasons &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; to put it in such a public place. I am after all a bit of an arXiv fanatic and there may be factors I'm not considering. Any thoughts?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is it advisable to upload theses to the arXiv" AnswerId="VbrKZowvTrZdVcUYZs++9Q==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-04T18:24:47.963" Text="If your university is fine with it, I don't see any reason not to. Well-written Master/Ph.D. theses are very helpful when learning new topics just like good survey/tutorial articles./>
<comment QuestionId="Is it advisable to upload theses to the arXiv" AnswerId="VbrKZowvTrZdVcUYZs++9Q==" Author="6690" Date="2013-06-04T18:01:37.180" Text="I also debated over putting stuff there and then I read, that you are not able to delete/withdraw that publication anymore?!?/>
<comment QuestionId="Is it advisable to upload theses to the arXiv" AnswerId="VbrKZowvTrZdVcUYZs++9Q==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-04T21:41:23.347" Text="Speaking as an ArXiv moderator: **MSc theses are definitely welcome on the ArXiv!**  @T.F. is correct; once you publish something on the ArXiv, it's public forever.  (You can revise and even withdraw ArXiv papers, but older versions are still available if you know how to look.)  In that respect, posting to the ArXiv is no different from any other form of archival publication./>

<answer QuestionId="Is it advisable to upload theses to the arXiv" AnswerId="U/GXQeOJpy70Y23m9hrM7w==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-04T19:18:16.880" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;There doesn't seem to be any real restriction on publishing theses of any kind to arXiv. Therefore, whether you choose to do so is a decision that should be made between you and your advisor, taking into account any regulations your school may have. If your work has been funded by an external agency or company, you should also take their requirements under advisement.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, so long as your topic falls under arXiv's category guidelines, and there are no restrictions preventing you, there isn't much to lose by submitting the &lt;em&gt;final&lt;/em&gt; version of your thesis to a public repository. It would ensure far greater visibility for your thesis than if it's left on your university's website alone.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10452	<question QuestionId="Prolonging undergraduate school to do research" Title="Prolonging undergraduate school to do research" Views="186" Tags="application,research-undergraduate,computer-science" " AnswerId="UB0ILYdwg/KuLv1+JqLrcg==" Author="6618" Date="2013-06-04T18:29:48.077" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am an electrical engineering (communications) undergraduate student. But my main interest is physics ( and/or CS, esp. it's common fields with physics - &lt;em&gt;but it doesn't affect my question here&lt;/em&gt; ), and I want to pursue my graduate studies in physics or computer science. However for application, as an engineering student  I'm at a disadvantage as &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;I think my major is not considered &lt;em&gt;rigorous enough&lt;/em&gt; by people in those fields &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;I don't have much (official) coursework in those fields, although I have studied (and am studying) even more than is expected from physics majors&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;because of the time I've put in studying ( and more importantly, exploring different areas of) physics and computer science,  my GPA so far is not good in electrical engineering.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So with these circumstances, I think the best or maybe the only way is to continue my studies in physics (and/or related areas) more seriously to do more rather good quality research projects and this way, show my ability and qualification for graduate studies in physics (and/or CS).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But, doing so I'll need more time for these additional studies and projects, and  I think I have to stay one year more at undergraduate school (5 years). Is this considered a negative point in application for graduate school?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10452" Date="2013-06-05T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10452" Date="2013-07-12T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10452" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10452" Date="2013-07-13T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10452" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Prolonging undergraduate school to do research" AnswerId="c3p4UGp7BKFfi6B4Q6SW5g==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-04T19:24:03.183" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I think there are a lot of students who spend an extra year as an undergraduate, and I know of a number of very good students who have done so, and will almost certainly get into very good graduate programs.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, that said, I think the value of the extra year as an undergraduate depends largely on what you spend that year doing:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Will you be taking classes that will help your application to a physics program?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;How much research will you be doing, and how will it help your application? (Is it physics-related, or EE-related?)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;How strong is your GPA in your physics classes? (This won't make up for a weak GPA in EE classes, but it can at least partially mitigate it.)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;How much will it cost you to spend an extra year before starting graduate school?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As for rigor, I don't think there's as much stigma as you might think. There's far more overlap between fields now than there used to be, and engineers do things that used to be primarily in the province of physics, chemistry, and even mathematics. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10454" Date="2013-06-04T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10454" Date="2013-06-05T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Prolonging undergraduate school to do research" AnswerId="ADGgqQ/KBzhRl8XJxwpGOg==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-04T21:37:05.740" Score="3" Text="&lt;h2&gt;No.&lt;/h2&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Nobody cares how long you took to graduate.&lt;/strong&gt;  There is no advantage to graduating early, and there is no disadvantage to graduating late.  It is &lt;em&gt;extremely&lt;/em&gt; common for students to take more than four years to get an undergraduate degree, especially if they change majors, as you are effectively doing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10456" Date="2013-12-18T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10458	<question QuestionId="A comprehensive question about personal statement" Title="A comprehensive question about personal statement" Views="1142" Tags="graduate-school,graduate-admissions,application" " AnswerId="M14qGndjuw1CA6uYecgqsA==" Author="7349" Date="2013-06-05T02:35:07.437" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have some questions regarding my personal statement for graduate school in math. I hope this is not the wrong place to ask. My question(s) are comprehensive and long, as the title suggests, thus I have numbered and sub-numbered the questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note that these questions are targeted at schools that do not allow me to upload a CV otherwise I think half of these questions would go away.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Courses&lt;/strong&gt;  &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;1a) Is it silly or a waste of space to talk about your math background? Or should I assume the graduate committee already has this? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;1b) Some schools I have checked out actually asked me to list out all my junior/senior courses along with their books, I guess for those schools I don’t need to? What about those who do not?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;1c) Should I write or mention courses I have self-studied? Or is this completely irrelevant to them? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;1d) Should I also bother explaining one W and one ‘bad’ mark that happened in the summer?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;1e) Should I mention my math department is understaffed and I tried to take as many “hard” classes as possible? How understaffed? We have only at most four math classes at the senior level every year. We are so small that most junior/senior classes stop only at the introductory level. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example, we only have: introductory PDE, introductory Number Theory, introductory Algebra, and Topology does not even exist at my university. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Very rarely do we get continuations to those courses. In comparison with all the other areas, we have quite a lot of Analysis courses, but all of them are focused in Optimization (excluding Real Analysis, we usually have one to two Analysis classes).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We have no Calculus of Variation, no Measure Theory, almost nothing. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;FYI, I had to go out my way to bug a professor to request an extra Analysis course this year to the unit head and even then I am short on Math classes next year.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;TA experience&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;2a) Should I talk about this? How will they even verify me? Because I have done some things that most TA don’t do at my university – writing exam solutions. The prof I TA’d for left everything for me to do, except the teaching and actually writing the midterms/finals. I never had a class with him, so I am not so sure about asking him to write a letter for me.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;2b) I also TA’d for another prof at another campus during one summer term(same university, but different Math department), should I mention this? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;EDIT&lt;/strong&gt;: &lt;strong&gt;I can provide a link of my exam solutions through the prof's site. I think he will give me permission, should I include this?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;3) &lt;strong&gt;Research Experience&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have &lt;em&gt;very very&lt;/em&gt; little experience, so much that I could probably only write one or two short sentences about it. I also have no publication, but I think the prof I worked for can&lt;br&gt;&#xA;confirm that I did do research under him. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;By the way, the “research experience” I had was a problem the prof had written by hand on a math paper and he asked me to answer the question he posed. It was not an analytic problem, it was coding, graphing, and writing a report. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;4) &lt;strong&gt;Area of Interest.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;4a) I already know my area of interest, I am wondering if it is a good idea to write why I got interested in the first place or is this completely irrelevant to the graduate committee? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My reasons are rather absurd, I am going into my desired area because of a textbook writer and the textbook I read by him isn’t even the area I was interested in, although the writer did write a book in the subject and I was simply in love with his style of writing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I later found out the writer’s background and plus some neat stuff I read on the Internet sealed the deal for me. If people think this reason isn’t silly or “cliché” (e.g. “I liked puzzles when I was young”), then please tell me.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;4b) Also one major problem is that I can’t talk too deeply about my area of interest. i can mention specific subfields, but that's about it. For instance, if I liked Number Theory, I could mention &quot;Analytic Number Theory&quot; and the &quot;Riemann Zeta&quot; or if I liked Differential Geometry/PDE, I could mention &quot;Geometric Analysis&quot;. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So would it be better to omit the details if I can't comment too much on the details of the subject and simply write &quot;Number Theory&quot;? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;5) &lt;strong&gt;Thesis Advisor&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I can find people and mention their names easily on my personal statement. I am just curious if I should narrow it down to only ONE person? Does it look bad that I am just listing out the people whom I want to work with instead of writing down just one name?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;6) &lt;strong&gt;Scholarships/Award&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have never liked the word 'Award', so i am going to use 'Scholarship'. Do I need to mention about a scholarship I got from a professor? Again, how can I be verified for this? I think I could ask the prof who gave it to me (whom I did reasearch for) to mention/confirm this?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;7) &lt;strong&gt;Skills&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;How much will it add to my application if I tell them I can use LaTeX (honor's thesis not required for honors degree at my university. I asked one of my profs why and even he doesn't know.), high proficiency with Mathematica, Maple, Matlab, etc...? I was going to add Photoshop, but then I realize how pointless and irrelevant that is. I can also use Python, but since I am postponed my 1st year computer science requirements till my last year I do not think they will buy this. Also my school teaches Java.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thank you very much for reading and taking this time to read this ridiculously long question(s)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;EDIT CLARIFICATION:&lt;/strong&gt; I am applying to US/Canadian universities&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="A comprehensive question about personal statement" AnswerId="cZKTJp+JsLRMO+fF1tzbUA==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-05T12:53:27.547" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Responding to questions approximately in order:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is not a waste of space to talk about your mathematics background. Mere course titles tell almost nothing, so it's good to explain more. Telling the &lt;em&gt;authors&lt;/em&gt; of the texts used explain a lot to experienced mathematicians.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Especially if your school has a relatively weak program, and even if not, telling what self-study you've done is very important. It is all the more important as an indicator that you take initiative, are driven by curiosity about mathematics, independent of grades and structured programs.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Explaining briefly that you've had TA experience is a small plus, because almost all grad students in math are supported by TA work, so knowing in advance that you can communicate will ease the minds of admissions committee members.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Despite the contemporary pretense that undergrads &quot;do research&quot; between their junior and senior years, it is very rare that any sort of genuine research occurs. Sometimes, but rarely. After all, if research only takes 8-10 weeks in the summer, with almost no prior background, why does a PhD takes years? :)  (There &lt;em&gt;is&lt;/em&gt; a good purpose served by the summer programs, though, of giving undergrads the idea that mathematics is not confined to a classroom and textbooks, as well as creating social connections with other undergrads seriously interested in math. But these situations don't really produce cutting-edge research.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;About &quot;specific interests&quot;: of course it is vastly better to have tentative, ill-formed, and inevitably ill-informed, &quot;interests&quot;, rather than &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt;. :)  I'd encourage you to tell how these interests arose, giving the admissions committee some insight into your approach to mathematics.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It's good to mention scholarships. People will not be so skeptical that you need to document it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Computing skills are a positive, and deserve a brief mention. Again, there is little need to offer &quot;proof&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In summary, it is a mistake to think that one's transcript explains what the admissions committee wants to hear or needs to know to make a reasonable decision. An informative personal statement makes a huge difference, especially in communicating your motivations and learning outside classrooms. Also, letters of recommendation from mathematicians well-acquainted with you, from contexts of relatively advanced mathematics (rather than elementary) are very important to give an idea of how well you'd fare with more advanced/sophisticated work. (After all, many people do well-enough in undergrad material, but find that graduate-level mathematics has a slightly different nature... of less interest...)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="A comprehensive question about personal statement" AnswerId="cZKTJp+JsLRMO+fF1tzbUA==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-06T12:30:16.587" Text="@sidht, these questions are completely reasonable. I have heard them many times, yes, but how could anyone who hasn't been through the system guess how it works? It is hard to guess the working of a machine one has never seen, etc./>

Those are skills that will be useful for graduate school./>

<answer QuestionId="A comprehensive question about personal statement" AnswerId="4ZSRrNcUti0bS0Mgr6SR/g==" Author="7354" Date="2013-06-05T09:00:37.057" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;Some ideas on your statements/questions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(1a)-(1b)-(1c): It seems to be your undergraduate university is not a very well known one and/or even not considered strong in mathematics. Graduate schools may be wanting to be sure you covered what they consider necessary as undergraduate mathematics. Upon being asked I'd consider sending along a short syllabus of the courses you took. I'm almost sure your university must have these things.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(1d)-(1e) Don't even mess with this unless specifically asked, which I think it's unlikely to happen.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The lack of any topology/measure theory (and perhaps more) courses in your university (or college...?) is a rather serious one, imo, and it may point, again, at some lack of elementary basis most mathematics depts. are supposed to have.&#xA;in fact, I think it is likely some universities could require from you to complete several courses before they considere you as an actual candidate for graduate school in mathematics...are you sure that what you studied in that school of yours was &quot;mathematics&quot;? Perhaps it was something like &quot;applied mathematics&quot;?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't think serious graduate schools require TA from undergraduates. In fact, mentioning you TA'd some course before being a graduate could be considered as (another) sign of a low mathematics level in your school.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To require research? From an undergraduate? I don't think there's such a university. What could be required, imo, is good skills to &quot;hunt&quot; for books, papers, etc. in a mathematics library and, in our days, perhaps also in the web.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;No need to dwell a lot with your area of interest. Perhaps mentioning some of the wide areas (analysis, topology, algebra) could be enough, though imo most decent graduate schools require from graduate students to take two or more rather hefty, year-long course in some of these areas, and only &lt;em&gt;later&lt;/em&gt; you begin to drift towards your love...&#xA;The same applies, imo, for thesis advisor.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please do mention any scholarship-award you got that's connected to your studies. This may be rather important.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;About skills: I don't think anybody will really care about it. Most probably schools will be more interested in finding out about your seriousness, love for the subject, responsibility, etc.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Good luck!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

Is it OK to do so? Do I have to ask the permission from the administrator of the website? And does he or she have rights to forbid my academic use? Thank you.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Is it legalethical to use data grabbed from a Stack Exchange site in a paper" AnswerId="PEMlzwIbq02a3fyq4fDImA==" Author="5944" Date="2013-06-05T15:31:24.540" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;Your University may have an Institutional Review Board (IRB) that reviews how you conduct experiments. This board may be known by various names (Ethics Committee, Experiment Review Board, Human Subjects Research, etc.) but they are generally the ones that you would go to to consult about whether what you are doing is within the scope of ethical behavior and good treatment of human subjects data.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As StackOverflow and associated StackExchange repository data is available under Creative Commons Attribution Share-Alike (as @piotr_migdal linked above) and is publicly available, your IRB will probably tell you, &quot;It's fine&quot; and not require review. However, it depends on the IRB and the institution and the nature of the data.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are entire research disciplines built on scraping web sites, software repositories, and social media, so don't feel bad for doing it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is it legalethical to use data grabbed from a Stack Exchange site in a paper" AnswerId="PEMlzwIbq02a3fyq4fDImA==" Author="118" Date="2013-06-12T23:07:13.233" Text="+1 for IRB approval. It's fairly easy to make the &quot;seatbelt study&quot; argument and say that something posted to a site like StackExchange is intended to be publicly viewable. But it never hurts to have IRB approval, and your university may indeed require it (mine does for all research - I have an IRB approval form for a purely simulation study around here somewhere)./>

<answer QuestionId="Is it legalethical to use data grabbed from a Stack Exchange site in a paper" AnswerId="3JntVWQZw3B5ErO4xcbK8g==" Author="1429" Date="2013-06-05T04:03:48.083" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;I believe you can do it with StackOverflow data, as long as you cite/attribute it properly. &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2009/06/stack-overflow-creative-commons-data-dump/&quot;&gt;This&lt;/a&gt; article affirms it. However, I do not know whether this can be extended to the rest of StackExchange. A question to the mods or to the support team might help you clarify.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is it legalethical to use data grabbed from a Stack Exchange site in a paper" AnswerId="3JntVWQZw3B5ErO4xcbK8g==" Author="1429" Date="2013-06-05T04:49:32.477" Text="This depends on the privacy policy of the particular website. There are ways to get around it. You can email the mods of the  websites in question and if you are a credible researcher, often they will give you permission to use their data, often in a de-identified dataset format./>

<answer QuestionId="Is it legalethical to use data grabbed from a Stack Exchange site in a paper" AnswerId="AuonxWy4LhAhOun/YEb2Vw==" Author="1010" Date="2013-06-05T04:10:00.043" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;Disclaimer: I am not a lawyer.  If you are seriously concerned about this issue, you should consult one; your institution probably has intellectual property lawyers on staff.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is a general principle that &quot;you can't copyright facts&quot;.  Wherever you get your data set, you probably can  legally publish any analysis of that data, without requiring anyone's permission.   However, you may not be able to legally reproduce the data itself.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Of course, by standard academic ethics, you must properly cite and attribute the source of the data.    And if you can't guarantee that the data will remain accessible, it could affect the reproducibility of your results and hence the quality of your paper.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is it legalethical to use data grabbed from a Stack Exchange site in a paper" AnswerId="AuonxWy4LhAhOun/YEb2Vw==" Author="1010" Date="2013-06-05T12:25:19.013" Text="@PiotrMigdal: Before your edit to the question's title, I read it as asking about data from Internet sources in general, not just SE./>

But an answer by @Shion interprets it as SE-specific. And anyway, I wrote a comment, it is not a downvote./>
<comment QuestionId="Is it legalethical to use data grabbed from a Stack Exchange site in a paper" AnswerId="AuonxWy4LhAhOun/YEb2Vw==" Author="49" Date="2013-06-05T10:00:15.137" Text="SE license all user content under [CC SA](http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/), so here there is no problem with copyright./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10467	<question QuestionId="What is the difference between review paper and research paper" Title="What is the difference between review paper and research paper" Views="2766" Tags="research,publications,journals,thesis,paper-submission" " AnswerId="Z+xTtColRs5j9cCHKjXRug==" Author="6912" Date="2013-06-05T16:30:33.850" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have been working on a paper, so it is called review works.&#xA;After reviewing the work how it will add on my academic research profile? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;When I will apply for MS or PHD admission, will it count as publication?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10467" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10467" Date="2014-02-15T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10467" Date="2013-06-05T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10467" Date="2013-06-07T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10467" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="What is the difference between review paper and research paper" AnswerId="bY3wOHJWvBk3GQcYXXtasA==" Author="1429" Date="2013-06-05T16:55:06.387" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;limited experience&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; regarding since I am still a graduate student but from what I understand, a review paper is also a research paper. However, unlike a piece of research, where you study the existing literature, develop research questions and hypotheses, collect data, run experiments/analysis and make inferences which accept or reject your hypotheses, a review article is a summarization and collation of existing articles in a given, specific research topic.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There has been some semi-formal writings on this already namely, &lt;a href=&quot;http://scientopia.org/blogs/genrepair/2011/02/01/do-you-really-count-a-review-article-as-a-publication/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v489/n7415/full/489177a.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt;. The consensus, so far, seems to be that review articles make fine additions to your publication record but &lt;em&gt;not as fine as&lt;/em&gt; articles where you actually did your own research.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10468" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10468" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="What is the difference between review paper and research paper" AnswerId="pmZUpdCI7EBaKO0iES7tTg==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-06T14:27:08.293" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;One important distinction should be made between papers in the humanities and the sciences. In the sciences, it would be much more important to have &quot;original research&quot; papers where new ground is broken. In the humanities, by contrast, the act of studying the existing literature and critically evaluating it may, in and of itself, be considered an act of research. (Similarly, in medicine, &quot;meta-studies&quot; in which the reports of various experiments are synthesized to produce overall results and recommendations may also be considered very important, although they augment direct clinical research, rather than substitute for it.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10488" Date="2014-01-07T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10488" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10488" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="What is the difference between review paper and research paper" AnswerId="LT4WL49nKi3prKeTXoGSKg==" Author="5944" Date="2013-06-05T18:19:52.590" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;A review paper is likely also known as a &quot;survey paper&quot;, where you read (i.e. survey) related works in the field and then comment on them. Usually, a review paper should be able to contribute a small amount of knowledge in its own right to the field by providing a taxonomy of work.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another type of paper that reviews extensively related work but isn't actually a review paper is a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0950584910000467&quot;&gt;&quot;systematic review paper&quot;&lt;/a&gt; in which you usually ask a meta-question about the field.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If it appears in a refereed, peer-reviewed journal, then yes, it is a publication. In fact, if done well, these works can often have pretty high impact and can be cited very frequently. However, as already noted, since they don't usually involve substantial original research they need to be augmented with traditional research papers. If a graduate student has only survey papers or systematic review papers, I'd wonder as a search committee reviewer if this student did nothing but read related work rather than working on research.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;With respect to MS or PhD applications, I'd think that the fact that you have a publication at all is already a bonus point for you. Most students who apply to these programs don't have publications.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10469" Date="2014-01-07T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10469" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10469" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10469" Date="2014-02-15T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10469" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10469" Date="2013-06-07T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10469" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10470	<question QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" Title="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" Views="519" Tags="research,publications,citations,research-undergraduate" " AnswerId="g1W5a5C1NcYk8a/0xbDIlQ==" Author="541" Date="2013-06-05T21:19:21.180" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;I've just written my first mathematical research paper. It proves some new results, which while not ground-breaking are (according to an expert in the field) at least somewhat interesting and surprising. At the moment however, I spend more of the paper developing the background material (giving standard definitions and constructions, proving standard lemmas) than proving the main theorems. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is this a problem? The way I see it, there are several arguments for and against:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;For:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;The background material is &quot;standard&quot; in the sense that anyone who works on this class of problems would know the definitions or results in some form. However, this is at most a few hundred people, while if I include the background material my paper should be comprehensible to an advanced undergraduate.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Some of the background results are part of the folklore of the field, and I've never been able to find a proof of them in literature. While they are believable and not hard to prove, I feel someone should bother doing it. More selfishly, this is one more reason for people to cite my paper.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;I don't know of any one reference which states &lt;em&gt;all&lt;/em&gt; the background material I need, so if I don't include it my readers have to chase down multiple sources and I have to use conflicting notations.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Against:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;It may be annoying to an expert in the field, although they could skip much of it and mainly refer to the background section for notation.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;It makes the paper longer, although even with the background the paper is not long (13 pages).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;From what I've heard, it is generally considered bad practice to restate definitions and constructions states elsewhere and to reprove theorems available in literature. In part this is because it gives the impression that I haven't read the literature. This is exacerbated by the fact that I only cite ~5 previous works, mostly for further reading or alternative presentations of some of the background.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'd like advice on this from someone with experience writing such papers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" AnswerId="g1W5a5C1NcYk8a/0xbDIlQ==" Author="946" Date="2013-06-07T19:01:26.303" Text="There are many reasonable answers below, I just want to stress a few principles: clearly separate the background from the new stuff; clearly and plainly indicate that what is not new is not new, and why you include it; especially for proofs of well-known lemmas, only include them if you cannot find a reference after trying at least twice to find one from MR or ZB databases (but in any case, include the precise needed statements). Inside these guidelines, you should be ok whatever choice you make./>
<comment QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" AnswerId="g1W5a5C1NcYk8a/0xbDIlQ==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-06T00:19:00.657" Text="I wonder if this might be better suited for MathOverflow./>

<answer QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" AnswerId="n0QQ2fMiHREEd9te1f8rUg==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-06T04:24:59.033" Score="16" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'd recommend putting in as much explanation, context, and background as you reasonably can.  In principle you could certainly put in too much, but in practice I don't think I've ever seen a mathematics paper I thought actually did have too much.  If you structure your writing so experts can easily skim things they already know, then I don't see why extra explanation should trouble anyone.  Tradition requires being concise, but that tradition was based on the economics of publishing.  Space in printed journals used to be a scarce resource, and if you spent it on unnecessary exposition you were keeping someone else from publishing at all.  Publishing still isn't free (and readers have only so much patience, as well), so you shouldn't include enormous amounts of unnecessary background, but traditional writing styles should be adjusted to account for the greater availability of space.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It's possible that a referee or editor will object that they don't like your style.  You may be able to resist making any changes (it depends on how exciting your paper is and how high your own status is within the community), and if you do make changes you can still keep a lot of explanation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If necessary, it's worth having two versions as Paul Garrett suggests.  If you do, then you should make it very clear which is which and what the differences are, to avoid serious confusion if someone refers to the paper without realizing they need to specify which version.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;The background material is &quot;standard&quot; in the sense that anyone who works on this class of problems would know the definitions or results in some form. However, this is at most a few hundred people, while if I include the background material my paper should be comprehensible to an advanced undergraduate.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One reason to be generous with explanation is that it's easy to overestimate how much people know.  Aiming at advanced undergrads is a good way to make sure grad students really can read the paper.  If you aim at experts, you may write a paper only your own collaborators can comfortably read.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Some of the background results are part of the folklore of the field, and I've never been able to find a proof of them in literature. While they are believable and not hard to prove, I feel someone should bother doing it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is a great reason to include a proof, although it's important to consult with experts to confirm that there really isn't an accessible proof in the literature.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;It makes the paper longer, although even with the background the paper is not long (13 pages).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You should make sure it doesn't look like padding, say with just a few pages of original content among the 13 pages.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;From what I've heard, it is generally considered bad practice to restate definitions and constructions states elsewhere and to reprove theorems available in literature. In part this is because it gives the impression that I haven't read the literature.  This is exacerbated by the fact that I only cite ~5 previous works, mostly for further reading or alternative presentations of some of the background.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This does seem like a worry, and five references is not very many, even for a 13-page paper.  You might not strictly need any more, but I'd recommend tracking down additional references for background.  As a general rule it's best to cite generously, giving plenty of credit to other authors and offering many resources to readers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Regarding giving the impression that you haven't read the literature, it's important to be clear about what's background from the literature (with a citation), what's folklore, and what's your own contribution.  If you reprove something you say is known but don't give a citation for, it can look like you were too lazy to track it down.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">
