<answer QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" AnswerId="CarpAWgcF2xJ1xJ9LjYPmg==" Author="346" Date="2013-06-05T21:29:36.170" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;It's not entirely clear whether the background material is just background, or is needed as scaffolding for the results you prove. Also, if certain lemmas are &quot;standard&quot; why are you proving them ? surely there's some text or other paper that proves these lemmas, and which you can cite ? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In general, in a paper you provide the scaffolding needed to prove your results. It's not necessary to provide other atmospherics unless its part of a larger discussion of related work. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" AnswerId="CarpAWgcF2xJ1xJ9LjYPmg==" Author="541" Date="2013-06-05T22:28:20.660" Text="I've considered adding an appendix. Also, not including any background material is the difference between an advanced undergrad being able to understand the paper, and only someone who has worked on irrational billiards being able to understand it./>
<comment QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" AnswerId="CarpAWgcF2xJ1xJ9LjYPmg==" Author="541" Date="2013-06-05T21:35:45.387" Text="Most of it is necessary for the theorems I prove. Regarding the results being standard, as I stated in the first point for including the background: The background material is &quot;standard&quot; in the sense that anyone who works on this class of problems would know the definitions or results in some form. However, this is at most a few hundred people, while if I include the background material my paper should be comprehensible to an advanced undergraduate./>
<comment QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" AnswerId="CarpAWgcF2xJ1xJ9LjYPmg==" Author="541" Date="2013-06-05T21:49:36.153" Text="And as I said, some of the lemmas are widely-known but I've yet to find anyone who knows where to find a proof./>
<comment QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" AnswerId="CarpAWgcF2xJ1xJ9LjYPmg==" Author="346" Date="2013-06-05T22:15:58.637" Text="My personal preference would in this case to state the lemmas without proof (stating that they're &quot;folklore&quot;, and then add proofs in an appendix &quot;for completeness&quot;. As for the background material, @paul makes the correct point that unfortunately or otherwise, you're not expected to cater to an &quot;advanced undergraduate&quot; audience in a formal paper./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10471" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10471" Date="2013-06-05T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" AnswerId="+mcBSA5+QXM+AYrlrLuIWQ==" Author="4511" Date="2013-06-05T23:38:21.897" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;If there are proofs in the literature for some of your background materials, it is better you do not prove them in your paper unless your proofs are much simpler or they use a method which will be used again in your other proofs (I have seen both instances in papers written by well known mathematicians). However if you cannot find a proof for some of the easy (or well known) results in the literature, it is a great help for your readers to add your proofs. About introducing your notation and/or definitions, you can be even more generous to your readers. Although there is a downside for including lots of backgrounds, not including some of them can delay the referee process of your paper. Do not hesitate to cite more references if they help to find some of the background materials. And finally, I suggest you devote some paragraphs to explain the motivation of your work. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Good luck with your paper!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" AnswerId="A9AS86TwZeHHI6jaBiVxvA==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-05T21:51:06.733" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;As you rightly perceive, there are conflicting desiderata for &quot;formal papers&quot;. The main tradition for refereed-journal publications is to assume one is writing for the experts, not for anyone who'd need much background or context. Yes, this makes reading such papers needlessly difficult for non-experts. Yes, the necessary background is likely scattered among several prior papers, and some occurs &quot;nowhere&quot;, in the sense of being apocryphal... lost in the mists of time? :)&#xA;Nevertheless, the highest-status refereed journals would probably want more-discursive broader explanations edited out... and the referees and editors might interpret your inclusion of such things as &quot;amateurish&quot; (&quot;It's just not done...&quot;), to your detriment.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But the expectations or standards of refereed-journals is certainly not the only criterion, and is manifestly antithetical to the obviously desirable outcome of wider dissemination of ideas, collection and organization of otherwise-chaotic literature, and so on. Some people will tell you that somehow it's not ok to &quot;mix&quot; &quot;research&quot; and &quot;exposition&quot;... but this is silly, even if traditional. But, then, given the traditional predilection of refereed-journals, if you want a more discursive version of your write-up, you may have to reconcile yourself to having two versions, one for referees, one for exposition/wider-dissemination.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The for-referees version should probably &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; cite the discursive version, but, instead, do the quasi-unhelpful bit of citing the disparate standard sources. The discursive version could cite the for-referees version, as well as the standard sources, and still include your own updated presentation, bringing apocrypha to the light of day, and so on.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But, I fear no single refereed-journal-publishable version could meet the nicer-exposition requirements you (completely reasonably) would like to impose.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" AnswerId="A9AS86TwZeHHI6jaBiVxvA==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-05T22:17:42.800" Text="Sure, arXiv is one reasonable venue for wider dissemination of a more discursive version, if you don't have a personal web-page that's well-known and that'll be stable./>
<comment QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" AnswerId="A9AS86TwZeHHI6jaBiVxvA==" Author="541" Date="2013-06-05T22:07:51.087" Text="How would the version for wider dissemination be disseminated? Through the arXiv?/>
<comment QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" AnswerId="A9AS86TwZeHHI6jaBiVxvA==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-06T00:20:33.490" Text="_to your detriment_ — And the journal's./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10472" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10472" Date="2013-06-05T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How much background material should a mathematical research paper include" AnswerId="qY+qA8NWrvgobcal9xPR0w==" Author="7389" Date="2013-06-09T17:39:28.803" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;One factor to add is that in many mathematics papers, there are many different definitions and notations for a subject. Some of these approaches may make your results seem more or less natural. Even someone who is familiar with the subject may become confused by the way in which you present things.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One good reason for a background section is so that you can &quot;set the scene&quot; using the presentation that you think is best. Sometimes just setting things up in a coherent way is more valuable than the new results themselves.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10474	<question QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" Title="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" Views="3409" Tags="publishing,journals,conference,peer-review,ethics" " AnswerId="7wxEjMdbce3IMhjveCxXDQ==" Author="2823" Date="2013-06-06T04:05:21.007" Score="21" Text="&lt;p&gt;I recently tried submitting a paper to a Journal. The submission process mandatory required suggesting three reviewers. Is it a norm in Journal submissions ? If yes, how should one choose reviewers since I do not personally know any experts in the field ? I have been submitting papers to conferences and never found such conditions there.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="7wxEjMdbce3IMhjveCxXDQ==" Author="411" Date="2013-06-06T12:54:17.543" Text="Related: http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/2695/having-preferred-and-non-preferred-reviewers-in-journal-submissions/>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="7wxEjMdbce3IMhjveCxXDQ==" Author="4125" Date="2013-06-11T17:25:03.203" Text="I know coming across at least one journal that used suggested reviewers as a benchmark of you knowing your field. They explicitly stated that, if they think your suggested reviewers are not the best possible experts to review your paper, it will be rejected without review./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="7wxEjMdbce3IMhjveCxXDQ==" Author="739" Date="2013-06-06T14:59:46.527" Text="You would need to find the word of mouth evidence of how the editors of this particular journal use this information. Some editors, being lazybones/busy people, just grab these names and send the paper out to them. Others assume that you provide the list of the easy-going people who will likely endorse your paper for non-existent merits, and never send requests to these people. There may be a continuum between these two positions, but that's what I often hear regarding how these suggestions are being utilized./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="7wxEjMdbce3IMhjveCxXDQ==" Author="10094" Date="2014-01-15T21:48:02.710" Text="@ThomasH Oh god. Please say you're making this up./>

<answer QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="YI6wWt11MEgMTb2lNSeKxg==" Author="4394" Date="2013-06-06T12:14:02.327" Score="16" Text="&lt;p&gt;Being editor of a journal where authors can provide preferred and non-preferred reviewers, I can provide some &quot;inside&quot; thoughts on the subject based on what has happened in &quot;my&quot; journal. Note that it is possible to suggest names for review but also provide names which are not preferred. The latter can be because of a scientific disagreement, personal issues or whatever. Such suggestions appear but not often and we usually follow the suggestions (not that we have to!). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When it comes to the preferred or suggested reviewers, I have been tempted to use such reviewers on occasion when it has been hard to identify reviewers directly. Sometimes because the topic is local and where it would make sense to have local input. In these cases, I cannot remember a single reasonable review that has come out of such reviewers. This can be for several reasons but most often the review is a close colleague who might have an incentive to help the author. In some cases the preferred names have been very senior scientists who, I am afraid, has lost touch with the subject and provide poor and in some cases almost non-existent reviews. Out of all immediate &quot;Accept&quot; review recommendations I get, the vast majority have come from these reviewers. So, I not longer trust these names and avoid them at all costs unless I personally know or know of the reviewer and his or her good reputation. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In addition to what I just describe, I also must state that it is often the weakest manuscripts that have listed several suggestions. This can be identified by the disparate review results, sometimes one accept (by the suggested reviewer) and one reject. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now, in principle, there is nothing wrong with suggesting reviewers, I have done so myself when being requested. I have then as a principle gone for established and well renowned names in the community. The problem lies in suggesting names for a purpose other than to get a fair and objective review.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is clear that the system can and is abused and since I became Editor-in-Chief, I have come to rely less and less on these suggestions and now mostly look upon them with suspicion and make selections from my own understanding of the field and investigations into the subject literature. The best suggestion, I can provide is to not avoid mentioning names but pick names that in your opinion can provide good constructive critique on your work (and not just favorable).  A note on why you have selected names as preferred or non-preferred would greatly help as well since it puts your choice in a perspective.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="YI6wWt11MEgMTb2lNSeKxg==" Author="4394" Date="2013-06-06T13:14:40.503" Text="Yes @YuichiroFujiwara, if it was only up to me to decide but it is not. That said, all such problems is subject to review by the editors to possibly improve on *Instructions for Authors* so hopefully improvements can still be made. I am not, however, sure that it is a disservice to not go along with suggestions, they are, after all, just suggestions. That doesn't meaa the names cannot be useful in other cases down the line./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="YI6wWt11MEgMTb2lNSeKxg==" Author="7075" Date="2013-06-06T13:42:40.030" Text="@Dikran I'll delete my comments too. Sorry for my wording. It was surely inappropriate.../>

I see the ethics in this as an important issue. The system with reviewers could be fine but abuse, to whatever extent it exists has negative repercussions./>

<answer QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="9wlzJiw0kqsqmzkbdOI1hw==" Author="2827" Date="2013-06-06T11:21:51.067" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;In my opinion, this is a practice that should be strongly discouraged.  While on average reviewers selected by the author give fair, high quality reviews, that doesn't mean that the unscrupulous can't exploit this opportunity to select reviewers that share opinions that are far from the scientific mainstream in order to get dubious arguments into the peer-reviewed literature.  This is especially the case where the paper is on a contentious topic that is only tangentially relevant to the journal, so the action editor may not be able to easily find adequate reviewers from within their own field.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As an example, their are numerous papers published on climate related issues in energy, astronomy or general physics journals, which can easily be shown to be fundamentally flawed.  Where the journal asks for the author to recommend reviewers, it does raise the question of how much this contributed to the evident failure of the review process.  It seems to me to be better to avoid the problem ever arising.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Ultimately if the action editors cannot identify satisfactory reviewers by themselves, the work probably doesn't belong in the journal in the first place.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Being able to specify people who &lt;em&gt;shouldn't&lt;/em&gt; be used as reviewers is, of course, another matter entirely.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To answer the question directly, suggests the names of reviewers that you consider to have the required expertise in your field and who can give you a rigorous, but constructive review.  Don't choose people you know personally if there is someone equally well qualified that you don't know.  I recall reading that when you receive reviews you are getting advice for free from experts who's time you couldn't afford to buy, so why not attempt to get the most value from it as you possibly can?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="9wlzJiw0kqsqmzkbdOI1hw==" Author="2827" Date="2013-06-06T12:12:01.643" Text="I know it is just a suggestion, but it is a suggestion that should not be necessary if the journal is appropriate and the action editors sufficiently familiar with the field.  As it can lead to failures of the review process, the costs outweigh the benefits in my opinion (having wasted/spent time writing a few comments papers, one of which was for a journal that required the author to specify candidate reviewers)./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="9wlzJiw0kqsqmzkbdOI1hw==" Author="3890" Date="2013-06-06T11:45:00.277" Text="It's just a suggestion. If the editor thinks that suggested reviewers are not experts, she will not consult them. Plus she should always select additional reviewers. For example, the policy of BioMed Central is to solicit 6 reviews per paper, but the authors are asked to suggest only 4. And those suggested must not be from the same institution nor coauthors./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="9wlzJiw0kqsqmzkbdOI1hw==" Author="2827" Date="2013-06-06T15:11:36.330" Text="And if the author does not disclose or recognise the conflicts of interest?  For example, there are several scientists that have tried to establish that the rise in atmospheric CO2 is a natural phenomenon and nothing to do with fossil fuel emissions (which is easily shown to be incorrect).  Would it be a conflict of interest for this small group of scientists to write each others names down on lists of suggested reviewers, they may not have even actually met each other.  It is not clear to me that there is any breach of ethics there./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="9wlzJiw0kqsqmzkbdOI1hw==" Author="739" Date="2013-06-06T14:57:40.330" Text="The journals that require a list of suggested and/or undesirable reviewers are usually smart enough to put a disclaimer to disclose the conflicts of interests, if any, concerning these reviewers./>

<answer QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="ulhOXSa/lq8fZb2hqtJRPA==" Author="3890" Date="2013-06-06T06:56:42.497" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;Some journals explicitly ask about suggestions for reviewers with a submission, some will consider any suggestions that you make in the cover letter, and others (probably) will just ignore any such suggestion.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are in fact scientific studies about the comparison between reviewers suggested by the authors, and those selected by the editor, for example &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.biomedcentral.com/1741-7015/4/13/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;this article in BMC Medicine&lt;/a&gt;. The overall conclusion seems to be that reviewers suggested by authors provide reviews of equal quality than those selected by the editor. While they are more likely to suggest acceptance in the initial review, at later stages these suggestions seem to equalize. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As an author, you should have a high interest in getting over that initial review, and if you do it well, suggesting reviewers is a very good opportunity for that. I'd always suggest to make use of such an opportunity, since you probably can judge best which potential reviewers &lt;strong&gt;will look favorably&lt;/strong&gt; at your paper. And that's of course what you want.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you know an expert personally, that's usually a good option. It has to be handled with care though. When you're too close to a suggested reviewer, the editor will give significantly less weight to the recommendation of that reviewer if he knows about personal ties. But if you go to conferences and talk to people about your research, you could suggest them as reviewers afterwards if they have similar interests. Or look at your reference list, as suggested in the answer by Anthony Labarre.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="ulhOXSa/lq8fZb2hqtJRPA==" Author="2827" Date="2014-01-23T13:59:11.967" Text="I work in machine learning/statistics where there is a very good example of approach A (frequentism) and approach B (Bayesianism).  I am a Bayesian, but I would never reject a statistics paper for not being Bayesian, and for all the banter that goes on I very much doubt there is any other statistician that would.  As long as it is a sound solution to the problem, that is what matters (I use frequentist methods all the time myself - even though they are clearly wrong ;o)./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="ulhOXSa/lq8fZb2hqtJRPA==" Author="3890" Date="2013-06-06T11:40:15.993" Text="@DikranMarsupial As mentioned in the study I cited, the quality of the reviews is unaffected by whether they are suggested by the authors or selected by the editors. It's clear that the quality of the reviews is the most important point, but as an author I hope for high quality **and** favorable reviews./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="ulhOXSa/lq8fZb2hqtJRPA==" Author="2827" Date="2014-01-23T13:56:43.640" Text="@silvado, they don't need to be neutral as long as they are objective.  Editors *should* choose proponents of both approach A and approach B, but be able to mediate the views of both reviewers in coming to a judgement about the value of the paper.  The problem you get with only getting reviews from proponents of approach A is that you get bland anodyne reviews that don't raise the problems with approach A. There are problems either way.  Seeking reviewers likely to be critical could have prevented the tragedy that befell &quot;Pattern Recognition if Physics&quot; recently (v. good topic for a journal)./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="ulhOXSa/lq8fZb2hqtJRPA==" Author="2827" Date="2013-06-06T11:52:51.543" Text="I want favourable reviews from a reviewer that was not predisposed to be favourable, that is a *much* better test of the quality of the paper, flaws are less likely to go unnoticed, and my arguments will end up sharper.  As I said, if your paper can only convince your friends, it needs strengthening, one that can convince your opponents is undoubtedly ready for publication./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="ulhOXSa/lq8fZb2hqtJRPA==" Author="3890" Date="2014-01-25T10:15:55.900" Text="In the mathematical based sciences, objectivity seems to be a bit easier to achieve than in natural sciences. There, I have the feeling that opinions can be very strong and do affect reviews./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="ulhOXSa/lq8fZb2hqtJRPA==" Author="3890" Date="2014-01-25T10:14:35.817" Text="@DikranMarsupial, I agree that editors should choose proponents of both approaches. Accordingly, an editor should try to get at least half of the reviews from reviewers *not* suggested by the authors./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="ulhOXSa/lq8fZb2hqtJRPA==" Author="3890" Date="2014-01-23T09:30:41.983" Text="@DikranMarsupial In an ideal world, reviewers would be neutral and objective. Unfortunately, it's often not the case in the real world. Assume there exists approach A and approach B to tackle the problem addressed in your paper, both scientifically sound, and you use approach A. I would recommend not suggesting someone who is known to oppose approach A in favor of approach B, unless you know the person to be particularly objective, or you want to get an unconstructive review along the lines &quot;Reject because does not use approach B&quot;./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="ulhOXSa/lq8fZb2hqtJRPA==" Author="725" Date="2014-01-16T10:26:45.310" Text="@DikranMarsupial: I guess it depends on what meaning you and silvado put into the &quot;favorable&quot;. If &quot;favorable&quot; means the reviewer reads the manuscript thoroughly because of deep interest in your work that's clearly wanted. If &quot;favorable&quot; makes the reviewer just write a sloppy &quot;accept&quot; that is obviously not what we want./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="ulhOXSa/lq8fZb2hqtJRPA==" Author="2827" Date="2013-06-06T11:26:17.663" Text="Reviewers that will look favourably on your paper is not what you *should* want.  The purpose of review is to weed out papers that are too flawed to be publishable and to improve the quality of papers published.  Ultimately it is in the best long-term interests of the authors for the reviewers to give them a hard time in order to maximise the quality of your papers that actually appear in print.  If you can't convince those who don't already agree with you, the paper is probably not ready yet./>

<answer QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="CIjX4soGLU7Abco15ltfFQ==" Author="26" Date="2013-06-06T06:11:18.803" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;I was asked to do that several times by an editor after being told (s)he couldn't find referees for my submission (to the point that I now spontaneously tell the editor upon submission that I can suggest referees if need be), but I don't know of any journal (or conference) for which this is &lt;em&gt;required&lt;/em&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Anyway, you don't need to know experts personally: you are &lt;em&gt;suggesting&lt;/em&gt; referees, not &lt;em&gt;forcing&lt;/em&gt; them on the editor (or your work on them), and whether or not you actually know them should be irrelevant (it's even better if you don't). Read your bibliography, see which authors come up most often, or whose work form the most important basis for your submission, or who would be the most interested in reading it based on their own work, and I'm sure you'll have plenty of names to suggest. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="CIjX4soGLU7Abco15ltfFQ==" Author="739" Date="2013-06-06T14:41:33.583" Text="The reference list would be the first place an editor unfamiliar with the research topic would look into, anyway. So the referee suggestions should probably be more specific. There could be other people not on the list who have not published recently, or just have not published much, yet are deeply familiar with the topics of your paper -- e.g., in industry or government (this is quite typical for some areas in which I work: statistics; these people don't have the [academic luxury] time to publish their work)./>
<comment QuestionId="How to suggest reviewers for a Journal" AnswerId="CIjX4soGLU7Abco15ltfFQ==" Author="26" Date="2013-06-06T15:27:53.117" Text="@StasK: common sense would indeed suggest so, but I've seen caseS where the editor was perfectly happy with a list of referees built in that way./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10479	<question QuestionId="How to determine similarity score of new manuscript against own yet-to-publish manuscripts" Title="How to determine similarity score of new manuscript against own yet-to-publish manuscripts" Views="359" Tags="publications,plagiarism,paper-submission" " AnswerId="MBnEyFxibfFXJ4t7+MPVuw==" Author="6393" Date="2013-06-06T07:04:42.263" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Considering the ethical and professional implications of self plagiarism, it is very useful to check new manuscript against old ones (which are under review and not yet published) to decrease self plagiarism. In a white paper by ithenticate (download from &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ithenticate.com/self-plagiarism-free-white-paper&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.ithenticate.com/self-plagiarism-free-white-paper&lt;/a&gt;), one way to avoid self plagiarism is to significantly paraphrase those text which are need to be used in new article. However, I have difficulties in identifying the similarity percentage of my current work against yet-unpublished works. Online tools (that I know) check the manuscript against published works. I have 3 journal papers, 1 is published, 1 is under review, and 1 is under preparation. Now, I need to check the third one to see the similarity score. Any suggestion?   &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to determine similarity score of new manuscript against own yet-to-publish manuscripts" AnswerId="MBnEyFxibfFXJ4t7+MPVuw==" Author="6393" Date="2013-06-06T16:22:32.487" Text="Thanks all of you for your fruitful suggestions. However, I need to check now, because I am in a situation where I need to check what is the similarity score. I checked recommended tools in sourceforge, but no clue. They are just not working. thanks for help./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10479" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How to determine similarity score of new manuscript against own yet-to-publish manuscripts" AnswerId="rbFtsgvbnUiATBhICqP7ew==" Author="4429" Date="2013-06-06T09:27:46.813" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Does the paper make an original disciplinary contribution to scholarly knowledge?&#xA;Has any reused material been rewritten from scratch?&#xA;Has the reused material been cited in relation to the paper under review?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If so, it should be fine.  The first one is the big one, I assume that people with a doctorate in their discipline should know whether this has been achieved.  One nostrum I use is meeting at least one of the three: new evidence set, new theoretical tools, new analysis.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As an example of this nostrum: Case A organisation demonstrating with Marxist class analysis concept Q.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Case B with Marxism demonstrating Q is novel&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Case A with Patriarchy analysis demonstrating Q is novel&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Case A with Marxism demonstrating R is novel&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to determine similarity score of new manuscript against own yet-to-publish manuscripts" AnswerId="rbFtsgvbnUiATBhICqP7ew==" Author="6393" Date="2013-06-06T09:57:45.810" Text="Certainly new manuscript are logically providing original contribution, however, it is time consuming to write some general text from the scratch, so people just copy and paraphrase it. It is good idea to support the text with reference to the under review paper. However, having a tool as Anthony mentioned to check the score would be fine./>
<comment QuestionId="How to determine similarity score of new manuscript against own yet-to-publish manuscripts" AnswerId="rbFtsgvbnUiATBhICqP7ew==" Author="4429" Date="2013-06-06T10:03:04.897" Text="@T.F. I've expanded the answer and hope this assists./>

If I did, I could not publish in top journals (though you are not really fan of journals). I am fast in writing (Though English is not my first language) and do not need to copy &amp; paste text from old papers. I dislike to copy and paraphrase old sentences since every time I write, the texts are more cohesive and interesting. But (my) brain sometimes generates similar sentences. That's why I need to make sure such identical sentences do not impact on my writings./>

<comment QuestionId="How to determine similarity score of new manuscript against own yet-to-publish manuscripts" AnswerId="HCykkXVJXNClHWpG8b8C1g==" Author="6393" Date="2013-06-06T10:34:29.590" Text="I check these tools and found them useless in the domain I need. <answer QuestionId="How to determine similarity score of new manuscript against own yet-to-publish manuscripts" AnswerId="DQu/DGpcmF4vnRQ93y3y+w==" Author="4394" Date="2013-06-06T13:09:52.713" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;First suggestion&lt;/em&gt;: Never copy-paste material from earlier works, always write everything from scratch.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This prevents you from moving critical passages from one paper to the other. It is of course still possible to end up with a similar or even identical sentence by accident, particularly if you describe a method or something similar. If you end up using the same method for several papers it is also possible to simply reference your original description in subsequent papers. The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ithenticate.com/Portals/92785/media/ith-selfplagiarism-whitepaper.pdf&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Ithenticate white paper&lt;/a&gt; mentioned by you provides good advice. Yuo can slso visit the &lt;a href=&quot;http://publicationethics.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;COPE (Committee On Publication Ethics)&lt;/a&gt; web site and search for self-plagiarism.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Second suggestion&lt;/em&gt;: Use the softwares such as &lt;em&gt;iThenticate&lt;/em&gt;,  &lt;em&gt;turnitin&lt;/em&gt; or the like depending what you are looking for. But, I would not blindly just look at percentages of overlap but focus on where the overlaps occur. If it is in the methods section describing a series of steps ina  process it is clearly not as critical as if it is in the discussion or conclusions. If you find overlap and you can identify what it is, then go to my first suggestion and critically review if you need to say it again.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10485" Date="2013-06-07T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10485" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10481	<question QuestionId="Reproducible research and corporate identity" Title="Reproducible research and corporate identity" Views="224" Tags="copyright,creative-commons" " AnswerId="mBe/QWboVDhO0MM3j3jjCw==" Author="929" Date="2013-06-06T09:11:05.863" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;My university is on a drive to unify its corporate identity (it makes me sick just typing that). This drive includes branding our lecture slides, research talks, and research posters. The branding templates are not released under an open license and utilize a copyrighted logo and proprietary fonts. I think this prevents me from releasing my talks and posters under an free and open license (e.g., &lt;a href=&quot;http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/&quot;&gt;CC BY&lt;/a&gt;) which is one of the tenets of &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.rrplanet.com/&quot;&gt;Reproducible Research&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Apart from creating two versions of everything, is there a way to reconcile this apparent incompatibility?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is my understanding of licenses like &lt;a href=&quot;http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/&quot;&gt;CC BY&lt;/a&gt; wrong? Can I release something (like a research talk or poster) with a copyrighted logo that I don't hold the copyright on under a free and open license?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Reproducible research and corporate identity" AnswerId="mBe/QWboVDhO0MM3j3jjCw==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-06T13:09:37.370" Text="Maybe you could specify &quot;everything except the logo and fonts is released under a CC BY license&quot;?  Strictly speaking, that would be fairly restrictive, since it would not give people permission to redistribute the file as is.  However, it would at least make it clear what is available for reuse if that's the aspect you are worried about.  I imagine your university would even agree to a more elaborate license (saying the whole file is distributable without modifications under CC BY-ND and everything but the logo and fonts can be reused under CC BY), which might be the closest to what you want./>
<comment QuestionId="Reproducible research and corporate identity" AnswerId="mBe/QWboVDhO0MM3j3jjCw==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-07T03:08:57.440" Text="_This drive includes branding our lecture slides, research talks, and research posters._ — Just say no.  Actually, don't even say no.  **Just don't do it.**/>
<comment QuestionId="Reproducible research and corporate identity" AnswerId="mBe/QWboVDhO0MM3j3jjCw==" Author="4429" Date="2013-06-06T09:31:26.173" Text="Have you contacted the division of your university responsible for copyright (Library, Division IP) regarding their licensing of their copyright material and their font licence for reproduction on CC BY?  Their own licences may be such to allow you to do so./>
<comment QuestionId="Reproducible research and corporate identity" AnswerId="mBe/QWboVDhO0MM3j3jjCw==" Author="929" Date="2013-06-06T12:38:29.820" Text="@SamuelRussell not yet, I am still trying to track them down. As far as I can tell no one wants to take responsibility./>
<comment QuestionId="Reproducible research and corporate identity" AnswerId="mBe/QWboVDhO0MM3j3jjCw==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-06T13:15:21.783" Text="Regarding the logo the university might agree to CC BY because it forbids reusing anything &quot;in any way that suggests that they endorse you or your use of the work&quot;.  One could argue that a logo automatically implies endorsement and therefore cannot be reused even if taken from a CC BY licensed work, in which case including it in such a work shouldn't be a problem.  However, I'm sure the university would want to discuss this with their lawyers before deciding that clause made it safe.  In any case, you are right that because you don't hold the copyright, you need their explicit permission./>
<comment QuestionId="Reproducible research and corporate identity" AnswerId="mBe/QWboVDhO0MM3j3jjCw==" Author="96" Date="2013-06-06T14:09:32.747" Text="What does capitalised &quot;Reproducible Research&quot; mean? Please can you add an explanation to the question? It must mean something different to uncapitalised &quot;reproducible research&quot;, because that wouldn't require talks and posters to be released under a free and open licence at all, so I guess you're talking about something more institutionalised and ideological?/>
<comment QuestionId="Reproducible research and corporate identity" AnswerId="mBe/QWboVDhO0MM3j3jjCw==" Author="929" Date="2013-06-06T14:27:59.497" Text="@EnergyNumbers I added a link to http://www.rrplanet.com/. The idea of capital Reproducible Research is that in the absence of free and open licensing (among many other steps) research isn't easily reproducible./>
<comment QuestionId="Reproducible research and corporate identity" AnswerId="mBe/QWboVDhO0MM3j3jjCw==" Author="929" Date="2013-06-07T06:08:01.257" Text="@JeffE talks are easy. Posters, and to an extent lecture handouts, need to be printed. The university approved printer won't print I branded material./>

<answer QuestionId="Reproducible research and corporate identity" AnswerId="UttR5FP6aji4j+YhIRPsOg==" Author="4394" Date="2013-06-07T10:31:35.690" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;My university has had enforced its &quot;corporate identity&quot; since the 1990s. It is described in details on a web site and available in a series of templates. Although I get a sense of tiredness when I read the material surrounding the &quot;identity&quot; I can also see benefits, to recognize the university &quot;products&quot; (sorry) among other materials at a congress etc. But, the question was about reproducing material. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As I see it I would want to have the logo on material such as posters or presentations so that people can identify my affiliation. I am free to post presentations and posters or other materials on my university site with the logos on them. If I want to put some material out that is mine I simply would not use a unversity logo. An example: I have written several hopefully useful booklets on scientific writing to be used by students. This material is my initiative and is not the result of the university asking for it. These booklets are distributed for free using our web-page and I would gladly distribute them more widely if there was demand. So from this perspective I can see two different &quot;products&quot; where one benefits from the logo and one where I do not want it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now the rules of my university says the logo is copyrighted which means others cannot use it. this still means I can post material with the logo in public places. The problem arises if someone takes my, say, presentation and uses it as their own. Then they break the copyright and make themselves guilty of a kind of fraud by associating themselves with an organisation to which they do not belong. I still have done nothing wrong, posting material is fine and even encouraged. The copyright also prevents people from the taking the university logo and adding it to their own &quot;product&quot; fo rexample showing it on their web-page or using it for commercial uses.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So now, the content. You seem to indicate that you will be prevented from displaying your work without the branding. I do not think this is correct. The laws on copyright and particulary intellectual ownership in my country is very clear. If you have created something it is yours. In a commercial company you may end up sign off this right by becoming employed so that the things your develop within that company belongs to them, not you. That is how research in pharmaceutical companies work, for example. My university system has made attempts to gain rights to lectures etc. but this has so far failed miserably due to the strong laws. You need to check these laws that apply to you since I do not know how they may vary internationally; I would expect them to look fairly similar.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You mention &quot;proprietary fonts&quot;. This means the university has selected fonts and bought them from a font foundry so that you can use and copy them for free within the university system. This does not mean other cannot use them, they must simply buy them first so providing copies to persons outside of your university would be illegal. Since fonts are not included in Office templates or in pedfs resulting from your templates there is nothing illegal about distributing such documents. If you were to take the fonts and produce a product that you were to sell for your won personal gain, you will, however, break the law.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The bottom line, then, is that you can put your  material in the creative commons as long as you avoid the logo (ater all who would want to use a figure with somebody elses logo in it?). I cannot see the university preventing you from doing this unless they explicitly ask you to waive your rights. Material with logo has its place when you want to make sure your afficilaition is clear. If you do not want that, then I believe you are free to post things in another style. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Finally awareness of the laws and regulations concerning intellectual rights are important and I strongly believe it is good to carefully look at whatever applies in each of our cases so that we can react if someone tries to infringe on such rights.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Reproducible research and corporate identity" AnswerId="UttR5FP6aji4j+YhIRPsOg==" Author="1429" Date="2013-06-07T19:36:13.083" Text="+1. very nice answer. I think that nothing prevents the OP from posting his materials online. If its about research communication as the OP indicates, it will do the job. Others can use the content without the fonts, logos etc./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10499" Date="2013-06-07T00:00:00.000/>

</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Reproducible research and corporate identity" AnswerId="Ey2ZlXVofWIFFYTb9eMnFA==" Author="4461" Date="2013-06-07T09:16:48.740" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;My suggestion is to follow your school's guidance as much as you have to, but figure out a way to remove (by script, macro, by hand, or otherwise) the branding for distribution.  Have both versions available on your website.  If you have a presentation that you may want to distribute, put a note at the bottom of the title slide, or at the end:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;A freely distributable version of this presentation is available here: [web address].&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If your branding mechanism is a master/template slide, it is trivial to remove this for a non-branded version.  I have a hard time believing that printing issues (for posters or handouts) should be a big concern for redistribution -- if it isn't digital, very few people are going to scan/copy for redistribution anyway.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Reproducible research and corporate identity" AnswerId="Ey2ZlXVofWIFFYTb9eMnFA==" Author="4461" Date="2013-06-07T10:46:34.587" Text="@DanielE.Shub My fault -- I didn't properly read that you wanted to avoid the two versions.  When it comes down to it, though, how do you want people to share the work?  Do you want the ideas shared, or the actual document?  If it is the former, it doesn't really matter what the document looks like.  I would absolutely avoid branding individual graphs or charts. As for the font issue -- unless your school is using a really odd-ball font, you should be able to find a suitable free replacement without much trouble./>
<comment QuestionId="Reproducible research and corporate identity" AnswerId="Ey2ZlXVofWIFFYTb9eMnFA==" Author="929" Date="2013-06-07T10:33:33.107" Text="This is the two version approach that I was hoping to avoid. Having gaps where a logo once was will look a little odd. Changing the type face may cause the text to reflow/change size requiring a new layout./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10486	<question QuestionId="Is searching in article references considered a systematic way of literature search" Title="Is searching in article references considered a systematic way of literature search" Views="98" Tags="reviews,literature-search" " AnswerId="EmZ2+/1HZ10mww5lFwTQLg==" Author="4018" Date="2013-06-06T14:04:00.783" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Doing a systematic review, either quantitative or qualitative, requires developing a well-defined protocol as a method of conducting it. This includes defining the search methods used in the identification of eligible articles, which include two methods:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;database search&lt;/em&gt; using &lt;em&gt;search queries&lt;/em&gt; (a main method)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;searching in the references and cited-by sections of the selected articles (which are already retrieved by the first method)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Let's assume that an author (of a large review) does her best to formulate the &lt;em&gt;search queries&lt;/em&gt; to better represent the review question, but later she realized that &lt;strong&gt;considerable amount (e.g. 50% or more)&lt;/strong&gt; of the relevant articles are found &lt;em&gt;only by using the second method&lt;/em&gt; (searching in articles);&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is the second method less 'systematic' than the first one? Does it compromise how much 'systematic' is the resulting review?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If so, does the above scenario affect the validity of the &lt;em&gt;search queries&lt;/em&gt; used (i.e. should they be reformulated to increase the recall of search and retrieve more of relevant articles)?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Edit:&lt;/strong&gt; More extremely: If 90 out of selected 100 articles are found only by using the second method, how much does this affect the quality of the systematic review?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is searching in article references considered a systematic way of literature search" AnswerId="EmZ2+/1HZ10mww5lFwTQLg==" Author="4018" Date="2013-06-06T14:18:57.063" Text="Thanks. To make it clear to you: if 90 out of the selected 100 articles are found only using 2, will you be happy with the quality of the review?/>
<comment QuestionId="Is searching in article references considered a systematic way of literature search" AnswerId="EmZ2+/1HZ10mww5lFwTQLg==" Author="96" Date="2013-06-06T16:22:46.823" Text="Thanks Orion - please do add that to the question: it does help a bit./>
<comment QuestionId="Is searching in article references considered a systematic way of literature search" AnswerId="EmZ2+/1HZ10mww5lFwTQLg==" Author="96" Date="2013-06-06T14:14:05.483" Text="I'm not sure I understand what you mean, because it seems to me that this is either trivial or unanswerable. If the protocol included 1 and 2, then following 1 *and* 2 is systematic; if you only followed 1 *or* 2, that would breach the protocol, and not be systematic. Whereas if the protocol included 1 and not 2, then following 1 and not 2 would be systematic; but following 1 *and* 2 would be a breach of the protocol, and thus less systematic./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10486" Date="2013-06-07T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10486" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10486" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10486" Date="2013-06-07T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10486" Date="2014-01-27T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Is searching in article references considered a systematic way of literature search" AnswerId="p4xwmqUb3hNBcsLDEOZsOQ==" Author="4394" Date="2013-06-06T14:22:39.423" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;Databases are not complete and published articles do not necessarily reference all pertinent literature so it seems unlikely that one would necessarily capture everything relevant by using just one method. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Databases are probably relatively complete when regarding more recent publications. I would not like to define &quot;recent&quot; however but I see it as mostly post-1990's. But my guess is that databases are centered around more widespread journals and more local journals may not be well-represented. This means that depending on the search area they may be more or less complete. Going back in time more and more will likely not be found in databases so if the topic has a vital history then database searches will cover the &quot;recent&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Reference lists may pick up more older material but that is of course dependent on the authors willingness to research literature. It is possible one might pick up more esoteric references this way but I fear the selection will be fairly random and not comprehensive.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So to use both methods seem like the safest way forward to me. Depending on the subject matter, having deeper understanding for where and when things might have been published in the past may be vital in order to capture most relevant literature on the subject. To venture so far as to say everything will be found is difficult. Particularly during the cold war much was published in for example Russian journals that never reached the west. Many discoveries published in the west were therefore missing out on the eastern counterparts and may not even have been first. Much has thus been lost by lacking translation and that goes for many if not most languages. One must also remember that the publication scene as we see it today was not utilized earlier, when internal reports and local journals may have taken up much research. To rely on just one of the two parts for methodology may therefore be inadequate.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10487" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10487" Date="2013-06-07T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10487" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10487" Date="2013-06-07T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10487" Date="2013-06-06T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Is searching in article references considered a systematic way of literature search" AnswerId="aHgr51BJY4HFk/qz/8jR+Q==" Author="6984" Date="2013-06-06T20:29:31.253" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would add to the other answer(s) that you could validate the first approach using the second approach. If your search criteria systematically miss relevant articles &lt;em&gt;in the journals covered by the database&lt;/em&gt;, then that's a clear sign you need to reformulate your search criteria because they're clearly not sufficient.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The second thing to add is that any search should also try to find unpublished articles. These are definitely not going to be in databases, but may be cited in papers (thus the importance, at least in my view, of the second approach). It might be worth adding a third approach that involves search conference abstracts, where unpublished (especially recent) work is likely to be found.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is searching in article references considered a systematic way of literature search" AnswerId="aHgr51BJY4HFk/qz/8jR+Q==" Author="4018" Date="2013-06-06T20:35:42.097" Text="+1 for finding *unpublished* articles in reference lists./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10493	<question QuestionId="Are alternative metrics taken seriously by hiring committies" Title="Are alternative metrics taken seriously by hiring committies" Views="169" Tags="bibliometrics,impact-factor,h-index" " AnswerId="6TAYPwhP52ppKMUC3+gjUw==" Author="2692" Date="2013-06-07T00:41:40.960" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;Knowing that there are some members of hiring committees here, I am hoping for some insights.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Having read &lt;a href=&quot;http://chronicle.com/article/Rise-of-Altmetrics-Revives/139557/?cid=wc&amp;amp;utm_source=wc&amp;amp;utm_medium=en&quot;&gt;Rise of Altmetrics&lt;/a&gt;, I started to wonder what would be the best way to measure the impact on my publications. I do care for many reasons but one of the reasons is to impress others enough to be able to get a job/promotion/tenure.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, my question is, do hiring committees take alternative metrics (Facebook likes, mentions in blog posts, etc.) seriously when trying to measure the impact of someone's work or are other issues like impact factor more important?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/1020/what-is-a-fair-metric-for-assessing-the-citation-impact-of-journals-across-disci&quot;&gt;This question&lt;/a&gt; is related but is more about measuring the impact of a journal but my concern is measuring the impact of my own work (which might be in several journals).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/4965/are-academic-indicators-h-index-impact-factor-etc-really-adopted-by-institut/4966#4966&quot;&gt;This question&lt;/a&gt; is also related by asking how impact measurements affect job prospects and has some excellent answers but my question is specifically about 'unofficial' metrics like tweets, downloads on SlideShare, etc.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/1206/how-many-people-read-an-individual-journal-article&quot;&gt;This question&lt;/a&gt; is also related asking how to measure readership of journal articles but my question is whether alternative measures are taking into serious consideration but those making hiring/tenure decisions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I know there is the h-index (with its own flaws) but that seems to measure my publications as one unit (all publications taken together, therefore measuring me overall). I'm more interested in measuring the impact publication by publication in order to show an improving trend.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On a side note, it seems that there is a general feeling that a publication in a high impact factor journal equals a high impact publication. This feels a little off to me since one might convince the editor their work is important while at the same time fail to convince their academic community of the same.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Are alternative metrics taken seriously by hiring committies" AnswerId="6TAYPwhP52ppKMUC3+gjUw==" Author="6862" Date="2013-06-10T02:49:29.037" Text="@earthling in the end, these alternative metrics quantify some form of citation, what changes is usually the method of quantification and the definition of a citation (e.g. a loose definition could include social media tags and blogging). The h-index that you mentioned is also based on citations. I just think it is more straightforward to give the actual numbers rather than some metric that aggregates them into a statistic./>
<comment QuestionId="Are alternative metrics taken seriously by hiring committies" AnswerId="6TAYPwhP52ppKMUC3+gjUw==" Author="4461" Date="2013-06-07T08:37:10.930" Text="I have not sat on a hiring committee for a higher education faculty position, but I would avoid putting soft alternative metrics on application material.  If I was on a committee and saw that someone listed Facebook likes on his CV, I would think it was odd (possibly unprofessional?), and I would wonder why he felt it necessary (i.e., is he trying to bolster a poor record?)./>
<comment QuestionId="Are alternative metrics taken seriously by hiring committies" AnswerId="6TAYPwhP52ppKMUC3+gjUw==" Author="2692" Date="2013-06-10T02:23:37.727" Text="@Bitwise There is no question about citations. My question is based on the idea in article linked above./>

If you want to show that your recent work had a lot of impact, why not just add a statement like &quot;my recent 2 papers, which were published 2 years ago, have already been cited more than 500 times&quot;?/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10494	<question QuestionId="Does it amount to plagiarism by supervisors" Title="Does it amount to plagiarism by supervisors" Views="757" Tags="advisor,plagiarism" " AnswerId="Vo20TTCCI9SHHsEWBKVNgQ==" Author="4340" Date="2013-06-07T05:45:42.693" Score="20" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have been working on an idea for last 2 years almost independently along with other research works. Recently, I am getting encouraging results with a lot of success to solve a complex problem using that idea. I have not published the work yet. Initially, my advisors were not at all interested in the idea and insisted that I spend my time in other research projects. I pursued it with my interest in spite of any support but with new results and potential benefit of the approach my advisors became extremely interested and even described the work as the next big thing in our lab meetings. I am happy about it or maybe they say it to make me happy.&#xA;However, recently I encountered a situation which was difficult for me to digest. I found my advisors present a perspective paper along with many other renowned experts in the field, proposing and highlighting the approach I have been working on as the future direction in the field along with other important developments in a conference. Even though I was not a co-author in that paper, I did not consider it something wrong alluding myself that it was an advertisement to the work I was doing. I happened to attend the conference as a PhD student, and found that the presenter of the perspective paper (whom I don't know) presented more than half of his talk on my idea with my slides that I shared with my advisors. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;People really liked the idea and the approach and many are convinced that the idea is going to impact the field. While I saw a very drastic change in the way my advisors treated me recently, but what really made me sad was when my advisor asked me to refer to this perspective paper (to which I was not a co-author) in my impending submission (on the idea) to a journal.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I feel like it was unfair but I don't know if research is done this way in academia or if it is perfectly legit to do something like that. I decided not to cite the perspective paper with possible consequences. I just wanted to know how other students handle such situations effectively and if such a thing is a common practice.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Edit: I do have all email traces and even a previous publication explaining part of the idea and a recent technical report submitted to the department with the complete idea.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Does it amount to plagiarism by supervisors" AnswerId="Vo20TTCCI9SHHsEWBKVNgQ==" Author="285" Date="2013-06-07T18:55:28.740" Text="I second the comments about the importance of evidence/paper trail. I think version control can be a useful tool in such situations as well. Version controlled data and writings can help show when you came up with stuff and what you came up with exactly. If this is a repository which other people have access to and have committed to (this does not mean the repos needs to be public) then that is even better./>

<answer QuestionId="Does it amount to plagiarism by supervisors" AnswerId="xRGx+53ZT6WPElJ3VtNpOQ==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-07T07:25:49.663" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;Check the policies of your university when it comes to intellectual property, specifically for the faculty you are studying under. Make sure you fully understand the guidelines, and I mean absolutely certain.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;If&lt;/strong&gt; you find that there is a discrepancy, meaning that this is frowned upon, then you have your original presentation (although, to be honest, I am not sure how credible this would be as evidence).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Perhaps, you cold speak to your supervisor about completing a co-authored paper on the topic to be peer-reviewed published in a journal (This is what my supervisor and I do).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Does it amount to plagiarism by supervisors" AnswerId="aPPzRHumUtBE1wXf4wWQ1A==" Author="1429" Date="2013-06-07T16:55:57.130" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;While the other answers are good, I have an alternative approach for you. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Have you actually gone and spoken to your advisers about this? A &lt;em&gt;perspective&lt;/em&gt; paper is just that. It talks about concepts and the &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;next big thing&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; - which very well may be your work.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I suggest that you have a nice, sit down, frank discussion with your advisers about this and make clear what future directions and expectations are regarding publications, collaborations and co-authorships. That would clear the air quite a bit, which frankly now, is rather hazy.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Does it amount to plagiarism by supervisors" AnswerId="9ei2/vgH0C82LEuY+dkwRg==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-07T13:55:44.843" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;The only way you're really going to be able to establish some sort of claim to recognition is if:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Your advisors did not independently come up with the idea, and choose to change their stance and give you credit for the idea; or&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;You can establish conclusively that this was &lt;em&gt;your&lt;/em&gt; idea, and not your advisors'. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The best way to do this is if you have a &lt;em&gt;verifiable&lt;/em&gt; documentation trail supporting your claim. This means that you have conclusive records showing that the work exists. This would include things like emails, &lt;em&gt;verified&lt;/em&gt; laboratory notebooks, and other documents that can be dated and that demonstrate that you came up with the idea. The challenge, of course, will be showing that you came up with it &lt;em&gt;independently&lt;/em&gt; of your advisors (which would require that you have documented proof showing that they discouraged you from working on it.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10504" Date="2013-06-07T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10504" Date="2013-06-07T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Does it amount to plagiarism by supervisors" AnswerId="xBevK8pg25imKXflArN50w==" Author="user7224" Date="2013-06-08T17:37:05.277" Score="10" Text="&lt;p&gt;I was in a similar situation before (in biology) about 5 years ago (and this was an ivy league school on the East coast of US) – I had paper A published and paper B (following from A) in the works, when the advisor tries to work on paper C (following from A, borderline with B). The deal is that neither B nor C would've been possible without A, and one of B or C was necessary to show the full impact and worth of A (think detailed theory paper A vs lab experiments B and C). For other reasons, it couldn't be written as a larger A+B or A+C paper, but that's besides the point. The problem here was that the advisor, being faster at churning out a paper, finished C before I finished B despite starting later and then he insisted that we focus on polishing and submitting C before returning to B (I was 2nd author). Indeed that's what happened and we cited C in B when B was also eventually published (thus changing the &quot;science order&quot; from how it was). Note: I was not actually worried about publishing C, just its appearance before B.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My issues were:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;A was my idea, my work.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The idea for C was also mine (leading from A), but was shelved (by me) until I had the time to run the experiments for those (the assays and lab experiments weren't a small deal).&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;I'm the student needing advising, not poaching of ideas.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;publishing order of C before B looks like it was the advisor's bright idea, when it was not (no, really... this didn't start with the &quot;here, work on my old unfinished idea&quot;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The advisor's view was:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;A is already published, so it's &quot;out there&quot; for everyone including him.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;B and C are not exactly the same, so what's the big deal?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;In the long run, precedence differences of O(weeks) won't matter, period.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;I'm also an author and I now have 3 papers instead of 2.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In the end, I came to terms with it and in hind sight (after 5 yrs), should not have made such a fuss because&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;I got 3 papers instead of 2 &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;It was a fresh change of roles (he did do the work, and I was in an advisory role)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;In the long run, precedence differences of O(weeks) didn't matter (might be different in other fields), and since I continued publishing in the same field, it now looks like I'm the man behind the plan.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Resentment never did anyone any good.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The dude is a hell of a supportive advisor in all other ways, so this wasn't worth burning bridges. Maybe he genuinely didn't see things from my PoV and didn't intend to poach.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The bottom line is – what you're describing, while borderline, might not be uncommon. Especially, using graduate students' results in a presentation to a funding agency, but passing it off as their &quot;project&quot; is very common, because despite what you might want to think, a lot of times, it's the reputation of the PI that brings in the money than the merit of the idea itself (i.e., a mediocre idea from a rock star PI has more chances of getting funded than a rock star idea from an unknown researcher). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, it was absolutely wrong of them to have not included your name or acknowledged your contribution (which has never happened with me). You might want to bring that up, but you should think if you really want to burn bridges for a &quot;small&quot; reason. I say &quot;small&quot; in quotes because while yes, from a strict ethical PoV, they might be in the wrong, you're justified in your anger and is &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; a small issue for you, in the long run, the objective function of life is a multivariable function. Don't just fixate on one and make a decision (that you might come to regret) based on a local minimum that you're stuck in now.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Does it amount to plagiarism by supervisors" AnswerId="xBevK8pg25imKXflArN50w==" Author="5944" Date="2013-06-12T20:35:52.867" Text="I upvoted this because I think it has a good perspective about what happens a lot in academia. Professors often take ideas that their students develop and write grants and papers out of them, but in the end, the interest that they drum up ends up generating more opportunities for the student. At the same time I heavily advise you to speak with your advisor about it and rather than carry an accusatory tone, take one that emphasizes the importance that you be involved in any and all aspects of the project (including authorship and appropriate credit)./>
<comment QuestionId="Does it amount to plagiarism by supervisors" AnswerId="xBevK8pg25imKXflArN50w==" Author="4340" Date="2013-06-23T18:32:33.193" Text="Grant fund is common practice in my area too. I am not speaking of grant proposal rather of conference/journal publication which is different. Is a grant proposal same as a journal/conference paper (where the student who has carried the work is not included) ? I may be wrong but please do not support misuse /exploitation as many students over here will consider that as the norm./>
<comment QuestionId="Does it amount to plagiarism by supervisors" AnswerId="xBevK8pg25imKXflArN50w==" Author="5596" Date="2013-06-21T14:52:48.437" Text="+1 It's absolutely standard practice in my field for advisors to include student research as &quot;their project&quot; in their grant proposals. Since these grants fund the student I don't see anything at all wrong with this (unless the student is senior and heading for academia, and wants(!) to be closely involved in the grant-writing process)./>

<answer QuestionId="Does it amount to plagiarism by supervisors" AnswerId="ckuIbDX60Csokg4UOxHDhg==" Author="946" Date="2013-06-07T18:52:44.587" Score="13" Text="&lt;p&gt;As far as I understand the situation, it seems to me that your advisors' behavior is borderline, even if likely on the wrong side of the border. Since it does not look like a very clear and frank misbehavior, even if you are perfectly right it would be tremendously difficult to prove it beyond doubt. In case of doubt, you could end up being seen more as the trouble maker than as the one who came up with that great idea; the surrounding people to whom you could complain (department head, etc.) would hesitate &lt;em&gt;a lot&lt;/em&gt; to go against tenured faculty when the misbehavior is not crystal clear, etc.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;With this in mind, I would strongly advise you not to confront to wildly with your advisors. You can (and should, as advised by Shion) discuss with them the fact that you are uncomfortable with the way they presented things, with the use without permission of your slides, and so on; but &lt;strong&gt;always let them a way to discuss it calmly&lt;/strong&gt;. If they feel cornered, there will be little chance of the situation not degenerating into a conflict, and it would be very difficult for you to survive professionally a conflict with your advisors.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You could cite their perspective paper in a way that friendly makes explicit that the idea is yours. Your aim should be to get decent credit for your idea, even at the cost of letting your advisors benefit from it: think about what you have to gain or loose first, rather than about what they have to unduly gain or what you can cost them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If everything goes smoothly, you can get into a good position to build on your idea, and be on track for your career. &#xA;Once you're a respected tenured faculty, you should remember this episode and be supportive of young researchers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Does it amount to plagiarism by supervisors" AnswerId="ckuIbDX60Csokg4UOxHDhg==" Author="43" Date="2013-06-07T20:10:05.693" Text="+1 for this answer, and specifically for : &quot;Once you're a respected tenured faculty, you should remember this episode and be supportive of young researchers.&quot;/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10497	<question QuestionId="Is there a community driven unified article database" Title="Is there a community driven unified article database" Views="178" Tags="publications,reference-managers" " AnswerId="DZ/G8pw6voz15CxljlOMYw==" Author="59" Date="2013-06-07T09:13:26.817" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am using Mendeley to keep track of my papers. It allows me to group the papers in folders, and I can easily export BiBTeX for a folder which I can include in a paper I am writing. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, almost always I need to fill in all the details when I add a new paper to my library. &quot;Search by Title&quot; feature does not do a great job.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think everyone around the world is creating their BiBTeX (or any other format) entries by hand. Is there a community driven (wikipedia like) website/service that unifies this process?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What I have in my mind is something like this: People add article meta information (title, authors, year etc.) to this public DB, if they see a mistake they correct it, if they see duplicates they prevent it by deleting one. And one can export entries as BiBTeX, etc.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The closest thing I saw is &lt;a href=&quot;http://scholar.google.com/&quot;&gt;Google Scholar&lt;/a&gt;. But because it tries to automate nearly the whole process there are still lots of mistakes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is there a community driven unified article database" AnswerId="DZ/G8pw6voz15CxljlOMYw==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-08T00:12:37.903" Text="_I don't create my bibtex by hand, I get them from online sources_ — Really?  DBLP and ACM DL (like Springer BibTeX) is _horrible_ — misspelled author names, incorrect proceedings titles, missing page numbers, using - instead of -- to separate page numbers, ....  I enter my BibTeX data by hand./>

<answer QuestionId="Is there a community driven unified article database" AnswerId="rSuBFhKpC+ZGsVMd1Xa9kw==" Author="6984" Date="2013-06-07T11:16:46.790" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;JSTOR and many publishers include BiBTeX format for articles on their webpages:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Example from Cambridge University Press (click &quot;How to Cite This Article&quot;): &lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&amp;amp;aid=92189&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&amp;amp;aid=92189&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Example from JSTOR (click &quot;Export Citation&quot;): &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.jstor.org/stable/2585925&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.jstor.org/stable/2585925&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Is there a community driven unified article database" AnswerId="0NYGvjuA2fWMwC/jTIoJDw==" Author="948" Date="2013-06-11T15:00:08.133" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;This applies only to mathematics.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Personally I get most of my bibtex entries from &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ams.org/mathscinet/index.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Mathscinet&lt;/a&gt; where one can search for a particular article and then ask for bibtex. Here is &lt;a href=&quot;http://mathoverflow.net/questions/20551/sources-for-bibtex-entries&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;a related question on MathOverflow&lt;/a&gt;; some of the answers there seem transferable to other fields. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[I agree that these are not community-driven resources, but address the related question of where to obtain bibtex entries.]&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Is there a community driven unified article database" AnswerId="qFA7NR7moiQmDHp58bWPTA==" Author="386" Date="2013-06-11T18:17:46.863" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I use &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.citeulike.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;citeulike&lt;/a&gt;. Their smart bookmark lets me create an entry automatically from most articles on the web. Once it is in your library, you can easily export it as BibTex (1 click). I almost never have to type in BibTeX entries anymore.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Although, a number of journals which do not have DOI support, and conference proceedings, unfortunately it comes down to editing the BibTeX entry myself. (Sometimes someone else who uses citeulike would have already done that and you can search for the entry and copy it to your library.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10561" Date="2013-06-14T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Is there a community driven unified article database" AnswerId="v1y2Kp6GPo5sMS/zXO4FJw==" Author="725" Date="2013-06-11T17:43:22.947" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;I find that Jabref's import from pubmed (pubmed search -&gt; display list of pubmed ids -&gt; copy to Jabref)  does a very good job for the bio/medical fields.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Is there a community driven unified article database" AnswerId="oDywAfCMDJ0SDuCkrxVrdA==" Author="651" Date="2013-06-10T23:04:27.693" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Sadly, not yet...&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Many publishers view their bibliographic metadata as commercial property and hold-on to it fairly tightly.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Mendeley will release little bits of the article data they have accumulated from all their users, but they will not let anyone download &lt;em&gt;all&lt;/em&gt; of it - it's valuable property that they want to keep 'in-house'.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are a few truly community-driven projects trying to change this e.g. &lt;a href=&quot;http://opencitations.net/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Open Citations&lt;/a&gt; &amp;amp; &lt;a href=&quot;https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/19047x2Awo_H5Gkx79i68eQ6FunUeBVGV5_9pBK-A8eU/edit#slide=id.gd13c835f_0142&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Open Citagora&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;These projects aim to build truly public &amp;amp; open databases for &lt;em&gt;anyone&lt;/em&gt; to build upon &amp;amp; annotate. The other tools mentioned in the question aren't really public or fully open.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10555" Date="2013-06-11T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10555" Date="2013-06-11T00:00:00.000/>
