<answer QuestionId="University Teaching Certifications for Different Countries" AnswerId="P+beH6Co9/+BV/b5JHJRyg==" Author="3890" Date="2013-06-12T19:58:06.760" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;Traditionally, the formal teaching requirement at universities in continental Europe is the so called &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habilitation&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Habilitation&lt;/a&gt;. It's a formal exam which requires submitting a thesis and defending it in a colloquium much like the PhD, but (supposedly) on a higher level. Usually it also includes a teaching-related element. The habilitation used to be a requirement for being appointed as a professor, but in recent times also other criteria, which represent a comparable achievement to a habilitation, are being used. In Germany, having passed the habilitation allows you to use the title &quot;Privatdozent&quot; (even before being appointed as professor), with the same teaching entitlements as an ordinary professor.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, also other personnel may teach at the university. Even fresh graduates from one study program may find themselves in front of a class of students who could be just a year or two behind them. However, that will always be under the supervision of a professor, or on the formal commission of the department dean.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In addition, there are recent efforts to offer a more formal teaching education for university staff, including certificates for those who take part in the programs. I'm mostly familiar with the situation in Germany, for example &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.bzhl.tu-berlin.de/en/news/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; or &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.hdz-bawue.de/das-hdz.html&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;this&lt;/a&gt; (in German), but I imagine similar efforts exist in neighboring countries. At the moment, these certificates are however &lt;strong&gt;not a requirement&lt;/strong&gt; for university teaching, and I even doubt that they will become so in the near future. Yet, in some announcements for professor positions it seems to be included as a desirable applicant qualification.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="University Teaching Certifications for Different Countries" AnswerId="P+beH6Co9/+BV/b5JHJRyg==" Author="2692" Date="2013-06-24T11:58:51.540" Text="After reading the Habilitation page I see it is for supervising PhD students (and for gaining full professorships). It is clearly quite an investment (almost a decade after a PhD). I'm wondering if there is something more teaching-oriented, that is for those wishing simply to teach, not necessarily those wishing to supervised PhD students. Something similar to the qualifications I've listed in the question. Are you aware of anything like that?/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10577" Date="2013-07-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10577" Date="2013-06-12T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>

What are the most common penalties for such a violation of privacy? Is jail time possible as a punishment?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Penalties for disclosing student grades without consent" AnswerId="Q4KKCHEOWEeJz/zXMx2O9Q==" Author="1429" Date="2013-06-10T17:39:44.313" Text="Does this question need to exist in the first place? <comment QuestionId="Penalties for disclosing student grades without consent" AnswerId="Q4KKCHEOWEeJz/zXMx2O9Q==" Author="6690" Date="2013-06-10T14:09:47.413" Text="-1 as this can't be answered with so few information. <comment QuestionId="Penalties for disclosing student grades without consent" AnswerId="Q4KKCHEOWEeJz/zXMx2O9Q==" Author="2692" Date="2013-06-10T14:18:35.800" Text="I've tried to edit this into a more answerable question./>
<comment QuestionId="Penalties for disclosing student grades without consent" AnswerId="Q4KKCHEOWEeJz/zXMx2O9Q==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-10T13:33:58.683" Text="It's not clear what you're getting at.  Is this a theoretical question about what could happen (but won't), or a practical question?  For example, in the U.S. it is illegal to share university grades with anyone else (the law is called &quot;FERPA&quot;).  I have no idea whether the theoretical penalties could include jail, but it's inconceivable that anyone would actually be jailed for sharing grades with a student's parents./>

<answer QuestionId="Penalties for disclosing student grades without consent" AnswerId="yTvt55ZDXGh3g2jFajoCfw==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-11T23:33:53.973" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;This is not legal advice... If only people giving mathematical or dietary advice without credentials could be sued for failing to make a similar disclaimer! :)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are two parts to this issue. First, is it ok to tell people students' grades? In the U.S., almost entirely &quot;no&quot;, if the student is 18 or older. FERPA. It doesn't matter whether or not the student's parents are paying the tuition, the student's grades are privileged personal information.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It &lt;em&gt;is&lt;/em&gt; acceptable use to disclose student grades for (e.g.) intra-math-departmental function, such as advising, admission committee work, and other &quot;privileged&quot; use.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A traditional practice that is no longer ok is posting grades on instructors' doors, for example.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For &quot;old&quot; people, the idea that one is not in fact legally entitled to know the grades of the student whose tuition you're paying will seem strange. Indeed, decades ago, the grades were sent to the parents directly, in paper mail.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But, now, 18-or-over people are essentially legal adults in the U.S., and their school records (and medical records) are not automatically open to their parents.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thus, despite intuition to the contrary, simply do not give grades to parents, ... without seeking legal advice about extenuating circumstances, such as emergencies.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Edit: but, then, &quot;jail time&quot;? Who knows? But maybe monetary damages if someone sues you for violation of their privacy rights. Apart from the risk of this, if we think it through, maybe kids' grades (if they're &quot;adults&quot;) should not be divulged to anyone... So don't do it?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10564" Date="2013-06-12T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10564" Date="2013-06-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10564" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10564" Date="2013-06-12T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Penalties for disclosing student grades without consent" AnswerId="iqAvax/pZv1pjs0nEe93hA==" Author="5962" Date="2013-06-11T21:40:22.677" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;A number of people have mentioned &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FERPA&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;FERPA&lt;/a&gt;. Looking at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/20/1232g&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;the text of FERPA&lt;/a&gt; and at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.registrar.clemson.edu/FERPA/violation.htm&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;this University web page&lt;/a&gt; suggests what some others have said: violations of FERPA can result, ultimately, in withholding funding from the university but the law does not list criminal sanctions for either individuals or institutions for violation. That is also my understanding.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That said, there other privacy laws or other kinds of laws that might be violated by disclosure of educational records. There are a variety of other state, local, and federal laws — plus plenty of common law tort law, that could take effect. And besides, people sue for all kinds of things including things that aren't even in violation of a law.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To be clear: I am not a lawyer nor a legal expert and this is not legal advice. But, as a non-lawyer that likes to believe that world has certain common-sense limits, it seems &lt;em&gt;insane&lt;/em&gt; to suggest that telling a parent a grade could result in jail time. If you're worried and need a &quot;real&quot; answer, you should find a lawyer and ask.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10562" Date="2013-06-12T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10562" Date="2013-06-11T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10562" Date="2013-06-11T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10562" Date="2013-06-12T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Penalties for disclosing student grades without consent" AnswerId="WZ4wZjImN4KcfCuwM/AvHQ==" Author="929" Date="2013-06-10T14:19:44.533" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;In the US the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) protects the privacy of students. This &quot;act&quot; is not a law (on further reading it is a law), but rather a stipulation by the Department of Education that universities must obey in order to receive funding. As such, I do not believe that violations are classed as a criminal offense and hence cannot lead to jail time. Universities which violate the FERPA can lose their funding and likely have grounds to dismiss employees who violate the act. The university might even be able to seek damages against those individuals, but again, not jail time.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would suggest that you not violate FERPA. If you intend to, or have done so (accidentally or otherwise), I suggest that you seek legal advice.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Penalties for disclosing student grades without consent" AnswerId="WZ4wZjImN4KcfCuwM/AvHQ==" Author="924" Date="2013-06-10T19:29:04.737" Text="+1 for seek legal advice. In addition to the institution seeking damages, the the student(s) can seek civil damages from the institution and the individual who disclosed the information./>
<comment QuestionId="Penalties for disclosing student grades without consent" AnswerId="WZ4wZjImN4KcfCuwM/AvHQ==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-11T10:02:25.090" Text="+1 also for the same reason Ben Norris gave - seek legal advice - this would apply in any country./>

The task to be done is what to mimic the results of one paper and from that point to carry more research about it. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Because of some personal problems, that project got delayed. The thing is that when I got the results of my program, and I compared with the ones that I was supposed to get it, there were some differences (it was a medical related project). When I started comparing those differences I saw that some of my results were backed up by some medical papers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now the initial project has ended, because there has been published one software tool that do almost the same thing. And that research group is focusing in other projects.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The question that I have is that if there is any way in which I can publish the results that I obtained with the program that I made? I have spent more than six months of doing that, without payment. How I can name it? is it a model? should be published like a technical report? Any help will be great&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thanks &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10645" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10567	<question QuestionId="Scholarship effects on later applications" Title="Scholarship effects on later applications" Views="101" Tags="graduate-school,career-path,scholarships" " AnswerId="ewHWhaPqkLHgowB2bkLJkQ==" Author="7102" Date="2013-06-12T07:02:51.137" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have the choice to either apply for a sholarship or get a regular salary. Economically, the position is slightly favorable (mainly due to pension prospects), but I also want to consider secondary effects such as prestige in the CV w.r.t. lateron applications.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I know it's hard to put a value on such a thing, so I'm interested in your opinions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10567" Date="2013-06-12T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10567" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10567" Date="2013-06-12T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10567" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10567" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Scholarship effects on later applications" AnswerId="ISLCaH4GHRNsHR4sUIqawg==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-12T08:11:37.820" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;Your situation describes a situation that is relatively common here in Germany, with the choice between &quot;fellowships&quot; at &lt;em&gt;Gradiuerterkollegen&lt;/em&gt; and traditional degree programs within faculties and departments. If this is in fact your case, I don't think I would make too much of a difference between the statuses—they are both graduate degree programs, and would effectively carry the same weight. It's largely viewed (correctly) as just different means of internally financing graduate studies. Thus, it would not really make a big difference on your later career.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What &lt;em&gt;can&lt;/em&gt; make a difference, however, are the &lt;em&gt;duties&lt;/em&gt; assigned to the different programs. Scholarship students may have a substantially reduced set of responsibilities, particularly with respect to teaching and other non-research activities. This may mean that you finish your degree program more quickly and efficiently than someone who has to do substantial teaching as part of the standard graduate program.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Scholarship effects on later applications" AnswerId="ISLCaH4GHRNsHR4sUIqawg==" Author="7102" Date="2013-06-12T08:41:56.547" Text="Thank you. This is exactly the situation I'm in./>
<comment QuestionId="Scholarship effects on later applications" AnswerId="ISLCaH4GHRNsHR4sUIqawg==" Author="442" Date="2013-06-13T05:13:00.137" Text="@Neuneck You might want to consider talking to people in the department who have either and check whether it is actually the case - while technically your mentor is not allowed to ask you to do duties others are paid for when you have a scholarship, your department _may_ be understaffed and you might then feel obliged to help anyway.../>
<comment QuestionId="Scholarship effects on later applications" AnswerId="ISLCaH4GHRNsHR4sUIqawg==" Author="7102" Date="2013-06-13T05:36:08.750" Text="@TobiasKienzler Thank you for the advice. I'm lucky to be free of teaching duties in both cases. I will choose the faculty position since I do not improve my retirement prospects. These are even larger than I thought at first./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10569	<question QuestionId="Finishing a PhD or quitting and taking a job in industry" Title="Finishing a PhD or quitting and taking a job in industry" Views="3198" Tags="phd,job,career,industry" " AnswerId="4baUjz7jocKYr1X0MwlyMA==" Author="7410" Date="2013-06-12T10:30:46.250" Score="14" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am in the second year of a research degree, and with one more year I could finish my PhD. However, I got a very good job offer at a leading company in the field, which would mean I'd have to finish my degree now (which would then be an MPhil) and start working.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am hard pressed to make a decision, but I find it very hard to judge: what are the benefits of finishing a PhD over taking a job at a good company? Often people do a PhD to get into such a company, but what if that is not the case? Also, I feel that at this point, a job would be more challenging than a third year of a PhD, which would just be a continuation of the same thing I've been doing for two years now.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the other hand, people tell me it would be silly to quit now that I am so close, because &quot;a PhD is worth so much more.&quot; I would very much like some extra input on this: is a PhD 'worth more' in the end? And what are other things that I'd have to take into account to make an informed decision? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm only 23 years old, so I could even do a PhD later, but I'd have to start from the beginning again. Would it be an advantage or a disadvantage to have worked for a couple of years, when applying for a PhD again later?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Finishing a PhD or quitting and taking a job in industry" AnswerId="4baUjz7jocKYr1X0MwlyMA==" Author="10" Date="2013-06-12T15:33:11.473" Text="Some universities will let you take a leave for a year or two and let you continue from where you left off if you choose to return (in your case, depending on how the job goes).  If your university &amp; advisor allow this, maybe this can be a way for you to have your cake and eat it too?/>

And two rounds of interviews later, it suddenly is a serious option./>

Most likely you can finish your PhD _and_ take the job at the company. If they think you're good enough to employ now, they'll still think you're good enough to employ in a year's time. As, most likely, will many other companies./>

For one, you assume that any job in this field is about revenue, which isn't the case, that an academic career is out of the question entirely, which isn't the case, and that companies indeed don't care, which, given that more and more people get PhD degrees nowadays, is at least not the whole truth./>

<answer QuestionId="Finishing a PhD or quitting and taking a job in industry" AnswerId="Jpk1i8LKqJI8Hamvxk94UA==" Author="8094" Date="2013-08-08T14:53:42.447" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am in my last year of PhD but decided to take up job now. Being clear and frank about my view towards PhD as I never joined PhD to have Dr. infront of my name. I joined as I liked the project which i will be working on and the skills I will be learning from it. Also this will be my opportunity gain new skills and test my research interest and skills.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I always want to work in industry, I worked before my MSc one year in industry. Now I got the opportunity to start working with the current market rate pay with my current work experience. I don't have any regrets if I can't complete my PhD till the end while working. I can say as most of PhD students in this situation are thinking what others gona say, guilt of living in middle. But i can say that something new to start, something should end. If you think the opportunity is great then go ahead. Your the one who will stand for your decision, dont worry what others gona say. If you become successfull in future with your current decision then same people who showed fingers on you, will come to you and will ask your help. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am lucky as my supervisor is realistic and his opinion is that it will depend on me if i get phd or not. As working your normal job and compelting remaining PhD stuff is tough task to do. So he gave me full freedom to choose as its my life and my career. and I will decide which direction it will go. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am taking up job before finishing PhD is not just because of job offer, As i got family situation where I need to have job soon and i think this is right choice for me. at the end of journey if I get PhD its well and good but if not the knowledge skill learned will stay with me always. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;regarding PhD will help you in industry to get job, its too tricky. It depends upon your PhD research area. as not all industry want to have PhD students. and with my interview experiences I realised few companies freffer students with first degree or MSc more than PhD. Companies are worried about PhD students as how the student after 3 years of research work will fit in industrial world?? if not then company will loose all investment on PhD students when he resigns job as he dont adjust with indsutrial world.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My opinion is think what your brain decides and listen what your heat want. when both want same thing then go for it.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Finishing a PhD or quitting and taking a job in industry" AnswerId="/cR60NSM2hoQJnOOLcyo8Q==" Author="546" Date="2013-06-13T04:09:34.260" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;The question is basically, Academia or industry?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't think doing both is a good idea at this moment.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Given that you are 23 years old, you probably never have a real industry job before. You will have to devote yourself to the new job if you accept the offer. You probably have to work 50+ hours a week in the first year. It's very hard to do both at the same time if not impossible.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You need to ask yourself a question. What was your reason to study for PhD in the first place? Were you interested in research? Or you wanted to have a PhD in order to have a better industry job?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If your ultimate goal was to have a good industry job, then you just got one. Grab it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you wanted to do research, being a retiree from industry, I can tell you that you are not going to have much freedom to do the research you want to do. You'll have to do whatever your employer wants you to do. You'll become a money maker.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, we are back to the basic question. What was your career plan? If you did not know the answer when you started the PhD program, now is the time to make that decision. If you still don't know the answer after pondering over for a while, then you need to think about Lev Reyzin's suggestion, that is, take leave of absence from Academia. This is not a true good idea, just a temporary solution. It delays your decision. Your attitude will be like going there to test water. Chances are, you'll not devote yourself to your new job. I am not too sure you'll succeed the industry job that way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My suggestion for you, figure out where you want to be 10 years from now. If the answer is Academia, continue your PhD. If it's industry, take the offer. You don’t need to have PhD to be a successful business person after all.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10584" Date="2013-08-09T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10584" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10584" Date="2013-08-09T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Finishing a PhD or quitting and taking a job in industry" AnswerId="frgcnerdApG0eesj1CHj6w==" Author="7413" Date="2013-06-12T14:38:09.027" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would say that it depends a LOT on the field you work in.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I can tell you my personal experience in my field: programming (although it was with the Masters degree, not with a PhD).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I started working during college, and by the time I finished it, I already had a bit of experience, and was able to get good jobs, although this kept me from finishing the Masters. So far, I had no issues at any interviews with this, I got some certifications and made some specialization courses in my free time, I learned what I wanted, and this helped me a lot.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I also have a few years of experience ahead of my former colleagues that didn't do what I did and finished their studies, but I don't regret my decision.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the other hand, some of my colleagues managed to get great internships after finishing their studies at very big, picky companies, where I could potentially go in a year or so, but not as an intern (and a good job).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are a few things you need to ask yourself:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Are you doing the PhD to get a job similar to what you have been offered, or to get a much better job in a few more years, and how big is that difference between what you have been offered now, and what you can find after the PhD ?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;How important is the experience in your field of work ? In more theoretical fields, your PhD can greatly outweigh the experience you can get.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Do you think that money will ever be an issue (since doing the PhD probably doesn't pay), and unfortunately you have to think of this as well.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If you don't do the PhD now - how likely are you to resume it in let's say 5 years.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;How well is the university rated in your country ? (check &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.arwu.org/&quot;&gt;http://www.arwu.org/&lt;/a&gt; )&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, you can go ask your professor at the university and see what he has to say, he probably saw both scenarios (people who quit to get jobs, and people who didn't) - and he/she will probably have some advice for you.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This is as much as anyone can say, after all, it's your life, and your decisions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;PS: I'm 25, so not much older than you :)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Finishing a PhD or quitting and taking a job in industry" AnswerId="frgcnerdApG0eesj1CHj6w==" Author="7410" Date="2013-06-12T16:12:21.847" Text="Of course it's my life and my decision, but I'm very happy with useful input and first-hand experiences like this, so thanks. :) And you answer made me realise the importance of asking myself the question what my motivations are for getting a PhD in the first place. I'm currently contemplating this. ;)/>

<answer QuestionId="Finishing a PhD or quitting and taking a job in industry" AnswerId="l9z7uzt2eo/dWL+fgj48ew==" Author="5962" Date="2013-06-12T16:14:05.610" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;Is your goal to go into industry after finishing your PhD? If the answer is &quot;yes&quot; and the current job is perfect, my advice will usually be to go. If you goal is to go into academia and to become a professor, the job is a distraction and you should pass on it and finish the PhD.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Of course, things vary by field but my general advice, which I believe is true in most (but not all) fields, is that you need a PhD if you want to be a professor but that it is not critical for doing most other jobs. And because PhDs take up time that you could be sending getting work experience and promotions, it may even be harmful for these other pursuits.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Potential students make the wrong comparison when they judge whether or not a PhD is helpful to their career goals. It is common for people to compare themselves without a PhD &lt;em&gt;now&lt;/em&gt; to themselves with a PhD &lt;em&gt;now&lt;/em&gt;. Obviously, the PhD will provide a leg up.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But that's not the accurate comparison because there are opportunity costs to doing a doctorate. The true comparison is between (a) yourself with 4-6 years of experience in industry and no PhD and (b) you with 4-6 years work in a PhD program, no industry experience, and a PhD. In &lt;em&gt;most&lt;/em&gt; fields, (a) is better, or at least not usually worse, than (b).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Doing a PhD includes a lot of effort that goes into navigating and succeeding in an academic environment. If you are going to be a professor, this is important training. If you are not, you are likely better off doing the things you want to end up doing somewhere more appropriate.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10576" Date="2013-06-12T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10576" Date="2013-08-13T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10576" Date="2013-11-07T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10576" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10576" Date="2013-06-12T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10576" Date="2013-06-12T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10576" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10576" Date="2013-06-12T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Finishing a PhD or quitting and taking a job in industry" AnswerId="bjFub9j14x7FeP2nIfb8fA==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-12T11:02:28.013" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;Well, firstly, congratulations on the job offer - you must have seriously impressed them to be offered a position before the completion of the PhD.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, we come to the crux of the issue, the main thing is (and you have no doubt heard this before), but the decision is up to you, and by that, I mean totally up to you.  But, to be a bit more helpful let's look at the information you provided.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You are young and in later years, should you choose to pursue the PhD, it &lt;em&gt;could&lt;/em&gt; be likely that you will be able to have some credits towards a future PhD (this would depend on the college).  If I understand you correctly, you'll be able to get a MPhil?  that will help with the first point (credits towards a PhD) and certainly is recognition of the study you have done so far.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So a couple of key questions you have to ask yourself are:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Which of the job or the PhD will lead you to your goals quicker and in a more enriching way?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;How much would working at this company mean to you?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;and related to the question above, will that opportunity resurface upon completion of your PhD?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Another option, once again depending on the policies of your university is to defer the final year of your PhD or complete it part time, while you work (which is what I am doing).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;- &#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Finishing a PhD or quitting and taking a job in industry" AnswerId="bjFub9j14x7FeP2nIfb8fA==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-12T11:22:48.783" Text="60 hour working weeks are not too bad, been doing it for 6 years (and had a natural disaster, hospital stay, 3 relocations in that time) - it helps build the organisational and time management skills valued by industry and academia alike./>
<comment QuestionId="Finishing a PhD or quitting and taking a job in industry" AnswerId="bjFub9j14x7FeP2nIfb8fA==" Author="7410" Date="2013-06-12T11:17:45.767" Text="Those are some very good questions I am going to ponder over for a while, thank you for the suggestions! Also the part-time option is something I'm seriously considering, with obvious advantage to do two things at once, but disadvantage of a near 60 hour working week for 2 years./>
<comment QuestionId="Finishing a PhD or quitting and taking a job in industry" AnswerId="bjFub9j14x7FeP2nIfb8fA==" Author="4091" Date="2013-06-13T08:58:42.193" Text="@Jelle, you could also talk with your new employer about spending part of the company time on the PhD. If they are in favor of you getting your PhD, they could invest, say, one day a week in this. I know of people in the Netherlands who have done their PhD sponsored by a company, working 50/50 on their PhD and on consultancy work. Of course, completing the PhD would take a bit longer than the nominal 4 years, e.g. 6 years./>
<comment QuestionId="Finishing a PhD or quitting and taking a job in industry" AnswerId="bjFub9j14x7FeP2nIfb8fA==" Author="4091" Date="2013-06-13T08:55:55.223" Text="60 hours work weeks can work, if you choose to sacrifice other things like hobbies, friends, volunteerwork, time spent with spouse/children, etc. And only of course if you really like what you do, at least to some extent./>
<comment QuestionId="Finishing a PhD or quitting and taking a job in industry" AnswerId="bjFub9j14x7FeP2nIfb8fA==" Author="4091" Date="2013-06-13T09:30:13.160" Text="@DamienIgoe but things are different than they would be if you would work 40 hours. I'm not saying you do not have any time, but the time you have left to do non-work things just becomes a lot shorter. It all comes down to choices, and I can imagine people that are happy to work 60-80 hours. For me, this would be impossible to combine with my family life./>

It just takes a bit of getting used to./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10570	<question QuestionId="Publish a thesis that summarizes papers on arxiv - copyright issues" Title="Publish a thesis that summarizes papers on arxiv - copyright issues" Views="168" Tags="thesis,copyright,arxiv" " AnswerId="cAVEU7zKEsYUUYDOYR0EyQ==" Author="6222" Date="2013-06-12T10:34:46.720" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Suppose one has written a master's thesis that summarizes several articles, and works out their details, on a complicated topic. It would be of general interest to have this thesis (in polished form) available for the general public.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Under what circumstances would it be acceptable to publish that thesis on arxiv.org? All sources are cited appropiately, down to each lemma, but I wonder whether rephrasing could actually lead to getting sued for copyright infringement.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Publish a thesis that summarizes papers on arxiv - copyright issues" AnswerId="cAVEU7zKEsYUUYDOYR0EyQ==" Author="6984" Date="2013-06-12T13:28:56.590" Text="As long as you're not copying substantial blocks of text or copying any amount of text without citation, I can't see how this would possibly be a problem./>
<comment QuestionId="Publish a thesis that summarizes papers on arxiv - copyright issues" AnswerId="cAVEU7zKEsYUUYDOYR0EyQ==" Author="4511" Date="2013-06-12T11:21:15.080" Text="As the second part of my comprehensive examination in my PhD, I gave a talk about certain mathematical works and I wrote a review article based on this talk. I have submitted this article in arxiv.org. I haven't encountered any such problems. So if you have cited all your resources, I don't suspect any problem. But I am not an expert in legal issues and I don't know the definitive answer./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10570" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10570" Date="2013-06-12T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10570" Date="2014-04-30T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Publish a thesis that summarizes papers on arxiv - copyright issues" AnswerId="tLhuSOwbKkFL4lmaTTC2IA==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-12T13:46:39.257" Score="8" Text="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;All sources are cited appropiately, down to each lemma, but I wonder whether rephrasing could actually lead to getting sued for copyright infringement.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It depends on what you mean by &quot;rephrasing.&quot;  If you are genuinely writing in your own words and citing everything appropriately, then there is no problem at all.  Copyright does not protect ideas, just how they are expressed, so writing your own version is not copyright infringement.  Academic norms require citation, but it is certainly OK to write expository papers on other people's research.  Your thesis sounds like a valuable contribution that should be made available to the community, and arxiv.org would be a fine place to do so.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the other hand, if by &quot;rephrasing&quot; you mean starting with their text and editing it (rearranging a little, changing some wording, making additions, but keeping the underlying framework), then your paper would be considered a derivative work under copyright law.  I've never heard of anyone actually being sued for this in an academic context, but you might be asked to take down your paper, depending on how closely you followed the original papers.  You might also offend the authors if you copy too much from them, even if there's no legal trouble.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The basic question I'd ask is whether you had the other papers (or near-verbatim notes on them) open in front of you while you were writing yours.  If not, then you should be fine, because everything you wrote came from you.  If you wrote your paper while actively studying theirs, then there's more risk: the fact that you needed to constantly look at their writing suggests you hadn't fully internalized their work.  In that case, you should look through your paper and make sure you didn't accidentally paraphrase too closely.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10573" Date="2014-04-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10573" Date="2013-06-12T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10573" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10578	<question QuestionId="How to read and take notes on research papers" Title="How to read and take notes on research papers" Views="357" Tags="reading,note-taking" " AnswerId="Iy14a7vF+PJ0pK4ivsjt8Q==" Author="6064" Date="2013-06-12T21:07:18.937" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;In each research paper, there are a lot of things that I want to highlight for later use such as definitions, explanations and concepts... While most of them focus on the topic of the paper, there are some relating to a different or broader topics, e.g. a paper about investigating performance of a specific system may introduce different benchmarks and metrics for performance evaluation and explain why those approaches are applicable for this specific situation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Normally, I just highlight all of them, put some notes directly into the paper or using &lt;a href=&quot;http://evernote.com/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Evernote&lt;/a&gt;. However, when I want to look for all highlights and notes about one specific topic, I find it difficult as they scatter in different papers and documents. So, are there any tools or techniques to affectively highlighting important points and group them by topic while reading research paper?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How to read and take notes on research papers" AnswerId="eGd1b1Fms+ozOG2F1cnjNw==" Author="5613" Date="2013-06-14T20:56:46.777" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;This probably isn't an ideal solution; but I still find it to be the most effective in the long run:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I simply keep a log of what I read, and I specifically do this using tex. That way, you will have a searchable document for any words that you may be looking for in your notes. You can also use the &lt;code&gt;makeidx&lt;/code&gt; package to add an index to your text document, which lets you &quot;tag&quot; sections of your documents with various keywords. I also make sure to cite what I read, even if it is for my own purposes. This is especially useful when you are writing a paper, since most of your references will be ready in &lt;code&gt;bibtex&lt;/code&gt; format.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It took me a while to get used to, but I find it very nice to have a well organized research log.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Since requested in the comments, given below is what the log looks like. I don't want it to become a full latex document, but it should be sufficient enough to give you an idea. Note the index markers, which are basically &quot;tags&quot; that don't show up in the text.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;pre&gt;&lt;code&gt;\section{Paper #1 Name, Authors, Date, \cite{...}}&#xA;My summary of the motivation and findings of the paper, or whatever I find interesting/useful.&#xA;May be as short as a few sentences or as long as a page, depending on how relevant it is. &#xA;\index{an important word}&#xA;&#xA;\section{Paper #2 Name, Authors, Date, \cite{...}}&#xA;Same thing here.. \index{another important word or two}&#xA;&#xA;\section{Paper #3 Name, Authors, Date, \cite{...}}&#xA;and so on..&#xA;&#xA;\printindex&#xA;&lt;/code&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Then you can look up your page numbers in the index, which is included at the end of the document. For more information about the package, see &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&amp;amp;rct=j&amp;amp;q=&amp;amp;esrc=s&amp;amp;source=web&amp;amp;cd=2&amp;amp;cad=rja&amp;amp;ved=0CDYQFjAB&amp;amp;url=http://www.ctan.org/pkg/makeidx&amp;amp;ei=rkS_UfmyE9LB4AOUqoDQBw&amp;amp;usg=AFQjCNFSKosvPcHUnkeA1dsO9RiBlBZ5QQ&amp;amp;bvm=bv.47883778,d.dmg&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;CTAN&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/LaTeX/Indexing&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Wiki&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

And I added some information on how to do the index./>

Now, maybe those words are based on what I have read recently because if not there won't be anything to say. Should I for example just comment in what other researchers say which I'm paraphrasing what they wrote or can I also write as if I was talking (words which are based on what I have read)?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How can I make sure that the words I write are my own" AnswerId="33a3HFf6lystN49hghRR2A==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-13T00:06:26.480" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I second @Suresh's remarks, but/and the situation is truly more complicated, as your explanation of your question correctly indicates.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example, complicated, sophisticated things are often so easy to mis-represent that it seems as though there's almost a unique path, a unique narrative, that is correct. And it may be non-trivial to learn what this path is. Thus, in effect, the phrasing of a high authority is not only &quot;burned into one's retinas&quot;, but, also, seems the only correct thing to say.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, first, do &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; try to &quot;say something else&quot;, just for the sake of avoiding &quot;quoting&quot;, because that seeming paraphrase may be wrong, or deficient, or ... &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But, at the same time, extended passages should not be quoted, unless put in quotation marks. It's best to internalize ideas well enough to give &quot;the standard definition&quot; and such things, even if that ends up sounding very similar to other sources. Similarity is inevitable in many cases.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As in many scenarios, honesty is a clarifying criterion. That is, is what you write coming out of your own head, even if it resembles other sources, or are you quite literally copying? The latter is not so good.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10582" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How can I make sure that the words I write are my own" AnswerId="6/5yz5tSNSa966vJiH/wJA==" Author="346" Date="2013-06-12T21:38:10.363" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I don't know what the purpose of your writing is, so the answer really depends on that. It sounds like you're writing some kind of review of prior work (either as a survey or as part of a paper) ? In that case, the goal here is not to regurgitate (in your words or via paraphrase) what others say. Rather, you should be reading what they say and thinking about it (and seeing if you're convinced by it). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Only after that should you even attempt to describe the work. And when you do so, put all reference material away. If you can't describe someone else's work without referring to it, then you don't really understand it yet. In this way you'll ensure that you use your own ideas/thoughts to express what's gone before. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10580" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10580" Date="2013-07-24T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10580" Date="2013-06-12T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10580" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10580" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10583	<question QuestionId="Research Design Help: Measuring the effects of plagiarism intervention" Title="Research Design Help: Measuring the effects of plagiarism intervention" Views="122" Tags="plagiarism" " AnswerId="exewoKiM8hcaa7YDlNypiQ==" Author="7317" Date="2013-06-13T01:39:39.833" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;(Background: I am a full-time EFL instructor at a university in S. Korea. I want to do independent research, as most faculty would not be interested to collaborate with someone who only has an MA.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Korea is known as the plagiarism capital of the world. Since I work with student writers there, I am very interested in the subject. I am trying to devise a research project which can measure the efficacy of plagiarism intervention strategies, namely teaching paraphrasing, summarization, and citation skills. I have done a small literature review and have ideas for getting student perspectives on plagiarism using already validated surveys. However, since I want to focus on effect, I was wondering if anyone had suggestion on how to actually measure this?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I was thinking some kind of pre-test/post-test, but would really love some more ideas.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Edit: to expand on the pre-test/post-test idea, I had thought about giving them a number of short paragraphs which they would need to paraphrase and cite correctly (assuming paraphrasing is a vital referencing skill) pre-intervention and then post.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Research Design Help: Measuring the effects of plagiarism intervention" AnswerId="pzsG0Yscimi/+a3vMZdj0w==" Author="1429" Date="2013-06-13T06:29:12.217" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am just improvising on the fly here but does Korea have software like &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turnitin&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;TurnItIn&lt;/a&gt; which measures (in a few different ways) the level of plagiarism in a particular paper or a set of papers usually from online sources. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you do, then you could think about devising an experiment where, in a class, you inform the students that you will be trying to reduce their &quot;plagiarism tendencies&quot; and take a pre-test perceptions survey. Next, you set a particular class paper as an assignment and note the different measurements on TurnItIn (or equivalent). Then, you make your intervention (in whatever form you choose) and finally set another class paper as an assignment and note the different measurements on TurnItIn this time. Finally, you set a post-test debriefing and follow up survey.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think this would make for a very nice repeated measures model (from the TurnItIn or equivalent data) and some nice latent variable analysis from your surveys.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I hope this helps you in some meaningful way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Research Design Help: Measuring the effects of plagiarism intervention" AnswerId="pzsG0Yscimi/+a3vMZdj0w==" Author="7317" Date="2013-06-14T08:21:41.827" Text="I will have them write short essays at the beginning of the semester as a diagnostic anyway. I suppose if I find a high incidence of plagiarism, I can start there.  What free alternatives to TurnItIn are as reliable? Also, What did you think of my edited idea above? Also/>
<comment QuestionId="Research Design Help: Measuring the effects of plagiarism intervention" AnswerId="pzsG0Yscimi/+a3vMZdj0w==" Author="7317" Date="2013-06-13T09:54:56.370" Text="So you recommend setting a small research paper, and checking for instances of accidental and deliberate plagiarism? I had also thought about this but was trying to find something a little more controlled. This will be their first time ever writing research papers (in English, maybe even Korean) so they may not use outside sources at all (plagiarized or cited)./>
<comment QuestionId="Research Design Help: Measuring the effects of plagiarism intervention" AnswerId="pzsG0Yscimi/+a3vMZdj0w==" Author="1429" Date="2013-06-26T01:36:34.413" Text="Sorry for the late reply. I checked your edited answer. It could work. Basically, we are talking about how you operationalize your theoretical construct. This can be done in multiple ways. I would need to know more about the specific literature in that idea to go deeper. Unfortunately, I do not have that expertise. :(/>
<comment QuestionId="Research Design Help: Measuring the effects of plagiarism intervention" AnswerId="pzsG0Yscimi/+a3vMZdj0w==" Author="1429" Date="2013-06-13T17:17:05.467" Text="As I said, I was improvising. :). This kind of a repeated measures study involving one controllable unit is quite common among the psych or comm scholars that I find myself collaborating with. As you pointed out, there will obviously be issues (like the language choice) that one must address while designing the study. However, if you are interested in this topic (and its a great topic), you must start somewhere, even in an exploratory way. :)/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10585" Date="2013-06-15T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10586	<question QuestionId="General structure of Research Statement (applying for faculty position)" Title="General structure of Research Statement (applying for faculty position)" Views="1178" Tags="job-search,cv,computer-science" " AnswerId="/WYHG6JINJ3Aysw6ap1/DQ==" Author="7092" Date="2013-06-13T10:45:37.173" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'm going to apply for assistant professor positions (in theoretical computer science) soon, and I'm trying to get a feeling for how to write a good research statement. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Should it contain a detailed overview of my (recent?) publications?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If the answer to 1 is yes, should I highlight my specific contributions in multi-author papers - as opposed to &quot;we proved this and that...&quot; ?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If the answer to 1 is yes, I must list the references here that I'm mentioning, which are also stated (in the full list of publications) in my CV, right?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Assuming there's no page limit, what's an appropriate length for a research statement?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My current plan is to group my work into topics and then, for each topic, provide a short overview of the respective papers (&quot;What I've done so far&quot;) and some outlook on some future work (&quot;What I would like to do&quot;). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="General structure of Research Statement (applying for faculty position)" AnswerId="/WYHG6JINJ3Aysw6ap1/DQ==" Author="643" Date="2013-06-13T10:59:37.443" Text="I would have more outlook for future work, and try to provide a coherent, long term theme under/most which all of your work can be described./>
<comment QuestionId="General structure of Research Statement (applying for faculty position)" AnswerId="/WYHG6JINJ3Aysw6ap1/DQ==" Author="102" Date="2013-06-13T11:06:38.643" Text="Related: http://academia.stackexchange.com/q/8369/102/>

<answer QuestionId="General structure of Research Statement (applying for faculty position)" AnswerId="Wz3nSfsladrPxVWpgo50YA==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-13T11:35:46.520" Score="6" Text="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Should it contain a detailed overview of my (recent?) publications?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;NO.&lt;/strong&gt;  It should contain a detailed overview of your &lt;strong&gt;research program&lt;/strong&gt;, including both your past accomplishments and your future plans/vision.  Of course you have to describe your published results in technical detail, but as part of a larger narrative, not as stand-alone pieces.  Focus on the big picture, not on the tiny technical details.  Remember that your audience is &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; just other theoretical computer scientists.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;If the answer to 1 is yes, should I highlight my specific contributions in multi-author papers - as opposed to &quot;we proved this and that...&quot; ?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;NO.&lt;/strong&gt;  &quot;My coauthors and I proved...&quot; is fine.  The public dogma in theoretical computer science is that in every paper, each of the authors contributed 100% of the work, which is why they are listed alphabetically.  You &lt;em&gt;own&lt;/em&gt; any paper that has your name on it.  Your narrative will naturally focus on the parts of the paper that you are the most proud of, which are usually the parts that you worked on the most.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Of course, if you're writing papers with your advisor or other more senior coauthors, there is a natural tendency for people to wonder if your aren't really just riding their coattails.  This is why you need a larger narrative in your statement—to convince the reader that you understand your results at a deeper level than someone who merely &lt;em&gt;read&lt;/em&gt; the papers.  This is also why you have papers with different sets of coauthors—so that the common thread through your work stands out as &lt;em&gt;your&lt;/em&gt; contribution.  In particular, you have at least one paper without your advisor.  Right?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;If the answer to 1 is yes, I must list the references here that I'm mentioning, which are also stated (in the full list of publications) in my CV, right?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The approach I always recommend is to treat your CV as your bibliography, and to include a footnote like &quot;Numbered references indicate papers listed in my CV.&quot;  Of course, this means that your research statement never cites anyone else's work, except in broad narrative strokes, but for a brief document intended to sell &lt;em&gt;your&lt;/em&gt; research program, I think that's appropriate.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Assuming there's no page limit, what's an appropriate length for a research statement?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Aim for three pages.  Less than two is too short.  More than four is too long.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That may not seem like a lot of space, but that actually works in your favor.  You want to give the impression that you've done just &lt;em&gt;gobs&lt;/em&gt; of really amazingly cool stuff, but dammit there just isn't room to write about everything.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="General structure of Research Statement (applying for faculty position)" AnswerId="Wz3nSfsladrPxVWpgo50YA==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-13T15:10:26.060" Text="As a note for those reading these questions who hail from other disciplines: the length of the research statement may vary. In my (mechanical engineering) department, for instance, job postings state that research statements are expected to be five pages long. The length should follow the requirements of the posting, or the norm of your field (whichever is more specific)./>
<comment QuestionId="General structure of Research Statement (applying for faculty position)" AnswerId="Wz3nSfsladrPxVWpgo50YA==" Author="1557" Date="2013-12-16T15:35:07.740" Text="&quot;for people to wonder if your aren't really just riding their coattails&quot; which is fascinating it itself. With some senior researchers writing 10+ papers with different members of their team in one year. It would seem so much more obvious that all the real work (i.e., coming up with the results) is done by the less senior ones... but I guess, as always it depends on both sides./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10587" Date="2013-06-14T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10587" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10587" Date="2013-06-14T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10587" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10587" Date="2013-09-26T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10587" Date="2013-06-13T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10588	<question QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" Title="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" Views="1577" Tags="harassment" " AnswerId="0ui8lV9W0UDdeg8aeFp7wA==" Author="6110" Date="2013-06-13T12:03:39.490" Score="30" Text="&lt;p&gt;Some sexism is obvious, blatant, and/or deliberate. Fortunately, my understanding is that this kind of sexism is &lt;em&gt;mostly&lt;/em&gt; a thing of the past.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, female colleagues have told me that more &quot;benign&quot;, but still harmful, sexism is still very prevalent in academia. In particular, I've heard that implicit assumptions that women are less capable, or more inclined to be teachers than researchers, are distressingly common. As a mathematician, the results are distressingly obvious: most math departments are overwhelmingly male.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What are some ways in which sexism is unknowingly perpetrated by well-meaning people, in academia in particular? And how can those of us who are well-meaning make sure to avoid doing so?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="0ui8lV9W0UDdeg8aeFp7wA==" Author="2692" Date="2013-06-19T06:20:14.943" Text="@scaaahu Good question. I do see many science/math-oriented departments to have more male faculty but my department (business/economics) is quite evenly balanced./>

<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="0ui8lV9W0UDdeg8aeFp7wA==" Author="7158" Date="2014-01-18T04:13:03.433" Text="Sexism can get perpetrated unknowingly by setting up a situation which makes it (almost) impossible to even recognize a potential problem which might exist. A dramatic illustration of this comes as how rape got defined by the FBI for a number of years, and also how rape gets defined today as some commenters here point out. http://feministing.com/2011/10/20/update-fbi-changes-official-definition-of-rape/  It is by no means impossible that male victims of sexual assault by women are NOT encouraged to speak up because of such a definition of rape.  People who ignore this might be rape apologists./>

<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="0ui8lV9W0UDdeg8aeFp7wA==" Author="7158" Date="2014-01-18T04:06:27.580" Text="Sexism can perpetrated by people by having policies that require different standards for people of different sexes.&#xA;&#xA;In order for a male to get student loans in the United States he has to register with the selective service system (which is still a real entity). No female has such a requirement placed upon them in order to obtain such a loan.  Sexism can get unknowingly perpetrated by believing that an educational equity for one sex can qualify as sufficient for both sexes. The Women's Educational Equity Act is one example of this./>

</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="pZDXKIlTNEvxJHNn8WsRpA==" Author="739" Date="2013-06-21T16:09:41.497" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;This is a shaky ground, as a bizzare negative rating of &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/a/10602/739&quot;&gt;Doug Spoonwood's answer&lt;/a&gt; shows. A entirely positive (in the sense of only trying to come up with a meaningful psychological theory; an economics term here) &lt;a href=&quot;http://web.archive.org/web/20080130023006/http://www.president.harvard.edu/speeches/2005/nber.html&quot;&gt;speech by Larry Summers&lt;/a&gt;, then President of Harvard, at NBER conference that promoted gender equality, costed him his presidency... not because he was biased, but simply because the bloody journalists highlighting the event had no clue about math. His argument was very simple: if we look at IQ curves, we see that females have an average IQ about the same or higher than males, and about 20% lower standard deviation. Mother Nature plays conservatively with females while experimenting on males throwing their abilities around. Whichever of these experimental traits the females find attractive are worth retaining through natural selection. So if we look at IQ&gt;80 or IQ&gt;100, we see more females; but at top 5% of the IQ distribution (115 or 120-ish on IQ scale), the ratio is roughly 2 males : 1 female. University professors are likely to be even higher on the IQ scales, probably circa 140+, at which point the ratio may be 5:1 (although of course the quality of the normal approximation in the tails becomes VERY questionable). Other examples Summers gave were underrepresentation of Jews in farming and agriculture, and of whites in the National Basketball Association (which may have to do with biological differences in genetic makeup for height, as well as how the proteins are being processed and muscles are built, between races).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think that conditional on having received a Ph.D. (probability theory term here), there is little difference between males and females in ability to produce meaningful research. Success in academia is dictated by &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19070437&quot;&gt;other personal traits&lt;/a&gt;. They are &lt;a href=&quot;http://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=gender+and+personality+traits&quot;&gt;correlated with gender&lt;/a&gt;, although again conditioning on high IQ/having finished a Ph.D. may change that correlation structure a lot.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Economists argue for distinguishing between the equality of outcomes and equality of opportunities. Do Nordic countries show greater equality of income because they redistribute more, or because they provide better equality of opportunities? &lt;a href=&quot;http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1475-4991.2008.00289.x/abstract&quot;&gt;Read here&lt;/a&gt;. Is stunning income inequality in Brazil the result of discrimination, differential &quot;circumstances&quot;, or what? &lt;a href=&quot;http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=497242&quot;&gt;Read here&lt;/a&gt;. Academia, as any other walk of life, should strive to create equality of opportunities; equality of outcomes may or may not follow, depending on whether the individual traits are correlated with whatever we are trying to equate (gender, hair color, height, language spoken at home, etc.). Forcing inequality of outcomes will aggravate those who have benign better abilities and make people of lesser abilities lose incentives to strive to do better.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If one claims that &quot;women are better teachers than researchers&quot;, just ask: &quot;Hm. That's an interesting observation. We are both scientists; can you give me some references to any peer-reviewed literature on this?&quot; (note that I gave mine above :) ). If they can't, that's a biased accusation you can go to your superiors (chair, dean, university president) with. Just like drivers found guilty driving under influence, and undergoing humiliating driving clinics, whoever makes such claims should be made to go the literature on the cross of psychology, sociology, gender studies and labor markets to dig into the issue -- who cares if they are good in math, if they have big mouth, they should learn to control it. Join your local committee on women in faculty, or whatever the name of that could be in your university to make sure you know the ways that the university can protect you against sexism, and make good use of what you learn there.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="pZDXKIlTNEvxJHNn8WsRpA==" Author="6782" Date="2013-06-23T06:38:46.160" Text="@PiotrMigdal StasK's argument has three parts: (A) Most people with extremely high IQ scores are men, (B) a high IQ is necessary and sufficient to get an academic job, and (C) given A and B we should expect to see more men than women in academia. I took issue with C, because if A and B are true, we would expect more men than women in all academic departments. You're taking issue with B, and I completely agree with you: intellectual skills are not a single number. So we are both saying that the &quot;lower variance&quot; theory is inadequate, just in different ways./>

<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="pZDXKIlTNEvxJHNn8WsRpA==" Author="6782" Date="2013-06-22T04:05:35.117" Text="There is a serious flaw in your argument: if &quot;the ratio may be 5:1&quot; at the university professor level, why don't we see that ratio in *all* academic departments?  At my undergraduate institution, chemical engineering was over 50% female, but computer engineering was about 20% female.  Presumably, chemical engineers and computer engineers have similar intelligence levels, and the entrance requirements were the same, so how do you explain the difference?  I'm not opposed to the idea of biological differences, but the &quot;lower variance&quot; theory does not explain the observable facts./>

Here's Noretta Koertge commentary on Andrea Nye's writing http://www.indiana.edu/~koertge/rfemlog.html .  A few different feminists' writing gets talked about here http://philosophy.hku.hk/joelau/?n=Main.FeministCritiqueLogic  Here's a book review http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/hyp/summary/v017/17.4ward.html  Here's a journal article http://muse.jhu.edu/login?auth=0&amp;type=summary&amp;url=/journals/library_trends/v056/56.2olson.html  .../>

<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="pZDXKIlTNEvxJHNn8WsRpA==" Author="1482" Date="2013-11-13T00:29:55.020" Text="If Summers' argument had been logically and factually valid, then it would have been wrong for him to suffer for it professionally. But his argument was factually and logically bogus. The most serious problem with his argument is that it takes as an assumption an idea that modern psychometricians mostly reject: that &quot;IQ scores&quot; are a valid measure of some innate quality that can be interpreted as intelligence. Furthermore, he assumes the validity of the tests at the tails of the bell curve, which is in fact where they're least valid./>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="pZDXKIlTNEvxJHNn8WsRpA==" Author="7158" Date="2013-06-23T02:40:10.057" Text="@Imi Really, your example that you find hard to explain is computer engineering?  But, that's too easy.  There exists a huge interaction between computer engineering and modern logic.  Exactly how many feminists and even other women try and persuade other women to avoid logic?  Do we not have dozens upon dozens of such feminists and other women?  Aren't feminists very, very well known for attacking logic?  Well, if so, then it comes as easy to explain the difference here.  Not enough women learn or apply enough modern logic to do computer engineering./>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="pZDXKIlTNEvxJHNn8WsRpA==" Author="7158" Date="2013-06-24T16:18:20.727" Text="@Imi You're finding the environment in your CS course uncomfortable is not any sort of evidence of sexism (not that you exactly claimed this).  You also have yet to ask how many boys avoid continuing with academic study of *many* sorts, since males comprise the minority of people who get upper level degrees./>

<answer QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="6782" Date="2013-06-13T23:01:42.423" Score="38" Text="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;And how can those of us who are well-meaning make sure to avoid doing so?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;If you see something, say something.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You're correct that blatant sexism is mostly gone.  I'm a female computer engineer, and I have never been told that I can't do the job because I'm female.  What remains is &quot;death by a thousand paper cuts&quot; sexism.  For example, I was recently at a conference, and the small group I was in was discussing one of the presentations.  An older professor in the group remarked that the presentation was particularly good because the presenter was beautiful and wearing tight clothes.  Nobody called him on it: after all, he was trying to give her a compliment, mentioning it would be rude, he's older and things were different then, and so on.  And it's hard to blame them, because if that were the only sexist comment I heard that day, it wouldn't be such a big deal.  But shortly after that, someone jokingly said I should marry my PhD supervisor.  Then someone said a new tool is so user friendly that &quot;even your mother could use it&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Each of these incidents on its own is fairly mild: most people probably don't even realize they're saying something exclusionary.  Unfortunately, if you're a woman, each one reminds you that you &lt;em&gt;don't belong&lt;/em&gt;, so the cumulative effect is very discouraging.  However, if you correct every person who says something mildly sexist, you get a reputation as a bra-burning feminazi.  As a result, most women keep quiet, or only point out the particularly insensitive comments.  It would make an enormous difference if &lt;em&gt;other men&lt;/em&gt; would call out the ones who make inappropriate comments.  You don't have to be dramatic or rude about it, but a quiet &quot;I don't think that's appropriate&quot; would take a lot of the burden off women.  And naturally, you can try to be more aware of the things &lt;em&gt;you&lt;/em&gt; say to make sure you aren't accidentally discouraging women.  A lot of sexist ideas are so deeply ingrained that otherwise fair and open minded people will say them without a second thought (like the &quot;even your mother&quot; comment).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't want to downplay the other valuable things you can do, such as volunteering at math/science camps for girls, but if enough men followed this rule -- even part time -- 80% of the sexism I encounter would disappear. To modify Edmund Burke's quote a bit,&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;All that is necessary for sexism to triumph is for good men to do nothing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="7158" Date="2013-06-21T19:26:16.330" Text="@BenoîtKloeckner No, I haven't claimed that no problem exists.  However, the problem lies *less* with the treatment of women than with the treatment of men in academia.  As I pointed out in another comment &quot;Ex-professor Sally Miller Gearheart has openly advocated for men to comprise no more than 10% of the population. Dean Catherine Comins has argued that male students can gain from the experience of getting falsely accused of rape, and said &quot;They have a lot of pain, but it is not a pain that I would necessarily have spared them.&quot;  Is anyone in academia saying those sorts of thing about women?/>

Doesn't take too many hints that &quot;one doesn't belong&quot; to get a bad feeling... and spend a lot of mental energy on it, too. Yes, that particular riff to directly or indirectly say &quot;she doesn't _look_ like a mathematician&quot;, with the understanding that mathematicians look like, _are_, nerdy guys? Conceivably meant as a compliment, etc., but emphasizes &quot;differentness&quot; with great force. And that idea that &quot;your mother&quot; can't do what? &quot;Guy stuff?&quot; Hm./>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="7158" Date="2013-06-14T05:21:48.687" Text="&quot;All that is necessary for sexism to triumph is for good men to do nothing.&quot;  Just complete and utter rubbish.  It is equivalent to say that &quot;all that is necessary for sexism to triumph is for good women to do nothing.&quot;  You simply can't create a nonsexist society by focusing only on the problems of one gender.  And you talk about volunteering at math/science camps for girls in the most objective fields of endeavor?  Really?  Do there even exist arts/humanities camps for boys?/>

So yes, &quot;men&quot; was used to refer to all people. The fact that I quoted outdated language accurately doesn't mean that people shouldn't insist on nongendered language today./>

<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="7158" Date="2013-06-14T14:53:38.470" Text="@Imi You indicated you modified the quote.  If you want to modify a quote and believe that insisting on nongendered language makes sense, then it would make sense to modify quotes so that they don't have gendered terms in them.  Consequently, if you do actually believe in insisting on nongendered language, yet have an example like the above, how can I believe anything but that you'll *only* modify quotes selectively to suit some personal agenda of yours?/>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="6782" Date="2013-06-14T15:41:48.823" Text="@T.F. It may not have been clear from my post that I'm currently a PhD student. So the person making the joke was essentially pretending to be surprised that I'm not *already* in a relationship with my supervisor. This implies some unsavoury things about female grad students, and I doubt he would have said it to a male student./>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="7158" Date="2013-06-14T16:02:13.730" Text="@Imi The sentence &quot;all that is necessary...&quot; has *no known* historical context.  The original phrase appears where, by whom, when?  Since we don't know that, it follows that the meaning of its terms is not clear, and consequently only has meaning in our present context.  In the present context &quot;men&quot; is gendered.  So, your argument implies that men by themselves can solve the problem of sexism.  It is false that men by themselves can solve such a problem, and thus your argument is invalid.  Nice try, but you only presented a logical cop-out./>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="7158" Date="2013-06-14T16:04:31.550" Text="@Imi &quot;So the person making the joke was essentially pretending to be surprised that I'm not already in a relationship with my supervisor. This implies some unsavoury things about female grad students, and I doubt he would have said it to a male student.&quot;  No, he's *pretending*.  Once you use have full use of your imagination, there doesn't exist any necessary logical system, and thus it comes as possible that NO implications exist./>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="946" Date="2013-06-23T08:02:40.817" Text="&quot;No, because people in general disregard men more than they do women and send more disincentives to men than they send to men in general&quot; Have you anything to back up such a claim? Numerous studies show that, e.g., the same CV is better considered when it bears a masculine name rather than a feminine name. That is rather important data. What is yours?/>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="7158" Date="2013-06-24T15:56:39.810" Text="To state the last point more clearly, we do have special programs to help women develop their abilities the hard sciences where they are a minority, but basically none for men in the arts and science where they are a minority.  That is extremely important data.  Do you have anything which even comes close in comparing to it?/>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="3849" Date="2013-09-25T22:34:28.333" Text="The concept of microaggression - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microaggression - summarizes your post.  &quot;The presentation was good because of the presenter's clothes&quot;, &quot;marry your advisor&quot; =&gt; microinsult; &quot;bra-burning feminazi&quot; =&gt; microinvalidation/>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="7158" Date="2013-11-11T02:47:17.103" Text="&quot;All that is necessary for sexism to triumph is for good men to do nothing.&quot;  This is *unknowingly* sexist in that it emphasizes only the agency of men, and thus absolves women of responsibility here.  Emphasizing the agency of men and de-emphasizing the agency of women, re-emphasizes traditional gender roles.  The number of upvotes here with such a sentence as its final one further indicates how sexism gets perpetrated unknowingly./>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-14T22:37:52.613" Text="@Imi, time to get away from this... send me email if you wish, it's easy to find./>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="7158" Date="2013-06-23T02:04:33.203" Text="@BenoîtKloeckner &quot;very offensive words from two people are negligible in regard of daily offenses, little disregards, disincentives sent to women, don't you think?&quot;  No, because people in general disregard men more than they do women and send more disincentives to men than they send to men in general.  I have no problem with criticizing Imi's ideas or correcting her when she makes a mistake, just as I have no problem doing the same with men.  To treat people as equals requires that.  I doubt you'd ever say such to me about talking down to a man or complain about correcting a man's error./>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="7158" Date="2013-06-24T15:54:34.710" Text="@BenoîtKloeckner  Please start looking around.  There exists *several* strands of converging evidence which back up my claim (note I said &quot;in general&quot;). There exists more funding for women's health than men's health. In the U. S. there exists an office of women's health, but none for men's health. We don't have men's centers in general at universities, but we do have women's centers.  We do have programs to help women when they have minority status, but we rarely have programs to help men when they have minority status. For instance, we virtually no programs for men in the arts and humanities./>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="2h5HhFQ3qBQum39ewvCJTQ==" Author="7407" Date="2013-06-21T19:01:49.303" Text="@lmi This is a great answer. Comments such as &quot;you don't look like a scientist/engineer/statistician&quot;, while intended as compliments, very much convey the sense of not belonging. I also can't help but note that of all the comments/answers on this post, only you and the OP have account names that are not clearly male. I think this highlights the discomfort that women often face when discussing sexism in academic-type spheres. I know I thought twice before using a feminine name when setting up my account, but women can't be seen as belonging in science or academia until we can be seen./>
