<answer QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="KuYXR2MIc39YtJJJ9x0PTA==" Author="7158" Date="2013-06-14T05:16:43.980" Score="-8" Text="&lt;p&gt;Sexism can get perpetuated unknowingly in all sorts of was via the law.  I suggest studying the book Legalizing Misandry by Katherine Young and Paul Nathanson to see how this can happen.  The law also has all sorts of effects on what happens on college campuses and how sexism either gets continued or abated.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;We know that at present there exist programs for woman to get ahead in academia, because of their gender, but extremely few, if any, in comparison for men. Have you ever heard of a scholarship program that specifically targets boys in the humanities where they are a minority now and have historically come as a minority also?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Men%27s_colleges_in_the_United_States&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;There exist&lt;/a&gt; only three non-religious male colleges in the U. S. &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_colleges_in_the_United_States&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;There exist&lt;/a&gt; many more women's colleges.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There exist women's studies programs, but male studies programs have trouble getting a foothold in academia. Ryerson &lt;a href=&quot;http://theeyeopener.com/2013/03/rsu-rejects-mens-group-on-campus/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;makes&lt;/a&gt; for an interesting example. Sexism, in the form of misandry, has popped up before when a men's &lt;a href=&quot;http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2012/05/20/robyn-urback-on-shocking-anti-male-hatred-on-the-sfu-campus/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;group&lt;/a&gt; formed. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Women &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.prb.org/Publications/Articles/2011/gender-gap-in-education.aspx&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;make up&lt;/a&gt; the majority of graduates in the U. S. in terms of high school degrees, associates degrees, bachelors degrees, masters degrees, and doctoral degrees. Trends also &lt;a href=&quot;http://i0.wp.com/www.avoiceformalestudents.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Four-Graduation-Rates-Degrees-Associates-Bachelors-Masters-Doctorate-by-Sex-and-Percentage-United-States.jpg&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;come&lt;/a&gt; as revealing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, some campuses have a standard of &quot;preponderance of the evidence&quot; for rape cases, which in effect eliminates due process mostly for men, but not for women, and such a standard thus effectively consists of a sexist policy against men. Some other policies can unintentionally end up sexist against men as a study of Daphne Patai's Heterophobia makes clear.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Male sports teams getting cut also comes as another way in which a policy has ended up &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/02/sports/02gender.html?_r=1&amp;amp;&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;sexist&lt;/a&gt; unknowingly.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you want to avoid sexism in academia and elsewhere you need to care about men in general just as much as you care about women in general.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The number of answers which only address sexism against women here, without also addressing sexism against men makes it very clear that you can NOT eliminate or reduce sexism by focusing exclusively on the needs or interests of just one sex.  In fact, that comes as a way to perpetuate sexism. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The key to avoiding sexism lies in fully understanding the plight of both sexes and acting accordingly.  At present it seems that most people have a very long way to go before they come close to understanding the plight of both sexes. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="es80ZfsH04shJGy+I3i8Mg==" Author="1010" Date="2013-09-25T04:26:42.340" Score="17" Text="&lt;p&gt;One issue I've often heard cited involves having a family.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For students on a traditional timeline in academia, the years from age 22 to 36 or so are critical: you go to grad school, get a PhD, perhaps do a postdoc or two, search for and land a permanent job, and finally get tenure.  You have to be constantly advancing and publishing your research, traveling to conferences and seminars, and generally impressing the community in your field.  Odds are you'll have to make at least one long-distance or international move, perhaps several.  Any delay or gap during this time could permanently derail your career.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Coincidentally, the years from age 22 to 36 are also the best time (biologically) for a woman to have children (assuming she wants to do so, and most do).  And bearing and raising a child can certainly put a major crimp in your ability to keep doing the things listed above.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It's pretty clear that this system was designed for men: men with wives who didn't work and could take care of children full-time.  It's very hard on anyone who wants to be an involved parent, and doubly so for the woman: pregnancy, childbirth, breastfeeding, and so on can't very well be delegated or shared!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Universities do tend to have standard-to-generous maternity and family leave policies, which certainly help with this in the immediate term.  What's less clear is whether (possibly male or male-dominated) advisors, hiring committees, chairs, deans, and tenure committees are as understanding in the long run.  If a candidate has a six-month or one-year gap in her research output, and then a slow period afterward as she gets back up to speed and learns to balance her work and family, it's hard to imagine that won't hurt her career, no matter what explanation is attached in her file.  And God forbid she should want to have &lt;em&gt;two&lt;/em&gt; children!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So this is a kind of sexism that's not based on any one person's behavior, but on the structure and norms of the community.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(Disclaimer: I am a childless man and have no personal experience with this issue, but I thought someone should mention it.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="es80ZfsH04shJGy+I3i8Mg==" Author="980" Date="2013-09-25T11:16:17.500" Text="Yes, exactly. Further, there would be the _anticipation_ that a women might/will take time &quot;off&quot; to bear children, even if she's not done so yet, ... giving ammunition to people who'll consciously or subliminally discount her future professional output... on the basis of events which have not yet occurred./>
<comment QuestionId="How is sexism unknowingly perpetrated in academia" AnswerId="es80ZfsH04shJGy+I3i8Mg==" Author="8966" Date="2013-10-11T21:45:12.077" Text="This problem also appears in many other career professions, I understand. Is academia special in this regard? (I frankly have no idea)./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10589	<question QuestionId="Mention engagement for mentally disordered people in application" Title="Mention engagement for mentally disordered people in application" Views="102" Tags="job,university,application,interview" " AnswerId="OUltzYg8YRstGiJx6tG9Uw==" Author="7421" Date="2013-06-13T12:10:09.413" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Im not sure if I am right on academia so please forward this topic to another page if necessary.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A friend of mine is writing her application for a job in research, e.g. studies about medications, diseases etc. Though she has lots of experience and a very good degree (diploma + master thesis) in public health it is not easy for her to find a job.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To increase her chance for an interview she thought about to mention her high engagement for mentally disordered people. She founded a self-help group at the university which is well established and has several dozen members. She does it almost by herself in her leisure time after university and sideline. She herself is not handicapped but has therapies running, but nothing which speaks against working regularly. On the one hand she could point out that she has a high level of soft skills and does a lot work voluntarily. But the problem then is how would an employer react about these facts? Wouldn't he think she has problems herself and therefore isn't a suitable candidate?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think it isn't good either to mention only vague information about this. What should she do?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Mention engagement for mentally disordered people in application" AnswerId="JtH98GxaZitP2Mq/TlzTkg==" Author="7407" Date="2013-06-13T14:59:36.517" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;Many medical research jobs require interfacing with patients, stakeholders, family members, potential study subjects, etc. Therefore, people-skills can be a great asset. Furthermore, it sounds like your friend started a support group on her own initiative and successfully ran this group for some period of time with a fairly large number of person. This speaks to being a 'self-starter', and to good organizational and time-management skills, since she was doing this will completing her degree. The volunteering aspect is not as important as the other aspects, in my opinion since volunteering usually provides evidence of being motivated/'self-starter' which creating the group already emphasizes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My feeling would be that this is a good thing to mention as it highlights several desirable qualities. In my opinion, whether or not your friend has mental health issues is her own personal business and not that of potential employers, unless it requires special considerations, so I would advise her to describe this work without reference to her personal health situation, framing it in terms of interest rather than personal experience - i.e. her interest in mental health issues led her to create this group which she managed for a certain period of time with however many clients.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10590	<question QuestionId="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" Title="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" Views="395" Tags="writing,style" " AnswerId="GxCDZHpP2rnJsmNDC2f6ww==" Author="6222" Date="2013-06-13T14:15:33.747" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Just as the title says: do you spell out Thm., Prop., Eq., Ch. and comparable abbreviations in a mathematical paper?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I suppose that, if in doubt, it is always best to stay consistent (in whatever way) throughout ones writing for the least. Do journals have (different) policies on this, or is there a prefered style when in doubt?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" AnswerId="GxCDZHpP2rnJsmNDC2f6ww==" Author="7424" Date="2013-06-13T23:47:08.203" Text="Assuming you're using `LaTeX` to typeset your papers, you can use the `cleveref` package to help ease this kind of thing :)/>
<comment QuestionId="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" AnswerId="GxCDZHpP2rnJsmNDC2f6ww==" Author="3900" Date="2013-06-13T18:48:04.770" Text="Use macros for them in the document markup; then you can later decide whether or not to expand them without doing tedious search and replace./>

<answer QuestionId="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" AnswerId="KnbqjS7OqsWfRlVp45VRNA==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-14T13:33:02.407" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;One heuristic is to write things as you would read them out loud.  In other words, don't try to save space in print unless you would use the same abbreviation in speech.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example, I'm happy to say &quot;i.e.&quot; or &quot;e.g.&quot; orally in certain situations, so those abbreviations can be fine (indeed, it would sound really weird if you wrote &quot;id est&quot; or &quot;exempli gratia&quot;), but I would never refer to &quot;Sec. 5&quot; or &quot;Eq. 3&quot; when speaking.  Trying to pronounce &quot;Ch. 2&quot; as written would be even worse.  By this standard, abbreviations like NASA or FFT are OK, although they can of course be overused and they may be more cryptic than the writer intends.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This principle extends beyond abbreviations: try not to write anything that would be awkward to read aloud.  (For example, mathematicians sometimes violate this by juxtaposing formulas with no words in between them.)  Of course this is not an absolute rule, but following it will generally make your papers easier and more pleasant to read.  The effects are admittedly small, but if you are explaining complicated or subtle ideas, you shouldn't add to the difficulties with clumsy writing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" AnswerId="KnbqjS7OqsWfRlVp45VRNA==" Author="643" Date="2013-06-14T14:12:37.690" Text="I never speak Latin./>
<comment QuestionId="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" AnswerId="KnbqjS7OqsWfRlVp45VRNA==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-14T18:42:30.443" Text="It's true that you can't necessarily control how the journal will copyedit things, but at least for math journals there's never any need to adopt their house style before acceptance (and even after acceptance you can just let the copyeditors change it)./>
<comment QuestionId="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" AnswerId="KnbqjS7OqsWfRlVp45VRNA==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-14T18:25:29.070" Text="The bits about &quot;Sec.&quot; and &quot;Eq.&quot; probably need to follow the journal you've decided to submit to. Even if you prefer something else, they'll likely adjust it during final processing!/>
<comment QuestionId="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" AnswerId="KnbqjS7OqsWfRlVp45VRNA==" Author="643" Date="2013-06-14T13:50:14.947" Text="Stylistically, I find that e.g., only really works for me when it proceeds a list of items, but not when it is used, for example, in the middle of a larger sentence (such as this one)./>
<comment QuestionId="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" AnswerId="KnbqjS7OqsWfRlVp45VRNA==" Author="7729" Date="2013-07-14T08:44:47.423" Text="In  mathematical writing you might use $\Latex$ and newcommand./>
<comment QuestionId="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" AnswerId="KnbqjS7OqsWfRlVp45VRNA==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-14T13:53:45.343" Text="I agree.  For example, I wouldn't write &quot;E.g., I wouldn't write...&quot;.  By expanding &quot;e.g.&quot;, I meant as &quot;exempli gratia&quot;, not &quot;for example&quot;.  I'll edit to clarify./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10608" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" AnswerId="cp+R7nGYuKB4DqWgM7d3aQ==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-13T15:14:38.267" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;To expand on Dave's answer slightly, abbreviations should follow the guidelines of the specific venue to which you are sending a paper. If they expect no abbreviations, don't use them. If they have standard ones specified, use those as appropriate. Typically, I would only use something like &quot;Prop.&quot; for &quot;proposition&quot; when it's referring to something with a specific number, &lt;em&gt;and&lt;/em&gt; that's what the style guide calls for. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Other abbreviations should be used to improve readability: for instance writing out &quot;fast Fourier transform&quot; one hundred times during a paper can start to get more tedious than using &quot;FFT&quot; as an abbreviation. But shortening individual words should only be done if it makes reading the paper easier, &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; simply to shorten it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" AnswerId="cp+R7nGYuKB4DqWgM7d3aQ==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-14T06:16:02.360" Text="So also says the [American Chemical Society](http://www.amazon.com/ACS-Style-Guide-Communication-Information/dp/0841239991/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1371190390&amp;sr=1-1&amp;keywords=american+chemical+society+style+guide) and a number of other publishers./>

<comment QuestionId="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" AnswerId="cp+R7nGYuKB4DqWgM7d3aQ==" Author="6222" Date="2013-06-13T15:37:20.497" Text="&quot;To make it easier&quot; - thanks for reminding me of that essential principle. One cannot repeat too much./>

<answer QuestionId="Do you spell out Thm Prop Eq Ch in mathematical papers" AnswerId="gSJbY86m5evcfOF0V2yilw==" Author="1010" Date="2013-06-13T15:11:13.327" Score="10" Text="&lt;p&gt;In my experience, authors almost always spell out words like &quot;Theorem&quot;, &quot;Proposition&quot;, and so on. I expect that journal styles will generally require this.  I can't remember the last time I saw a published paper that abbreviated them.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But if you're writing a paper, you must have read a lot of other people's published papers.  Surely by now you've formed your own opinion of the consensus?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10595	<question QuestionId="Is there any difference between journals and conferences which charge money vs those which dont" Title="Is there any difference between journals and conferences which charge money vs those which dont" Views="221" Tags="research,journals,conference,writing" " AnswerId="PEjbSw6LNWM88+SxusfYag==" Author="2823" Date="2013-06-13T17:30:53.823" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Some journals and conferences charge money before/after paper acceptance, similarly there are some which don't (like Open Access Journals). Does money matter in judging such journals/conferences before sending paper ? Unfortunately my organization is on a cost cutting and isn't funding for any such activities. Is there a list of journals which do not charge fees or charge modest fees, so that I can publish there on my own ?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is there any difference between journals and conferences which charge money vs those which dont" AnswerId="PEjbSw6LNWM88+SxusfYag==" Author="1429" Date="2013-06-13T20:01:46.397" Text="agreed. if there are page charges, you do not publish, usually. (field: information science/HCI)/>
<comment QuestionId="Is there any difference between journals and conferences which charge money vs those which dont" AnswerId="PEjbSw6LNWM88+SxusfYag==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-14T03:57:06.630" Text="_Is there a list of journals which do not charge fees or charge modest fees, so that I can publish there on my own?_ — If a journal charges to publish, it's probably a low-quality venue that nobody reads or cites.  So conversely, the journals that you read and cite probably don't charge to publish./>
<comment QuestionId="Is there any difference between journals and conferences which charge money vs those which dont" AnswerId="PEjbSw6LNWM88+SxusfYag==" Author="351" Date="2013-06-14T18:51:17.287" Text="This *might* be useful: http://www.doaj.org/doaj?func=byPublicationFee&amp;uiLanguage=en — Directory of Open Access Journals / Browse by publication charges./>
<comment QuestionId="Is there any difference between journals and conferences which charge money vs those which dont" AnswerId="PEjbSw6LNWM88+SxusfYag==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-14T06:56:46.957" Text="The same applies generally to my field - physics./>
<comment QuestionId="Is there any difference between journals and conferences which charge money vs those which dont" AnswerId="PEjbSw6LNWM88+SxusfYag==" Author="643" Date="2013-06-13T17:36:30.310" Text="I think this might depend on the field. In my subpart of computer science, if the journal asks for money, you don't publish with them./>
<comment QuestionId="Is there any difference between journals and conferences which charge money vs those which dont" AnswerId="PEjbSw6LNWM88+SxusfYag==" Author="1033" Date="2013-06-14T09:13:28.887" Text="I do not agree with your characterisation of open access.  Open access means that there is no charge to access a paper.  There can still be a charge to publish a paper.  For example, open access [journals by the European Geophysical Union](http://www.egu.eu/publications/open-access-journals/) charge for publication *instead* of for access.  Either the money comes from publication charges, or from subscription charges, or a combination thereof./>

<answer QuestionId="Is there any difference between journals and conferences which charge money vs those which dont" AnswerId="Ex6ALg4rpDok8TC92H+lPg==" Author="user7429" Date="2013-06-15T04:31:24.170" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;I must disagree with the CS folks in the comments&lt;sup&gt;†&lt;/sup&gt;. Whether a journal charges or not is immaterial to the quality of the journal. You can only gauge its quality by being an active researcher in that field, not by silly metrics (this is an order of magnitude worse than impact factor).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Different journals from the same publishing house might also charge different rates for publications. For instance, AIP publishes both the Phys. Rev. series (+ PRL) and the J. Acoustical Society of America. While there are no charges for the former set, JASA has &quot;voluntary&quot; charges for publishing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Such &quot;voluntary&quot; charges are very common (some flagship and top-of-the-line IEEE journals come to mind) and serves primarily as an opt-out for researchers from low income countries in Asia/Africa/S. America. Researchers in N. America, Europe and Australia/NZ are &lt;em&gt;expected&lt;/em&gt; to pay the publishing charges, since with the way grants are structured in these countries, there is almost always a specific budget earmarked for publishing costs. Of course, if a researcher has no budget or is publishing in his spare time or as a secondary interest, then they're also welcome to not pay the charges, but I've never seen anyone that's on a grant decline to pay charges.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;sub&gt;† Opinions on this site seem to be overrun by CS folks, who generally state them as facts of life. From my years of experience in a variety of fields, I've found their customs to be more of an outlier than the norm (perhaps only mathematics has something in common).&lt;/sub&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is there any difference between journals and conferences which charge money vs those which dont" AnswerId="Ex6ALg4rpDok8TC92H+lPg==" Author="5912" Date="2013-06-22T14:32:20.193" Text="I know there are good journals which charge money ***after*** acceptance, but are there any which charge money before acceptance? Would your grant pay these charges if they reject your paper?/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10620" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10620" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10620" Date="2013-06-15T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10620" Date="2013-06-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10620" Date="2013-06-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10620" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Is there any difference between journals and conferences which charge money vs those which dont" AnswerId="arRhVGd8Ih16zZJcPFV1fg==" Author="3890" Date="2013-06-14T14:45:27.553" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;Generally speaking, whether a journal charges money for publication or not should &lt;strong&gt;not be a criterium&lt;/strong&gt; for judging the quality of one journal compared to another one. Use other means for that, for example checking where good papers are published, the academic reputation of the editorial board, opinions of colleagues, and, yes, even numeric factors such as the impact factor of the journal.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are very high-quality open access journals, for example the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.plos.org&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;PLoS&lt;/a&gt; series of life science journals, but also no-quality open access journals, for example the ones produced by most of the publishers on &lt;a href=&quot;http://scholarlyoa.com/publishers/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Beall's list&lt;/a&gt;. Some very high-quality non-open access journals ask for page fees (or even submission fees, as I learnt recently), others don't.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am not sure whether there is a specific list of journals which don't require paying fees, or an overview listing publication fees for a range of journals. There is the quite well-known &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sherpa.ac.uk/romeo/search.php&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;SHERPA/Romeo&lt;/a&gt; list, which distinguishes between different levels of self-archiving. I guess most of the green journals (highest self-archiving rating) listed there will be open-access journals and ask for publishing fees, so you could go and check the other journals in more detail, by looking at their instructions for authors.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Is there any difference between journals and conferences which charge money vs those which dont" AnswerId="arRhVGd8Ih16zZJcPFV1fg==" Author="3890" Date="2013-06-14T19:18:29.193" Text="@JukkaSuomela you're right, I clarified this point in my answer. But I assume there will be a high correlation for a journal between being green in the SHERPA/Romeo list and being open access.../>
<comment QuestionId="Is there any difference between journals and conferences which charge money vs those which dont" AnswerId="arRhVGd8Ih16zZJcPFV1fg==" Author="351" Date="2013-06-14T18:47:46.600" Text="The SHERPA/Romeo list is about the self-archiving policies of various journals. It is **not** a database of open-access journals. The &quot;green&quot; journals in the list are **not** necessarily open-access journals./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10609" Date="2013-06-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10609" Date="2013-06-15T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>

academia.stackexchange.com_10600	<question QuestionId="Can I recover after a really bad first year" Title="Can I recover after a really bad first year" Views="757" Tags="university" " AnswerId="pI5AjTNIqIcxqEKaUm7DEw==" Author="7425" Date="2013-06-14T00:55:46.350" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Going into college I had a great record, 3.65 GPA and a 30 on the ACT and about 18 AP and concurrent credits in statistics, calculus, literature, and Spanish. However, trying to balance religious callings and duties during my first year of college left me very unbalanced academically, and as such I failed two major classes, one of which being college, a class that I had already passed in high school and was simply taking to help acclimate myself to the college environment.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The following semester was about the same. I ended up deferring for two years to serve full time under a religious calling, I was able to do this because the university is owned and operated by my church. Going back I am resolved to do better this time, but I am wondering if there is any possible way to wipe away my record of my first year and start fresh again, maybe by applying to a new college instead of transferring, is that possible? Or could I petition on part of my ADHD and Aspergers syndrome for the first year to be overlooked?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Can I recover after a really bad first year" AnswerId="EMGYOTZPZvw6NOJMzdWYbg==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-14T06:24:21.077" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Another big question here is in what classes those bad grades are, relative to your major. IF those are intro classes in your intended major, this is a very, very bad thing, as it will have to be explained to anyone who looks at your transcript (admissions committees or prospective employers). On the other hand, if these are classes outside of your major, while still not ideal, they can at least be viewed as temporary aberrations or difficulties in the transition from high school to university.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Can I recover after a really bad first year" AnswerId="EMGYOTZPZvw6NOJMzdWYbg==" Author="7425" Date="2013-06-17T17:17:35.233" Text="do not think that was too much of a failing, after failing Calc 1 I thought I had enough concept of the university atmosphere that I would fare better in calc 2, I was able to do calc 2 because i had passed the calculus AP test in highschool, however I ended up failing at that relatively early in the semester and could not drop it because doing so would have put me underneath the minimum credit limit for my scholarships. I did do fairly well in my computer classes however, the build of those classes were more familiar to me and I understood the concepts, so I had little trouble with them./>
<comment QuestionId="Can I recover after a really bad first year" AnswerId="EMGYOTZPZvw6NOJMzdWYbg==" Author="6820" Date="2013-06-14T19:58:46.057" Text="I actually disagree with this. For introductory classes in the major, you have the opportunity to show (by going above and beyond in more advanced classes) that the first year was an anomaly, that you do know the material, that you are persistant, etc. For outside of the major classes, it might look like you simply blow off work just because it doesn't interest you. Few employers appreciate the &quot;lazy genius&quot;, and this can be a difficult impression to shake, even if it's not really merited./>
<comment QuestionId="Can I recover after a really bad first year" AnswerId="EMGYOTZPZvw6NOJMzdWYbg==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-15T19:05:05.177" Text="I think we might be talking about matters of degrees. For instance, a student with a 4.0 in the major and a 3.0 outside of it is fine; I'd much rather have that than a 3.0 in and a 4.0 out. . . ./>
<comment QuestionId="Can I recover after a really bad first year" AnswerId="EMGYOTZPZvw6NOJMzdWYbg==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-14T21:17:18.497" Text="As someone who has sat on admissions committees as well as been a student worker processing applications, I can tell you that I've seen comments like &quot;grade in intro chem is _deadly_.&quot; If you fail a class that's considered important, that's a big deal. As an engineer, I don't really care what a person got in music appreciation or French literature./>
<comment QuestionId="Can I recover after a really bad first year" AnswerId="EMGYOTZPZvw6NOJMzdWYbg==" Author="6820" Date="2013-06-15T16:19:20.833" Text="I mostly agree with that, but my point is more that if a student has a bad time in Physics II but then aces their senior E&amp;M course, it *isn't* deadly. I can effectively lobby on their behalf, because something has *changed* and there isn't any clear gap in their knowledge. I don't care what a person got in French Lit either, but if the *student* doesn't care what they get in French Lit, that might indicate personality issues that will make it difficult for them to mesh with the potential advisors they are interested in./>

<answer QuestionId="Can I recover after a really bad first year" AnswerId="4W9m8Hqp4ALdVwuXlaz7dw==" Author="643" Date="2013-06-14T09:20:49.380" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;If you do really well from now onwards, then a couple of poor years can be overlooked, for instance if you are going to apply for PhD studies. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, it seems that the problem is not necessarily ADHD or Aspergers; it seems to be taking on too many different activities. So prioritising your time and commitments during your degree studies seems to be the solution to the problem and then working very hard, not getting the record wiped.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Can I recover after a really bad first year" AnswerId="3PxuRB01/Or+s4qeOTec6w==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-14T03:22:43.817" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;I can tell you from experience that one can recover from a bad first year, though it would be up to the university what options there are regarding your GPA.  Having said that, it is very unlikely that the university would wipe the results without making you repeat the subjects.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You would need documentary evidence for ADHD and Asperger's Syndrome to be considered as reasons for wiping the first year's grades.  Even then, I am doubtful that a university would allow it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A major option is to learn what you can from the first year, apply those lessons as part of your resolve to do better in coming academic years.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10611	<question QuestionId="How do journals and conferences verify if the results in paper are genuine" Title="How do journals and conferences verify if the results in paper are genuine" Views="233" Tags="journals,conference,writing" " AnswerId="ZfJkppReUcSoyUaGW8lFqA==" Author="2823" Date="2013-06-14T19:20:14.193" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;Most of the conferences and journals doesn't ask for code to be submitted along with the paper. How common is it to detect fake or incomplete results in such conference/journal review ? In my field of study in Computer Science, sometimes overwhelming claims are made in some papers, but since the field is still growing, how do reviewers/editors determine the authenticity of the results ? Is it common to ask for code or working demo in such cases.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How do journals and conferences verify if the results in paper are genuine" AnswerId="ZfJkppReUcSoyUaGW8lFqA==" Author="643" Date="2013-06-14T19:29:25.247" Text="Peer review .../>

<comment QuestionId="How do journals and conferences verify if the results in paper are genuine" AnswerId="ZfJkppReUcSoyUaGW8lFqA==" Author="5711" Date="2013-06-14T19:44:15.160" Text="possible duplicate: http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/7602/what-should-raise-red-flags-to-detect-fabricated-data/7609#7609/>

<answer QuestionId="How do journals and conferences verify if the results in paper are genuine" AnswerId="5LKZUmJe8Uj7I6d/AZ2rHw==" Author="346" Date="2013-06-14T19:46:49.683" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;Since you're referring to computer science, I'll talk about conferences. Peer review, as Dave Clarke mentions, is primarily how papers are scrutinized. But conference reviews are often on a severe time constraint. So for an experimental paper, the reviewer looks at the main ideas, sees if the experiments are convincing and handle the cases that the reviewer thinks are important, and evaluates the overall work for &quot;general excitement&quot;. But the reviewer has no ability to check if the work is correct. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In a theoretical paper, a reviewer might skim proofs, and see if the main claims pass a &quot;smell test&quot;. If the result is important, or surprising, the reviewer might try to verify key claims in detail, and expect the authors to argue why their techniques should work. But even there, no formal proof checking happens (that happens in the journal review). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Ultimately, there are two (imperfect) safeguards against incorrect claims:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;author reputation - you don't want to get a rap for writing faulty papers&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;reproducibility - I might reproduce your work, or ask for your code, when writing my papers. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10612" Date="2013-06-15T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10612" Date="2013-06-14T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10612" Date="2013-06-14T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10612" Date="2013-06-14T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10612" Date="2013-06-14T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10612" Date="2013-06-14T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10612" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10612" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10612" Date="2013-06-14T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10612" Date="2013-06-15T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10612" Date="2013-06-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10612" Date="2013-06-15T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10613	<question QuestionId="Do part time degree from reputed institute have market value" Title="Do part time degree from reputed institute have market value" Views="292" Tags="research,university,study,degree" " AnswerId="PF2sNOXO6BwIn3Hv/W6HfQ==" Author="2823" Date="2013-06-14T19:46:59.577" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have recently graduated with Computer Science and Engineering and joined an R&amp;amp;D firm. During the job, I enrolled for a part time MS(Research) from the topmost institute in my country (with reputable world rank). &#xA;Though the only difference from full time course is that we get 1 extra year to complete part time course.Everything else, like the courses, class timings, labs, exams and rigor remains the same. I intend to join academia in future. How valuable is a part time degree with respect to joining academia and industry ?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Do part time degree from reputed institute have market value" AnswerId="PF2sNOXO6BwIn3Hv/W6HfQ==" Author="5944" Date="2013-06-14T20:33:38.800" Text="What country are you from? In most of North America and Europe, a Ph.D is needed to join academia. In some countries the MS is sufficient to get an introductory professor position./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10613" Date="2013-06-14T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10613" Date="2013-06-14T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Do part time degree from reputed institute have market value" AnswerId="MpxRaFZUKXmSm7nvZdL4RQ==" Author="5962" Date="2013-06-14T22:49:29.007" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;The fact that you have done your degree either part or full time will not change your degree's value.&lt;/em&gt; I have never heard of part-time degrees being treated differently from full-time degrees. In fact, it would be unusual to list a part-time or full time status on your CV so it's not clear how people would know. And I doubt many people would react differently.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Your decision to do a degree part-time or full-time has other important implications on your long term goals but they are indirect. If you want to go into industry, choosing a part-time degree might mean you have more time to build up industry experience which might be nice. If you want to go into academia — and you can afford to go to school full time — do the full time degree because work in industry will only slow you down from the pursuit of your long term goal. Being a part-time student might also mean less attention from faculty who might think you are less serious about an academic track while you are doing the degree.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10617" Date="2013-06-15T00:00:00.000/>

As you stated, everything but the time to complete it is the same.  I am in the same boat and I have found that when I apply somewhere, that they are not in the slightest bit concerned about me studying part time.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Look at it this way, once you complete your research degree, you will also have a considerable amount of practical experience, that will speak volumes in your favour.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

Though I was advised to take one semester off to rest physically and mentally (I was extremely paranoid waiting for the pathology report, and luckily it came back benign), I still decided to take all the courses and the heavy research that I had started before. <answer QuestionId="A creepy C in transcript" AnswerId="fTkBTcx2I38QLcUjI6bsww==" Author="2823" Date="2013-06-15T08:25:06.610" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Your final GPA already shows that you have done well in your study and a bad grade in one of the semester or subject wouldn't matter much. Even if you are concerned about your grade affecting the admission chances, you can include in your &lt;em&gt;Statement of Purpose&lt;/em&gt; why you performed badly, what did you learn from that and how did you managed to improvise upon it. Failure is also a learning experience, and if you are applying to a sane school, the admission committee are usually intelligent enough to understand it. Moreover, by describing how you improvised after a bad grade, would reflect your commitment and seriousness.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10622	<question QuestionId="Roleimportance of letters of recommendation for PhD-applications in Europe" Title="Roleimportance of letters of recommendation for PhD-applications in Europe" Views="304" Tags="graduate-admissions,recommendation-letter,europe" " AnswerId="rK91E0WRgBhp/VhV4pjfUw==" Author="6690" Date="2013-06-15T06:57:37.900" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;In the US PhD prospects apply to several universities and those select an amount of applicants from that pool according to how many open spots the universities have for that term. Criteria for admission are GPA, GRE/SAT and research experience documented by 2-3 &lt;em&gt;letters of recommendation&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In Europe the application process is often times quite different in the way, that not a selected number of applicants get admitted each year, but each available research/teaching assistants position is treated individually. Because the requirements differ vastly, a lot of the times the only &lt;strong&gt;formal&lt;/strong&gt; requirement for application is a 'good' or 'very good' masters degree and/or experience in field x or with technology y.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I wonder, are letters of recommendation expected, if so how many, and how important are they actually?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10622" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10622" Date="2013-06-15T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10622" Date="2014-02-12T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10622" Date="2013-06-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10622" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10622" Date="2013-06-15T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Roleimportance of letters of recommendation for PhD-applications in Europe" AnswerId="q23RLspVYZg9i8/JCx4edw==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-15T10:23:47.237" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;We can distinguish two different kinds of doctoral graduate studies in Europe:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Programs through &quot;graduate colleges&quot; and &quot;graduate schools&quot; with centralized admissions policies&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Individual PhD positions in the research group (or institute, chair, etc.) of an individual professor&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In the first case, everything is essentially along the lines of an application to a US-based graduate program, and letters of recommendation still carry the same weight.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For an individual position, letters of reference may be important, but as you suggested, it depends on the individual professor doing the hiring. For some research groups, the posting of an application is a formality, as they're only interested in hiring &quot;internal&quot; candidates (that is, people who have already worked in the group as bachelor's or master's students, and who thus can be &quot;directly&quot; evaluated). For people doing real searches, however, letters of recommendation are also important, because they can provide information about a candidate's research abilities in a way that is not possible just looking at a transcript or set of certificates.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Roleimportance of letters of recommendation for PhD-applications in Europe" AnswerId="q23RLspVYZg9i8/JCx4edw==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-15T19:02:07.183" Text="@gerrit: I've added an additional clarification of &quot;centralized admissions policies&quot; which I hope makes my intention clear./>
<comment QuestionId="Roleimportance of letters of recommendation for PhD-applications in Europe" AnswerId="q23RLspVYZg9i8/JCx4edw==" Author="1033" Date="2013-06-15T17:16:31.210" Text="I don't fully agree.  For example, I'm enrolled in the [Swedish National Graduate School in Space Technology](http://www.ltu.se/research/Utbildning-pa-forskarniva/Forskarskolor/Forskarskola-i-Rymdteknik?l=en).  However, it was still the individual professor who decided to hire me as a member of the research group (in fact, I was a master student at the time).  So I'd say that in at least some cases, the two kinds that you describe are mixed together./>
<comment QuestionId="Roleimportance of letters of recommendation for PhD-applications in Europe" AnswerId="q23RLspVYZg9i8/JCx4edw==" Author="1033" Date="2013-06-16T21:24:04.567" Text="Right, clearer now (:/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10624	<question QuestionId="Do Fall Courses Count in PhD Admission" Title="Do Fall Courses Count in PhD Admission" Views="143" Tags="graduate-admissions,coursework" " AnswerId="nUBRCk0JlA/Twsbf2650pw==" Author="7430" Date="2013-06-15T08:38:52.600" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am currently an undergraduate at a university. I am looking at graduate programs in Mathematics, and if I am applying for math graduate programs for the year 2014-2015, are fall courses (2013) taken into consideration for graduate applications?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If so, could you elaborate according to your knowledge and experiences. I'm sure this question is applicable to other graduate programs other than Mathematics, so any comments pertaining to this question would be appreciated.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Do Fall Courses Count in PhD Admission" AnswerId="nUBRCk0JlA/Twsbf2650pw==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-15T09:34:37.410" Text="where are you considering applying to?/>

<answer QuestionId="Do Fall Courses Count in PhD Admission" AnswerId="uws0kLCr/P494fxBgmrvYQ==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-15T10:26:36.780" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;The easiest way to tell if fall grades will be taken into account is to &lt;em&gt;look at the application instructions&lt;/em&gt;. If you see instructions asking you to provide your mid-year grades, then that's a pretty clear indication that they will be taken into account during the admissions process. If you are not asked to submit it, then follow that guideline. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If it's &lt;em&gt;optional&lt;/em&gt; for whatever reason, I would assume that you should plan as if it were a mandatory submission. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10629	<question QuestionId="How much code to include in a Physics paper" Title="How much code to include in a Physics paper" Views="319" Tags="phd,publishing,code" " AnswerId="cHbxvbgZ0+PEKjlpS3c2qA==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-15T13:47:18.083" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;This question is related to Physics research papers, particularly one that will be coming up for my ongoing PhD research (4th paper in all).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A core part of the research is developing, testing and validating relevant self-written code.  So, my question is how much of the code should be included in the upcoming paper?  Should it be the whole thing, or a written summary of the main components/subroutines used?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How much code to include in a Physics paper" AnswerId="cHbxvbgZ0+PEKjlpS3c2qA==" Author="285" Date="2013-06-18T09:28:30.360" Text="I think that if you are discussing the code or using it to illustrate a point, it can go into the paper, but preferably only snippets. If not, it should be in a repository somewhere where people can download it, eg github bitbucket or similar. If you put a lot of code in the paper it adds clutter, making the paper harder to read, and is also harder for people to run the code. I mean, cutting and pasting code from a document is no fun./>
<comment QuestionId="How much code to include in a Physics paper" AnswerId="cHbxvbgZ0+PEKjlpS3c2qA==" Author="49" Date="2013-06-23T17:44:01.937" Text="Regardless of the content of the paper, it would be great if you uploaded your whole working code to [GitHub](https://github.com) (with some full examples of usage)./>
<comment QuestionId="How much code to include in a Physics paper" AnswerId="cHbxvbgZ0+PEKjlpS3c2qA==" Author="81" Date="2013-06-18T14:14:35.073" Text="You might also try asking on scicomp.SE./>
<comment QuestionId="How much code to include in a Physics paper" AnswerId="cHbxvbgZ0+PEKjlpS3c2qA==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-15T21:34:36.273" Text="Yes, and we're both wondering, as we've seen papers that include some code, some that included all code and some that had details of the main subroutines used./>

<answer QuestionId="How much code to include in a Physics paper" AnswerId="UXIir0E/sy6rzPBzaDR3yg==" Author="10233" Date="2013-12-24T14:42:16.270" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Another option, in the field of astrophysics, is to submit your code to a repository, and register it in the Astrophysics Source Code Library (ASCL) at &lt;a href=&quot;http://asterisk.apod.com/wp/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://asterisk.apod.com/wp/&lt;/a&gt;, which is indexed by the SAO/NASA's Astrophysics Database System (ADS), the official compilation of literature (and now source code and datasets) in astrophysics.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If that's your case, you look at this link to find out how to submit your code to it: &lt;a href=&quot;http://asterisk.apod.com/wp/?page_id=14&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://asterisk.apod.com/wp/?page_id=14&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The page has additional resources telling you how to cite said codes, and this is what a citation might look like:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Garrido, J. et al., 2013, AstroTaverna, Astrophysics Source Code Library, record ascl:1307.007&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="15037" Date="2013-12-24T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How much code to include in a Physics paper" AnswerId="3UPwP1XqhMGP16gakXSQRA==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-15T19:21:55.660" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;If the goal of your paper is to show that your code solves a particular problem or performs a specific task, then it is your responsibility to prove to the reviewers that your code does what it claims to do. The easiest way to do this is to include the code as part of the supporting information for your paper. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, &lt;em&gt;reproducibility&lt;/em&gt;—which is what you're asking about, to a certain extent—is a not-so-simple question when it comes to showing codes do what they're supposed to. For instance, a code that runs one way under one configuration may return a slightly (or perhaps _very) different result when run under another configuration. This doesn't mean that one result or the other is wrong—it just means that this behavior needs to be taken into account when evaluating the correctness of software.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One way to help this is to provide as much information as possible on your testing environment, so that any differences between the system on wich you were working and the conditions the reviewers and future potential users of your code will have can quickly be identified. This would be included, perhaps, as a text file that accompanies the code in the supporting information.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How much code to include in a Physics paper" AnswerId="3UPwP1XqhMGP16gakXSQRA==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-16T06:33:59.423" Text="very good points, particularly on the testing environments - which would not only be the 'external' environment (field testing etc), but also the 'internal' environment - each subroutine of the program itself./>
<comment QuestionId="How much code to include in a Physics paper" AnswerId="3UPwP1XqhMGP16gakXSQRA==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-16T14:53:58.810" Text="@NPcompleteUser: The issue here is that there might **not** be a bug in the code, but simply how the code was compiled and executed could make a substantial difference. In my field, for instance, you will likely get very different outputs if you run on different numbers of processors—although the long-term averages you get should still be consistent. So you can't simply say &quot;my run does not agree with yours, therefore the code doesn't work!&quot;/>
<comment QuestionId="How much code to include in a Physics paper" AnswerId="3UPwP1XqhMGP16gakXSQRA==" Author="6346" Date="2013-06-16T14:01:38.517" Text="As long as there is input and output should be easy to debug the code. Of course, THERE ARE EXCEPTIONS.../>

<answer QuestionId="How much code to include in a Physics paper" AnswerId="3CpG+0SB13lHcweOXLRyDg==" Author="6820" Date="2013-06-15T15:57:20.783" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would second @NPcompleteUser's answer about having the code and some sort of walkthrough for reproducing your results online. However your question about how much to include in the &lt;em&gt;paper&lt;/em&gt; is very journal specific. There are a number of publications specifically for computational science with formats where large chunks of code are expected, but if it's a journal whose focus is more on the science than the techniques, I would just describe in words the tricky parts of your algorithm and give a footnote reference to the website where the code lives.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

Providing inputs and gnuplot (matplotlib/whatever) scripts for graph reproduction.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How much code to include in a Physics paper" AnswerId="/3RZwh+PocEQYRdbgDmsbg==" Author="4503" Date="2013-12-25T22:30:43.090" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Papers on physics which utilise code should primarily describe the algorithms and their relevance to the physical problem at hand, and not focus on nuts and bolts of the code. There are several reasons for this: the printed article is the wrong place to include code, as page space is generally limited and not suited to formatting of code; there are issues with copyright as in most cases the ownership of the code is transferred to the journal, or if open access then put in the public domain; generally the audience of a paper should be broad enough to be useful to a wider range of researchers than your specialist area.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As others have suggested, you should release your code on GitHub or similar and apply a suitable licence, and simply refer to it in the paper. There are some exceptions to including code in a paper, generally when understanding the algorithm is essential for the reader or complicated, in which case pseudo code is acceptable since the essential information is included without any language specific distractions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="15062" Date="2013-12-25T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10636	<question QuestionId="Is it common to ask students to help the teacher in the teachers normal duties" Title="Is it common to ask students to help the teacher in the teachers normal duties" Views="402" Tags="teaching,ethics,students" " AnswerId="2hwOl/vuuFbNk2PnTr8Aww==" Author="2692" Date="2013-06-16T08:07:45.387" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;It seems quite common for other teachers at my university (in Asia) to have students help with what are the normal duties of a teacher. Examples range from asking a student to help carry one of many stacks of books (because the teacher cannot carry all of them) to asking students to carry very small things (which the teacher could easily carry but the teacher would prefer not to carry anything at all and let the student do it) to having students complete marking sheets for graded assignments (where the teacher has already decided what the marks should be but prefers to have a student do the typing and printing).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It's very strange for me because I've never seen it in my own culture (which doesn't mean it doesn't happen), but I'm not Asian so perhaps I'm just not yet adjusted to the local culture.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Do most universities allow a teacher to put some of the teacher's regular duties on the shoulders of some students? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note: This has nothing to do with teaching assistants, I'm just talking about regular students who appear willing to help (either to learn/understand more, to get in good graces with the teacher, or perhaps for other reasons I cannot see at this time).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;[EDIT]&lt;/strong&gt; I've modified the questions slightly away from ethics towards being common due to concerns from other users feeling it was too much of a discussion / opinion question.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Is it common to ask students to help the teacher in the teachers normal duties" AnswerId="I+eYzOhHoLbppJjviVsovA==" Author="6690" Date="2013-06-16T10:39:21.607" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I can only provide &lt;strong&gt;anecdotal&lt;/strong&gt; value from the 3 european universities I attended up to this date and from what I heard from others.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It is not common at all to do this here.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;It would however not be a problem to ask for help &lt;em&gt;occasionally&lt;/em&gt; either. If a professor did this regularly, especially if it would affect the grading process, problems would arise very soon as students would not be fine with this and intervene by talking to other professors or the director etc etc.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I believe this can only work in cases where the students massively respect or depend on the professor, right? Because if a professor was known to ask students to help them outside of the classroom, most students would probably have better things to do and find an excuse when asked.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Is it common to ask students to help the teacher in the teachers normal duties" AnswerId="4AccqRn0l/GZ0sZcoQFMIQ==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-16T12:46:22.423" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;It is highly unusual for &lt;em&gt;students&lt;/em&gt; to be asked to take part in teaching duties such as the ones you have ascribed. It would be unusual to ask someone to help with &quot;mundane&quot; or &quot;brute force&quot; tasks—although you could see asking anyone to help out in such circumstances, so I wouldn't think much of being asked to move books or other materials, if the individuals just happened to be standing there at the time.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As for grading and more &quot;official&quot; tasks, I think it would be &lt;em&gt;highly&lt;/em&gt; inappropriate to ask a student to prepare the list of grades, or to assist in grading, if the student is actively enrolled in the course. That is because you are then placing those students in a position of authority over their fellow students, and potentially creating a conflict of interest. Note that this does &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; preclude the use of &quot;graders,&quot; as they are not also enrolled in the class at the time. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10639	<question QuestionId="How to reference confidential data in reference list" Title="How to reference confidential data in reference list" Views="487" Tags="references" " AnswerId="HJtn/GhpiUB44vriw4NfMQ==" Author="7438" Date="2013-06-16T11:33:08.973" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'm writing my BA thesis in computer science at a larger company and need to reference a confidential statistics report that has been made available to me in my reference list.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So my question is, how does one normally cite a confidential source? I assume you would somehow include the contact details of someone at the company with access to the material?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'm using the Vancouver reference style by the way. Cheers!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Edit: I should clarify that the confidential &quot;report&quot; that was made available to me really isn't a report, but rather just raw data. It doesn't have an author or even a title, only site visitor statistics, thereby my confusion on how to reference it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How to reference confidential data in reference list" AnswerId="NgSwEBkcbKA/Uv8uP1K86w==" Author="6984" Date="2013-06-16T16:42:09.157" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;It may be best to just cite the source as if it were any other reference, then include in your acknowledgements and/or a footnote more details on how you acquired the data and who to contact if it is indeed available to others.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10642" Date="2013-06-16T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How to reference confidential data in reference list" AnswerId="UIvfdMf4EGPm7No95JZZpw==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-16T12:49:45.580" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Before you do &lt;em&gt;anything&lt;/em&gt; with the confidential data, you should have cleared its use with the company in question. Giving away the data in any form without their express permission could get you into a lot of trouble.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That said, if the report containing the data is a internal company technical report, it should be cited as such in a bibliography. This provides enough information for a person to track it down, although you may want to state that it is not available to the general public.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to reference confidential data in reference list" AnswerId="UIvfdMf4EGPm7No95JZZpw==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-17T09:49:26.737" Text="Normally, it's just the name of the individual and the date of the communication. But that depends on the bibliography style./>

<comment QuestionId="How to reference confidential data in reference list" AnswerId="UIvfdMf4EGPm7No95JZZpw==" Author="7438" Date="2013-06-17T05:43:03.597" Text="Thanks, this is a great help. The work I'm doing is in web optimisation and about finding ways to optimise the company's web site. The data was given me in a personal meeting and was a csv file detailing site statistics, which  I use to decide in which browsers to test the optimisations. I'm not allowed to directly quote the data in the thesis, but instead make statemenets like &quot;IE9, Firefox and Chrome are the three most common browsers used to access the site and therefore the ones that will be tested&quot;. So what information do I give in the references, the person in question's name and email?/>
<comment QuestionId="How to reference confidential data in reference list" AnswerId="UIvfdMf4EGPm7No95JZZpw==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-16T20:49:36.723" Text="Well, now it becomes the dreaded &quot;Personal Communication.&quot; You cite the sender, and the date of the communication. Obviously, someone might ask for this, in which case you will need to redact the data, but show that the correspondence took place. (Unless you can't even do that—in which case that data probably shouldn't be in the thesis in the first place!)/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10643	<question QuestionId="Half good and some not good results in a research paper" Title="Half good and some not good results in a research paper" Views="260" Tags="conference,writing" " AnswerId="BNa23rjTMqqa0Pb/2ryQyw==" Author="6144" Date="2013-06-16T22:47:04.463" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have made some research about a computer science topic. The initial idea seemed good, but when I implement the idea; this works in some cases and in some others it does not bring conclusive results.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;How can I write a paper about this subject in particular? I mean, I do not want to hide the bad results. I want to include them, but I feel scared that my paper could not get accepted because of that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I was thinking also to submit it in a not so prestigious conference, but also I do not see any advantage on doing so.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Half good and some not good results in a research paper" AnswerId="BNa23rjTMqqa0Pb/2ryQyw==" Author="8966" Date="2013-10-12T03:24:43.713" Text="Points similar to the answers are also covered by Dick Hamming's [You and Your Research](http://www.paulgraham.com/hamming.html), which is a great read anyway./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10643" Date="2013-06-23T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10643" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10643" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>

</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Half good and some not good results in a research paper" AnswerId="0ptIaZUqW6aWfLezbhdDtA==" Author="346" Date="2013-06-18T01:53:25.590" Score="10" Text="&lt;p&gt;It's important to remember that a paper is supposed to make some kind of contribution. It's not merely a report on &quot;things you did&quot;. So if you have some good results and some inconclusive results, what's the contribution ? As sr3u says, you need to work out what's going on and come up with some answers. It's entirely possible that you fail in this endeavour and end up with NO paper. That's not fun, but it's something that you must accept as a possibility. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10657" Date="2013-06-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10657" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10657" Date="2013-06-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10657" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10657" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10657" Date="2013-06-23T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10657" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10657" Date="2013-06-23T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10657" Date="2013-06-23T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10657" Date="2013-06-28T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Half good and some not good results in a research paper" AnswerId="WGE6Qv/x1JYg5vyeENwraA==" Author="6448" Date="2013-06-17T02:17:10.647" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;It would be good to dig a bit deeper and analyze why the idea works in some cases and not in some others.  More than the fact that your idea seems not to work in some cases, a conference PC may be less than impressed by the fact that you have not worked out all its ramifications and clearly identified the structure of the problem for which it is good.  In all CS research conferences and journals of some reasonable quality, it is the responsibility of the author(s) to present ideas as well as to work out their consequences in some depth -- it is in general not acceptable to present a bare idea (or an idea not thought through properly) with the expectation that the audience/readers will take it forward on their own.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Presenting more analyses would also make your submission stronger by adding some other theoretical results to the paper.  You could also identify future research directions for addressing the cases not covered by your current work, which could add gravitas to your current paper as well as suggest your own future direction.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10644" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10646	<question QuestionId="Overcoming nerves from anticipating conference questions" Title="Overcoming nerves from anticipating conference questions" Views="554" Tags="conference,presentation" " AnswerId="mZCZgmAhoDJw4mV9koZqGw==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-17T09:38:48.713" Score="14" Text="&lt;p&gt;My field is atmospheric physics.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The irony is that I have been a school teacher for over a decade, but soon, I'll be giving a presentation of some of my findings at a conference.  I think that the nerves stem from speaking about my own research in front of my peers - something that I have not done to a large audience.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The questions that will no doubt be ask fill me with anticipation in both positive and negative ways.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Asides from being prepared, making sure the presentation is seamless and that I have a good night's sleep beforehand and 'knowing my stuff' inside and out.  What are some strategies to anticipate the type of questions that would likely arise from a conference presentation?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Overcoming nerves from anticipating conference questions" AnswerId="mZCZgmAhoDJw4mV9koZqGw==" Author="546" Date="2013-06-17T09:53:42.597" Text="Have rehearsal in front of your colleagues would help./>

<answer QuestionId="Overcoming nerves from anticipating conference questions" AnswerId="v6uFzv1JciJzA708orAabQ==" Author="2827" Date="2013-06-19T10:26:44.547" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;There is absolutely nothing wrong with not knowing the answer to a difficult question; if we know the answers to all the questions, then by definition it isn't research.  Being comfortable with not knowing the answer should help with nerves.  The questions are generally asked out of genuine interest, rather than as a test, so the person asking the question is not necessarily expecting you to have a good answer anyway. User168715's suggestion (+1) of saying &quot;I don't know offhand, but I'd be happy to chat more off-line&quot; is a good one&quot;, and is a good way of exchanging ideas with others interested in the same sorts of work as yourself.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10680" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Overcoming nerves from anticipating conference questions" AnswerId="AxyqG3svawrRqFxv3mzjUQ==" Author="6862" Date="2013-06-17T17:58:04.950" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;In addition to strategies for anticipating questions, I thought it would be helpful to suggest how to cope with the nerves. I find that it sometimes helps to remind yourself a couple of things:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Remember that you have been working and thinking about your specific question probably more than most people hearing the talk - they are just hearing about your work for the first time. Even if there are important and smart people in the audience, &lt;strong&gt;you are the expert on your work&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Personally, I find that I am similarly anxious before giving talks regarding my work. However, it somehow always plays out fine - the atmosphere is usually relaxed and the questions tend to be either simple clarifications or interesting discussions. I suspect I am not the only person who experiences this.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Overcoming nerves from anticipating conference questions" AnswerId="AxyqG3svawrRqFxv3mzjUQ==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-18T10:18:11.537" Text="Yes, in the smaller scale speeches I have given, this tended to happen.  I switched into 'teacher mode' (my day to day job)/>

<answer QuestionId="Overcoming nerves from anticipating conference questions" AnswerId="egzEtYjrhFS1cNHScJslkg==" Author="5596" Date="2013-06-19T01:10:38.143" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Most of the questions you'll receive will either 1) ask for clarification about your methodology/results, or 2) suggest avenues of future work. Questions of the first kind are usually very easy (presumably you did the research and know the answer ;) ) and the second kind can be very helpful for identifying new research directions and collaborators! If you've already thought about the proposed direction, obviously chip in any insights you might have, but if not, &quot;that's an interesting suggestion, and something I'd be interested in looking at in future work&quot; is all you really need to say.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There are only a few realistic ways the Q&amp;amp;A session can go off of the rails. You might get questions like&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;How does your work compare to [Foo et al 2003]&quot; (you have no idea who Foo is or what his method does)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;Does your work account for (some factor you don't understand)?&quot;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;How might your work apply to (some area you know nothing about)?&quot;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can fall into the trap of feeling that you &lt;em&gt;should&lt;/em&gt; know the answer, and that admitting ignorance is embarrassing... but the worst thing you can do is to bluff or make stuff up. If people &quot;smell blood in the water&quot; and get the impression that you are being misleading, they &lt;em&gt;will&lt;/em&gt; come back with even more hostile questions. Instead, remember that you are in control of the conversation, and hold the ultimate trump:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;Unfortunately I'm not familiar offhand with the method of Foo et al, but I'd be happy to chat with you offline about it after the session.&quot;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;I don't know offhand, but I'd be happy to chat more offline.&quot;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;Unfortunately I'm not too familiar with (area X), but I'd love to talk to you later about possible applications of my work there.&quot;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10672" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10672" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10672" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Overcoming nerves from anticipating conference questions" AnswerId="d8KZNSB0dUpQx0+hPUvKuQ==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-17T09:54:20.113" Score="12" Text="&lt;p&gt;There are a few obvious questions to ask yourself in planning for questions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;What are the inherent weaknesses in the current work? (Almost no research is completely &quot;airtight,&quot; so figuring out where the weak spots are will make a difference.)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;What are the ramifications of whatever assumptions I have made? Are they logical? What happens if I strengthen, relax, or eliminate some of those assumptions? Will everything still work in the more general (or more restricted) case?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;How would I apply this work to other problems? How will it help others in the field?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;And then, with respect to the presentation:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Have I left anything out in the interests of time that would potentially interest the user? Is the research methodology clear? &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If there's anything in the last point, you may want to plan on having additional &quot;backup&quot; slides which highlight that info, but that aren't part of the &quot;main&quot; talk.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Overcoming nerves from anticipating conference questions" AnswerId="d8KZNSB0dUpQx0+hPUvKuQ==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-17T10:00:48.407" Text="Thank you for this, (+1).  I totally agree that there is no such thing as an 'air tight' research, and the additional backup slides would logically have information pertaining to your first 3 points./>

<answer QuestionId="Overcoming nerves from anticipating conference questions" AnswerId="sQSkzaTp0j4sxyQmi5FMUw==" Author="643" Date="2013-06-17T10:33:05.990" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;One strategy to adopt when answering questions is to first repeat back the essence of the question to the questioner:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;If I understand correctly, you are asking ....&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This will have two effects. Firstly, it ensures that you are actually answering the correct question. Secondly, it will buy you a little bit of time to gather your thoughts and think a bit about an answer.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Take your time when answering questions, rather than rushing to the first answer that pops into your head. In the end, it is okay to say, &quot;I don't know&quot; or to ask to discuss the question off-line, but the latter can seem like a bit of a cop-out. Try to answer the question, but only if the message is not getting through can you suggest to take it off-line.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But the real key is to practice your presentation extensively. If you deliver a good presentation and you know it, you will feel great and thus comfortable to answer questions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Overcoming nerves from anticipating conference questions" AnswerId="sQSkzaTp0j4sxyQmi5FMUw==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-17T10:34:42.270" Text="Similar in effect to a well prepared and executed lesson./>
<comment QuestionId="Overcoming nerves from anticipating conference questions" AnswerId="sQSkzaTp0j4sxyQmi5FMUw==" Author="5674" Date="2013-06-17T11:57:52.180" Text="really good advice/>
<comment QuestionId="Overcoming nerves from anticipating conference questions" AnswerId="sQSkzaTp0j4sxyQmi5FMUw==" Author="6661" Date="2013-06-17T14:14:33.890" Text="On a side note, repeating the question also makes sure the rest of your audience knows what the question was. If someone in the front asks a question (without a microphone), the people in the back will most likely not have heard it./>
