academia.stackexchange.com_10649	<question QuestionId="Advantages of second marking" Title="Advantages of second marking" Views="166" Tags="assessment" " AnswerId="aEols2QtLPEMDOuNRaew8g==" Author="929" Date="2013-06-17T12:24:37.223" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;In the UK a portion, and in some cases all, work is &quot;second marked&quot; where an independent marker also marks the work. In cases where the 1st and 2nd marker disagree, a 3rd marker may be used. Finally, the entire work of each student over the course of his/her studies is evaluated by an exam board with (sometimes) 2 additional independent markers. These exam board markers tend to only consider cases that are on the border of different degree classifications.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;From my understanding of statistics, having all of these different markers will regress marks towards the mean. As I am currently faced with the daunting task of 2nd marking a large stack of off topic papers, I am curious what are the advantages of second marking?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Advantages of second marking" AnswerId="aEols2QtLPEMDOuNRaew8g==" Author="929" Date="2013-06-17T12:50:06.343" Text="@AndyW presumably because the noise at the high and low ends is not zero mean. If markers will not/cannot give a mark higher than an A, A work will sometimes, because of noise be marked as A-, but never marked as A+ (since the A+ mark doesn't exist). Similarly, F work will sometimes be marked as D- but never as F- (again assuming F is the lowest mark). Meaning that with enough markers no one will get an A or an F, which seems like regression towards the mean to me./>
<comment QuestionId="Advantages of second marking" AnswerId="aEols2QtLPEMDOuNRaew8g==" Author="3" Date="2013-06-17T12:55:48.723" Text="@DanielE.Shub, that is reasonable, although presumes a negative correlation between the rating and the true score (which would violate the assumptions of classical test theory). It is not the same as regression to the mean, and like I said the literature on classical test theory would be of interest./>
<comment QuestionId="Advantages of second marking" AnswerId="aEols2QtLPEMDOuNRaew8g==" Author="929" Date="2013-06-17T12:54:23.910" Text="@scaaahu apart from marking fatigue, I don't think it matters since you often you split the stack in half with someone else and then swap after you have both &quot;1st marked&quot;./>
<comment QuestionId="Advantages of second marking" AnswerId="aEols2QtLPEMDOuNRaew8g==" Author="3" Date="2013-06-17T12:34:55.893" Text="What understanding of statistics suggests it will regress to the mean *of the population*? See literature on [reliability and classical test theory](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reliability_(psychometrics)#Classical_test_theory). If you consider the outcome scoring of the test to be a function of the true score plus random error, having multiple raters will provide an estimate of the true score, with more graders providing a more reliable estimate./>
<comment QuestionId="Advantages of second marking" AnswerId="aEols2QtLPEMDOuNRaew8g==" Author="643" Date="2013-06-17T12:39:10.150" Text="To keep academics off the streets./>
<comment QuestionId="Advantages of second marking" AnswerId="aEols2QtLPEMDOuNRaew8g==" Author="546" Date="2013-06-17T12:46:26.737" Text="@DanielE.Shub You already know you're second marking the papers. What if you did not know that and think you're the first marker?/>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10649" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10649" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10649" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10649" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10649" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10649" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10649" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10649" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Advantages of second marking" AnswerId="z15KYwNqh+FZGA9ndlrHRA==" Author="2692" Date="2013-06-18T10:43:05.000" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;Like the other answers, I don't think it is an issue of regression to the mean (in the sense that the mean is the mean of all the students in the module). It is an issue of finding the true quality of the student's work.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In my current university we do sampling in that one marker will check maybe 1/3 of another marker's work. The point here is clearly not to catch every mistake a marker might make but rather to check for signs of abuse of power. Because everyone marking knows that &lt;em&gt;some&lt;/em&gt; of their marks will be checked by another is supposed to keep the original marker from giving inappropriately high or low grades to any students, since the marker does not know which of the marks will be checked (admins actually do the selection of the sample).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I've worked at other universities where all work is double marked and in this case my experience is similar to Peter Jansson's.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Again, as I see it, the purpose of double marking (whether full or sampling) is to simply make sure that the student is getting marked fairly. Unfair marks can happen with intent (bad marker) or on accident (marker interpreting an ambiguous question differently from the student).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10662" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10662" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10662" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10662" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Advantages of second marking" AnswerId="IdB03TcNB5LHRNjVGS41/Q==" Author="4394" Date="2013-06-17T13:52:36.693" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;I will provide some little experience I have had. I am sure details will differ depending on how the system of two graders are set up. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In the system I experienced it is a custom to have the course responsible plus someone external (in my case even from a different country) do the grading. The grading was completed by having a discussion between the two graders about possible deviations. In the system grades are given as a number between one and six in steps of 0.1, so very detailed. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My experience was actually quite remarkable; it concerned a masters/PhD level course. We were most often within 0.2 of each other except in one case (answer) where one had given a 1 and the other a 6. In that case it turned out the question was ambiguous and could be interpreted in different ways. The grades were basically calculated as the average of both but only after we had discussed the problems/deviations. This is, for example, how we discovered the ambiguous question formulation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;From this, albeit miniscule, experience, I felt that the benefit of having two persons grading is that ambiguities in terms of questions and answers can be sorted out. It is also possible to discuss the apropriateness of the interpretations of answers given by students. The method also provides what I can call &quot;legal certainty&quot; since the grades will be based on two persons view rather than one. Of course the degree to which it is certian depends on the transparency of the process and to what extent the two gradings become official. The point in &quot;my&quot; case is that both graders have to agree so it is not signed by just one person. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As a grader I also appreciated the possibility to discuss the grading and the corrections jointly made were fair and made the process worth while. I would personally like ot see the system used more, but fear it will be difficult from a financial point of view in many universities (-y systems).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10651" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10651" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10651" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Advantages of second marking" AnswerId="CKZOBaxomnRxsKmZXMNWdw==" Author="643" Date="2013-06-17T13:52:26.857" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Double marking has many roles, but mostly it is to ensure accuracy and fairness. The main way of achieving this, and avoiding the statistical anomalies alluded to in the comments is to produce an effective marking scheme, so that academics with sufficient background can grade the exam and produce virtually the same grades. &lt;em&gt;Easier said than done.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;More details can be found on the Internet, for example, on &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.swan.ac.uk/registry/academicguide/assessmentandprogress/doublemarkingpolicy/&quot;&gt;Swansea University's website&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10650" Date="2014-02-03T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10650" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10650" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10650" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10650" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10650" Date="2013-10-10T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_1065	<question QuestionId="MSc with relation to Cloud" Title="MSc with relation to Cloud" Views="126" Tags="masters" " AnswerId="jyoGvkqw8sMkDLtLZnYltg==" Author="618" Date="2012-04-09T01:55:17.687" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I wonder if there are universities having real-world MSc related courses. My focus is to understand cloud technologies and services(especially if it is Amazon). Preferably in UK, but can be actually anywhere around the world. Maybe general or specific like PAAS , SAAS etc. Could you suggest any?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="MSc with relation to Cloud" AnswerId="NbONhYoYLHoBOzXqrHi07Q==" Author="643" Date="2012-04-11T20:03:43.217" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;At the &lt;a href=&quot;http://wms.cs.kuleuven.be/cs/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;K.U. Leuven&lt;/a&gt; there is a lot of research done in distributed systems, with a recent focus on cloud computing. You could do a Masters in Distributed Systems and do your thesis on an issue related to cloud computing.  (One would need to first check that the course could be done in English.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="MSc with relation to Cloud" AnswerId="S4V3QzwOZWPm2g7R9Rhk6A==" Author="12" Date="2012-04-09T16:10:57.460" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;There's an MSc specialising in Networks and Distributed Systems at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cs.st-andrews.ac.uk/?q=node/47&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;St Andrews&lt;/a&gt;. There's also quite a large group that does cloud computing research and a &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cs.st-andrews.ac.uk/stacc&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;cloud lab&lt;/a&gt;, so you would almost certainly be able to do an MSc project on that topic.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10652	<question QuestionId="Ways of developing non-core skills during PhD studies" Title="Ways of developing non-core skills during PhD studies" Views="550" Tags="research,development" " AnswerId="ougUrzQYER7ChbOAZS6x6A==" Author="5674" Date="2013-06-17T15:00:01.310" Score="17" Text="&lt;p&gt;Working on a cross-disciplinary project, in an increasingly cross-disciplinary field I often find myself wondering whether or not I am developing skills in multiple different areas of my work. I intend this question to be as general as possible, but for the sake of clarity I will give my case as an example:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have a MSc in applied mathematics, and have been working with biomedical research for three years now. Being branded as a &lt;em&gt;bioinformatician&lt;/em&gt; I feel very appreciated on one hand, and absolutely disregarded on the other. In many cases I am expected to learn more of the biology and develop an understanding of &quot;the real science&quot; while all the tools and analysis should just work. I mean many of the seniors have absolutely no idea of the time and effort it takes to develop at software tool, maintain and further develop it. It appears as all that is given once and for all in the engineering school, after all programming is just programming... (please note the sarcasm here)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Be as it may, I have been trying to improve my knowledge and experience in the technical aspects of the work on my own; learning new algorithms, new languages, new tools... It is surprisingly hard to get accustomed to these when you are not in the uni anymore. Consequently, I have given up on learning Maven for my Java projects, or Perl for speeding up my day-to-day scripting. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So my question is; what are good methods for learning or developing techniques that are not immediately in the scope of your project but is still very relevant in your development as a scientist?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Follow up question: am I mistaken in thinking that I should develop a broad set of skills in order to become as efficient and competent as possible? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Ways of developing non-core skills during PhD studies" AnswerId="AVyo7niQsPq3HmrHDlAADw==" Author="6862" Date="2013-06-17T18:25:40.993" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Some methods I have found:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Taking courses in the field you want to learn.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Learning from books in the field you want to learn. Best done in a learning group of people with a similar background.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Working with experts in the field you want to learn.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Taking on research projects in the field you want to learn.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Remember that your PhD is the best time to gain this knowledge - later you will be much more busy with other things.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Finally, bioinformatics and computational biology is a bit of an odd field because you need to know math, biology, chemistry, physics and computer science (I won't detail all the subfields, but there are dozens). My point is that this is a HUGE field - don't expect to be an expert in every possible aspect. Instead, it is better to find a niche which you enjoy and become an expert there - but always keep your mind open to learning new things.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10655" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10655" Date="2013-06-17T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Ways of developing non-core skills during PhD studies" AnswerId="tPFvTbKJBu8TIVQVMYltYw==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-18T10:59:54.087" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;Am in a very much similar situation as you, doing a PhD in physics - however, there is strong connections to biology, photography and signal processing - but very specific topics therein.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A couple of methods that I use on top of what has been mentioned are:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Join stack exchanges, forums and discussion groups of similar topics&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Set myself challenges to determine something new, partly relevant to my studies, but also to build my skills in that topic.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Attending conferences, workshops and seminars (as many as time and funds allow).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;But one main method that seems to work particularly well is setting up 'Google alerts' of specific topics - I always have a great reading list.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;">

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10664" Date="2014-01-08T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Ways of developing non-core skills during PhD studies" AnswerId="XvN/y4vzVM46Mj1q8A6x0A==" Author="5760" Date="2013-06-17T15:30:16.873" Score="12" Text="&lt;p&gt;My goodness, but this is a tough one.  We all learn and maintain our skills in our own unique way.  Especially in industry or when operating independently, so it's difficult to say what would work for you.  I'm in a similar situation except that I'm a developer first and I've been tasked with 'just making security happen'.   Much like with you and bio-med, there is an awful lot that is changing in the landscape of info-sec and staying sharp in both domains is a real challenge.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That said; your mileage will vary but here are some techniques that work for me. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Find overlapping areas:&lt;/strong&gt;&#xA;When I started to move toward developing a new aspect of my skill set I looked for areas where the old and the new overlap.  Luckily for me; this was a pretty easy thing to do with infosec and software development.  The benefit here is that it allows you to leverage your existing skills in a new area.  If can can find areas where you can turn two jobs into one you can ease your way into it, rather than just sitting down one weekend and deciding &quot;I'm going to learn X.&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Sit down one weekend and decide &quot;I'm going to learn X.&quot;:&lt;/strong&gt;&#xA;Sometimes there is no easy overlap to ease your way into a new tech or topic. In those cases I've found that a couple of days in power study mode can be a real benefit.  Strap on the headphones, coffee up it that's your thing, and just read the literature &amp;amp; work problems.  If it's tech then do tutorials.  If it's topic then vacuum up as much as you can.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Find mentors:&lt;/strong&gt; Maybe you can't find the all encompassing guru of everything you want to do, but that's OK.  Someday that guru will be you.  In the meantime find people with expertise in your subject areas to help you fill in the gaps. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Keep it fun:&lt;/strong&gt;&#xA;If at all possible and whenever possible. If you hate what you're doing then you're not going to do it well. At least that has been my experience. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Don't give in to the temptation to 'dumb it down':&lt;/strong&gt;  You're a smart person.  You've taken the time to learn a new skill. You've actually read the materials.  You work hard to develop and maintain a system that crosses a number of subject matter domains.  Don't let people off easy when they ask hard questions; give them hard answers.  My approach is to ask them 'do you want an answer or a response?'  If all they want is a response that's OK. I give them a short and succinct response.  If they want an answer then I do my best to provide the most exhaustive and thorough explanation of what I do, that I can.  When I work hard to learn a new skill I don't need to show it off but I won't let it be taken for granted either. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Well, that's what I've got. All the best to you in your endeavors. If you ever need Java help feel free to grab me on chat and I'll get you an email address. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Ways of developing non-core skills during PhD studies" AnswerId="XvN/y4vzVM46Mj1q8A6x0A==" Author="739" Date="2013-06-17T19:54:52.500" Text="+1 just for &quot;Don't dumb it down&quot;/>

<answer QuestionId="Ways of developing non-core skills during PhD studies" AnswerId="LGOp9yhvmlpuIxn7m1DFuw==" Author="739" Date="2013-06-17T20:03:20.227" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;My understanding from &quot;I am not in the uni anymore&quot; phrase is that you work in some of sort of industry or semi-academic environment. If that is indeed the case, you are probably filling in time sheets for you work; if that is the case, you should be telling your superiors, &quot;&lt;em&gt;This feature that you requested requires 10 hours of immediate development, and another 20 hours to test it properly. How high do you want me to put it on the priority list?&lt;/em&gt;&quot; It is unfortunately a little late for you to start talking like that, as you have been used as an ultimate programmer-who-can-code-anything-without-any-problem for three years now. But you can also bring it up in the sense that &quot;&lt;em&gt;I am getting a variety of requests that I must process one by one&lt;/em&gt;&quot;, and then put the feature value-vs-development time trade-off.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What you are asking, actually, is even more advanced: you need to reneg for some 5-10% of your time to be spent on professional development so that you can continue improving as the applied mathematician on the job. Again, you can say that this process will eventually pay off as you will do things on the projects faster. That's a tough sell given that your time is needed for actual research.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You might want to ask something like that on the &quot;main&quot; StackOverflow website: how people continue training themselves on the job. In an academic setting, you as a student could just commit yourself to write your next thing (be that a research publication or a term paper) using the new tool. In a production environment, you don't have that luxury of being able to make some errors and give yourself some time to recover from them. So once again, that's tough.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Ways of developing non-core skills during PhD studies" AnswerId="LGOp9yhvmlpuIxn7m1DFuw==" Author="5674" Date="2013-06-17T20:15:23.990" Text="I am a fulltime PhD student at the university. By that sentence I meant that I am not enrolled in the courses given at undergrad or masters level. PhD courses I took/will be taking are focused on my field, and provide little flexibility towards &quot;peripheral&quot; subjects./>
<comment QuestionId="Ways of developing non-core skills during PhD studies" AnswerId="LGOp9yhvmlpuIxn7m1DFuw==" Author="739" Date="2013-06-21T00:17:39.967" Text="@posdef, I see. That's a different game, as your time will hardly be considered of much monetary value by your professors. But the limited amount of time that you have in your day is still a valid argument, and that's what you should be presenting. On the other hand, if you don't report your time, it is also somewhat easier to keep developing your &quot;side&quot; skills. You would want to talk to your adviser as to why you want to do this, how much time you want to spend, and identify the specific skills you want to acquire. You can even ask them to cover online courses or short courses at conferences./>
<comment QuestionId="Ways of developing non-core skills during PhD studies" AnswerId="LGOp9yhvmlpuIxn7m1DFuw==" Author="725" Date="2013-06-18T15:32:24.753" Text="+1 for telling people how much work the requested feature takes. Also for telling people that testing (and writing nice and readable and reusable code) needs lots of time./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10658	<question QuestionId="How can a senior undergraduate find academic journals in math and computer science" Title="How can a senior undergraduate find academic journals in math and computer science" Views="340" Tags="journals,mathematics,computer-science,reading" " AnswerId="db6MfQEmjHnGsZPvW3UuPQ==" Author="7450" Date="2013-06-18T02:55:15.363" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am going to be a senior undergraduate and am looking to really find the area of research that I would like to be engaged in during graduate-school/senior year. I have submitted one conference paper as a collaborating author (currently waiting for the reviewers) in the area of Social Network Analysis (mathematical modeling) and am currently working on a conference paper in Graph Algorithms. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As you might guess, I am double majoring in Math and Computer Science and would like to pursue a graduate degree in applied math. So far (I haven't taken all the undergrad courses yet!) I have enjoyed Algorithms, Real Analysis, Graph Theory and Differential Equations. In the future I am curious to learn more about Stochastic Modeling, Mathematical Logic, Artificial Intelligence, Complex Analysis, Fractals and Abstract Algebra.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Where can I find current research journals about both the topics I have enjoyed and the topics I am curious to learn more about?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Do any journals have mobile apps (IOS, Android, or Windows) in which they can be viewed?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Where can I find unbiased information about the quality and related-data about journals?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;EDIT:&lt;/strong&gt; Do any journals &quot;stream&quot; (RSS feed) to GNU Emacs? or is there any type of package manager that will automatically download the latest publications? For example, I just found this &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.emacswiki.org/emacs/MitAiMemos&quot;&gt;&quot;package/program&quot;&lt;/a&gt; available in GNU Emacs. It is a list of AI publications from MIT up until 2005 (why would they stop then?)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thanks for all the help! I am at least looking for a copy of a physical journal so I can take my eyes off the computer for a little bit! :)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How can a senior undergraduate find academic journals in math and computer science" AnswerId="Cm/E/BuxwOzvR/7U2ExPzQ==" Author="81" Date="2013-06-22T09:19:22.497" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;@willwest has answered regarding CS.  I will answer regarding math.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would start with the journals &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ams.org/journals&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;of the AMS (pure math)&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://siam.org/journals/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;of SIAM (applied math)&lt;/a&gt;.  These are the pre-eminent professional societies in their fields and virtually all of their journals are top tier.  In particular, you might start by browsing &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ams.org/publications/journals/journalsframework/jams&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;the Journal of the AMS&lt;/a&gt; and the &lt;a href=&quot;http://siam.org/journals/sirev.php&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;SIAM Review&lt;/a&gt;, the most selective journals from each society.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The journal that a paper gets published in is becoming less and less important, since most researchers find articles through search engines or social media rather than by browsing journals.  The best way to keep up with new research in a particular subfield of math or CS is to subscribe to the appropriate arXiv RSS feed; for instance, for numerical analysis this is &lt;a href=&quot;http://arxiv.org/rss/math.NA&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://arxiv.org/rss/math.NA&lt;/a&gt;.  This is how I usually learn about relevant new research.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note that few mathematical conferences have proceedings, and none that I know of are considered prestigious.  If you want to know which journals are the most highly regarded, talk to faculty in the field.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Journal articles are PDFs, so you can view them with any mobile app that understands PDFs.  If you want to read a hard copy, either print the paper or go to your campus library.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How can a senior undergraduate find academic journals in math and computer science" AnswerId="Cm/E/BuxwOzvR/7U2ExPzQ==" Author="5912" Date="2013-06-22T14:15:33.573" Text="The problem with the arXiv feed is that if you don't know anything about the field, you can't separate the good stuff from the junk. As an undergraduate who isn't that knowledgeable about a subfield, I'd suggest you look in one of the pre-eminent journals for that subfield. There are usually a small number of these (I'd guess between one and five). How do you identify these? The most accurate way is to ask a mathematician who is familiar with the subfield, but googling (say) &quot;Journal ranking numerical analysis&quot; also seems to work pretty well./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10716" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How can a senior undergraduate find academic journals in math and computer science" AnswerId="vjJIMIVmsvTbTQYxYsuLEA==" Author="7474" Date="2013-06-19T19:17:11.260" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would agree that you should mostly be ignoring journals and focusing on conferences, as they publish the majority of new computer science research.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://academic.research.microsoft.com/?SearchDomain=2&amp;amp;entitytype=3&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Microsoft Academic Search&lt;/a&gt; is a good place to go to get an &lt;em&gt;approximate&lt;/em&gt; listing of the top conferences for each sub-field of computer science. Other fields other than Computer Science are listed there too.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Use your school's network to access the &lt;a href=&quot;http://dl.acm.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;ACM Digital Library&lt;/a&gt; (this should be free through your school's library), and download the proceedings for the conferences in the past year or two. Find the papers that look interesting to you and then search for them on Google Scholar. You can print them out if you prefer hard copies.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Hope this helps!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How can a senior undergraduate find academic journals in math and computer science" AnswerId="vjJIMIVmsvTbTQYxYsuLEA==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-21T09:42:04.707" Text="No discussion of mathematics-based material would be complete without mentioning [arXiv](http://arxiv.org)./>
<comment QuestionId="How can a senior undergraduate find academic journals in math and computer science" AnswerId="vjJIMIVmsvTbTQYxYsuLEA==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-22T22:29:43.687" Text="Don't assume that all CS conferences are available in, or even indexed by, the ACM Digital Library.  See, for example: FOCS, SODA, CCC, COLT, VLDB, USENIX, ICALP, WAFR, ICRA, CVPR, .../>

But you do very well in a masters program in computer science. If you want to apply to a PhD program in computer science, will the masters degree grades offset the undergraduate degree grades?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Doing bad in undergraduate but good in a masters program" AnswerId="7vkIQDaCA8UsDf9wRBNVoQ==" Author="621" Date="2012-04-09T09:06:55.417" Text="What does bad mean? in general, undergraduate  grades *count more*.. more grades to see, plus more indicative overall. ..but try n see/>
<comment QuestionId="Doing bad in undergraduate but good in a masters program" AnswerId="7vkIQDaCA8UsDf9wRBNVoQ==" Author="21" Date="2012-04-22T22:21:31.290" Text="@Adel what I found was although I did *badly* during my undergrad (B/BC grade), I did *reasonably well* during my masters degree (AB/A grade) and that tipped the scale in my favor for admission into the PHD program./>

<answer QuestionId="Doing bad in undergraduate but good in a masters program" AnswerId="hMINxZ1V5u2sq5kiuhk2tA==" Author="65" Date="2012-04-09T19:33:31.663" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;Sort of.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I was in exactly the situation you describe 20+ years ago.  My undergrad GPA was horrible (even restricted to computer science classes); my MS GPA was near-perfect; I got into Berkeley as a PhD student.  But I don't think the improvement in my &lt;em&gt;grades&lt;/em&gt; was as important as the improvement in my &lt;em&gt;letters&lt;/em&gt;.  My undergrad letters said &quot;He's smart but lazy&quot;, which is the kiss of death.  My MS letters were much more positive.  Also, when I applied to Berkeley, I had some research results in submission, so my positive letters had some substance to draw on.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, I got very, &lt;em&gt;very&lt;/em&gt;, &lt;strong&gt;very&lt;/strong&gt; lucky.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now, as a faculty member who reviews PhD applications, I would certainly look at the improvement in grades as a good sign.  But as I've mentioned elsewhere, above a certain threshold of &quot;good enough&quot;, &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/958/priority-of-application-materials-for-admission-decision/961#961&quot;&gt;grades don't matter&lt;/a&gt;.  Especially since you're applying with a master's degree, your demonstrated research ability is &lt;strong&gt;much&lt;/strong&gt; more important.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Doing bad in undergraduate but good in a masters program" AnswerId="hMINxZ1V5u2sq5kiuhk2tA==" Author="53" Date="2012-04-10T12:43:52.763" Text="In particular, I'd take this to mean that you should have some research component of your degree (that is, a thesis), and you should hopefully receive the highest possible grade on such a thesis (or as close to it as possible). What amounts to a &quot;B&quot; grade won't help./>

<answer QuestionId="Doing bad in undergraduate but good in a masters program" AnswerId="oohfx173J5PV36T8xOuZ2Q==" Author="53" Date="2012-04-09T12:06:31.267" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;In general, recent performance will tend to outweigh prior performance. I will look at a student with a graduate 4.0 and an undergraduate 3.2 much more favorably than the converse (unless there are obvious extenuating circumstances, such as a large jump in the quality of the graduate program compared to the undergraduate). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The source of the GPA drop is also important. A bad freshman year is almost certainly ignorable. A bad senior year is a red flag. Similarly, I will give much less weight to grades in &quot;general education&quot; classes, as I'm not hiring them based on their ability to analyze Shakespeare or Milton.  Important classes for the major, though, can be deadly even if they are in the undergraduate years. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

Since I' m not a native speaker, I don' t quite understand what this means. And I didn' t find any results online.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I' m not sure if this site is appropriate for such questions. Please let me know if I posted at the wrong place.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="What does &quotprincipled approach&quot mean in papers" AnswerId="ATUlO+CqhTRVlDZLhPSAwA==" Author="5760" Date="2013-06-18T18:23:44.593" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;A 'principled approach', at least the way that I've been exposed to this term, implies due care and diligence with regards to the rigor and discipline used in the material's context. A paper that describes a principled approach would be one that is presenting a procedure for the execution or evaluation of a given subject matter. For example: if I picked up a paper titled 'A principled approach to algorithm selection and implementation' then I would expect the contents of that paper to clearly enumerate a system of algorithm analysis, with exhaustive supporting documentation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Conversely; a paper which uses a principled approach would be one that follows such a detailed and rigorous methodology that the data collected from its research may be considered to be functionally with out bias and with a low probability of corruption or inaccuracy. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10668" Date="2013-09-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10668" Date="2013-12-04T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10668" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10668" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10668" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10668" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="What does &quotprincipled approach&quot mean in papers" AnswerId="dTuFPBtZ5qBvygOUriX3Xw==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-18T18:18:10.713" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;(I am in mathematics, but similar language is used roughly similarly, I believe.) As a place-holder answer: a &quot;principled&quot; approach in science is at least &lt;em&gt;opposite&lt;/em&gt; to a quick-and-dirty, or &lt;em&gt;ad&lt;/em&gt; _hoc_, or &quot;kludge-y&quot; approach, the latter three synonymous expressions meaning that the priority is getting &lt;em&gt;some&lt;/em&gt; result out, perhaps even finding some rationalization for the conclusion one &lt;em&gt;wants&lt;/em&gt;. Obviously a non-principled approach more lends itself to corrupted (but also quick, desired, easy) results.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The &quot;principled&quot; approach &quot;takes the high road&quot;, does not bias conclusions, does not rationalize-away weaknesses or flaws in methodology or information.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;That is, one could hope that a &quot;principled&quot; approach involves &lt;em&gt;no&lt;/em&gt; conflict of interest for the parties involved, and could be trusted. At its worst, &quot;unprincipled&quot; approaches (which no one would ever admit to, except perhaps as a mildly perverse claim to fresh unorthodoxy) produce completely untrustworthy outcomes, because those outcomes are chosen in advance, and whatever results are obtained are &quot;interpreted&quot; to support the original premise.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A hilarious example I witnessed was a computer science M.S. (details elided to protect privacy), on which I was an &quot;outside examiner&quot;, in which &quot;the goal&quot; was to prove that two bunches of events were correlated, thus proving that the people who were promoting the one as &quot;cause&quot; of the other were right, and people should invest in their product. (Nevermind that correlation is not causality.) The guy failed to find any correlation in any of the first twenty or so statistical tests he applied... but he kept at it, until he found a statistical test that &lt;em&gt;did&lt;/em&gt; seem to assert a slight correlation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Of course, what he had &lt;em&gt;really&lt;/em&gt; proven was that there was apparently no correlation... but, taking an &quot;unprincipled&quot; approach, claimed the opposite of what his own evidence showed, etc.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10667" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10667" Date="2013-09-18T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10667" Date="2013-06-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10667" Date="2013-06-18T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>

I am not seeking to be rich, but I would like to make a sufficient income in doing what I love. I have experience dealing with international students, but I do not know which route to take in order to advance in a career in International Development.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10671	<question QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" Title="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" Views="2663" Tags="professors,etiquette" " AnswerId="AYmFN7ubbMakTXqE7BR+rA==" Author="5596" Date="2013-06-19T00:30:13.360" Score="20" Text="&lt;p&gt;I've read at least one career advice essay that calls out asking your PhD students to call you by your first name as unprofessional.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My coworkers and I always called our PhD advisor by his first name, and a graduate student calling &lt;em&gt;any&lt;/em&gt; professor by their last name, much less their own advisor, strikes my sensibilities as quaint and old-fashioned (undergraduates are a different story, of course).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What is the standard practice for this?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="AYmFN7ubbMakTXqE7BR+rA==" Author="4249" Date="2013-06-19T09:46:34.090" Text="Echo @VedranŠego Same thing... I was actually very glad after coming from Croatia to France that in English, there is no distinction between 2nd person pronouns for informal/formal talk as in Croatian/French (we talk in Eng). My French supervisor insisted everybody be on first-name-basis, but I did not feel at ease with it. Currently, with my new French supervisors, I settled on starting the e-mail with &quot;Dear Prof. X&quot;, but addressing in the e-mail body and in person by their first name. In an e-mail, it is just very distracting and in person - I have trouble pronouncing their last name well ://>

<comment QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="AYmFN7ubbMakTXqE7BR+rA==" Author="7161" Date="2013-06-19T03:10:13.480" Text="It depends on the local customs. In Croatia, it is customary for students to address professors by the title. In England, first-name basis seems to be the standard, to the point that one professor actually told me, semi-desperately, &quot;PLEASE, call him by his name!&quot;, when I kept mentioning &quot;prof. &lt;the name of the other professor&gt;&quot;. It took me some time to get used to it./>
<comment QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="AYmFN7ubbMakTXqE7BR+rA==" Author="6346" Date="2013-06-20T12:35:07.473" Text="NO! They should call you &quot;Master&quot; ;)/>
<comment QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="AYmFN7ubbMakTXqE7BR+rA==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-19T02:22:16.393" Text="In some circumstances, the issue is not first (given) name or last (family) name, but perhaps of implied respect, which can at least formally be given by an honorific &quot;Professor&quot; or &quot;Doctor&quot;. When I was not so much older than the grad students, some of them decided to call me &quot;Doctor Paul&quot; or &quot;Professor Paul&quot;, which was perhaps a bit silly, but did not insult me so much. First-naming, &quot;tutoyer&quot;ing en francais, is an iffy thing. Especially now that I'm as old as kids' grandfathers, it seems strange to be addressed by my first name by them./>
<comment QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="AYmFN7ubbMakTXqE7BR+rA==" Author="546" Date="2013-06-19T04:05:02.937" Text="Echo @VedranŠego . This question is definitely local custom dependent. Please specify your location or answers by locations./>

<answer QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="lWWUAnfBrXYN9tH1kbCgYg==" Author="7357" Date="2013-06-19T10:54:48.053" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;I recall a teacher of mine saying : &quot;Dealing with different cultures is dealing with different expectations&quot;, and calling someone by his title or his first name is definitely related to customs. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Being a French (from Chinese parents) student myself, I have never called my teachers/professors by their first names, but things tend to change just as customs evolve. Maybe it is because of my chinese backgrounds, which implies a strong use of titles (even for family members) that is explained by the importance of respect for the elders in the society.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Then I got to study in Oslo for a few months, and people explicitly asekd me to call them by their first names, which I did later. However, it still feels akward for me to call someone by his first name when he is &quot;much&quot; more older than me.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now what I do is that I say &quot;Monsieur&quot; or &quot;Madame&quot;, and use the first name if I am invited to do so.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="lWWUAnfBrXYN9tH1kbCgYg==" Author="7239" Date="2013-06-19T21:11:23.333" Text="I had the same experience as you, in my French classes calling a professor by his first name would have been insulting, but then I studied in Norway and my Norwegian teachers laughed when I called them by their second name as it sounded extremely formal for them./>

<answer QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="aakwo589daTdvWQDVQKWfw==" Author="2827" Date="2013-06-19T10:15:00.390" Score="22" Text="&lt;p&gt;Yes, a PhD is essentially an apprenticeship in academic research, so they should be treated as a colleague in potential (it seems normal practice for an RA to refer to their supervisor by their first name).  Also I think it is a bad idea for researchers to be overly formal and deferential towards their supervisors; if you ware working at the cutting edge of your subject, not all of your ideas will be good ones, and the PhD student should feel comfortable pointing out where they feel this is the case.  This sort of self-skepticism (being comfortable with the idea of being wrong occasionally) is a key component of being a good scientist, and it seems to me to be difficult to communicate this by example if the student is constantly reminded of their place in the hierarchy by making them call me &quot;Dr Marsupial&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="aakwo589daTdvWQDVQKWfw==" Author="7239" Date="2013-06-19T21:19:00.620" Text="You're right that PhD students should be treated as colleagues in potential, but the fact that this implies first-naming is location dependent./>
<comment QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="aakwo589daTdvWQDVQKWfw==" Author="2827" Date="2013-06-20T10:58:45.123" Text="I fully agree (+1), first naming is indeed location/culture dependent, however the point about inculcating self-skepticism shouldn't be. I think informality encourages the student to be questioning and not take what I say to be the ultimate truth.  In a more formal culture there needs to be other ways of encouraging this sort of occasional and entirely appropriate dissent.  While I prefer my students to refer to me by my first name, this is difficult for some of them and I don't insist on it./>
<comment QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="aakwo589daTdvWQDVQKWfw==" Author="348" Date="2013-06-20T12:21:14.327" Text="I agree with your point about formal distance and the invitation to criticise. In the same vein I feel that emphasising authority this way is antithetical to science anyway./>
<comment QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="aakwo589daTdvWQDVQKWfw==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-19T11:20:56.813" Text="+1 &quot;PhD is essentially an apprenticeship in academic research&quot;/>

<answer QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="FVwc50QthGs+oEWPbpREQA==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-19T09:22:31.920" Score="13" Text="&lt;p&gt;This is definitely a local practice. Here in Germany, it is not standard that &lt;em&gt;colleagues&lt;/em&gt; call each other by their first names without specific invitation to do so. However, in other institutes, it is now standard policy that everybody refers to each other by their first name. So what is considered acceptable varies very much from location to location and group to group. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Within my own group, my undergraduate students tend to call me &quot;Professor,&quot; while the graduate students and postdocs call me by my first name. This seems to me to be a reasonable balance—but I wouldn't really have a problem if an undergraduate who's worked for me for a while calls me by my first name.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A graduate student who isn't in my group, however, should not automatically expect to call me by my first name in an initial email. That would be rather presumptuous.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="FVwc50QthGs+oEWPbpREQA==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-19T16:53:31.140" Text="I work in an English-language institute, but outside of it, the patchwork is crazy./>

<comment QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="FVwc50QthGs+oEWPbpREQA==" Author="725" Date="2013-06-19T15:21:29.243" Text="Plus we have the combinations of Du + Lastname () and Sie + Firstname (http://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamburger_Sie)... Main point: if you (= teacher/advisor) want to be addressed by Du and/or given name, do not forget to invite the students to do so (for some students, it will be invitation enough if you start saying Du + given name, others will consider this impolite without your invitation for a *mutual* Du). And if you do so, do it with *all* of them. Otherwise, the situation will become awkward./>

Does it somehow cause you harm or insult? If so, do you have a reason for this to be the case?/>

<answer QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="BGdHD75hFL28zhVNrFX79w==" Author="2692" Date="2013-06-19T05:58:26.360" Score="10" Text="&lt;p&gt;I always have my students call me by my first (given) name. Currently, I'm teaching in Asia and the students have the local custom of calling everyone as Mr. Givenname or Miss Givenname (yes, even if she is married - strange, I know). This is completely different from my native culture but I bring my culture with me...for a reason.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have no desire to introduce the formality of calling me in any sort of official way. I feel it distracts from the importance of focusing on the matter of education. As long as my students do not refer to me in a rude way, I'm quite flexible. I do, however, encourage (without insisting) them to use simply my first name, without any title, rank, or any other identifier. This is true not only for my graduate students but for my undergraduate students as well.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Others in my departments, most notably Asian teachers, do prefer to have the greater level of formality. To each their own. It really does come back to culture. For me, I allow my students to follow which ever culture they prefer, but I do let them I know I don't want formalities to interfere with the educational process in any way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Should your PhD students call you by your first name" AnswerId="BGdHD75hFL28zhVNrFX79w==" Author="546" Date="2013-06-19T06:52:43.953" Text="_most notably Asian teachers, do prefer to have the greater level of formality_ is very true in my Asian location. Some would not only prefer but also insist on it./>

<answer QuestionId="Are there any good job directories for academic work" AnswerId="95/A8B8UVz8NosuDAqY9Bg==" Author="21" Date="2012-04-09T18:09:42.377" Score="8" Text="&lt;p&gt;It would depend on what your field of work is. <answer QuestionId="Are there any good job directories for academic work" AnswerId="j9ZRE6V1Wb9fHHIqKzypjA==" Author="612" Date="2012-04-09T14:46:02.757" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;It's almost impossible to give a general answer to this question, since different fields handle things in very different ways.  Your profile says you're a cognitive scientist and philosopher, which is beyond my competence, but for other readers here's an answer for mathematics jobs in the US:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The largest number of job ads for US academic jobs in math, especially at but not limited to reseach-oriented schools, are found at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ams.org/profession/employment-services/eims/eims-home&quot;&gt;http://www.ams.org/profession/employment-services/eims/eims-home&lt;/a&gt;.  In particular, most math departments do not advertise on generic websites (not field specific) unless there are university requirements to do so, and you cannot find most math jobs without going to math-specific sites.  I have no idea whether this is typical for academic fields, or unique to mathematics.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One unusual feature of mathematics (compared with computer science, for example) is that there's a centralized application site, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mathjobs.org/jobs&quot;&gt;http://www.mathjobs.org/jobs&lt;/a&gt;, which covers a surprisingly large fraction of jobs and makes handling letters of recommendation very easy.  It's still important to look at ads on math society websites, since some schools do not allow departments to use mathjobs.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For industrial or government employment, it's a real mess, and different subfields advertise in rather different places (or sometimes hardly advertise at all).  I don't think there's anything valuable to say there without narrowing things down quite a bit.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Are there any good job directories for academic work" AnswerId="SKhCySGv31Mm7YRkVAY17g==" Author="622" Date="2012-04-09T11:55:58.517" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.higheredjobs.com&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.higheredjobs.com&lt;/a&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;They have jobs broken down by Job Category, Region, and Institution Type. They also do a great job of keeping you informed of opportunities when they are added to the their database.  You provide your CV and potential employers can search for applicants by credentials. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="Are there any good job directories for academic work" AnswerId="pj2h5oC6GOyK7ub1WY1xyA==" Author="2700" Date="2012-10-28T06:32:35.587" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;You should consider location-specific job directories:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Some countries maintain such directions: in this UK, for example, there is &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.jobs.ac.uk&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;jobs.ac.uk&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Most universities have a job directory, so if you have decided on your dream geographic area, you can look at the corresponding listings.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Also, some journals have a job listings section (just like your local newspaper):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://sciencecareers.sciencemag.org&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Science&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nature.com/naturejobs/science/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Nature&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10686	<question QuestionId="Restriction on working hours for full-time students" Title="Restriction on working hours for full-time students" Views="262" Tags="working-time,students,international-students" " AnswerId="anvQPN6e995hctGJqTi08A==" Author="7469" Date="2013-06-19T13:16:18.283" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I know that 20 hours/week when school is in session and 40 hours when school is out is the legal maximum working hour for international full-time students in United States. I was wondering whether this also holds for students other than international students. The &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.dol.gov/elaws/esa/flsa/docs/ftsplink.asp&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;website&lt;/a&gt; of U.S. Department of Labor mentions the same, but it is not clear whether it holds for all. Here is the extract from the website. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&quot;&lt;strong&gt;Full-Time Student Program&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;  &#xA;  &lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;This program is for full-time students employed in retail or service stores, agriculture, or colleges and universities. The employer that hires students can obtain a certificate from the Department of Labor which allows the student to be paid not less than 85% of the minimum wage. The certificate also limits the hours that the student may work to 8 hours in a day and no more than 20 hours a week when school is in session and 40 hours when school is out, and requires the employer to follow all child labor laws. Once students graduate or leave school for good, they must be paid at least the federal minimum wage.&#xA;  There are some limitations on the use of the full-time student program...&quot;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10686" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10686" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10686" Date="2013-06-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10686" Date="2013-06-19T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Restriction on working hours for full-time students" AnswerId="x52gG7mznFRxIKzvevx7iw==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-19T16:59:19.150" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;The extract you have linked is specifically for a program that &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.dol.gov/whd/minwage/q-a.htm&quot;&gt;exempts employers from paying the full minimum wage&lt;/a&gt;. There is, in principle, no &lt;em&gt;law&lt;/em&gt; stating that students can only work 20 hours per week when school is in session. In fact, it's quite the opposite—students can work as many hours as they would like. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the other hand, it &lt;em&gt;is&lt;/em&gt; possible for universities to place conditions on financial aid recipients that they not work more than some number of hours per week, and in general it's not really that smart of an idea to be studying full-time and working full-time on top of that. And the university may also have limits on what students can do with on-campus student aide positions, whether or not they are on financial aid.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But as far as the US government is concerned? I don't think they really care.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Restriction on working hours for full-time students" AnswerId="x52gG7mznFRxIKzvevx7iw==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-19T21:18:27.650" Text="Yes, I see that it is a US based question - my comment is just noting how different the systems are, and seemingly quite different from Germany as well./>

<comment QuestionId="Restriction on working hours for full-time students" AnswerId="x52gG7mznFRxIKzvevx7iw==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-19T21:16:35.047" Text="That may be true—although in this specific case, it does ask about practices in the US. Things are also different here in Germany: universities cannot hire undergraduates as employees for more than 19 hours per week, for any reason./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10692	<question QuestionId="How much detail to include for an award listed on a CV" Title="How much detail to include for an award listed on a CV" Views="661" Tags="cv" " AnswerId="2BW+beED6zSevJWp0XOrYQ==" Author="948" Date="2013-06-20T03:03:58.457" Score="14" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would like to have a section titled 'Awards/Honors' in my CV and I am confused about how much detail to include for the items in this section. Here are some formats and levels of detail I am considering: &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Harry Potter scholarship.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Hogwarts school of Witchcraft and Wizardry, Harry Potter scholarship.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Hogwarts school of Witchcraft and Wizardry, Harry Potter scholarship: awarded to one student every year for demonstrated excellence in horcrux-gathering.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For certain things, I feel like the first does not include enough context, beyond some very well-known things (such as a Fulbright or Goldwater, neither of which I have received). For some particular names I have in mind the second looks pretty clunky and does not always fit on a single line. The third option is even clunkier, and might be perceived as an attempt to add fluff to inflate the CV. I am personally leaning towards the second option, but I don't know that it adds much value beyond the first option. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is there an accepted way to list awards/scholarships? Should I even be listing them at all?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Some context.&lt;/strong&gt; I am a PhD student in Mathematics and I will be on the academic job market this coming year. I am currently based in the US and intend to apply to jobs here as well as internationally if I find any that are interesting. I am wondering both about the CV I keep that lives on my professional website and the one I hope to send as part of my job applications.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;hr&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Edited to add&lt;/strong&gt;: The first couple of answers suggest that one might choose the format/level of detail based on the type/prestige of award. If I were reading a CV and came across inconsistent formatting within a section, I would find it quite jarring. Is this something that only worries someone mildly-OCD such as myself (I notice things like en-dashes and em-dashes) and therefore perhaps to not be worried about, or should I be careful about such things (e.g. consistency of formatting) when creating a CV? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="How much detail to include for an award listed on a CV" AnswerId="Qy7KJfnh3YAQmBjvKR17GA==" Author="5596" Date="2013-06-20T15:01:20.517" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would go so far as to give the opposite of Dan C's advice: the more prestigious the award, the less detail you need to provide.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you won the NSF fellowship or the Hertz, or got best paper at your national conference, everyone will understand what the award is and its significance, and belaboring the point has the risk of looking desperate or inexperienced.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;On the other had, if you won your department's annual [famous former faculty] Memorial Award for Excellence in Teaching, the award is still worth listing and you should include at least that much information on the CV. Assume nobody is going to take the time to Google your awards.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I would say, as my rule of thumb, that each award should fit on one line. If explaining an award's significance requires more than one line, that is a red flag that perhaps the award is not pulling its weight. Understating your accomplishments and aggressive mediocrity will both kill your chances in the job market, but in my opinion the latter is the most dangerous of the two.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10699" Date="2013-06-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10699" Date="2013-12-28T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10699" Date="2014-01-16T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10699" Date="2013-06-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10699" Date="2013-06-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10699" Date="2013-06-20T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10699" Date="2013-06-20T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How much detail to include for an award listed on a CV" AnswerId="KGfs3Ly5Wri9F03m6pXsHw==" Author="1069" Date="2013-06-20T04:56:48.360" Score="10" Text="&lt;p&gt;The &lt;strong&gt;amount of detail&lt;/strong&gt; you give should be &lt;strong&gt;proportional to the award's prestige&lt;/strong&gt;.  So for example, &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If you were recognized as an &quot;excellent&quot; teacher, among a list of 100s at your university, that's worth mentioning, but it gets formatted as option 1.  &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If you won a best student paper award, that probably gets option 2.  &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If you won &quot;best PhD thesis in your department&quot; from a department with more than say 10 graduates each year, that might merit option 3, although it's likely to fit easily in format 2.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;If you won a prize from a professional society (awarded to very few each year), that might merit option 3.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How much detail to include for an award listed on a CV" AnswerId="KGfs3Ly5Wri9F03m6pXsHw==" Author="546" Date="2013-06-20T05:00:59.237" Text="This answer makes sense to me./>

<answer QuestionId="How much detail to include for an award listed on a CV" AnswerId="HADOlSUtW7IJnhK0J5JnnA==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-20T12:52:49.710" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;I will disagree with Dan C's answer above and state that you should only be choosing between options 2 and 3. At the very minimum, you want to indicate &lt;strong&gt;who&lt;/strong&gt; gave you the award. Otherwise, it's not all that valuable to the reviewer of your CV, as they may not know whether an award is a big deal or not. If it's a major award, I'd default to option 3 if it's &quot;non-obvious&quot; how it works. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, in general, I'd opt for option number 2, unless there's some specific information that needs to be shared, in which case I'd go for number 3.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10695	<question QuestionId="Splitting publication fees among coauthors" Title="Splitting publication fees among coauthors" Views="209" Tags="publishing,collaboration,fees" " AnswerId="WcnFnXgdodQNIT7VtKAdNQ==" Author="3890" Date="2013-06-20T08:37:16.667" Score="13" Text="&lt;p&gt;What are accepted ways of splitting publication fees among coauthors, when authors are from different research groups and potentially even different institutions? Especially with open access publication, the fees tend to come out at a substantial amount.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In general, the corresponding author seems to be responsible to the journal for the payment of the fee. I wonder what would be commonly acceptable agreements with coauthors to split such fees?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There is already a general question on splitting collaboration costs &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/5177/how-to-organize-a-joint-collaboration-plan-and-fees&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;, but the current answer does not apply to publication fees, and I am really interested in this specific case.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Splitting publication fees among coauthors" AnswerId="WcnFnXgdodQNIT7VtKAdNQ==" Author="4394" Date="2013-06-20T08:43:25.263" Text="I think an issue like this should be sorted out early on in the collaboration. Obviously one would expect the first author (team) to cover (most of) the costs, possibly sharing according to input (author order) but in general: whoever has money should use it./>
<comment QuestionId="Splitting publication fees among coauthors" AnswerId="WcnFnXgdodQNIT7VtKAdNQ==" Author="7482" Date="2013-06-20T20:57:10.703" Text="@PeterJansson: Of course the first part doesn't apply to fields (like math) where authors are unordered/alphabetized./>
<comment QuestionId="Splitting publication fees among coauthors" AnswerId="WcnFnXgdodQNIT7VtKAdNQ==" Author="546" Date="2013-06-21T08:09:52.960" Text="I understand this question is different from collaboration cost. I think you can use the same concept. First, try the institution(s). Their reputation benefits from the publication. They should share some cost. Second, authors with full time salary may be able to (not necessarily willing to) share the cost. If still not enough, divide the cost evenly among the coauthors. I don't have personal experience with this case. Only my two cents./>
<comment QuestionId="Splitting publication fees among coauthors" AnswerId="WcnFnXgdodQNIT7VtKAdNQ==" Author="6820" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:56.773" Text="In a field where there are journals that are very good and do not have a substantial fee, I would hope that the author who is pushing for the open access journal would foot the bill./>

<answer QuestionId="Splitting publication fees among coauthors" AnswerId="1X3hepgegOjPy4VwtjQSqw==" Author="929" Date="2013-07-09T12:46:46.360" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;I think your question is a little backwards: All ways of splitting the publication fees are acceptable. You might run into some problems with your grant officer about transferring money around, but in the end they will get over it.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The more important question in my opinion is: What behaviour is acceptable from you and your co-authors. I believe the answer is to be nice since these are your co-authors after all. I wouldn't be too put off if a co-author refused to contribute to open access fees or if I was asked to contribute 1/N of the fees for an N author paper where I was a tertiary author and currently under-funded.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10700	<question QuestionId="How to edit name on existing publications after a name change" Title="How to edit name on existing publications after a name change" Views="548" Tags="publishing" " AnswerId="YlzoFKp6lNdDJ7g8dJSTSA==" Author="7382" Date="2013-06-20T16:37:07.543" Score="10" Text="&lt;p&gt;Assume that I publish many papers in many journals and someday I changed the family name (my last name). <answer QuestionId="How to edit name on existing publications after a name change" AnswerId="/K5U5+cZZezY/vfHgjY9Pw==" Author="7116" Date="2014-04-02T12:38:05.380" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;As others have pointed out, there is almost certainly no way to change your name in already published papers. In line with the previous answer, I would like to call your attention to initiatives like &lt;a href=&quot;http://orcid.org/&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;ORCID&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.researcherid.com/Home.action?returnCode=ROUTER.Unauthorized&amp;amp;SrcApp=CR&amp;amp;Init=Yes&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;ResearcherID&lt;/a&gt; that aim at creating unique identifications for each researcher, so you can collect all your scientific output under a single ID, more or less independently of a particular name or spelling.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How to edit name on existing publications after a name change" AnswerId="/K5U5+cZZezY/vfHgjY9Pw==" Author="1471" Date="2014-04-02T13:25:50.163" Text="+1, and plus as well for pointing out the spelling issue: I'm Hejda, but after publishing in countries using the cyrillic alphabet, I could easily become Cheida, Xeida, Geida, Gejda, .../>
<comment QuestionId="How to edit name on existing publications after a name change" AnswerId="/K5U5+cZZezY/vfHgjY9Pw==" Author="7116" Date="2014-04-02T13:47:30.667" Text="@tohecz a common situation for many scholars, think for instance of researchers with Chinese or Arabic names publishing in western journals and the inevitable mess with the transliteration of their names./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="18834" Date="2014-04-02T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="How to edit name on existing publications after a name change" AnswerId="CBk457slR0cZYbs7zIK50A==" Author="958" Date="2013-06-20T19:06:45.933" Score="15" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am afraid that you can't easily change the name on a published article. Publishing is (at least theoretically) still done on print, so there is simply no way to change the physical journal once it has been sent to university libraries all over the world. Even for more important issues such as plagiarism or factually incorrect data, only an errata is issued, or the paper is marked as &quot;retracted&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What you can do instead is advertising the double name on your webpage and CV, and ensuring that the academic databases (such as Web of Science and Scopus) correctly recognize and handle your name change, marking all of your papers as written by a single author. You will probably need to notify them using the &quot;contact us&quot; functions on their websites.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Several authors in the same situation choose to keep the old name also on new papers; this makes it simpler for other researchers to recognize you, at the price of using a name that you might have disowned and now consider a relic from the past. In practice, there is no requirement that your academical &lt;em&gt;nom de plume&lt;/em&gt; coincides with the one that is written on your ID and that you use on legal papers, so you are free to sign your papers using a different version of it. Once you choose this route, however, it will be more practical if you consistently use the old name also when attending conferences.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If you are simply getting married, then signing your papers with both surnames is probably the easiest option. (I realize that probably you have already considered and discarded this option, but I thought it more appropriate to include it in my answer anyway.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10701" Date="2014-04-02T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10701" Date="2014-04-02T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10705	<question QuestionId="How might I improve my math department as an undergrad" Title="How might I improve my math department as an undergrad" Views="357" Tags="research,undergraduate,mathematics,funding" " AnswerId="E5n1lc4Tlfhh+iomv9iLzw==" Author="5985" Date="2013-06-20T23:23:08.207" Score="11" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am an undergraduate math major at a small state university in the US. Our math department has about 20 tenured/tenure-track faculty, including applied mathematicians and statisticians. We have only 3 current NSF grants, two in statistics and one in biomathematics. According to MathSciNet, only 4 of our faculty have published something this year. Additionally, our current department head mainly does applied interdisciplinary research, but I suppose it is not rare for math department heads to be in some kind of applied math field. To be fair, my university was founded less than 50 years ago, but I still want my department to become better.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Is there anything I could do as an undergrad to help improve my department? It's hard to say exactly what would make my department &quot;better&quot;, but to be somewhat vague, I would consider research productivity and funding to be important factors to improve on.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How might I improve my math department as an undergrad" AnswerId="E5n1lc4Tlfhh+iomv9iLzw==" Author="5985" Date="2013-06-21T02:11:05.037" Text="Paul, do you mean that I should convince my department to acquire more funding to go towards offering more _rigorous_ courses (e.g. proof-based linear algebra versus applications-based linear algebra) or more _upper-level_ courses (i.e. end of program courses besides the typical topology, analysis, and abstract algebra courses)?/>
<comment QuestionId="How might I improve my math department as an undergrad" AnswerId="E5n1lc4Tlfhh+iomv9iLzw==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-21T14:56:43.073" Text="Both less cook-book oriented, and higher-level. (I do think it is a mistake to exaggerate &quot;rigor&quot; in lower-level courses.)/>
<comment QuestionId="How might I improve my math department as an undergrad" AnswerId="E5n1lc4Tlfhh+iomv9iLzw==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-20T23:46:58.600" Text="&quot;Funding&quot; in math is a very volatile, and often irrelevant measure, especially for &quot;out-state&quot; places. It is not clarifying to think in such terms, because of all the skewing. It's not that the money is &quot;really necessary&quot;, so lack thereof won't impede _anything_... apart from maybe having largesse to throw around... yes, to undergrads, but, ... More to the point would be militating for more-advanced courses to be offered. Pushing for this would help in many ways./>
<comment QuestionId="How might I improve my math department as an undergrad" AnswerId="E5n1lc4Tlfhh+iomv9iLzw==" Author="2686" Date="2013-06-22T11:42:51.363" Text="@Matthew, MathSciNet isn't a good way to judge research activity: there can be very long delays -- a year, even more -- between math papers being written and their being listed on MSN./>

<answer QuestionId="How might I improve my math department as an undergrad" AnswerId="H3ooeuvGA6NqnThJ4eXsJQ==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-21T03:01:14.170" Score="17" Text="&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;Is there anything I could do as an undergrad to help improve my department? It's hard to say exactly what would make my department &quot;better&quot;, but to be somewhat vague, I would consider research productivity and funding to be important factors to improve on.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;There's not much you can do as an undergraduate to help improve research productivity or funding.  It's not clear whether the department wants to improve in these ways, or should want to: there's nothing wrong with focusing on teaching.  Even if the faculty do want to become more research active, or the administration wants them to, it's not easy and there's little you can do to make it easier.  I'd be careful with how you frame things, since you could easily cause hurt feelings by giving your professors the impression that you consider them substandard.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Instead of focusing on what might improve the department in some abstract sense, I'd focus on what would create a stimulating, exciting environment for the current students.  You don't want to be too demanding, and some things just might not be feasible, but it can't hurt to ask what could be possible and what it would take to make it happen.  You could look into various sorts of activities:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Advanced courses or independent study.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Undergraduate research supervised by faculty.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Informal mathematical activities: math club, Mathematical Association of America student chapter, Putnam team, etc.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If all of these things are regularly available, then your department is doing pretty well.  Otherwise, you could try to initiate or reinvigorate some of them.  You aren't likely to get clubs or courses for just one student, so you'll probably have to gather some other enthusiastic students.  This may be the biggest way you could contribute, as a catalyst to bring together a group of students the department hadn't realized wanted or needed these activities.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How might I improve my math department as an undergrad" AnswerId="H3ooeuvGA6NqnThJ4eXsJQ==" Author="5985" Date="2013-06-21T03:36:22.117" Text="Thanks for your answer!&#xA;&#xA;I was also thinking I could convince my department to apply for a NSF Research Training Group grant or to host an undergraduate math conference for the benefit of our math undergrads, but it would make sense to start with the suggestions you mentioned.&#xA;&#xA;I expected that I wouldn't be able to do much in the way of research or funding for my department, but I'll still leave this question open to see what others may suggest./>
<comment QuestionId="How might I improve my math department as an undergrad" AnswerId="H3ooeuvGA6NqnThJ4eXsJQ==" Author="1171" Date="2013-06-21T13:05:14.520" Text="Just to add to this excellent answer, if you don't have one already, I suggest starting a student seminar series. Work with other enthusiastic students to organize a weekly (or whatever) seminar where the *students* give talks on various topics. This is beneficial for all of the students involved, and the faculty may take an interest as well./>
<comment QuestionId="How might I improve my math department as an undergrad" AnswerId="H3ooeuvGA6NqnThJ4eXsJQ==" Author="5596" Date="2013-06-22T15:17:41.250" Text="+1 For Jeff's suggestion. Organizing seminars is perfect for an undergraduate, and can go a long way towards generating excitement about research projects in your department./>
