academia.stackexchange.com_10710	<question QuestionId="To stay or leave PhD after having completed 4 years" Title="To stay or leave PhD after having completed 4 years" Views="2022" Tags="phd,advisor,personal-advice" " AnswerId="Z8pQEp2yVn/uv+YCvFkApw==" Author="7489" Date="2013-06-22T00:55:31.083" Score="13" Text="&lt;p&gt;I apologize if this is too long a post, but I could really do with a few&#xA;pointers about my current situation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am 25 years old and I will complete &lt;strong&gt;4 years&lt;/strong&gt; of my PhD in a computational applied mathematics  program in the US in August 2013.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My bachelors was in pure mathematics.  I had gotten interested in numerical analysis in that time and so I had applied to my current PhD program. I have been under my adviser for 3 years now (the first year at my university is spent in coursework).  A PhD at my university is usually 5 years long. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Right now, I have &lt;strong&gt;almost nothing&lt;/strong&gt; to report in the way of research, and consequently no publications , no conference submissions. I am getting increasingly nervous and frustrated about whether or not I will make it, &lt;strong&gt;even&lt;/strong&gt; if I give myself an extra year by funding myself. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My adviser has consistently been making me work on uninteresting stuff, where most of the work involved is purely technical like writing brain-dead code, with almost zero chance for innovation. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;strong&gt;BREAKDOWN OF MY PHD&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;After monkeying around reading research papers, in the &lt;strong&gt;first year&lt;/strong&gt; under my adviser,  he got very confident about getting an industrial project and got me working on that, in anticipation that the contract would go through. At the end of the year we found out that we did not get the project.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In the &lt;strong&gt;second year&lt;/strong&gt;, he said he wanted to get into GPU parallel computing &#xA;and to implement a few fluid dynamics algorithms. I slogged over many manuals, spent months and months writing and debugging code, all the time thinking that &#xA;this would be used to do some simulations he was interested in and get them published. But at the end of the second year my professor completely lost interest in these numerical techniques he was making my implement. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Seeing this schizophrenic attitude, I almost wanted to quit then and there itself. But I decided to just stick it out, thinking it might be 'just a phase'.  Due to funding issues, he once more got me working in the &lt;strong&gt;third year&lt;/strong&gt; on another project which essentially involved writing a lot of stupid code, and running endless benchmark tests.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have basically ended up trying to do a PhD in mathematics without any mathematics in this PhD. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Finally, a couple of weeks back, I told him that I had had enough, and to give me some actual &#xA;problems/material to work with. After about an hour of discussion, and informing him that I was ready to fund my self if required, he finally gave me a couple of possible starting points for what I hope would actually turn out to be worthwhile research.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;strong&gt;MY QUESTIONS&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;I do realize it was &lt;em&gt;extremely&lt;/em&gt; foolish waiting for so long before putting my foot down, and not having the courage to speak up before. My adviser is well-regarded by colleagues in his field, and maybe I was subconsciously scared of &#xA;contradicting his handling of my PhD for pissing him off. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But even though he has now suggested problems which do seem interesting, after having had so many negative experiences  I am very skeptical about the future. How should I proceed, and what are the factors I should consider ? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Frankly, I am feeling very burned out.  In the way of future plans, I have been toying with the idea of dropping out,  getting a break for a few months and then sitting for some entrance exams for a Masters in Economics in some good universities back in my home country. I always found economics very interesting through my undergrad and more so these past few-months while studying it has a hobby.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Continuing would require me to stay on for an extra year till August 2015, &#xA;which leaves me &lt;strong&gt;about 17 months tops&lt;/strong&gt; from now, before I start hunting in academic job market. This includes about 2-3 months I will have to spend doing literature review on the proposed topics and learning the requisite mathematical tools. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So if I decide to stay on, how should I re-structure my study/research time and the relationship with my adviser in these 17 months so that I can make some head-way.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Maybe 17 months is too short a time? Any suggestions would be really helpful !!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="To stay or leave PhD after having completed 4 years" AnswerId="Z8pQEp2yVn/uv+YCvFkApw==" Author="4472" Date="2013-06-22T21:32:51.733" Text="You are young ... I am sure you will make it. But if you are not happy with your field, professor, or university .. then run away now ! ... I am sure you have more experience in research now .. so if you switch to another topic, it will be easier for you to tackle it. My advice .. don't leave your PhD (take a break .. that's fine, but don't give up your PhD). You need to know (learn) how things work in Academic Research. They re really nothing but few tricks you need to learn .. if you get that, then everything will be fine./>
<comment QuestionId="To stay or leave PhD after having completed 4 years" AnswerId="Z8pQEp2yVn/uv+YCvFkApw==" Author="7489" Date="2013-07-03T21:45:19.237" Text="@Irwin Frankly, at this point, I just don't see myself doing  what I am currently working on 5 years down the line, since there is almost no central 'spirit' to my PhD because of the reasons above. <answer QuestionId="To stay or leave PhD after having completed 4 years" AnswerId="Uz+zDGN4EVFXp/ZnFyKopg==" Author="9978" Date="2013-12-12T23:29:44.933" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;It really helps if you take some time off and get a job in your field if you can. That way it serves to rejuvenate your mind and gives you a breather. By doing so you can hit three birds with one stone: 1) you take a break and feel better 2) you have some money to use 3) you become more interested in other subjects you never thought you would have liked, such as technology, fashion, the business world, different languages and culture, etc. I didn't say to quit, I said to take some time off and &quot;find yourself, to rediscover yourself&quot;. Will it help? Maybe or maybe not. Perhaps if you look at yourself in comparison to the rest of the world. You're doing a PhD which is one of the most prestigious and most sought after degree in the world. Not many people are able to do that let alone get a bachelor degree. Be grateful. Some people don't even have enough money to afford a days meal or a roof over their head. Hell be lucky you're not in combat or war. Sometimes it helps to appreciate with what you have. That may give you motivation to keep going. Maybe PhD isn't for you. Maybe it is for you. maybe you're meant to become the next Bill Gates or the next president. Who knows. My point is no matter what happens always keep your head up, stay confident, and don't ever give up. Take a break. But don't give up. No don't worry you are not alone. The fact that you made it this far shows you are a winner (Charlie Sheen haha just kidding). Don't give up doc.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="To stay or leave PhD after having completed 4 years" AnswerId="2m8zgke0ZtexdICOawMBHA==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-22T01:35:04.060" Score="14" Text="&lt;p&gt;Firstly, no apology needed, your question is thorough and easy to read and understand.  It sounds like you are in quite an unpleasant situation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Don't take any advice I may give as gospel, but in answer to your questions:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You are most certainly &lt;strong&gt;not&lt;/strong&gt; foolish to waiting until now to stand up to your advisor, you have had several leads and have given many chances for the project to kick into gear. You have every right and reason to feel sceptical about the current promises and project direction.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Ultimately, how you proceed is up to you (you're probably understandably sick of hearing that), but look at the following considerations (no doubt many other members will add to this):&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;The new direction could well be a winner, leading to papers, conferences and most of all, fulfilment.  It could also be a good one as now, you have made your feelings clear to your supervisor.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Could this be just another academic 'false positive'?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Perhaps outline a couple of potential papers and present them to your advisor (this is something I do).  This could be an ongoing thing, alongside your research - outline potential papers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As for the timeframe, 17 months - I would not be too worried about that - I have been able to get 3 papers published in less than 10 months, with a 4th on the way and the 5th planned (I finish my PhD at the end of the year).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I hope this helps, and I hope it all gets sorted out for you.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10712	<question QuestionId="Transcript Evaluation Services vs Internal Evaluation of Transcripts" Title="Transcript Evaluation Services vs Internal Evaluation of Transcripts" Views="103" Tags="graduate-school,graduate-admissions" " AnswerId="GPzvjz5DgicghiG1GwO+iQ==" Author="3983" Date="2013-06-22T02:09:11.277" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I would like to know, if given both options, which of the options, would officials at the american universities follow?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;By internal evaluation, my GPA at some of the universities is translated/scored as 2.87/4.00. Disbarring me from all of their programs.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;By WES evaluation, my GPA is translated/scored as 3.25/4.00. This option allows me to run/apply for all the programs at the said universities.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Which of these evaluations would the university use?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Does WES's evaluation hold any weight?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Wouldn't this be a problem for those who are not aware of such services?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10712" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10712" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Transcript Evaluation Services vs Internal Evaluation of Transcripts" AnswerId="B3l6/XLKKQiqzVisNit0aA==" Author="5596" Date="2013-06-22T15:26:19.707" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;Every school does admissions in a different way, so it's hard to say, but I've never heard of &lt;em&gt;anyone&lt;/em&gt; using any external services to evaluate transcripts. I'd say send in your application, and let the chips fall where they may.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Although quantities like GPA, GRE scores, etc. might be used as a filter to narrow the applicant pool, what will really get you accepted are 1) strong letters, 2) successful undergrad research projects, and 3) direct contact with a potential advisor at the university. If a professor knows about you and your work and wants you as a student, that will go an incredible way towards getting you admitted no matter what your GPA.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10721" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10721" Date="2013-06-30T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Transcript Evaluation Services vs Internal Evaluation of Transcripts" AnswerId="WQzJp95lUmZpWZH3uRckiQ==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-22T10:51:52.960" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;As far as I know, American universities do not rely on &quot;transcript evaluation services&quot;; they ask you to convert your GPA to whatever system they happen to use, since there are so many of them out there (5-point versus 4-point systems, A+/A/A- versus A/B/C, and so on).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You could of course provide the results of such an evaluation service, but I would &lt;strong&gt;not&lt;/strong&gt; expect it to carry any weight with admissions committees, who can accept or ignore it as they please.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Transcript Evaluation Services vs Internal Evaluation of Transcripts" AnswerId="WQzJp95lUmZpWZH3uRckiQ==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-22T11:40:41.857" Text="I don't know whether how or even *whether* my American university asks for GPAs, but by the time they reach me (in the admissions committee), they are reported using the system from the applicant's home university.  In other words, **don't convert them at all.**  Even numerically equal GPAs using the same system are not equivalent if they come from different universities./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10718" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10718" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10718" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10718" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Transcript Evaluation Services vs Internal Evaluation of Transcripts" AnswerId="2djAQpc0t1v4iJb8nmqzPw==" Author="127" Date="2013-06-22T20:32:00.537" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;My experience differs from the others. Although I am American, my wife is Polish and she applied to a slew (by which I mean 9) of grad schools for computational linguistics. Of them, three wanted the external transcript evaluation, and they even recommended which service to use.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;But they also asked for a copy of the original transcript.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't know what impact it had, but she ended up going to a school that didn't require such an evaluation. But there is funny story here: no where on her transcript did it say that she actually finished her degree program. So when her chosen graduate school requested her &quot;final transcript&quot; (even though my wife graduated a year and a half ago, so they already had her final transcript), she ended up sending them an extra copy of the evaluation along with her explanation that she had, in fact, graduated.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;From my point of view, the whole external evaluation process seemed overly expensive and annoying. I would advise that you just ask whatever graduate program that you're interested in whether they want applicants to have them (they don't bite, really), and hope that they don't.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10722" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>

academia.stackexchange.com_10713	<question QuestionId="About email contact with prospective advisors who are yet to join the institute" Title="About email contact with prospective advisors who are yet to join the institute" Views="316" Tags="phd,graduate-school,advisor" " AnswerId="I6Cv+rpJ4vs26hCBwGql6g==" Author="6683" Date="2013-06-22T02:42:23.340" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am a second year grad student who is trying to find advisors in two people (quite brilliant scientists!) who are going to join my grad school as faculty. They are going to be in campus only rarely now but will be full-time here from the next year. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Does this situation sound very bad or scary or depressing or something wrong? &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Am I late into the game? &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So I have done studies and have written up research drafts in areas related to these scientists and have been trying to get into discussions with them over emails. Both sounded quite interested in me - one of them met me for a few hours of discussion while in campus about a month ago - and the other one said &quot;we should keep in touch and meet when I am there the next time&quot;  etc. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;But I get very scared and nervous when I don't get replies from them after even a week from the last email (stating my progress in their respective subjects)- I am always thinking if they struck me off from their mind - did they just forget me - did they decide I am not worth it etc. etc. &lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[...I am getting sick of just the unbearable tension of the fear of having been dropped...]&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Anyway is the implicit expectation that I am going to read up all current papers in their fields and be able to come up with a paper on my own? (...thats what I am trying to do but clearly thats not easy!...) I don't know how &quot;advising&quot; is supposed to work with so little contact (...may be there is a culture conflict because in my previous institute one met one's professors daily and even multiple times a day at times...) &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;[just a side information - may be irrelevant but still for completeness of information - I think I am way ahead of my peers in terms of depth and breadth of knowledge and speed of learning new papers and my grad school grades are all at the top..] &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

In one extreme, some advisors are really picky and check every tiny thing you do. On the other extreme, some really have no clue what you are doing till you show up in their office. DO NOT ever think you are better than your peers (even if you actually are ! )../>

<answer QuestionId="About email contact with prospective advisors who are yet to join the institute" AnswerId="ZNiC0OHlhOrfocDpexxjug==" Author="5596" Date="2013-06-22T15:08:45.320" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;Understand that faculty, even junior faculty, can get over a hundred emails a day, and even dealing with only the most urgent of these, such as&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Bureaucracy from the department chair / funding agency program director / etc.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Requests from existing students and collaborators&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Reminders about late paper reviews&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Conference and travel logistics&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Letter of reference requests&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Complaints about grades from undergrads&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;takes up a huge chunk of their time. Recruiting good students is also usually a high priority... but if you've already agreed to work together next year, and have established an outline of what you can be doing until then to prepare yourself, I wouldn't read too much into a slow response to your follow-up emails, especially if they are in the form of long reports.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The best approach is probably the direct one: ask them what you can do between now and the fall to get a head start on the research project, and what kind of updates, if any, they would like from you between now and then.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="About email contact with prospective advisors who are yet to join the institute" AnswerId="ZNiC0OHlhOrfocDpexxjug==" Author="6683" Date="2013-06-22T15:12:10.043" Text="@user16875 Both these people are currently post-docs and will be permanently moving here as faculty in 2014./>

<answer QuestionId="About email contact with prospective advisors who are yet to join the institute" AnswerId="CwCu2zGhrgqZU9eg9MTMzg==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-22T10:47:36.587" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;I personally would be a little &lt;em&gt;too&lt;/em&gt; concerned about a graduate student who keeps trying to &quot;hard sell&quot; themselves &lt;em&gt;before I arrived.&lt;/em&gt; Partially this is because, if I were just starting a new position, I'd be worried about a million things, including winding down my previous employment situation, preparing for a move, figuring out all the different things that have to be done in the new position, and so on. Others may very well be different, though!&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note that I don't think it's wrong to be active when you sense a good opportunity, such as working with a scientist you hold in high regard as an advisor. However, being too aggressive may be just as damaging as being too passive. Steer clear of both extremes. For instance, have the advisors in question &lt;em&gt;asked&lt;/em&gt; you to send them weekly updates? Have you asked them to  schedule a phone or Skype chat? Do you know if they are even &quot;at home&quot; or if they're on travel when they're not responding?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Advisors have their own personal styles, and your style should mesh with theirs. If it doesn't, it will likely be an unproductive and unhappy situation for both of you.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="About email contact with prospective advisors who are yet to join the institute" AnswerId="CwCu2zGhrgqZU9eg9MTMzg==" Author="6683" Date="2013-06-23T05:45:06.637" Text="There is no formal process of becoming an advisee. What else can I do but to just keep reporting them of my thoughts and progress?/>

<comment QuestionId="About email contact with prospective advisors who are yet to join the institute" AnswerId="CwCu2zGhrgqZU9eg9MTMzg==" Author="6683" Date="2013-06-23T08:47:09.420" Text="Securing an advisor seems to be an extremely complex process - far far more complex than mastering difficult science! Its not clear that I can just keep learning and thinking about my subjects and that will somehow get me a PhD!/>
<comment QuestionId="About email contact with prospective advisors who are yet to join the institute" AnswerId="CwCu2zGhrgqZU9eg9MTMzg==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-23T05:56:02.743" Text="The issue is _they_ have not agreed to supervise _you._ You should have checked with them if they wanted these updates, how often they would like to talk or meet with you, and so on. If they haven't given any indication that what you're doing is appreciated, then you may want to back off a little. Wait a few weeks before contacting them again. _Ask them_ about how to continue this process. At this point, they may not be as willing to do so as before./>
<comment QuestionId="About email contact with prospective advisors who are yet to join the institute" AnswerId="CwCu2zGhrgqZU9eg9MTMzg==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-23T00:20:20.437" Text="That's a reasonable approach if they asked you to do this work (or at least agreed with you that you should do it). However, if you're doing this &quot;unsolicited,&quot; then you're effectively asking them to commit time to reading and evaluating this work when they may not actually have the time to do so./>
<comment QuestionId="About email contact with prospective advisors who are yet to join the institute" AnswerId="CwCu2zGhrgqZU9eg9MTMzg==" Author="6683" Date="2013-06-23T01:22:08.777" Text="@aesmail The works started off in two different ways (1) the first person happened to attend my group meeting talk and he made very useful comments and then I started corresponding with him after that and he met me once and gave me various feedback on future emails- but has been now silent since 1 week! (2) The second person when contacted by me gave me a list of topics that we could probably work on and then I sent him details of my studies on those topics - and then he has also been silent for a week! -/>
<comment QuestionId="About email contact with prospective advisors who are yet to join the institute" AnswerId="CwCu2zGhrgqZU9eg9MTMzg==" Author="6683" Date="2013-06-23T01:23:05.420" Text="@aesmail I don't know what to do given that they are my best advisor options here - though they will be in campus full-time only from 2014./>
<comment QuestionId="About email contact with prospective advisors who are yet to join the institute" AnswerId="CwCu2zGhrgqZU9eg9MTMzg==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-23T05:37:41.757" Text="You are _not yet_ their advisee. They are under no _obligation_ to respond to your email on any sort of schedule! The innocent explanation is they're on vacation, and haven't seen your recent emails. It's also possible they've had more important issues to deal with. It's also possible that they're not appreciative of the emails—particularly if you've already been sending them frequently without being asked to do so (which appears to be the case here)./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10717" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10717" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10717" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>

academia.stackexchange.com_10714	<question QuestionId="Official abbreviations for CS conferences" Title="Official abbreviations for CS conferences" Views="143" Tags="journals,conference,computer-science" " AnswerId="XpWHfF5We33/bi1XE8CTSA==" Author="26" Date="2013-06-22T06:57:09.227" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;Some journals like to abbreviate journal names in the papers they publish, and the AMS maintains &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ams.org/msnhtml/serials.pdf%20bgb&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;a list of abbreviated journal names&lt;/a&gt; for those who need them. Is there a similar resource for conferences (in computer science)?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;EDIT: to clarify, I'm not looking for acronyms (SODA, STOC, ICALP), but rather for something like &quot;Proc. 6th Ann. ACM-SIAM Symp. Discrete Algorithms&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Official abbreviations for CS conferences" AnswerId="XpWHfF5We33/bi1XE8CTSA==" Author="532" Date="2013-06-22T07:55:29.300" Text="usually I just take the .bib source of the paper whether its abbreviated or not/>
<comment QuestionId="Official abbreviations for CS conferences" AnswerId="XpWHfF5We33/bi1XE8CTSA==" Author="26" Date="2013-06-22T08:03:51.763" Text="@seteropere: I usually use unabbreviated citations, but I'm told to shorten a submission and I'd rather sacrifice unimportant parts like these before I modify the actual text./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10714" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10714" Date="2013-06-22T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10714" Date="2013-11-19T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Official abbreviations for CS conferences" AnswerId="X+Si6YEmi6ku81SwZDQ2Dg==" Author="351" Date="2013-06-22T13:31:45.587" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;AFAIK, there is no such resource, and even if it existed, it would not be very useful.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In general, people do not know the full names of the conference, only their acronyms. The full names tend to change slightly every now and then, while the acronyms are much more stable.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;You can safely write pretty much anything that resembles the correct name, as long as you include the acronym. You can often save some space by removing useless words such as &quot;Annual&quot;, &quot;International&quot;, &quot;ACM&quot;, &quot;IEEE&quot;, etc.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;For example, &lt;em&gt;&quot;Proc. 6th Symposium on Discrete Algorithms (SODA)&quot;&lt;/em&gt; would be perfectly fine and unambiguous.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Official abbreviations for CS conferences" AnswerId="X+Si6YEmi6ku81SwZDQ2Dg==" Author="5912" Date="2013-06-22T14:39:23.750" Text="@Anonymous: &quot;IEEE&quot; isn't on the cover title of [the Proceedings](http://ieee-focs.org/images/FOCScover.gif) for the FOCS conference. How do you justify putting it in?/>
<comment QuestionId="Official abbreviations for CS conferences" AnswerId="X+Si6YEmi6ku81SwZDQ2Dg==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-22T22:39:02.957" Text="@JeffE: That's exactly what I meant by listing it separately (but not modifying the title to include it).  I meant the &quot;IEEE Computer Society&quot; as being the publisher, not a continuation of the title./>
<comment QuestionId="Official abbreviations for CS conferences" AnswerId="X+Si6YEmi6ku81SwZDQ2Dg==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-22T14:50:03.650" Text="@Peter Shor: If it's not in the title, one certainly shouldn't modify the title to include it, but it's worth listing separately then (&quot;Foundations of Computer Science 1997, IEEE Computer Society, ...&quot;).  For really major conferences it's not such a big deal, but minor conferences can be difficult to track down, and even major conferences may be unfamiliar to people in other fields./>
<comment QuestionId="Official abbreviations for CS conferences" AnswerId="X+Si6YEmi6ku81SwZDQ2Dg==" Author="5912" Date="2013-06-22T14:06:42.853" Text="Why wouldn't it be useful? Some journals have a misguided official policy of not using conference acronyms, and it would be good to have a standard set of abbreviations of conferences to use in these journals./>
<comment QuestionId="Official abbreviations for CS conferences" AnswerId="X+Si6YEmi6ku81SwZDQ2Dg==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-22T22:25:24.530" Text="I disagree with @AnonymousMathematician; if the society isn't named in the title, _don't_ add it to the title. Report the title literally.  I rare cases that Google doesn't find the correct proceedings as the first hit, you should definitely include the publisher in the citation (for example, Springer), but not in the title./>
<comment QuestionId="Official abbreviations for CS conferences" AnswerId="X+Si6YEmi6ku81SwZDQ2Dg==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-22T14:17:04.793" Text="Removing &quot;Annual&quot; and &quot;International&quot; might be OK if you really have to save space, but it's better not to remove the &quot;ACM&quot; or &quot;IEEE&quot;, since knowing the sponsor makes the conference easier to track down./>

<answer QuestionId="Official abbreviations for CS conferences" AnswerId="CZWoa/Dwwv3Sbj8joUlvjw==" Author="532" Date="2013-06-22T08:19:20.640" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am not aware of any &lt;em&gt;comprehensive&lt;/em&gt; list of abbreviations for CS conferences. One way to see many abbreviations is through CS conference listings and ranking. For example, &lt;a href=&quot;http://core.edu.au/cms/images/downloads/conference/08sort%20acronymERA2010_conference_list.pdf&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_computer_science_conferences&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;here&lt;/a&gt;. The most obvious way is googling the name of the conference then checking the conference website. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10725	<question QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" Title="How common is college graduation at an early age" Views="564" Tags="graduate-school,undergraduate" " AnswerId="LNDtUX9a2Q9R3kWtgN2+gA==" Author="7493" Date="2013-06-23T03:01:25.017" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am interested in the statistics of early college graduation, or more generally, the statistics of extreme ages in academic settings (highschool, college, grad school, etc.). For instance, how many students who earn a college degree graduate one, two, three, or more years earlier than the typical age of 22 or so? I am willing for any statistics to qualified in any way (percentages in country W, at university X, in state Y, or from year Z). A quick Google search does not easily reveal this information.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I estimate that less than 5% of the population graduates college two years earlier than normal based on my acquaintances, but this is likely biased as I am a graduate student and it may be smaller.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;EDIT: It occurs to me that my question does not ask for any opinions on whether early graduation is good, neutral, or bad. Perhaps it would be interesting to expand the question and have those who experienced graduating early give their stories or opinions.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

I fit the latter category but not the former./>

<comment QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" AnswerId="LNDtUX9a2Q9R3kWtgN2+gA==" Author="7123" Date="2013-07-02T07:45:47.680" Text="I started early and skipped a grade, before spending four years in college. I think the biggest concern that people have is that skipping grades can be socially awkward, but I actually skipped largely for social reasons: I was splitting my time between two grades with different schedules, and when I moved, I just decided to take all my classes in the same grade (my school agreed). The other thing is that you spend _years_ getting used to being younger than everyone else, so when you get to college, it's not that much different. I can elaborate more in an answer if you have specific questions./>

<answer QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" AnswerId="8USaaAEWCdTCbPj7BIlmVg==" Author="929" Date="2013-06-26T07:28:35.107" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;In the UK this number is likely to be extremely small. Within our department we circulate a list of all students under the age of 18 at the beginning of the year. This includes both our students as well as students sitting in on our classes. For this sample size of about 500 per year the number under 18 is typically about 1%. Of these, the vast majority turn 18 there first year. Further there is either a bug in our software, possible, or the remainder turn 18 during the summer since I have never been told about a 2nd year student being under 18. The sample size for 2nd year students is about half as big since we do not get drop ins to our second year classes.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Obviously this could be biased by our department or university not attracting these students.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10765" Date="2013-06-28T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10765" Date="2013-06-26T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" AnswerId="La4H61hRGqreXCEbcfpYIw==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-23T21:04:42.340" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;At least in the USA, the number is probably &lt;em&gt;much&lt;/em&gt; smaller than 5 percent. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The reason for this is that there are generally fixed lengths for education, and minimum enrollment ages at which the process can start (at least for publicly educated students, who are still the majority).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Finishing two or more years ahead of schedule means that you probably have had at least two events that belong to the following categories:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Started education a year earlier than &quot;normal&quot; (perhaps because of birthday-limited enrollments)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Skipped a grade during primary or secondary (high-school) education&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&quot;Accelerated&quot; college studies by reducing the expected enrollment time by either a semester or a full year (through early accumulation of credits via work in high school, or taking college placement exams, credit overloading, and other methods)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The first is the most common, but still only applies to about one-third of the population. The others are much less frequent, with the second probably pertaining to only about 1 percent of students (if that many). The third also probably is not that common, but I don't have hard numbers (but again, probably less than 5 percent of college students finish in three years or less!).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now remember that you have to have at least &lt;em&gt;two&lt;/em&gt; such events, and you can start to see why the odds are stacked against a 5 percent rate. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" AnswerId="La4H61hRGqreXCEbcfpYIw==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-24T16:06:27.763" Text="@aeismail, Ah, ok, I didn't understand the specifics of your point there. Perhaps a person who'd be asking the question in the first place would benefit from your amplifying your points?/>
<comment QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" AnswerId="La4H61hRGqreXCEbcfpYIw==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-23T23:31:33.807" Text="Good analysis/explanation./>
<comment QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" AnswerId="La4H61hRGqreXCEbcfpYIw==" Author="1010" Date="2013-07-12T12:35:12.920" Text="As you say, publicly educated students are in the majority overall; however, my impression is that precocious students are disproportionately likely to be privately educated or homeschooled (neither of which are particularly unusual in the US).  Of course, this is probably *because* these options don't necessarily require a regimented progression through numbered grades, so they'll appeal to students naturally inclined to an accelerated timetable.  Thus, I think that concentrating on the issues facing public-school students will tend to undercount./>
<comment QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" AnswerId="La4H61hRGqreXCEbcfpYIw==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-24T13:45:49.287" Text="@JeffE: My first point means rules like &quot;Start at age 6 unless you were born after (for instance) September 1, in which case start at age 5.&quot;/>
<comment QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" AnswerId="La4H61hRGqreXCEbcfpYIw==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-24T16:04:05.290" Text="@paulgarrett: That's my point 3—reducing the time of study through any means, whether it be &quot;overloading&quot; on credits or placing out through tests./>
<comment QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" AnswerId="La4H61hRGqreXCEbcfpYIw==" Author="746" Date="2013-06-26T01:16:39.647" Text="I graduated early by taking more than the typical limit of courses per semester, dual enrolling, and taking summer courses./>
<comment QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" AnswerId="La4H61hRGqreXCEbcfpYIw==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-24T03:23:58.607" Text="Hm... I met only one of those three criteria, but I graduated at 20./>
<comment QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" AnswerId="La4H61hRGqreXCEbcfpYIw==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-25T04:38:34.037" Text="The first point is disconnected, since it's just when your birthday falls on the calendar. The other two are more likely to be correlated. (As far as statistics are concerned, the university I attended rarely has more than 0.5% graduate a year early.)/>
<comment QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" AnswerId="La4H61hRGqreXCEbcfpYIw==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-24T15:32:32.997" Text="There is another possibility, namely, &quot;testing out&quot; and earning credit for it. In the U.S., the &quot;AP&quot; (advanced placement) courses in high school supposedly help toward this. One can also negotiate such things on an individual basis. In extreme cases, one can generate many more credits, and complete requirements, than the time would otherwise allow. Naturally, one must have read some relevant books _sometime_, and/or be a good test-taker./>
<comment QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" AnswerId="La4H61hRGqreXCEbcfpYIw==" Author="7493" Date="2013-06-24T23:42:12.627" Text="I like your breakdown. Though, may it be possible that these events are highly correlated? If one skips a grade in highschool or earlier, they may be more likely to accelerate through college? Also, I am still interested in any references to statistics, or personal experience. I came up with my estimate after thinking over my acquaintances./>

<answer QuestionId="How common is college graduation at an early age" AnswerId="tjEHxnelO+VSPQP3pG9L5Q==" Author="7123" Date="2013-07-11T21:41:28.237" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;Specifically addressing the edit to to the question regarding experiences as a younger student:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Aside from what I've already posted in my comment, I guess the only social aspect that I felt I missed out on was getting into university-sponsored senior class events where alcohol was served (I was under 21 at a US school). Most of the time, my age was not an issue socially. I was also an RA (residential advisor), so my age was not assumed to correlate with lack of leadership ability. Academically, it might have even helped me get certain positions, because I was seen as a &quot;driven&quot; individual with prior academic success, and all of those positions helped me get into graduate school. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Now that I'm in graduate school, the only thing I really miss is not having interesting stories to tell about cool things I did during my gap year(s). That problem is common to a lot of people in my class, though, regardless of them being a few years older than me. I don't have people that are my age in my year, but I don't think it's affected my academic success here: I've had four years of high school, four years of undergrad, and three summers of undergraduate research, like (or better than) many of my peers.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10727	<question QuestionId="Changing fields from PhD to postdoc" Title="Changing fields from PhD to postdoc" Views="868" Tags="career-path,career" " AnswerId="mOHKuufrdeA6mRF9cNtgxQ==" Author="7494" Date="2013-06-23T13:40:54.423" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;All of the following takes place in a UK university&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I have a BSc in Physics and an MSc in Computer Science. My thesis was on applying various machine learning/statistical techniques to biological datasets. I wanted to do something similar for my PhD, however my supervisor left the university. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I am now in the first year of my PhD in Computer Science, specifically Computational Biology. My work focuses on comparing different techniques (physical/statistical/machine learning) in single cell simulations. I am finding it hard to incorporate machine learning techniques into my work as there aren't many datasets for the kind of thing my supervisor wants me to do and so the machine learning approach is proving tricky.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I desperately want a job/postdoc in a machine learning/stats environment. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Lots of post docs I know switched field after their phd e.g. Astro-physics to machine learning, dependable systems to machine learning, Biophysics to compiler design. In my case would anyone in the ML community take me seriously? (I thought my msc would help me out...) &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;I have taught myself a fair bit of ML and stats, is there anything else I should do to increase the likelihood of getting an ML/stats postdoc?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Would anyone in a stats department take me seriously as I have no maths degree?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Do people that change career areas have successful careers or is this normally a red flag? &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thanks guys&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Changing fields from PhD to postdoc" AnswerId="mOHKuufrdeA6mRF9cNtgxQ==" Author="6862" Date="2013-06-23T16:15:18.200" Text="Are you planning to do theoretical CS work in your PhD, or will it only be application of known methods? <comment QuestionId="Changing fields from PhD to postdoc" AnswerId="mOHKuufrdeA6mRF9cNtgxQ==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-23T20:25:18.280" Text="_is there anything else I should do to increase the likelihood of getting an ML/stats postdoc?_ — Yes.  **Publish.**/>
<comment QuestionId="Changing fields from PhD to postdoc" AnswerId="mOHKuufrdeA6mRF9cNtgxQ==" Author="5944" Date="2013-06-24T17:16:47.790" Text="One question I would ask is if you're in the first year of the Ph.D, but are thinking so far ahead that you want your eventual career to be about ML, why not switch gears and go into ML right now (or after your project) by switching topics/advisors/data sets, or getting collaboration with an ML prof, etc.?/>
<comment QuestionId="Changing fields from PhD to postdoc" AnswerId="mOHKuufrdeA6mRF9cNtgxQ==" Author="7494" Date="2013-06-24T21:12:45.117" Text="@Irwin this is exactly what I am trying to do, I am trying to make my current work as ML-centric as possible. <comment QuestionId="Changing fields from PhD to postdoc" AnswerId="mOHKuufrdeA6mRF9cNtgxQ==" Author="7494" Date="2013-06-23T17:45:30.053" Text="@Bitwise I'm pretty sure that it will be mostly applications of existing techniques. <answer QuestionId="Changing fields from PhD to postdoc" AnswerId="rhTt+ma1dG4a2wfWGwPLXg==" Author="14619" Date="2014-04-27T20:23:33.090" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;It depends strongly on what you want to do after pursing a PhD degree. More precisely, if you want to work as a technical staff then yes. It affects your career chances because it doesn't help a company that you are an expert, and therefore they have to pay you more than the average, in a different area and you don't have a &lt;em&gt;proven&lt;/em&gt; solid background in the area where they want to be hired.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, if you decided for working as a manager, sale, marketing or administration (e.g. signing applications) then it doesn't matter in which field do you have your PhD. In some positions, it is required to have a PhD title, no more. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Changing fields from PhD to postdoc" AnswerId="tMGwM1Zj4D6SGts+FAWHWQ==" Author="6862" Date="2013-06-24T00:45:38.323" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;My answer is based more on experience from computational biology, but I think it is relevant for other fields:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Changing fields is very common in academia, especially at the PhD/postdoc transition. In many cases it is actually considered an advantage, since you can import your skills, expertise and a certain thought-process into a field in which many people do not have those skills. For example, many physicists, computer scientists and mathematicians have migrated to biology and have made significant contributions. In fact, there are even postdoctoral fellowships that specifically fund this type of field-change.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Regarding your &quot;will they take me seriously&quot; questions: Since you are aiming mostly at applied ML/stats, I don't think you should be too concerned if the ML/stats theoretical community take you seriously. Many theorists tend to look down on applied science - don't worry about it, you can still have a significant impact without advancing any theory. It sounds like in the future you will either belong to the department in which you want to apply the techniques (e.g. a biology department) or will work very closely with people in those departments. In this case, you will usually be considered the ML/stats expert.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Having said all that, of course it is your job to become an expert. Teaching yourself the theory is important, but if you are going for applied science, especially applied ML/stats, it would be a big advantage to get actual experience in using them. There is a huge difference between learning about these methods and actually implementing and using them. You will see that during your PhD you can often expand your research in directions you are more interested in. It shouldn't be too difficult to use some ML/stats creatively in some sub-projects (which could later be expanded).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Changing fields from PhD to postdoc" AnswerId="tMGwM1Zj4D6SGts+FAWHWQ==" Author="7494" Date="2013-06-24T12:38:35.460" Text="thanks. If I were to decide that I wanted to stay in a CS department and work on something more theoretical, then I suppose my publications would have to include coming up with some novel techniques instead of just applying existing ones?/>
<comment QuestionId="Changing fields from PhD to postdoc" AnswerId="tMGwM1Zj4D6SGts+FAWHWQ==" Author="6862" Date="2013-06-24T13:00:50.023" Text="@RRs_Ghost theoretical work would either be coming up with new methods, improving/expanding current methods or general theoretical work. Of course when I say &quot;coming up with a new method&quot;, I mean this in the theoretical sense, i.e. mathematically developing the method and proving certain properties of it (e.g. convergence to a good solution with the increase of the amount of data)./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10734" Date="2014-04-28T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10734" Date="2014-04-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10734" Date="2013-06-24T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10734" Date="2013-06-24T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10734" Date="2014-04-27T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Changing fields from PhD to postdoc" AnswerId="MFZkt8XdBkUUVGwvdf2yQA==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-23T14:45:11.157" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;Some thoughts on your questions (please don't take any of this as gospel, I am in the final stages of my PhD and are looking for a Postdoc also).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Your ML MSc would more than likely benefit you in any postdoc application (to what extent would depend on the institution).  Something to consider, is it possible to build/include ML principles in your current research?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;One major way to get noticed in the fields that you are interested in is to get published in peer-reviewed journals and present at relevant conferences.  Speak to academics involved in your field of interest, speak to your supervisor/advisor - perhaps inquire if there would be a chance of collaborative papers/conference presentations.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As for changing career paths, this is increasingly the norm - my own example is a switch from economic geology, through teaching to atmospheric physics.  One major thing about this aspect is to focus on the skills that you have developed, particularly in research.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I hope this helps.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Changing fields from PhD to postdoc" AnswerId="MFZkt8XdBkUUVGwvdf2yQA==" Author="7494" Date="2013-06-23T17:46:34.650" Text="Thanks, I have the opportunity to teach some AI &amp; ML stuff this coming academic year so I will make the most of that opportunity. Also, that's quite a switch!/>
<comment QuestionId="Changing fields from PhD to postdoc" AnswerId="MFZkt8XdBkUUVGwvdf2yQA==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-23T19:59:34.090" Text="Teaching AI and ML will definitely help as well!/>

The problem is that I have to work in my native country. I have read that this university, UNISA, is known because of their online Master and Doctoral studies.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The question that I have is because I see different comments from people from United States or Europe that wanted to enter into this online degrees. In case of the latter, which institution of quality offers online PhD degrees in CS?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Consider that this question is not focused locally, because as I mentioned in the aforementioned paragraph; there are people from all over the world that want to take those UNISA degrees.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

I would suggest you get a list of supervisors and then check their backgrounds, to ensure they have the necessary skills. This university is very popular in the southern hemisphere, has huge physical locations in Pretoria and Johannesburg, and has various research related on-site workshops for masters and PhD students including everything from R to SPSS. (Disclaimer: completing my M here currently)./>

<answer QuestionId="What is the statusreputation of the University of South Africa (UNISA)" AnswerId="aZSwQ6UYRV7wRE9s8XeYxw==" Author="12047" Date="2014-02-18T01:38:53.453" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'm a postdoc at the Computer Laboratory at the University of Cambridge, and do collaborate with some researchers at UNISA. However, this is with the Department of Decision Sciences, rather than Computer Science - I don't know the latter.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When it comes to PhD studies, generally the advisor plays a large role, too, compared to the university. I'd recommend to look at what and where the potential advisors for you publish, where their co-authors are from etc to get a vague impression how connected and well-regarded they'll be in your chosen discipline.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="What is the statusreputation of the University of South Africa (UNISA)" AnswerId="lKzT5tzCTTqbmbyDJJtaZA==" Author="406" Date="2013-06-27T13:00:45.360" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;I do not have a direct experience with UNISA, but this kind of universities (having massive number of students) does not have international reputation usually. They normally address the local needs for graduating professionals, but what pushes a university among top ones is interactive connection of the staff and students, which is almost impossible to be conducted in a university with 5,000 staff and 300,000 students (even in the digital world).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thus, if you do care about your education and reputation of your PhD degree, it is more reasonable to choose a university with international standards.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="What is the statusreputation of the University of South Africa (UNISA)" AnswerId="Vb8U27unt9MKxeU+ANWHcw==" Author="11365" Date="2014-02-25T06:46:48.120" Score="9" Text="&lt;p&gt;I offer the following evidence from credible and official sources &lt;strong&gt;against&lt;/strong&gt; doing a PhD in Computer Science at UNISA:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Low graduation rates&lt;/strong&gt;:  17 doctoral students graduated from the College of Science, Engineering, and Techonology (which includes the PhD in Computer Science degree) in 2010, 2011, and 2012 combined. Compare this to the 99 doctoral student enrollments five years earlier in 2005, 2006, and 2007 (combined). Graduation rates are expected to be somewhat low for distance learning students, but rates this low are a bad sign. (&lt;a href=&quot;http://osprey.unisa.ac.za/pg/req.pdf&quot;&gt;PDF source&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Inadequate supervisory capacity&lt;/strong&gt;: The school admits that &quot;many [research] areas in the School of Computing have reached supervisory capacity&quot; and says that &quot;long waiting lists started forming due to lack of supervisors,&quot; which is another worrying sign.  (&lt;a href=&quot;http://osprey.unisa.ac.za/pg/req.pdf&quot;&gt;Same source&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Very, very low research output&lt;/strong&gt;: Research output is arguably the most important indicator of a reputable PhD program. On &lt;a href=&quot;http://osprey.unisa.ac.za/supervisors.php&quot;&gt;this page&lt;/a&gt;, 6 professors in the School of Computing (which offers the PhD in Computer Science degree) are listed as having openings for PhD students. I looked up the Google Scholar and/or DBLP profiles of these 6 (for those that had them) and consulted personal pages of the rest to get a sense of their research productivity. &#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Averages across two years (2012 and 2013), the number of publications per person per year was 0.58 on average (range of 0-1.5)&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Of the 7 publications I found for these professors in 2012 and 2013, 3 were in conferences or journals with the name &quot;Africa&quot; in the title (i.e., not international venues). So the average publication rate per person per year in non-local venues was 0.33.&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10730	<question QuestionId="Should I pursue a second MSc or start a PhD" Title="Should I pursue a second MSc or start a PhD" Views="356" Tags="phd,publishing,research,masters,computer-science" " AnswerId="yP5tJ/pLuhvT9+JoNdusPQ==" Author="7496" Date="2013-06-23T17:09:53.777" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I am currently studying in a small university and I will finish my master's degree in CS about in 6 months. Now, I am thinking how should I continue my academic career. I think I have at least three options:&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;1) Stay in my current university, and start a PhD (I already have two research papers)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;I have some very good contacts here, but on the other hand I have some serious problems with my supervisor. Because our university is so small, it is not possible to change supervisor.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;I have some good ideas how to continue the research, but very probably my supervisor would not let me to pursue them. The papers my supervisor would make me to do instead might get filled up with names who did not really participate in the research (again, because of my supervisor).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;If I can somehow manage to avoid my supervisor as much as possible, I could do research with other people, but not 100% of the time.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Since I already have published papers, I would probably get the PhD quite fast from my current university.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;My family would live closer to me&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;2) Do another master's degree in a bigger university on a topic other than CS that has fascinated me for years. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;Is another master's degree wasted time?&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;3) Do a PhD in a bigger university.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;ul&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;A bigger university would enable me to make more, since they do not have problems of having needed equipment, funding, etc.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;I would not know anyone there, and I might end up with another bad supervisor.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;My family would live far away&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ul&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Well, honestly, I have almost abandoned 1) already. Any ideas?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Should I pursue a second MSc or start a PhD" AnswerId="yP5tJ/pLuhvT9+JoNdusPQ==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-23T20:24:01.383" Text="_A bigger university would enable me to make more_ — Do not confuse size with availability of resources.  You want a _stronger_ department, but not necessarily a _bigger_ one./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10730" Date="2013-06-27T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10730" Date="2013-07-29T00:00:00.000/>

<answer QuestionId="Should I pursue a second MSc or start a PhD" AnswerId="ol0HjxjJmWFEbsee5oyClA==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-23T17:27:35.007" Score="6" Text="&lt;p&gt;A situation in which you do not get along with your current advisor is &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; one that you want to maintain indefinitely, particularly because your advisor's recommendation and participation is normally required to launch a career afterwards. Having an advisor who is not on your side can make life very, very difficult indeed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As for choosing between (2) and (3), I wouldn't do another degree—either a second master's &lt;strong&gt;or&lt;/strong&gt; a PhD—&lt;em&gt;unless&lt;/em&gt; you were planning to make it the basis for a career. Otherwise, you are wasting your time, since it's not going to be a credential that helps you in the long run.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

academia.stackexchange.com_10733	<question QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" Title="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" Views="3681" Tags="phd,plagiarism" " AnswerId="OpyueevZm+wbvsXG41/iPw==" Author="7502" Date="2013-06-24T00:44:57.460" Score="41" Text="&lt;p&gt;Here's a not so hypothetical situation. International student x is very talented but comes from a background where technical writing is not taught and understood. She writes a great thesis with a good literature review and nice results. However, the results are based on two key papers from previous students in the group. She decides to give credit to the papers in a special chapter, which she starts by saying &quot;I need to give credit to this and that paper&quot; and proceeds with copying paragraphs wholesale to describe what those other students did. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;This was a few years back; X is now faculty at a good school and she contacts me (past advisor) in teary-terrified voice to let me know that she plagiarized in her thesis. I am now in a panic as well. How could I miss those? And how could she do that?? We both risk losing our jobs, and she is at risk of losing her degree as well (which, by the way, was a very strong thesis with a good number of top journal publications). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As far as I know there's no process for revising a thesis after it's been submitted and I don't know what else to do short of turning ourselves in - which I feel morally obligated to do.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Please advise. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Edit&lt;/em&gt; &#xA;Thanks all for weighing in on this. I spent the night going through the thesis and there appear to be three more sources that are suspect of being plagiarized, all in the same wretched chapter; one is a thesis of a colleague, the other is a textbook and the third is a book I wrote a while back. So this is more serious than I thought. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;She has unfortunately not used quotes for the material, i.e., instead of saying &quot;[paper i] says ,&quot; she just went on with &quot;[paper i] says this and that.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;She has &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; been accused of plagiarism by anybody. I am guessing that she has finally come to grips with good writing standards and upon looking through her thesis she realized that her &quot;summary&quot; was actually plagiarism. I have every reason to believe that she dd what she did in good faith (she has proved her honesty on many occasions). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="OpyueevZm+wbvsXG41/iPw==" Author="3900" Date="2013-06-24T03:51:08.860" Text="Any text which is attributed is not plagiarism. If I write, 'John Smith wrote &quot;&lt;whatever&gt;&quot;', then &lt;whatever&gt; is not plagiarism. What is going on here is **alleged** plagiarism. Fight the allegations. Find out how they are substantiated and strike at those arguments. Simple as that./>
<comment QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="OpyueevZm+wbvsXG41/iPw==" Author="532" Date="2013-06-24T05:05:19.340" Text="what makes her *-after few years-* think that she plagiarised? I can't see the plagiarism./>
<comment QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="OpyueevZm+wbvsXG41/iPw==" Author="3900" Date="2013-06-24T07:15:36.933" Text="Ideally, what is needed here is to obtain a version of the paper from the accusers which is properly annotated with clear indications where the alleged plagiarisms occur, down to the starting and ending word of each one. Each one should be given a number or identifier, and then discussed in attached notes.  There should be one final version of this annotated paper which everyone involved signs off on, so that the accusations of plagiarism are **not an unfair, moving target**.  Then the instances of alleged plagiarism can be dealt with calmly on a case-by-case basis./>
<comment QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="OpyueevZm+wbvsXG41/iPw==" Author="49" Date="2013-06-24T08:41:39.450" Text="Do you have any reasons to assume it was in good faith (e.g. verbatim instead of 'in own words' of an otherwise cited material, because of lack of exposure to the contemporary culture of scientific writing)? Are the plagiarized people aware of it? If so, what is there stance?/>
<comment QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="OpyueevZm+wbvsXG41/iPw==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-24T00:57:54.923" Text="related (not a duplicate) http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/1482/who-is-responsible-for-detecting-plagiarism-in-a-phd-thesis?rq=1/>
<comment QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="OpyueevZm+wbvsXG41/iPw==" Author="6862" Date="2013-06-24T01:51:05.010" Text="Perhaps there is some form of mechanism for adding errata or clarifications to a thesis? Googling &quot;errata phd thesis&quot; results in quite a few such documents./>
<comment QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="OpyueevZm+wbvsXG41/iPw==" Author="7055" Date="2013-06-25T08:27:59.637" Text="So, I know this isn't very constructive, but .. As you say, how did you miss this?   You read your student's thesis and didn't notice material plagiarized *from your own book*?   I mean, I'd think you *might* recognize the work of your colleauge or 'other students in the group', but your own work ...   Did you actually read the thesis before it was submitted?/>
<comment QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="OpyueevZm+wbvsXG41/iPw==" Author="7502" Date="2013-06-24T02:02:37.003" Text="Bitwise, thanks for looking this up. I feel that errata would probably be acceptable if it were for only a few words or equations. Not sure about doing an erratum for a lot of material./>
<comment QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="OpyueevZm+wbvsXG41/iPw==" Author="4512" Date="2013-06-24T19:28:23.397" Text="All this discussion makes it abundantly clear that most academics don't understand the subtle meanings of the word &quot;plagiarism.&quot; There is the *unattributed* republishing of facts, as academics tend to care about, and there is the *unauthorized* reproduction of exact wording, as is the concern of copyright law (which does *not* cover facts in the US - see *Feist Publications v. Rural Telephone Service*). This is a rather important distinction, and a good answer should address it./>
<comment QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="OpyueevZm+wbvsXG41/iPw==" Author="7502" Date="2013-06-24T12:12:39.017" Text="Thanks all for weighing in on this. I spent the night going through the thesis and there appear to be three more sources that are suspect of being plagiarized, all in the same wretched chapter; one is a thesis of a colleague, the other is a textbook and the third is a book I wrote a while back. So this is more serious than I thought./>

<answer QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="S7GadDMqbxG0ePLtnssP9g==" Author="6144" Date="2013-06-24T02:37:04.070" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;Well, here is the responsability of two persons: the advisor and the student, but the amount of responsability is somehow lesser for the advisor. I am pretty sure that your past student has signed a non-plagiarism form or put an statement that she was not plagiarizing anything in her thesis work, so she was doing that on purpose. It seems harsh my opinion, but it seems that way.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The only solution is to tell the truth to the Dean and for what I know, the penalty will come sooner or later. According to what you reply, that person plagiarized about 10 pages and also parts of the appendix, so in that case the only way out is to inform about the accident.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I do not think that she will lose her degree, remember the scandal that happened in Germany a few months ago?. The worse thing that could happen is that she get somehow &quot;banned&quot; from the journals that she has been cited, but only for a certain amount of time. About your case, I think that is not so probable that you will get into trouble.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Wish you the best.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

It's very well possible in the German system, even decades after the PhD was awarded, such as in the case of the former minister of eduction and research http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annette_Schavan/>

<answer QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="6cFccFiUJfsXmnroU2UhlA==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-24T02:57:25.520" Score="24" Text="&lt;p&gt;Did any of the plagiarized material make it into journal papers, or was it all literature review that was never published outside of the thesis?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If some of it made it into papers, then it's important to contact the journals and publish corrections.  This is more straightforward and predictable than dealing with the thesis itself.  If the plagiarism is confined to background material, then I don't think retracting the papers would be necessary.  Instead, I expect it would be possible to publish a correction that indicates the plagiarized portions and provides citations.  This would be embarrassing and would hurt her reputation a little, but it would solve the problem as far as the papers were concerned.  It would also strengthen the student's case for dealing with the thesis if she can say she voluntarily corrected the publications and did not need to retract any of them.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;If none of the plagiarized material was published elsewhere, then it's trickier.  Once all the original results are published in research papers, I doubt anyone will read the thesis and discover the plagiarism.  Even if they do, they might take pity on the student and ignore the plagiarism.  (I once ignored some mild plagiarism of my writing in the background sections of a thesis at another university.  The student had already graduated, and I found no evidence of plagiarism in any of his research papers.  If I knew for sure he could just file a correction to the thesis, then that would make sense, but I wouldn't want to potentially destroy his career over this mistake.)  So she might well get away with it if she doesn't say anything.  Still, I'd advise her to officially confess to the university.  Turning herself in is likely to lead to a &lt;em&gt;much&lt;/em&gt; better outcome than being caught by someone else.  Plus it's the right thing to do, and it will save her from years of worrying about getting caught.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;blockquote&gt;&#xA;  &lt;p&gt;We both risk losing our jobs, and she is at risk of losing her degree as well (which, by the way, was a very strong thesis with a good number of top journal publications). &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Unless your university is extraordinarily strict, I don't think your job is in jeopardy.  On the other hand, the student's degree or job might be, depending on how the university handles the situation.  Based on your description, I think it would be unfair for her career to be ruined, but I can't predict what will actually happen.  I hope your administration's sense of fairness is the same as mine, in which case a correction will suffice.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The hardest situation will be if she decides to remain silent.  In that case you probably have an obligation to turn her in, and it would look terrible if anyone found out that you knew but didn't say anything.  On the other hand, turning her in would be a tough decision.  Much better for her to turn herself in voluntarily.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="6cFccFiUJfsXmnroU2UhlA==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-24T03:26:31.580" Text="I'd be surprised if this ruins her career, I think it could be a very valuable and hard-earned learning experience./>
<comment QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="6cFccFiUJfsXmnroU2UhlA==" Author="7502" Date="2013-06-24T03:13:11.300" Text="Good points, Anonymous Mathematician. The plagiarism was limited to background information. None of the material made it into publications. It really wasn't the literature review (which she did in earnest), but the chapter after the literature review, where she specifically cited the initial papers on the topic. I agree that coming clean is the only thing to do and realistically her thesis is very strong otherwise. I would just hate to see her career ruined since she did very well as a PI so far./>

<answer QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="8eOEj8czA///MDOTiiN+SA==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-24T01:05:48.490" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;Take what I say below as a perspective, I am by no means an expert in how to deal with plagiarism.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I will say (as someone who has been plagiarised before), detecting and preventing plagiarism is the responsibility of all involved. But, having said that, we are human and we make mistakes - is it just that special chapter that has the plagiarism?  How much did she copy?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I think being open and upfront is the best (and most probably, the &lt;em&gt;only&lt;/em&gt;) course of action, as it would be far worse for both of you if it was detected by another academic, or worse still - the authors of the papers plagiarised.  It may be best to be &lt;em&gt;honest&lt;/em&gt; about both of your &lt;em&gt;mistake&lt;/em&gt;, rather than being &lt;em&gt;perceived&lt;/em&gt; in trying to cover it up.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Perhaps, find out what options are available in terms of resubmitting the thesis, or even the chapter in question.  The original research in your former student's papers may also be in both of your favour in that it would show no malicious intent.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

I am working on the thesis now to make sure that there isn't anything else fishy about that chapter./>

She copied about 10 thesis pages worth of material and there's some ancillary material in an appendix as well. Worse still, the papers were from our group./>

They had a temporary sanction placed on them (similar to what Layla mentions in her answer), but that was temporary.  The academic apologised to me, and nowadays all is good for all concerned./>

<answer QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="ih7+0AI5i9aGq2h2p/y1ow==" Author="929" Date="2013-06-24T07:34:21.410" Score="12" Text="&lt;p&gt;First off, just to make it clear, this is plagiarism. Providing a reference and then long string of text implies that the text is YOUR description of ideas of someone ELSE. To give full credit to someone else requires some sort of formatting distinction (typically block indentation or quotation makes). Potentially the plagiarism was accidental, but it is still plagiarism.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Supervisor&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A doctoral dissertation is generally a single author piece of independent work. Plagiarism in a dissertation should have little direct impact on the career of the supervisor. It might have some indirect consequences like people questioning how you can be so unfamiliar with your students work that you do not catch plagiarism, but I think most people would be pretty understanding about this. If the thesis was not single author or if the work was published with your name on it, that is a different story since co-authorship implies you have BOTH plagiarized.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Failure to report academic misconducted (whether it is your student or not) can impact your career. At my university we do not classify failure of a student to report academic misconducted of another student as academic misconducted. I don't know the disciplinary process when faculty are involved. Personally, I would say that we all have a responsibility to the scientific process to report ALL cases of academic misconduct that we are aware of.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Student&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;At my University, the penalty for plagiarism by a current student is zero on the piece of work. This would mean the student would have failed her dissertation. As a department we would deem this penalty too severe and push that she would be able to re-submit a new dissertation that reuses the non-plagiarized material. The University would push back and ask for a completely independent dissertation. I have never experienced this with a PhD student, but this occurs regularly with our final year undergraduates and about 70% of the time the student is allowed to reuse the non-plagiarized material.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I don't know what would happen if the plagiarism was found after the degree was given. My guess is the University would have to retract the dissertation from the library and any electronic database. They may revoke the degree, but they could also look at other work and count those towards the dissertation.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The current university may try and fire or penalize her, but this seems harsh compared to the typical penalty of plagiarism in a dissertation of not getting/delaying a degree.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="ih7+0AI5i9aGq2h2p/y1ow==" Author="6346" Date="2013-06-24T12:40:52.690" Text="&quot;people questioning how you can be so unfamiliar with your students work that you do not catch plagiarism, but I think most people would be pretty understanding about this.&quot; its not Master's fault ;)/>

She gave credit for the results,&#xA;it was in the context of describing other people's work, it seems to only involve&#xA;the language.  This is not a literary topic, so I would tell her to not worry about&#xA;it but learn how to write.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="What to do with otherwise good international student who has accidentally plagiarised part of PhD thesis" AnswerId="5X7sg9vTDTt3qOr8xaciLA==" Author="248" Date="2013-06-24T15:27:00.613" Text="An author owns both the written ideas and the language they used to express those ideas.  Failure to identify the original author of the ideas and/or the language is plagiarism and should be treated seriously./>
