academia.stackexchange.com_10745	<question QuestionId="when should I stop searching the literature" Title="when should I stop searching the literature" Views="211" Tags="literature-search" " AnswerId="PVE30HIZ/MNTiAQR6rBLuA==" Author="7382" Date="2013-06-24T17:21:27.110" Score="4" Text="&lt;p&gt;I'm seaarching the literature at the moment to write a literature review but I don't know when should I stop searching and start writing? &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="when should I stop searching the literature" AnswerId="PVE30HIZ/MNTiAQR6rBLuA==" Author="532" Date="2013-06-24T18:19:38.360" Text="you stop when you defend your thesis.. specially if there are other folks working on the same thing. Here is the trick: you either publish along the way (before thesis defense) or you will find your ideas in others papers./>
<comment QuestionId="when should I stop searching the literature" AnswerId="PVE30HIZ/MNTiAQR6rBLuA==" Author="65" Date="2013-06-25T02:05:35.807" Text="You should write while you search, not after you search./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10745" Date="2013-06-24T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10745" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10745" Date="2013-07-01T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10745" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10745" Date="2013-07-01T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10745" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10745" Date="2013-06-24T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10745" Date="2013-06-24T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10745" Date="2013-06-26T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="when should I stop searching the literature" AnswerId="7rciNuhXOPTVx3LPpdLx8Q==" Author="532" Date="2013-06-25T02:47:27.720" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;You need to be very productive in terms of knowing your area. &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;knowing&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; what is happening is different from &lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;understanding&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; it. This includes utilising every available tool which makes it easier to keep updated with what is published. An easy way , in Computer Science, is setting alerts (both on Arxiv and Google Scholar) and following pioneers in your area. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;As a personal experience, I spent plenty of time gathering, reading and understanding related papers/books. I came across many interesting ideas. But finally, I found some of my ideas are published in others papers. Some were exactly the same! This is the curse of PhD. Try to publish before others as long as you have the required knowledge and a clear contribution.  The literature is then translated to the cumulative process of publishing different papers related to your thesis problem.  You stop when you do the defence (assuming you will change the area thereafter).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10754" Date="2013-06-26T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10754" Date="2013-06-26T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10754" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="when should I stop searching the literature" AnswerId="uJKj/aFQCOnwPUx1U3rpPg==" Author="53" Date="2013-06-25T08:01:28.647" Score="5" Text="&lt;p&gt;The facile answer is &lt;strong&gt;you don't stop searching the literature&lt;/strong&gt;. Even as the review evolves, you should be including new references &lt;em&gt;if&lt;/em&gt; they are noteworthy in addressing questions within the field. This process should continue as long as you are working in the field of the problem.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Of course, from a practical standpoint, you do need to select a cutoff. There should be a reasonable point in time in which you've set the outline of the review, and decided on the main topics and questions to be discussed. At that point, it would be fair to set aside adding more references, and stick to what's been published. However, you should continue to monitor the field, and if further revisions or updates of the text are necessary, then you should include the papers published in the interim as part of your updates.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10756" Date="2013-06-26T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10756" Date="2013-06-30T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10756" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10756" Date="2013-07-24T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10756" Date="2013-06-26T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10756" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="when should I stop searching the literature" AnswerId="HztUnJHuddRqJczpZmzp9A==" Author="user7130" Date="2013-06-24T17:58:41.940" Score="0" Text="&lt;p&gt;You should develop an outline, in consultation with your advisor, of what is to be included in the literature review - this should be based on the research foci and priorities of your research.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;What I do when writing a literature review, is to actually write the review at the same time as doing the research.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;When should you stop?  when you have covered each of the foci and priorities to the point when you (and your advisor) are satisfied that you have synthesised the scope of each of the foci and priorities.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


</answer>
<answer QuestionId="when should I stop searching the literature" AnswerId="qnbfRL3YHCr0TofAtXq2PA==" Author="3890" Date="2013-06-25T09:06:55.197" Score="5" Text="&lt;ol&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Start writing the review &lt;strong&gt;before&lt;/strong&gt; (or at the same time) as you start searching the literature.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I'd suggest to determine the scope of the review before you start searching the literature, and &lt;strong&gt;already write it down&lt;/strong&gt;. This would answer questions like &lt;em&gt;Which problem am I looking at?&lt;/em&gt; or &lt;em&gt;Why is this problem relevant now?&lt;/em&gt; Answers to these questions will also guide your literature search.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt;Stop searching the literature when you stop writing.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Writing is not a linear process - it is going from a rough outline to a focussed text. As you go into focus, you will need to research more and more specific references. While you define your questions, search for literature dealing with these questions, and when you develop an argument, search for literature that would support (or contradict!) that argument.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&#xA;&lt;/ol&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My key suggestion would be to not view the literature search as shopping around randomly, but more like a visit to the grocery store with the shopping list in your hand.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Note that these suggestions apply to writing a literature review. &lt;a href=&quot;http://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/7615/how-to-stay-on-top-of-recent-literature&quot;&gt;Staying on top of recent literature&lt;/a&gt; or reading to get into a new field would be a different story.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10757" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10757" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10757" Date="2013-06-26T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10757" Date="2013-06-26T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10757" Date="2013-06-27T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>

<answer QuestionId="What percentage of STEM PhD applicants have peer-reviewed publications" AnswerId="dnZxnJupuuz0tnqKey9Krw==" Author="705" Date="2013-06-30T06:11:47.893" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;In computer science at a top-ranked US university, I'd estimate that about half of admitted Ph.D. students have a publication while they were an undergraduate.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;So, having a (good) publication is really helpful, but not an absolute necessity.  What matters most is research potential, i.e., the potential to be a successful researcher.  Showing that you have done good research that led to a publication is one powerful way to show that you have good research potential, but there are other ways (e.g., by doing research, getting strong letters of recommendation from folks you have worked with, excelling in academic work, doing independent work).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10855" Date="2013-06-30T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="What percentage of STEM PhD applicants have peer-reviewed publications" AnswerId="Zigcdbp7WJQQSsU6mzMCMw==" Author="6862" Date="2013-06-25T02:50:47.660" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;In countries where it is common to do a MSc, many PhD applicants have either published papers or prepared/submitted manuscripts, since a MSc would include a research thesis. The level of the publication can vary, and this can also vary by field (experimental projects typically take longer so probability of publication is smaller).&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<answer QuestionId="What percentage of STEM PhD applicants have peer-reviewed publications" AnswerId="wYoOXyPOHsl4LtgtJQ0oww==" Author="980" Date="2013-06-24T23:31:52.997" Score="13" Text="&lt;p&gt;In mathematics, at a 10-20 ranked place in mathematics, essentially &lt;em&gt;no&lt;/em&gt; grad-program applicants have an &lt;em&gt;real&lt;/em&gt; publications.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;About 1/3 may have some (as Suresh put it) &quot;fluff-pubs&quot; as spin-offs from summer REU programs. These are not &lt;em&gt;bad&lt;/em&gt; things, by any measure, but are more indicative of the socio-economic class of the applicant than their talent or potential. For that matter, it is sometimes quite awkward to explain to novices that their &quot;publication&quot; is a fluff-pub, not real. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Thus, in fact, there is an actual negative to fluff-pubs on an application, since it suggests a possible unfortunate rigidity or over-confidence.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;(Once again, in mathematics, if it were possible to do wonderful research in a few weeks over the summer, why does it take 5 years to earn a PhD? There is a misunderstanding... though, yes, it is good to cultivate enthusiasm among talented beginners! Let's just not lie to them.)&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

I didn't compile detailed numbers, but my sense is that the number of candidates with &quot;actual&quot; publications (as opposed to fluff pubs) is of the order of 5%. I suspect this number is higher for the top-ranked school. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

I don't mind that much though, if the student can articulate something about the actual research in their statement./>

If it's at a conference, workshop, or journal I've heard of (and don't classify as a write-only venue), it's a &quot;real&quot; publication./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10748	<question QuestionId="Finding number of publications in a subject" Title="Finding number of publications in a subject" Views="110" Tags="publications" " AnswerId="ZQCbH9eJFpLQQpTApaJ3WQ==" Author="7529" Date="2013-06-24T22:04:58.187" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;I have often seen in review papers in which the author mentions that there are more than # number of publications in the subject, to highlight the importance of the subject.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;How are such numbers determined? While searching for certain keywords in websites such as Scopus or ScienceDirect may be useful, it does not necessarily give an accurate number, as some publications may mention the keywords but not actually deal with the subject, while others may use synonyms of the keywords.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Finding number of publications in a subject" AnswerId="ZQCbH9eJFpLQQpTApaJ3WQ==" Author="1010" Date="2013-06-25T01:36:12.773" Text="Roll 3d20 and multiply by 50 :)  I think that would give you a number just as useful as any other method; i.e. impressing the reader while meaning nothing at all./>

<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10748" Date="2013-06-24T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10748" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10748" Date="2013-06-24T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Finding number of publications in a subject" AnswerId="YSbr0Y13n6dEZfanGk52Hw==" Author="7558" Date="2013-06-26T19:25:52.920" Score="1" Text="&lt;p&gt;In my field (mathematics) this can become even more questionable because there are papers that consider related problems, papers that consider problems that are essentially equivalent with a different terminology, and so on. The issue of different terminology is especially troublesome because you cannot search for consistent keywords. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Nevertheless this is an important metric. In mathematics you typically cannot point to real-world applications (any way, that is not the kind of importance you necessarily want for your paper). But it can provide context that the problem you are studying has been analyzed before, it gives you some other results that you can compare your paper to, and so on.  &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10775" Date="2013-06-26T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Finding number of publications in a subject" AnswerId="NQpi4PnDZhOQPOSpq/NrfA==" Author="532" Date="2013-06-25T00:53:25.150" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;I agree with @Peter answer.&lt;br&gt;&#xA;Moreover, I really doubt this relation of &lt;strong&gt;more publications = more importance.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&#xA;Actually, I see it very weird information in my field (Computer Science) regardless of its source.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;To show the importance of a subject, refer to some main papers/findings in that subject, show how and why its important to the general audience of your field. For example, in Computer Science, this can be done through listing some applications/real world scenarios of the subject. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10753" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10753" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Finding number of publications in a subject" AnswerId="UIEUPcfQ6tA1tY/ZUnCdKg==" Author="4394" Date="2013-06-24T22:26:36.247" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;First, I would argue that a precise number would be virtually impossible to obtain. This is because there is a large grey-zone between work published in established journals and work &quot;published&quot; in more &quot;questionable&quot; sources. Obviously the way to obtain a number would be to use search services such as Web of Science, Scopus etc. or reference data bases. But, for example, Web of Science only covers works published in ISI listed journals or papers referenced by ISI listed papers and on top of that only back in time for as long as journals have submitted reference information. This means such searches will be incomplete. Hence to arrive at a number may require quite a bit of work unless one would state the limitations imposed on a search sich as limting it to Web of science.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;The choice of key word(s) will also be important and it is not certain keywords are systematically applied between sources or over time. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;A claim to have found &quot;all&quot; literature is very questionable and I would argue that when one makes such a claim one must provide a picture of the limitations of the search because there will certainly always be such limitations.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10750" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10750" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10750" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
<answer QuestionId="Finding number of publications in a subject" AnswerId="D0j7lHj5xJYmudVXH6g/Ug==" Author="6862" Date="2013-06-24T22:45:46.800" Score="3" Text="&lt;p&gt;In medical/life sciences, the situation is slightly better than in other fields since indexing in PubMed is the standard for a manuscript to be considered a &quot;real&quot; publication. I suspect that in life sciences, stating that there are more than &lt;em&gt;x&lt;/em&gt; publications on a subject means counting the number of hits found when searching for that term on PubMed.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10751" Date="2013-06-25T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10751" Date="2013-07-01T00:00:00.000/>
<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10751" Date="2013-06-27T00:00:00.000/>
</answer>
</question>
academia.stackexchange.com_10758	<question QuestionId="Does your institution have a policy regarding policing online student feedback" Title="Does your institution have a policy regarding policing online student feedback" Views="159" Tags="teaching" " AnswerId="Yb4cYG88lXoERV2cgju45w==" Author="1424" Date="2013-06-25T11:06:28.130" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;There has been a lot of recent comment regarding the UK release of the &quot;Rate Your Lecturer&quot; website. This website allows users to comment on and rate their lecturers. Comments are submitted anonymously.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;I do &lt;strong&gt;not&lt;/strong&gt; want to enter the debate on whether this sort of anonymous online reviewing of lecturers is good, bad or indifferent. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;My question is whether your institution has a policy regarding how to deal with demonstrably untrue, insulting or unfairly negative comments about lecturers posted online, and what that policy is.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Does your institution have a policy regarding policing online student feedback" AnswerId="Yb4cYG88lXoERV2cgju45w==" Author="1424" Date="2013-06-26T09:46:10.237" Text="@AnonymousMathematician: I was curious to see if there were any institutions that have a policy on dealing with damaging comments posted anonymously online, which has the effect of damaging the reputation of the University's brand. This is aside from the lecturers themselves taking action against the website, as you suggest./>
<comment QuestionId="Does your institution have a policy regarding policing online student feedback" AnswerId="Yb4cYG88lXoERV2cgju45w==" Author="7357" Date="2013-06-25T13:35:38.913" Text="It seems complicated to have a policy on that, even more when reviews are anonymous. Maybe you can flag a message as inappropriate. Anyway, I guess you should not focus on the obviously aggressive feedback and concentrate on the one that can help you improve your teaching skills./>
<comment QuestionId="Does your institution have a policy regarding policing online student feedback" AnswerId="Yb4cYG88lXoERV2cgju45w==" Author="612" Date="2013-06-25T15:01:51.827" Text="What might an institutional policy consist of?  Since the comments are anonymous and the web site is not run by the university, there's no way to enforce anything even if you established a policy like &quot;students mustn't submit unfair comments&quot; or &quot;offensive comments must be removed at the request of the lecturer&quot;.  You can write a complaint letter to the site or even sue them for libel without needing an institutional policy to back you up, and I'm not sure what the other options are./>

<answer QuestionId="Does your institution have a policy regarding policing online student feedback" AnswerId="W9/CQpgN9yuiPHY4fvaoHg==" Author="4461" Date="2013-06-25T11:51:12.427" Score="7" Text="&lt;p&gt;No policy that I am aware of at any of the four universities and two high schools I've been associated with.  When the sites first appeared in the U.S. about ten years ago, questions came up about whether anything could be done about it, and the institution I was associated with then decided that there wasn't anything legal that could be done.  I believe that libelous material can be appealed directly through some of the websites, but I've never heard of anyone having success with that.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;Personally, I love anonymous feedback, and I've had my share of good and bad reviews.  I've tried to use the bad reviews as a means for informing where I can improve, and I've tried to limit my head from getting too big at the good reviews.  Teaching takes a certain amount of thick skin, and sites like these can be a good way to test if you've grown enough of that calloused layer to ward off any long-term effects.&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">

<comment QuestionId="Does your institution have a policy regarding policing online student feedback" AnswerId="W9/CQpgN9yuiPHY4fvaoHg==" Author="2692" Date="2013-06-26T00:10:49.550" Text="+1 for _I love anonymous feedback, and I've had my share of good and bad reviews_. It's a great learning opportunity./>

academia.stackexchange.com_10759	<question QuestionId="Letter to the editor from the referee" Title="Letter to the editor from the referee" Views="271" Tags="peer-review,referee" " AnswerId="sqoAQYKB5jSR5TMdN1Mjqg==" Author="5894" Date="2013-06-25T11:17:54.950" Score="2" Text="&lt;p&gt;Nowadays most journals use electronic forms for the referees to submit their recommendations to the editor. &lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;However, if that's not the case, how should the letter to the editor be structured?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;p&gt;In the referee report I have already mentioned some points I consider should be revised. But, do I have to explicitly state these points in the letter? or should I just say that the points mentioned in the referee report should be considered before publication?&lt;/p&gt;&#xA;">


<vote QuestionId="" AnswerId="10759" Date="2013-06-26T00:00:00.000/>
